WASHINGTON, Feb. 16-- If you have a short-wave receiver and didn't hear what General Westmoreland said to General Taylor you haven't been listening very hard.

Botany Retail Stores, which operates 82 units across the country, has named Robert Schaffner as vice president in charge of its women's division. Botany Retail Stores is a division of Botany Industries, Inc.

LONDON, Feb. 16--The National Theater, Britain's popular repertory company, will more than double its seating capacity next summer by presenting for the first time a 10week season of plays at two London theaters.

The collapse of three floors of a 103-year-old loft building, which injured 12 persons on Jan. 27, started at a point in the building altered "20 or 30 years ago" without the approval of the Buildings Department.

A variety of new police techniques will be introduced here if Howard R. Leary, the newly designated Police Commissioner brings in some of the ideas he has put into effect as Philadelphia's commissioner since 1963.
Harold Freedman, one of the nation's leading literary agents, died in his sleep yesterday morning at his home, at 23 East 74th Street. He was 69 years old.

Agreements were signed yesterday for the sale of the Martin Beck Theater, 302 West 45th Street off Eighth Avenue, to William L. McKnight, board Chairman of the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Corporation, who acquired the property as a personal investment.

SOCIAL figures who see each other virtually every day in restaurants, nightclubs and at charity balls are beginning to find new playgrounds --in department stores. No fashion show is complete these days without a lineup of well-known women stategically seated as backdrops for the store's merchandise.

PARIS, Feb. 16--Louis Aragon, noted poet and member of the Central Committee of the French Communist party, sharply attacked the Soviet Union today for its sentencing of Andrei D. Sinyovsky and Yuli M. Daniel.
The change in administration hasn't changed New York's favorite game: fiddling while Rome burns. Only in this case the disaster area is not Rome, but Staten Island, the city's last open-land area.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16-- Once again, and this time by Senator Russell, one of its most respected members, the Senate has been assured that an affirmative vote for the Presidents request for more billions to wage the war in Vietnam does not imply commitment to whatever courses the President may decide to pursue.

NEEDHAM, Mass., Feb. 16-- The engagement of Miss Mary Eleanor Howland, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Howland of Needham and Marion, to David Brooks Smoyer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley C. Smoyer of Princeton, N.J., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents.

ABOARD THE HOSPITAL SHIP REPOSE, off South Vietnam, Feb. 16--This 15,000-ton floating infirmary steamed into the South China Sea off Chulai this morning--the first hospital ship to enter the combat zone.

A British psychologist suspects that the type of optical illusions that astronauts are likely to encounter while assembling a space station or exploring the moon may be dangerous enough to require them to wear personal radar units.

Corporate expenditures for research and development, those twin sources of new products, show no sign of declining in the next five years, according to a survey conducted by the National Industrial Conference Board.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Feb. 16--A heavy flow of oil from South Africa to Rhodesia was reported here today and the British Ambassador called on Foreign Minister Hilgard Muller, apparently in an attempt to persuade the South African Government to halt it.
Assault, rape, robbery and other major crimes, but not murder, increased in the city last year, the Police Department announced yesterday.

A top-rated utility bond issue that cannot be called for redemption for five years was priced yesterday to give the highest yield for such a security in the postwar period. It was spoken for immediately.
BOSTON, Feb. 16 (AP)-- Antony Bashir, Metropolitan Archbishop of the Syrian Antiochian Orthodox Church of North America, died last night in New England Baptist Hospital.

DETROIT, Feb. 16 (AP)--A Detroit lawyer, representing 13 survivors and widows of crewmen killed in the sinking of the Cedarville, a Great Lakes limestone carrier, said yesterday he had asked the Coast Guard to reopen the case.
Mayor Lindsay has gathered around him a kitchen cabinet whose opinions he seeks on major policy matters.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 16--Albania and Yugoslavia have signed an agreement to increase trade during 1966, it was announced here today.
SPLIT, Yugoslavia, Feb. 16 (AP)--A passenger train and a train carrying coal collided today, killing at least 29 persons and injurying 27. The wreckage burst into flames.

"Philadelphia, Here I Come!" an Irish drama, opened as scheduled at the Helen Hayes Theater last night, 24 hours after the play's final preview had been canceled because of what were described as "technical difficulties."

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 16--President Johnson accused the Vietcong tonight of committing atrocities against teachers as part of a terrorist strategy to conquer South Vietnam. He told an audience of school superintendents at Convention Hall that a Communist takeover in South Vietnam would be followed by similar "wars of liberation" in other countries. "It must not succeed," he said.

The roles of soloist and accompanist were switched last night for the performance of Rachmaninoff's Third Piano Concerto by the New York Philharmonic. Jerome Lowenthal, the pianist, played the notes of the solo part, often brilliantly. But Leonard Bernstein played the music.
ALBANY, Feb. 16--The Legislature today reluctantly passed Governor Rockefeller's bill exempting New York City's 35,000 transit workers from the penalties of the Condon-Wadlin Law.
Former Mayor Robert F. Wagnet, a 1933 Yale graduate, has been appointed a Chubb Fellow at the University. He will spend four days on the campus in April as the guest of Timothy Dwight College.

NAPLES, Fla., Feb. 16 (UPI) --A light plane carrying three Cuban defectors flew undetected through the intricate United States Air Defense Command radar network today and crashlanded at this Gulf Coast resort, killing the pilot.
Air you can't breathe, perfumes you can't smell and flavors you can't taste are all products in a market now worth more than $40-million a year.
SKI center operators keep bemoaning the belief of many enthusiasts that a ski trip is foolish because of a brief period of rain or thaw.
BOSTON, Feb. 16 (UPI)--Pit Martin scored three goals and set up Ron Stewart's deciding score tonight as the Boston Bruins scored a 5-4 victory over the Detroit Red Wings.

ROME, Feb. 16--Pope Paul VI voiced praise today for plans to attack "misery, hunger and mortality." He used terms that appeared to endorse President Johnson's recent proposals for worldwide action against want.
Whitney M. Young Jr. said yesterday that the civil rights movement had arrived at a crucial time of decision making.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16-- Most Americans, including Catholics, favor Federal aid to states, cities and foreign governments for birth control programs, according to a recent poll.

HOUSTON, Feb. 16--The death of Representative Albert Thomas in Washington yesterday has created an unusual political situation in Texas. It would be possible for Mr. Thomas's successor not to be able to run for re-election.
The tragic farce that was the Moscow trial of Soviet writers Andrei Sinyavsky and Yuli Daniel has ended with imposition of severe prison sentences on both defendants.
Attended memorial services for Representative Thomas, Democrat of Texas, Washington National Cathedral; participated in ceremony to announce increase in savings bonds interest rates; received
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Feb. l6 --Haward H. Baker Jr., a 40year-old Knoxville lawyer, announced his candidacy today for the Republican nomination for United States Senator from Tennessee.
ALBANY, Feb. 16--Republican and Democratic leaders reported tonight that they had made "real progress" toward an agreement on new Senate and Assembly districts after a twohour meeting.
Larry Newbold scored 22 points and directed Long Island University to an 82-53 victory over Adelphi at the Blackbirds' gym in Brooklyn last night.
SALISBURY, Md., Feb. 17-- The toll in the national indoor tennis championships today was catastrophic.

Dr. Armistead C. Crump, a physician who invented surgical instruments and a method of catching thieves red-handed, died Tuesday evening at the Presbyterian Hospital. He was 89 years old and lived in Greenwich, Conn.

INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 16 (UPI)--Deliquent teen-age girls rampaged through the Indiana Girls School tonight, smashing and looting as a cover for a breakout involving 30 to 35 of the 190 imnates at the state institution.
Lower-than-expected purchases of cocoa, beans by Ghana's central marketing agency helped push up prices of cocoa futures here yesterday. Trading was active at 2,423 contracts.
The Chicago Black Hawks skate like men possessed--possessed of first place in the National Hockey League.

THE British master Bruce Hayden, with unflagging drive and high imagination, overpowered the expert P.E. Chapman in a recent London league game. As White, Hayden unleashed a weird Wing Gambit against Chapman's Sicilian Defense.

Steve Ellis, a silver-tongued sports announcer whose colorful delivery was reminiscent of some of radio's early greets; died yesterday morning at Flower-Fifth Avenue Hospital of a kidney ailment. His age was 50. He resided at 11 Fifth Avenue.

PARIS, Feb. 16--The French Government adopted today a new economic program for the second de Gaulle term. It is a more modest program than had been expected, but the Government said there is more to come.

Richard S. Salant, who was replaced by Fred W. Friendly two years ago as head of the Columbia Broadcasting System News Division, was named acting president of the division yesterday, succeeding Mr. Friendly, who resigned Tuesday. Since early 1964, Mr. Salant had been vice president and special assistant to Dr. Frank Stanton president of C.B.S.
CHICAGO, Feb. 16 (AP)-- The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. asked labor unions today to back his drive to clean up slum conditions in Chicago.
Gaston Azcarraga Tamayo, a Mexican citizen, was elected yesterday to the board of American Airlines, Inc. He becomes the first foreign national ever elected a director of the large airline.
Bronx Community College and the New York College of Music will introduce in September a joint program leading to the Bachelor of Music degree.
Dr. Andre Frederic Cournand has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss MarieClaire Cournand, to Francis Jacques Sypher Jr., son of Mrs. Sypher of New York and the late Mr. Sypher.
The entry of Britain's giant International Publishing Company into the American publishing business through a partnership with the Cahners Publishing Company of Boston was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16--The Government increased today the interest rate on savings bonds from 3.75 to 4.15 per cent.
BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 16-- The Argentine Government is committed to liberalize its tight foreign exchange policy and to free its pegged peso by April 30.
BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 16--Jacob S. Potofsky, president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, called today for speedy action in Congress to increase the minimum wage to $2 an hour.
CHICAGO, Feb. 16 (AP)-- A strike of hodcarriers may cause St. Louis to lose the 1966 major league All-Star basebail game, Dick Meyer, the St. Louis Cardinals' executive vice president, said today.
More than 100 City College students, with overnight satchels and sleeping bags, began a three-day fast in the college's ballroom yesterday to protest United States involvement in Vietnam.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 16 --The Atlanta Falcons, the National Football League's new $8.5-million team, came to life today. The Falcons bought 42 players from the existing 14 clubs at $200,000 per athlete and they now have the bodies to play the games. Counting drafted rookles and free agents, they have 94 men, of whom 54 must be discarded before midSeptember.
Max Bressler, president of the Jewish National Fund of America since 1963, died Tuesday in Miami Beach of a heart attack. He was 64 years old and lived in Chicago.
A would-be lady astronomer whose favorite stars are the Beatles made the highest score on the Regents college Scholarship examinations last fall.
In a steady atmosphere, prices rose slightly on the London Stock Exchange yesterday in dull trading.
The New York office of the World Council of Churches announced yesterday the election of the Rev. Dr. Philip A. Johnson as associate executive secretary for the council in this country.
Pope Paul VI has issued new regulations relaxing the Roman Catholic Church's rules of fast and abstinence, the Apostolic Delegate to the United States announced yesterday.

Miss Suzanne Spear and George H.C. Lawrence, plan to marry in June. Their engagement has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mrs. Robert E. Thornhill of 485 Park Avenue and Islip, L.I., and John Spear Jr. of East Hampton, L.I. Mr. Lawrence, is the son of Mrs. John G. Jackson Jr. of Locust Valley, L.I., and the late Christopher Lawrence of Bronxville, N.Y.
ATHENS, Feb. 16--A blackrobed, gray-bearded Greek Orthodox Bishop sat in an Athens court today--the first Greek bishop ever to be tried by lay judges.

A group of Staten Island homeowners who discovered recently that they were living in a little Netherlands are fighting to hold back the dikes.
LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., Feb. 16--Overcoming a 38-35 half-time deficit Rider College scored a 84-74 victory over City College of New York, in a Tri-State League game here tonight.

ALBANY, Feb. 16--Julius Hegyi has been named conductor of the Albany Symphony Orchestra, effective June 1. He succeeds Edgar Curtis, who announced his resignation earlier this season after 18 years in the post.
Whether or not one agrees with all the interpretative decisions of Bernard Ringeissen, the pianist who played last night at Carnegie Recital Hall, is beside the point.

MIAMI, Feb. 16--Overlooked by most of the 21,059 in attendance, despite the fact That she had stakes accomplishments to her credit, Mrs. Leslie Combs's Gold Digger took first money in the $30,600 Columbiana Handicap at Hialeah today. With Larry Adams riding her. Gold Digger beat the favored Tosmah by a half-length in the seven furlong race, and returned the breathtaking mutuel of $108.80 for $2 to win.
ROME, Feb. 16--Italy's Communist party took issue today with "the" particular harshness of the sentence of Andrei D. Sinyavsky and Yuli M. Daniel.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Feb. 16--Mr. and Mrs. Vilas J. Boyle have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Boyle, to Donald Charles Palmer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harris H. Palmer of Sydney, N. C.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP)--The Central Intelligence Agency confirmed today that it had recruiting teams visiting about l00 college campuses to interview students as prospective analysts and agents.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 16-- Some revolutionary ideas in education, including an increase in the school year of 40 to 70 days, were set forth here today and received warm response from a representative assembly of the nation's school superintendents.

The Air Line Pilots Association continued its month-long campaign yesterday to persuade the United States and other governments to abandon a new air traffic rule across the North Atlantic providing narrower flight corridors.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16--The Internal Revenue Service said today it was auditing the tax returns of the National Right to Work Committee, which led the successful fight against the Administration's proposal to prohibit state laws that ban union shop contracts.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 16 (AP)--Australia retained "The Ashes" today when the fifth and final test of the cricket series with England was declared a draw despite a recordbreaking 307 runs by Bob Cowper of Australia.
The National Cash--Register Company rang up new records last year in sales, rentals and earnings, according to the annual report issued yesterday.

THE echoes of praise that developed from the West minster best-in-show victory achieved by the English-bred wire fox terrier, Ch. Zeloy Mooremaides Magic, in Madison Square Garden Tuesday night included a tribute to Jimmy Butler, the Yorkshireman who was her profes sional handler.
LONDON, Feb. 16 (UPI)-- Output from Britain's industry rose by 2.5 per cent in 1965 over 1964, Central Statistical Office figures showed today.

TORONTO, Feb. 16--A $330-million hydroelectric development of the Nelson River in the wilderness of northern Manitoba will get under way this summer, according to announcements in Winnipeg and Ottawa.

The rising tide of prosperity swept nine out of 10 companies to higher profits last year. And four out of 10 of the first 500 industrial companies reporting for 1965 turned in record earnings after taxes.
Vast quantities of cargo from the United States are being pilfered at South Vietnamese ports and are finding their way to the Vietcong, a maritime union official said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16-- Soviet officials are making quiet disclaimers of the aggressive calls for revolution in Latin America, Africa and Asia issued at last month's tricontinental conference in Havana, according to reports here.
Morris J. Rubin, the Chicago industrialist who is leading a proxy fight against the management of the Crucible Steel Company of America, announced yesterday that four other dissidents had joined him.
JERSEY CITY, Feb. 16-- Mrs. Luz V. Carino de Morales became the first Puerto Rican elementary school teacher in Jersey City today.
The Bank of America announced yesterday the appointment of G. Robert Truex Jr. as vice president and manager of international banking for its southern division.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb. 16--Selwyn Lloyd said today that he believed it still possible to reach a basis for negotiation between Britain and Rhodesia.

"Cissy Patterson," by Alice Albright Hoge, will be published by Random House on Feb. 25.

The New York Philharmonic will offer its fourth season of Promenade concerts at Philharmonic Hall at Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts between May 25 and June 25.

The Franklin National Bank of Mineola, L.I., unveiled yesterday plans for a branch office in the "sylvan setting" of a vest pocket park that the bank will build and maintain for customers and the public.

At least two banks, Chase Manhattan and the Chemical Bank New York Trust Company, have programs under which their electronic computers are made available to landlords with large holdings to speed rent collections.

A New York general practitioner urged his fellow physicians yesterday to do more to help prevent suicides by exercising extra caution in prescribing sleeping pills for depressed persons.

BEFORE gallantly risking sunstroke in unselfish sacrifice to the call of duty all self-respecting baseball experts prepare for spring training departure by doing more than packing suntan lotion in their suitcases. Antagonism between the Senate Foreign Relations Committee and Administration foreign policy managers flared openly again today.
Special-situation issues characterized by wide price fluctuations dominated trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.

Three plainclothes policemen had to wait more than two hours to arrest a Harlem clergyman yesterday while he testified at City Hall budget hearings and conferred with aides to Mayor Lindsay on civil rights matters.

The Allied Products Corporation, a major supplier of components parts to the automobile industry, reportedly has purchased a large number of shares of the Studebaker Corporation.

Mrs. Elmes Crawford, a tall, willowy mother of three, was crowned queen of the Junior League's Mardi Gras Ball last night. The 15th annual event at the Waldorf-Astoria took on more of the aura of a private league party than its 14 predecessors.

Kamil Abdul Rahim, former permanent observer of the League of Arab States at the United Nations, died in Cairo Feb. 3, according to word received here yesterday by the Arab States Delegations Office. He was 68 years old.
The nation's electric power production rose 9.5 per cent in the week ended Feb. 12 from the level in the corresponding 1965 week, it was reported yesterday by the Edison Electric Institute.

"I yelled, 'Allle, Allie!' but it didn't mean nothing." WHAT with a new conductor and a new Duke, Verdi's "Rigoletto" last night at the Metropolitan Opera took on a certain amount of advance interest.

Hans Richter-Haaser, the German pianist who has become a fairly regular visitor since his debut here in 1959, turned to the music of Beethoven for his recital in Carnegie Hall last night. Princess Margrethe, the 25year-old heiress to the Danish throne, breezed through town yesterday on her way to Mexico and Latin America. The Maryland-National Capital Park and Planning Commission sold yesterday two bond issues totaling $11.46-million to a group of investment banking concerns managed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and Robert Garrett Sons, Inc., of Baltimore.

The British pound was slightly lower in moderately active trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday. The currency closed at $2.8024, down 3 points from Tuesday.

A picture of a citywide sewer system suffering from many years of poor management was painted yesterday in a 54-page report by the Deputy MayorCity Administrator, Timothy W. Costello.

Mass resignations at the municipal hospitals were threatened yesterday by the New York State Nurses Association unless the Lindsay administration meets its contract demands for higher wages and improved working conditions.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16-- The National Labor Relations Board invalidated today an-election at a Mississippi plant on the ground that hostile community action had coerced the workers into rejecting unionization.
THE HAGUE, Feb. 16--The Netherlands, in a gesture of limited support for the United States, plans to establish five medical stations in Saigon.

The Wyandotte Chemicals Corporation announced yesterday it had developed a new basic urethane coating material that the company expects to be used widely in such consumer applications as rainwear and gloves, shoes, luggage, auto-seat covers and permanent-press formulations.
THE annual Greenwich House antiques show opens today at 27 Barrow Street with a range of offerings from a bit of pottery for a few dollars to some bits by Carl Faberge for quite a few dollars more.

ONTARIO, Calif., Feb. 16 (UPI)--Two corporations announced plans today to build and operate what is claimed to be the world's largest and most modern auto racing speedway on a 710-acre site in this city, 40 miles east of Los Angeles.
DETROIT, Feb. 16--The Federal Government was reported today to be planning to seek substantially more stringent safety requirements for the 1968 model automobiles it buys.

KEY WEST, FIa., Feb. l6-- Vacationing anglers come to the end of the road when they reach this southernmost town. It is here thet the Atlantic and the Gulf of Mexico meet, with fishing grounds stretching in almost every direction.
Late selling again on the American Stock Exchange yesterday left the market weak for the second consecutive day in heavy trading.

Dr. and Mrs. Rubin Josell of 201 East 66th Street and Lido Beach, L.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Karen Louise Josell, to Steven Jay Toegfer. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham E. Toepfer of New York.

Ernie Terrell was denied a license to fight in New York because he rode on a plane from Chicago here with Bernie Glickman on the day he testified he had broken off all relationships with the Chicago fight figure, the New York State Athletic Commission disclosed yesterday.
AUSTIN, Tex., Feb. 16 (AP) University of Texas authorities have vetoed publication in the February issue of the Texas Ranger a photograph of President Johnson retouched to place a wig on his head.

GENEVA, Feb. 16--A hundred distinguished world churchmen unanimously endorsed today a call for immediate peace in Vietnam. In doing so they criticized both the United States policy of containing Communism and the Communist policy of supporting wars of liberation.
Joseph Bruna has been elected vice president of the TransWorld Financial Company. He continues as controller.
Meyer Lesofsky, who recognizes his 24 grandchildren, 22 great-grandchildren and 16 great-great-grandchildren by sight, yesterday became the oldest applicant in the country for Medicare benefits.

CAMDEN, N.J., Feb. 16 (AP) --One of three men accused of having slain a wealthy restaurateur-real estate developer confessed on the witness stand today, burst into tears and had to be taken to an anteroom.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16-- --Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman gave President Johnson today a strategy for achieving victory on the "second front" of the Vietnamese war by bringing greater prosperity to the South Vietnamese farmer.
SAIGON, Feb. 16--Troops of the United States First Cavalry Division (Airmobile) finally found the enemy force they have been chasing for more than a week and killed 61 insurgents yesterday.
Division and suspicion appear to have frustrated a major effort to stage an international Communist rally of support for North Vietnam.
TRENTON, Feb.17 The Hughes administration is considering creating a new state agency to supervise New Jersey's creaking commuter rail service to New York City.
In a voice of despair and steely hatred, the widow of Malcolm X yesterday denounced the three men who are on trial for his murder.
Governor Rockefeller was Caught yestrday in a crossfire of unions with one labor organization thanking him while another union picketed him.
CHICAGO, Feb. 17 Leaders of the American Bar Association have agreed to help the Johnson Administration seek changes in the Electoral College system of electing Presidents.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 United States officials believe that the Soviet Union has stationed atomic weapons under its own control in East Germany and perhaps some other of the Warsaw Pact countries in Eastern Europe.
The following reports were provided yesterday by operators of ski areas. Messages were filed at times indicated in parentheses.
Forty young men of Long Island, eligible for military service, paid $80,000 in the last three years to evade the draft, it was charged yesterday in Federal Court, Brooklyn.
The Travelers Insurance Company plans to acquire the unprofitable Phoenix Insurance Company, the control of which has been sought by an investor group.
The combined application of 8,700 horsepower developed by three vessels failed to dislodge the stranded British tanker Chelwood Beacon yesterday morning.
The Bankers Trust Company announced the promotions yesterday of four officers to the rank of vice president. All had previously been assistant vice presidents.

ROME, Feb. 17 Pope Paul VI gave national bishops' conferences today the power to decide whether Roman Catholics should continue to abstain from eating meat on Fridays or express penitence in other ways.
A $1-million grant was announced yesterday by the Ford Foundation to help further archeological excavations in the Athenian Agora, the ancient civic center at the foot of the Acropolis.
ALBANY, Feb. 17--Mayor Lindsay has altered his transit consolidation plan because of criticism that he was attempting to put all city transportation under the political thumb of City Hall.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 The United States, in its first application of a recently-adopted policy, has authorized three prominent medical specialists to visit Cuba.

MARGATE, N.J., Feb. 17 Miss Janice Shapiro and Law rence Lipsitz of Fort Lee plan to marry here in the summer. Mrs. Elizabeth Shapiro, mother of the bride-to-be, has announced the engagement. Mr. Lipsitz is the son of Mrs. Ray Quint of Hauppauge, L.I., and the late Samuel Lipsitz of Paterson.

SAIGON, Feb. 17 The toll taken by two Vietcong mines here today has been found to be 12 Vietnamese dead and 60 injured. The two fragmentation mines, which exploded outside the rear gate of the Vietnamese Armed Forces Headquarters, hurled scores of steel balls into the area.
ISLAMORADA, Fla., Feb.17 This is the story of a stick, a nice, friendly, thick stick that was a branch on a tree until a wandering storm blew it into Florida Bay.

A center to provide research and treatment for the psycho logical disorders of Harlem residents was opened yesterday by City College in a move described as a significant departure from the "middle-class" orientation of modern clinical methods.
A few low-price issues attracted most of the buying interest on the American Stock Exchange yesterday as the market lost ground for the third consecutive day in hectic trading.
THE Greater New York Championships, a fiveday sectional tournament organized by the Greater New York Bridge Association, will begin this afternoon at the New York Hilton Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 President Johnson at this time does not have any serious proposals for a tax increase under study, Bill D. Moyers, the President's press secretary, said today.

Hospitals Commissioner Alonzo S. Yerby called "unfounded" yesterday the charges made by Representative James H. Scheuer, a Bronx Democrat, who called clinic treatment at Lincoln Hospital "an affront to the Hippocratic oath."

General Wheeler, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, told two groups of Senators that "in the long term, we can achieve military victory" in Vietnam. But President Johnson has said: "We know, as our adversaries should also know, that there is no purely military solution in sight for either side."

UPPER SADDLE RIVER, N.J., Feb. 17 Miss Joan Andrews Vroome, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ray Livingston Vroome, was married this evening to David Beattie, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan Sinclair Beattie of Killingworth, Conn. The Rev. Michael Dowling performed the candlelight service at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of the Presentation.
MOSCOW, Feb. 17 A Soviet TU-114, the world's largest airliner, crashed today on take-off from Moscow's international airport. Soviet sources said 48 persons aboard were killed.
ENUGU, Nigeria, Feb. 14 One month has passed since the army overthrew the discredited civilian regime and a new sense of discipline has begun to be felt throughout Nigeria.

Secretary of the Treasury Henry H. Fowler emphatically rejected yesterday proposals from critics of Administration economic policies that tighter money and higher taxes are needed now to head off the danger of serious inflation.
The City of Newburgh, N.Y., is advertising for a man to replace the incumbent by March 1.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 President Johnson has been urged to order an immediate airlift of food to India for "those isolated provinces where Communists are leading food riots" and for other areas of the famine-ridden subcontinent.
PRAGUE, Feb. 14 The Barbara Bar on Jungmannova Street is two steps down. They lead from the street-level Com munist reality of today's Prague to a past almost as mythical as the seacoast of Bohemia.
The wholesale commodity price index maintained Wednesday the level of 114.3 it reached Tuesday.
BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 17 The general presidents of the nation's building trades unions dealt a major blow today to the wage restraint program of President Johnson's Administration.
FRANKFORT, Ky., Feb. 17 (AP) The House voted overwhelmingly today to defeat a bill to abolish capital punishment in Kentucky.

HOUSTON, Feb. 17 (UPI) Neil A. Armstrong and Maj. David R. Scott of the Air Force are scheduled to ride the Gemini 8 spacecraft into orbit March 15 and try to link up with an Agena satellite high above earth, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today.
WALTHAM, Mass., Feb. 17 West Germany's progress as a democracy will be judged by its relationship with Israel, a rabbi who was once exiled by the Hitler regime asserted tonight.

American Airlines will put the first of its new fleet of British-made, twin-jet airliners into service on its New York-Toronto run next month, Marion Sadler, president of American, annuonced yesterday.

Helen Hayes will go on the road for five weeks in "The Circle" and "Lovers, Villains and Fools." It will be the star's first touring appearance with the repertory company named in her honor. Performances will be given at colleges, universities and regional theaters. The trip will get under way April 11 at Butler University.

PARIS The Greek Communist party is now admittedly engaged in a long-range campaign to take over control of Greece, neutralize it and withdraw it from NATO. This is openly stated in the current "World Marxist Review" by Leonidas Stringos, an important official who represented, the party at an international Communist conference in Brussels last June, just before the Greek political crisis erupted.
MIAMI, Feb. 17 (AP) A Jackson Memorial Hospital nurse testified today that Mrs. Jacques Mossler entered the hospital about 2:45 A.M. on June 30, 1964 the morning her husband was slain.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 Pick a nnmber from 100 to 300 one of them is likely to be right about the ceiling President Johnson's pilot enjoyed when he took Air Force One into Atlantic City yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. Harmon C. Quarles of Aruba in the Netherlands Antilles have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Deborah Elizabeth Quarles, to John Charles Voosen Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Voosen of Chicago.

Clinton, Iowa, a city on the west bank of the Mississippi River 138 miles west of Chicago, sold $60-million of taxexempt bonds yesterday to finance a petrochemicals plant for the American Can Company and the Skelly Oil Company.
ATHENS, Feb. 17 Bishop Chrysostomos of Piraeus told an Athens court today that he could not be convicted of usurpation of office because he had acted under the guidance of the Holy Ghost.
Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that he wanted the new rapidtransit tunnel between Manhattan and Queens put under construction during the fiscal year that begins July 1.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor repeatedly assured the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today that the Administration intended to wage only a "limited" war in Vietnam, but he refused to be pinned down on the limits.

"The Man From U.N.C.L.E." may be joined by "The Girl From U.N.C.L.E.", a companion series, on the National Broadcasting Company television network next fall. Both shows are listed on a tentative program schedule that N.B.C. has drawn for next season and distributed to advertising agencies.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 17 The president of the Maritime Trades Department of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. said today that its 30 affiliated unions were considering a boycott of ships from countries trading with North Vietnam.
Expansion projects involving outlays totaling in excess of $30-million were announced yesterday by steel, chemical and rubber companies.

Secret Service agents seized more than $1-million in counterfeit money yesterday and arrested four alleged members of a ring suspected of having flood ed the subways with phony $5 bills printed in a private house in Camden, N.J.
ATLANTA, Ga., Feb, 17 The Southern Regional Council today began a campaign to help 2 million eligible but unregistered Negroes toward the voting rolls in 11 Southern states.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 President Johnson believes that his Vietnam policy has the backing of a majority of the American people.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 17 The National Football League's annual meeting ended today and the commissioner, Pete Rozelle, revealed some general policy that had been established.
Detectives of the District Attorney's office recovered late last night nearly half of the $2.1-million in securities stolen in a holdup last July of Goodbody Co., a brokerage concern at 2 Broadway.

Thieves made off with $90,000 worth of jewelry belonging to Mrs. Wyatt Cooper, the former Gloria Vanderbilt, in a daylight burglary of her town house at 45 East 67th Street, the police reported yesterday. .
WESTPORT, Conn., Feb. 17 Mr. and Mrs. George W. Wassell have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Joy Wassell, to David B. Armor, son of Mr. and Mrs. Burd H. Armor of Abington, Pa.,

Fifty-seven member colleges of the National Collegiate Athletic Association were given until midnight Tuesday to prove compliance with the N.C.A.A's new and controversial scholastic requirement for athletic scholarship aid or have their athletes declared ineligible for the association's championship events. This is an extension of a week; the original deadline was midnight last Tuesday.
PARIS, Feb. 17 President de Gaulle was reliably reported today to have sent President Johnson a blistering message on United States policy in Vietnam.

A compromise is shaping up between the New York Stock Exchange and the Securities and Exchange Commmission on Rule 394 of the Big Board, which effectively forbids members from off-floor dealings in listed securities. The exchange's board of governors, during the course of a monthly policy meeting yesterday, heard a progress report on the knotty problem from a special committee.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 Senator Jacob K. Javits of New York proposed today that the Federal Government experiment for a three-year period with subsidizing half the operating deficits of commuter transit systems.
Time, Inc., the nation's largest publishing company, set records in revenues and earnings in the three and 12 months ended Dec. 31, the company announced yes terday.
LAHORE, Pakistan, Feb. 17 (Reuters) Five prominent Opposition leaders were arrested in their homes before dawn today.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Feb. 17 (UPI) Former Oklahoma Supreme Court Justice Wayne W. Bayless has resigned from the bar while under charges of conspiring to bribe fellow justices, the Oklahoma Bar Association disclosed today.
The advertising agency business is changing. This was Madison Avenue's message to Providence R.I., yesterday.
Two new vice presidents of Dan River Mills, Inc., were named yesterday by the textile company's board of directors in Danville, Va. Four other corporate officers also were chosen.
SALT LAKE CITY, Feb. 17 T.R. May, vice president of the Lockheed-Georgia Company, disclosed plans today for four commercial derivatives of the company's huge Air Force C-5A fan jet transport.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 Two-party politics and the growing Negro vote apparently have not changed the main theme of campaigning in Mis sissippi.
PARIS, Feb. 17 France launched a satellite into orbit aboard a French Diamant rocket today.
The world's largest corporate enterprise the American Telephone and Telegraph Company had to be content with second place in the 1965 earnings sweepstake.
GARFIELD, N.J., Feb. 17 Mr. and Mrs. Henry Sucorowski have announced the engagement of, their daughter, Miss Carol Sucorowski, to Ronald Ruiz, grandson of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Ruiz of New York.

JACKSON, Miss., Feb. 17 Mississippi Republican leaders boycotted a speech here tonight in which Charles H. Percy, the Illinois senatorial candidate, urged Southern members of the party to steer away from racist politics.

A DRESS collection that some observers considered the most significant fashion breakthrough since Christian Dior's New Look was presented yesterday in a photographer's studio far from Seventh Avenue. Tzaims Luksus, who has designed fabrics used by such houses as Norman Norell, Ben Reig and Geoffrey Beene, decided to put the fabrics directly into dresses.

AUSTIN, Tex. Feb. 17 Texas oil production was raised slightly today when the Texas Railroad Commission increased allowables on Texas wells for March from 32.7 to 33.2 per cent of their abilities to produce. This will increase average calendar day allowables by 28,824 barrels, to a total of 3,118,951.
DELRAY BEACH, Fla., Feb. 17 Jazz Time, a 7-year-old brown gelding, continued his domination of the green jumper division in the Bethesda Hospital horse show today by winning the time class.
BOGOTA, Colombia, Feb. 17 Congressional debate on a United States research program here concluded yesterday with an announcement that the study would continue.
Twelve students fled from the burning Kappa Sigma fraternity house across the street from the Bronx campus of New York University early yesterday morning.
Rumors of an impendiug increase in the margin rate made the rounds of Wall Street yesterday and sent a chill through the stock market.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17--The Federal Aviation Agency has proposed a series of changes in cockpit procedures and crew training on the Boeing 727 jetliner--a design that has had four fatal crashes since last August.
PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Feb. 17 A zoning application was filed here today for three 27story apartment buildings to be built on the waterfront. They would be the tallest buildings in Westchester County.

SCARBOROUGH, N.Y., Feb. 17 Hjalmar Hertz, former board chairman and general manager of the Old Diehl Manufacturing Company, makers of electrical equipment, died at his home on Scarborough Road here today. He was 86 years Old:

OKLAHOMA CITY, Feb. 17 (AP) A regulation of the American Bar Association concerning public statements by attorneys on pending cases was adopted unanimously last night by the executive council of the Oklahoma Bar Association.

LOS ANGLES, Feb. 17 (AP) Student absenteeism hit the quarter million mark 15 per cent of the city and county total today as a widespread outbreak of Asian flu went into a second day of epidemic pro portions.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 17 (AP) Art Stephanson's rebounding and 29 points helped Rhode Island upset sixth-ranked Providence, 84-61, tonight. The loss ended the Friars' string of 39 home-court victories.
The Texas Gulf Sulphur Company reported yesterday that its earnings for last year increased 57 per cent on a gain in sales of 41 per cent.

MIAMI, Feb. 17 An Illinoisbred making his debut on the turf won the feature race today at Hialeah. Abe's Hope of the Grand Prix Stable surprised the 17,803 spectators by staging a closing rally that enabled him to defeat the favored Poker by three-quarters of a length.
W. Allen Taylor, president of E.F. Hutton Co., Inc., was elected yesterday as the vice chairman of the American Stock Exchange's board of governors.
With or without the half-mile of the year, the New York Athletic Club Games at Madison Square Garden tonight shape up as the most attractive meet of the indoor track season.
Nine members of a nationwide ring that included bogus policemen who preyed primarily on homosexuals to extort money on threats of arrest were taken into custody here yesterday.

Something is going on these days behind the glassy square eye Of television news broadcasting. David Brinkley came out publicly the other day against "star" newscasters which is a little like Lyndon Johnson attacking Texas and Fred W. Friendly, the president of C.B.S. News, quit because some advertising man cut his copy.
ST. JOHN'S, Nfld. Feb. 17 (AP) The 8,228-ton freighter American Importer, with water rushing in through a cracked bulkhead and weighed down by ice, arrived here early today assisted by tugs.

GENEVA, Feb. 17--The Soviet Union said today that the crash of an American nuclear bomber along the Spanish coast last month threatened to contaminate the high seas. It accused the United States of having "flagrantly" flouted its commitments under the 1963 treaty for a partial ban on nuclear tests.
President Johnson named Rear Adm. Willard J. Smith yesterday to be the new commandant of the Coast Guard. The White House said the President intended to nominate him for the rank of full admiral.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 The directors of Dow Jones Co. have asked their stockholders to approve a $3.5-million lump payment to Bernard Kilgore, president of the concern, in exchange for his pension rights.
Mayor Lindsay introduced the all-star members of his new Sports Commission yesterday in a brief ceremony in the Blue Room at City Hall.

The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company announced here yesterday the appointment of Frederick W. Oswald as senior vice president in charge of personnel. He had been a vice president in the personnel department.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given every Friday on this page. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost of dining in any particular establishment.

TORONTO, Feb. 17 Howard D. Graham, the president of the Toronto Stock Exchange during some of its most turbulent years, announced today he would retire on June 30. As yet, no successor has been chosen.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17--The White House confirmed today that President Johnson and President de Gaulle recently exchanged letters but it denied that a recent response from the French leader was harsh or severe in tone.

OLYMPIA, Wash., Feb. 17 (AP) Bail was posted today for Dick Gregory, the comedian, who ended a 48-hour foodless jail stay so he could take part in a college student forum on Indian fishing rights. His wife remained in jail.
Skin specialists substituted statues for patients last night to see if they could diagnose lesions nearly 2,000 years old.

The new Chairman of the city's Commission on Human Rights charged yesterday that Police Commissioner Vincent L. Broderick had increased the racial minorities' distrust of policemen by insisting on the independence of the Police Department.
GENEVA, Feb. 17 (AP) A call for measures to prevent the use of nuclear weapons, capped today a 10-day meeting of representatives of 214 church denominations.
CHICAGO, Feb. 17 Letters praising Krebiozen were received by jurors in the Krebiozen trial, five jurors said today.

Government bond prices recorded one of their rare advances yesterday, corporate bonds held the gains made Wednesday following the successful sale of the Duquesne Light Company issue and municipal bond sales speeded up, helped by some price cutting.

NEW DELHI, Feb. 17 (AP) Two time bombs exploded in a third-class coach on the Assam mail express in northeast India last night, killing 36 passengers and injuring 53, Railways Minister Ram Subhag Singh told Parliament today.

Gordon S.Ierardi, assistant vice president of John Wiley Sons, book publishers, 605 hird Avenue, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, at his office. He, was 48 years, old and lived in Old Greenwich, Conn.
Mayor Lindsay's self-imposed deadline on announcing a new tax program expires today, and City Hall sources said a fireside chat disclosing the new program was at least a week away.

President Johnson has now asked Congress to remedy a mistake of last year and appropriate the money needed to start the Teachers Corps and the rent subsidy plan. Both programs were authorized in the last session of Congress; both promise to be exceptionally useful in helping impoverished people.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) Only seven Americans were put to death by legal authorities in 1965, the Justice Department said today.
MALVERNE, L.I., Feb. 17 First Lieut. Janet Marie Ryan and First Lieut. William Patrick Dickey, both of the Air Force, plan to marry next month in the Philippines.
CHICAGO, Feb. 17 (UPI) Brig. Gen. Roy T. Dodge of the Army Engineers confirmed here today that a proposal to shut off the American Falls to stop erosion at Niagara was in the planning stage.

TUCSON, Ariz., Feb. 17 (AP) Chares Coody, a 28-year-old Texan, rebounded from a bogey on the first hole today to shoot a five-under-par 67 and take the the first-round lead in the $60,000 Tucson open golf tournament. The event is being played over the Tucson National Golf course, measuring 7,200 yards.

Assistant Commerce Secretary Eugene P. Foley yesterday declared the Naval Shipyard in Brooklyn and its immediate surrounding area eligible for Federal assistance to help develop it as an industrial park.

ELLAVILLE, Ga., Feb. 17 (UPI) A Jury of 11 Negroes and one white man convicted a teen-age Negro tonight of voluntary manslaughter in the slaying of a white policeman and set the sentence at six years' imprisonment.
The basic objective of Mayor Lindsay's proposed new transportation legislation is to bring order, coherence and unity into the making of the city's transit policy.

The New York Athletic Club's international fencing tourney opens today with a field of past, present and future cham pions.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor brought out in public today what other high Officials here have made increasingly plain in private namely that the United States' terms for peace in Vietnam are much stiffer than the offer of "unconditional" negotiations has implied.

The career of Hans Hofmann was in many ways emblematic of the changing values and shifting geographical locale of modern painting itself. It was a career that traced a course from Munich and Paris, in the days before World War I when they were the artistic capitals of Europe, to New York..

BRANFORD, Conn., Feb. 17 Mr. and Mrs. Archibald Hanna Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jean Prescott Hanna, to Jeffry Kurt Larson, son of Mrs. Jeanette Larson of North Kansas City, Mo., and Roderick Larson of Manteca, Calif.
The Wagner College Choir from Staten Island, led by Sigvart J. Steen, gave a concert at Philharmonic Hall last night for the benefit of the Lutheran Medical Center of Brooklyn.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Friday, Feb. 18 (Reuters)--The prosecution has demanded the death sentence for the Communist leader Njono, on trial here on charges of treason, according to informed sources.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 Governor Rockefeller called on Congress today to reject a proposed system of Federal supervision, over the taxes states exact from businesses operating across state lines.

EXCEPT for the pleasure of doing it, there is not much point in going on at any length about Georges Feydeau's 'Un Fil a la Patte" as performed last night at the New York City Center by the troupe of the Comedie Francaise. There are no pros and cons to be weighed. The whole thing was perfect.
Mrs. Francisco Cuevas Cancino, wife of Mexico's perma nent representative at the United Nations, died yesterday at Flower-Fifth Avenue Hospital after a sudden illness. She was 39 years old.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 The Secretary of Commerce urgently requested the business community today to start thinking about what should follow the present voluntary program for solving the nation's balanceof-payments problem.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 17 An annual prize of $50,000, the world's largest medical award, has been established to find the cause, treatment and prevention of two killer diseases hardening of the arteries and high blood pressure.

Advocates and opponents of school reorganization, of clustering schools in complexes of educational parks and of transforming academic and vocational high schools into "comprehensive" institutions, joined yesterday in attacking the Board of Education.

The city administration announced yesterday that the head of a Brooklyn neighborhood antipoverty center who was dis-" missed on Tuesday had been rehired in response to strong reaction from the community.
AUSTIN, Tex., Feb. 17 City leaders urged the White House today not to move its Texas headquarters from Austin to San Antonio. Such a move has been rumored.

Julius Katchen's playing of Brahms piano pieces last night in Town Hall was a high point of the recital-ridden season. He ended his four-part survey of the piano works of Brahms and played with security, intellectual probity--both of which one expects--one with intimacy and poetry--which one rarely gets.
