WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 Intercity truck tonnage and rail freight ton-mileage in the latest week ended Feb. 12 were both considerably ahead of the volume in the corresponding week of 1965. Increases, particuarly at Atlantic and Gulf ports, are attributed to the longshoremen's strike at this time last year.

LONDON, Feb. 17-- A member of the exclusive club of five London bullion dealers estimated today that the Soviet Union had sold 10 million ounces of gold last year to the West to pay for wheat purchases.

TORONTO, Feb. 17 MasseyFerguson, Ltd., a leading producer of farm machinery with headquarters here, plans to offer shareholders in Canada and the United States rights to buy more stock on the basis of one additional share for each five common shares held.

The most effective and most persistent white voices raised against the seizure of independence by Rhodesia's white minority regime have been those of the country's major newspapers: The Rhodesia Herald and Sunday Mail of Salisbury and The Chronicle of Bulawayo.
ANNISTON, Ala., Feb. 17 (UPI) An all-white Circuit Court jury found Johnny Ira Defries not guilty today of the slaying last July of Willie Brewster, a Negro.

ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 17 (UPI) Michael H. Silver's Spearfish scored a two-length victory today at Santa Anita in the $47,000 Santa Susana Stakes to capture the 3-yearold filly championship of the meeting.

The 19th annual card party and tea to raise funds for scholarships at the Cornell University-New York Hospital School of Nursing will be held the afternoon of March 16 at the school's nurses' residence, 1320 York Avenue.

MANY of the designers on Seventh Avenue have been running scared during the last two weeks as they presented their summer collections. Many designers of grown-up clothes, like their Paris colleagues who indulged in some strange behavior last month, have rushed backward into childhood.
For about 45 days, the length of the Chilean copper strike, the copper futures market here and in London has been kept jumping.
Three detectives used their heads and their noses to recover almost $4,000 worth Of stolen Italian cheese yesterday.

Attended with Mrs. Johnson a prayer breakfast at the Shoreham Hotel; received a book of original cartoons from representatives of the American Editorial Cartoonists; nominated Rear Adm. Willard J. Smith to be Commandant of the Coast Guard with a promotion to admiral.

MIAMI, Feb. 17 Cassius Clay, reclassified 1-A today by his Louisville draft board, said that his lawyers would appeal the decision and charged that he was being "picked on" because he was a member of the socalled Black Muslim sect.

The Garden Bay Manor Apartments in Jackson Heights, Queens, one of New York's largest pre-war garden-apartment developments, has been sold by N.K. Winston, builder-owner, to a partnership that includes Harry B. Helmsley and Lawrence A. Wien.

Evans D. Cohen of 20 West 77th Street, general manager of the Shuttleworth Carton Company, manufacturers of folding paper boxes, 474, West Broadway, died on Wednesday at New York Hospital. He was 54 years old.
ATLANTIC CIY, Feb. 17 Lost revenue of $1,000 a month has forced the New Jersey Expressway Authority to end its honor system at the unmanned toll gates along the Atlantic City Expressway.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 The big increase in Social Security taxes that went into effect the first of the year cut sharply into the amount of money income received by individuals in January.
A 17-year-old Queens youth was arraigned yesterday for disorderly conduct and faces possible grand jury action on a felonious assault complaint by a policeman who arrested him.

IT is always interesting to watch a new conductor. Each has his mannerisms; conductor-collectors note and file away eccentricities, pos tures, motions and techniques the way baseball experts talk about Hornsby's batting form and the way Babe Ruth used to keep both feet together.
The big buyer of Studebaker Corporation stock on Wednesday was Kleiner, Bell Co., a Beverly Hills, Calif., investment banking concern and member of the New York Stock Exchange.

Hans Hofmann, the painter, and one of the most influential art teachers of the century, died last night, apparently of a heart attack, in his home at 1 Washington Square Village. He would have been 86 years old next month.

Just before the National League held its expansion draft for the New York Mets and Houston, the do-gooders and wishful thinkers were urging that the league make available to the newcomers a better selection of talent than the Americans had offered their new teamas a year earlier. These pleas were greeted by a stony silence.

SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., Feb. 17 A group of 50 men's wear retailers and manufacturers grappled here today with the selling problems in the youth market and ended with the conclusion that it was still easier said than done.

GLENVIEW, Ill., Feb. 17 Mr. and Mrs. Gordon H. Kerber have announced the engagement of their, daughter, Miss Mary Elizabeth Kerber, to Richard David Krugman, son of Dr. and Mrs. Saul Krugman of New York. A July wedding is planned.
MEMPHIS, Feb. 17 -- Eight young Negro men were convicted today in the rape of one of two teen-age white girls.

Alfred P. Sloan Jr., who shaped the General Motors Corporation into one of the world's largest manufacturing enterprises, died of a heart attack yesterday afternoon at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Center here. He was 90 years old.

MADISON, Wis., Feb. 17 Aaron Bohrod, nationally known painter and University of Wisconsin artist in residence, was fined $10,000 in United States District Court here today for Federal income-tax evasion.

VIENNA, Feb. 17 A war crimes trial ended in Salzburg today with the virtual acquit tal of two former SS men who had been accused of mass slay ings of Jews in Nazi-occupied Poland during World War II. But the judge said he could not accept the jury's decision and ordered the case put before the Supreme Court.
The stock market fell severely yesterday in active trading, with the investment-grade issues showing the largest losses.
THE HAGUE, Feb. 17 Beatrix of Orange and her fiance, Claus von Amsberg, registered their forthcoming marriage in the town hall in Baarn today almost as any other Dutch couple would.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 The United States partly lifted today the veil of secrecy from its plans for massive retaliation in the event of an enemy nuclear attack.
The police in Nassau County and Queens are investigating two separate assaults reported by women Wednesday night.

The question of whether a theater critic should base his review on the last preview of a Broadway show rather than on the official premiere was the topic of a lively television discussion on Channel 13 last night.

The American Turkish Society will honor two Turkish envoys at its annual luncheon, Feb. 25, in the Grand Ballroom of the Pierre. They are Ambassador Turgut Menemencioglu and Orhan Eralp, delegate to the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 The head of the United Mine workers of America said tonight that he could not be bound by the Government's noninflationary guideposts in this year's negotiations with the soft coal producers.
BROOKLINE, Mass., Feb. 17 (AP) Two St. Louis women moved into the semi-finals of the national women's indoor tennis championship today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (UPI) Lieut. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey clashed with members of the House today when he insisted that a Michigan draft board was right in reclassifying as 1-A some youths who staged a sit-in at its office.
Edward G. McEneaney of Old Westbury, L.I., a commission broker on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange, was suspended yesterday by the Big Board for six months.
A play that has just finished a three-day run at Frederick Douglass Junior High School in Harlem may get a chance to go ...

SAIGON, Feb. 17 A vast allied offensive on the central coast of South Vietnam appeared to be drawing slowly to a close today. Qualified military officials considered the results disappointing in view of the effort's size and expense.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb. 17 The Rhodesian Government, which has been quietly planning a strategic railroad that would provide a direct link with South Africa, is suffering the embarrassment of an open civic battle over the route it should take.
TRENTON, Feb. 17 New Jersey's State Highway Department has turned to a device developed in the mountains of 'Chile to try to solve its perennial fog problem.

The dean of Harvard University's arts and science faculty charged yesterday that many universities were using an academic "star system" to "pick up" a few renowned professors. At the same time, these institutions are destroying the morale of the rest of the faculty, the statement warned.

Net borrowed reserves of the Federal Reserve member banks were estimated at $122-million on a daily average basis in the week ended Feb. 16, according to figures issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

SALISBURY, Md., Feb. 17 Following his victory yesterday over Dennis Ralston, the ranking player of the United States, Tomas Koch of Brazil eliminated Rafael Osuna of Mexico tonight in the national indoor tennis championships.
The TU-114 that crashed was the same model that brought former Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev to the United States on his 1959 visit to the United Nations.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 A comprehensive program to test sonic booms that will include flights over American communities is being prepared by a top-level Government committee.

THAT hardy perennial, the courtroom melodrama, is back with us. The current example "Hostile Witness," which opened last night at the Music Box is of the English garden variety. Sturdy and serviceable.
REDLANDS, Calif., Feb. 17 Miss Carolyn Everett and Winberg Chai plan to marry May 27.
Col. George Edward Levings 2d, a lawyer and a retired Army officer, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in Hillsboro, N.C. He was 61 years old.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 17, (AP) Wayne Hardin, who resigned as head football coach at Navy in 1964 during a debate of his contract, signed a two-year today as coach of the Philadelphia Bulldogs of the Continental League.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 17 Secretary General U Thant contended today that he had no knowledge that the North Vietnamese Government had put forth three requirements for negotiations to end the war in Vietnam.
Composers who write in advanced idioms, such as 12-tone and aleatory (music of chance) techniques, have emerged from the underground in the Soviet Union.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 17 One of the most familiar figures in the public lobby of the United Nations has been denounced as an imposter.
Department-store sales in the United States during the week ended Feb. 12 amounted to $364-million, compared with $333-million last week, the Department of Commerce reported yesterday.
McKesson Robbins, Inc., elected Rudolph J. Drews, Prentis C. Hale and Wayne D. Hudson to its board, Herman C. Nolen, chairman and chief executive officer, announced yesterday.
The American Electric Power Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday a record net income of $80,703,000 for the 12 months ended Jan. 31.
The spot rate on the British pound rose 6 points, to $2.8030, yesterday in moderate trading on foreign exchange markets here.
John S. (Bud) Palmer, the sports broadcaster and former basketball star, was reported last night to have been offered the position of official greeter for New York City.
ALBANY, Feb. 17 Leaders of the divided Legislature are putting on pressure to accelerate the pace of lawmaking.

Harold Gottfried, head of the Gordon Baking Company, producer of Silvercup Bread, asked yesterday that the Gottfried Baking Company, a competitor, be forced to put up an indemnity bond while it is in the process of reorganization under Chapter XI of the Bankruptcy Act.
LONDON, Feb. 17 Experts of the Government and the British Motor Corporation agreed today that it was not a defective component in an Austin 1100 automobile that caused a fatal accident recently.

New York University rolled up its highest score in the 28game series against Notre Dame defeating the Irish, 10278, last night in the featured basketball game at Madison Square Garden. The margin also was the Violets' largest since the two teams initiated the Garden's double-header programs in 1934.

NEW DELHI, Feb. 17 Vice President Humphrey announced here today a $100-million loan to India in a resumption of economic aid. The United States froze such aid last September after fighting started between India and Pakistan.
The war in Vietnam has provoked a national debate on United States policy in Southeast Asia.
The London Stock Exchange closed yesterday with widespread gains, bolstered by a late rally on an unexpectedly good profit report by the Imperial Chemical Industries.
The National Sport, Vacation and Travel Show, a New York fixture since 1935, will open under a new name tomorrow at the Coliseum.
OSLO, Feb. 17 (AP) Eero Maentyranta, a handsome Fin nish customs officer, won a third gold medal in the 80-kilometer race as the world Nordic ski championships opened today.

SINGAPORE, Friday, Feb. 18 (AP) John W. Goetzecke, 72-year-old American yachtsman, reported today that Indonesian authorities detained him for 32 days after his ketch got into Indonesian waters last month.
Rain, snow and some unseasonably warm weather added 19.6 billion gallons to the city's water supply in the last week.
MIAMI, Feb. l7 At the Miami Boat Show, a salesman has to be careful what he tells a customer about a boat's capabilities.
TOLEDO, Ohio, Feb. 18 (AP) Four men were sentenced in Federal District Court today to three years in prison for violation of the Selective Service Act.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 President Johnson talked about the weather today and suggested that something can and should be done about it.

Directors of the Kennecott Copper Corporation proposed yesterday a three-for-one split of the common stock the first split since 1929 when a 2-for-1 split was voted. The proposal is subject to shareholder approval at the annual meeting May 3.

The Giller Tool Company, a division of Hydrometals, Inc., has received new defense contracts totaling $1.9-million. Fred M. Zeder 2d, president of Hydrometals, said this contract brings the backlog to more than $4million.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 Clyde A. Tolson, associate director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, was granted a patent this week for a device that opens and closes windows automatically.
AKRON, Ohio, Feb. 18 (AP) Lawrence J. Bader, an Akron appliance salesman who disappeared from a Lake Erie motorboat nine years ago, was declared officially alive today.
The Aetna Life and Casualty group reported yesterday that there were gains last year in premium and investment incomes, but substantial losses in its fire and casualty-insurance business.
SAIGON, Feb. 18 A military spokesman said today that there was "pretty good evidence" that about 4,000 North Vietnamese Army troops had been infiltrated into South Vietnam since Jan. 1.
The traumas of the executive suite will be explored in a halfhour comedy series next season, when the National Broadcasting Company presents "Occasional Wife."
Plans to merge the Standard Forgings Corporation into the Transue Williams Steel Forging Corporation were announced yesterday. The deal had been under discussion since Last April.

THANHTAN, South Vietnam Feb. 16 Two teams are competing for the allegiance of the 4,200 regular inhabitants of an island about 12,000 yards long and 1,000 yards wide in the broad, brown Hamluong River

Hillary G. Carroll, the 18 year-old son of George Carroll, aviation editor of The New York Journal-American and other Hearst newspapers, was killed early yesterday in an automobile accident in Flushing, Queens.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Feb. 18 Middlebury's skisquad staged a mighty showing in the giant slalom and a wellrounded one in cross-country today to lead Dartmouth by a substantial margin in the Williams College Carnival.
TELAVIV Fashion may be only fabric deep, but that's deep enough for Israeli designers, who believe their versatility comes through the weave.
EMERSON AND THOREAU : Transcendentalists in Conflict, by Joel Porte (Wesleyan University, $7).

EVERYTHING is intensely overheated in the new Marlon Brando film, "The Chase," which blowtorched its way into the Sutton and the Victoria yesterday. The screenplay is overheated, the emotional content, the pictorial style, the directing, the acting, the fist-fighting, the burning of a junkyard at the end--everything.
The Celanese Corporation of America, registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday its previously announced rights offering of 1,478,622 common shares.

AMONG several diverting attributes of the new Salum Sanctorum restaurant is the management's candor about cost. When a reservation is made, the caller is advised, more or less, to come armed with a bag full of money and more perspicacious advice would be hard to come by.

The City Planning Commission made public yesterday its plan for changing the planned routing of a controversial Staten Island highway so as to minimize the inroads it would make on the island's greenbelt.
PASADENA, Calif., Feb. 18 (UPI) Customs agents made today what they believe was the largest single seizure of marijuana in United States history.

It might be unthinkable to hang a John Sloan painting between a pair of Davids, but you can get away with a comparable juxtaposition in music and with delightful results. Last night in Philharmonic Hall, the Festival Orchestra of New York, vender Thomas Dunn's direction, planted Charles Ives's evocation of an American camp meeting between an elegant symphony by Haydn and two Mozart concertos and produced a thoroughly enchanting program.
NEWARK, Feb. 18 The fight for control of Newark's major antipoverty program, supposedly ended, broke out again today.

MOSCOW, Feb. 18 (AP) The Soviet Union announced tonight the formation of a Goverment commission headed by a Deputy Premier to investigate the crash of a TU-114 airliner on take-off here yesterday. Tass, the official press agency, said six passengers and the crew had lost their lives.
WARSAW, Feb. 18 (AP) Stanislaw Mackiewicz, a controversial Polish writer, died in his sleep of a heart attack today, informed sources reported. He was 70 years old.
Twelve soloists, including a narrator, will appear with the New York Philharmonic during the season of "Promenades" that will start at Philharmonic Hall May 25.
PARIS, Feb. 18 The United States extended an "open door" invitation to French businesses this week to establish themselves on American soil.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) The Pentagon said today that its program for flying service personnel in Vietnam to rest and recreation areas was being expanded.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Feb. 18 (AP) The Midwestern Governors' Conference established a regional atomic resources authority today as a "helpful tool" in the sharing of nuclear information.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 Secretary of State Dean Rusk told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee at its hearing today that a provision of the Southeast Asia Collective Defense Treaty was a basis for the Administration's policy in Vietnam.

The Rev. Dr. Eugene Carson Blake, newly elected General Secretary of the World Council of Churches, said yesterday that American policies in Vietnam were "self-defeating" because they were being carried out on a unilateral basis.

The American merchant marine will either increase substantially or decline in size by 1985, depending on which of two official shipping policy proposals is adopted, according to a new maritime research publications.
BOGOTA, Colombia, Feb. 18 ?This nation has been stunned by the death in a gun battle Tuesday of Camilo Torres Restrepo, a defrocked Roman Catholic priest who had turned Communist.
Federal Judge Dudley B. Bonsal has set May 9 as a tentative trial date for the Securities and Exchange Commission's action against the Texas Gulf Sulphur Company.
DETROIT, Feb. 18 (UPI) There is a "good probability" that the nation's auto industry will turn out more 1966-model passenger cars than the record 1965 output, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.
It looks as though Mayor Lindsay may have his troubles putting across his new transportation plan, and not just from Robert Moses.

For 24 hours up to 9 o'clock last night, the taped voice of a Franciscan priest was broadcast into a battery of telephones asking listeners to send a postcard of thanks to Police Commissioner Vincent L. Broderick, who will retire Monday.
LONDON, Feb. 18 A neolithic hunting shrine, its walls covered with rich paintings of hunting scenes, has been excavated by a British-led international archeological team in Anatolian Turkey.
ATHENS, Feb. 18 An Orthodox Bishop was sentenced to prison today in the first such action by a lay court in Greece. But the sentence was suspended.

A late recovery erased many early losses in the stock market yesterday, and prices at the close presented a scrambled picture. Trading was moderate. Stocks declining exceeded those advancing by about seven to five. The leading averages ended with only slight losses. Interest again was centered in special-situation stocks, many of which showed substantial gains.

Russel A. Deller, employment director of the Bell Telephone Laboratories from 1947 until his retirement in 1958, died Thursday in Wethersfield, Conn. He was 67 years old and lived at 4 Norwood Lane, Westport, Conn.

Steven Kapchak, formerly of the Waldorf-Astoria, is going to shine shoes at the St. Regis Hotel beginning Monday. He is taking the place of Joe Loscalzo, former bootblack of the St. Regis, who replaced him at the Waldorf on Jan. 14.

MIAMI, Feb. 18 Bob Fetters of the Cooper River (N.J.) Yacht Club went in front in the Comet Class midwinter championship today as the firstday leader, Don McPherson of Ithaca, N.Y., fouled out of the third race.
Msgr. Edward J. Kellenberg, pastor of St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Millbrook, N.Y., died on Thursday at his summer home in Wappingers Falls. He was 62 years old.
The Cunard Line's initial experiment with gambling as part of the fun in the sun available on Caribbean cruises appeaed to have been well received by passengers and crew of the liner Franconia.
The Bahamian Government, which will adopt a 7-shilling dollar starting May 25, to replace its old 20-shilling pound sterling currency, released photographs yesterday of its new currency.

A sweeping shift of powers fiscal, appointive and legislative from Washington to a civilian board was recommended for the United States Merchant Marine Academy yesterday by a member of the college's sevenman board of advisers.
Brooklyn was virtually without bed space last night for patients who required emergency surgery because of an unusually large number of cases.

CANBERRA, Australia, Feb. 18 Vice President Humphrey, who announced this week the renewal of United States economic aid to India and Pakistan, has obtained their agreement to stern requirements for its continuance.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 18 Canada is seeking a peacemaker's role in Vietnam as a member of the International Control Commission established by the Geneva conference in 1954.
The controversial Bryn Mawr hotel, once notorious as a center of narcotics addiction, prostitution and other crime, has been purchased by Barnard College.

Police Commissioner Vincent L. Broderick charged yesterday that "the patronage officer" for Mayor Lindsay had "apparently summoned" him last month "to discuss the organizational setup in the Police Department."
DURHAM, N.C., Feb. 18 A Soviet official said here today that legal authorities in Russia regarded war propaganda "as the greatest threat to humanity."
John Powell, head of Powell Magazines, Inc., 855 Avenue of the Americas, died Thursday at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived at 945 Fifth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Feb.18 The three major leaders of the New York Congressional delegation voiced surprise today at the announcement that $10-million in Federal aid might be available to convert the Naval Shipyard in Brooklyn into an industrial park.
The bond market ended the week yesterday on a downward note, after the recovery here and there earlier this week fizzled out.
TUCSON, Ariz., Feb. 18 (UPI) Johnny Pott, on the wings of a six-under-par 66, seized a three-stroke lead today at the halfway mark of the $60,000 Tucson open golf tournament.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 18 A Federal jury late today convicted Don C. Silverthorne of misapplication of $270,000 in funds of the defunct San Francisco National Bank, which he founded and of which he was president.

A Brooklyn honor patrolman charged with illegally detaining and beating a merchant seaman in October, 1964, was dismissed from the department yesterday after he was found guilty at a departmental trial.

PANAMA, Feb. 18 (AP) Bob McCallister of Corona, Calif., posted his fifth birdie of the day on the 18th hole for a four-under-par 68 today and a tie at 137 with Canada's Wilf Homenuik at the halfway mark in the Panama open golf tournament.

CRISTOBAL, C.Z., Feb. 18 No attempt is being made to pursue the 114-foot American flag vessel Joan D., which slipped out of port before dawn one day last week without paying some $6,000 in towing and other charges owed to the Panama Canal.
Ming Cho Lee, Shanghai-born set designer now working in New York, has a Washington's Birthday problem: how to be in two places at once.
DORTMUND, Germany, Feb. 18 (UPI) Dick Tiger of Nigeria, world middleweight champion, knocked out West Germany's Peter Mueller tonight in the third round of a scheduled 10-round nontitle bout.

MIAMI, Feb. 18 (AP) One of the world's finest collections of ancient Chinese jades, stolen nearly three months ago, has been recovered near here, apparently as the result of a mysterious telephone call.
The Detroit Steel Corporation reported yesterday a decline in earnings for 1965 to $1.19 a share, from $1.31 in 1964.

Visitors at the opening today of the New York International Sport and Camping Show at the Coliseum will have a wide range of activities thrust upon them. More than 150 exhibitors will be displaying sports, camping, vacation and travel products.
MOSCOW, Feb. 18 Cultural exchanges between the United States and the Soviet Union, which nearly became an incidental victim of the Vietnam war, now seem assured of continuation for two more years.
First National Stores, Inc., reported yesterday a sharp drop in earnings to $426,437, or 26 cents a share, for the quarter ended Dec. 31.

The Curtiss-Wright Corporation had a net income last year of $8,774,632, including a special credit of $782,552 relating to adjustment of preceding years' depreciation, less taxes, according to the report yesterday of T. Roland Berner, chairman and president.
CHICAGO, Feb. 18 (AP) The Cassius Clay-Ernie Terrell heavyweight title bout here March 29 appeared a certainty today as Clay plans to appeal his 1-A draft reclassification.
The election of Ellis H. Clark as a vice president of the Carlisle Corporation was announced yesterday in Carlisle, Pa., by George F. Dixon Jr., president.
Tom Paxton, a folk singer and guitarist, gave a program of his own works at his Town Hall debut last night.

Alfred P. Sloan Jr. was the archetypical corporation man of his age. His organizational and management skills, amounting almost to genius, submerged the personality. In directing the growth of General Motors to pre-eminence in the automotive industry, Mr. Sloan was a quiet, selfless executive who worked principally in and through committees.

The president of the Emerald Association of Long Island, who led the grand march at the Emerald Ball at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night, was of Italian rather than Irish ancestry. But aside from that, the character of the 127-year-old charity ball has survived the years.

Political crises in Belgium invariably have their immediate, superficial reasons; but underneath there is always the basic conflict between the Frenchspeaking Walloons of the south and the Flemings of the north.
The state's Condon Wadlin Law is unworkable and should be "completely reorganized," Mayor Lindsay said yesterday.
"Where's the bucks?" supporters of Haryou-Act, the controversial Harlem antipoverty program, demanded yesterday of Mayor Lindsay.
Sent to Congress seventh annual report on weather modification; named a 12-member national advisory council on correctional manpower and training.
DALLAS, Feb. 18 Federal Judge Joe E. Estes will be asked to decide on Monday who owns the rifle with which Lee Harvey Oswald killed President Kennedy on Nov. 22, 1963.

MIAMI, Feb. 18 Braulio Baeza, the 25-year-old Panamanian who was been leading the jockeys at the current Hialeak meeting, suffered a concussion today and was taken to the North Shore Hospital. It was the second accident this week for Baeza. On Tuesday he suffered a bruised right Achilles tendon, a circumstance that did not prove serious.
The Glen Alden Corporation announced the sale yesterday of its coal division to the Blue Coal Corporation of WilkesBarre, Pa., in a transaction involving more than $10-million.
MANILA, Feb. 18 (AP) Ken Fletcher of Australia defeated Sam Ang of the Philippines, 6-4, 6-3, 6-3, in a singles quarter-finals match of the Philippine national tennis championships today.

The Chapel of the Beloved Disciple of the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Miss Joan Whitney Powers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. Hayward Powers Jr. of New York to Donald Eugene Harwood. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. A.R. Harwood of Chatfield, Minn.
MIAMI, Feb. 18 Dinner Key, described unblinkingly by its boat-rental merchants as the "sailing Mecca of Greater Miami," assumed an even broader role tonight.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Feb. 18 Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama is expected to announce formally next Thursday his wife's candidacy to be his successor, sources close to the Governor disclosed today.
The prosecution completed its case yesterday against three men on trial in the murder of Malcolm X, the black nationalist leader.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 18 Tim Flock, one of four brothers whose names are written prominently in the early history of Southern motor racing, came back to Daytona International Speedway after a five-year absence today and signed an entry form for the eighth annual 500-mile race to be run on Feb. 27.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 114.4 on Thursday from 114.3 on Wednesday.
Seminar, Harlem Lawyers Association, Criminal Courts Building 100 Centre Street, 10 A.M. Speakers: Judge John M. Murtagh, Edward Q. Carr, Anthony F. Marra.

General, de Gaulle's latest words about Vietnam would arouse more enthusiasm in the United States if they were not so couched as to give the appearance of mere sniping at American policy and if he had not so completely ignored his own role in starting the war the United States now is fighting.
ST. LOUIS, Feb. 18 Louis La Coss, former editorial page editor of The St. Louis GlobeDemocrat and a winner of the Pulitzer Prize, died yesterday of heart disease. He was 76 years old.

A detective formerly assigned to the Manhattan District Attorney's office denied yesterday that he had plotted with others to pass secret grand jury information to persons interested in an investigation of the Finger Lakes Race Track.
DETROIT, Feb. 18 (UPI) The Detroit Pistons withstood the New York Knicks' persistent comeback efforts to score a 120-118 viotary in a National Basketball Association game tonight.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Feb. 18 Little prospect is seen here of any action by Prime Minister Hendrik F. Verwoerd to curtail the heavy supplies of oil that are now being sent across the Limpopo River from South Africa to Rhodesia.
The Episcopal Diocese of Long Island has called a special convention to elect a successor to the late Right Rev. James P. DeWolfe, Bishop of the diocese from 1942 until his death two weeks ago.
Two rabbits ran in the New York Athletic Club's indoor Track meet last night at Madison Square Garden. One didn't quite do his job, and the other did his too well.
The question of how big "a serving" might be green beans, tomatoes, corned beef hash or whatever troubled five home and food editors of a group of women's magazines yesterday.

LONDON, Feb. 18 (Reuters) Somerset Maugham, reputed to have been one of the world's wealthiest writers, left an estate in England of 98,307 ($275,259), it was announced today. Details of the estate duty to be paid were not given.
The short interest on the New York Stock Exchange as of last Tuesday stood at 10,369,123 shares, an increase of 262,332 shares over Jan. 14.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 18 Mr. and Mrs. James P. Kneubuhl have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Janet Pritchard Kneubuhl, to G. Warren Schloat 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Schloat Jr. of Pleasantville, N.Y.
DAVENPORT, Iowa, Feb. 18 (AP) The 90,000 residents of this Mississippi River community were warned today to mobilize all flood protection from water backed up by an ice jam five miles long.
FRANKFORT, Ky., Feb. 18 (UPI) A Kentucky State Senator said today that ticketscalping was no more than free enterprise. Most of his fellow legislators agreed.
The United States Steel Corporation said yesterday that it would raise prices $4 a ton Monday on certain types of plate steel that are in tight supply.

Mrs. Mary Powers is a cheery grandmother with a youthful voice who for nine years has worked as an information operator in Manhattan. In that time, she has answered roughly 963,900, calls all anonymously.
BAUSCH AND LOMB, INC. Maurics F. Hasler, a director, sold 5,000 shares on Jan. 18, cutting his holdings to 15,000 shares.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 Dean Rusk, the Georgia hillbilly who became a Rhodes scholar, showed before the Senate and the country today the bearing of a man of forti tude and forbearance that he has presented for five uncontroversial years as Secretary of State.
The Consolidated Natural Gas Company reported yesterday that 1965 was a "highly successful year, with continued gains in sales, revenues and earnings."

VIENNA, Feb. 18 A Salzburg jury's acquittal of two men yesterday on charges of mass murder shocked public opinion here today. Students marched in protest demonstrations, and editorials denounced the action.

A CHARTERED bus lumbered through the pale light of early dawn on a re cent Saturday, stopped briefly at the Post Ski Sport Shop, 1131 Lexington Avenue, to pick up its load of well-bundled youngsters, their faces still rosy with sleep, and took off for the Lincoln Tunnel and a day on Catskill Mountain slopes.

LONDON, Feb. 18 John Cranko's "Card Game," given tonight for the first time by the Royal Ballet at Covent Gardent, is that rarity, a Stravinsky ballet in which another choreographer has beaten the old master, Georges Balanchine, at his own game.
CANBERRA, Feb. 18 After a 14-hour, 7,000-mile flight from New Delhi, Vice President Humphrey, arrived tonight in Canberra, a city that Australians call the "Washington of the wilderness."

Herman Wolfe, dean of boys at Francis Lewis High School in Flushing, Queens, and a leading high school basketball coach here for many years, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home at 525 East 82d Street. He was 63 years old.
Jimmy Brown, the National Football League's most valuable player, said here yesterday there was a remote chance he would retire before the 1966 season.

A two-alarm fire across the street from a firehouse damaged a five-story building last night at 799 Eighth Avenue between 47th and 48th Streets and caused a serious traffic tie-up in the midtown theater district.
Directors of Armour Co. elected Frank E. Stehlik as vice president and corporate controller and Robert L. James as a vice president, it was announced yesterday by William Wood Prince, chairman.

Several hundred residents of Queens, the Bronx and Manhattan fought City Hall yesterday. In anger as well as sorrow, they protested cuts in the Board of Education's $248-million capital budget at hearings in the Board of Estimate chamber.
Witold Woyda of Poland, the smallest ranking fencer in the world, won the New York Athltic Club's international foil competition last night.

MIAMI, Feb. 18 (UPI) A police chemist testified today that bloodstains had been found on the clothing of Melvin Lane Powers, who is on trial with his aunt, Mrs. Candace Mossler, for the murder of Mrs. Mossler's husband.

SAIGON, Feb. 18 Troops of the United States First Cavalry Division (Airmobile), who wiped out a Vietcong heavyweapons company in a daylong fight yesterday, plunged into combat again shortly after noon today.

"America's Paradise Lost," by Willard Price, will be issued by John Day on March 14. The book concerns the 2,000 Pacific islands of Micronesia. The author writes of an 8,000-mile trip that he made with his wife through the area. He tells of the beauty of the islands, but criticizes the Department of the Interior for what he describes as the deterioration of the Territory, which it administers.
Verdi's "Aida," at the Metropolitan Opera last night, was alive with the kind of excitement one hardly hopes for in so familiar a work, and rarely encounters in any.

MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 18 Israel will have to rely to a greater extent on American Jewish aid for its economic development because West German reparation payments, which amounted to $65-million annually, have ended.

The Anaconda Company, the world's largest copper producer, announced yesterday it planned a 50 per cent increase in production capacity by 1970. The plan will require capital expenditures of between $400-million and $600-million.

Stocks were mixed as a late recovery erased many of the early losses; interest again centered in special-situation stocks; volume, 8.47 million shares. Corporate bonds were steady; transactions, $12.77-million.

ALTHOUGH Constantine Sidamon-Eristoff is a hereditary prince, he prefers to be known as plain Connie Eristoff. "I have trouble enough pronouncing my full name," he said yesterday before biting into a tired-looking sandwich that he had unwrapped from some silver foil.

SALISBURY, Md., Feb. 18-- Arthur Ashe was beaten tonight, and followed Manuel Santana of Spain, Dennis Ralston of Bakersfield, Calif., and Jan-Erik Lundquist of Sweden out of the national indoor tennis championships.

The spiralling prices of copper and the need to scrounge for supplies have given copper traders and dealers a kind of humorous resignation. Yesterday proved no different, with prices rising again. No new highs were set, however.
Dr. John J. Meng announced yesterday that he would definitely retire as president of Hunter College next summer.
Stocks drifted down on the London Stock Exchange yesterday after early steadiness. Little selling pressure was reported and most shares declined only by fractions.

Twelve, young women descended from men who served in the American Revolution were presented to society last evening at the 31st annual Colonial Ball of the New York Chapter, Sons of the American Revolution, and the Daughters of the American Revolution. The ball was held at the Plaza.

Four major lumber associations reported an increase of 12.8 per cent in production for the week ended Feb. 12, compared with the level in the 1965 week. Output rose 3.2 per cent from the preceding week.

BAKERSFIELD, Calif., Feb. 20 The convention of the California Democratic Council, largest volunteer political group in the country, today condemned the Administration's policy on Vietnam and called for direct negotiation with the Vietcong to end the war.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Feb. 20 Attorney General Richmond M. Flowers has decided to seek the Democratic nomination for governor of Alabama and will announce his candidacy this week, a source close to Mr. Flowers disclosed today.

MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 20 George Meany, president of the A.F.L-C.I.O. asserted tonight that while Israel deserves greater economic assistance from the United States its "most dangerously aggressive neighbors are disqualified" from receiving such aid because of their hostile attitude toward this country.
A Transit Authority patrolman shot and killed last night one of three youths who were mugging an elderly man in a subway stairwell.

DANBURY, Conn., Feb. 20 Miss Loin Carole Yasler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Yasler, was married this afternoon to Herbert Gordon Isaacson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph S. Isaacson of Winsted. Rabbi Jerome R. Malino performed the ceremony at the United Jewish Center.

HONG KONG, Feb. 20 Peking asserted today that Chinese Communist influence could not be contained by any force. In replies to recent statements by two high United States officials, the Chinese served notice that neither war threats nor attempts to contain China would stop them from supporting the Vietnamese Communists and "all revolutionary people."
The Composers Forum concert presented at Donnell Library Auditorium on Saturday night was given over to music by John Rogers and Harold Seletsky.

The Cleveland Orchestra with George Szell conducting joined forces with John Browning for the Brahms piano Concerto No. 1 last night at Carnegie Hall, and closer, warmer collaboration would be hard to imagine.

THREE white children are playing among the foxgloves in the forest that surrounds their back-country New Zealand home or whare (in Maori). "Look at me," says one, "I'm a dancer." "Me too," chime the two smaller children. "...and the next thing here is a line of one-two-three as they whirl and dip down the path through the red and white blooms, secret yellow buttercups and starfaced daisies, and as they dance the rain returns, a
DAVENPORT, Iowa, Feb. 2O (UPI) Iowa National Guardsmen were called to duty today to help patrol levees being threatened by Mississippi River waters backed up by a massive, eight-mile-long ice jam.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Feb. 20 In an eerie Victorian house set on 80 rolling acres of Connecticut farmland, the night sounds are the shimmering music of a Javanese Gamelan orchestra, the thump of a mridangam, the drone of a tamboura and the resonant sounds of the vina.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 20 An Inner Belt Highway route being considered for Cambridge would cost the Massachusetts Institute of Technology at least $80-million and be a "disaster" to the institute, Dr. James R. Killian Jr. said today.
HONG KONG, Feb. 20 Peking implied today that there was a body opinion in the Soviet Union sympathetic to Communist China.

The election of Paul Revere as a director of Revere Copper and Brass, Inc., was announced over the weekend by John H. Eikenberg, chairman. Mr. Revere is a great-great-grandson of the American patriot of the same name, from whom the company traces its corporate origin and for whom the company was named.

Three full floors in the 17story building at 216 East 45th Street, between Second and Third Avenues, have been leased to three tenants in separate transactions accounting for a total of more than 33,000 square feet of space.
MOSCOW, Monday, Feb. 21 (Reuters) Valery Tarsis, the Russian anti-Communist author now in Britain, was stripped today of his Soviet citizenship by state edict.
A psychiatrist who treats artists warned yesterday against a trend in psychoanalysis that can make the creative person "feel that he is the sickest of us, rather than the healthiest."

MIAMI, Feb. 20 (AP) Darby Dan Farm's undefeated Graustark, the early favorite for the $100,000 added Flamingo Stakes, has been injured and will not race in the Hialeah event March 3, his owners announced today.

NORTH SALEM, N.Y., Feb. 20 Highclere, a 9-year-old brown gelding who spent most of his life as an outcast on a Maryland farm, won both the junior and open working hunter championships today at the Salem View Farm's horse show.
NEW ROCHELLE, Feb. 20 A priest proposed today that the Roman Catholic church make further revisions in its liturgy to eliminate Scriptural readings that hurt the Jews.

The economic debate between the Johnson Administration, which wants to wait and see before taking further action to dampen inflationary pressures, and many private economists, who think that now is the time to act, shows no sign of waning.
BONN, Feb. 20 West Berlin officials are studying the possibility of establishing a free trade zone in their part of the city to serve as a show window for East-West trade.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 20 (UPI) Guy Perillat of France fought off a challenge by Karl Schranz of Austria today to win the slalom event at the Kranjska Gora skiing tournament.

BOSTON, Feb. 20 Miss Judith Sue Grossiman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Grossman of Chestnut Hill, was married today to Steven J. Molinsky, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Molinsky of West Hartford, Conn.
TUCSON, Ariz., Feb. 20 (UPI) Joe Campbell won the $60,000 Tucson open golf tournament today with a birdie on the first hole of a sudden-death playoff with Gene Littler.
Administration officials have let it be known that they will request increases in taxes if inflationary pressures become more intense, but will wait until early May before making their decision.

The 199-man graduating class of the United States Merchant Marine Academy has asked Rear Adm. Gordon McLintock, superintendent, to hold commencement exercises in May instead of August. The cadets said they want to go to sea earlier to relieve the officer shortage.
THE similarity between the maternity dresses David Loring designs for Jeanette and any other dresses worn by young, fashionable women is not coincidental.

THE two-session open pair championship played Sat urday in the George Washington birthday tournament of the Greater New York Bridge Association ended in a victory for Jan Krasinski of Brookville, L.I., and Ray Root of New York City.
A study financed by the Ford Foundation urged yesterday that the Deputy Mayor-City Administrator be given more power to ease the day-to-day work of the Mayor.

Vic Hadfield, at least, could do something about Henri Richard he beat him up again. But Hadfield's teammates on the New York Rangers could do nothing with the Montreal Canadiens or the referee last night and wound up losing, 5-3.
PARIS, Feb. 20 The United States has pushed Europe into an expansion of capital markets that Europeans never dreamed of. Some Europeans do not like it. Others welcome it.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Feb. 20 Pakistan criticized the United States tonight for apparently having made its economic aid dependent on Pakistan's awareness of "the threat of Communist China."
President Johnson was reported by the magazine Newsweek yesterday to have issued secret orders forbidding United States planes to bomb the northern half of North Vietnam except for Dienbienphu.
A solo performance by Emlyn Williams in readings from Charles Dickens will be televised on a special one-hour show next fall by the Columbia Broadcasting System.

The Association of Building Inspectors said yesterday that it would go to court to fight a plan to put the city's housing inspectors into uniform. It denounced the proposed uniforms as "Gestapo green' but said it would object to a uniform of any color.
The new Soviet Five-Year Plan indicates that the successors of Premier Nikita s. Khrushchev have abandoned his economic aspirations for more modest, but possibly attainable, production goals.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 20. (UPI) California's flu epi demic which has already claimed at least three deaths continued to spread today, and health officials warned that the peak was still to come.
Miss Virginia Mergentime Bayer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Merwin Bayer, was married yesterday to Peter Robert Strasser, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Strasser. Both families are of New York.

Temple and Nancy Fielding, travel-guide writers, and William Morrow Co., Inc., New York book publishers, will establish today a new concern, Fielding Publications, Inc. Morrow will provide capital and guarantee the Fieldings annual salaries.

State Senator William Ozzard, Republican minority leader of the New Jersey Senate, said here last night that he feared Gov. Richard Hughes would use "the patronage whip" to force legislative approval of a state income tax.
SAIGON, Feb. 20 The field headquarters of the United States' First Cavalry Division (Airmobile) came under mortar attack tonight.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Monday, Feb. 21 Vice President Humphrey today described Senator Robert F. Kennedy's suggestion for a coalition government in Saigon as "a prescription for the ills of South Vietnam which includes a dose of arsenic."

A bipartisan bill to block Mayor Lindsay's plan for an expanded board to review civilian complaints against the police will be introduced in the State Legislature this week, the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association said yesterday.
The Democrats have appointed a committee to pick a site for this year's Democratic State Convention.

GRAND MASTER Leonid Stein won first place in the recent Soviet Union championship at Tallinn, scoring 14 points out of a possible 19, half a point more than Grand Master Lev Polugayevsky, who was second.

"The Enrichment of American Culture Through the Desegregation of the Arts" will be the subject of a "working conference" from 9 A.M. to 6 P.M. on March 5 at the Ethical Culture Society, 2 West 64th Street. The discussion was arranged by the society in cooperation with an ad hoe committee of actors and writers in cluding Frederick O'Neal, president of Actors Equity.

TRENTON, Feb. 20 A team investigating charges of racism and anti-Semitism among New Jersey's Rat Finks for the National Young Republican Federation today attacked the "at titude and inmature conduct" of Clark Allen, president of the state's Young Republicans.

THE performance charts are now virtually com pleted on some of the nation's major independent college basketball teams, and the National Collegiate Athletic Association will start making calls to some of them Wednesday morning with bids for the N.C.A.A. champion ship next month.

ALBANY, Feb. 20 Negotiations for a compromise on reapportionment collapsed today and a Republican legislative leader charged that some topechelon Democrats outside the Legislature had made the decision to end the talks.

Increasing snow, hail, mist, rain and sleet falling over the 300,000-square-mile watershed of the Great Lakes indicates that a five-year drought in the Northeast may be ending, the State Power Authority reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (UPI) President Johnson said tonight, upon learning of Admiral Nimitz's death: "Admiral Nimitz loved his country and the sea. His devotion to one inspired his mastery of the other, earning for his quiet courage and resolute leadership the undying gratitude of his countrymen and an enduring chapter in the annals of naval history."

The Eastman Kodak Company achieved records in 1965 in sales, earnings, dividend, payments, number of shareholders and number of employes. Fourth-quarter profit and volume were also the highest for any quarter in its 85-year history, according to the report over the weekend of Albert K. Chapman, chairman, and Wil liam S. Vaughn, president.

New Jersey's rapidly growing commuter crisis cannot be solved on a piecemeal basis. While the plight of the commuter railroads is most acute at the moment, the basic problem is how to provide most efficient transportation for the 170,000 residents of New Jersey who work in New York, At present about 60,000 of these go to and from their jobs by rail, 70,000 by bus, and 40,000 by private car.
A critical threat to the American merchant marine is posed by a new cargo insurance rate that will go into effect on March 1 on all ships more than 20 years old, it was disclosed at the week's end.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 Two high Administration officials today assailed Senator Robert F. Kennedy's suggestion yesterday that the United States offer the Vietcong a role in a South Vietnamese coalition Government.

A supper dance in the Trianon Room of the New York Hilton will follow the March 29 premiere of the motion picture "Cast a Giant Shadow" at the De Mille Theater in Times Square. Both events will benefit the Association for the Help of Retarded Children. Chairman for the evening is Mrs. Charles C. Bryan and vice chairman is Mrs. Owen R. Cheatham.

BREMEN, Germany, Feb. 20 (AP) A Norwegian tanker carrying 40,000 tons of crude oil and a British freighter collided in thick fog off the island of Helgoland in the North Sea today and both vessels caught fire. The blazing tanker was abandoned, but the freighter, its fire under control, reported she was heading for Hamburg.

BRATTLEBORO, Vt., Feb. 20--Eric Merrill, the 20-year-old University of Massachusetts junior, realized a long-held ambition today by taking the Eastern ski-jumping championship on the Fred H. Harris Memorial Hill.

Carnegie Hall was filled to the gunwales with brisk, outdoorsy music when the United States Navy Band played there yesterday afternoon. It was the band's first trip to New York in what a representative said was 20 years, and the first time that the sailors had ever played in Carnegie Hall.
TEL AVIV No country has been straining more eagerly than Israel for a breakthrough in sweetening salt water.
Yeshiva University announced yesterday a $10-million plan to develop its Midtown Center in the Murray Hill section of Manhattan.
The General Electric Company introduced a new consolidated-method of reporting its financial results yesterday with an announcement of record sales and earnings for 1965.
TRENTON, Feb. 21--The State Supreme Court ruled today that a barber's refusal to cut a Negro's hair is racial discrimination prohibited by law.

CHICAGO, Feb. 21--The American Bar Association's House of Delegates today passed by unanimous voice vote and without debate a resolution affirming the legality of the United States participation in Vietnam under international law, the United Nations Charter and the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Feb. 21 --Hessel Edward Yntema, an expert in comparative law and a professor emeritus of the University of Michigan, died here today. He was 75 years old.

Mrs. Claire Beaudry Kelly of 10 East End Avenue and Eugene Carroll Kelly of New York and Stony Brook, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Suzanne Kelly, to George Anthony Whaling, son of Mrs. George Collins Whaling of Carthage, N.Y., and the late Mr. Whaling. An April wedding is planned.
Cornelius von E. Mitchell, former partner in Mitchell Van Winkle, lawyers at 60 East 42d Street, died yesterday at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived at 27-East 53d Street.

The black hulls of the Italian Line's Leonardo Da Vinci and the Cristoforo Colombo will be painted white to bring them into color harmony with the line's two other ships on the New York-Mediterranean service, the company announced yesterday.
Once a haven for men eligible for the draft, the military reserves in the metropolitan area have become a maze of despair for young men facing induction into the armed forces.
QUEBEC, Feb. 21 (UPI)-- --Christl Haas of Austria won the women's slalom event of the DuMaurier international ski meet yesterday with runs of 40.22 and 40.78 seconds.
URICHSVILLE, Ohio, Feb. 21 (AP)--Representative Wayne L. Hays, Democrat of Ohio, said in a statement today that he would forfeit a $69 bond in Mayor's Court on a speeding charge.

The refusal of former Premier Pierre Mendes-France of France to answer questions on Vietnam or President de Gaulle ruffled feelings at a student gathering at Wagner College in Staten Island last night.

LINDEN, N.J., Feb. 21-- Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Galle have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lynne Galle, to Richard John Mulligan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard V. Mulligan of New Brunswick.

Indonesia has again exploded a political bombshell. Last October the army led by General Nasution saved President Sukarno from a Communist plot. Yesterday Mr. Sukarno dismissed General Nasution from his Cabinet.

Production of papers of all sorts--newsprint, paperboard, printing papers and a variety of other forest products--is reaching for new records under the spur of war, rising demand and the booming economy.

RUMSON, N.J., Feb. 21-- Mrs. Warner Marsden, president of the Association of Junior Leagues of America, and Mrs. John J. Bell, president of the Junior Service League of Monmouth, have announced that the service league has joined the association and will be known as the Junior League of Monmouth, Inc.
Robert Bacon Seward, a retired patent attorney, died yesterday in his home at 38 Livingston Street, Brooklyn. His age was 94.

For soybean traders yesterday it was a matter of "which report do you read?" Two Government reports were issued -- one bullish, one bearish. Soybean futures, however, took the bearish cue, and tumbled.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP) --Luci Baines Johnson, looking ahead to married life, says she intends to live on the income of her husband-to-be, Patrick J. Nugent. "He wouldn't want it any other way," she says.

MONTREAL, Feb. 21--The body of Lieut. Gov. Paul Comtois of Quebec was found this afternoon in the burned-out ruins of his official residence in Quebec. The building was swept by fire in the early morning hours.

PARIS, Feb. 21 (UPI)-- Jacques Marty, the undefeated French middleweight, got off the floor tonight to score a technical knockout over Gil Diaz of Puerto Rico in the secand round of a scheduled 10round bout.
Retail installment contracts bought by the General Motors Acceptance Corporation last year climbed to a record of $4,924,000,000 from $4,557,000,000 in 1964, the company reported yesterday.

Mayor Lindsay in his first TV fireside chat Jan. 19 spoke of the "problem underlying almost every one of this city's troubles." That problem is, of course, money, and the imperative need to reform what the Mayor has aptly called "credit-card budgeting."
Richard Goode, a pianist who has been a member of Young Concert Artists since the nonprofit organization was formed in 1961, played for the last time under its auspices last night.

MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 21 (UPI)--Minnesota's Insurance Commissioner, Cyrus Magnusson, charged with fraud and conspiracy in the collapse of the American Allied Insurance Company, announced his candidacy yesterday for the Democratic-Farmer-Labor party nomination for Governor.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21-- The issue over Vietnam policy between the Administration and Senator Kennedy of New York is whether this Government, in advance of negotiations, should specify that it would accept a duly elected coalition regime composed of South Vietnamese and indigenous Vietcong.
Henry V. Kobin was elected yesterday to the board of U.S. Industries, Inc., a producer of industrial and consumer products and educational systems.
LAKE GEORGE, N.Y., Feb. 21 (AP)--Dick Wurster of Ballston Spa, N.Y., won the senior men's title yesterday in the Northern New York speedskating championships.

More than 1,000 students from a dozen colleges in the metropolitan area--half of them clad in suits and dresses, the others in blue jeans and slacks--turned out last night for a rally in support of striking St. John's University faculty members.

The City Department of Personnel has announced that several jobs in real estate management with the Department of Real Estate are open. The positions, which pay $7,100 to $8,900 a year, require a high school diploma and three years experience, or a college degree and two years experience. A written examination will be held June 4, but applications must be submitted by March 22.
More than 30 new television shows are expected to be on the program schedules of the three national networks next fall. As to type, the shows will be comedy, science fiction, suspense and adventure.
Bob Maltz, who had presented jazz concerts in New York for more than 20 years, died yesterday at Maimonides Hospital, Brooklyn.

The victim of a $3,000 jewel theft asked a Criminal Court judge here yesterday to dismiss charges against a 21-year-old man and his 22-year-old sister, but the judge refused and sent the case to a grand jury.

High school students in New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania have become the nation's most disadvantaged youths in terms of their chances for college admission. For the first time, this area --the Middle Atlantic region --has replaced New England as the most restrictive part of the country for college admission.

PLEASANTVILLE, N.J. Feb. 21 (UPI)--Ernie Terrell characterized Cassius Clay as "an irresponsible kid" today and said Clay "says things all the time that don't make sense." Terrell is in training here for the title bout with Clay.
The spot rate on the British pound closed down 9 points from its Friday level at $2.8018 in moderate trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday.
OXFORD, Miss., Feb. 21 (AP) --Kentucky's Wildcats crushed Mississippi's basketball team, 108-65, tonight for their 22d straight victory.
ACCRA, Ghana, Feb. 21-- President Kwame Nkrumah left by air today for Hanoi to pay what is described officially as a "friendly visit."

MIAMI, Feb. 21--Bobby Ussery, the strong-armed jockey who had been doing most of his work in California this season, demonstrated today that he had a feeling for the Hialeah track by steering home four winners.

SINGAPORE, Feb. 21--Gen. Abdul Haris Nasution, widely regarded as the emergent strongman in Indonesia, was dismissed as Defense Minister tonight by President Sukarno. General Nasution had held the post since July, 1959.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 21--Yale's "Little Boy Blue, a two-time all American tallback at Princeton and a former New York Giant quarterback were among those elected today to the National Football Foundation Hall of Fame.
An East Harlem community action agency that operates without government antipoverty money opened its new headquarters yesterday in a reno vated loft building.

MOSCOW, Feb. 21 (Reuters)--Yevgeny Yevtushenko's chances of winning his country's top literary award, the Lenin prize, were dashed tonight but another poet who is a favorite of Soviet youth, Andrei Voznesensky, took a step near the award.
The Remington Arms Corporation, a subsidiary of the du Pont (E.I.) de Nemours Co., has received a $5,904,094 Army contract for production of ammunition.
The Chemical Fund, Inc., has announced the appointment of N.J. Prestigiacomo as a vice president. He is a partner of F. Eberstadt Company and is national sales manager of Chemical Fund shares.
CHILLICOTHE, Ohio, Feb. 21 (AP)--Dard Hunter, an authority on papermaking and printing, died here yesterday, apparently of a heart attack. His age was 82. He was stricken at his home, Mountain House.

The Consolidated Foods Corporation of Chicago is acquiring the E. Kahn's Sons Company of Cincinnati, a processed-meat concern, William Howlett, president of Consolidated Foods, told the Boston Security Analysts Society yesterday. Terms of the cash transaction were not disclosed.
Lawyers for two of the men accused of the murder of Malcolm X said yesterday that they would prove the defendants were not in the Audubon Ballroom when the assassination took place.
DAVOS, Switzerland, Feb. 21 (UPI)--Mayor Christian Jost declared the 13-nation world figure-skating championships opened in a brief ceremony at town hall tonight.

Common sense has eased if not solved one of the many difficult problems that had seemed likely to hamper British Guiana when it achieves independence an Guyana May 26. Venezuela has agreed not to press its claim to 50,000 square miles of Guyanese territory --nearly five-eighths of the entire country.
HARLEM in the twenties could not possibly have been as primly starched or as lifeless as it was made to appear in "The Strollin' '20's" last night by the Columbia Broadcasting System.

"Communist China in World Politics," by Harold C. Hinton, will be published by Houghton Mifflin on March 16. The author is associate professor of international affairs at George Washington University in Washington. The book gives the foundations of China's foreign policy, traces the Chinese attempt to influence the balance of power in Asia and the world, and suggests how the United States might answer future challenges from China.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 21 --A safeguard that failed was blamed today for a $1.3-million explosion and fire last July 5 at the Cambridge Election Accelerator, a center for nuclear experiments.
PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 21 --A collection of rare books and manuscripts by Oscar Wilde went on public display today at the Princeton University Library.
The Kewanee Oil Company has increased for the second time its offer to acquire the stock of the Kendall Refining Company.

Shredding a pocket tissue in his shaking hands, Detective. Sidney Berkowitz shouted from the witness stand in the Hyman E. Mintz bribery trial here yesterday that a previous witness had "destroyed" him.

State Senator Basil A. Paterson asserted yesterday that only 5 or 6 per cent of the City Police Department ranks were Negroes, compared with the more than 30 per cent in the housing and transit police.

DALLAS, Feb. 21--Federal Judge Joe E. Estes ruled today after a three-hour hearing that the Government could confiscate the rifle used by Lee Harvey Oswald to assassinate President Kennedy on Nov. 22, 1963. The hearing was held about a dozen blocks from the spot where Mr. Kennedy was shot.

MANILA, Feb. 21--Vice President Humphrey arrived in Manila tonight to deliver again his message that the best way to avoid a military confrontation with Communist China is to take economic and political preventive action in the rest of Asia.
The Hapco division of Kearney-National, Inc., raised prices by 3 to 7 per cent yesterday on a broad range of aluminum utility poles.

VUNGTAU, South Vietnam, Feb. 21--A group of men in black pajamas began the work today of trying to create the social revolution promised by President Johnson and the leaders of South Vietnam at the Honolulu conference.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Tuesday, Feb. 22--Five Negroes, including a 15-year-old boy, were shot last night by a young white man at a supermarket during racial picketing, the police reported.

Two former narcotics bureau detectives who were dismissed by Police Commissioner Stephen P.Kennedy in 1960 were dismissed again Saturday by Police Commissioner Vincent L. Broderick as one of his final acts.
Mayor Lindsay, swore in Howard R. Leary as the city's Police Commissioner yesterday and later criticized what he called "desperate voices" that say "the Police Department is a law unto itself."
ALBANY, Feb. 21--Over vehement Democratic protests, Senate Republicans passed a bill today that would make it unlawful for a citizen to resist arrest even when the policeman was in the wrong.

WESTBURY, L.I., Feb. 21-- Guy K. Dudley and Australianbred Lindsay Scott captured their $10,000 semi-finals of the Early Bird Pacing Series before 25,137 fans at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. Following their easy one-mile victories in 2:05 3-5 and 2:06, respectively, Guy K. Dudley and Lindsay Scott were named with five others to start in next Monday night's $15,000 final.
HOLMENKOLLEN, Norway, Feb. 21 (AP)--Georg Thoma of West Germany closed out his competitive skiing career today by winning the combined title in the world Nordic championships.
BREMEN, Germany, Feb. 21 (AP)--Three German tugs extinguished the fire aboard a partly submerged Norwegian tanker today and began efforts to salvage the ship adrift in the North Sea.

W. Harcourt Woods, the chairman of the Davis Cup committee, said yesterday at a United States Lawn Tennis Association meeting here that it was "the plan of the committee this year to keep our team intact. It is most beneficial to have them operating as a unit."
TRENTON, Feb. 21 (AP)-- The New Jersey Supreme Court refused today to permit an immediate half-cent-a-quart increase in the minimum price of milk sold in stores.
MALVERNE, L.I, Feb. 21-- Nine housewives were arrested here this morning as they attempted to block preparations for the integration of the Malverne elementary schools.
The Jim Walter Corporation, a Tampa, Fla., producer of shell homes and building materials, announced yesterday the election of Eugene R. Katz and Arthur Lautz as vice presidents.

CHICAGO, Feb. 21 (AP)-- Cassius Clay will go to Chicago Friday and apologize for his "unpatriotic remarks" that threatened to cause the cancellation of his March 29 heavyweight title fight here with Ernie Terrell, Joe Triner, the chairman of the Illinois Athletic Commission, said today.
Steel production continued to climb last week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
DETROIT, Feb. 21 (AP)-- Auto output in the United States was expected to show a slight drop this week as American Motors' production lines closed down today until March 7.
COLD SPRING, N.Y., Feb. 21 (UPI)--The 36-year-old wife of a Peekskill hair stylist gave birth to quadruplets today.

A 15-year-old pianist names David Oe (pronounced wee) knows that it pays to do good deeds. As a result of one, he will be a soloist in the New York. Philharmonic Young People's Concert, to be televised tonight at 7:30 over the Columbia Broadcasting System.

Who switched pianos for Sunday night's concert of the Cleveland Orchestra in Carne gie Hall? Was there a prankster loose in the house? Or is there a "Phantom of Caraegie Hall," a young, dark, good-looking one who has a girl friend?
Three men pleaded guilty yesterday in State Supreme Court, Brooklyn, to manslaughter charges in the slaying on Feb. 13, 1965, of Arthur Abrams, a teacher who drove a taxicab.

WOODBURY, L.I.--Set back in the woods, across the road from Syosset High School, is a little, red brick schoolhouse that is a haven for children nobody could cope with--neither their parents, their schools, their psychiatrists nor themselves.

Del Benjamin and Ed Mulvihill are fine, thank you, and so are Manhattan College's chances in the 24th annual Metropolitan Intercollegiate indoor track and field championships. The meet starts today with four field events outdoors.
GREENBURGH, N.Y., Feb. 21 (UPI)--A family of three was found dead today in their home here in what the police said appeared to be a double murder and a suicide.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21-- Washington's coffee sit-ins for Government employes may be on their way out.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 21--Robert Boles Heppenstall, a leader in the steel forgings industry, died today at the age of 62. He apparently suffered a heart attack while visiting his wife, Katherine, at West Penn Hospital.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP)--The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved today President Johnson's nomination of Jack Hood Vaughn to be director of the Peace Corps.

PORTLAND, Maine, Feb. 21 (AP)--Maine voters rejected today a 1965 legislative act permitting limited Sunday sale of liquor. The state bus remains the only one in New England that does not permit some form of Sunday sales.

TEL AVIV, Feb. 21--Premier Levi Eshkol announced new fiscal measures tonight in response to mounting offers by wage earners to waive part of their pay if the Government takes effective steps to check spiraling prices.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Feb. 21 --Howard C. Sykes, former president of the New York Curb Exchange, now the American Stock Exchange, and a big game hunter and sportsman, died yesterday in his home at 90 Franklin Street, after a long illness.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (UPI)--Senator John J. Williams, Republican of Delaware, demanded today the dismissal of Federal Housing Administration officials who approved a "fantastic scheme" to guarantee mortgages on a $4.6-million housing project that went bankrupt before it opened.
WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 21-- A reapportionment plan that would enlarge the Westchester County Board of Supervisors and give 13 of its members less than one vote each was presented to the board today.
SALT LAKE CITY, Feb. 21-- The pilot of a Boeing 727 jetliner that crashed short of the runway here last Nov. 11 told today how he was unable to check a steep descent as the plane neared the ground.

A drive to raise $1-million for the resuscitation of the Actors Studio Cheater was launched last night by its supporters, meeting in 21 on West 52d Street. John Mosler, president of the Mosler Safe Company, was named national chairman of the group's business and finance committee.

VALLEY FORGE, Pa., Feb. 21--The Department of Defense and the military services of the United States have been chosen to receive the Freedoms Foundation's highest honor-- the George Washington Award --for 1965.

The New York State Superintendent of Insurance has issued rules designed to limit the sale of industrial life insurance policies--costly weekly premium contracts for small amounts of protection, usually less than $500.

CONTINUING its unyielding stance of noncontroversy at all costs, Channel 13's New York Television Theater" last night offered two one-act plays by Bertolt Brecht. No great theatrical explosions resulted, but the occasion provided several poignant glimpses into the middle-class German soul under Hitler.

The Securities and Exchange Commission charged yesterday that David M. Milton "knowingly and willfully" caused the S P National Corporation to file "insufficient, false and misleading" annual reports from 1952 through fiscal 1964.
OAK PARK, Mich., Feb. 21-- Miss Charlaine Elizabeth Ackerman and Lewis Alan Coburn, graduates of the University of Michigan and members of Phi Beta Kappa, plan to marry in June.

FARMINGTON, Conn., Feb. 21--Mr. and Mrs. B. Bartram Cadbury have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Anne Cadbury, to David Montagu of Ithaca, N.Y. The future bridegroom, the son of Mrs. Phillip Applebaum of Chicago and the late Mr. Applebaum, changed his name.

CAIRO, Feb. 21--Anwar el Sadat, a member of President Gamal Abdel Nasser's inner circle for more than a decade, left Cairo today for an official visit to Washington that symbolizes the steady improvement in United States--Egyptian relations over the last year.
SAIGON, Feb. 21--This was a day of dedication and mourning for the First Cavalry Division (Airmobile).
The new Queens District Attorney urged clergymen yesterday to help crack what he described as the "honor code" of today's youngsters--don't tell on criminals.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 21 (AP)--A young, brilliant space scientist--chosen last month as one of the nation's 10 outstanding young men--shot himself to death today, the police reported.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 21--The Johnson Administration and organized labor confronted each other today over how to handle inflationary pressures. They came away with their conflicting views firmly intact.

Bruno Sammartino disposed of his latest rival, Baron Michele Sciculma, in 17 minutes 51 seconds of a wrestling exhibition last night at Madison Square Garden. A crowd of 14,303 cheered the champion as he caught Sciculma off the ropes and applied a reverse backbreaker.

LONDON, Feb. 21--A soft Virginian accent is heard these days in London's wine cellars asking about the kind of old wine bottles that Thomas Jefferson knew. The accent belongs to James A. Bear, curator of Monticello, home of the United States' third President.
Many early advances on the American Stock Exchange were erased yesterday by late selling and as a result, the market declined on strong volume.

Affluence, the teen-ager's zest for novelties and more home entertaining are causing the gift business to boom in such varied places as Riverdale, N.Y.; Kill Devil Hills, N.C.; Toronto, Canada, and Yarmouthport, Mass.
The Government bond market continued to move downward yesterday, depressed by news of Federal agency securities sales and the continued tightness of credit conditions.
IOWA CITY, Feb. 21 (UPI) --Iowa's basketball team upset ninth-ranked Michigan, 91-82, in a Big Ten game tonight.
Ernest Hemingway's widow lost her legal fight yesterday to block publication of a book of reminiscences about her husband, including a detailed account of his "breakdown" before he killed himself.

The essence of Senator Robert F. Kennedy's proposal for bringing about a Vietnam settlement-- which, if negotiated rather than imposed by force, inevitably, must include some Vietcong participation in The provisional Saigon government--is this:

Eight dissident stockholders of the Boston Maine Corporation have notified the Securities and Exchange Commission of their plans for conducting a proxy contest at the annual meeting in Boston on April 13.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21-- Administration sources said to day that the statements by President de Gaulle at his news conference in Paris hardly constituted a threat to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 21--Dr. Joseph W. Willard of Canada was unanimously elected today as chairman of the 30-nation Executive Board of the United Nations Children's Fund, Dr. Willard is Deputy Minister of National Welfare in Canada.

IF Neal S. Hochman had been manufacturing lingerie 20 years ago, he would have been worrying about where to put the lace on a slip. Today, he explained the other afternoon, the problem is figuring out "what a slip is."

THE sixth and final program in the Cleveland Orchestra's annual visit to Carnegie Hall offered three works last night that could be classified as neither common nor uncommon in the concert repertory: Rossini's Overture to "The Turk in Italy," Mozart's Piano Concerto in B flat (K. 456) and Bruckner's Third Symphony. By superlative,conducting and playing, George Szell and his ensemble made them all seem like masterpieces.
The nation's leading chain stores and mail-order houses began 1966 in the same fashion as they ended 1965--on a cheerful note.
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company has received its first formal backing from the investing public in the coming full-scale Federal Communications Commission investigation.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21--The three-month Treasury bill rate was essentially unchanged at today's auction from last week's rate, the Treasury disclosed tonight.
Mayor Lindsay participated in his first ceremonial signing at City Hall yesterday without signing anything.
Dr. Alexander Freed, former medical director of Yeshiva University, died in Israel an Feb. 13. He was 66 years old and formerly lived at 596 Riverside Drive.

The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company has leased five additional floors in the 25 story office building at 37 Wall Street, between Broad and William Streets. The bank already occupies six stories in another section of the building that fronts on Exchange Place.
The New York chapter of the Institute of Real Estate Management has elected new officers.
MONTE CARLO, Monaco, Feb. 21 (Reuters)--A jury deferred a decision tonight on appeals by 10 British cars disqualified at the end of the Monte Carlo rally last month.

MADRID, Feb. 21--Spanish authorities foreibly prevented hundreds of artists and intellectuals from paying tribute yesterday to the memory of the poet Antonio Machado Ruiz at Baeza, his birthplace in southern Spain.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21-- When Senator Joseph R. McCarthy was making, headlines with charges about Communism in the Government, ...

OCEANSIDE, Calif., Feb. 21 (UPI)--Six persons were killed today on a fog-shrouded highway in a chain of fiery collisions involving more than 100 automobiles and three exploding tanker trucks. At least six persons were injured, two critically.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (UPI) --The Soviet Union and the United States will open negotiations March 2 in an effort to reach a new agreement on scientific, educational and cultural exchanges, the State Department announced today.
