Shearson, Hammill Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange, announced here yesterday the appointment of Arthur H. Ross as vice president and a voting stockholder.
Councilman Joseph Modugno, the Queens Republican who frequently stands alone, or nearly so, in a City Council dominated 30 to 7 by Democrats, admitted yesterday he felt a bit frustrated about it all.
Closing quotations for issues not traded on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday:
A sharp decline in the stock market yesterday sent leading market averages to their lowest closing levels of 1966.
PARIS, Feb. 21--President de Gaulle recalled in his news conference today that France's withdrawal from participation in integrated NATO activities had been under way for some time.
PARIS, Feb. 21 (Reuters)-- Following, in unofficial translation, are excerpts from President de Gaulle's news confer ence here today:

PARIS, Feb. 21--President de Gaulle declared today that France would claim control of foreign military bases on her soil by April 4, 1969, the day the North Atlantic Treaty Organization may be renounced by its 15 members.
HONG KONG, Feb. 21--Peking relegated Premier Fidel Castro today to the growing ranks of its antagonists.

In World War II Admiral of the Fleet Chester W. Nimitz commanded a thousand ships and two million men over the Pacific expanse of 65 million square miles. It was his task to organize and deploy these formidable resources as they became available after the catastrophe of Pearl Harbor--his to direct them against a shrewd and powerful enemy, a Japan emboldened by an initial control of the western Pacific.

CAMDEN, N.J.--When he thinks of tomato soup, William B. Murphy smiles. Tomato soup, beautiful soup Best-selling soup in the Campbell (55 and growing) line. Least expensive soup, too. Only up half a cent a can in the just 10 years.

RUTHERFORD, N.J., Feb. 21 (AP)--Dick Holub resigned today after 17 seasons as Fairleigh Dickinson University's basketball coach to become director of the university's new Master of Arts in Teaching program on the Teaneck, N.J., campus.
WASHINGTON, Feb.21 (UPI) --The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether a Federal law barring interstate transport of lottery information applies to the New Hampshire sweepstakes.
ALBANY, Feb. 21--Assembly Speaker Anthony J.Travia told the Democrats in the Assembly late today to prepare for the Court of Appeals to take over the reapportionment of legislative districts.
New findings by two Wisconsin pediatricians demonstrate how the normal "magnifying" mechanism of the human placenta may overload the unborn child with harmful materials from the mother's blood .

The Fair Labor Standards Act has been revised several times since its original passage in 1938, but it still covers only about half of the workers who are employed for a wage or salary. Now dormant in the House of Representatives is a bill to increase the present minimum wage from $1.25 an hour to $1.75 over a period of years and to extend the law's coverage to eight million additional workers.
MIAMI, Feb. 21--Last week, mechanics tuning up boats for tomorrow's 172-mile Griffith Memorial ocean race were saying, "Speed-wise, nothing's going to touch this baby."
KIMBERLEY, South Africa, Feb. 21 (AP)--Ann Fairlie, a 16-year-old South African high school student, set a world rec ord of 1 minute 8.6 seconds for the women's 110-yard backstroke tonight.

ROME, Feb. 21--Pope Paul VI warned the priests of his own Rome diocese today to guard against any uncertainties in their faith, their priestly function or the reforms under way since the Ecumenical Council.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21-- The Government issued the first in a new and improved statistical series on construction today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21-- Senator J.W. Fulbright agreed today with Senator Robert F. Kennedy that any hope for a negotiated settlement in South Vietnam lay in admitting the Vietcong "to a share of power and responsibility."
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 21 (AP)--One bobsled racer was killed and four were injured today in two accidents at the spectacular Zigzag turn of the international Diamond Trophy competition course.

A splendidly sung and acted "Don Giovanni" was heard at the Metropolitan Opera last night. Elfego Esparza sang Leporello for the first time with the company and Ingrid Bjoner and Justino Diaz made their first seasonal appearances as Donna Anna and the Commendatore.

One argument for an increase in initial margin requirements --now 70 per cent--on securities purchases appeared to have been dissipated yesterday when the New York Stock Exchange announced that net debit ballances of its member firms had increased by only $33-million in January to $5,576,000,000.

Vittorio Gassman, the Italian film actor, best known in this country for his roles in "Bitter Rice" and "Big Deal on Madonna Street," gave the first of three New York concert readings last night at the Vivian Beaumont Theater, home of the Repertory Theater of Lincoln Center.
MOSCOW, Feb. 21--Prime Minister Wilson arrived today for a three-day official visit and said he was here to try to get East-West relations moving again.

ALBANY, Feb. 21 (AP)-- Representative Theodore R. Kupferman, State Senator william J. Ferall and Assemblyman William J. Giordano were officialy certified today as winners of the three special elections held Feb. 8 in New York.
Arnold Palmer, who already has an army, apparently is escalating his war on par to the extent that he needs an air force.

The National Colection of Fine Arts, sponsor of the United States exhibition at the Venice Biennale, the most important of the international art exhibitions, has canceled its agreement with the Guggenheim Museum to put on the show this June.
NASSAU, Bahamas, Feb. 21 (AP)--Rough water limited boaters to one race today in the Harold A. Johnson Trophy 5.5Meter series. Gordon Lindeman of Milwaukee, in Charade, held the lead with 13 points.

A bomb squad detective who interrupted a Town Hall gathering for peace in Vietnam Sundays night by starting to sing "God Bless America" did not report for duty yesterday. His superiors and the Police Department surgeon were looking into the case.

The Rockefeller Brothers Fund has given $35,000 to send some American collections of traditional African art to the First World Festival of Negro Arts in Dakar, Senegal, which will be held from April 1 to 24. More than 40 nations will participate in the project.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 21--With Mickey Mantle still sending optimistic reports from Rochester, Minn., but not expected to arrive for two more weeks, the New York Yankees began spring training today. For the first time in 40 years, they were coming off a seconddivision finish with an extremely uncertain future.
LONDON, Feb.21--American shipping men met with members of the Institute of London Underwriters today in an attempt to obtain new cargo-insurance rates for ships more than 20 years old.
Welfare recipients who are eligible for Medicare's supplementary medical insurance program are being assured that enrollment in the program will not reduce their monthly checks.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 21 (UPI)--Sam Jones, held to only 12 points in the first half, scored 21 after intermission to lead the Boston Celtics to a 115-108 victory over the Los Angeles Lakers tonight at the Sports Arena in a National Basketball Association game.
THE ghost of Ivan Petrovich Pavlov seems to be lurking on the second floor of the Coliseum, where the New York. International Sport and Camping Show is holding forth this week.
Two young men who campaigned for Mayor Lindsay last year were sworn in yesterday to jobs in the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity.

Tarsis, Disowned by Soviet, Asks Asylum in West LONDON, Feb. 21--Valery Tarsis, the Russian anti-Communist writer who was stripped today of his Soviet citizenship, has appealed for asylum "in the West."
Winston L. Bailey, vice president since 1964 of the Bank of America, was named yesterday to the additional post of secretary in the head office in San Francisco.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21-- Patents will be more difficult to obtain under a Supreme Court decision announced today.

Eastern Illinois University sold yesterday $5,750,000 of residence-hall revenue bonds to a group led by John Nuveen Co., Inc., and White, Weld Co. The winning bid of 100.01 for bonds with coupons of 5, 4 , 4.40 and 4 per cent set an annual net interest cost of 4.4899 per cent.

The war in Vietnam will probably end not around a conference table but with the quiet withdrawal of North Vietnamese units and Vietcong guerrillas late this year or in 1967, Life magazine suggests in an editorial in its Feb. 25 issue.

Samuel Desist, a retired United States Army major arrested in France as a conspirator in a multimillion-dollar heroin ring, was flown here yesterday hand cuffed to a Federal narcotics agent. Arraigned in Federal Court here, he was held for arraignment tomorrow. Judge Edward Weinfeld set bail at $100,000.
Joseph J. Harris, president of J.J. Harris Co., Inc., 20 Ex-- change Place, stockbrokers, died Sunday of a heart attack in his home, 315 West 70th Street. He was 48 years old.
Prices on the London stock market fell slightly yesterday as prospects of an early national election kept traders cautious.

The recent surge of "speculative activity" in the stock market hasn't escaped the notice of Keith Funston, president of the New York Stock Exchange. Although Mr. Funston has somewhat of a reputation for almost never using the words "speculation" and "speculative," in his letter to exchange members included in the 1965 annual report published yesterday, he said:
Deere Co., the producer of tractors and farm machinery, announced yesterday in Moline, Ill., that sales and earnings rose to new highs in the first fiscal quarter ended Jan. 31.
Governor Rockefeller will be the official greeter on Thursday to three French art experts who will tell Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz the French style of authenticating works of art.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21--The State Department announced today that direct telegraph communications had been established with the United States Embassy in Moscow, greatly reducing the time for transmission of diplomatic messages.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP)--The White House denied today that President Johnson had issued secret orders barring United States bomber flights over the northern part of North Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, Feb.21 (AP) --The Supreme Court upheld today an apportionment plan for the Ohio Legislature devised by Gov. James A. Rhodes and other Republican state officials and approved for this year's election by a lower Federal court.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 21-- The founder and president of the John Birch Society said today that California members of the organization probably would split their votes in this year's election fox Governor.

ALTHOUGH complaints rarely passed his thin lips, Field Marshal Wilhelm Keitel, chief of the German High Command from 1938 to 1945, was Mr. Bad Luck of World War II. He had the worst job in the German Army. In almost daily personal contact with Hitler, which was awful enough, his task was to transmit the military orders --some crazy some touched with genius-- that issued in a torrent from the Fuhrer.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 21--Secretary General Thant stressed today the need for "humanitarian measures" to assist persons persecuted for their opposition to South Africa's racial policies.

HAVING last month missed, through a conflict of duties, the appearance of the Gloria Contreras Dance Group at the 92d Street Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association, I found the prospect of going to the anditorium of Fordham University in the Bronx on Sunday night to catch up with it less than enchanting. But luckily, as the old Baedeker guidebooks would put it, the troupe was "worth a detour."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21--In two current films, "Darling" and "Juliet of the Spirits," we are invited to forget briefly about the teen-age problem long enough to concede that Womanhood also has a special case against contemporary western society.

SAIGON, Feb. 21--Helicopters dropped hundreds of teargas grenades today to douse a small patch of jungle--believed to be a fortified Vietcong area --265 miles northeast of Saigon in preparation for a bombing raid.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 21--A knowledgeable East European diplomat said here this week that Albania was having serious economic difficulties, and that this was the main reason for a gradual thaw in her relations with other European Communist countries.

OTTAWA, Feb. 21--Victor Moore, senior Canadian representative on the International Control Commission for Vietnam, conferred "in the last 10 days" with high officials in Hanoi, the North Vietnamese capital.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP) --A self-described former American Nazi storm trooper said today the Ku Klux Klan "should thank me" for backing up testimony of fanciful plots of violence laid to the Klan's Grand Empress of Ohio, Eloise Witte.
A gunman ended a night of crime with a dash of chivalry that resulted in his being shot five times early yesterday morning, according to the police.

MIAMI, Feb. 21 (UPI)--The wife of a key prosecution witness in the murder trial of Candace Mossler and her nephew, Melvin Lane Powers, tearfully testified today that her husband was a drug-addicted liar.

Like gathering a mighty armada to land a single dinghy, the United States is spending billions of dollars, mobilizing thousands of people and building a new generation of spacefaring machines to put two men on the moon for a few hours.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21-- The Supreme Court ruled today that Federal labor laws do not bar state courts from awarding libel judgments for statements made during union organizing campaigns.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21-- The Supreme Court was asked today to outlaw multimember legislative districts and apportionment based on registered voters in Hawaii.
HOLLYWOOD, Feb. 21.-- "Doctor Zhivago," "The Sound of Music" and "Ship of Fools" dominated nominations announced today for the Academy Awards. The winners will be disclosed April 18.
A Federal district judge ruled yesterday that the Government may eavesdrop on conversations between a prisoner and his lawyer if the prisoner gives his consent.
Record car and truck sales were reported yesterday by the Ford division of the Ford Motor Company for the Feb. 11 to Feb. 20 selling period.

The American maritime union boycott of ships from countries trading with North Vietnam should not be applied to merchant ships of Norway and Denmark, shipping spokesmen from the two Scandinavian nations said yesterday.
LAGOS, Nigeria, Feb. 21-- After less than six weeks in power, Nigeria's military Government unveiled today its formula for an eventual return to civilian rule.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21-- The gap between New York State's two Senators has widened perceptibly over the issue of who can claim credit for Federal investment in the state.

ALBANY, Feb. 21 (UPI)-- The New York State Assembly completed action today and sent a bill to Governor Rockefeller giving the State Racing Commission authority to fix a 234day racing season between March 10 and Dec. 15. The vote in the Assembly was 140-10. The measure previously passed the Senate.

BAN PHON SAVATH, Laos, Feb. 18--"We are trying to get the people to want more than they have now," the young American said. "We are trying first to create same Joneses and then to get somebody to keep up with them."
The three airline terminal corporations in New York City have announced the election of Hutchinson DuBosque as president.

Of all the antiques shows in New York, the annual event at Madison Square Garden, which opens today for a 10-day run, is the most determinedly educative. There are always displays of cultural content that may open new vistas to budding collectors.
MYSTIC, Conn., Feb. 21--Carl Custer Cutler, one of the three founders of Mystic Seaport, the marine historical shrine here, died yesterday in the Westerly (R.I.) Hospital. He was 87 years old.
MIAMI, Feb. 21 (UPI)--A stolen, centuries-old art treasure in jade was recovered in a rented automobile trailer, an insurance agent disclosed today.

Vincent Lyons Broderick arose at 6:30 yesterday morning in his rented Pelham, N.Y., home, made some coffee and waited for a limousine to arrive and take him to New York City for his last day at a job he adored.

Irvington House, a privately supported treatment and research agency for rheumatic fever and allied diseases in children, will be the beneficiary of the fourth annual Bal Rouge et Noir at the New York Hilton on April 20.
MYSTIC, Conn., Feb. 21--Carl Custer Cutler, one of the three founders of Mystic Seaport, the marine historical shrine here, died yesterday in the Westerly (R.I.) Hospital. He was 87 years old.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21--In the Supreme Court of the United States today, the following proceeding were had.

Famous fliers alighted last evening at the Americana to sing, fiddle and dance at the third annual Air Force Salute. A few even made speeches in honor of colleagues at the party in the Imperial Ballroom.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Feb. 21 --Pennsylvania Democrats, in disarray over a choice of candidates for what many observers here feel is a strong Republican year, completed a slate today.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 21 (UPI)--An Arizona Army National Guard gun crew accidentally fired a live antitank shell while practicing "aiming" in a neighborhood schoolground yes terday.

WHAT'S a "pollster?" one National Football League executive asked another last week as they shared two drinks in the Florida Room of the Palm Beach Biltmore Hotel. These executives and all the others at the N.F.L.'s annual meeting had just been mesmerized by Commissioner Pete Rozelle's newest toy, the poll, and by its high priest, Louis Harris.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21-- The Supreme Court took the following actions today:
ALBANY, Feb. 21--Governor Rockefeller promised today to "do everything in my power" to help Mayor Lindsay get the kind of tax legislation he needs to solve New York City's "tremendous" budget crisis.
PRETORIA, South Africa, Feb. 21 (AP)--Gary Player and Jack Nicklaus, both smarting from bee stings, shot three-under-par 69's today and tied their first round in a $50,000 six-match challenge series.

The Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States reported yesterday that a record $2.38-billion of life insurance was sold to individuals last year, up 10.8 per cent above the 1964 total of $2.15-billion, the previous record.

THE last thing Kenneth Kolker expected to see on his return yesterday morning from a vacation in South America was a collection of Mexican-looking furniture, as red as paprika, standing by the elevators on the sixth floor of Abraham Straus.

DALLAS, Feb. 21 (UPI)-- The Most Rev. Thomas K. Gor-- man has forbidden the playing of guitars and drums and the singing of folk songs in the 100 churches of the Dallas-Fort Worth Roman Catholic Diocese of which he is bishop.

William F.R. Ballard, chairman of the City Planning Commission, foresees a sharp decline in the power of independent authorities, making possible more comprehensive and effective planning in New York.
HACKENSACK, Feb. 21-- Superior Court Judge J. Wallace Leyden invalidated today the nominations of 32 of 64 poll watchers for Teaneck's refererendum on a $64.14-million budget Wednesday.

THE Master Pair Championship at the George Washington Tournament of the Greater New York Bridge Association on Sunday resulted in a victory for two young players, Ed Manfield of West Hempstead, L.I., and Richard Schwartz of Roslyn, L.I. Winners of the Flight B Championship were Jerry Locks of Cherry Hill, N.J., and Fred Klat of Willingsboro, N.J.

The Avco Corporation announced yesterday the election of E. Douglas Kenna as group vice president in charge of its new missiles, space and electronics group. The group was formed through a cent tralization of Avco's research and development division.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 21-- The Philadelphia Orchestra has Refused to accept the resignations of four of its members, who constitute the Philadelphia String Quartet. The musicians had planned to leave at the end of the season to be "quartet in residence" at the University of Washington in Seattle in the fall.
MOSCOW, Feb. 21--The Soviet edict that stripped Mr. Tarsis of his Soviet citizenship today said that the action was his punishment for "actions discrediting a Soviet citizen."
Central Harlem got a new bus route yesterday--a 14-block trip born of fear.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP)--A bill to authorize Federal aid for construction of nuclear power merchant vessels was introduced in Congress today by Senator Norris Cotton, Republican of New Hampshire.

Dr. and Mrs. Isidor Margolis of the Bronx have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Aviva Margolis, to Jonathan J. Halpert, son of Dr. and Mrs. Max Halpert of Manbattan. A June wedding is planned.

ROCHESTER, Minn., Feb. 21 --The engagement of Miss Katherine de Saulles Ellis, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. F. Henry Ellis Jr. of Rochester and Seal Harbor, Me., to David Macdonald Felsen, son of Mrs. Herman Felsen of Easthampton, Mass., and the late Dr. Felsen, has been announced by the future bride's parents.
RICHMOND, Feb. 21--Mrs. Mary Reid McCaw Bright, grandmother of Mrs.--John V. Lindsay, wife of New York's Mayor, died at her home today. She was 91 years old.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (UPI)--The House Agriculture Committee approved today a bill that could pave the way for a $13-million-a-year farmer-financed research and promotion campaign to help cotton compete with synthetic fibers.

Bill Evans, a pianist who is one of the jazz romantics, gave the first New York concert last night at Town Hall. He played with his trio, as an unaccompanied soloist and as part of a 15-piece orchestra.
For an opera company on the brink of its first season in a new house--and an allcontemporary season, at that --the situation at the City Opera Company yesterday was remarkably unfouled up.
By 1968, about half the world's supplies of crude oil will be transported by tankers exceeding 60,000 tons, according to a recent study of trends in tanker growth.

The Avco Corporation announced yesterday the election of E. Douglas Kenna as group vice president in charge of its new missiles, space and electronics group. The group was formed through a cent tralization of Avco's research and development division.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 21-- The Philadelphia Orchestra has Refused to accept the resignations of four of its members, who constitute the Philadelphia String Quartet. The musicians had planned to leave at the end of the season to be "quartet in residence" at the University of Washington in Seattle in the fall.
THE distinctive Pucci type of print is one of the strongest fashion statements brightening the tag end of winter.
SANTA MONICA, Calif., Feb. 22 A 31-year-old Roman Catholic priest formally initiated today an organizing drive aimed at unionizing the nation's 58,000 priests.

THE ever-loving adherents of W.C. Fields, who seem to be almost as numerous today as they were when the great man died in 1946, may not be entirely contented with the W.C. Fields Comedy Festival, an hour-and-a-half sampling of Fieldsiana that went on yesterday afternoon in the auditorium of the Gallery of Modern Art. That is because the Fields adherents are a voracious and insatiable lot.

The British pound came under pressure in London's foreign-exchange market yesterday and dropped to its lowest level since last Sept. 29. But there was a rally before noon, and the Bank of England was believed to have intervened.

A miscellaneous aggregation of works, most of them first performances of one sort or another, was offered at this season's second "Evening for New Music" last night at Carnegie Recital Hall. The result was a set of isolated, disconnected events that did not build up to a forceful whole.
New York became a children's playground, an invitation to a stroll, and a lazy man's front stoop on Washington's Birthday yesterday.

Arnold Palmer, the distinguished golfer-capitalist-pilot, whisked through a full schedule yesterday. He flew his new $750,000 jet place to New York, celebrated his wife's birthday and they received the Gold Tee Award at the Metropolitan Golf Writers' Association dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria.
ALBANY, Feb. 22--Negotiations to create new judgeships in New York City seem likely to bring results this year after long frustration by strife in the Democratic party and by interparty rivalries.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (UPI) President Johnson invited Congressional leaders of both parties today to a White House conference Thursday to hear a briefing by Vice President Humphrey on his Asian tour.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Feb. 22 "Spy" satellites, adapted to peaceful observations of the earth's surface, hold promise of bringing revolutionary scientific and economic advances, a national conference of aerospace engineers and executives was told today.
BRYN MAWR, Pa., Feb. 22 Miss Julia Weston Faunce and William Dillard Carragan plan to marry on April 2 in the Ardmore Presbyterian Church.

Herman Edelman, a 68-yearold cutter in the garment industry, died yesterday in an ambulance en route to Kings County Hospital after having suffered a heart attack at his home, 2250 Brigham Street, Brooklyn.
Dr. Gerald Silk, who practiced dentistry at 135 Essex Street, died Monday at Memorial Hospital. He was 33 years old and lived at 770 Ocean Parkway, Brooklyn.

PROMISE HER ANYTHING," a new roman tic comedy, in color with Leslie Caron and Warren Beatty, just about gets by and for two surprising reasons. One is Michael Bradley, 18 months old, surely one of the cutest little tykes in all of Engand.
Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary declared yesterday that he planned to permit policemen to belong to the John Birch Society if membership did not "impair their efficiency."
A student production of "Oklahoma!" in which Jud lives to marry, drink is taboo and brotherhood eclipses romance, is wowing audiences at an integrated Harlem school.
ALBANY, Feb. 22 A coalition of Republicans and Democrats killed an attempt in the Assembly today to limit the use of confessions in criminal trials.
BONN, Feb. 22 The Bonn Government has expressed its opposition to a merger agreement between two of West Germany's largest shipyards.
The National Steel Corporation, which ranks among the nation's top producers, announced yesterday it had elected a new chief executive officer and was planning to step up its expansion program.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Feb. 22 Boris I. Nicolaevsky, one of the world's leading experts and writers on the Russian Revolution, died yesterday in his home at nearby Menlo Park of a heart attack. He was 78 years old.

NOUAKCHOTT, Mauritania, Feb. 22 (Reuters)--President Moktar Ould Daddah dropped several of his Government ministers, including the Interior and Justice and the Foreign Affairs Ministers, in a Cabinet reshuffle announced today.

The first phase of the nationwide 20th annual drive for the Catholic Bishops Relief Fund will be opened today, Ash Wednesday, by a 10 minute radio message to Roman Catholic schoolchildren by Pope Paul VI.

SALT LAKE CITY, Feb. 22 The Federal Aviation Agency plans to reactivate a task force on airliner crash-worthiness, the agency's director of flight standards, George S. Moore, told a Civil Aeronautics Board hearing here today.

Eight New York City detectives and their former squad commander have been subpoenaed to testify before a Nassau County grand jury tomorrow on charges of brutality, Nassau District Attorney William Cahn said last night.

ALBANY, Feb. 22 Democratic and Republican leaders of the Legislature were reported tonight to have shied away from a proposal that the Legislature adopt a resolution supporting President Johnson's Vietnam policies.

CHICAGO, Feb. 22 Theodore C. Sorensen, former special counsel to President Kennedy, said tonight there were limits that clergymen should observe in their involvement in civil rights or in efforts to obtain peace in Vietnam or better treatment for the poor.

NEWARK, Feb. 22 Four VISTA volunteers who charge that their efforts at community organization have been blocked by local officials "eager to maintain the status quo" have refused transfers to other cities and have been dismissed from their Federally paid jobs.
MIAMI, Feb. 22 (AP) The Hialeah February sales ended tonight with the 188 horses sold during the month bringing $994,800.

MOSCOW, Feb. 22 The Soviet Communist party replied today to foreign criticism of the conviction of two Soviet writers last week. It said that the critics, including influential Western Communists, apparently did not understand the nature of the Soviet Union's "Socialist democracy."

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Feb. 22 Theodore Wachtell, founder and senior partner in Livingston, Wachtell Co., certified public accountants, 19 West 44th Street, New York, died today at University Hospital in the city. He was 77 years old and lived at 25 Vanderbilt Road here.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. Feb. 22 The southern portion of Florida's East Coast has an unusually dense concentration of baseball training camps and it is growing denser. Today, torrential rain and strong wind curtailed workouts throughout the area, but the reasons that bring so many clubs here remain sound.
Mayor Lindsay is about to try his hand at ridding the Times Square area of honkytonks, promenading perverts, bookstores featuring salacious materials and sex movies.

The St. Louis Hawks found out last night what the rest of the National Basketball Association teams have been finding out for the last month the New York Knickerbockers are the hottest club in the league.

In the Holy Family Roman Catholic Church yesterday, Miss Maureen Cecilia Baldwin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent Edward Baldwin of Breezy Point, Queens, was married to Robert Bruce Lambent of New York. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. James J. Lambert of Pittsfield, Mass.

Former City Councilman Paul O'Dwyer said yesterday that he would file a taxpayer's suit next week in an attempt to prevent construction of a children's animal farm in Prospect Park. The Abraham Straus department store has donated $90,000 toward the project.

An all-day study conference, entitled "Judaism and World Peace," heard pleas yesterday for a peace settlement in Vietnam, containment of aerial fighting there and a general decrease in the war effort.
MIAMI, Feb. 22--The ocean came close to winning everything here today in the first ocean powerboat race run under international rules.
HONG KONG, Feb. 22 A senior North Vietnamese general has asserted that a fullscale invasion of North Vietnam by the United States could be defeated, regardless of the size of the attacking force.
BIRMINGHAM, Feb. 22 Ninety Negro ministers marched in protest today to a supermarket where five Negroes were wounded by a white man last night.
TOKYO, Feb. 22 Chuzo Iwata, former Minister of Justice died today in his home at the age of 90.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 22--Horace Baker, the Negro who was subjected to neighborhood abuse when he moved into the previously all-white borough of Folcroft two years ago, was arrested in a 26-block chase here today.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York said yesterday it had loaned member banks in this district more than $24-billion last year twice the amount borrowed in 1964 and the highest total reported since 1957.
WNYC's 27th American Music Festival closed yesterday at Carnegie Hall with a concert, by the United States Army Band of Washington.

CALCUTTA, India., Feb. 22 (AP) Members of Opposition parties and the ruling Congress party battled today with steel rods and stools in the West Bengal Legislative Assembly. Two legislators were injured.

Dr. David H. Goldstein was elected president of the New York University School of Medicine Alumni Association yesterday at the organization's annual alumni day meeting at which the 125th anniversary of the school's founding was celebrated.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Wednesday, Feb. 23 A political crisis in Syria erupted into a coup d'etat today and the Damascus radio announced that Lieut. Gen. Amin el-Hafez had been overthrown as head of the Socialist state.

"The Great Adventure," the musical version of Arnold Bennett's novel and play, "Buried, Alive," has undergone two changes: S.N. Behrman will furnish the adaptation and the director will be Albert Marre. Mr. Behrman took over from the British adapters, Keith Waterhouse and Willis Hall, who found it impracticable to work on the show from their London base. Peter Wood bowed out as director.

SINGAPORE, Feb. 22 Jakarta was reported to be tense today amid indications that a showdown was nearing between forces loyal to President Sukarno of Indonesia and supporters of the ousted Defense Minister, Gen. Abdul Haris Nasution.
The Metropolitan Intercellegiate indoor track and field championships started yesterday with four events. To the surprise of no one, Manhattan College won them al.

THE biggest sectional tournament ever held in New York ended last night at the New York Hilton. Some 2,000 tables were in play during the five-day period and there seems to be no end to the expansion of duplicate bridge.
BRUSSELS, Feb. 22 Sabena Airlines said today that it was gradually replacing its piston planes and by 1970 would be carrying its passengers and cargo exclusively in jets.

TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 22 Dr. Ralph Roy Byrnes, past president of the American Dental Association and former dean of Atlanta-Southern Dental College died here Sunday in a nursing home. He was 86 years old.
Criminal activity on the waterfront is steadily declining, but the house-cleaning job is not complete and there remains a continuing need for surveillance and policing.
Earnings of the New York Telephone Company rose last year to $176,562,000, equal to $1.99 a share, from $168,967,000, or $2.00 a share on fewer shares in 1964, it was announced yesterday.
The New York State Council on the Arts will enter its sixth year with nearly 1,000 touring performances behind it and ahead of it a budget that may be twice as large as its initial one.

CHARLESTON, W.Va., Feb. 22(UPI) The socially prominent widow and the, stepdaughter of Justine Hardman, well-to-do victim of a bizarre death plot, were charged with murder and released under $10,000 bond each today.

LAST spring Jean Stafford went to Fort Worth, Tex., to interview Mrs. Marguerite Oswald. She wanted, she says, to get more of a feel of the background of Mrs. Oswald's son, Lee Harvey Oswald to somehow understand more profoundly what made Oswald an assassin. There may also have been an element of therapy in Miss.
GRAND JUNCTION, Tenn., Feb. 22 (AP) There were 23 coveys of quail moved today within a six-hour period at the national bird dog championships.
City College's basketball team rallied in the second half and defeated St. Francis College, 68-53, at the 69th Regiment Armory last night.
ST. LOUIS, Feb. 22 The General Board of the National Council of Churches voted 90 to 3 today for the admission of Communist China into the United Nations.
The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation announced yesterday the promotion of three officers to executive vice presidents.
PARIS, Feb. 22 President de Gaulle's challenge yesterday to the integrated structure of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization illustrates again the basic disagreements between Washington and Paris.

HIGHLAND FALLS, N.Y., Feb. 22 Martin J. Walsh, a 20-year-old member of the graduating class at West Point and son of New York City's chief of detectives, was killed late last night when his sports car missed a curve.
MOSCOW, Wednesday, Feb. 23 The Soviet Union launched two dogs into space yesterday in a project that may at some future time place dogs on or in orbit around the moon.

DAVOS, Switzerland, Feb. 22 (UPI) Emmerich Danzer of Austria, the European champion, took an early lead today in the world figure-skating championships. There are 103 skaters from 13 countries competing in the four gold medal events the men's, women's, pairs and ice dancing.

Miss Eda Lisbeth Marous, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Marcus of 40 East 84th Street, was married yesterday afternoon to Robert Jay Malenky of 155 East 84th Street, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Malenky of Woodside, Queens.
Retail sales of new cars by two large producers in the second 10-day period of February fell behind the year-earlier level, according to reports yesterday from Chrysler and Chevrolet.

TO view the camping display at the New York In- ternational Sport and Camping Show at the Coliseum is to get the impression that the most physical effort a camper has to make these days is to push a few levers or twist a few screw locks.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 Joseph W. Barr, Under Secretary of the Treasury, said today that Congress had demonstrated "amazing adaptability" in being able to handle tax legislation quickly, suggesting there was no longer a need for formal procedures to assure fast action.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 The German capture of a top-secret Allied plan for dividing and occupying defeated Germany helped stiffen Hitler's resistance and prolonged World War II, according to Cornelius Ryan, a writer and an editor for the Reader's Digest.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Feb. 22 The one-room schoolhouse preferred by Iowa's Old Order Amish received a new lease on life today.
NEW HAVEN, Feb. 22 Eleven American poets, including five Pulitzer Prize winners, will gather next Monday evening on the Yale campus to pay tribute to the late Randall Jarrell.

A. Arnold Vas Dias, New York correspondent of The Nieuwe, Rotterdamse Courant a newspaper of Rotterdam, the Netherlands, and a well-known journalist at the United Nations, died on Monday at Sarasota, Fla. He was 75 years old and lived at 1040 Park Avenue.
The 3,000-member Detectives Endowment Association pledged support yesterday to Detective John Heslin, who interrupted a Town Hall read-in Sunday protesting United States policy in Vietnam.
Francis I. duPont Co., the New York Stock Exchange member firm, joined yesterday the other major Wall Street firms that have begun to make their earnings data public.

ALBANY, Feb. 22 The Republican-controlled Senate passed a bill today that would give. Mayor Lindsay greater power to select members of New York City's Board of Education, even though the Mayor had not requested it.

CAIRO, Feb. 22 President Gamal Abdel Nasser denounced tonight the latest United States arms sale to Israel. He also charged that Washington and London had instigated the formation of a new conservative coalition in the Middle East to oppose Arab revolutionaries.
MILWAUKEE, Feb. 22 John A. McQiggan, producer of the Milwaukee Repertory Theater for the last three years, will not return next season, the theater announced today.

Mayor Lindsay has put the focus back where it ought to be in the synthetic row over "political interference" in the Police Department. The day-to-day responsibility for running the department rests with its new Commissioner, Howard R. Leary; but the ultimate responsibility rests with the Mayor just as it does for every other municipal agency. The department that enforces the city's laws cannot function as a law unto itself.

WESTBURY, L.I., Feb. 22 Bret Hanover, harness racing's horse of the year in 1964 and 1965, and that champion's only conqueror, Adios Vic, are among 15 standardbreds still eligible for the rich Realization Pace to be presented at Roosevelt Raceway on the night of May 28.

MIAMI, Feb. 22 (AP) Ken Harrelson of the Kansas City Athletics shot a 1-over-par 72 in the third round of the national baseball players golf tournament today and took a 12stroke lead with a 220 in a field of baseball dignitaries.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 22 (AP) Howard Clifton and James Crawl of the Keene Valley Bobsled Club captured the Diamond International Trophy for two-man bobsleds today with an average speed of more than 60 miles an hour.
Elementary and high school students across the country are to have new and broadened experience in the arts on a scale surpassing anything in American history.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 President Johnson's $3.3-billion Food for Freedom program will start tomorrow to run the gantlet of a critical House Agriculture Committee that is apparently bent on expanding rather than restricting United States food production.

THE pair of one-act plays by Tennessee Williams collectively called "Slapstick Tragedy," which opened last night at the Longacre, confirms that this brilliant talent is sleeping. Not dead (as the tombstones say and as we can hope), just sleeping.

Total American, Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of Compagnie Francaise des Petroles, Paris, has offered to purchase 300,000 shares of Leonard Refineries, Inc., representing about 25 per cent of the outstanding stock, at $17.15 a share.
ARTHUR THOLE started something. Two years ago, his antiques shop was pushed off the edge of Brooklyn Heights by the Cadman Plaza development.

SEOUL, South Korea, Wednesday, Feb. 23 Vice President Humphrey, buoyed by a belief that the Phillippines is about to send an engineering battalion to South Vietnam, arrived last night in South Korea, which is also about to increase its troop commitment.

A Federal judge said yesterday that opponents of civilian review boards seemed to be saying that constitutional limitations imposed on the police could be "lived with" as long as there was no one around to see that they were observed.
LONDON, Feb. 22 The Standard Poor's Corporation, in a European expansion move, is considering teaming up with a British computer research service used by investors.

ALBANY, Feb. 22 The Legislative Commission of the State Council of Churches, which represents about two million Protestants in New York, voted unanimous endorsement today of all but one provision of the pending bill to liberalize the state's divorce law.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 22 George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, asserted today that organized labor was prepared to "make our own way" politically, if the Democratic party did not support its legislative program.

LONDON, Feb. 22--A rare folio of landscape studies in water-color by Thomas Sully, the British-born American painter, was sold here today for the equivalent of $8,232. The 63 water-colors were begun by Sully in New York in 1814 at the age of 22.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 The key question in all the mystifying discussions between the Johnson Administration and Senator Robert Kennedy is: Who will be in charge in Saigon when the elections are held, if ever?
Groups representing, a wide range of interests are stirring opposition to Mayor Lindsay's new tax program, even before the program is announced.
LIBERAL, Kan., Feb. 22 (AP) The women of Liberal won today their annual pancake race with the women of Olney, England.
A real estate brokerage concern, the Harbison Harbison Company, Inc., has been formed by William J. Harbison 3d.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22--West Germany and Italy have made it clear that they do not regard a proposed nuclear planning committee as an acceptable alternative to creation of an allied nuclear force, State Department officials disclosed today.
ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 22 (AP) Unbeaten Sabre Mountain ran his victory string to five today when he won the $62,900 San Felipe Handicap at Santa Anita Park.
Library officials in the five boroughs have sent a letter to Mayor Lindsay asking that the libraries be exempted from his recent job-freeze order so services can be maintained.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Feb. 22 (AP) John Marshall of Greenwith, Conn., was declared the winner of the Enterprise Class yacht races for the North American championship today although bad weather forced cancellation of the final race.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 22 (AP) The death toll continues to rise in an influenza epidemic that has spread throughout California, closing schools and slowing business. Seven deaths related to the epiidemic have been reported.
The New York City Opera celebrated Washington's Birthday yesterday in its new home, the New York State Theater, with the most lavish opening night in its 22-year history.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Feb. 22 Matthew H. Kaplan, founder and chairman of Mallary, Inc., furniture retailers in the metropolitan area, died today of cancer in New Rochelle Hospital. He was 71 years old.
LONDON, Feb. 22 Britain will reduce her overseas forces by a third in the next four years but will continue to play a military role east of Suez.

Prof, and Mrs. Olof Tedin of Svalov, Sweden, have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Inga Gunnel Birgitta Tedin, to Cary Prescott Clark of Boston. He is the son of Judge George E. Clark of the Municipal Court of Lisbon, N.H., and Mrs. Clark.
Two jazz groups used a variety of percussive techniques to stir up and maintain a sustained sense of exilaration at Philharmonic Hall last night.

LONDON, Feb. 22--Another trans-Atlantic shipping dispute was threatened tonight as American shipowners and British insurers failed to come to terms on new insurance rates on cargo that are fixed by the London market.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 22 Dick Hutcher son of Keokuk, Iowa, and more recently of Charlotte, N.C., the center of the South's major sport automobile racing is now rated an equal choice with Richard Petty of Randleman, N.C., to win Sunday's 500-mile late model race here.
BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 22 George Meany threw his support today behind the plan of leading maritime unions to boycott vessels trading with North Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 The White House and Senator Robert F. Kennedy represented themselves as being in substantial accord today on some steps to be taken to achieve a peaceful settlement of the war in Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 The foundations of bipartisanship in the New York Congressional delegation, relatively new and never too sturdy, are being severely shaken by the stresses of election-year politics.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 22 George Meany announced today that the A.F.L-C.I.O. would spend $10,000 a year in each of the next three years to work with the National Urban League in preparing Negroes for union apprenticeship tests. The Urban League has received a $100,000 Ford Foundation grant for such a program.

The State Insurance Department has fined six fires and casualty insurance companies for issuing and delivering policies covering buildings at rates that differed from the department's standards and regulations.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 22 (UPI)--The Western Bancorporation reported today that its 1965 earnings and both the deposits and loans of its group of affiliiated banks showed an increase over last year's figure.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 22 Two young West Germans ana their camel were stalled on the YugoslavBulgarian frontier today pending issuance of a transit permit by a state veterinarian.

The country's producers of paper and paper products were warned yesterday that the present seller's market, in which customers are clamoring for supplies, could not last forever and that plans must be made for a new era.
One of the biggest clients of a small agency spends no money for its national advertising program.
Unilever, N.V., and Unilever, Ltd., which form one of the world's largest manufacturing enterprises, announced yesterday that sales and earnings in 1965 rose moderately from the levels of 1964.
In trying to do right by Scandinavia, Inger Wikstrom threw her second New York recital out of kilter last night and just managed to set things more or less right before the evening ended.
WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Feb. 22 The Army hockey team scored four first-period goals and went on to defeat Williams tonight, 7-3.

FAR HILLS, N.J., Feb. 22 Clarence V.S. Mitchell of this community, a partner in Penick, Gass Mitchell, lawyers, of 37 Wall Street, New York, died today at the Morristown Memorial Hospital. He was 75 years old.
AMHERST, Mass., Feb. 22 (AP) Lloyd Dove and Bob McIntyre supplied the scoring punch and cleared the boards tonight in leading St. John's to an 80-73 basketball victory over Massachusetts.
KAMPALA, Uganda, Feb. 22 Prime Minister Milton Obote announced today that he had assumed "all the powers of the Government of Uganda" and that he had arrested five members of his Cabinet.

AFTER 22 years, 115 productions, and goodness knows how many, performances, the New York City Opera moved into a new and glamorous home. Last night the company formally took possession of the New York State. Theater, unveiling in the process a dazzling production of a contemporary opera Alberto Ginastera's "Don Rodrigo."
James J. McFadden, the city's Acting Labor Commissioner, has notified Mayor Lindsay that he plans to resign next Monday.
TORRINGTON, Conn., Feb. 22 (AP) A bank robbery today believed to be the first in Torrington's history netted a masked bandit $18,000.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Feb. 22 (UPI) Seven white persons were stabbed, one possibly critically, by a group of Negroes who ran through a crowd of people leaving a high school basketball game tonight, the police said.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 One of the main sections of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 the provision pertaining to use of Federal funds to attack discrimination is not working nearly as well as many backers of the legislation had hoped.
The first-large-scale study of women cigarette smokers shows that their death rate from coronary heart disease and lung cancer is twice that of nonsmokers, it was reported yesterday.
The Grumman Aircraft Engineering Corporation, concerned heretofore with the mysteries of outer space, is now preparing to explore life below sea level.
SAIGON, Feb. 22 (Reuters) Nine United States Coast Guard patrol vessels arrived in South Vietnam today in a move to tighten checks on international shipping in and out of the country.

A nursing staff that encourages patients to pour out their troubles and face up to their emotional difficulties has drastically reduced the readmission rate at Montefiore Hospital, officials of the institution report.

BUFFALO, Feb. 22 Mr. and Mrs. Charles Wriggins Walker have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Dewees Walker, to James Hamilton Dolvin Jr. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Dolvin at Atlanta.

RABAT, Morocco, Feb, 22 King Hassan II reshuffled his Cabinet today but kept his Interior Minister, Brig. Gen. Mohammed Oufkir, accused by President de Gaulle yesterday of having engineered the kidnapping of Mehdi Ben Barka in Paris last October.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Feb. 22 The engagement of Miss Betsy Adler to Geoffrey P. Picket, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morway Picket of Scarsdale, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Adler.
ROANNE, France, Feb. 21 The annual remaking of the gastronomic map of France got under way here this weekend, a month early.
AUSTIN, Tex., Feb. 22 (UPI) A jury tonight found confessed strangler James C. Cross Jr. guilty of murdering a University of Texas coed, Susan Rigsby, and sentenced him to life imprisonment.

BUDAPEST, Feb. 22 (AP) Ten young Hungarians four of them accused of sedition, spreading "hostile propaganda," and other crimes will go on trial shortly, Nepszabadsag, the Communist party newspaper, reported today.

OTTAWA, Feb. 22 A move by Quebec to restrict support of McGill University, the large English-language educational institution in Montreal, has inflamed the ever-simmering English-vs.-French passions in Ottawa, the Canadian capital.

Sales promotions in New York's stores for Washington's Birthday received one of the strongest responses in years yesterday as a nip in the air and one of winter's sunnier days brought a heavy turnout of family shoppers.
John J. Scully, who retired in 1960 as a vice president of the Chase Manhattan Bank, died yesterday in Miami. He was 63 years old and resided in Red Bank, N.J.

The recent contest in the Seventeenth Congressional District between Theodore R. Kupferman and Orin Lehman underscored a serious omission in the New York State Election Law. That law fails no provide for absentee ballots in special elections, except for the handicapped and for members, of the armed forces.

The "Sammy Davis Jr. Show" will be discontinued by the Na tional Broadcasting Company television network in late April. So far there is no indication it will resume next fall and the chances are not considered good.

WASHINGTON, Feb, 22 The Administration is urging the Guatemalan Government, with no great hope of success, to conduct next month's presidential elections in a fashion that will remove any suspicion of fraud.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP) President Johnson has signed into law the bill that sets a single standard for judging the legality of bank mergers and limits the powers of the Justice Department to bring suits against such mergers.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Feb. 22 The launching of the nation's first unmanned Apollo spacecraft, scheduled for early tomorrow morning, was postponed tonight because of cloudy, uncertain weather here.
SAIGON, Feb. 22 Under the burning February sun in the cities and villages of South Vietnam, the people are resignedly talking about a long war.
Genaro Soto of Puerto Rico gained an eight-round split decision over Victor Baerga of Puerto Rico last night and nearly caused a riot at Sunnyside Garden, Queens.

Ronald B. Ramsey, who as "Granny Goose" tapes pacifist propaganda for the Hanoi radio, appeared briefly here yesterday after disappearing from California two weeks ago and said he would continue producing his broadcasts.
Mayor Willy Brandt of West Berlin said here yesterday that the outlook for a new pass agreement permitting West Berliness to visit relatives in East Berlin was very dim.
WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., Feb. 22 (UPI) Bob Leonard and Paul Crinkley scored key baskets in overtime tonight as the Wake Forest basketball team upset second-ranked Duke, 99-98.

After a week of bewildering fluctuations, the Democrats and Republicans are back in their familiar posture of deadlock over the question of reapportioning the New York State Legislature. The optimism both parties briefly held about agreeing on a compromise formula for drawing new Senate and Assembly district lines has once again evaporated. Today the extended time limit given them by the Court of Appeals expires.
THE Charles Bowdens' apartment is a stage setting where the curtain never falls.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (UPI) The White House, in what it described as a routine precaution, has been keeping tabs on the condition of a Secret Service agent who collapsed while on duty during President Johnson's visit to Atlantic City last week.

CORNWALL, N.Y., Feb. 22 The chief executives of seven Hudson River communities in Orange County united last night to fight what they understand to be Governor Rockefeller's plan to beautify the river valley.

To convince the traveling salesman that downtown motor hotels offer him more than motels on the outskirts, the Downtowner Corporation is using historical personages to represent its satisfied customers.
The London stock market was quiet yesterday as trading was influenced by election and budget uncertainties.
Special to The New York Times

KARACHI, Pakistan, Feb. 22 Signs of improving relations between the United States and Pakistan that grew out of the visit to Karachi last week by Vice President Humphrey appeared to have been largely dissipated by statements attributed to him after his departure.

The St. Regis, one of the dwindling number of elegant hotels in Manhattan, has been leased to the Sheraton Corporation of America under terms its owners believe will prevent the world-famous structure from being razed.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 22 The New York Mets today acquired Dick Stuart, his explosive bat and his erratic glove in a four-man trade with the Philadelphia Phillies.

MOSCOW, Feb. 22 The Government leaders of Britain and the Soviet Union recited differing assessments of world crises today and agreed to talk again tomorrow. Prime Minister Harold Wilson urged the convening of a conference to reach a political settlement

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Feb. 22--About 100 angry residents of Malverne picketed Nassau County's Republican headquarters today seeking support for their efforts to block integration of Malverne's elementary schools.

Economic forecasters have been making sharp upward revisions in their predictions for business activity in 1966 even though the ink has not dried on their original prophecies. Their new prophecies envision a rapid rate of climb and much higher prices than they had expected earlier.

BLOEMFONTEIN, South Africa, Feb. 22 (AP) Jack Nicklaus, the bulky golfer from Columbus, Ohio, lost control of his putter today and posted a 75 while Gary Player of South Africa carded a 1-under-par 70 in the second match of their South African series.

The Erie-Lackawanna Railroad announced yesterday that the contingent interest "which became owing on Dec. 31, 1965" on six bond issues of the former Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad would not be paid this year. It explained this was "on account of the necessity of conserving cash for other purposes."
A new international guest will soon be checking in at the waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

MIAMI, Feb. 22--Buckpasser, Ogden Phipps's champion 2-year-old of 1965, will compete in the Everglades Stakes at Hialeah tomorrow, and his toughest opposition is expected to come from his own entrymate, Stupendous of the Wheatley Stable. This pair, trained by Eddie Neloy, will be the 2-to-5 choice against seven other colts in the 1 1/8-mile event.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP) The Rev. Dr. Bernard Braskamp, chaplain of the House of Representatives since 1950, died at his home today of a stroke. He was 79 years old.
SAIGON, Feb. 22 South Vietnamese troops kiled 186 Vietcong guerrillas in four separate actions yesterday, a Government military spokesman said tonight.

CHICAGO, Feb. 22 (AP) The American Bar Association's standing committee on Federal judiciary expressed both pleasure and "sincere disappointment" today with President Johnson's selections for 57 appointments to the Federal bench.
John S. (Bud). Palmer, sports commentator and former Princeton All-American basketball player, was named Commissioner of the Department of Public Events yesterday by Mayor Lindsay.

International poker has rarely known a more skilled player than Charles de Gaulle. When the general sat down at the table for the second time in 1958 he held few high cards and his credit was limited. Now, after almost eight years of gambling on France's account, he has more than $5 billion in chips and experts are studying his technique.

LONDON, Feb. 22 When the going gets rough, as it is now with navy resignations and stepped-up Tory attacks against Britain's defense policy, Defense Minister Denis Winston Healey is fond of recalling these words of the late Hugh Gaitskell:

Buildings Commissioner Charles G. Moerdler said last night that starting today complaints against multiple dwellings operated by city agencies would be processed in the same way as complaints against privately owned properties. That is, all but the final action.

FEW things whet the fashion appetite as much as scarcity, especially when the commodity in question is fine Russian ermine, described by Emeric Partos, Bergdorf Goodman's fur designer, as "the most romantic of furs."
KAMPALA, Uganda, Feb. 23 (AP) Archbishop Joseph Kiwanuka of Uganda, Africa's senior Roman Catholic bishop, died here last night. He was 67 years old.
The Carrier Corporation achieved record sales and earnings in the first fiscal quarter, ended Jan. 31, William Bynum, chairman, told shareholders at the annual meeting yesterday in Syracuse.

The New York Rangers, on the sparkling maneuvers of Cesar Maniago in the goal, downed the Detroit Red Wings, 5-0, in a National Hockey League game last night in Madison Square Garden before 11,727 fans.

IT would be difficult to find any resemblance between the dangling volutes that Marguerite Stix has designed to be used as earrings and the shell jewelry sold as souvenirs in resorts in every corner of the globe.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 23 Three hundred pro-Government demonstrators broke into the grounds of the United States Embassy here today and ripped down the American flag before they were dispersed, by policemen firing into the air.
Deputy Mayor Timothy W. Costello said last night that he hoped the city's lagging Head Start centers would get into operation next week at the rate of "several a day."

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Feb. 23 Mr. and Mrs. George Warren Knapp have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Jane Knapp, to Charles Henry Herz. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Herz of Bethesda, Md.
Earnings of International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., climbed to a record of $4.85 a share from $4.59 in 1964, the company reported yesterday.

BETHEL PARK, Pa., Feb. 23 The engagement of Miss Linda Price Addington, daughter of Brig. Gen. Jerry S. Addington, commander of the 31st Artillery Brigade near Pittsburgh, and Mrs. Addington, to Robert John Stewart, son of Mr. and Mrs. John L. Stewart of New York, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents.

MINEOLA, L.I., Thursday, Feb. 21 A 20-year-old youth, said to have been reprimanded by the owner of the Mineola Hotel for his unkempt appearance, was charged early today with setting a fire yesterday that destroyed the hotel and killed one person and injured seven.

The Allied Products Corporation caused a flurry in the stock market yesterday when it announced that directors had authorized the creation of a new class of preferred stock "to facilitate possible future acquisitions."
The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday it had increased minimum capital requirements for specialists, effective March 1.
The Ford Foundation announced three grants yesterday totaling $2.2-million for more research to cope with rapid urbanization in the United States and abroad.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Feb. 23 David Moss, former president of the Industrial Engineering Company, a New York construction concern, died today at North-Shore Hospital, Manhasset. His age was 62 and his home was at 70 Longfellow Road.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 Every once in a while the advertising industry comes forth with a campaign that drives the reasoning man to unreasoning fury. In recent years innumerable campaigns like this have been built on the plea for the public to "move up."
MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 23 Milton G. Lipson, Nassau County Commissioner of Accounts, has resigned effective March 1 to become director of security for the American Express Company.

The Communist Party, U.S.A., made public yesterday a 128page "new program" for leftwing unity on a path toward socialism by majority vote, and said its first national convention since 1959 would be held here June 22 to 26.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 The Administration's tax bill encountered unexpectedly strong opposition in the House today but was passed, 246 to 146, and sent to the Senate.
MOSCOW, Thursday, Feb. 24 An envoy of North Vietnam has promised the British to clarify some of Hanoi's conditions for a Vietnam peace conference, qualified sources reported early today.

St. John's University, which has won four National Invitation Tournaments, was one of five basketball teams to accept bids yesterday to the 29th annual N.I.T. at Madison Square Garden next month. The others are De Paul, Boston College, Penn State and Virginia Polytechnic Institute.
LONDON, Feb. 23 The Dowager Countess of Suffolk and Berkshire, also well known as Mimi Crawford, the musical comedy actress, died yesterday at the age of 61.

The 1966 Belmont Ball will be held at the Waldorf-Astoria on June 1. Mrs. Elizabeth N. Graham (Elizabeth Arden) is chairman for the dinner dance, traditionally given during the week of the Belmont Stakes. The 98th running of the event will be on June 4 at Aqueduct Race Track.

THE proper marriage of wine and food is a serious business, Michel Dreyfus said recently as he tasted a vintage Pommard. And when the gentleman makes a statement like that, people listen with a serious ear.

A utility bond yielding 5.13 per cent the highest yield ever placed on a high-rated corporate issue with call protection was put on the market yesterday. By late afternoon, it was estimated to have been half spoken for.

A group of well-known theatrical performers will appear in a benefit show for Channel 13 to be staged in a theater before a paying audience. The show will be taped for presentation the next evening by the educational station. WNDT.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 Richard M. Nixon is moving a couple of blocks closer to the White House.

OROVILLE, Calif., Feb. 23 Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Felipe have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Jo Felipe, to Thomas Anthony Russo, son of Lucio Russo, a New York State Assemblyman, and Mrs. Russo of Dongan Hills, Staten Island, New York.

SPRING LAKE, N.J., Feb. 23 (AP) Daniel A. Bolich, a former assistant United States tax commissioner, died early today at his home at 209 Morris Avenue. He was 66 Years old.

The Texas Gulf Sulphur Company announced here yesterday the election of Donald B. Smiley as a director.

Walter Susskind brought a British program to the Manhattan School of Music last night. The affable British conductor prefaced his performances with casual remarks, and the Manhattan Orchestra played like young professionals.

Mrs. August Belmont has given $500,000 to the endowment fund of the Metropolitan Opera, it was announced yesterday. The income from the gift will underwrite the annual student matinees given under the sponsorship of the Metropolitan Opera Guild.
Albert Schweitzer said: "Man has lost the capacity to foresee and to forestall. He will end by destroying the earth."

The Court of Appeals has finally accepted responsibility for reapportioning the New York State Legislature, as the courts in half a dozen other states had already done when their Legislatures proved unable or unwilling to carry out what is clearly a legislative function. It had become abundantly evident that the deadlock between the Republican Senate and the Democratic Assembly could not be broken by further delay.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (UPI) The police chief of Mount Dora, Fla., said today he did not know whether the "Dunkers Club," of which he was president, was a front for a local Ku Klux Klan group.

The way was cleared yesterday for the return of the classification system of harness racing when the pacers and trotters switch from Roosevelt Raceway in Westbury, L.I., to Yonkers Raceway in Westchester County March 4.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Feb. 23 The "first major break" in the investigation of a 12-year string of racial bombings was announced today by Jefferson County Sheriff Mel Bailey.
Women trainers have been licensed by The Jockey Club in the United States since 1935. In that year the first license went to Mary Hirsch, daughter of he famous trainer of thoroughbreds, Max Hirsch.
Albert Philip Cohen, a wellknown stamp collector, of 137 East 28th Street, died Tuesday at Bellevue Hospital. He was 55 years old.
Mrs. Sandra Canning Walker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Brown Canning of Oyster Bay, L.I., was married yesterday to Richard L. Feigen of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur P. Feigen of Chicago.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23--The yield on the Government's regular monthly series of one-year bills approached the 5 per cent mark in today's auction, reaching the highest rate recorded for these securities since the Treasury began offering them in August, 1963.
ROME, Feb. 23 Premier-designate Aldo Moro presented his four-party coalition cabinet to President Giuseppe, Saragat today after 33 days of wrangling and compromise.
Columbia University's School of International Affairs will have a new home early in 1968, the university announced yesterday.

AUSTIN, Tex., Feb. 23 Justice Hugo L. Black ruled today in Washington to allow a courtordered suspension of the Texas poll tax to stand, a decision that could have a decisive effect on Texas elections this year.

Mrs. Cecelia Holloway Cabaniss Saunders, former executive director of the Upper Manhattan branch of the Young Women's Christian Association, died yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital. She was 86 years old and lived at 80 La Salle Street.

HOUSTON, Feb. 23 Mr. and Mrs. Herman E. Detering have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Deborah Inez Detering, to William P. Pannill, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fitzhugh Hastings Pannill of Midland.
Dr. George Francis Hoch, a urologist at 115 East 61st Street, died on Tuesday at St. Luke's Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived at 1901 Dorchester Road, Brooklyn.
A Federal jury heard charges yesterday that the Government had conspired with "the worst elements in society" to "destroy" a woman lawyer.
Three Margo Jones Memorial Awards, given annually to encourage the production of new plays, were distributed yesterday by Mayor Lindsay at City Hall.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Feb. 23 Heavy winds and driving rain battered the launching area of the nation's first Apollo spacecraft today. The launching, originally scheduled today, has been tentatively reset for Friday.

NEW HAVEN, Feb. 23 John M. Martinez, a retired chemical engineer, died yesterday at the Hospital of St. Raphael here. He was 73 years old and lived at 403 Whitney Avenue.

Dr. J. Andrew Simmons, executive director of the Hillcrest Center for Children in Bedford Hills, N.Y., a private institution financed by New York City, died yesterday at Roosevelt Hospital. His age was 62.

The Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee (S.N.C.C.) will hold its annual fund-raising dinner on March 20 at the New York Hilton.

Three news items from different parts of the world influenced futures prices of three commodities yesterday. From London there was a rumor of a minimum fixed price for world sugar. Ghana announced a weekly purcase figure that disappointed some cocoa futures traders.

In his message on conservation yesterday, President Johnson put forward an excellent program to combat water pollution, on which we will comment later, and he reaffirmed his support for several desirable bills now pending for national parks and seashores.
A program involving the construction of 22 shopping centers in 11 states during the next two years has been announced by Frank Properties, Inc., real estate development concern.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, Feb. 23 Testimony by the flight engineer of a Boeing 727 jetliner that crashed here last Nov. 11 indicated today that the pilot sought a final burst of power to check a steep descent only seven or eight seconds before the crash.

The New York State Legislature continues to shirk its moral obligation to raise the minimum age for purchase of liquor from eighteen to twenty-one. A new proposal to raise it to nineteen, and a half, speedily rejected by Connecticut and New Jersey, is the most devious yet.
Election uncertainties and further evidence of declining profit margins sent prices slightly downward on the London Stock Exchange yesterday.

President Johnson read a letter last from the father of an American soldier killed in Vietnam.

Alfred P. Sloan Jr., the industrialist who built the General Motors Corporation into one of the world's greatest manufacturing enterprises, bequeathed $20-million of his vast fortune to cancer research and $10-million to the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

Salvador Dali reigned over a performance last night at Philharmonic Hall. It was billed as "a super gelatinous melting, Silly Putty Happening." But a Happening, Dali-style, is hardly the low-budget affair produced by artists in lofts and outdoor parking lots. It turned out to be a melange of Metro-GoldwynMayer spectacular and slickly packaged Bohemian cliche.
