Governor Rockefeller declared "an all-out war on crime and narcotics addiction" yesterday and announced a program under which addicts would be sentenced to hospital confinement for treatment and rehabilitation for a maximum period of three years.

One of three men charged with the murder of Malcolm X told a Supreme Court jury yesterday that he could not have shot the former Black Muslim to death, because "the only thing I had in my hands was my hat."

FLAGSTAFF, Ariz., Feb. 23 (UPI) The body of a man believed to be John G. Dorsey, a prominent Minneapolis lawyer who disappeared after he was charged with income tax evasion, was found today in a snowy field near Flagstaff. He had apparently shot himself in the head.
HAMILTON, N.Y., Feb. 23 Cornell scored three goals in the final period tonight and defeated Colgate's hockey team, 5-2.
ALBANY, Feb. 23 The Court of Appeals took over the reapportionment of the Legislature today and appointed a five-man judicial commission to complete the job by March 14.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 President Johnson called upon Congress today to provide a "sane," clean and enjoyable environment for the people of America.

The heart of President Johnson's message on conservation is his program on water resources. At last, the nation appears to be moving toward an effective confrontation with the urgent problem of polluted water.

DAVOS, Switzerland, Feb. 23 (AP) Emmerich Danzer of Austria virtually clinched the men's title at the world figure skating championships today, dashing the hopes of Scott Ethan Allen of Smoke Rise, N.J.
TEANECK, N.J., Feb 23 This township's $6.14-million budget was rejected for the second time tonight by the narrowest margin in memory.

LONDONDERRY, Vt., Feb. 23 The skies were blue, the temperature was above freezing and the slopes at Magic Mountain were in fine condition today, but the base lodge's balcony, with its gingerbread decor, proved as popular as the slope. Skiers kept taking breaks for a bit of suntanning.
The Cunard Line freighter Parthia sent out a call for assistance yesterday morning after she lost her rudder in the Atlantic about 400 miles east of Cape Race, Nfld.

A person injured by a hit-run driver or an uninsured and financially irresponsible motorist would have little chance of collecting any money unless he lived in the right state or had bought his protection.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 23 Wes Westrum sat in the sunshine in Casey Stengel's old chair today and greeted the first New York Met players to arrive for spring training.
Don Kalinowski scored on a desperation jump shot an instant before the final buzzer and gave Loyola of New Orleans a 51-50 victory over the Fordham basketball team at Fordham's gymnasium last night.
LONDON, Feb. 23 The Bristol Old Vic theater company will make its first tour of the United States early next year in connection with the commemoration of its 200th anniversary.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 23 Three maritime union leaders asserted today that a boycott against ships trading with North Vietnam could begin at any time. But they said they still were developing strategy for the boycott, and that they intended to keep it a secret.

THE Interlochen Arts Academy Orchestra did not spare itself in its concert in Carnegie Hall last night. The 104-piece teen-age ensemble tackled Mozart's "Linz" Symphony, calculated to show up any flaws in precision; Kodaly's virtuosic Concerto for Orchestra; Berlioz's "Ro-...
Jams J. O'Leary, director of economic research for the Life Insurance Association of America, made yesterday one of the sharpest attacks yet on the economic policies of the Johnson Administration.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman urged Congress today to approve President Johnson's $3.3-billion "Food for Freedom" program and promised that if successful it would save more lives than had been lost in all the wars in human history.

Max Pollikoff opened the first concert in his 10th Music in Our Time series last night at the Kaufmann Auditorium of the 92d Street "Y" by pointing out to the audience that new music has come a long way since the series started.
The American Stock Exchanges reported yesterday the changes carried below in the shareholdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of listed companies.
A two-for-one split of the common shares of the American Seating Company was proposed here yesterday by its directors.

A meet-record pole vault of 13 feet 7 inches by Greg Farah of New York University highlighted the field events of the metropolitan intercollegiate freshman indoor track and field championships yesterday at Ohio Field on the Violet's uptown campus.

The Ivy League and the National Collegiate Athletic Association came to an agreement yesterday that ended their dispute over the N.C.A.A. "academic floor" rule and made it possible for the Ivy basketball champion to compete in the N.C.A.A. championship tournament next month.

MOST of the winners of the major championships in the George Washington Birthday tournament of the Greater New York Bridge Association that ended Tuesday were young players and many of them are recent university graduates.

Auto sales of the General Motors Corporation in the Feb. 11 to 20 period fell to 105,304 units from 137,265 units in the comparable period of 1965. Sales of all five divisions of the company slipped below last year's figures.

The death of Sharon Lewis, 22-year-old actress, was apparently caused by a combination of alcohol, caffeine and amphetamine (a pep pill), Chief Medical Examiner Milton Helpern reported yesterday. He said the finding in an autopsy was tentative.
The spot rate on the British pound continued a weakening trend yesterday, slipping 11 points below the Monday level, to $2.8007 on foreign exchange markets here.
Charles (Ruby) Stein, reputedly the most notorious loan shark in the metropolitan area, was sentenced yesterday by Federal Judge Edward Weinfeld to four years in prison and fined $30,000.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 The Supreme Court today declared unconstitutional a New York law that allows mentally ill prisoners to be retained, without a jury trial, in a prison menthal institution after their terms have expired.
Mayor Lindsay will sponsor both a personal and a business income tax as the keystones of his program to overcome the city's financial difficulties.

THE Grand Slam Tournament of the Metropolitan Bridge Unit the New York affiliate of the American Bridge Association that caters primarily to Negro players begins today at the SheratonAtlantic Hotel. The schedule is: today, Mixed Pairs, 8 P.M.; tomorrow, Open Pairs, 1 P.M. and 7 P.M.; Sunday, Open Teams, 2 sessions, 11 A.M.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 24 Troops used bayonets and fired warning shots in the air to stop hundreds of students demonstrating against the new Indonesian Cabinet from storming President Sukarno's palace here today.
BOSTON, Feb. 24 (AP) The Boston Celtics crushed the St. Louis Hawks, 134-106, today to increase their lead in the National Basketball Association's Eastern Division race to 2 games.

The Ivy League confirmed yesterday that it had settled for the time being a dispute with the National Collegiate Athletic Association. But it insisted it had not capitulated, and it indicated that the N.C.A.A. had done the capitulating.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Feb. 24 Although his team's campus is 100 miles to the south, tomorrow will be Homecoming Day for Dave Rikert of Williams as the Middlebury College Carnival provides this quiet Green Mountain community with its annual hoopla.
A major international freight-rate war has been averted by the decision of British underwriters to abandon plans to charge penalty premiums on cargoes carried on all ships more than 20 years old.
MOSCOW, Feb. 24 Modern art, which is anathema to the official Soviet doctrine of socialist realism, has won an important new showing among the intellectual and scientific elite here.
For the fifth straight year the Zenith Radio Corporation achieved record sales and earnings. Joseph S. Wright, president, reported yesterday.

Commissioner Charles G. Moerdler, who wants to have instant communication with his Buildings Department when he is at scenes of building emergencies, is having a telephone installed in his official car.

Union Carbide Corporation announced yesterday that it planned to construct a polyethylene plant at its chemicals and plastics complex at Taft, La., that will increase the company's annual capacity by 500million pounds to 1.25 billion pounds.

It has been obvious for years that a Britain largely bereft of empire was carrying heavier global burdens than its hard-pressed economy and balance of payments position could sustain. The Labor Government has now taken difficult decisions aimed at bringing defense costs under control and gradually scaling down overseas commitments.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Feb. 24 The president of the Morristown Young Republican Club has decided to become a Democrat, he said, because of the failure of the guards to investigate evidence of racist antisecurity activity.

A private employment agency was retained and newspaper "want ads" used to recruit several secretaries for the city's new Transportation Administration, but top city officials disclaimed knowledge yesterday of how it had all come about.
The American Stock Exchange took one of its worst beatings in weeks yesterday as the market lost ground for the third consecutive session.

William A. Titus, a general partner in Wertheim Co., investments, 1 Chase Manhattan Plaza, and a well-known member of the financial community, died yesterday in his home, 190 East 72d Street. He was 63 years old.

Sean Connery, the screen's Secret Agent 007, will make his debut as a director with "The Secret of the World." He will not appear in the "modern tragedy," written by Ted Allan, author of "Oh What a Lovely War."
MOSCOW, Feb. 24 (Reuters) The Soviet Army newspaper Red Star today announced the death on duty of Lieut. Gen. Stepan D. Dorokhov, a leading artillery commander.
LAGOS, Nigeria, Feb. 24--Ghana's army was in control of Accra today after a morning coup d'etat ousted President Kwame Nkrumah while he was traveling abroad.
Prices on the London stock exchange continued to drift downward yesterday.
Two ambitious conservation projects for New York Harbor were begun yesterday by the Secretary of the Interior, Stewart L. Udall.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) The House Judiciary Committee named a special three-man subcommittee today to look into a controversy involving three Federal judges in Oklahoma.
They hailed him as "Osagyefo," signifying "Redeemer." Sometimes he was even called "His Messianic Majesty."

A final legislative hearing on divorce reform is to be held in this city today. After the views expressed there have been studied, no further excuse will exist for failure to bring the matter out of committee for open discussion and action on the floor of the State Legislature.
Blue Cross, Blue Shield announced yesterday a new policy that will complement Medicare at substantial savings for 600,000 local subscribers 65 and more years old.
LONDON, Feb. 24 (UPI) The military coup that ousted Ghana's dictatorial President, Kwame Nkrumah, today was triggered from a chintz-curtained office in London's fashionable West Cromwell Road.
Farm organizations and trade journals have been urging farmers since last fall to hold their grains and soybeans off the market to get higher prices.

LONDON, Feb. 3 There is a crisis in Belgravia. Residents of this swank area of central London where peers, nannies and chauffeured Bentleys are counted by the score are up in arms over plans to dot the sidewalks with parking meters.
The Rev. Gommar A. De Pauw, the embattled leader of the Catholic Traditionalist Movement, was refused permission yesterday to say mass at the parish church of the University of Notre Dame.

QUEBEC, Feb. 24 (Canadian Press) A funeral mass was sung today in the Basilica of Quebec by Maurice Cardinal Roy, Archbishop of Quebec and Roman Catholic Primate of Canada, for Paul Comtois, Lieutenant Governor of the Province of Quebec, who was killed Monday night in a fire that destroyed his official residence.
Leonard Bernstein, music director of the New York Philharmonic, is scheduled to leave for Europe today to conduct in Vienna and London.

LONDON, Feb. 24 Britain is going to increase her subsidy of the arts by about one-third, to 6,070,000 ($16,996,000).

The Air Line Pilots Association charged yesterday that a recent international ruling narrowing the flight corridors over the North Atlantic had endangered the flying public because of the "increased risk of midair collisions."

NEWARK, Feb. 24 The Prudential Insurance Company, the world's second largest life insurance concern, announced today the achievement of new sales and asset-growth records in 1965, its 90th year in business.
LONDON, Feb. 24 The Conservative party took a stand on Rhodesia tonight that signaled an end of the tenuous bipartisan approach to the rebellious colony.

With so much that is basically right about his playing, it was surprising last night that David Bean's piano recital at Carnegie Hall was so unexcit ing. Certainly Mr. Bean's instincts were keen and his technical flash was dazzling. But there was a lack of personal flair, of rapt involvement that kept the music from pulling the listener in, much less overpowering him.

THE West branch of the Ausable River, one of New York State's better streams, is deep under the snow and ice that has piled up in the Adirondacks. But its values and merits are being promoted at the New York International Sports and Camping Show at the Coliseum.
HOUSTON, Feb. 24 (AP) A Federal judge gave the Braves a temporary home today, ordering them to play their 1966 home games in Atlanta.

New York University put a serious crimp in Manhattan's hopes for a bid to the National Invitation Tournament by turning back the Jaspers, 59-53, in Madison Square Garden last night.
Jean and Kenneth Wentworth made their formal debut here as a four-hand piano team at Carnegie Recital Hall last night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (UPI) Constantine Brown, a nationally syndicated newspaper columnist for nearly a quarter of a century, died last night at the age of 76. He suffered a heart attack while he and his wife were playing cards at the home of friends.

PATERSON, N.J., Feb. 24 Theodore H. Boss, president and a director of American Aniline Products, Inc., manufacturers of dyestuffs and chemicals, with headquarters at 25 McLean Boulevard here, died of a heart attack Tuesday in Manchester, England, where he had gone on business. He was 61 years old and lived at 59 Elm Place, Nutley.
MIAMI, Feb. 24 Miss Martha Penny Schatt and Charles Michael Abbott plan to marry in June.
SAIGON, Friday, Feb. 25 Several hundred Vietcong guerrillas attacked an encampment of Australian and American troops before dawn yesterday on a rubber plantation 30 miles north of Saigon.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 24 Mrs. Christine Leland Hires, widow of Harrison S. Hires, died yesterday. She was 77 years old and lived in Haverford.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 The Federal Aviation Agency will hire an architectural engineering firm in about a month to plan a new terminal for National Airport.
MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 24 A defendant in a murder case whose conviction was upset by the State Court of Appeals was found guilty last night after retrial in the Nassau County Court.

Dr. and Mrs. Daniel Catlin of New York and Islip, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Doris Catlin, to Douglas Thomas Yates Jr. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Yates, also of New York and Islip.

The Brill Building, a 10-story office building with a penthouse at the northeast corner of Broadway and 49th Street, has been sold ny the Ruspyn Corporation to an investing client of Milbank Tweed Hadley McCloy, lawyers, for $1.85 million.
Corporations continue to come to the long-term capital market in increasing numbers. Yesterday, four major companies disclosed plans to sell $320-million of bonds.

A major reorganization of overseas operations was announced yesterday by the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey). The plan calls for the transfer of much of the control for the company's foreign operations to four regional organizations.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24(UPI) The Supreme Court ruled today that an employer could not claim exemption from the minimum wage and overtime laws solely because his business was recognized in its industry as a retail operation.

City Council President Frank D. O'Connor, considered to be well in the lead in maneuvering for the Democratic nomination for Governor, caustically assailed Governor Rockefeller's economic program yesterday.

CHICAGO, Feb. 24 The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and his civil rights groups today ran into a hornets' nest of opposition for their assumption of control of a West Side slum building without authorization from the owner or a court.

The Rand Daily Mail, Johannesburg's English-language morning newspaper, which has been fighting South Africa's racial policies and denouncing reported brutality in that country's jails, will receive the World Press Achievement Award for 1966.
CHICAGO, Feb. 24 (UPI)--Dr. Stevan Durovic, developer of Krebiozen, was charged today with evading $200,000 in income taxes for the year 1960.

Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Inc., the film producer, said yesterday that with the exception of "a very special opportunity" such as its film "Doctor Zhivago" the company does not intend to invest more than $6million in any motion picture.
The Holland-America Line announced yesterday the appointment of Laurens J. Platteel as manager of its new container division.
An air mail stamp with an upside-down airplane sold for a record price of $18,000 last night in a $285,920 auction that was said to be a record for a single auction sale of postage stamps.

PLEASANTVILL,E N.Y., Feb. 24 A private engineering report released here today accused Federal and state engineers of a $16,105,280 blunder in estimating the cost of Interstate Highway 87 and collateral roads through Bedford and North Castle estates.

WESTBURY, L.I., Feb. 24 Snowflakes the size of 50-cent pieces, an 18 mile-an-hour northeast wind with 30-mile gusts, slippery roads and other handicaps did not deter 9,155 harness racing fanatics from completing their, horseplaying rounds at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. It was easily the slimmest turnout of the meeting.

Montserrat Caballe, Hilde Gueden, Christa Ludwig and Roberta Peters will be among the singers in concert performances of "Der Rosenkavalier" and "Die Fledermaus" at the Saratoga Performing Arts Center next summer.

MIAMI, Feb. 24 A triple by Bob Ussery, including a victory in the feature, entertained the 17,173 customers at Hialeah today. Careless Juror, running in the colors of Mrs. Clark Hartwick, took the main event in an exciting finish against Tulip Tree.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Feb. 24 A committee of leading Negro ministers, stirred by the recent shooting of five Negroes, announced plans today for a citywide boycott of white merchants.
Governor Rockefeller will propose low-cost state loans to help modernize New York City's rundown hospitals, sources close to the Governor said yesterday.
The golf pro to the Presidents says Lyndon B. Johnson doesn't have the zest for the game that marked his predecessors, Dwight D. Eisenhower and the late John F. Kennedy.

Dr. Conor Cruise O'Brien, a former Irish diplomat and United Nations official who served until July as vice chancellor of the University of Ghana, attributed the coup d' tat in Ghana yesterday to the exhaustion of patience of an impoverished people with the conspicuous waste and extravagance of a corrupt and bungling Government.

Mrs. Jean Wise May was given an 85th birthday luncheon yesterday by the National Federation of Temple Sisterhoods. About 150 women attended the fete in the organization's headquarters at Union House of Living Judaism-Berg Memorial, 838 Fifth Avenue.

The design unveiled yesterday for Ellis Island by the Department of the Interior is a creative, imaginative response to the problem of making a national landmark and shrine out of 27.5 weedy acres that have neither grace nor grandeur, but were the point of entry to a new world for 16 million immigrants.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 24 Weather, mostly wet, is a threat to what otherwise might be the most successful weekend in the history of Daytona International Speedway. Most of the grandstand seats for the Friday, Saturday and Sunday races have been sold. Only a few hundred of the 48,000 places in the seven-section stand are left for Sunday's grand finale, the eighth annual 500-mile late-model race.

CAIRO, Feb. 24 Saudi Arabia is pursuing further peace negotiations with the United Arab Republic on Yemen, ignoring for the time being President Gamal Abdel Nasser's personal attack on King Faisal two nights ago, diplomatic sources reported today.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 24 The general board of the National Council of Churches created today a new Advisory Committee on Peace, authorized to work closely with secular agencies, as well as with Roman Catholic, Jewish and other religious groups.
Philip Morris, Inc., the cigarette producer, announced here yesterday the appointment of Fred M. Stefan to the new post of vice president for industrial products.

A case of kwashiorkor a protein deficientcy disease that is one of the leading childhood killers in underdeveloped countries has been diagnosed and treated in a 10-month-old Bronx boy by two pediatricians at Montefiore Hospital.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 The Justice Department urged the Supreme Court today not to rule out interrogations of criminal suspects by extending the right of counsel into police stations.

THE entire program of the New York Philharmonic last night was devoted to Mendelssohn's "Elijah," an oratorio that does not turn up very often these days. A hundred years or so ago it was an article of faith that "Elijah " ranked with the Bach passions and the Handel oratorios. Those were the great days of Mendelssohn worship.
KANSAS CITY, Feb. 24 (AP) Alvin Dark, manager of the Kansas City Athletics, drew the first "penalty" of the baseball season today.
The election of Herbert L. Hodgets as a senior vice president of the Federal Insurance Company was announced here yesterday.

DON'T think it hasn't been fun but, in the succinct words of Beatrice Lillie, it hasn't, at least not all of it. To see all the Broadway musicals in one week--all the surviving Broadway musicals that is and nearly in one week--is clearly one of the labors Hercules ducked. It is easy to see why.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 24 (UPI) Admiral of the Fleet Chester W. Nimitz, who was retired only by death from the Navy he loved, was buried today alongside many of the men he led to victory in the Pacific in World War II.
DETROIT, Feb. 24 (AP) Auto production in United States plants dropped to 194,067 units this week as American Motors closed its assembly lines for 10 working days to get inventory in line with sales.
The Studebaker Corporation took the unusual step yesterday of issuing a forecast of its 1966 earnings.
SAIGON, Feb. 24 A broad new intelligence operation is producing the first sustained flow of information about Vietcong military and political activity.
The spot rate on the British pound recovered most of the preceding day's loss here yesterday, rising 10 points at the close to $2.8017 in moderate trading on foreign exchange markets.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 24 Mickey Mantle will report to training camp on Tuesday, with the rest of the squad, instead of four days late, the New York Yankees learned today.

Policemen from the 24th Precinct took 37 sixth-graders from a West Side parochial school on a tour of some of the city's points of interest yesterday in an effort to show them that "cops have hearts as well as nightsticks."
ALBANY, Feb. 24 Mayor Lindsay's tax proposals face rough going in the divided Legislature, but they could receive grudging approval, key legislators said tonight.

COHASSET, Mass., Feb. 24 Miss Constance Paddock Wilson and Lieut. George Stephen Mason, U.S.A., plan to marry at the Princeton University Chapel in June. Mr. and Mrs. John L. Wilson have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Mason of Princeton.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson will take two months out this summer from official commitments to devote herself to arranging "a wedding to remember always" for her younger daughter, Luci.

Gasoline supplies in the United States rose 1,961,000 barrels, to 214,238,000 barrels, in the week ended last Friday, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday. In the comparable week a year ago, supplies totaled 222,683,000 barrels.
BALTIMORE, Feb. 24 (AP)--Long-shot winners gave their backers a warm feeling, at Pimlico Race Course today despite a storm that dumped two inches of snow on the racing strip.

ELBA, Ala., Friday, Feb. 25 (AP) Two heavy explosions wrecked one wing of newly integrated Elba High School last night, less than an hour after a banquet attended by some 200 people had ended. Police Chief I.F. Dunaway said that the area around the explosions "smelled just like dynamite."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24--The Civil Service Commission issued today new regulations designed to open more Federal jobs to Negroes and members of other minorities.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Feb. 24 For the third consecutive day, the weather cast a wet blanket on America's plans to begin unmanned flight testing of its new Apollo spacecraft.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 The Supreme Court ruled today that former Representative Thomas F. Johnson could not be prosecuted on a charge of having taken a bribe to make a speech on the floor of the House.

Members of the cast of the film "The Group" will serve as models for Alexander's international haute couture spring fashion show and champagne luncheon, to be held at the department store's branch at Lexington Avenue and 58th Street on March 21.

PEKING, Friday, Feb. 25 (Reuters) President Kwame Nkrumah of Ghana last night publicly ignored the coup that toppled his regime and announced his intention of going aread with his Vietnam peace mission.

MANILA, Feb. 24 (AP)--Billy Casper, the favorite, got bogeys on each of the last three holes today and dropped four strokes off the pace set by an Australian pro and an unknown amateur from Taiwan in the first round of the Philippine open golf championship.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Feb. 24 Laurence Gandar, editor in chief of The Rand Daily Mail, said today that the award given his paper by the American Newspaper Publishers Association would provoke a new wave of denunciations of the newspaper by the Afrikaan press and the South African radio.
ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 24 (UPI) Willie Shoemaker rode Straight Deal to a victory of nearly three lengths today in the $40,000 added Santa Barbara Handicap for his third stakes victory in three days.
The stock market was battered again yesterday and the leading industrial averages sustained their biggest loss since midsummer.

MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 24 The Nassau County grand jury indicted an unemployed machinist tonight on charges of murder and arson in a fire at the Mineola Hotel. One man died and seven others were injured in the blaze, which destroyed the hotel.

Tom Farrell, Sam Perry and Herb Germann are the major attractions as the 24th annual Metropolitan Intercollegiate indoor track and field championships end tonight. Manhattan is the overwhelming favorite to keep the varsity team title in the 10-college field.
TORONTO, Feb. 24 The Alliance Credit Corporation, Ltd., a Montreal-based sales finance company, held a shareholders' meeting in tight secrecy today and refused to disclose what had been discussed.
NEWPORT, R.I., Feb. 24 George T. Wein has been granted licenses to hold his 1966 jazz, folk and opera festivals on the same ground in Newport on which they were held last year.

As a servant of the musical theater, the New York City Opera wears many faces. No two could have been more different than Tuesday night's "Don Rodrigo" and last night's "Street Scene" at the New York State Theater. The pageantry and stately passion of eighth-century Spanish royalty gave way to steamy tenement life in a New York slum. Music in an austere, modern idiom was replaced by the rhythms of musical comedy.
ROME, Feb. 24 (AP) Pope Paul VI visited a pharmaceutical plant today and said "I came here to pay homage to women in the working world."

EL TORO MARINE AIR BASE, Calif., Feb. 24 (UPI)--Two Navy Skyhawk fighter planes collided in flight tonight, but both pilots ejected safely--one after he stayed with his aircraft long enough to fly clear of congested coastal areas.

GENEVA, Feb. 24 Sweden said today that the question of nuclear sharing among the North Atlantic Treaty powers was an "obstacle for truly responsible negotiations" on a treaty to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons.

A violation of the Roman Catholic prohibition against the eating of meat on Friday is not necessarily gravely sinful, according to a Jesuit theologian whose views on the matter have been published by the Vatican daily, L'Osservatore Romano.
A wet snow that began early yesterday and built up through the night left up to four inches in the city and eight inches in the suburbs by this morning.
MADISON, Wis., Feb. 24 The National Coordinating Committee to End the War in Vietnam issued a call today for "International Days of Protest" on March 25 and 26.

HARTFORD, Feb. 24 Among the prominent outcroppings of operatic culture in America is the Hartt College of Music of the University of Hartford. Every season sees the presentation of an opera; and, more often than not, it is an opera that either is rare or is receiving its first American performance.
The Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority announced yesterday that it would fight Mayor Lindsay "all the way to the Supreme Court" in resisting his plan to take control of the authority.
The Commonwealth of Puerto Rico sold yesterday $37.2-million of public improvement bonds to a nationwide banking group led by the First National City Bank.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 24 The head of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations said today that the federation would not consider any application for affiliation from the union of Roman Catholic priests.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 An Administration move to head off a $1.60 minimum wage before 1968 is winning strong Congressional support.
The Board of Education has given the National Renaissance party, a neo-Nazi group, permission to meet on March 18 at 7 P.M. at the Robert F. Wagner Junior High School, 220 East 76th Street.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) The failure of a taxpayer to indicate his Social Security number in the upper right hand corner of his income tax return may delay his refund this year, the Internal Revenue Service said today.
The nation's outstanding yachtsman and yachtswoman for 1965 were announced last night at ceremonies in the New York Yacht Club.
LONDON, Feb. 24 The body of Nikolai Platonovich Ogaryov, a Russian revolutionary writer who died in London 88 years ago, was exhumed at Shooter's Hill Cemetery in southeast London today and cremated.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 Sherman J. Maisel, a member of the Federal Reserve Board, called on the nation's bankers today to help curb excessive demand by being more selective in making loans.
A portwide tie-up of cargo and passenger ships on April 1 was forecast yesterday by two high officials of the longshoremen's union.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 Intercity truck tonnage in the latest week ended Feb. 19 was 4.4 per cent ahead of the corresponding week of 1965.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) The House Committee on UnAmerican Activities concluded today its hearings on the Ku Klux Klan.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 24--The newest New York Yankee is also one of the oldest, Bob Friend. After 15 years with the Pittsburgh Pirates, the right-handed pitcher and right-thinking banker became a Yankee... 15 years with the Pittsburgh Pirates, the right-handed pitcher and right-thinking banker became a Yankee last Dec. 10, in exchange for Pete Mikkelsen, a less distinguished right-hander, and a bundle of unassailably distinguished United States currency.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) Representative Adam Clayton Powell introduced a bill today aimed at breaking down school segregation resulting from racially imbalanced neighborhoods in Northern cities.
The annual carnival of the Jewish Guild for the Blind will be held at its headquarters, 1880 Broadway, on April 3. Features of the benefit will be games of skill and dancing.
MALVERNE, L.I., Feb. 24 A boycott of the elementary schools by the parents of 140 white children continued today in protest against a plan to end racial imbalance in the district.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 24 Rear Admiral Joseph N. Murphy, who was commanding officer of the Naval Air Development Center in nearby Johnsville at his retirement in 1962, died Tuesday. He was 60 years old and lived in Penn Valley.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Feb. 24 For the third time since December, 1963, when it first approved a merger of the Atlantic Coast Line and Seaboard Air Line railroads, the Interstate Commerce Commission had to defend itself in court today against a broad attack that the merger would violate the antitrust laws.

Mayor Lindsay denounced the John Birch Society yesterday as "infamous" and "hostile to everything I think is decent." He said membership in the group "may well be" inconsistent with being a good policeman.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 24 The arrest of five Americans who came to Brazil on a business trip produced today a diplomatic representation by the United States Embassy for their release.

The American Investment Company is planning to diversify its operations further through the proposed purchase of the Biederman Furniture Company and National Manufacture Stores Corporation, independent furniture and appliance retail chains.

Mr. and Mrs. A.M. Johnstone of Birches Court, Codsall, England, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia Johnstone, to E. Timothy McAuliffe, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward C. McAuliffe of Cherry Hill, N.J. A June wedding is planned.
The Police Department announced yesterday that an embroidered gold design has been added to the visor of uniform caps to be worn by deputy chief inspectors and higher ranking officers.
Kwame Nkrumah has been his own worst enemy the biggest single obstacle both to the rapid development of Ghana and to the building of the united Africa of which he is so impassioned an advocate.

A $12-million Community Health Center that will include a 265-bed "day hospital" the patients would actually live at home will be built at the Brookdale Hospital Center in Brooklyn, it was announced yesterday.
BAYONNE, N.J., Feb. 24 Mrs. Agnes Cogan O'Connor, a teacher and widow of Peter O'Connor, a realty man, died at her home at 98 Avenue C yesterday. She was 78 years old.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) The United States has paid out $973-million in ocean transportation charges on surplus food shipped overseas under the Food for Peace program that began 10 years ago.
LONDON, Feb. 24 The Government took unusually tough action today to buttress its policy of price and wage restraint.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 24 Reports circulated here today that longshoremen would make their first move against ships of nations trading with North Vietnam by demonstrating at this morning's sailing of the Queen Mary from New York.
NEW ALBANY, Ind., Feb. 24 (AP) Parking fines by credit card have 5,000 "established and satisfied customers," officials of this Ohio River city say.

MAPLEWOOD, N.J., Feb. 24 Dr. Ludwig Oberndorf, retired managing editor of The New York Staats-Zeitung and Herold, the German-language daily, died yesterday at his home, 30 Claremont Avenue. His age was 78.
A new ambulance to be presented to the 105-year-old Knickerbocker Hospital today will have these words on a plaque affixed to one side: "This ambulance was purchased with pennies."
Winter played hob with the nation's money system during the week ended last Wednesday, but there was no significant change in the Federal Reserve's policy of "moderate restraint."
The Defense Supply Agency has completed issuance of highest priority orders to 20 manufacturers for cotton trousers needed by the troops in Vietnam.
Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz closed his hearings into art frauds and forgeries yesterday with an all-star variety cast.

The debut this summer of a Sunday night television network, which was to be organized by Sylvester L. Weaver and Oliver E. Treyz, has been postponed. The venture, the Prime Network, Inc., was to provide film programing for about 15 independent stations in major Cities from 7 to 11 P.M.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 The Ghanaian army's ouster of President Kwame Nkrumah was greeted with a noticeable lack of regret by the Administration today.
A liquid formula designed to prevent the erosion threatening the finest stone monuments of antiquity has been developed at the Conservatory Center of the New York University Institute of Fine Arts.

Sol Kittay, president of B.V.D. Corporation was nominated yesterday to head the board of directors of Timely Clothes, Inc., Rochester men's clothing manufacturer, control of which is being sought by B.V.D. through a tender offer.
ROME, Feb. 24 "Here I am an outsider, but I do not consider myself an enemy. I am a Soviet man and my works are not hostile."
Renewed interest by Yonkers Raceway in purchasing controlling interest in Roosevelt Raceway was reported yesterday in Wall Street.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) Miss Michele L. Behn, 21year-old granddaughter of a founder of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, was found dead today in her apartment here.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) George V. Allen is being called back to Federal service by a special act of Secretary of State Dean Rusk, State Department officials said today. The diplomat will become head of the Foreign Service Institute next Tuesday.

Rafael Osuna of Mexico and Frank Froehling 3d of South Orange, N.J., winner and runnet-up in the United States grass court tennis championship in 1963, will meet in the opening match of the first Vanderbilt invitation round-robin tournament for the Tiffany Troppy at 8 tonight.
At 9:30 A.M, yesterday, in the Blue Room at City Hall, Mayor Lindsay briefed City Council President Frank D. O'Connor on the details of his new tax program.

A retrospective exhibition of paintings and drawings by Nicolas de Stael, one of the leading figures of the postwar Paris art scene, opened yesterday at the Guggenheim Museum, Fifth Avenue at 88th Street.
MANHATTAN, Kan., Feb. 24 (UPI) Mickey Walker, for five years a lineman for the New York Giants of the National Football League, was named an assistant coach at Kansas State University today.
Three issues of bonds of American corporations' foreign affiliates were placed on the market overseas yesterday to raise a total of $55-million.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 King Faisal of Saudi Arabia has appealed to President Johnson for diplomatic and military support, including American air power, if the United Arab Republic resumes the fighting in Yemen.
Dr. Harvey S. Collins, associate attending physician at Memorial Hospital for Cancer and Allied Diseases, died yesterday in his home, 142 East 16th Street. His age was 52.
DAVOS, Switzerland, Feb. 24 (AP) Ludmilla Belousova and Oleg Protopopov, a wife-andhusband team from the Soviet Union, retained their world pairs figure skating championship today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 Officials here sought to make clear today that a call-up of military reserves was not contemplated for the war in Vietnam and that only an expansion of hostilities to areas outside that country might force President Johnson to order mobilization.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 The International Monetary Fund announced today that the increase in members' quotas and drawing rights of 25 per cent approved in September, 1964, was now in effect.

The first meeting of the Brooklyn Philharmonica's new Conductor's Council will be held at 8 P.M. next Thursday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The council, headed by Siegfried Landau, Philharmonia music director, will meet once a month to discuss a contemporary score. Those interested are invited to write the Philharmonia at 30 Lafayette Street, Brooklyn, for details.

When he is in trouble, Lyndon Johnson goes back to his old dreams. He was formed on the hard land of Texas and came to political power in the Depression and the early days of the New Deal, and when he talks about Franklin Roosevelt, as he did here this week, this link with the struggles of the thirties is perfectly clear.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP)--Americans may now send letters to North Vietnam with the assurance that they will get at least as far as Hanoi.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia-- In the curious twilight world of business activity that has grown up around Rhodesia since it seized its independence last November, the Americans appeared today to be faring rather less well than the British.
SAIGON, Feb. 25--Senior United States and South Vietnamese officials are showing a new sense of purpose and direction in the war against the Vietcong.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Feb. 25--The countdown for the launching of the new Apollo spacecraft proceeded smoothly into its final hours tonight, after three postponements because of the weather.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 25--The president of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development called today for ending the "paralyzing conception" in developing countries that "agriculture and industry should exist in a perpetual state of divorce."

AN outsize towel of pima cotton, as coolly colored as Italian ices, as thick as a rug and as expensive as monogrammed offerings ($10) may carry more fashion weight this year than anything shown at the recently completed linens markets. Wholesale showings are held twice a year here, drawing buyers from across the country.

Hyman E. Mintz, former Sullivan County Republican Assemblyman, and Carl Kaplan, former Fallsburg, N.Y., police chief, were found guilty last night of conspiring to bribe a detective to obtain grand jury secrets.
The Federal Reserve Board came under heavy fire yesterday for its proposed regulation that in effect would bar commercial banks from selling unsecured promissory notes.
Public School 119 in Harlem, where five years ago a rat almost met a Mayor, surrendered its 1,100 students yesterday to a new three-story brick building next door.
DAVOS, Switzerland (UPI) --Peggy Fleming of Colorado Springs gained an early lead over the defending titleholder, Petra Burka, of Canada tonight in the women's world figureskating championship.
The legislative spokesman for the state's Roman Catholic bishops set forth, for the first time, yesterday, specific objections to the divorce reform bill now pending in the Legislature.
LAGOS, Nigeria, Feb. 25-- Over the years Kwame Nkrumah has seemed increasingly destined for the tragedy of a man whose dreams could never catch up with reality.
New Yorkers tiptoed or jumped around the city yesterday while a six-inch snowfall quickly melted into slush pools of heroic dimensions.

The fourth annual Leatherneck Ball in behalf of the Marine Corps Scholarship Foundation was held last evening in the Waldorf-Astoria's Grand Ballroom. Lieut. Gen. Richard C. Mangrum, assistant commandant of the Marine Corps, was guest of honor.

SINGAPORE, Feb. 25--President Sukarno of Indonesia ordered a powerful anti-Communist student organization dissolved today, banned all demonstrations and imposed a curfew in Jakarta, a broadcast from the capital reported.

Dr. Joseph Broadman, a physician here for 57 years and the creator of the Broadman Library of World War I and World War II, died yesterday in Bellevue Hospital. He lived at 330 Third Avenue and was 83 years old.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 25-- Syria's new ruling military junta named Dr. Nureddin Attassi chief of state and Dr. Yussef Zayen Premier in a decree broadcast late tonight by the Damascus radio.
The Soviet Union has devoted far greater resources to exploration of the planets than has the United States, two American scientists have estimated.
Vice President Humphrey said last night that the Administration was determined to pursue the fight in Vietnam, "using military power of almost limitless quantities in measured, limited degree."
The opening of a nationwide program to combat illiteracy appears to have encountered resistance and delay in Washington.
For the first time this week, the American Stock Exchange moved yesterday into the plus column as advances outnumbered declines by a good margin on strong volume.

MONTREAL, Feb. 25--Cana da's long-stalled Churchill Falls hydroelectric development may be activated by a new customer, a nonprofit Vermont corporation, rather than by the Consolidated Edison Company of Nw York City, as had been assumed.
Two piglets will be on hand Monday to add a live note to futures trading in the first livehog contract ever to be traded on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange or on any other exchange.
The general outlines of a city tax program are beginning to emerge. While published accounts agree on its important elements, there are still enough differences to cause confusion in the public mind.
Plans to consolidate control of all instrument flying in and out of the metropolitan airports into one facility by November, 1967, were described yesterday by the Federal Aviation Agency.

ALBANY, Feb. 25--Governor Rockefeller stepped up the flow of his program in the Legislature today with proposals to give pay increases to the State Controller and Attorney General and to repeal the railroad fullcrew law.

The mischievous ramifications of the maritime unions' decision to run a State Department of their own were well illustrated by yesterday's brief strike of longshoremen on Cunard Line piers in this city. The dock workers felt no need to wait for formal instructions to put into effect their union leaders' planned boycott against ships of foreign nations trading with North Vietnam.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 25--Everybody showed up on time today as the New York Yankees began Phase Two of spring training. The rest of the pitchers and a catcher joined the younger players, who have been working out since Tuesday, and by next Wednesday the entire squad will be in action.
Dr. Jesse Talbot Littleton, developer of Pyrex glassware, died on Thursday at Fort Pierce, Fla. He was 78 years old.

American corporations, which announced plans Thursday for $320-million of long-term financing, are intensifying their search for new funds. Plans to raise an additional $218-million came to light yesterday.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 25--Promptly at 10:30 this morning, 33 New York Mets charged out of the clubhouse at Huggins-Stengel Field, headed toward right field to start a lap around the park, scattered the seagulls in center and opened a new spring training season on the run.

ACCRA, Ghana, Feb. 25-- At least 400 political prisoners jailed by deposed President Kwame Nkrumah were freed today in the wake of yesterday's military coup.
OWING perhaps to the place that postwar American art now occupies in our consciousness, our acquaintance with the new art that has emerged from Europe in the last two decades tends to be fitful.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25--The index of wholesale primary market prices remained unchanged at 105 (1957-59 equals 100) during the week ended Feb. 22, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. Farm products moved lower in price while processed foods and industrial commodities averaged unchanged.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Feb. 25--Attorney General Richmond M. Flowers, once a college friend and now a bitter foe of Gov. George C. Wallace, announced today that he would seek the Democratic nomination for Governor of Alabama.
The National Council of Churches voiced a "deep sense of shock" this week over what it described as Turkish harassment and oppression of the Greek Orthodox Patriarchate in Istanbul.

Ever since the elected President, Carlos Julio Arosemena, was overthrown on July 11, 1963, the officers have ruled quietly and, on the whole, efficiently. Now the time has come for them to prepare elections, and the quietude, at least, is going to be shattered.
The Maritime Administration expects to take action this year on close to $150-million in applications for ship loan and mortgage insurance for 41 vessels, the agency announced yesterday.

NEW DELHI, Feb. 25--India completed today on schedule the withdrawal of troops from Pakistani territory seized during last fall's fighting, an official spokesman said. Today was the deadline set in the Indian-Pakistani agreement signed last month at Tashkent in Soviet Central Asia.
The London stock market closed the week on a steadier note yesterday although losses were still fairly widespread.

When Herb Germann of Seton Hall wanted to move, he did. When Tom Farrell of St. John's wanted to move, he couldn't. That accounted for Germann's surprise victory over Farrell last night in the 24th annual Metropolitan Intercollegiate indoor track and field championships.

SAIGON, Feb. 25--Economists predict that South Vietnam, which three years ago exported 300,000 tons of rice, may have to import 400,000 tons from the United States this year. During the last year the United States shipped 200,000 tons to the country under the aid program.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25-- Vice President Humphrey indicated today that he would decline an invitation to appear before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee in closed session to discuss his recent visit to South Vietnam and other Asian countries.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced yesterday a group of executive changes in the present company and in three operating subsidiaries. All are effective April 1.

TWO world championship tournaments are scheduled in Europe this spring. The team championship, a five-cornered event in St. Vincent, Italy, in which Italy and North America will start joint favorites, will be followed immediately by a pair championship in Amsterdam, the Netherlands.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25-- The District of Columbia's chief law enforcement officer reversed himself today and agreed to let lawyers volunteer advice to poor suspects at all police stations.

Seated in the living room of his parents' Bronx home, Joe Foy, a stickball champion turned professional baseball player, appeared a bit groggy the other morning. His woolen, plaid slacks and red turtle-neck sweater were slightly rumpled.

CHICAGO, Feb. 25 (AP)-- The Cassius Clay-Ernie Terrell world heavyweight title bout, scheduled here for March 29, cannot legally be held in Illinois as now licensed, Attorney General William G. Clark said today. Clark gave his opinion shortly after Clay refused to apologize for his "unpatriotic remarks" about the draft.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 25--Ralph C. Teatsorth, a specialist in Asian affairs for United Press International, collapsed and died outside the United Nations Secretariat building this morning. He was 57 years old.
FINN BIRGER CHRISTENSEN, a jolly Dane who is part of an international network of irreverent furriers, is in town for his annual buying stint.

GREGORY GILLESPIE, now exhibiting at the Forum Gallery, 1018 Madison Avenue, at 79th Street, is a rare painter, one of the very few at work today who cannot be grouped within a past school or a current vogue.

KANSAS CITY, Feb. 25 (AP)--Jim Ryun, the 18-yearold Kansas freshman, stole the show from the varsity athletes by running a mile in 3 minutes, 59.6 seconds, the ninth fastest ever run indoors, at the Big Eight indoor track trials to night.
NEW LONDON, N.H., Feb. 25--Howard Coonley, a former president of the National Association of Manufacturers, died this afternoon at the New London Hospital. He was 89 years old.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25-- United States exports and imports declined 5 per cent each in January from their December levels, seasonally adjusted, the Commerce Department reported today.

PEKING, Feb. 25--Kwame Nkrumah said today that he was still ruler of Ghana despite the military coup there yesterday and that he would return to the West African country soon.

Murphy, who has been athletic director at the United States Military Academy for the last three years, was reassigned yesterday and will be replaced in June by Col. Jerry Capka. Those who know where to look can find spring--or nearly so. The witch hazels have already shown their ribbonlike flowers and very soon the red maples will bloom. The wild ones grow in the swampy parts of the woods where boots will be handy to keep feet dry. (Maybe the tips of skunk cabbage will be poking up, too.) Because red maples frequent moist woodlands, they are also called swamp maples.

IN anthologies and studies of contemporary poems it is the unex pected poems and poets who are increasingly evoked. Of these the least heralded, yet most rewarding, and even now perhaps the most enduring, is Edwin Muir (1887-1959): his best poems are short, and in contemporary company, resemble no one else's. The poems stand quite alone, and in their outward dress, innocent of fashionable 20th-century devices. Read carefully, their character is both traditional and unique.

March hasn't a really verdant ring to its name, but still it doesn't have the brusque sound of February. And it is worth remembering that the Roman god who gave his name to March was a god not only of war but of growing things, of life renewed in root and branch. March was the beginning of a new year in the early calendar, a time of hope and change for the better.
With the end of February at hand, can spring and annualmeeting time be far behind?

Model apartments with one, two and three bedrooms are on display in a 252-apartment complex under development in New Windsor, N.Y.

BERLIN, Feb. 12--An exhibition now showing here seeks to throw light on the life of Franz Kafka, the German Jewish writer from Prague, a man whose personal existence is hidden in the shadows of the visions and nightmares of his work.

The Atlanta Falcons completed their coaching staff last week with the appointment of Brad Ecklund as their offensive line coach. Norb Hecker's staff will start a long, tedious inspection this week of films of the Falcons' 14 upcoming opponents in the National Football League.

LUSAKA, Zambia, Feb. 26-- President Kenneth Kaunda announced today regulations making strikes illegal in the copper industry. In an action unparalleled in Zambia, he also restricted for an indefinite period to a rural area a white miners' union leader.

BRUSSELS, Feb. 26--Leaders of Belgium's two biggest political parties, the Social Christian and the Socialist, are making progress in their negotiations on a program for their third consecutive coalition government.

PISA, Italy--For almost a year, many newspapers and magazines throughout Europe have carried alarming stories about this beautiful city's most famous landmark, the Leaning Tower. Reading them, tourists might get the notion that the tower is about to topple, and that they had better rush here quickly if they want to see it.

The State Board of Regents announced yesterday that it would seek legislation to revamp the Board of Higher Education and give greater administrative authority to the chancellor of the City University.
The New York Fire Department will report savings of $1,322,000 or more in the next 16 months through cutbacks, Fire Commissioner Robert Lowery said last night.

Bernardo Segall, a Brazilian pianist who made his debut here in 1936 and appeared here often in the next two decades, gave his first New York recital since 1957 at Carnegie Hall last night. SARASOTA, Fla., Feb. 27 (UPI) J.C. Martin, a catcher, became the first Chicago White Sox spring training casualty today when he underwent an emergency appendectomy.

The Liberian Government "has not and will not" permit ships flying its flag to serve North Vietnamese ports. Albert J. Rudick, deputy commissioner of maritime affairs for the republic, declared yesterday.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 27 Room rentals for students at Harvard University will be increased by 8 per cent for the 1966-67 academic year, officials announced today. This will amount to a $40 rise for a total of $550 for the two semesters.

SAIGON, Feb. 27 Vietcong guerrillas shelled a commercial freighter on its way to Saigon today, apparently in an attempt to seal off the capital's port by sinking the ship and blocking the river channel. But the ship, bound from Hong Kong, reached Saigon.

The Tristate Transportation Commission, set up as a compact agency by the Legislatures of New York State, New Jersey and Connecticut, announced yesterday it had elected Dr. William J. Ronan of New York as chairman.

Contrary to popular conception the agricultural colleges of the nation have a long way to go before they meet the demands being made upon them, a report released yesterday said. The need for the agricultural colleges, the report indicates, is greater than ever.

The Medical Examiner's office reported yesterday that a detective lieutenant found dead after a street fight outside the Copacabana night club early Saturday was the victim of a severe battering of the head.

A blueprint for the establishment of departments of correction in all states and for the modernization of the court and penal systems was published here yesterday by the National Council on Crime and Delinquency.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 President Johnson is expected to send to Congress within the next few days legislation calling for a $1-billion-a-year program to rehabilitate and modernize many of the nation's 7,000 private and public hospitals.

Steve Vehslage of the Racquet and Tennis Club and his brother, Ramsey, of the University Club captured the David C. Johnson Jr. Memorial squash racquets doubles tournament yesterday at the Heights Casino in Brooklyn.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported over the weekend that outstanding letters of credit for 23 LatinAmerican countries declined in January from the December level of $254.5-million to $244.6million, the lowest total since the December, 1964, figure of $237.8-million.
Panels of doctors and lawyers will soon be established in New Jersey to hear charges of medical malpractice before suits go to court.

The chief of detectives of Detroit has disclosed a statistical survey of confessions that sharply contradicts the usual contention of law enforcement authorities that suspects will not "talk" if they are warned by the police of their right to remain silent and their right to counsel.

The American Broadcasting Company television network has drawn up a tentative program schedule for next season, in which 19 present shows would be canceled an 17 new ones added.

Governor Rockefeller says he is "hopeful" that his special panel to devise a workable law against strikes by public employes will have recommendations in time for submission to the Legislature this term. That is encouraging, but not encouraging enough. It will be a criminal breach of responsibility if the legislators adjourn without putting on the statute books a substitute for the Condon-Wadlin Act, now exposed as worse than useless.
Jim McDonagh, a 37-year-old Irishman, is at the midpoint of a 240.5-mile journey that he hopes will take him to Britain in Septemher.

Douglas Moore's "The Ballad of Baby Doe" is practically a full-fledged repertory piece at the New York City Opera. And as sees yesterday afternoon in the company's first performance of it at the New York State Theater in Lincoln Center the opera deserves its place of honor.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., Feb. 27 Dr. Saul K. Gluckman, a specialist in occupational medicine, died this morning at the New York University Medical Center. He was 60 years old and lived at 33 Troy Drive here.
EAST MEADOW, L.I., Feb. 27 The lions that adorn the official Nassau County seal are merely pretenders to the throne and a search is under way to determine the county's true monarch.

CAIRO, Feb. 27 The Soviet Union has signed a technical agreement with the United Arab Republic to help the government-owned General Petroleum Corporation to explore new concession areas for oil, economic experts reported today.
Victims of multiple sclerosis acquire the disease from outside their bodies, a Georgetown University neurologist suggests.

MIAMI, Feb. 27 William Robert Beattie of Barrington, Ill., a vice president of Robert F. Warner, Inc., of New York, hotel consultants and representatives, died of a heart attack He was here on business.

EAST ROCKAWAY, L.I., Feb. 27 Miss Lois Geraldine Adelsohn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clement Adelsohn, became the bride today of Neil Heller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Heller. Both families are of Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 Vice President Humphrey and Senator Robert F. Kennedy differed sharply today on whether the United States should be prepared to concede to the Vietcong a share of power in a South Vietnamese Government.

OLIVER HAILEY'S play 'First One Asleep, Whis tle" opened Saturday night at the Belasco. The audience deserves an apology. This is not a failure of art, as was the previous night's "Nathan Weinstein, Mystic, Connecticut." It is a pseudo-clever, pseudo-sexy, pseudo-hip attempt at commercial success.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 27 Mr. and Mrs. William P. Malloy have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Barbara Maloy, to Robert R. Freeman, son of Mr. and. Mrs. John P. Freeman. A May 28 wedding is planned.
A leading maritime industrial relations expert, William G. Mullins of the American Merchant Marine Institute, will be honored at a testimonial dinner tonight on his retirement.

After a six-month investigation of the Federal antipoverty program, itself only 18 months old, Representative Adam Clayton Powell reported yesterday that the effort "has been going very well, all things considered."

VERO BEACH, Fla., Feb. 27 (UPI) General Manager Buzzie Bavasi of the Los Angeles Dodgers told the club's players today he would not give in to the' "fantastic" contract demands of Sandy Koufax and Don Drysdale.

The Coast Guard's ocean watch its Automated Merchant Vessel Report system last year recorded more than 250,000 position reports from ships at sea in its continued effort to make the Atlantic, the Pacific, the Caribbean and the Gulf of Mexico safer places for navigation.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (UPI) Labor Secretary W. Willard Wirtz proposed today a possible Administration weapon against inflationary wageprice increases a cutoff of Federal aid.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Feb. 27 The engagement of Miss Susan Engelmann, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Christopher Engelinann, to James Joseph Mahoney, son of Mrs. Timothy E. Mahoney and the late Mr. Mahoney, has been announced by the prospective bride's. parents. A June wedding is planned.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 The American Jewish Community was challenged today to sharply revise its approaches to religious education, spend more money than it now does for religious training on the university campus, and involve college youth in the community's leadership councils.
PARIS, Feb. 27 Motorists in Paris will be able to use two levels of a new six-level parking area under the Boulevard Haussmann, not far from the Opera, beginning tomorrow.

DAVOS, Switzerland, Feb. 27 (AP) Peggy Fleming, an attractive, dark-haired 17-yearold high school senior from Colorado Springs, gave they United States a world figureskating gold medal today with a dazzling victory in the women's competition.

MILAN, Italy, Feb. 27 A metal disk that reproduces motion pictures through a television set in much the same manner as a long-playing record reproduces music through a high-fidelity phonograph is in an advanced stage of development.
Senator Jacob K. Javits called yesterday for a public hearing to determine whether a policeman could be a member of the John Birch Society and still perform his police duties properly.

Early in February a weekly newsletter on African affairs posed the question: Will 1966 be Africa's "Year of the Generals?" It referred to the fact that five African countries south of the Sahara had been taken under army rule in less than two months.
Dr. George M. Lewis, a dermatologist, died of cancer yesterday in New York Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived at 252 Elderwood Avenue, Pelham, N.Y. His office was at 40 East 61st Street.

Municipal bond sales this week are scheduled to pick up only slightly from last week, a period shortened a day by the Washington's Birthday holiday. Corporate bond underwriting activity will decrease in a lull before the late-March buildup in offerings.

MANILA, Feb. 27 (AP) Luis Silverio, a 28-year-old Filipino amateur, won the Philippine open golf championship today, beating a field of international pros that included two American stars, Billy Casper and Gene Littler.
As the first shipments of Paris spring fashions arrive to be fed into American workrooms for adaptations and mass production, expressions of discontent are being heard from fashion land.

Miss Nancy Miller, director of radio and television for the Girl Scouts of the United States of America, died Saturday in the Park East Hospital after a long illness. She was 36 years old and lived at 200 West 16th Street.

Growing affluence, a trend to bigger cars and the concomitant headache of traffic congestions are helping automatic transmissions to gain rapidly in popularity abroad, according to an industry spokesman. Lester G. Porter, president of the Borg-Warner Corporation, who recently returned to the United States from talks with European auto industry executives, said the fastest growth in the use of automatic transmissions could be expected in Britain, Australia and Japan.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP Major league baseball clubs will receive a sum estimated at $27,510,000 during 1966 for radio-television rights to their games, Broadcasting Magazine said today.

SAIGON, Feb. 27 (AP) Troops of the United States' First Cavalry Division (Airmobile), continuing a sweep of the central coast near Bongson, carried out three ambushes against the Vietcong today. One was described as highly successful.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Feb. 27 The road southwest of Damascus to the Israeli border was peaceful tonight at sunset despite unconfirmed reports of troop movements toward this capital. The reports came from outside Syria.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Feb. 27 The first detailed assessment of how well the Apollo spacecraft survived its maiden flight yesterday is not expected until about March 10, a spokesman for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 24 Orlando Manuel Cepeda lives in a house on the side of a hill so steep that there is the constant illusion of insecurity, of falling into space. This is good conditioning for Senor Cepeda. He must live with this same illusion when he joins the San Francisco Giants on Monday for spring training.

Chuck McKinley of Port Washington, L.I., the erstwhile champion of Wimbledon and now a businessman and parttime player, won the roundrobin medal-play indoor tennis tournament at the Vanderbilt Athletic Club yesterday over a field that included top-ranking amateurs of the world.
WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 27 Terri Ardleigh, a 14-year-old eighth grader at Greenwich, Conn., Academy, won four classes, including the horsemanship championship, today at the Secor Farms horse show.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 27 (UPI) Jackie Stewart Kwon the 100-mile International Cup auto race at Sandown Park today in a contest marred by an accident that injured 28 persons.

Directors of the American Brake Shoe company have elected William T. Kelly Jr. as president and chief operating officer, it was announced over the weekend. Also elected to a new post was John S. Hutchins, former president, who becomes vice chairman.

BELLEVILLE, N.J., Feb. 27 Mrs. Salvatore G, di Biase has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Joyce Frances di Biase, to James A. Reilly, son of Mrs. Edward Really of Bloomfield and the late Mr. Really.

Syria is the most politically unstable of all the Near Eastern countries and now she has given new proof of that quality. The country became independent in 1946. Since 1949 there have been eight successful coups d'etat and at least five unsuccessful revolts.
NEW DELHI, Feb. 27 The leading political astrologer in this star-crazed capital has become the focus of a political scandal.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (UPI) The Labor Department announced today plans to ease manpower shortages in defense industries by giving on-the-job training to new workers.

The Columbia University Orchestra presented a "Salute to Puerto Rican Music" Saturday night to an audience of about 800 people, including leaders of New York's Puerto Rican community. The concert was held in McMillan Theater on the university's Morningside Heights campus.
KENTUCKY and four other basketball teams reached the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament late last week through the automatic-bid route by clinching conference championships.
MANILA, Feb. 27 (UPI) Leading American diplomats in the Far East gathered here today for an annual conference on problems in Southeast Asia.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (UPI) The Central Intelligence Agency and the Boy Scouts backed away today from a confrontation in the woods of the capital's Virginia suburbs.

The Pennsylvania Railroad has agreed to continue its fresh fruit and vegetable transportation operations from its West Side Hudson River piers in Manhattan for three more years, Leo Brown, Commissioner of Marine and Aviation, announced yesterday.
Kenny Burrell, a stalwart of the jazz guitar in New York for the past decade, gave his first New York concert last night at Town Hall.
DARIEN, Conn., Feb. 27 Gordon Gray and Mrs. William G. Symmers of the Field Club of Greenwich won the United States Platform Tennis Association mixed doubles championship today.

CLINTON, N.Y. Feb. 27 Mrs. Flora McDonald Shute, widow of Berrian R. Shute, who was head of the music department of Hamilton College until his death five years ago, died in Utica. Hospital yesterday. She was 74 years old and lived in Clinton.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Feb. 27 Alabama Republicans this year could elect their party's first Southern Governor since 1920 and sweep many local candidates into the state's Legislature, courthouses and city halls for the first time since Reconstruction.

PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla., Feb. 27 (UPI)-John Barnum of Belmont, Mich., surged from behind with a 69 today to take a two-stroke lead in the third round of the Professional Golfers' Association seniors Teacher Trophy championship.

Miss Clara Sheinman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Sheinman of New York, was married yesterday noon to Sheppard Warren Zinovoy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Zinovoy of Mount Vernon, N.Y. Rabbi David J. Seligson performed the ceremony at the St. Regis.
Net new orders for machine tools the presses, lathes and other machinery that make up a production line advanced slightly in January from the high levels of the month before.

TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 27 (UPI) Cliff Drysdale of South Africa used an unerring backhand and a fast ground game today to defeat Boro Jovanovic of Yugoslavia in the final of the Dixie international tennis tournament. The scores were 6-2, 6-4,6-4.
PITTSBURGH, Feb. 27 The first leveling-off of steel orders in months was reported by a major sheet mill last week.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., Feb. 27 Frank R. Kemmer, a noted metallurgist, who held more than 20 patents in his field, died yesterday in his home, 93 Echo Lane. He was 78 years old.
DETROIT, Feb. 27 (UPI) A third-period goal by Claude Larose led the Montreal Canadiens to a 5-3 victory over the Detroit Red Wings in a National Hockey League gamy tonight.
PARIS, Feb. 28 John J. McCloy, former chairman of the board of the Ford Foundation, has been named chairman of the board of governors of the Atlantic Institute, the institute announced today.
BRISBANE, Australia, Feb. 27 (AP) Roy Emerson won the Australian hard-count tennis title today by defeating Tony Ruche, 6-3, 8-6, 4-6, 6-3, in the final.

WEST HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Feb. 27 The marriage of Miss Maxine Lois Groten, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harris H. Groten of Roslyn, to First Lieut. Philip Litwak, U.S.A., son of Mrs. Benjamin Cohen of Brooklyn and the late Hyman Litwak, took place today. Rabbi Leo Lichtenberg performed the ceremony in the Nassau Community Temple.

WAITSFIELD, Vt., Feb. 27 (UPI) Three children of Mickey Cochran, a former University of Vermont ski coach, continued their domination of the Eastern Junior Alpine championships today and were named to teams that will compete in the national championships in Colorado next month.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Feb. 27 There has been no evidence that a council of generals planned to depose President Sukarno last October, the Jakarta radio said today.

Dr. Gerson G. Rapoport of 85-02 139th Street, Jamaica, Queens, a retired physician and former chief of the venereal section of the Health Department clinic in Jamaica, died Saturday of a heart ailment in Miami Beach where he was spending the winter. He was 63 years old.

Miss Erica Mann, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Mann of 211 Central Park West, was married yesterday afternoon to Capt. Allan Jong of the Army Medical Corps, son of Mrs. Harry Chin of New York and Philadelphia and the late Goddard Jong.

Ezra Pound once quoted someone as saying that Henry James would be quite comfortable after death, as he had been dealing with ghosts all his life. Now James himself has been fifty years a ghost, but it is only in this last quarter century that he has come back to haunt us delightfully.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 27 (AP) The boards of directors of the Pennsalt Chemicals Corporation, and the S.S. White Company have approved in principle the merger of the two companies, a joint announcement disclosed yesterday. The proposal is subject to approval by White's stockholders.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 27--"Everything doesn't have to break exactly right for us to return to contention. Just reasonably normal will do."
More than 20 persons who fled their unheated apartments about a month ago for the free warmth of the Astor Hotel under a city-sponsored program are still living in the hotel.

The Citizens Union yesterday hailed efforts by both Mayor Lindsay and City Council President Frank D. O'Connor to establish "community district organizations" to bring city government closer to the people.

LONDON, Feb. 27 London financial markets have been hit by a bad case of pre-election jitters.

Theodore C. Borensen, former special counsel to President Kennedy, said last night that "platitudes and pieties" had been issued by the Johnson Administration, but that new ideas were needed on how to end the war in Vietnam.
CHICAGO, Feb. 27 (UPI) Bobby Hull got his 49th goal and four assists tonight and paced the Chicago Black Hawks to a 7-1 victory over the Boston Bruins.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 27 The men who ran last night's allEastern indoor track and field meet were aghast when they discovered they had the wrong Germann in their half-mile. As, it turned out, however, the wrong Germann was the right Germann.

ALBANY, Feb. 27 Mayor Lindsay, facing a city deficit of at least $600-million in the next fiscal year, flew here late today with a delegation of New York City officials to urge Governor Rockefeller and the Legislature to approve a broad new city tax program.
MOUNT HOPE, N.Y., Feb. 27 The Nutmeg No. 1 Curling Club from Darien, Conn., skipped by Howard (Rod) Roderick, won the 11th annual St. Andrew's invitation mixed bonspiel today.

WAITSFIELD, Vt., Feb. 27 Roger Buchika, a senior at nearby Middlebury College, plunged down a 60-gate course in 2 minutes 1.1 seconds today to capture honors at the annual New England Kandahar at Mad River Glen.

PANAMA, Feb, 27 (Reuters) The United States proposed revisions of the charter of the organization today that would give its council in Washington the power to try to achieve peaceful settlement of disputes between member states.

Contracts for future construction work in the nation in January totaled $3,373,813,000, anincrease of 8 per cent over the total for January, 1965,, the F.W. Dodge Company reported yesterday.

Proceeds of the 31st annual spring dance for the benefit of the Boys Club of New York will help it build another clubhouse. The event will be in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza on April 28.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27--The United States is reported to be planning five-year arms programs to modernize and strengthen the Greek and Turkish defense forces at a cost of several hundred million dollars.
