LONDON, Feb. 27 Christopher Cockerell, the inventor of the Hovercraft, resigned today from the government-sponsored company formed to develop it.
LA PAZ, Mexico, Feb. 27 (AP) The police captured today two Americans who had escaped from prison Thursday. They were brought here to face charges of kililng a guard during the escape.

Color television helped the Radio Corporation of America turn in record sales and earnings for 1965. The annual report, released over the weekend, placed sales above $2-billion for the first time, while net income went above the $100-million level for the first time.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 27 Deputy Mayor Robert Price of New York said today that Mayor Lindsay, "like Napoleon," has discovered that "it is easier to conquer the land than to hold it."

Lary Levy, a City College of New York sophomore, won two individual championships and finished second in another race yesterday to win individual honors at the Brooklyn Poly invitation swimming meet at the Brooklyn Central Y.M.C.A.
Two families of guitarists took over Town Hall and Carnegie Hall Saturday night. About 1,300 listeners attended each program.

David and Donald and Gregory leaped over a ripped mattress yesterday afternoon and began tossing bricks and empty beer cans into a puddle in their favorite lot a lot that Mayor Lindsay had promised to turn into a recreation area.
Burgess Meredith and Zero Mostel disclosed yesterday that they were forming a repertory company to open on Broadway next January. The idea has been germinating with them for two years, they said.
The election of Jack Walter Leason as a vice president of E.F. Hutton Co., Inc., a member of the New York Stock Exchange, was announced over the weekend.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 The United States gold stock rose by $5-million in January, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
MADISON, N.J., Feb. 27 (AP) The controversy between Negroes and barbers in this Morris County community flared anew today, shortly after it appeared to have been settled.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Feb. 27 Mrs. Eunice Clapp Johnson, wife of Stuart H. Johnson, retired member of J.H. Lane Co., New York textile manufacturer, died today at hem home, Kaintuck Farm, in Feeks Lane. She was 70 years old.
MOSCOW, Feb. 27 The shadow of the trial of the two clandestine Russian writers, Andrei D. Sinyavsky and Yuli M. Daniel, is lengthening through the Soviet intellectual world.

Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, asked the Federal Government yesterday to set up trust funds to enable the United Nations relief agencies to assist "almost one million refugees in South Vietnam."

WEST ORANGE, N,J., Feb. 27 T. David Gibb, who operated an automobile agency in East Orange for 38 years, died Friday at Pompano Beach, Fla., where he had been spending the winter. He was 81 years old and lived at 2 Collamore Circle here.
A trip through the Internal Revenue Service's incomeaveraging labyrinth can be highly rewarding to the taxpayer who made a lot more money last year than he did in

SAN DIEGO, Feb. 27 George Christopher surprised 275 membes of the Republican State Committee today by matching oratorical skill with Ronald Reagan in the heralded joint appearance of the two leading, Republican candidates for Governor of California.

THE novice games in therecent New York tourna ment totaled more than 300 tables but some novices reached for higher honors. The most successful was certainly Beth Massey, a young New York player taking part in her first tournament, who was a member of a squad that placed second out of 79 teams in the Mixed Team event.

SAIGON, Feb. 27 Officials in Saigon are privately voicing concern that the Honolulu conference of American and South Vietnamese leaders may have raised unrealistic expectations for rapid political and economic progress.

RAHWAY, N.J., Feb. 27 Dennis P. Donovan, a senior member of the New York and White Plains law firm of Bleakley, Platt, Schmidt, Hart Fritz, died of a heart attack today in his home at 688 Stone Street. He was 61 years old.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., Feb. 27 Alden T. Mann Jr., a former vice president of the Intertype Company, a division of the Harris-Intertype Corporation, producers of typesetting equipment for newspapers and commercial printing, died Friday of a heart attack in his home in the Wynwood Court Apartments. He was 70 years old.

Two churchmen one a minister and the other a layman are leading the field as potential candidates to succeed the Rev. Dr. Eugene Carson Blake as stated clerk, or chief executive officer, of the United Presbyterian Church.
PARIS, Feb. 27 Gino Severini, a founder of futurism whose painting "Le Panpan a Monico" was destroyed by Adolf Hitler as a "decadent" work of art, died here yesterday. He was 82 years old.
Some 700 Cuban anti-Castro exiles demonstrated here yesterday afternoon to support President Johnson's Vietnam policy, to urge a tougher campaign against Communism and to denounce antiwar groups.
MOSCOW, Feb. 27 (UPI) The Soviet Union's two orbiting space dogs "are feeling well" and can be seen moving in their spacecraft, Tass, the Soviet press agency, reported today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 Following are the votes of delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll-calls in Congress during the week ended yesterday.

A charge that Mayor Lindsay's bills for a centralized transportation administration "could cost New York area motorists millions of dollars annually" and block future traffic improvements was issued yesterday by the Automobile Club of New York.

ROME, Feb. 27 Pope Paul VI, standing at a window of his apartment overlooking St. Peter's Square, today blessed a contingent of heavy-duty trucks and agricultural equipment destined for India for famine relief.
CHICAGO, Feb. 27 (UPI) Elijah Muhammad today accused white Americans of being afraid to fight for their country.
ACCRA, Ghana, Feb. 27 (UPI)?Ghana's traditional chiefs came forward today to support the revolutionary regime that took power in a coup against Kwame Nkrumah last Thursday.

ACCRA, Feb. 27 (Reuters) An overflow crowd attended a memorial service today in honor of Dr. Joseph B. Danquah, who was the virtual dean of Mr. Nkrumah's political opponents before his death in prison last February.

"Nathan Weinstein, Mystic, Connecticut" was withdrawn after its third performance, presented Saturday night at the Brooks Atkinson Theater. The run was preceded by 23 previews. Sam Levene, Zohra Lampert and Estelle Winwood were starred in David Rayfiel's comedy. It received unfavorable reviews.
BOSTON, Feb. 27 Dr. Francis Nkrumah, son of the deposed Ghanaian President, Kwame Nkrumah, said yesterday that he knew nothing of what was happening in his homeland.

TOKYO, Feb. 27 (UPI) Communist China said unofficially today that the United States was willing to allow National Liberation Front participation in any future South Vietnamese Government but said the Communists would accept only complete control.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 "Mr. President," the reporter began, "there have been reports that there may be a change " "What reports?" President Johnson interrupted. "I don't want to deny just rumors."

Leading scientists and animal lovers from many parts of the nation will begin battling in a Newark courtroom this morning over whether high school students have the right to experiment on live animals.
FORT AMADOR, Canal Zone, Feb. 27 (UPI) Rear Admiral Louis A. Bryan, commander of United States Naval Forces, Southern Command, died tonight of a heart attack. He was 57 years old.
President Johnson's budget for fiscal 1967 and the economic policies that it implies have taken their lumps from the business community in recent weeks.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 27 (AP) St. Francis (Pa.) spurted to a 12-point lead in the second half and went on to defeat Duquesne, 76-68, today in the second game of a basketball double-header at the Civic Arena. Parsons defeated Steubenville, 76-68, in the first game.
HARTFORD, Feb. 27 Second-seeded Mrs. Newton Meade Jr. of Philadelphia won today her first United States women's squash racquets singles championship at the Hartford Golf Club.

HOLMENKOLLEN, Norway, Feb. 27 (AP) Bjorn Wirkola, a 22-year-old shop clerk from Norway, won the special 90-meter ski jump today for his second gold medal as the world Nordic ski championships closed. Norway won the team title with five gold medals.
LACONIA, N.H., Feb. 27 (AP) Dr. Charles Belford of Deerfield, Mass., won the world sled dog championships today for the third successive year, outclassing 27 other competitors in the three-day event.

Following is a weekly listing of unaudited net asset value of closed-end investment fund shares, as reported by the companies through the Association of Closed-End. Investment Companies at the close of business Friday. Also shown is the closing market price at each funds shares, with the percentage of difference (discount or premium). Where the stock is traded over-the-counter, the market price is the NASD dealer-to-dealer asked price.
KINGSTON, Jamaica, Feb. 27 (UPI) Fire wrecked the historic three-story Myrtle Bank Hotel in downtown Kingston today, forcing more than 100 guests, including about 60 American tourists, to flee.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 27 (AP) A man accused of failing to assist a policeman was cleared of the charge today but a magistrate lectured him and 150 courtroom spectators on the subject.
SOFIA, Bulgaria, Feb. 27 (AP) Bulgaria's Communistdominated Fatherland Front won 99 per cent of the vote today in national elections.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 McGeorge Bundy, the Administration's custodian of the world, moves to New York tomorrow to become the caretaker of the Ford Foundation's millions.
What were 500 men, women and children doing two weeks ago when they plunked themselves down in the middle of the Markham Bridge in Portland, Ore.?

LYONS, France, Feb. 27 (AP) Michel Jazy of France set a world indoor record for 1,500 meters today, running the distance in 3 minutes, 40.7 seconds in a French-West German meet.

PHILADELPHIA, Miss., Feb. 27 On a muddy red clay country road 12 miles east of here, a new Mount Zion Methodist Church was dedicated today to, the memory of three young men who were murdered 20 months ago in the cause of civil rights.
Central Park resounded with political invective and the "thwack" of paunch meeting paunch yesterday as local Republicans and Democrats clashed in a touch football game.
DERTOIT, Feb. 27 (AP) The Rev. Gomar De Pauw left Detroit today after failing to find a Roman Catholic Church where he could say Mass.
George F. Kennan said last night that he would make a statement "in a few days" about suggestions that he run for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator from New Jersey.

The presidents of the alumn associations of the City University's four senior colleges charged yesterday that any change in the structure of the Board of Higher Education would lead to "the destruction of local control of the university."
A break in a 36-inch water main in the East Bronx closed the IRT Pelham Bay Park subway line yesterday and flooded basements and sewers in a 10block area.
BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 28 George Meany served notice today that he would oppose any effort by the Johnson Administration to obtain Federal antistrike legislation covering city and state employes.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Feb. 28 Josiah T. Semans, who with his wife, the former Mary Luise Sanderson, bred Golden Retrievers at their Golden Pine Kennels, Ballston Lake, died today of a heart ailment in Saratoga Hospital. He was 66 years old.

City Controller Mario A. Procaccino proposed yesterday a 1 per cent sales tax on all stock market transactions here in place of Mayor Lindsay's tax package. The stock tax would yield at least $500-million a year.

LUSAKA, Zambia, Feb. 28 The Zambia Government reacted to a walkout today by 260 white miners at Nchanga, the country's biggest mine, by making it an offense for any miner in the country to go on strike.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) United States Information Agency has received word of the death today of Jack C. McDermott, a former Texas publisher who was the agency's public affairs officer for El Salvador. Mr. McDermott was 61 years old.
LONDON, Feb, 28 A London coroner ruled today that Vicky, Britain's well-known cartoonist, had commited suicide last Wednesday.

CAIRO, Feb. 28 A plucky Israeli who was defeated for office kept a campaign promise today with a solo flight to Egypt in an old unarmed biplane on a self-appointed mission to try to open peace talks between Israel and the Arabs.

In a ruling of fundamental importance to the savings and loan industry in New York, the State's highest court, the Court of Appeals, has held unanimously that account holders in a savings and loan association have "a common law right" to communicate with other account holders and borrowers.

Three hours after Miss Rita Wandel unlocked the door of her lingerie shop on the Upper West Side last Saturday, the first two "customers" of the day stepped in, shut the door and one of them pressed a revolver against her ribs.

There are rumors, and then there are rumors. When they persist, and the denials get louder and louder, something is usually up. One such rumor involving the Ford Motor Company has persisted for months, and yesterday what had been up came down.
Three of five children, the eldest 5 years old, died yesterday as a result of a fire in an apartment in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) The Peace Corps never was the "Kiddie Corps" its critics had predicted it would become and now it is more than just a good thing to join, its newly confirmed director, Jack Hood Vaughn, said today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 Dr. and Mrs. Louis Ross have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Gail Helene Ross, to James L. Nova, son of Mr. and Mrs. Barnett J. Nova of New York.

The Board of Regents has wisely refused to embark on a punitive expedition in dealing with the administrative conflict at the City University. The recommended changes in control are prudent enough to avoid any risk of destroying an institution that is essentially sound though plagued by growing pains.

ALBANY, Feb. 28 If a bill that passed the Senate today is passed by the Assembly and signed by the Governor, the Seneca Indians will be able to sell liquor for the first time on their reservations in New York.
The works of Salvador Dali are being held over at the Gallery of Modern Art.

A nation grown blase about the heroism of its pioneers in space got a terrestrial reminder yesterday of the hazards that attend every phase of the preparations to put a man on the moon. Astronauts Elliot See and Charles Bassett were killed not in outer space but in the crash of a conventional training plane against the very building in which had been built the Gemini capsule that was to carry them into orbit.

The six redeeming virtues organization, sacrifice, humility, righteousness, dedication and youth came to ground yesterday at lunch, masquerading as young heavyweight boxers. In this guise, they will scuffle among themselves at Madison Square Garden Friday night, but their true identities were readily apparent.
TORONTO, Feb. 28 (AP) A mob of about 500 youths brought Toronto's new East-West Subway Line to a halt for 14 minutes today on its first full business day of operation.

William A. Kane, credit manager of the New York American Beverage Company, Inc., at College Point, Queens, died Saturday in Peck Memorial Hospital, Brooklyn. He was 64 years old and lived at 295 Clinton Avenue, Brooklyn.
PAWTUCKET, R.I., Feb. 28 (AP) Former Mayor John Quinn, who broke a 27-year Republican control of the Pawtucket city government, died today. He was 65 years old.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (UPI) President and Mrs. Johnson attended the military funeral today for Capt. Albert M. Smith Jr., an Army helicopter pilot killed in South Vietnam.

February was the first month in a year to show above-normal precipitation, the Weather Bureau reported today. The precipitation totaled 4.92 inches. Last February, it totaled 3.66 inches, as compared with a normal 2.84 inches.

MIAMI, Feb. 28 Eddie Neloy was the most enviable figure at the Flamingo breakfast today. The highly successful trainer has two horses going in the $100,000 Flamingo on Thursday Ogden Phipps's Buckpasser and the Wheatley Stable's Stupendous. From the way things appear now, that entry figures to run one, two.
WHEN Dr. Efren Esteban Ramirez first began to work with narcotics addicts, it almost cost him his job.

A South Vietnamese Peace Commitee in Hanoi was reported yesterday to have written a letter of thanks to the Lawyers Committee on American Policy Toward Vietnam here. The lawyers group had questioned last month the constitutionality of President Johnson's actions on Vietnam.
LONDON, Feb. 28 Britain will vote for a new Parliament March 31.

Dreaming of a Central Park free on a springtime Sabbath of the hum, smell and menace of cars, Parks Commissioner Thomas P.F. Hoving proposed yesterday the banning of automobiles from the park's east and west drives on weekends as a test.
ALBANY, Feb. 28 Wendell P. Brown, a former State Solicitor General, died at the Albany Medical Center here today after a long illness. He was 82 years old.

The fruit peddler who makes curbside sales, the proprietor of umbrella-shaded soft drink carts, the butcher, the baker and the supermarket owner all must obtain city Health Department permits by April 1.

The stock market was mostly higher yesterday, with strength centered in the aerospace-defense, electronics, airline and rail groups and a scattering of individual issues in which special developments were taking place.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 In the Supreme Court of the United States today, the following proceedings were had:
The New Jersey Zinc Company, the largest domestic zinc producer, announced yesterday the election of Lindsay F. Johnson as president.
New York State is trying to find a way to give some confidence to timid art experts, wary of possible lawsuits. And it's no accident that one of the state's legal experts is an artist.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 The Agriculture Department ruled today that Government-subsidized exports of farm products could not be shipped on foreign vessels that have called at a port in North Vietnam since last Jan. 25.
President Johnson appeared on television yesterday to proclaim "Red Cross Month"
NEWARK, Feb. 28 (AP) Drivers of the state's largest bus line voted overwhelmingly tonight to reject what has been described by the bus line as its "final" offer for a new contract.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 The United States is planning further economic sanctions against Rhodesia as part of its policy of "full support" for Britain.
John E. Staren of Brookfield, Ill., president of the Chicago meat-broking concern that bears his name, died Saturday in Los Angeles while on a business trip. His age was 63.
The Singer Company, the world's largest manufacturer and retailer of sewing machines, said yesterday it was set to go into the European mail-order business.

PROSPECTORS from the mainstream of feminine fashion have been moving into the American men's wear field with such enthusiasm that the operation is taking on aspects of the California Gold Rush. There were these nuggets in the merchandising pan as of yesterday:
RALEIGH, N.C., Feb. 28 Administrators of the University of North Carolina regained the power today to allow or reject campus speeches by Communists and other controversial leftists.
The A.C. Nielsen Company said yesterday it had learned of an apparent attempt to influence its television program ratings through underhanded means.
LONDON, Feb. 28 The British Government announced today that it would hold talks here with the Spanish Government in April about Gibraltar.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 28 The Soviet Union and Bulgaria have refused to accept a letter by Akira Matsui, President of the Security Council reporting failure of its members to agree on a course of action on Vietnam. They are expected to challenge the legality of his action.
Miss Anna Fisch, a retired editor of Jewish books, died Sunday at Parsons Hospital in Flushing, Queens. She was 90 years old.
MIAMI, Feb. 28 A. Gerardo Rodriguez-Morejon, a Cuban historian and journalist, died last night of a heart attack at his home. He was 72 years old and had lived in exile here since 1960.

ALBANY, Feb. 28 Mayor Lindsay has given his support to a bill that would exempt New York City welfare workers from the penalties they face for their strike in January, 1965, informed sources said tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 The White House announced today that Federal District Judge Leo F. Rayfiel of Brooklyn would go on senior judge status next month, retiring from regular active service but retaining his seat on the court.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 Treble damages under the antitrust laws were added by the Supreme Court today to the general area of ship operator and shipper relations under the Shipping Act of 1916.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Feb. 28 A group of 18 to 20 Negro pupils staged a "learn-in" at the predominantly white Donald A. Quarles Elementary School here today while outside, in a cold, day-long drizzle, their parents marched quietly up and...

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) The Supreme Court denied today a hearing to Columbus, Ohio, on an appeal from a decision that it must compensate property owners who com plained of noise and vibration from planes using a runway at the municipal airport.
The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, the world's largest insurer, reported yesterday that 1965 was its "best year."

TORONTO, Feb. 28 Gerard Gingras, a former president of the Investment Dealers Association of Canada, was elected president today of the Alliance Credit Corporation, a Montreal finance company that is feeling the pinch of the tight money market.
The International Utilities Sorporation announced yesterday formation of a new overseas subsidiary, the International Utilities Overseas Capital Corporation.
ALBANY, Feb. 28 Leaders of the divided Legislature sought today to shift the onus for approving Mayor Lindsay's tax proposals onto the Democratic-controlled New York City Council.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) President Johnson has told Congressmen that he still always carries a copy of the Tonkin Gulf resolution, Represenative Frank J. Horton, Republican of upstate New York, reported today.

Cornell McNeil last night added another to his long string of vocal triumphs here that began when he joined the Metropolitan Opera last season. He took the role of the Count di Luna in Verdi's "Il Trovatore" for the first time with the company and gave a much-needed lift to a production that sags at the Met as often as not.

Oakley S. Evans, vice president and director of real estate and store planning for the J.C. Penney Company, has been elected to the concern's board of directors. Mr. Evans has been with Penney's for more than 30 years, and assumed his present post a month ago when Everett L. Moore retired.
Stock of the Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc., advanced in heavy trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 28 The handling of dry-cargo in the Port of Philadelphia remained at a standstill for the third day today when longshoremen failed to report to work in a dispute over the "setback" provision in their contract.

CHICAGO, Feb. 28 Alexander B. Trowbridge, Assistant Secretary for domestic and international business in the United States Commerce Department, urged today that every American manufacturer of exportable products allocate a predetermined part of output for export.
CAMBRIDGE, England, Feb. 28 (AP) Prince Richard of Gloucester, 10th in line to the British throne, has been assigned to guard a $280,000 art exhibition opening here tonight.
A total of 114 stakes races carrying almost $4.6-million in added money will be run during the New York Racing Association's forthcoming season at Aqueduct and Saratoga.

THE Metropolitan Collegiate Basketball Conference, with six members listed as major colleges and four called small colleges, was asked yesterday to decide just what it is a small-college league or a major-college one.
The Union Carbide Corporation said yesterday it would enter the spandex fiber field with new production facilities to be constructed at the company's chemical complex at Institute, W. Va.

KHALLET al MASAUDI, Libya Twenty-five miles east of Tripoli, in a sea of barren sand dunes where Romans once grew barley and tended their olive groves, a small band of men is confidently planting a forest in the desert.
DURHAM, N.C., Feb. 28 (AP) Two men believed kidnapped by two recaptured mental patients were found shot to death tonight near a fire station in Granville County, 14 miles northeast of Durham.
MIAMI, Feb. 28 (AP) About 150 unionists, some wielding pipes, clubs, hammers, wrenches and knives, fought at a downtown construction project today. Six were hospitalized and 14 others arrested.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 The Administration's $2.3-billion program to rebuild blighted areas of American cities received an unexpectedly sharp cross-examination today as hearings on the measure opened in Congress.
DETROIT Feb. 28 (AP) The United States automobile industry is scheduled to build its two-millionth vehicle of calendar 1966 on Wednesday, the same date on which it reached that record last year.

GRAND JUNCTION, Tenn., Feb. 28 (AP) Riggins White Knight upheld his tradition in the national bird dog championship field trials today.
W. Howard Miller, vice president of the First National City Bank, has been elected a director of the American Book Company.

NEW HAVEN, Feb. 28 A constellation of American poets, including five Pulitzer Prize-winners, called up tonight at Yale University the memory, of Randall Jarrell, poet, novelist and critic, who was struck and killed at Chapel Hill, N.C., by an automobile while he was walking last Oct. 14.
ACCRA, Ghana, Feb. 28 With the end of Ghana's close identification with the Communist bloc under Kwame Nkrumah, Ghana's new military government is taking steps to redress the East-West balance here.

A century-old English common law, the M'Naghten Rule, until recently the rigid guideline for determining the mental competence of defendants in criminal cases, was discarded yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Antipoverty funds amounting to $5,300 have been spent in the last month to provide, emergency shelter in armories and at the Astor Hotel for 700 persons who had been living in unheated apartments.
NORMAN HARTNELL, the British couturier whose fashion philosophy is personified by one of his customers, Queen Elizabeth II, watched a "Young Britain" fashion show at Altman's yesterday and commented:

Philip J. Levin, a director of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Inc., who was replaced last Thursday night by another director, Gen. Omar N. Bradley, as an executive committee member of the film company, said yesterday that "I am not making any tender offer at this time."

Sylvan N. King, vice president in charge of advertising of Bond Stores, Inc., nationwide retail clothing chain, died of a coronary attack yesterday in his office at 3 West 35th Street. Mr. King, who would have been 66 years old on March 31, was a native New Yorker and lived at 200 Central Park South. He was a member of the chain's board of directors.

Events tonight: "Un Ballo in Maschera," Metropolitan Opera, 8; Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Verdi's "Giovanna d'Arco," American Opera Society, Carnegie Hall, 8; works by Johannes Somary, Amor Artis Chorale and Orchestra, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30;

Consolidated Electronics Industries Corporation showed record net earnings for 1965 of $10,099,000, or $2.30 a share, the report disclosed yesterday. This compared with earnings of $8,160,295, or $1.86 a share, in 1964. Sales rose to $257,001,000 from $223,906,156.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 Perhaps it was the missionary impulse of those currently in power in this country that lured the Department of Justice into the error of involving the constitutional grant of immunity to members of Congress in the prosecution of former Representative Johnson of Maryland...

MEMPHIS, Tenn., (UPI) A goaltending foul by John Tresvant of the Detroit Pistons put St. Louis ahead, 102-100, with 1:48 to go and the Hawks went on to defeat the Pistons 108-103, in a National Basketball Association game tonight.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 28 When Tony Kubek was a Yankee rookie, Pete Sheehy, the custodian of numbers, assigned him uniform No. 34. One day Mickey Mantle offered a suggestion.

WATCHUNG, N.J., Feb. 28 Horace Spencer Kipe, founder in 1933 and president from then till 1962 of the Kipe Offset Process Company, Inc., lithographers in New York, died of a heart attack yesterday while attending a service at Long Hill Chapel, a Christian and Missionary Alliance Church in Chatham. He was 58 years old and lived at 312 Valley Road here.

The port's oldest regularly scheduled offshore cruise service?Furness Bermuda Line's weekly sailings to Bermuda--will be discontinued after 46 years at the end of December, the line announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 A Supreme Court that appeared to be deeply divided on the subject of confessions began today to consider a sweeping challenge to present police interrogation practices.

Paul Jacobs, a pianist who earned columns of praise in recent years for his performances of formidably difficult contemporary scores, and who is the official pianist of the New York Philharmonic, made a striking departure in a new direction last night by appearing in his recital debut as a harpsichordist.

The City Commission on Human Rights held the first of its series of weekly public hearings in different boroughs last night by listening to the complaints of about 100 residents of the Bedford-Stuyvesant area of Brooklyn.
NEW DELHI, Feb. 28 India's Prime Minister, Mrs. Indira Gandhi, will pay a four-day visit to the United States beginning March 27.
The Franklin Institute in Philadelphia has undertaken a two-year research program to determine whether highway landscaping affects the value of nearby property.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 The Interior Department moved today to enlist its newly developed fish protein concentrate in President Johnson's drive on hunger and malnutrition in developing nations.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 Senate Democratic leaders reached agreement late today on avoiding any vote on amendments to the supplemental military authorization bill that would express approval or criticism of the Administration's policy in Vietnam.

NEW HAVEN, Feb. 28 (AP) C. Harry McGill, who worked his way up from waterboy to senior vice president of the New Haven Railroad, died yesterday in Las Vegas, Nev., where he was on vacation. He was 72 years old and lived on Hartford Turnpike in North Haven.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 The Food and Drug Administration announced today that it had seized a quantity of a heart drug, Peritrate SA, manufactured by Warner-Chilcott Laboratories at Morris Plains, N.J., for false and misleading advertising.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Feb. 28 (UPI) Michigan moved closer to its second straight Big Ten basketball title tonight by defeating Iowa, 103-88, on the second-half shooting of Cazzie Russell and Jim Myers.

HAVING already adjusted to the knowledge that we are poor drivers, uninformed on matters of health and civil rights, and no more honest than we should be, we were not surprised to learn last night that we are often remarkably unobservant of the world around us.
For the second time within a month, the United States Steel Corporation has raised prices and the Government has approved.
MIAMI, Feb. 28 (UPI) Testimony in the Mossler murder trial concluded today with a state witness providing an apparent alibi for a man the defense said might have killed Jacques Mossler.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Feb. 28 Juan Bosch, president of the Dominican Revolutionary party, lashed out at President Hector Garcia Godoy today in a radio speech on the eve of the opening of the Dominican Republic's presidential election campaign.

Ernest Hemingway did not consider himself a member of a "Lost Generation" and thought that Gertrude Stein's label of the Paris writers and artists of the nineteen-twenties was "bull," a fellow writer discloses.
SPRINGFIELD, N.J., Feb. 28 Ray B. Smink of 156 Pitt Road, a teacher of industrial arts in the Irvington public schools for 30 years, died yesterday at his home. He was 69 years old.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 The use of radio devices by private citizens to eavesdrop on each other was prohibited today by the Federal Communications Commission.

SEOUL, South Korea, Tuesday, March 1 The South Korean Government disclosed its intention last night to send a combat division and a regiment to Vietnam to double the strength of its 21,000-man force there.

TORONTO, Feb. 28 Newsprint prices in Western markets of the United States and Canada will be increased $10 a ton April 1 by the Crown Zellerbach Corporation of San Francisco and its Vancouver-based subsidiary, Crown Zellerbach Canada, Ltd.
LONG BEACH, Calif., Feb. 28 Leo Durocher strode into the dressing room beneath the high school baseball stadium at 9:15 A.M. today and headed for a locker set off from the rest.

Jerry Lewis said yesterday that he was "consummating important negotiations" leading to his Broadway stage debut next October in "The Hero of the Whole World." The comedy by Mac Benoff concerns a Long Island architect who has five wives, each of whom is responsible for a different chore in the hero's menage.
A Congressman's former clerk has been indicated on charges of embezzling $1,126,36 in antipoverty funds, the Bronx District Attorney announced yesterday.

The New York division of the United Daughters of the Confederacy will hold a dessertcard party at the American Association of University Women at 111 East 37th Street the afternoon of March 12. Proceeds will go to the philanthropic fund shared by its five chapters.

Mrs. Daisy Givens Page of Wilmington, N.C., widow of Rinaldo Burrus Page, was married yesterday morning to Oliver Cromwell Hutaff, also of Wilmington. The Rev. Kenneth O. Jones of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church performed the ceremony at the Pierre.
The Continental Insurance Companies announced here yesterday the appointment of John A. Dodd and Donald R. Haverick as vice presidents of its domestic companies.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) President Johnson announced today that he would set up a study group "to help open the doors of opportunity to every American woman."

The First National City Bank threw the market for individual savings accounts into turmoil yesterday by announcing an increase to 5 per cent in the maximum rate it is willing to pay on investment certificates of deposit.

KAMPALA, Uganda, Feb. 28 Prime Minister Milton Obote told a delegation from his parliamentary Opposition today that he intended to recall Parliament soon and restore Uganda to a more normal system of government.
American Airlines said yesterday it had averaged 1,100 youth-fare passengers a day since it began offering half-fare travel last Jan. 27 to persons 12 through 21 years of age.
WASHINGTON Feb. 28 The Supreme Court took the following actions today:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--The Supreme Court today reversed contempt convictions of a former New York police lieutenant who had refused to testify before a grand jury.

The six-year, one-man campaign of James H. Van Alen to gain public recognition for the VASSS scoring system he devised had its biggest reward in the round-robin tennis tournament over the weekend at the Vanderbilt Athletic Club in the Grand Central building.

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Feb. 28 (AP) Top officials of the National Collegiate Athletic Association and the Amateur Athletic Union began talks today with a Government-appointed mediation board in an effort to resolve their dispute.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Feb. 28 The Foreign Ministers of India and Pakistan are scheduled to meet in Rawalpindi tomorrow for talks designed to bring about a further "normalization" of relations disrupted by the war over Kashmir last September.
SAN QUENTIN, Calif., Feb. 28 (AP) Larry Lord Motherwell, imprisoned in 1960 for the murder of a wealthy widow, died today in San Quentin prison of an apparent heart attack.
An aura of watchful, nervous waiting appeared yesterday to have pervaded all segments of the bond market, and they all gave ground.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 The Treasury bill rate fell back slightly this week after reaching record levels in the two preceding weeks, the Treasury disclosed tonight.
The American Stock Exchange started the week in a bullish fashion yesterday as the market made a good advance in active trading.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Feb. 28 James E. Curran of 3 Rutland Lane, for more than 20 years a cargo-booking salesman with States Marine Lines, freight steamship operators, died Saturday of a heart attack. His age was 56.
The spot rate on the British pound declined 14 points at the close yesterday from the Friday level to $2.7995 on foreign exchange markets here. Trading was moderate.

The Philadelphia and Reading Corporation mailed to its stockholders yesterday a proxy statement and notice of a special meeting to be held in New York on March 24 to authorize an issue of 5 per cent Class A $100 par cumulative preferred stock.
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that a Federal Communications Commission timetable for investigation of Bell System interstate rates was "very questionable."
ATLANTA, Feb. 28 Attorney General Nicholas deB. Katzenbach told civil rights leaders today he expected more than half of the eligible Negroes in the Deep South to vote in this year's elections.

Bus convoys shuttled nearly 29,000 subway passengers in the East Bronx past five flooded or closed stations on the IRT's Pelham Bay Park branch during the morning rush hour yesterday. Local service was fullY restored at 4:35 P.M. in time for the peak of the evening rush last night.

MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 28 The continuing rise in imports of women's apparel poses a real threat to American manufacturers of coats and suits and the production workers they employ, the annual meeting of the National Board of the Coat and Suit industry was told today.

MINEOLA, L.I, Feb. 28 A suit by the East Meadow Community Concerts Association to enjoin the East Meadow School Board permanently from canceling an appearance by Pete Seeger, the folk singer, was dismissed in the State Supreme Court here today.

LONDON, Feb. 28 The implications of the British defense white paper, made public last Tuesday, go well beyond the text. Unmentioned is the power against which British overseas defense is to be principally, though not exclusively, organized Communist China.
Charles Lucet, the French Ambassador to the United States, will preside over the charity ball to be given Saturday by the Federation of French War Veterans.
STOWE, Vt., Feb. 28 (UPI) The Columbia Broadcasting System has bought exclusive rights for the United States Alpine and international championship ski races at Stowe, March 18 through 20.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 28 While everyone was waiting eagerly for the arrival of Mickey Mantle (to pelt him with profound questions like "How do you feel?") the New York Yankees unexpectedly unveiled their latest acquisition, Bob Biletnikoff.
Miss Margaret Clapp, the retiring president of Wellesley College, will become the principal of a small liberal arts college for women in South India.
Engineers could provide a solution to misunderstandings between Government and business, such as the recent aluminum, copper and steel "price wars," an executive suggested yesterday.

Lecture series on urban affairs, Brooklyn Center, Long Island University, Conolly Hall, Flatbush Avenue Extension and DeKalb Avenue, Brooklyn, 11 A.M. "Land Use in the City of the Future," William Zeckendorf.
HIBBING, Minn., Feb. 28 (AP) Favored teams scored first-round victories today in the 1966 United States Men's Curling Association championship.
Prices on the London stock exchange retreated along a broad front yesterday as traders awaited word on the scheduling of a general election.

STORRS, Conn., Feb. 28--Mike Tiedmont set two state records as his team, Notre Dame of West Haven, won the Connecticut Interscholastic Athletic Conference swimming championship tonight at the University of Connecticut pool.
The eight Soviet track and field athletes competing in America have returned home suddenly because of a change in the track administration in the Soviet Union.

MURRAY HILL, N.J., Feb. 28 Harold A. Stewart of 58 Hunterdon Boulevard, sales supervisor of the international division of Dun Bradstreet, Inc., publications and services for management, died yesterday in Overlook Hospital, Summit, after a long illness. He was 55 years old.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--Over-all consumer prices stopped rising in January despite a continued increase in the cost of food, the Department of Labor reported today.
CLEVELAND, Feb. 28 (AP) The M.A. Hanna Company announced today an agreement to sell its bituminous coal properties to the Consolidation Coal Company for $5.5-million.
The first known poll of John V. Lindsay's popularity as Mayor showed yesterday that 81 per cent of those questioned thought he had done a good job in his first month in office.
A RECORD number of black bears, 648, was killed in New York State during the big-game hunting season last fall. The State Conservation Department said the previous high was 622, in 1960.
WASHINGTON, Feb., 28 (AP) Robert K. McConnaughey, trial commissioner in the United States Court of Claims, died in his office today of a heart attack. He was 61 years old.

HAVERTOWN, Pa., Feb. 28 Mr. and Mrs. William T. Robinson Jr. have announced the engagement of their niece, Miss Lynn Anne Gilroy, to Airman 1st Cl. Stephen Friel Whitmore, son of David N. Whitmore of New York and Mrs. Elizabeth E. Whitmore of Baldwin, L.I.
The New York Stock Exchange took another major step yesterday in its long-range automation program by introducing the use of optical scanning devices to collect market data for its computer system.
LIBORIO, 150 West 47th Street. Pedrito Rico, singer; Emilia Rivas's Flamenco Ballet and Candido's Orchestra.

A woman's auxiliary corps for the campaign against pov erty was proposed yesterday by Sargent Shriver, director of the Office of Economic Oppor tunity. The corps would be composed of unemployed girls between 15 and 21.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Feb. 28 (UPI)?The United States orbited today a new Essa weather satelite designed to beam instant cloud pictures to forecasters of any nation as part of America's contribution to the world weather watch.

"The man that hath no music in himself," wrote Shakespeare, "is fit for treasons, stratagems and spoils." Would it follow that the man who hath music in himself would be fit to catch criminal malefactors?

Army accepted a bid to the National Invitation Tournament for the third straight year yesterday, bringing to seven the number of colleges that have been named for the 14team tourney at Madison Square Garden next month.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 The nation's largest farm organization urged Congress today to reject President Johnson's $3.3-billion-a-year Food for Freedom program as a breeder of unwanted surpluses and "Socialist farm planning."
ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Feb. 28 Emperor Haile Selassie called today for unanimous action by African states to bring about the downfall of the white rebel regime in Rhodesia.

The John Birch Society's national publicity director, former Representative John H. Rousselot, offered yesterday to disclose the names of the 500 policemen he said were society members. He said he would disclose the names if requested to do so by the Lindsay administration and if the individual policemen were willing.
CHICAGO, Feb. 28 (AP) Loyola's basketball team bewildered a taller Bowling Green five with extraordinary shooting and rebounding and rolled up a 109-70 victory tonight.

WESTBURY, L.I., Feb. 28 Lindsay Scott, the Australian bred, side-wheeling ace who often had competed under more trying conditions back home, had no difficulty in winning the $15,000 Early Bird Pacing Series final in the rain at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

WEST HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Feb. 28 Mr. and Mrs. K.W. Lehnberger have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Sigrid Louise Lehnberger, to Dr. Marcel Coz of Orsay, France. An early summer wedding is planned.

SAN LORENZO DEL ESCORIAL, Spain, Feb. 28 The Spanish monarchy relived its past and perhaps gained a subtle hint of its future at a brief ritual today in the old royal monastery at the foot of the Guadarrama mountains.
DAYTONA BEACH, Feb. 28 The Petty family of automobile racing fame was in its local countinghouse today, counting out the money (about $28,000) won in Sunday's 495mile late-model contest.
A teller in a Greenwich Village bank was robbed again yesterday, apparently by the same man who took $7,400 from her on Valentine's Day.
The expressions and mannerisms of Danny Kaye will soon be as familiar to international business groups as to television and motion picture audiences.

SEA CLIFF, L.I., Feb. 28 The Rev. Lauren D. York and Mrs. York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothy Grace York, to Michael Remen Althoff, son of Dr. and Mrs. Charles C. Althoff of North Woodstock, N.H.
The color-television industry added two new companies yesterday and one set maker said it planned to raise prices on most of its color receivers.
BRUSSELS, Feb. 28 With France back at the bargaining table for the first time in eight months, the Council of Ministers of the European Economic Community convened here today.
(The following quotations are selling prices in United States dollars and cents for banknotes of New York. These rates do not apply to regular exchange business transacted by banks.)
Dr. H. Guyford Stever, president of the Carnegie Institute of Technology in Pittsburgh, was elected yesterday to the board of the United Aircraft Corporation.
Mrs. Ada Holman Jones of 1150 Fifth Avenue, wife of Robert A. Jones, a vice president of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York, died of cancer yesterday in Midtown Hospital.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 Most of the time it is fairly tolerable not being a dynamic businessman on the way up. The exception is the hour between 10 and 11 A.M. each day when the phone begins to ring with luncheon invitations from desperate young executives.

Mayor Lindsay has made a return visit to Albany, this time in search of enlarged taxing powers for New York City. His previous mission, to demand more state aid, was doomed to disappointment. But on taxation it is imperative that he get what the city needs to avoid deficit operation and drastic reduction of services.
The 54th annual appeal of the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund closed yesterday with record contributions.
PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla., Feb. 28 (AP) Fred Haas Jr. of New Orleans shot a par 72 in the final round today and won the Professional Golfers' Association Seniors golf tournament by two strokes.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., Feb. 28 Mr. and Mrs. John R. Gaines have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Josephine Gaines, to David W. Fraser. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Grant C. Fraser of George School, Pa. The couple plan to marry in June.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 28 The New York Mets solved their most pressing financial problem today when Jack Fisher ended his holdout and agreed to pitch this season for $23,000.

The Commercial Credit Company, the nation's second-largest independent sales finance corporation, reported yesterday net earnings for 1965 of $34,297,567 after credits from transfer of reserves no longer required of $8,711,786. This offset, in part, extra charges of $15,237,644 representing "unusual" bad-debt losses, the company said.
Abraham D. Beame, former New York City Controller and Democratic candidate for Mayor last year, was elected yesterday to the board of directors of American Trust Company.
Two of the three highestranking police officers who served under Police Commissioner Vincent L. Broderick quit the force yesterday. The third had retired last week.
Motorola, Inc., reported yesterday record sales and earnings for the three-month and 12-month periods ended Dec. 31.

Talmadge Hayer, who last week swore to his innocence in the murder of Malcolm X, returned to the witness stand yesterday and confessed his guilt. At the same time the tried to absolve his co-defendants, Norman 3X Butler and Thomas 15X Johnson.
The Board of Higher Education urged the State Board of Regents last night to reconsider its proposals for reorganizing the administrative structure of the City University.
MILWAUKEE, Feb. 28 (AP) Baseball went on trial today, but after 10 minutes Circuit Court Judge Elmer W. Roller called a recess for behind-thescenes legal skirmishing over exhibits.

An important step toward revising the Organization of American States Charter is being taken in Panama, where technicians from the United States and nineteen Latin-American countries are now meeting. The aim is to draw up amendments in the form of resolutions to be presented to an Inter-American foreign ministers meeting in Buenos Aires in July.
GENEVA, Feb. 28 The World Health Organization said today that a widespread outbreak of rabies among wild animals in many parts of the globe had been noted for the first time in about 100 years.

James J. McFadden, the city's Acting Labor Commissioner for three and a half years, said yesterday on his last day in office that he had "stepped on too many toes" to be promoted, to Labor Commissioner.
THE first daffodils are already appearing in florist's windows, but it will be a while before they raise their bright yellow faces in the local gardents to announce the end of winter.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 The long expansion in the nation's economy completed its fifth year today.

ALBANY, Feb. 28 The Senate voted 59 to 40 today to close a loophole in a ninemonth-old law through which Governor Rockefeller recently commuted the death sentences of two holdup men who murdered two New York City detectives in 1962.
The election of Ralph H. MacKinnon as vice president, treasurer and a director was announced here yesterday by the South Brooklyn Savings Bank.

Attended funeral of Capt. Albert Merriman Smith Jr., son of U.P.I. White House reporter, Merriman Smith; received the Federal woman's award winners; sent message to Congress asking approval of national visitor center here; met with Democratic Congressional leaders.

IN rubber bridge the player has no difficulty in deter mining, his primary target. He is trying to make his contract, or to defeat an opposing contract if he is a defender. If this primary target is either simple or impossible to achieve, his attention is inclined to wander.

WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 28 The recently formed Council for the Arts in Westchester announced the election today of Representative Ogden R. Reid of Purchase as board chairman and George C. Newlin of Scarsdale, a New York lawyer, as president.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Feb. 28 President Sukarno declared today that any attempt to deter Indonesia from her leftist course would fail, the Jakarta radio reported.
Cassius Clay will go home again on March 29 to defend his heavyweight championship against Ernie Terrell in Louisville.

The growing interest in the computer was solidly demonstrated here yesterday. More than 1,000 executives gathered at the Statler-Hilton Hotel for the American Management Association's 12th annual Data Processing Conference.
CHICAGO, Feb. 28 (AP) The Santa Fe Railway announced today it had ordered more than $38-million of covered hopper freight cars for delivery in September.
The State Department disclosed last night that it mailed a passport yesterday to Gus Hall, leader of the Communist party. U.S.A., in response to a request he revealed last week.

MALVERNE, L.I., Feb. 28 A group of white parents began operating secret private schools here today so their children would not have to go to an integrated school assigned to them by the Board of Education.
Stocks closed with more advances than declines in active trading. The strongest were the electronics, aerospace-defense and airline issues; volume, 9.92-million shares.

WEST NYACK, N.Y., Feb. 28 The Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Theophilus M. Taylor have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jessica Anne Taylor, to Russell Carlton Parker Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Parker of Sea Cliff, L.I.

APARTMENT houses do not, as a rule, inspire much affection. But there are a good many along Central Park West that seem to elicit from their tenants almost the same kind of chauvinistic pride and all-forgiving loyalty that small towns draw from their inhabitants.
Columbia College began yesterday a defense of general education on its own campus and throughout the country.
BONN, Feb. 28 West Germans are using chemicals to try to sink oil leaking from a tanker sunk in the North Sea and threatening to foul beaches.

How does a mosquito bite? For years scientists had only a vague understanding of the answer to this question, but now a Chicago biochemist has developed an electronic device that precisely measures how and when a mosquito bites.
The sugar market, both world and domestic, demonstrated a form of split personality yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 The Samuel H. Sheppard murder case was presented to the Su preme Court today as an illus tration of the contention that prejudicial newspaper articles could be proof enough of an unfair trial, even without evidence that jurors had been swayed by the publicity.

Harold Wilson has called a general election in Great Britain for March 31 for one compelling reason: He has been persuaded that the Labor party can win comfortably at this time and thus insure extension of its rule into the 1970's.
Dr. Efren E. Ramirez, a 35year-old Puerto Rican psychiatrist, was sworn in by Mayor Lindsay yesterday as the city's first Narcotics Coordinator.
The Police Commissioner's confidential unit is investigating charges of misconduct by a white police sergeant in a Harlem bar.

CHILDREN with a penchant for music and those who just enjoy reading may be interested in the following new books, each based on an opera or a ballet. The books were written for children 7 and older, and are now available in book stores.

LONDON, Tuesday, March 1 (Reuters) Five productions two British, one American, one Russian and one of Greek-United States origin have been nominated for the British Film Academy's award for the best movie from any source in 1965.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 The commander of United States Marine forces in South Vietnam said today that he had told President Johnson that he needed more forces in his area.

Justin Feldman, one of four Democrats seeking Reform support to make a primary fight against Representative Leonard Farbstein, called on all New Yorkers in Congress yesterday to vote against the $4.8-billion supplemental authorization for the Vietnam war.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 115 on Friday from 114.9 on Thursday.
SAIGON, Tuesday, March 1 United States Marines and South Vietnamese troops fought Vietcong guerrillas in three places last night in South Vietnam's northern provinces, military sources reported.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 The Gemini 9 astronauts Elliott M. See Jr. and Maj. Charles A. Bassett 2d were killed today when their jet trainer struck the building in St. Louis where the Gemini capsules are made.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 28--Mr. and Mrs. Jacob S. Shuster have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Renee Beth Shuster, to Stephen I. Goldberg, son of Dr. and Mrs. Philip M. Goldberg of New York.

Events today: Rossini's "The Barber of Seville," Metropolitan Opera, 8 P.M.; Douglas Moore's "The Ballad of Baby Doe," City Opera, New York State Theater, 8:15; Boston Symphony Orchestra, Philharmonic Hall, 8:30.

The Appellate Division ruled yesterday that Representative Adam Clayton Powell had until March 29 to appeal a $575,000 judgment set by the State Supreme Court, for the illegal transfer of a home in Puerto Rico to avoid paying a defamation of character judgment.
WEST HARTFORD, Conn., March 1 Miss Karen A. Golden's engagement to Dr. Joseph Hartman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Hartman of New York, has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Alfred W. Golden.

Rodney Laver of Australia, the top-seeded player, was matched with Michael Davies of Britain in the upper half of the draw, made yesterday, and Kenneth Rosewall of Australia and Richard (Pancho) Gonzalez of Los Angeles both received byes in the lower half for the $25,000 Madison Square Garden professional tennis tournament.

The Brazilian Government's decision to choose its main officeholders through indirect elections is a step in the direction of authoritarianism. It is designed to maintain in power the revolutionary regime of President Castelo Branco a regime that has done a good job of restoring Brazil's economy but has been gradually stifling democracy in Brazil.
The Government was awarded a $2.5-million judgment yesterday by Federal Judge Richard H. Levet for income taxes owed by a stockbroker and tax expert who advises investors how to avoid income taxes.
MIAMI BEACH March 1--The National Board of the Coat and Suit Industry will call on the Government to control the flow of wool, cotton and synthetic garments into this country from abroad.
A man who flew a kite in Central Park last fall with a "Vote for Lindsay" sign attached to it was freed yesterday of charges that he had illegally displayed a banner for political purposes.

Thirteen years ago a city management survey team urged appointment of a City Administrator to keep the Mayor from becoming the "direct manager of half a hundred specific operating agencies" and to leave him free for service as the "chief executive of a great enterprise." Over the years the lack of a clearcut mandate in the City Charter has prevented the Administrator's poet from achieving its objectives.
The New York Rangers, exhibiting a bit more muscle than usual in recent games, resume their National Hockey League rivalry with the Boston Bruins tonight at Madison Square Garden.
DANANG, South Vietnam, March 1 A company of United States marines routed a large force of entrenched guerrillas yesterday in a two-hour battle north of this port town, Marine officers said today.

Air France announced a series of executive changes yesterday in the eastern region. Effective May 1, Donald W. Broadley, district manager here, will become the New York passenger sales area manager, responsible for the New York and Newark districts. Mr. Broadley joined the airline in 1959.

MIAMI, March 1 (UPI) A prosecutor, summing up the state's case, leveled a finger at Mrs. Candace Mossler today and said she was the one "most guilty" in her millionaire husband's death "even though she didn't strike the fatal blow."

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 1 Mickey Mantle is unlikely to play in any Florida exhibition games and may not be ready when the regular season opens April 12. But he was still the figure of surpassing interest today as the final contingent of New York Yankees began spring training.

Newsstand purchasers of the April issue of McCall's magazine will not only be able to read about a Coty perfume, but will also be able to smell it. A half-page ad insert will contain a gold-foil envelope containing a towelette soaked in the perfume.
Representatives of Robert Moses have had two meetings with city and state officials this week to discuss the fine points of a project most politicians doubt will ever be built.

The Chrysler Corporation announced yesterday that it plans the overseas sale of $50-million of convertible debentures, which will be issued through the Chrysler Overseas Capital Corporation, a Delaware subsidiary.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 1 (Reuters) Two Indonesian student organizations joined forces today to stage noisy but nonviolent anti-Communist demonstrations in defiance of a Government ban.
TEL AVIV, March 1 Abie S. Nathan returned this evening to the tiny Israeli airfield from which he left yesterday on his personal peace mission to the United Arab Republic.

The establishment by the city's Commission on Human Rights of field offices in the five boroughs was proposed yesterday by its chairman, William H. Booth. He also called for a reinforced team of 70 inspectors to insure more effective action against discrimination.

J.P. Stevens Co., Inc., will raise its capital outlays this year by 50 per cent to a total of about $40-million, against $27.1-million in 1965, Robert T. Stevens, president of the large textile concern, told shareholders yesterday at the annual meeting here.
Luncheon, American Institute of Consulting Engineers, Engineers' Club, 32 West 40th Street, 12:45 P.M. "A New Era for the Hudson River," William B. Shore.
SEBRING, Fla., March 1 The scene shifts. Here in south central Florida, 150 miles from Daytona Beach, is the site of America's first endurance test for sports cars.

AND still they come, those unknown pre-1850 Italian operas that little groups (and big ones, too) have been digging out of the ruins ever since 1948. Last night it was Verdi's "Giovanna d'Arco," and those associated with the American Opera Society, its proud sponsors, believe that it was receiving its first American performance.
The City Council elected and seated its second woman member yesterday amid bemused speculation on whether she was a Councilman or Councilwoman.
MOSCOW, March 1 (AP) Nikolai Barabashov, a Soviet astrophysicist, intimated today that he did not accept as final Mariner 2's findings on Venus's temperature.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall suggested to the oil industry today that it was time to consider "how the nation's enormous future demands for petroleum energy will be supplied and what corrective actions, if any, are indicated."

THE artist, big as life behind his work, is the idea of Channel 13's new series, "U.S.A.: Artists," produced by National Educational Television. Last night's program, the first, involved Jim Dine, a so-called pop artist noted for his paintings of ties and bathrobes.
WEST HEMPSTEAD, L.I. March 1 Mr. and Mrs. Robert R. Levine have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nina Beth Levine, to Harry J. Link.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 114.7 on Monday from 115 on Friday.

WASHINGTON, March 1 The buildup of inventories by manufacturers continued in January, but at a significantly slower pace than in the hectic fourth quarter last year, the Commerce Department reported today.
WASHINGTON, March 1 Both houses of Congress overwhelmingly approved today the $4.8-billion military authorization bill to provide additional funds for the Vietnam war.
Governor Rockefeller yesterday appointed the Rev. Wyatt Tee Walker, former aide to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., as his special assistant for urban affairs.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) The national population had the lowest rate of natural increase last year since 1945, the Public Health Service reported today.

LA JOLLA, Calif., March 1 (UPI) Hugh Baillie, a dynamic force in The United Press (now United Press International) for more than 40 years, died today in Scripps Memorial Hospital of a heart ailment. He was 75 years old.

MIAMI, March 1 The sign over the office door said, "Ulcer Department." But when Eddie Neloy emerged into the bright Florida sunshine at an unfashionably early hour this morning, he was neither biting his nails nor wearing the harried, haunted look that trainers are wont to get as a big race approaches. Eddie sauntered serenely into the shed row of Barn C at Hialeah and looked the picture of a contented man.
Douglas S. McDonald has been elected president of the First Lincoln Financial Corporation. Formerly financial vice president, he succeeds Roy P. Crocker, who was elected chairman.

BONN, March 1 For the first time since World War II, neoNazi, anti-Semitic and other extreme right-wing activity rose sharply in West Germany last year, the Minister of the Interior, Paul Lucke, reported today.
GENEVA, March 1 The Swiss Government announced today that employers would have to cut by another 5 per cent the number of foreign workers on their payrolls by the end of next January.
Price changes on the London Stock Exchange were mixed at the close of trading yesterday after a late rally checked a general downdrift.
WASHINGTON, March 1 President Johnson urged the Vietnamese Communists today not to let "endless and unrewarding argument over what has already happened" prevent peaceful settlement of the war.

MIAMI-BEACH, March 1 The nation is "about to face a quite serious" manpower shortage, Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz said here today. He said the shortage called for preparation to take care of industry's expanding needs, and he asked for support of the Federal on-the-job training program.

About 100 students demonstrated in front of the Bronx High School of Science early yesterday to protest an armed forces career guidance assembly as "an invasion of our civilian lives by the military."
CHINA designers are looking backward as they make the leap ahead, judging by the latest crop of tradition-oriented dinnerware now coming to the stores.

The Bankers Trust Company, in a major innovation in international finance, will announce within the next day or two in a proxy statement to its shareholders tentative plans to sell in Europe an issue of about $25-million of convertible capital notes.

RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, March 1 Some progress toward the establishment of friendly relations between India and Pakistan was reported today at the end of the first day of meetings of their Foreign Ministers.
Holy Cross defeated St. John's, 63-60 last night in basketball, snapping the Redmen's 16-game home court winning streak.

MIAMI, March 1 The $50,000 Black Helen, the richest handicap race for fillies and mares on the Hialeah calendar, tomorrow will share the interest with a $10,000 allowance race. The main event, at 1 1/8 miles, is a representative one, with 11 contestants listed, and in its own right it could hold top attention quiet easily.
WASHINGTON, March 1 Following are excerpts from a speech on Vietnam made by Senator J.W. Fulbright, Democrat of Arkansas, in the Senate today:

Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc., is planning to enter the educational field through the proposed acquisition of Creative Playthings, Inc., suppliers of three-dimensional educational systems for nursery schools and kindergartens.

The spokesman for the nation's leading association of shipowners said yesterday that the maritime industry's chief concern was that the Administration's proposed remedial measures would be applied on "a kill-or-cure principle."
The problems of banking in a period of tight money were the focus of the annual meeting of the First National City Balk yesterday at the bank's elegant headquarters at 399 Park Ave.
BRUSSELS, March 1 A twoday meeting of the Council of Ministers of the European Economic Community has shown that France's seven-month boycott has produced lasting effects.

Directors of the Boeing Company have proposed a two-forone stock split and a dividend of 30 cents a share on the new shares. This would be equivalent to 60 cents a share on the present stock, which now receives 50 cents quarterly.
WASHINGTON, March 1 The Senate Finance Committee unanimously approved the Administration's tax, bill today with an amendment to bar tax deductions for advertisements in political publications.

The El Paso Natural Gas Company announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement to buy as much as 600-million additional cubic feet a day of Canadian natural gas from the Westcoast Transmission Company over a 25-year period.
TRENTON, March 1 Bernard Alexander, an industrialist who was a leader in Jewish activities, died in his home here today. He was 67 years old.
LOS ANGELES, March 1 (AP) A welder was accused by the police today of plotting the wholesale poisoning of Negroes in all parts of the United States.
LONDON, March 1 The Government announced today that Britain would change to a decimal system of currency in 1971.
The Ogden Corporation, a construction and electronics concern, announced here yesterday the election of Pierce J. Gerety as vice president for legal affairs and corporate development.
Cazzie Russell, a two-time allAmerica from the University of Michigan, was named college basketball's player of the year by The Associated Press yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 1 The District of Columbia Young Republican Club, which last year had a bitter wrangle over the John Birch Society, elected a new leadership last night pledged to the course of "moderate" Republicanism.

WASHINGTON, March 1 Senator J.W. Fulbright, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, proposed today that the Vietnam conflict be resolved by an agreement with Communist China for neutralization of all of Southeast Asia.

GLEN RIDGE, N.J., March 1 Robert O. Wolf, sales executive for Wellington Sears Company, New York textile manufacturers, died last night at Mountainside Hospital here. He was 49 years old and lived at 22 Argyle Street.
MINNEAPOLIS, March 1 (AP) Eighteen University of Minnesota students, and two faculty members protested today against radio stations' playing a popular record. "The Ballad of the Green Berets."
MOSCOW, March 1 An unmanned spacecraft bearing an emblem with the Soviet hammer and sickle crashed onto the surface of the planet Venus today, the Soviet Union announced.
Legislative leaders at Albany, Republican and Democrat alike, are handling Mayor Lindsay's $600-million tax package as gingerly as if it were a ton of TNT.

LONGMEADOW, Mass., March 1 Mr. and Mrs. Francis Warren Miller Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jo Anne Miller, to Peter Middlebrook Kellogg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic Rice Kellogg of Middlebury, Conn.

Fashions for mothers and daughters will be shown on Tuesday morning at a champagne breakfast in the Park Avenue Room of Saks Fifth Avenue. Mrs. Tucker Ridder and Mrs. R. Post Eddy are co-chairmen of the event.
A safe and low-cost method of freezing and preserving human blood is about to be put to work for the first time.
GREENWICH, Conn., March 1 "Do we have a 'dollar curtain' across Greenwich? Is there an off-limits sign north of the Merritt Parkway?"
HAMILTON, Bermuda, March 1 Bermuda's Trade Development Board plans to take immediate steps to find a replacement for the ships Queen of Bermuda and Ocean Monarch on the New York-to-Bermuda run.

WASHINGTON, March 1 The United States Government is reported to be planning to deport John Michael Hooper, head of the small Rhodesia information office here, unless he agrees to cease styling himself as an agent of the Rhodesian Government.
The American Stock Exchange took a drubbing yesterday on heavy volume as the number of declines outnumbered advances by a wide margin.

THE band moves, with a certain gallantry, into a waltz, and a gray-haired couple, smiling and confident, whirl round the floor with practiced ease. This is Roseland, ballroom dance capital of New York, and practically, athough not quite the final bastion of that tribal custom of people touching each other when they dance.

WESTFIELD, N.J., March 1 Everett E. Thomas of 739 Fairacres Avenue, former treasurer of the A.L. Watson Company of New York, a coal brokerage concern, and executive vice president of the Westfield Chamber of Commerce, died Sunday at Overlook Hospital, Summit. He was 68 years old.

ALBANY, March 1 A proposed constitutional amendment to permit New York City to increase its real estate tax "wouldn't stand a chance" of winning legislative approval right now, Assembly Speaker Anthony J. Travia said today.

BUENOS AIRES, March 1 Alberto Heber Usher, a businessman-politician who challenges Uruguay's traditional tolerance of Communism, be came President today of the nine-man National Council that governs Uruguay. He succeeds Washington Beltran in the chiefly honorary post.
LONDON, March 1 Britain's Royal Society has been quietly conducting for the last three years a slowly expanding exchange of scientists with the Chinese Communist Academy of Sciences.

WASHINGTON, March 1 Secretary of Defense McNamara is increasingly fascinated with an apocalyptic view of Communist China's mission in the world, and since he is probably the most influential member of President Johnson's Cabinet, his views are highly significant.

MILWAUKEE, March 1 (AP) Wisconsin's special antitrust prosecutor charged today that the Braves had moved from Milwaukee to Atlanta because "some young men borrowed too much money and had to make money in a hurry in order to stay in baseball."
WASHINGTON, March 1 Mayor Lindsay came to the Capital today to enlist bipartisan support from New York's Congressional defegation for a developing program of legislation for New York City.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 1 Poland presented to Secretary General Thant today an application from East Germany for membership in the United Nations. Mr. Thant transmitted the message to the Security Council President a few hours later.
Rudolf Smutny, a partner in R.W. Pressprich Co., celebrated his 50th year on Wall Street yesterday and if he had to do that half-century all over main he'd do it all over again.
Only three defending champions are entered in the Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America indoor track and field championships to be held Saturday at Madison Square Garden.
His Swedish Majesty's Ship Alvsnabben, a small and old-fashioned looking man-of-war in these days of nuclear, missile-carrying warships, arrived here yesterday morning for a six-day stay.
WASHINGTON, March 1 The Soviet Union today launched a Cosmos satellite that may herald the most spectacular Russian manned flight to date.
IT'S no longer enough for a fabric to sit around and look pretty. It has to do tricks to attract any attention at all in the fashion whirl.

DAMASCUS, Syria, March 1 The leftist junta that has ruled Syria since last Wednesday announced today the formation of a 20-man Cabinet. The Cabinet, headed by Premier Yussef Zayen, includes seven ministers who served with him in the Government that was forced out of power last December.
WASHINGTON, March 1 Justice Abe Fortas today compared the establishment of the right to counsel in police stations to the Magna, Carta and the Bill of Rights.

Business is flourishing on the road, the Theater Guild-American Theater Society reported yesterday. Guaranteed audiences for touring theatrical productions have increased this season in 12 of the 16 cities where the group sponsors programs.

A white patrolman who allegedly orderd a 30-year-old Negro housewife to partly disrobe in the back of a Harlem bar was temporarily transferred out of the area yesterday, pending completion of a Police Department investigation.

It has been service as usual at the Abbey and Victoria, Hotels in recent months while a $1,250,000 renovation project rejoined the two buildings to form once again the Abbey Victoria Hotel in the heart of Manhattan's theatrical district.

ST. LOUIS, March 1 (UPI) A seven-man team, working under security, today attempted to reconstruct the crash of the T-38 jet training plane in which two astronauts, Elliot M. See Jr. and Maj. Charles A. Bassett 2d, died yesterday.
TOKYO, March 1 (AP) Horacio Accavallo of Argentina gained a split decision over Katsuyoshi Takayama of Japan tonight and gained a share of the world flyweight boxing cahmpionship.

MADRID, March 1 About 1,500 tons of radioactively contaminated topsoil from the area in southern Spain where a hydrogen bomb was damaged in an accident in January will soon be shipped to the United States for laboratory tests.

Fresh ammunition for imposing broader and more effective restraints on the economy is furnished by a new and authoritative private survey of business investment plans that reports an explosive upsurge in corporate spending on new plant and equipment this year.

MONTREAL, March 1 (AP) Bobby Hull of the Chicago Black Hawks scored goal No. 49 and added four assists against Boston last Sunday for a league-leading point total of 84, according to official National Hockey League figures issued today.
It was an erratic day for the bond market yesterday.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 1 (UPI) Four homicide inspectors have been assigned to hunt down two men who mugged Roman Catholic Archbishop Joseph T. McGucken in a fashionable residential area.
Milton Wine, a lawyer and co-president of the AmericanTurkish Society, was stricken and died yesterday in the building where he lived at 320 West 86th Street. His age was 70.

HARTSDALE, N.Y., March 1 The engagement of Miss Barbara Gail Doernberg to Gideon A. Feibelmann, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kurt F. Feibelmann of New York, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Edwin J. Doernberg Jr. A June wedding is planned.

The search for a state that would sanction the Cassius Clay-Ernie Terrell heavyweight championship bout was renewed yesterday when Louisville, apparently bowing to the pressure of veterans' groups, snatched back the welcome mat it had laid out two days ago.

PARIS, March 1--Eugene Ionesco received official and academic recognition Monday evening when his latest and longest play, "La, soif et la faim" (thirst and hunger), had its premiere at the Comedie-Francaise.

For hide futures, yesterday brought another repeat performance with new life-of-contract highs and relatively heavy volume. In their quiet, unobtrusive way, hide futures have been a star performer among commodities lately.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (UPI) The Marine Corps has reactivated its famed Fifth Division, which took Iwo Jima and raised the flag on Mount Suribachi, it was announced today.

Four prominent real estate men met with Buildings Commissioner Charles G. Moerdler yesterday to seek a solution to tenant abuse of buildings, which takes the landlord rather than the tenant into Housing Court.

"Designing for the Theater" describes Jo Mielziner's chief preoccupation for four decades and is the title of a show of tempera paintings and studies that he prepared for about 80 of the 265 productions in which he has collaborated.
WASHINGTON, March, 1 Following are excerpts from President Johnson's remarks on Vietnam today at the swearing in of Jack Hood Vaughn as director of the Peace Corps:

UNITED NATIONS N.Y., March 1 Secretary General Thant held private talks today about Cyprus's future with representatives of the four countries directly interested in Cyprus. The Security Council must decide before March 26 whether to extend the mandate of the island's peace-keeping force, which expires on that date.
The United Gas Corporation's plan to acquire the Kaneb Pipe Line Company was dropped yesterday because of opposition from the Pennzoil Company.
Norman 3X, Butter, one of the three men on trial for the murder of Malcolm X. swore yesterday that he was lying down in his Bronx apartment, nursing an infected leg, when the slaying took place.
The McCrory Corporation, which operates a chain of variety, apparel and automotive supplies stores, announced here yesterday the election of Jerome Twomey as a director.
NEW HAVEN, March 1 A Yale University expedition has reported discovering "what might be called a missing link" in the evolutionary history of North American dinosaurs.
