PHILADELPHIA, March 1 Federal District Judge Ralph C. Body imposed a $100,000-a-day fine tonight on Local 1291 of the International Longshoremen's Association.

Three young real estate men have organized a new development and construction company that will specialize in condominium housing and rental apartments in Westchester and Rockland Counties and in Connecticut.

A study reveals that all 130 of the city's private and municipal hospitals are critically in need of revitalization. More than a third should be completely replaced, the United Hospital Fund reports; 24 others require major modernization and 59 need renovation. Those who undertook the basic research for the Hospital Review and Planning Council of Southern New York describe their findings as "disquieting," but this is an understatement.
Prince Philip, the Duke of Edinburgh, will be honored at a luncheon for 1,500 persons in the Grand Ballroom of the New York Hilton on March 18.
ROSLYN HEIGHTS, L.I., March 1 Miss Susan Brandt and Arthur David Gray plan to marry in August.
The younger brother of Vito Genovese, the racketeer, complained to the State Supreme Court yesterday that he was being harassed by the police because of his name.
Fred Darsey is going out of business, and as a result, he's going to jail.
The spot rate on the British pound closed at $2.7993, down two points from Monday's level, in active trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday.

TOWSON, Md., March 1 Earl R. Van Sickle, a New York custom tailor for many years till his retirement in 1962, died Saturday in Chesapeake Manor Nursing Home here after a long illness. He was 87 years old and lived at 8705 Raven Drive here.
WASHINGTON, March 1 The United States had no plans to land a spacecraft on Venus, a the Soviet Union did toady.
ALBANY, March 1 The Assembly deferred action today on a Democratic bill to repeal the London-Wadlin Law, which prohibits strikes by public employes.

CAIRO, March 1 The Cairo press today ridiculed Abie Nathan's flight from Tel Aviv to Port Said as a "comic act which failed to catch any laughs. "But the Egyptian Government treated Mr. Nathan with traditional Arab hospitality.
Did the Russians hit Venus yesterday by mistake? Did their spacecraft land a microbial invader that will proliferate and possibly foil future efforts to learn if the planet has any native life?
The province of Ontario registered yesterday a proposed $35-million debenture offering with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Robert Moses has asked the City Council to enter his dispute with the Lindsay administration over the Mayor's proposal to consolidate the city's transportation agencies.
Three more major banks in the New York area said yesterday that they would pay the "magic" 5 per cent on individual savings certificates of nine months and longer.
Fletcher L. Byrom was elected yesterday to the board of the Philips Electronics and Pharmaceutical Industries Corporation, which is controlled by the Consolidated Electonic Industries Corporation.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., March 1 Voters here today defeated a proposal for a $4.3-million school expansion bond issue that its supporters said would end racial imbalance.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 1 Every morning at 11 o'clock sharp, Yogi Berra shouts "Hitters!" and a 200pound six-footer, wearing No. 14 on his uniform, steps into the batting cage.
NOW that Norman Thomas is in his eighties, how does he feel about the fond tolerance and admiration he receives from those the old Socialist fought so vigorously over the years?
Benito Ortiz of Puerto Rico, 129 pounds, scored his 11th straight victory last night, an easy six-round decision over Angel Rivera, 127 , of Puerto Rico in the main bont at Sunnyside Garden, Queens.

Sales in New York City's department stores in February were an average 11 per cent higher than the year-earlier level. The holiday gains helped offset losses suffered during the citywide transit strike in January.

Leon Goldstein, a broadcasting consultant and former vice president and program director of radio station WMCA, died Monday night in Lenox Hill Hospital after a long illness. He was 62 years old and lived at 360 East 72d Street and in Carmel, N.Y.
The Warner-Lambert Pharmaceutical Company achieved record sales and earnings last year, Alfred E. Driscoll, president, reported yesterday.

Claudio Arrau and the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra opened a three-part Beethoven concert cycle last night at Philharmonic Hall with the Piano Concertos No. 1 in C and No. 4 in G, and the Coriolanus Overture for an opener.
Dig they must or so thought a crew of the State Department of Public Works on the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive yesterday morning.

PHILADELPHIA, March 1 Pennsylvania won its first Ivy League basketball championship in 13 years tonight but found itself in the position of possibly being like the pretty girl who was all dressed up with nowhere to go.

The American Broadcasting Company announced yesterday that Edgar J. Scherick had resigned as vice president in charge of programing of its television network. It also was learned that Douglas S. Cramer, vice president of program development, will resign soon.
BALTIMORE, March 1 (UPI) Fly By Venus, a daughter of Dark Star owned by Warner L. Jones Jr., breezed to an eight-length victory today in the $5,500 Randallstown Purse at Pimlico.
LONDON, March 1 Britain has repaid all of the $890-million borrowed on a short-term basis from the United States last year to defend the pound.
WESTBURY, L.I., March 1 A spectacular accident involving all eight starters in the second race marred the program tonight at Roosevelt Raceway.

PHILADELPHIA, March 1 Dr. Harold J. Grant Jr., curator and chairman of the entomology department Of the Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia and president of the American Entomological Society, died Sunday in a swimming accident in Trinidad. He was 45 years old and lived in Berwyn.
CASA GRANDE, Ariz. March 1 (UPI) Willie McCovey ended a brief holdout today and agreed to terms with the San Francisco Giants after a conference with General Manager Chub Feeney.
Gilbert and Sullivan may be in for some golden years if they stick with Benjamin Adler.
A 35-year-old major in the Marine reserves was killed yesterday when he was struck on the head by a heavy board blown off the roof of a building under construction in Brooklyn Heights.
ALBANY, March 1 New York City would become eligible for the first time as a site for state parks and recreation areas under a bill to be introduced this week by the Lindsay administration.

President Johnson has set forth a program for further expansion of Federal Government activities to protect the public's health. The underlying premise is the conviction that the traditional combination of individual self-reliance, private philanthropy and local government is no longer adequate.

MANCHESTER, England, March 1 (UPI) A leading British scientist asserted today that the Soviet Union had endangered future studies of life on Venus by contaminating its surface with the Venus 3 space probe.

Mr. and Mrs. Clifford W. Kirmss of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Martha Katherine Kirmss, to Willem Hendrik Daniels, son of Mr. and Mrs. Willem A. Daniels of De Koningshof, Heelsum, the Netherlands.
DUCKS UNLIMITED, the conservation association of waterfowl hunters, has surveyed its building activities in Canada on behalf of ducks and geese during 1965.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (UPI) Eight women Congressmen, including one from New Jersey, urged today a ban on sex discrimination in the selection of juries in both Federal and state courts.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) The Southern Railway Company announced today it had contracted to purchase stock control of two short-line railroads in Georgia.
Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson has accepted the honorary chairmanship of the United States Committee for the first World Festival of Negro Arts.
A Soviet scientist has called for the importation of large amounts of Western machinery and technical know-how to make possible the speedy computerization of the Soviet economy.

WALTHAM, Mass., March 1 (AP) Waltham High School offered a three-day trial last month of cafeteria breakfasts similar to those proposed by President Johnson today. But only 100 students came to eat each morning.
NEW HAVEN, Conn. March 1 Frank Wisneski, a reserve, spurred a first-half Yale scoring attack and the Elis went on to defeat Brown, 77-64, in the Ivy League finale for both teams tonight.
NEWARK, March 1--A 32-year-old laborer wanted in the fatal shooting last October of an East Orange, N.J., police sergeant surrendered here tonight, the Federal Bureau of Investigation announced.

The Pennsylvania General State Authority sold yesterday $50-million of revenue bonds to a group headed by the Chase Manhattan Bank, the First National City Bank, the Philadelphia National Bank and the Continental Illinois National Bank Trust Company.

Johannes Somary is best known here as conductor of the Amor Artis Chorale and Orchestra, which gives programs of rarely heard music, mostly old, at Town Hall each season. Mr. Somary presented Amor Artis in a new physical and musical setting last night when it gave the first performances of two of his own cantatas in a program devoted exclusively to his music at Carnegie Recital Hall.
WASHINGTON, March 1 President Johnson sent to Congress today a potentially farreaching program to improve the nation's health care services and recommendations to expand aid to education.

Whitney M. Young Jr., executive director of the National Urban League, said last night that he was "annoyed by liberal intellectuals who show anger in far-off places but are not concerned about fighting for civil rights in this country."

GLENDALE, Calif., March 1 (UPI) Casey Stengel, at the age of 74, said today he would take over new duties this week with the New York Mets at their St. Petersburg, Fla., training camp. He will fly to Florida Thursday.
ALBANY, March 1 (AP)--About 100 New York City tenants, most of them Negroes, staged a shouting, singing protest demonstration today near Governor Rockefeller's second-floor office at the Capitol.

Asbestos dust, which has already been connected with the development of fatal cancer in one-half of asbestos workers, may be a potential health hazard for one-quarter of the population or more, it was reported yesterday.
ACCRA, Ghana, March .1 Officials of Ghana's five-day-old Government disclosed today that 130 Soviet technicians and their families were being sent home.

WASHINGTON, March 1 Senator J.W. Fulbright said today that Vice President Humphrey had agreed to meet in sacret session with the senate Foreign Relations Committee tomorrow at 2 P.M. to discuss his recent trip to the Far East and the $415-million supplemental foreign aid bill.

TUCSON, Ariz., March 1 (UPI) Charles Schmid Jr. was convicted today of first degree murder and the penalty fixed at death for strangling two sisters because one assertedly knew too much about a third killing of which he is also accused.
WASHINGTON, March 1 A group of 30 Republican Representatives called today for an "immediate" Congressional investigation of the draft.
Most petroleum refiners in the midcontinent section of the United States announced price cuts on branded gasoline for northern pipeline shipments by of a cent a gallon to 11 cents.

John F. Shanley, replaced last week as the city's ranking police officer, charged yesterday that Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary had named Sanford D. Garelik to succeed him without consulting other high police officials or department records.

LONDON, March 1 The Government's decision to change Britain's ancient coinage of pounds, shillings and pence to a decimal currency in 1971 ends a public debate that has gone on for more than 100 years.

The championship race in the National Basketball Association is over as far as the New York Knickerbockers are concerned. The local club lost to the San Francisco Warriors, 114-112, at Madison Square Garden last night and with the defeat went all hope for a play off berth.

ASTONISHING as it may seem to anyone who has not sampled them, more than a million pounds of mussels are sold in the United States each year. And most of them, according to John von Glahn of the Fishery Council, are consumed right here in Manhattan.
TAMPA, Fla., March 1 (UPI) Deron Johnson, the major league runs-batted-in champion last year, officially became a Cincinnati Reds' holdout today.

Patrick J. Frawley Jr., chairman of the Schick Safety Razor Company, believes that American business has the greatest array of sales, advertising and public relations talents in the world, but that these talents have not been effectively mobilized to merchandise freedom.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, March 1 The delegation of the new government of Ghana was seated in the Organization of African Unity today after a dispute reflecting important political differences among the 36 member states.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (UPI) Two Government officials asked Congress today to approve a proposal to permit the temporary suspension of import duties on copper.

DURBAN, South Africa. March 1 (AP) Thirteen-yearold Karen Muir of South Africa broke her world record for the women's 110-yard backstroke with a time of 1 minute 8 seconds today in the South African swimming championships.

If current negotiations succeed, United Artists will acquire the film rights to "The Persecution and Assassination of Marat as Performed by the Inmates of the Asylum of Charentun Under the Direction of the Marquis de Sade."

ALBANY, March 1 R. Peter Straus, who brought the court action nearly five years ago that overturned the state's formula, for legislative reapportionment, urged a judicial commission today to draft a nonpartisan not a bipartisan plan for Senate and Assembly districts.

A luau and dinner dance at the Sun Luck Imperial, to be given by the women's division of the Horace Mann Alumni Association on March 18, will aid the school's scholarship fund. Mrs. John H. Freund and Mrs. Peter Miller are co-chairmen of the benefit.
WASHINGTON, March 1 President Johnson faces one of the stiffest Congressional fights of the year as he seeks to rejuggle the nation's school feeding programs to reach more needy children.
One of Manhattan's liveliest neighborhood shopping centers took another step on the road to oblivion yesterday.
If ever a child had two strikes against him, that child was Gerard.
PARIS, March 1 A one-day subway strike today made traffic jams in Paris worse than usual, but left the city's economic life virtually unaffected. Only a handful bf trains ran.
PHILADELPHIA, March 1 (AP) Tom Gola said today he would retire as a professional basketball player and run for the state legislature on the Republican ticket in the May primary election.

TO SOME old-line police officers the type of man represented by the new Chief Inspector, Sanford Daniel Garelik, is suspect. He holds a Bachelor of Science degree from the University of North Carolina, is fond of classical music and theater and has a knowledge of sociology.
WEST POINT, N.Y., March 1 Army scored in every period today and posted a 3-1 hockey victory over Merrimack. The cadets have a 17-6-1 won-losttied record, with one game remaining.

ITHACA, N.Y., March 1 Cornell closed Columbia's best basketball season in nine years on a sour note tonight, downing the Lions, 84-73. Cornell and Columbia thus finished in a tie for second place in the Ivy League with 10-4 won-lost records.
An alcohol still operation that capitalized on the heavy aroma from a next-door cocoa factory to cut the smell of raw alcohol ran into trouble yesterday after revenue agents got a closer whiff.

High-ranking police officials held a stormy meeting last night with more than 300 residents and businessmen in the West 145th Street area and were told in blunt terms what was wrong with the police in Harlem.

WASHINGTON, March 1 G. Mennen Williams, Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, said today that United States economic and military interests in South Africa could not override this country's political interest in seeing an end to apartheid there.

The passage of Mayor Lindsay's tax program may be substantially delayed if the Legislature insists on a preendorsement of it by the City Council. Council Majority Leader David Ross said yesterday that the Council might want to hold public hearings on the tax program before voting an endorsement.

SANTA MONICA, Calif., March 1 Synanon House, an institution that cares for narcotics addicts, accepted today a controversial Catholic priest, the Rev, William H. DuBay, as a religious counselor after first balking over his application for the post because of the priest's alleged affinity for Socialism.

Those faint-hearted betting fans who had been hoping the optional, or "chicken" procedure would be part of the regular twin-double framework at Yonkers Raceway, starting with Friday night's opening, are going to be disappointed. The Westchester County harness racing plant will have nothing to do with any fowl form of wagering.

THE free publication of "Story of O" in this country is an event of considerable importance not because the book has more than limited artistic or literary merit (it probably doesn't) or because it is in some way attractive (it isn't), but because it marks the end of any coherent restrictive application of the concept of pornography to books.

This year's program of the Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York will be built around efforts to curb the breakdown of family life, Bishop George H. Guilfoyle, executive director, announced yesterday.

MALVERNE, L.I., March 1--Private classes were continued here today for white children whose parents have refused to permit them to attend an integrated school assigned to them by the Board of Education.

English furniture styles introduced in Chicago in January, which are about to arrive in New York stores, can contribrite to interiors such as the ones here. For English is a perennial in decor. Its ingredients, as shown in homes of antiques collectors, include chintzes, flamestitch, cane patterns, needlepoint rugs and pillows and clear, warm colors.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, March 1 There is evidence that the Rhodesian Government expects to get deliveries of crude oil through the Mozambique port of Beira soon.
A rag fire in the hold of a freighter loading at a Brooklyn pier for Japan, raged for four hours before being brought under control early yesterday.

A new "Phase Two" for the militant Congress of Racial Equality opened yesterday. Floyd B. McKissick, a lean North Carolina, lawyer, took over as national director with plans for new leadership training and an attack on social inequities for whites and Indians as well as Negroes.

MOST new ideas in bridge are too esoteric for the average player, and most old ideas are too hackneyed. The problem for a bridge author is to provide a fresh, entertaining slant on old themes, and to help the reader make the most of his existing technical equipment.

The stock market droppedsharply yesterday is the heaviest trading in about three months. Stocks that declined outnumbered advances by a ratio of nearly four to one as the Dow-Jones industrial average tumbled more than 13 points, its biggest loss since June 28.

The Dow-Jones industrial average, which plummeted 13.59 points yesterday, to 938.30, has declined nearly 6 per cent in less than three weeks. This average had reached a historic high of 995.15 on Feb. 9.
The Board of Higher Education will hold a special meeting next Wednesday the outcome of which could determine whether Dr. Albert H. Bowker remains as Chancellor of the City University.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., March 1 Mrs. Emily Sayers Costain, who painted pictures, wrote poetry, played the piano and made embroidery when past the age of 100, died in her sleep here today in her home at 105 Brown Road.
LONDON, March 1 (Reuters) Dior of London jolted a salon full of dignified clients here today with a spring show that was primarily a pants parade.
WESTON, Conn., March 1 Devil's Den, a wild, 477-acre tract of "unspoiled Connecticut," has been given to the Connecticut chapter of the Nature Conservancy as a nature preserve.
Horses arrived by plane, via nearby John F. Kennedy International Airport; train and van yesterday at Belmont Park and Aqueduct.
RIO DE JANEIRO, March 1 Brazil's great mass of unskilled workers got some relief today from rising prices through 30 per cent increases in minimum wages.

WASHINGTON, March 1 The United States will place a nuclear reprocessing plant under limited international inspection, Dr. Glenn T. Seaborg, Chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, said today. The step is symbolic of the United States efforts to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons.

In the financial program that Mayor Lindsay will reveal to the public tonight he will ask large new taxing powers. But before the Legislature will grant them, the City Counci controlled by Democrats must join in the Mayor's request. A lot of politics is mixed up in this Albany demand for prior action here; but the demand is reasonable nevertheless.
RIO DE JANEIRO, March 2 The Government announced today the terms of its contract for the purchase of the telephone system of the Brazilian Traction, Light and Power Company.

WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) John W. Gardner, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, was told bluntly by Senators today they would not support Administration plans to reduce sharply the impacted areas school funds.
RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, March 2 Washington has agreed to resume the sale of "nonlethal" military equipment to India and Pakistan.
WASHINGTON, March 2--President Johnson asked Congress today to establish a Cabinet-level department of transportation to plan for an efficient national trasportation system.

Dr. Austin J. McCaffrey has been elected a director of Channing Shares, Inc., Channing Income Fund, Inc., and Chanring Securities, Inc., Thomas A. Martin, president of the Channing group of mutual funds announced yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, March 2 The National General Corporation reported today that it had sold its 50 per cent interest in several California real estate holdings for $5,637,000 to Sunset International Petroleum Corporation, which owns the other 50 per cent.

A new investment company that will supervise industrial and commercial enterprises throughout the United States and commercial real estate outside New York City, has been formed by a group led by Roger D. Malkin and Lawrence A. Wien. It will operate as the WM Capital and Management Corporation.

NUTLEY, N.J., March 2 Mr. and Mis. William Schmidt of Nutley and Riverdale have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eleanor Schmidt, to Thomas Jennings Winans, son of Mrs. Laurance C. Winans of Bronxville, N.Y., and the late Mr. Winans.
WASHINGTON, March 2 Following is the text of a statement by Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara analyzing allegations concerning the readiness of United States military forces:
The Board of Education voted yesterday to extend the school year by two days despite the threat of a boycott by the United Federation of Teachers.
A step toward obtaining Federal funds for "a massive attack on slums" here was announced jointly yesterday by Mayor Lindsay and Mrs. Constance Baker Motley, Borough President of Manhattan.
WASHINGTON, March 2 President Johnson pinned the National Security Medal today on the man who broke the Japanese code 25 years ago.

WASHINGTON, March 2 A major challenge to the Byrd Democratic organization of Virginia developed today when former State Senator Armistead L. Boothe announced his candidacy for the Senate seat held by Harry F. Byrd Jr.

WASHINGTON, March 2 Vice President Humphrey defended the Administration's Vietnam policy before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today, shortly after House Republican leaders said Communist aggressors were being encouraged by "the deep division within the Democratic party."

WASHINGTON, March 2 President Johnson was hewing to the line of his soaring concept that the national economy can provide simultaneously for an American utopia and whatever may be needed for a war of incalculable costs, duration and geographical scope when he submitted his health and education programs yesterday to a Congress in process of approving a supplemental, appropriation of $4.8 billion to finance the military conflict in Vietnam.
WASHINGTON, March 2 Chief Justice Earl Warren questioned today Attorney General Nicholas deB. Katzenbach's ruling barring the burial of a Communist in Arlington National Cemetery.
SKIERS may find themselves digging deeper into their stretch pants next winter because of an increased price for lift tickets. The reason will, be the familiar one rising costs.

BONN, March 2 West Germany will not apply for admission to the United Nations and will reject any deal whereby both West Germany and East Germany would be elected, a Foreign Ministry source said tonight.
TRENTON, March 2 New Jersey's proposed new gun-control law and its chief sponsor, Attorney General Arthur J. Sills, were booed today by sportsmen and gun collectors.

The Citizens Committee for Children of New York, one of the city's most influential civic groups condemmed the public welfare system yesterday as "a monster bureaucracy that dehumanizes its clients." The committee called for major changes in its administration by the city, state and Federal governments.
BERNE, March 2 (AP) Prof. Friedrich Georg Houtermans, a noted research physicist, died here yesterday at the age of 63.

WEST NEWTON, Mass., March 2 Mr. and Mrs. David N. Bedrick have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Judith Lee Bedrick, to Leon Mir, son of Mrs. Faiwish Mir of New York and the late Mr. Mir.
The New York Chamber of Commerce rejected yesterday almost all of Mayor Lindsay's tax package, including the proposal for a graduated personal income tax and a corporate income tax.
The New York City Housing Authority will receive bids for the sale of $33,295,000 in temporary loan notes next Tuesday. Bids will be opened at 1 P.M. in the office of the authority, 250 Broadway.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., March 2 Robert Henrich of 52 Meisel Avenue, former traffic manager for Cannon Mills, Inc. of New York City, died yesterday at Overlook Hospital, Summit, at the age of 69. He had retired in 1960 after 43 years' service with the New York firm.

WASHINGTON, March 2 (UPI) A Federal appeals court upheld today a controversial Civil Aeronautics Board ruling that the all-cargo airlines should be given the exclusive right to carry "blocked space" shipments.

MILWAUKEE, March 2 (AP) The former secretarytreasurer of the Milwaukee Braves testified today that the club showed cash profits in 1963 and 1964 part of the period in which the team's owners contend they lost $3.5-million.
Montreal was announced yesterday as the latest refuge of the embattled Cassius ClayErnie Terrell heavyweight title bout, shortly after it was officially run out of Chicago.
Former Chief of Detectives Philip J. Walsh described Chief Inspector Sanford D. Garelik yesterday as a man "I wouldn't work a minute for." He also criticized Mayor Lindsay's anticrime task force.

(AP) The American Bankers Association said today it can see no compelling reason for the controller of the currency to continue to be a member of the board of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 2 (AP) Herbert Rice Penney, brother of J.C. Penney, died in University Hospital today after a long illness. He was 79 years old.

ACCRA, Ghana, March 2 Ghana's new military government today dealt the Communist world a major setback in Africa by ordering the expulsion of all Soviet, Chinese Communist and East German teachers and technicians.
The possibility of high-rise apartment buildings along the Hudson River below the Cloisters was killed yesterday by the City Planning Commission.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., March 2 Rent Raas, former president of Occo International, Inc., of Jersey City, chemical exporters, died of a heart attack on Monday in his home at 32 South Munn Avenue. He was 72 years old.
Expansion and modernization programs requiring capital outlays of more than $400-million were announced yesterday by a number of companies.
LA JOLLA, Calif., March 2 (UPI) Retired Vice Adm. William R. Munroe, an early day submariner and the commander of the Fourth Fleet in World War II, died yesterday in his home here at the age of 79.
The United States announced yesterday that seven scientific experiments would be conducted by its next Venus probe.
Polished, but not deep artistry is the outstanding ingredient in the singing of Flore Wend, a soprano born in Switzerland and trained in France, who made her New York debut at Town Hall last night.

POMPANO BEACH, Fla., March 2When the New York Mets were seeking a successor to Casey Stengel as manager, it's no secret that they cast covetous eyes in the direction of Gil Hodges in Washington. He had everything they wanted in one large economy-sized package.
The controversy over the size and location of the proposed Redwood National Park has produced an odd political pattern on Capitol Hill.

An actor who has appeared in many ads of a major New York bank couldn't get a loan from that bank or any other he tried. A Harlem resident who earns a nominal in come and has little in the way of tangible assets, found it impossible to borrow a vitally needed small sum of money from the usual legal sources.

QUITE a few Goethe-derived "Faust" scores are in the repertory. The great pixy has stimulated composers ever since it was published. But there is one "Faust" score from a major composer that has been a history-book item: Schumann's setting of scenes from the play. One has read about it, but has not encountered the piece in a lifetime of concert-going.
The General Aniline and Film Corporation submitted a merger proposal yesterday to the management of the Nopco Chemical Company that would involve more than $55-million of stock.

TORONTO, March 2 (UPI) Jean Beliveau of Montreal scored the 380th goal of his National Hockey League career tonight to become the third highest scorer in the league's history as the Canadiens and the Toronto Maple Leafs played to a 3-3 tie.
WATERTOWN, N.Y., March 2 Governor Rockefeller said today that he strongly favored lowering the voting age in the state to 18.
MOORESTOWN, N.J., March 2 There was a good reason why the Anderson children Wendell Jr., 11 years old; Helen, 9, and Tom, 6 never made it to school today.
The nation's electric power production rose 8.2 per cent in the week ended Feb. 26, from the level in the corresponding 1965 week, it was reported yesterday by the Edison Electric Institute.
The J.C. Penney Company has registered the highest annual sales and earnings in its 63-year history.
WASHINGTON, March 2 The Senate Banking Committee approved today without dissent the nomination of Andrew F. Brimmer as a member of the Federal Reserve Board.
Directors of the Household Finance Corporation proposed in Chicago yesterday a 2-for-1 stock Split of the common shares. Plans to raise the guarterly dividend on the new shares were also announced.

JERSEY CITY, March 2 Long Island University was knocked out of a tie for first in he Metropolitan Collegiate Basketball Conference tonight when the Blackbirds were upset by St. Peter's College, 92-85, in an overtime game at the Jersey City Armory.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., March 2 Norman D. Valentine, executive officer of the New Jersey Legalized Games of Chance Controls Commission, died today at St. Michael's Hospital, Newark, He was 61 years old and lived at 7 Timber Acres Road.

President Johnson's message to Congress yesterday on transportation appears to promise a concerted application of modern technology to one of the American merchant marine's basic problems its inability, because of higher operating costs, to compete effectively with foreien shipping.
The American Stock Exchange retreated again along a broad front yesterday although the number of declines were less than on Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, March 2 A five-minute rocket flight has discovered the first two X-ray galaxies and doubled the number of known X-ray sources in the universe, Navy scientists announced today.
The spot rate on the British pound continued to decline on foreign exahange markets here yesterday, closing at $2.7987, 6 points off from the Tuesday level.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 2 Alabama Negroes, many of them barred from even voting a year ago, are seeking elective offices in every county in which their race is in the majority.
NORWALK, Conn, March 2 An effort to create a "historical district" around the Norwalk Green, which dates to Colonial days, has failed by a narrow margin.
BOSTON, March 2 (UPI)The Boston Celtics opened both halves with scoring surges tonight and coasted to a 140-104 victory over the New York Knickerbockers in a NationaL Basketball Association game.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 2 East Germany's application for admission to the United Nations suggested that the cause of peace in Europe would be served if West Germany had full membership too.
DURBAN, South Africa, March 2 (Reuters)-Cathy Ferguson of Burbank, Calif., beat Karen Muir of South Africa tonight in the 220-yard free-style event at the South African swimming championships.
BRUSSELS, March 2 Belgium's political crisis deepened today when Paul-Willem Segers, a Social Christian, abandoned his efforts to form a new government.

MIAMI BEACH, March 2 David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, told leaders of the women's and children's coat industry today that a large collective effort to promote the sale of their product was long overdue.

AUSTIN, Tex., March 2 Gov. John B. Connally of Texas today denounced as a "great disservice to the people of Texas" a Department of Justice order that the Federal Bureau of Investigation monitor a special registration of voters that opens tomorrow.
William Seabrook has retired as director of public information in the city's department of Marine and Aviation.
GUATEMALA, March 2 The military regime here has rejected suggestions that it accepted "foreign influence or interference" in domestic politics.

PRINCESS IRENE GALITZINE, the Italian couturier who was born in Russia and has been on the move ever since, whirled into the lobby of the Sheraton-East Motel yesterday morning to dash off a few cables. Every hair of her Pierre of Revlon coiffure was neatly in place

For the first time in the seven-week trial of the three men aecused of the murder of Malcolm X, the prosecution suggested yesterday that the killing had been ordered by the national headquarters of the Black Muslims.

Two Brooklyn residents were fined in Criminal Court yesterday for possession of contraband, tax-free cigarettes. They had been arrested in a roundup by 40 special agents and examiners of the State Department of Taxation and Finance and detectives of the prosecutor's rackets squad.
On Wall Street they were talking yesterday about Mario Procaccino, George Schaefer and what the stock market was doing. But mostly it was about what the stock market was doing and why.

The move to pay the "magic" 5 per cent on individual savings certificates of nine month's maturity or more spread to three more New York City banks yesterday the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, the Chemical Bank New York Trust and the Bank of New York.

WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) The Jewish War Veterans of the U.S.A. said today the Soviet Union had denied a travel visa to the group's national commander, Milton A. Waldor, only a few days before a long-planned visit to Moscow.
DAKAR, Senegal, March 2 (Reuters) Former President Nkrumah of Ghana arrived in Guinea today and told a cheering crowd, "I am on my way back to Ghana."

HOUSTON, Tex., March 2 (AP) Separate memorial services were held in churches near the Manned Spacecraft Center here today for Elliot M. See Jr. and Air Force Maj. Charles A. Bassett 2d, who were killed Monday when their T-38 jet trainer crashed into a building at the McDonnell Aircraft Corporation plant in St. Louis. The two men were to have manned the Gemini 9 spacecraft in May.

WASHINGTON, March 2 Bill's wife phoned and said Bill was down with an acute case of galloping futility and needed somebody to buck him up. There was nothing to do but drop by. It was depressing. The house smelled of doom and decaying resolution.
Some persons have the knack of finding their silver linings in the clouds of others.

IF one can imagine a Eugene O'Neill younger as an artist than O'Neill ever was, then "Laughwind" is a very early, crude play that such a youth might have written in the present day. Tom Waters's drama, which opened last night at the Off Broadway Bouwerie Lane, is overblown and sophomoric; but it has intense honesty, some gropings toward the tragic depth of human character and the courage to attempt large-scale language.

SAIGON, Thursday, March 3 (AP) Vietcong gun squads attacked a Shell Oil Company tanker near Saigon today, wounded 10 of the crew and set the ship afire in the canal leading to the big Nhabe fuel dump.

WASHINGTON, March 2 Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara insisted today that the armed forces were not overextended or suffering shortages but were "fully capable" of meeting their commitments anywhere.
Drivers of a school bus system that serves 6,000 Bronx public and parochial pupils went on strike last night.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 2 Casey Stengel was missing, and so were Warren Spahn, Eddie Stanley, Don Hoffner and Jesse Owens. But 51 other New York Mets opened formal spring training today under the direction of Wes Westrum, who told them that there was gold "at the end of that rainbow."

While a Consolidated Edison Company plant superintendent was being tried, for an air-pollution vioiation yesterday, the company announced it was going to buy more natural gas to ease its recurring smoke problems.
Louis H. Mueller has resigned as chairman of Continental Air Lines, a post he has held since 1937. The resignation of the 70year-old executive became effective Monday.
BERLIN, March 2 One hundred Polish girls are scheduled to go to East Germany March 15 to work at a syntheticfiber plant in Guben, a town on the Neisse River.

Leon I. Ross, against whom the Government has obtained a $2.5-million judgment for income taxes owed, has been deported from Nassau, the Bahamas, where he had operated a securities investment business since 1953.
ALBANY, March 2 The Assembly passed by unanimous vote today a bill that would require a financial accounting in every piece of literature seeking gifts for charity.

HIBBING, Minn., March 2 (AP) The defending champion Wisconsin North Dakota and California were the only unbeaten rinks in the 1966 United States Men's Curling Association championship after the fourth of the eleven rounds were completed last night.

PARIS The French often do not see what is spring ing up in their own back yard of fashion until an outsider strolls in and points it out. Andre Courreges was a historic example. The Americans were the first to pick up his futuristic fashions.

Last November's power blackout has spurred a sharp increase in sales of jet-powered peaking and emergency electricity-generating units, according to the Worthington Corporation, a large manufacturer of such equipment.

Vincent Fanelli, solo harpist of the New York Symphony Orchestra under Dr. Walter Damrosch from 1908 to 1911 and later of the Philadelphia Orchestra under Leopold Stokowski, died yesterday in his home at 5 Hardy Place, Great KillS, S.I. He was 82 years old.
BOSTON, March 2 With some of the trappings of a peace treaty signing, Gov. John A. Volpe placed his signature today on a $180-million tax program for Massachusetts.
WASHINGTON, March 2 Forty-four days after a B-52 bomber accident over Spain, the United States acknowledged today that one of its multimegaton hydrogen bombs was missing.

The stewards said the management asked them for permission to cancel all betting on the Flamingo, and they replied that such permission could be gained only from the chairman of the commission, Judge Louie Bandel.

OTTAWA, March 2 Canadian Government leaders are vexed and Opposition leaders angered by published reports that the United States Defense Department began an investigation of Quebec's separatist movement while researching revolutionary, processes in various parts of the world.
Met with officers of the Investment Bankers Association; attended swearing in of Lee C. White as Federal Power Commission chairman; presented the National Security Medal to Frank B. Rowlett;
"THIS," Adelaide de Menil said as she pointed to four empty drawers, "is my dining table. Or what's left of it."

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 2 Mrs. Sydney L. Throckmorton has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Nanette Jacquelyn Throckmorton, to Robert Erwin Stickney. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Alan C. Stickney of Rancho Bernardo, Calif.

THE actions of two California quail hunters re sulted in the rescue of onefortieth of the world population of California condors recently, according to the bulletin of the Wildlife Management Institute.

President Johnson's message on transportation policy offers a modest start on a mammoth problem. The chief reason why the United States has never developed a coherent transportation policy is that it has never had a policy maker who determined the priorities and possessed the authority to carry them out. The various private companies airlines, railroads, truckers, barge operators, ocean shippers have resisted such centralization.

WASHINGTON, March 2 United States forces in South Vietnam require more than a thousand times the amount of supplies needed by the Vietcong to sustain the present level of warfare, the Government indicated today.
Leaders of the Congress of Racial Equality vowed yesterday to continue community pressure on the Police Department and Mayor Lindsay until "vicious, racist acts by the police are ended in this city."

LOS ANGELES, March 2 A contract to acquire 1.4 trillion cubic feet of additional gas reserves was announced today by Howard Boyd, chairman of the El Paso Natural Gas Com pany. The gas will come from the Delaware-Val Verde Basin of West Texas, he said.
ARCADIA, Calif., March 2 (UPI) Zooron rallied to beat the favorite, Hoist Bar, by a nose today in the $23,050 Sierra Madre Handicap at Santa Anita.
Presentation of the two-hour television production of Arthur Miller's "Death of a Salesman," which the Columbia Broadcasting System had scheduled for April 3, has been postponed two weeks.
ANKARA, Turkey, March 2 Damages estimated at $3.3 million resulted last night from the Istanbul harbor fire caused by the collision of a Soviet tanker and a Soviet freighter.

A group jointly managed by the Harris Trust and Savings Bank and the Chase Manhattan bank purchased yesterday $8,255,000 of general obligation bonds from Fort Worth, Tex. The noncallable issue is rated A by Moody's Investors Service and AA by the Standard Poor's Corporation.
WASHINGTON, March 2 Mayor Lindsay strongly endorsed today President Johnson's new approach to the problems of city slums, but he said the money requested for the program was not nearly enough.
At dusk, when the writers have left and the room is quiet, Martha Foley may peer out the window facing East 19th Street and recall similar afternoons when spring burst upon Boulevard St. Michel.

A new company, park Avenue Imports, which will market imported wines and liqueurs and other distilled products, has been formed by Joseph E. Seagram Sons, Inc., Edgar M. Bronfman, president of Seagram, announced yesterday.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 114.5 on Tuesday from 114.7 on Monday.

MIAMI, March 2 In as unobtrusive a way as possible, at first merely by a notation on the mimeographed sheets containing the entries for the fol lowing day, the Hialeah Race Track management made it known today that one of the most famous races in the nation, tomorrow's $136,400 Flamingo for 3-year-olds, would bel a nonwagering event.
Fayette S. Dunn, president of the Otis Elevator Company, has been elected to the board of the General Cable Corporation, it was announced here yesterday.
TORONTO, March 2 (AP) T. Eaton Co., Ltd., Canada's largest department store group, has announced plans for a $260million development project in downtown Toronto.
A $64-million Navy contract has been awarded to the electric boat division of the General Dynamics Corporation for construction of three dock landing ships.
The Boston Maine Railroad made its best showing last year since 1957, the road announced yesterday.

SAIGON, Thursday, March 3 (Reuters) William P. Bundy, Assistant Secretary of State for Far Eastern Affairs, arrived today as the flow of highranking United States Government visitors to South Vietnam in the wake of Last month's Honolulu conference continued. Mr. Bundy flew to Saigon from the Philippines, where he had been presiding over a meeting of heads of United States diplomatic missions in Southeast Asia.

A special study panel of labor, municipal and public representatives is reported to favor the establishment of a new, independent administrative agency to deal with relations between the city and its nearly 200,000 organized employes.
WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) Lee C. White was sworn is today as chairman of the Federal Power Commission and President Johnson said the job was going to be in skillful, fair and just hands.

John B. Oakes, editorial page editor of The New York Times, was among nine winners of the 18th annual George Polk Memorial Awards announced yesterday for outstanding journal istic achievement during 1965.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange fell slightly yesterday as the market showed practically no reaction to the preceding day's economic review by the Chancellor of the Exchequer, James Callaghan.
Faculty organization from the City University have come out in strong support of Chancellor Albert H. Bowker in His conflict with the Board of Higher Education.

WESTBURY, L.L., March 2 Roosevelt Raceway's first of three meetings in this longest season of harness racing ends tomorrow night. Weather per mitting, upward of 30,000 devotees of the horse-and-buggy sport are expected to turn out.

Earnings of the RockwellStandard Corporation are expected to reach 75 to 80 cents a share in the first quarter, a rise of at least 30 per cent over a year before, W.P. Rockwell Jr., told stockholders at a regional meeting at the Commodore Hotel yesterday.
LOS ANGELES, March 3 Everybody knows that smog is obnoxious. But just how detrimental is it to the average man's health?

WASHINGTON, March 2 The Food, and Drug Administration ordered one long-acting sulfa drug off the market today and directed the manufacturers of certain other Types to change their labels to include a sharp warning against possibly lethal side effects.
ALBANY, March 2 A proposal to liberalize New York State's 83-year-old abortion law will be considered at a public hearing here on Monday.

ROSLYN, L. I., March 2--Battle lines are forming in this usually placid North Shore community over a plan to raze a building designed as a memorial to World War I veterans and to replace it with a parking lot.
An argument with a Meter Maid produced nothing but trouble yesterday for Jerome Boonshoft, a 54-year-old Washington Heights drugstore manager.
CIF, Inc., international investment and merchant banking concern, announced here yesterday the election of J.R.N. Shirreff as president and a director, succeeding Charles H. Baudoin.

MIAMI, March 2 Kelso, Mrs. Richard C. du Pont's famous champion who holds the world record for thoroughbred earnings, received the applause today, but the victory went to an invader from the Argentine.

PARIS, March 2 The United States Embassy was attacked early tonight by a group of demonstrators hurling ink bottles and shouting "U.S.A. assassins!" apparently in protest against the United States' policies in Vietnam.
WASHINGTON, March 2 Following is the text of President Johnson's message to Congress today on transportation:

THE veteran British master and chess writer Robert Wade received the "best game" prize during the' last Ilford Congress for his victory as White in a Pirc Defense against the British expert M.J. Franklin.

HAVERFORD, Pa., March 2 Mrs. Baba Lewis of Boston fought off four match points at 14-17 in the third game today in reaching the final round of the United States senior squash racquets championship at Merion Cricket Club.
BRUSSELS, March 2 Foreign Minister, Paul-Henri Spaak warned today that time was working against Britain's entry into the European Common Market.

CHICAGO, March 2 (UPI) Bobby Hull of the Chicago Black Hawks scored a recordtying 50th goal tonight as the Hawks beat the Detroit Red Wings, 5-4. Hull has 13 games left in which to break the mark for goals in a single season.

PARIS A series of major mergers in Europe reflects the growing anxiety over competing with the international giants particularly the American ones-but also shows the difficulty in doing something about it.

The New York Rangers, angered by the roughhouse tactics of the Boston Bruins in the second period, unleashed a three-goal barrage in the final 20 minutes of action to score a 5-3 victory in Madison Square Garden last night.
America's commitment in Vietnam has led to a special kind 'of "escalation" here at

Brig, Gen. John H. Hay Jr., U.S.A., commander of the United States Berlin Brigade, and Mrs. Hay of Berlin have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Elsabeth Hay, to Capt. Peter Hamilton Ward, U.S.A. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Ward of Orchard Park, N.Y., and Delray Beach, Fla.
A student can't go wrong in a new physical science program for junior high schools. And he can't be right either.
WASHINGTON, March 2 Mayor Lindsay has asked the tax expert he imported from Congress, Murray Drabkin, to head the full-time office his administration is opening in Washington.
PHILADELPHIA, March 2 Dr. Glen Darwin Camp, professor of statistics and operations research at the University of Pennsylvania, died Monday in his home here at the age of 61.

LONDON, March 2 Arthur J. Goldberg walked out of a British Broadcasting Corporation studio after having refused to make a scheduled appearance on the current-affairs television program "Twenty-four Hours." At the beginning of the program it was announced that the United States delegates to the United Nations would appear.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 2-Until further notice, Ruben Amaro will be the regular shortstop for the New York Yankees. The club intends 'to open the season with Amaro occupying the position held primarily by three men in the past 25 years-Phil Rizzuto, Gil McDougald and Tony Kubek.
Western Union has adopted a new trademark the first official corporate symbol in the company's 115-year history.

CREWELWORK, cross-stitching and quilting, far from becoming lost arts, are reported to be enjoying a rise in popularity for home decoration. Two new books on needlework have recently been published, both filled with imaginative contemporary and traditional ideas.

Boston's nonprofit Theater Company has received $14,800 from the Rockefeller Foundation to evaluate a number of new works and do staged readings. Ten thousand dollars are to be used for financing tryouts and $4,800 for readings.
NEW DELHI, March 2 Mizo tribesmen have made a daring attack on the Indian administration in their district in the hills of eastern India.

WASHINGTON, March (2 (UPI) Sixteen Congressional Republicans proposed today that the United States might give up some of its sovereignty in the interest of forming a federal union with its NATO allies.

MIAMI, March 2 (AP) Prosecutor Gerald Kogan charged today that the defense in the Mossler trial was "using the oldest technique in the world placing everybody in the world on trial but the defendants."
PHILADELPHIA, March 2 (AP) Seventh-ranked St. Joseph's crushed Providence, the nation's eighth-ranked team, 8667, tonight in the second game of a Palestra basketball doubleheader.
NEW HAVEN, March 2 Bill Clarke's goal at 16:57 of the third period gave Brown a 7-6 Ivy League hockey victory over Yale here tonight.

THERE are some situations in duplicate bridge in which both sides can see triumph and disaster looming on the horizon. The complicated deal shown in the diagram is a case in point. It was played in the recent New York sectional tournament, and was reported by Mrs. Ruth Sands Bentley of New York, who held the North cards.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, March 2--Indonesian students defied a presidential ban on demonstrations again today and carried an effigy of Foreign Minister Subandrio through the streets of Jakarta.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 2 An extreme leftist program for the new Syrian Cabinet was announced today by Al Baath, a Damascus newspaper controlled by the junta that seized power in Syria Feb. 23.
The Lindsay administration has asked the state for a sixmonth delay on construction of a parkway through Staten Island's green belt area, to permit study of five alternate routes.
CHICAGO, March 2 A corps of 50 city inspectors began today a door-to-door survey in three West Side areas of Chicago.

The Imperial Commodities Corporation has leased a total of 21,000 square feet in the new building at 110 Wall Street, near Front Street. In the new quarters the trading concern will consolidate its executive offices, now at 555 Madison Avenue, its coffee, spice and tea divisions, now at 10 Hanover Square, and its rubber division at 1 Liberty Street.
Harry E. Hanes, an appraiser, died yesterday at his home at 63 Wendover Road, in Forest Hills Gardens, Queens. He was 85 years old.
SAIGON, March 2 In the first two months of 1966, the United States suffered more than 4,300 casualties in the Vietnamese war. American casualties for all of last year were under 7,000.

ACCRA, March 2 (Reuters) Ghana's former Foreign Minister, Alex Quaison-Sackey, declared his support of the country's new leaders when he returned to Ghana today, but he was placed in protective custody.

IF anyone was defeated at Vatican Council II, it was Alfredo Cardinal Ottaviani, head of the Holy Office, official guardian of Roman Catholic orthodoxy, president of the all-important Theological Commission, fiery spokesman for the council's intrepid conservatives and, in his own

WINNIPEG, Man., March 2 (AP) Two men driving a service truck stolen from Air Canada escaped with 12 cases of gold bullion last night from Winnipeg International Airport. An unofficial estimate put the value of the bullion at $200,000, although mining sources said it could be as high as $650,000.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 2 Nikolai T. Fedorenko, the Soviet representative, has bitterly criticized last week's action by Akira Matsui of Japan, then Security Council President, in calling for efforts toward peace talks on Vietnam.
The American Stock Exchange yesterday reported the changes carried below in the share holdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of listed companies.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 2 The California prohibition on pay television was declared unconstitutional today by the State Supreme Court in a 6-1 decision. Pay-TV was outlawed in a statewide vote in November, 1964.

OTTAWA, March 2 (Canadian Press) Prof. Staughton Lynd, the Yale University professor who defied the State Department by visiting North Vietnam, tonight urged the Canadian Government to join its colleagues on the International Control Commission for Vietnam in an investigation of United States actions during the Vietnam Christmas peace offensive.

John Ogdon, the 28-year-old English pianist who made his debut here two years ago, is both a serious musician and an exceptional virtuoso. If the latter aspect of his playing won out in his recital in Carnegie Hall last night, it was still a pleasurable event, for the young artist got around the piano with a speed and brilliance that seemed nothing short of miraculous.

TOKYO, March 2 Highranking educators of Japan and the United States began a sixday meeting here today to plan how their two countries, widely separated by geography and divergent cultural patterns, could work together through their respective universities for greater mutual understanding.
AUGUSTA, Me., March 2 (AP) Secretary of State Kenneth M. Curtis said today the wets, rather than the drys, had won last week's Sunday liquor sales referendum in Maine.
Net earnings of the Transamerica Corporation rose last year to $42,417,677, or $2.16 a share, from $39,557,375, or $2.04 a share, in 1964.
CHICAGO, March 2 (AP) James W. Clement announced his resignation from the Chicago Board of Education today, contending Superintendent Benjamin C. Willis is running a "dictatorial administration."

THE Hungarian National Ensemble, which returned last night to the New York City Center, is an ingratiating troupe. Its program, apart from the finale, is completely different from its first appearance in January, but it is the same mixture as before.

MALVERNE, L.I., March 2 The names of children who have been attending private classes in homes in this community for the last three days in protest against an integration order were presented today to the Superintendent of Schools.
PORTLAND, Ore., March 2 Represeatative Robert B. Duncan announced his candidacy today for the Democratic nomtnation for United States Senator.

Copper prices spiraled upward again, rising close to their recently made life-of-contract highs. The factors continued the same tight domestic supply conditions, the 58-day-old Chilean strike and a union-inspired production slowdown in Zambia.
The Department of Marine and Aviation is taking a hindsight look at the Pan Am Building Heliport to determine whether it should remain in operation or be closed as a hazard.
Grey Advertising, Inc., was smoking more yesterday and certainly enjoying it more. The agency was assigned an additional $15-million in billing by the P. Lorillard Company to handle Kent cigarettes.

A syndicate jointly managed by Blyth Co., Inc. the First Boston Corporation, Salomon Brothers Hutzler and Dean Witter Co. announced yesterday an offering of $25-million Arkansas Power and Light Compuny first-mortgage bonds due in 1996. The issue, with 5 per cent coupons, wad priced at 102,167 to yield 5.60 per cent. The group was awarded the issue with a bid of 100,7777.

Eminent educators, including at least two deans of Eastern universities, prominent theatrical personalities and officers of the armed services all homosexual have been the victims of an extortion ring that has operated throughout the nation for nearly 10 years.
LONDON, March 2 "I am not looking for trouble. I am looking for revenue." With these words Chancellor of the Exchequer Winston Churchill introduced a 5 per cent general betting tax in 1926.
CARBONDALE, Pa., March 2 Mrs. Ellen Gordon McCann, a retired New York public school teacher, died yesterday in St. Joseph's Hospital here. She was 84 years old and the widow of Andrew McCann.
WASHINGTON, March 2 (UPI) The House overwhelmingly approved legislation today that would establish 45 new judgeships in Federal appeals and district courts.

WASHINGTON, March 2 (UPI) The nation's space agency launched two rocket probes today for simultaneous studies of the upper atmosphere at various altitudes and the influence on it of radiation from the sun.
The American Civil Liberties Union advocated yesterday draft exemptions for those who conscientiously object to a particular war although they do not oppose war in general.
Watchmen of the Port of New York have voted, 333 to 239, to accept a four-year contract that they rejected narrowly on Jan. 26.

Alfredo Cardinal Ottaviani, the leading spokesman for the conservative viewpoint in the Roman Catholic Church, will be named head of a reorganized papal commission to study the church's traditional teaching on contraception.
WASHINGTON, March 2 A leading group of waterway operators accused the President's Council of Economic Advisers today of bias in making recommendations on national transportation policies.
New-car sales slipped almost 3 per cent in February, reports from the nation's major manufacturers indicated yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, March 2 In defiance of court and union orders, longshoremen in the Post of Philadelphia continued their wildcat strike through a fifth day today, despite a fine of $100,000 for each day they stay out
NEW HAVEN, March 2 A Connecticut Superior Court judge has ordered a grand jury investigation into reports of alleged payoffs for the illegal return of suspended drivers' licenses.

SEOUL, South Korea, March 2-United States and South Korean military officials are watching closely for any sign of intensified military pressure from North Korea in retaliation for the stepped-up warfare in Vietnam.
A wage settlement involving 25,000 plant employes was reached last night between the New York Telephone Company and the Communitations Workers of America.
LONDON, March 2 The elderly politician is rubbing his bruised shins as angry youngsters stand behind him surveying the damage.
The Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation announced yesterday that it was quitting the nail business because it could not compete with imports.
WEEHAWKEN, N.J., March 2 At 1:03 this morning water in the Oradell Reservoir spilled over the top of the dam for the first time since the spring of 1964.

A will filed on behalf of a Protestant scion of German nobility has left half of a reported $500,000 estate to Cardinal Spellman for Roman Catholic charities and the other half to the United Hias Service to aid Jewish immigrants.

PENSACOLA, Fla., March 2 Bruce Devlin has returned to the pro golf tour. The slim 28-year-old Australian will make his first tournament start in this country after a six months' lapse in the Pensacola open tomorrow.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., March 2 (AP) Ara Parseghian has signed a new six-year contract as head football coach at the University of Notre Dame, Edward W. Krause, the athletic director, announced today.
HILLSBOROUGH, N.J., March 2 (AP) Rickcliffe Decker a designer and driver of racing cars, died yesterday in Somerset Hospital, Somerville. He was 65 years old.
The Wankel rotating combustion engine, which has intrigued engineers since its invention in Germany 10 years ago, is now going to be developed commercially in the United States.

The Cumberland Chemical Corporation, a subsidiary of the Air Reduction Company, announced yesterday the development of a series of vinyl resins that, the company, said, offers superior gloss, color and clarity in vinyl plastics.
WASHINGTON, March 2 The Supreme Court was told today that some questioning by the police is necessary to help clear innocent suspects, as well as to convict the guilty.

THE restoration of the poodle to its original use as a retriever of waterfowl has been the subject of more than usual attention this winter. Half a dozen members of the William Penn Poodle Club have started a movement they hope will lead to a national poodle retriever club.

ALBANY, March 2 The ornate Senate Chamber, traditionally off-limits to cameras, will be opened to permit television coverage of the debate on proposed controversial changes in the state divorce law introduced this year.
Mrs. Sara Kotulanski Schweber, former general secretary of the Clothing Workers of Poland, died yesterday at Beth Abraham Home, 612 Allerton Avenue, the Bronx. She was 90 years old.

Retailers and producers, who in their competitive zeal sometimes forget that it is the consumer who calls the turns in the distribution process, were reminded yesterday of this fact in forceful and even accusing terms.
Senator Robert F. Kennedy, the father of nine children, has financially adopted a 9-year-old Peruvian; Jose Serrano, the Foster Parents Plan, Inc., disclosed yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, March 2 Directors and their crews are working around the clock this week often called the cruelest of the year here to complete their pictures before Monday, a day they call "Blue Monday." Millions of dollars depend on the outcome.

A recruiting drive for a "Committee of 100,000" American Telephone and Telegraph Company stockholders to intervene in the Federal Communications Commission investigation was outlined yesterday by Benjamin A. Javits, president of United Shareowners of America, Inc.

The electoral campaign in the Dominican Republic has, for all practical purposes, begun. Legally, it is still necessary for Provisional President Garcia Godoy to make an official declaration opening the campaign and then for the Electoral Commission to register the parties and candidates. However, the moratorium on electioneering ended March 1, which is 90 days before the June 1 date set by the Institutional Act for the election.

PARIS, March 2 An audience of second nighters, composed of Comedie-Francaise subscribers, greeted Eugene Ionesco's latest play, "La Soif et la Faim" ("Thirst and Hunger") with a storm of disapproval tonight.

A white physician was voted a member yesterday of the Manhattan Central Medical Society, an interracial group that is predominantly Negro. The action by the society's executive committee ended an investigation of it by the City Commission on Human Rights.

Books recounting key voyages to the New World and preparing for the opening of the country's Northwest Territory drew many prominent rare-book dealers yesterday to an auction of duplicate books from the John Carter Brown Library of Brown University. The sale of rare Americana was held at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.

Manuel F. Cohen, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said last night that the government agency had historically been "in constant friction" with Wall Street, but noted that this had, on the whole, been a good thing for both the S.E.C. and the securities industry.

Hyman E. Mintz, the former Sullivan County Assemblyman who was convicted here last Friday of conspiring to bribe a detective to obtain grand jury information, demanded yesterday release from City Prison, where he is awaiting sentence on the misdemeanor conviction.
ALBANY, March 2 A preview of the bitter fight in store for Mayor Lindsay's tax package unfolded in the Assembly today.

THE fashion industry got a chance yesterday to do a little snapping at the hand that feeds it. "Is fashion a game of follow the leader?" four designers and a lingerie company president asked retailers gathered in the Grand Ballroom of the New York Hilton for a three day meeting of the American Management Association.
W.R. Grace Co. announced yesterday that its request For tenders of as many as 700,000 shares of stock of the Ruberoid Company, at $50 a share, had been extended to 5 P.M. on March 11.
Stock prices lost ground yesterday after the market was unable to sustain an early rebound from Tuesday's downturn. Trading continued at a brisk rate.
THE New Squares are merchants of instant triteness. They are driving serious avant-garde novelists mad. Their poaching particularly in the field of the novel poses a problem in inflation.
A five-year-o1d dream of establishing a performing arts center on a Missouri campus is about to come true for a Roman Catholic nun.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) Legislation to provide for building a prototype of a commercial, supersonic transport plane without using Federal fund was introduced today by Representative Frank T. Bow, Republican of Ohio. He is a member of the House Appropriations Committee.

Paperboard production in the nation rose 12 per cent to 457,700 tons, a new high, in the week ended Feb. 26 as compared to the level reached in the corresponding 1965 week, the National Paperboard Association reported this week.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 114.8 on Wednesday from 114.5 on Tuesday.
LOS ANGELES, March 3 Alice Pearce, a versatile comedienne who appeared in nightclubs, on the stage, in motion pictures and on television, died of cancer here today. Her age was 47.
PENSACOLA, Fla., March 3 Doug Sanders, who likes to jest on a golf course, laughed at par today. With a first-round 63 in the $65,000 Pensacola open he was nine under regulation figures.

WASHINGTON, March 3 The Coast Guard today placed heavy blame on the captain and ships' officers in the fire and sinking last November of the Panamanian cruise ship Yarmouth Castle, in which 90 lives were lost.

City Councilmen briefed on Mayor Lindsay's tax program say he estimates his new executive budget for 1966-67 at just under $4.5 billion. That would mean an increase of $600 million over the city spending program as adopted a year ago.
November 9, 1965 ... 5:28 P.M. ... Where Were you when the lights went out?

CHICAGO, March 3 The, Rev. Dr. Charles Clayton Morrison, long an editor of The Christian Century magazine and a renowned leader in the ecumenical movement, died late yesterday in a Chicago nursing home. He was 91 years old.

SAIGON, March 3 South Vietnam's Communist party leadership has called for an intensified political struggle in the country to overcome "difficulty" and "confusion" caused in guerrilla ranks by the presence of large numbers of United States troops.

PITTSBURGH, March 3 Mr. and Mrs. William Adams Elliott have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Elliott, to Richard Clinton Montgomery. He is the son of Judge Harry M. Montgomery of the Superior Court and Mrs. Montgomery of Allison Park.
Mayor Lindsay made both friends and enemies in the City Council yesterday when he briefed its members on his tax proposals.
A new organization set up by St. John's University to give the faculty a greater voice in academic affairs met for the first time Wednesday night and elected 37 members to standing committees.

Maurice Hunter, whose fierce likeness appeared for half a century on billboards, in sculpture, in paintings and drawings, was found dead Wednesday night at his home, 254 West 135th Street. Authorities believe he died Saturday, probably of a heart ailment. He was 80 years old.
OTTAWA, March 3 Six Cabinet ministers left here today for talks in Washington on economic relations between the United States and Canada.

The Board of Higher Education's angry reaction to the state Regents proposals to reform, the management of the City University has put the controversy into sharper focus. The main demand of the Board of Regents is that the position of the university's chancellor be
WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) Florists complained bitterly to the Congress today about Western Union's plans to enter the flowers-by-wire business.

The Singer Company achieved the best results for a quarterly period in its history in the three months ended Dec. 31, but earnings for 1965 failed to match the record net posted the year before, according to yesterday's report of Donald P. Kircher, president.
WASHINGTON, March 3 Imperial Wizard Robert M. Shelton Jr. and six of his top leaders in the United Klans of America, Inc., were indicted today on charges of contempt of Congress.

BERLIN, March 3 Glinter Grass, Peter Weiss and other writers from East and West Germany have been invited to Princeton University for a meeting next month of their private literary association, which is known as Group 47.
The Grace Line passenger-cargo vessel Santa Isabel rammed the Raritan River Drawbridge yesterday and disrupted New Jersey shore railroad commuter schedules.

A white police captain at the West 126th Street police station has been transferred to Queens in connection with an incident in which a Negro woman was allegedly forced to remove part of her clothes in a Harlem tavern.
BRUSSELS, March 3--The Common Market's Executive Commission gave qualified encouragement today to mergers in the European textile industry to assure its place in the world market.

WASHINGTON, March 3 Lawyers who advise Sargent Shriver on the legal services program of the antipoverty campaign demanded today a $50-million fund plainly marked for that work so, they said, they would not have to kowtow to community action agencies.

The Imperial Smelting Company, a subsidiary of the Rio Tinto-zinc Corporation, of London, announced here yesterday that it had begun construction of what it termed the world's largest simultanious zinc-lead smelter at Avonmouth, near Bristol England.

Events today: New York Philharmornic, Philharmonic Hall, 2:15 P.M.; "Manon Lescaut" Metropolitan Opera, 8; "Oedipus Rex" and "Carmina Burana," New York City Opera, New York State Theater, 8:15; Boston Symphony Orchestra, Philharmonic Hall, 8:30; Anna Russell, concert comedienne, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Patrick Sky, folk singer and composer Town Hall, 8:30.
The following reports were provided yesterday by operators of the ski areas. Messages were filed at times indicated in parentheses.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 3 Troops and the police fired in the air in several parts of Jakarta today in efforts to restrain students demonstrating against leftists in President Sukarno's new Cabinet.

THIS is the time of year when skiing's entrepreneurs speculate about the length of the season. And they were doing plenty of speculating yesterday. The reason was the continued warm weather and a forecast of rain today.

RALEIGH, N.C., March 3 (AP) Bob Verga scored 29 points as top-seeded Duke crushed Wake Forest, 103-73, with a brilliant second-half surge tonight in the opening round of the Atlantic Conference basketball tournament.
Dartmouth, Mass., sold yesterday $3.44-million of A-rated school bonds to a group managed jointly by the National Shawmut Bank and the Hartford National Bank and Trust Company.

Former Police Chief of Staff William J. McQuade, who said yesterday he quit the department at the request of the new Chief Inspector, has been invited to return by Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary.
The Park Department deployed its own special forces yesterday to "revolutionize" the repair of dilapidated playgrounds.
LONDON, March 3 (UPI) Prime Minister Wilson agreed to face the Conservative party leader, Edward Heath, and the Liberal party leader, Jo Grimond, in a television debate.

THE Spring National Championships of the American Contract Bridge League will begin tonight at the Kentucky Hotel in Louisville, and continue 12 days. Six major championships, including play for the famous Vanderbilt Cup, and 20 minor ones will be contested by 4,000 or more players from all parts of North America.
CAIRO, March 4 (Reuters) President Ho Chi Minh of North Vietnam has rejected an Indian proposal for an Asian or African peace-keeping force in Vietnam, according to a report here today.

The Federal Government obtained an indictment yesterday against three top gambling operators the third time it has accused them of crimes but it had only a hope of arresting them and bringing them to trial.

The engagement of Miss Kathleen Ann McFarland to Edward Vincent Farrell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel F. Farrell, has been announced by the prospective bride's mother, Mrs. Allen A. McFarland. Both families live in the Bronx. A wedding in August is planned.
Governor Rockefeller's Committee on Public Employe Relations warned yesterday against the application of rigid rules to widely varying situations in the labor relations of state and city employes.
WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) Sales by merchant wholesalers rose to a record level in January, the Commerce

ROME, March 3 Delicate incidents have a way of arising in television everywhere, but last night Radiotelevisione Italiana had to smooth over a situation rather different from the experience of American networks. It was a case of video finesse, Italian style.
Prices on the London stock exchange strengthened yesterday as late buying interest brought small gains in oil issues and selected industrial shares.

A $118,000 project to study the possible effect of a proposed steam generating electric plant on the Cape Cod Canal will be financed by the Plymouth County Electric Company of Cambridge, Mass., the firm that may build the plant.

TEN youthful women, none of whom had ever been to Africa but to whom lionhunting was not necessarily new, went on safari last night at the Pierre Hotel for the benefit of the New York City Mission Society

LONDON, March 3 Color television will be introduced in Britain toward the end of next year, Anthony Wedgwood Benn, the Postmaster General, announced in the House of Commons today. Viewers will pay an extra license fee to receive it.

The U.S. Rubber Tire Company, a division of the United States Rubber Company, announced yesterday it was notifying its tire dealers and other customers that it would increase tire prices "in the near future."
An official of the country's leading association of private schools asserted yesterday that students had adopted "terrifying" attitudes toward sex.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) Republican Congressional leaders said today the Administration's antipoverty program had been marked politics, fraud, waste and other abuses and called for a special investigation.

A German Protestant aristocrat, who has left a $500,000 estate equally to Cardinal Spellman and the United Hias Service, was reported yesterday to have entered the United States through the good offices of Jewish agencies and a pioneering museum director.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 3--If Mayor Lindsay's new expense budget is a clue, more money will be spent to run New York City than most member countries of the United Nations have available to spend.
A sharp rebound in the last half hour of trading yesterday pushed most stocks on the American Stock Exchange into the plus column following two days of sharp decline.
MUSEUMS and stores seem determined this year to unlock the art and home furnishings mysteries of the East.

Long Island Rail Road trains would be able to use a projected subway tunnel under the East River between Queens and Manhattan, under a proposal made public yesterday by William J. Ronan, chairman of the Metropolitan Commuter Transportation Authority.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopa, March 3 The delegations of Guinea, Mali and Tanzania walked out of the Ministerial Council of the Organization of African Unity today iri protest against the seating of a Ghanaian delegation representing the new military government.
BONWIT TELLER was the first on the firing line with Paris imports at a showing yesterday of 30 pieces carefully edited "to eliminate the vulgar and the shocking."

WASHINGTON, March 3 The Association of American Railroads reported ton-mileage generated by carloadings in the latest week was estimated at 13.5 billion 12.7 per cent above the corresponding week a year ago.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 3 The Government won the first round today in a test of strength with labor by arresting five more union leaders at three of the Anaconda mining properties in northern Chile, Salvador, Potrerillos and Barquito. Seven leaders were arrested yesterday.

HIALEAH, Fla., March 3 More than 600 persons attended the Flamingo Ball last night at the Hialeah Race Course. The American Cancer Society benefit was held in the track's paddock area, becoming the most extravagant barn dance ever staged south of Nashville.
LONDON, March 3 The American actress Diana Sands dazzled theater critics here with her performance in "The Owl and the Pussycat," which opened last night at the Criterion Theater.
