Police Lieut. Thomas R. Gilligan, accused by civil rights groups of touching off the 1964 Harlem riots with his fatal shooting of a Negro boy, filed a $1.5-million suit in Federal Court yesterday against the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

It is incredible that Sekou Toure can fulfill his offer to step aside and make Ghana's fallen Kwame Nkrumah the President of Guinea. He is likely to have compelling second thoughts. Guineans hardly would relish being ruled by a man whose ouster in his own country waa greeted with such popular enthusiasm; a man or another language and culture unable even to communicate with them in French.
The stock market recovered sharply in heavy trading in the final hour of yesterday's session, halting the steep break in prices that had been under way for most of the week.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 3 Secretary General Thant has made new proposals for efforts to end the crisis in Cyprus between the Greek and Turkish ethnic groups.
So one day you're down, and the next day you're up. At least that's the hoped-for pattern in account losses and gains.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (UPI) A Federal judge ruled today that rail unions may not call a nationwide strike to compel railroads to rehire about 22,500 firemen and trainmen who lost their jobs under a Federal arbitration award.
ACCRA, Ghana, March 3 Ghana's new National Liberation Council appealed today for a $50.4-million loan abroad to shore up Ghana's finances and pay for urgently needed food.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (UPI) Robert E. Thompson of The Los Angeles Times was elected today as president of the White House Correspondent's Association. He succeeds Alan L. Otten of The Wall Street Journal.

HOUSTON March 3 A Texas labor leader said tonight that pressures were being brought on the Texas Council of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations to endorse State Attorney General Waggoner Carr for the United States Senate seat once held by President Johnson.
GREAT NECK, L.I., March 3 Steven B. Derounian, who backed Barry Goldwater in the 1964 Presidential election, was designated tonight as the Republican candidate in the Third Congressional District.
ROME, March 3 Premier Aldo Moro appeared before Parliament today to seek a vote of confidence.
IN the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.
Ivy Improta, a Brazilian pianist who was first heard here in 1947, played at Carnegie Recital Hall last night.

WASHINGTON, March 3 The Administration plans a four-fold increase in birth-control expenditures under the foreign aid program. Annual outlays of about $20-million are contemplated within the next few years.

HOLLYWOOD, March 3 (UPI) William Frawley, the character actor who co-starred in the "I Love Lucy" and "My Three Sons" television series, collapsed and died on Hollywood Boulevard tonight. He was 72 years old.

ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, March 3 Ghana's ousted President, Kwame Nkrumah, can now be considered the head of state of Guinea, and speaks with the full authority of that country, President Sekou Toure said last night according to the Guinean radio.
WASHINGTON, March 3--Three maritime union leaders asserted today that they still intended to boycott ships trading with North Vietnam despite the State Department's expressions of dismay.

WASHINGTON, March 3 Senator Jacob K. Javits told Attorney General Nicholas deB. Katzenbach today that the Administration was about to send conciliators into racial disputes "with the prosecutor's pistol packed right on their side."

Commodore Frederick George Reinicke, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Reinicke of 116 East 68th Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ann Reinicke, to James Bishop Peabody of New York and Paris. He is the son of Mrs. John Damon Peabody of Hancock, N.H., and the late Mr. Peabody.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) President Johnson told Congress today that the Government intended to use global commercial satellite communications facilities for most of its business even after the proposed Defense Department satellite system was in operation.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) The Justice Department defended tonight its use of agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation in 43 counties to monitor 15-day voter registration in Texas. It said their use was necessary to comply with the Federal court order that declared the state's poll tax unconstitutional.
WHAT the Beatles did to music in 1964, they've apparently done to American men's fashion, too: Revolutionized it.
MONTREAL, March 3 (UPI) The Toronto Maple Leafs stalled the title drive of the Montreal Canadiens by blanking the Canadiens, 4-0, tonight in a National Hockey League game.

Manhattan College became the first champion of the new Metropolitan Collegiate Basketball Conference last night by beating St. Francis, 75-64. New York University routed Fordham, 82-70, in the second game of the twin bill at Madison Square Garden.
Dr. Ross F. Nigrelli, a research scientist at the New York Aquarium for 32 years, was appointed director yesterday by Fairfield Osborn, president of the New York Zoological Society.

TOKYO, March 3 An American expert on Asia predicted today in a speech on the emerging relations between Japan and Communist China, that Japan was "bound to change" her present policy of withholding diplomatic recognition from Peking. Japan recognizes the Government of Nationalist China on Taiwan.

BOSTON, March 3 (AP) Reg Fleming put in a rebound late in the third period for his second goal of the game tonight and gave the New York Rangers a 5-4 victory over the Boston Bruins in a meeting between the last two teams in the National Hockey League.
Strange "rumbling" noises reported by East Side residents to the Police and Fire Departments about 9:45 last night were the sounds of Consolidated Edison blowing off steam, according to a spokesman.

George G. Stier, president of the Nopco Chemical Company, denied yesterday that merger negotiations had been under way with the General Aniline and Film Corporation for several months. He said a previous proposal made last October by Aniline was considered by the Nopco board, but was rejected as "not in the best interests of Nopco shareholders," Mr. Stier said.
Thomas 15X Johnson told a Supreme Court jury yesterday that he was spending a quiet Sunday at home, doing chores for his pregnant wife, when Malcolm X was slain.

The New York Stock Exchange denounced Mayor Lindsay's proposed 50 per cent increase in the securities transfer tax as "bad medicine" last night and for the third time in 33 years threatened to move out of town.
WASHINGTON, March 3 Uncertain whether to laugh or grimace, the State Department pondered today whether President Toure of Guinea had really abdicated in favor of the ousted President of Ghana.
WASHINGTON, March 3 The Federal National Mortgage Association lowered its mortgage-buying prices by another point today, and the Veterans Administration raised

The directors of the General Telephone and Electronics Corporation authorized the filing of a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday for the public sale of 2.5 million.
WASHINGTON, March 3 (UPI) More persons cashed in more United States savings bonds than bought them in February, the Treasury reported today.
PHILADELPHIA, March 3 The five-day wildcat strike of longshoremen in the port of Philadelphia ended at 8 A.M. today as suddenly as it started.
WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) A collect Western Union telegram will cost 10 cents more after April 1, the Federal Communications. Commission said today.

Herbert A. Kammer, senior vice president of the American Electric Power Service Corporation and a director of its parent company, American Electric Power Company, died Wednesday at Nassau Hospital, Mineola, L.I. He was 60 years old. He preferred to be known by his initials.

Two major chemical producers the Allied Chemical Corporation and W.R. Grace Co. set records last year in sales and earnings, their reports disclosed yesterday. Grace joined the elite billion-dollar sales club for the first time, while Allied exceeded the billion-dollar rate for the second year.

Representatives of Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union land of the Parochial Bus System, Inc., will meet today at the State Mediation Board, 270 Broadway, to seek an end to a strike by drivers serving 6,000 Bronx public and parochial school pupils.
LOS ANGELES, March 3 One of the largest antipoverty programs in the nation is smarting from a tacit rebuff by the people it was designed to help.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., March 3 Mr. and Mrs. Isaac Kaplan have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sara Kaplan, to Kenneth J. Endick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Endick of Woodhaven, Queens.
Directors of Gulf and Western Industries, Inc., proposed here yesterday a three-for-one stock split of the common shares, to be followed by an increase in the dividend rate.

The British pound recovered slightly from its recent weakening trend in moderate trading yesterday on foreign exchange markets here yesterday. The spot rate on sterling closed at $2.7989, up 2 points from the previous day's quotation.
There were signs of improvement in the corporate and Treasury bond markets yesterday, and, as one dealer put it, "the change is welcome, even it turns out to be short-lived."
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), March 3 David BenGurion today entered the growing controversy over Abie S. Nathan's peace mission by saying the flier should be respected and not ridiculed.
KUALALUMPUR, Malaysia, March 3 The University of Indonesia was temporarily closed today and placed under guards of the Jakarta military command.
State officials have questioned the legality of Mayor Lindsay's decisions to rescind permission for the state to start building a parkway through Staten Island's green-belt area.

GENEVA, March 3 The United States and the Soviet Union rejected today attempts by nonaligned nations to make an accord to halt the spread of nuclear weapons depend on other agreements for peace and the halting of nuclear weapons production.

Runoff from Monday's rain added 4.7 billion gallons of water in 24 hours to the city's supply in upstate reservoirs. The supply stood at 235.5 billion gallons at 8 A.M. yesterday, or 49.4 per cent of capacity.
David Stimer, a pianist and accompanist for well-known recitalists, died of a heart attack in his home at 300 Fort Washington Avenue on Feb. 23, it was announced yesterday. He was 51 years old.

Count and Countess Antonio Martini-Crotti of Rome have announced the marriage of their daughter, Miss Alessandra Martini-Crotti, to Henry William Sage Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Sage of 888 Park Avenue.
Many people who started walking or using private autos during the recent transit strike have not gone back to the buses and subways, and the Transit Authority is conducting a survey to find out why.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) Congressmen were told today that Federal stockpile materials were being sold at the rate of nearly $1-billion a year and that defense-stockpile needs were about the same for a possible nuclear war as for a conventional war.

CHICAGO, March 3 (UPI) Dr. David T. McCann, 32 years old, who has seven children, is going to Fort Rucker, Ala., Monday. He has been drafted. Dr. McCann said today he had received a letter of induction Jan. 25.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (UPI) Representative Michael A. Feighan, Democrat of Ohio, charged yesterday that steelworkers in his hometown of Cleveland were losing work because of the competition of Asian steel mills.

People who ride buses like to sit facing front, at right angles to the windows. Engineers have designed new buses in which most people have to sit parallel to the windows and face one another. If bus riders wanted to ride that way, they would have taken the subway. Watch on the next bus you enter to see how everyone rushes to the few right-angle seats in the rear.

Menasha Skulllnik and Molly Picon will for the first time appear together in a Broadway presentation next season. "Chu Chem," which means wise man in Yiddish, is the title of their show, described as "a Zen Buddhist-Hebrew musical comedy."
Government scientists have reported achieving the first transmission of a lethal degenerative nerve disease of human beings to laboratory animals.
LONDON, March 3 The price of gold, which had been creeping up in the London market, fell today on mysterious offerings from Switzerland.
FRANKFURT, West Germany, March 3 (UPI) West Germany announced today the award of its highest medical prize to an 86-year-old New York cancer researcher.

"We have no formal program of acquisitions, but as a private investment partnership, we like to put our money into things with good value and good management," Warren Buffett, general partner in Buffett Partner ship, Ltd., of Omaha, said yesterday.

HAVERFORD, Pa., March 3 Mrs. Donald Manly-Power of Philadelphia won the United States senior women's squash racquets championship today by defeating top-seeded Mrs. Baba Lewis of Boston, 17-16, 15-8, 8-15, 14-15, 15-10, at the Merion Cricket Club.

BUDAPEST, March 3 The recent disclosure by the Hungarian Communist party that a number of persons convicted of "antistate" activity and amnestied in 1963 had been rearrested for continued subversion named three Roman Catholic priests among the eight persons seized.
WASHINGTON, March 3 (UPI) The House agreed today to let cotton farmers tax themselves $1 a bale, and maybe more later, to finance a promotional struggle against the inroads of synthetic fibers.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 3 (Reuters) Die Transvaler, pro-government Afrikaans-language morning news paper, sharply criticized today hearings on apartheid held recently by the United States House of Representatives African Subcommittee.

One of the best political shows in town is being put on by a touring non-team of four Reform Democrats who want to oppose Leonard Farbstein, their party's incumbent Representative in Manhattan's 19th District.

Kitcho Restaurant, 103 West 44th Street, LT 1-5477. There are numerous enthusiasts for Japanese food who say this is the best of the city's many Japanese restaurants. The dining room is physically no thing of beauty, but the kitchen is rewarding whether it offers such basics as sukiyaki and tempura or a notable pork and mushroom dish on skewers, kushikatsu.
JACKSON, Miss., March 3 Tornadoes smashed across central Mississippi at dusk today, killing 57 persons and injuring 404.
The Horn Hardart Company, which operates a chain of automats, restaurants and food shops in the New York area, announced yesterday the election of Thomas F. O'Neil as a director.
ALBANY, March 3 Republican legislative leaders suggested to Mayor Lindsay today that he raise the New York City transit fare to help get his tax package through the Legislature.
The International Business Machines Corporation announced here yesterday the elections of Kenneth N. Davis Jr, and Y. Parran Dawkins as vice presidents.

Eastman Dillon, Union Securities Co., investment bankers, announced yesterday the admission of Robert L. Cruikshank as a general partner. Also admitted to general partnerships were Robert C. Johnson, John E. Stoddard, H. Lawrence Jones Jr., Donald R. Mayne and Donell D. Moor.

WESTBURY, L.I., March 3 Roosevelt's winter meeting that started Jan. 3 the earliest opening in Roosevelt Raceway's 25-year history ended tonight. Tomorrow the scene will shift to Yorkers. There were 23,592 on hand for tonight's program. The crowds here have averaged 18,669 nightly with an average handle of $1,737,000 and they have made the state $9,524,088 richer.
LONDON, March 3 The City of London approved today the construction of a 1.25-million ($3.5-million) concert hall as the first permanent home for one of London's four leading symphony orchestras.
With her mother in charge, a 15-year-old Queens girl had her blood purified yesterday in the first artificial kidney machine to be installed in a home here.

PAOLI, Pa., March 3 Mr. and Mrs. Albert Byecroft have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Pamela Hardee Byecroft, to David Constable Wetherill, son of Mr, and Mrs. Samuel Price Wetherill of Haverford.

MONTGOMERY, March 3 A three-judge Federal court struck down today the Alabama poll tax law, terming it "one of the last great pillars of racial discrimination." The vote of the judges, all natives of Alabama, was 2 to 1.
NEW DELHI, March 3 The Soviet Union has offered food aid to India, official sources said here tonight.

GREENWICH, Conn., March 3 The Greenwich Planning and Zoning Commission was told last night that "the town has no obligation to accommo date every person or form of development that may wish to come to Greenwich."

WASHINGTON, March 3 Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara said today that Communist China "has no reason to fear military action" by the United States as a result of American involvement in the war in Vietnam.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 3 Britain, France and the United States joined today in asserting that there was no place in the United Nations for East Germany.
WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) President and Mrs. Johnson greeted members of Congress and their wives tonight at a White House reception.
WASHINGTON, March 3 The major oil companies serving South Africa have agreed to limit their sales there to discourage shipment of oil products to Rhodesia in defiance of the British embargo.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 3 It was the last day in the New York Mets training camp before Casey Stengel's arrival sort of the calm before the storm but Dick Stuart did his best today to take up the slack.
MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., March 3 Negro civil rights leaders here roundly rejected tonight as "inadequate" the city's plan for desegregating its elementatry school system.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 3 Whitey Ford, who is starting his 15th season as a New York Yankee, wheeled his 37-year-old left arm around and fired the ball to the plate.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) A merger of the Chicago North Western Railway and the Great Western Railway into a nearly 12,000-mile system was recommended today by an Interstate Commerce Commission examiner.

MILWAUKEE, March 3 (UPI) The defense in Wisconsin's baseball antitrust suit raised strenuous objections today to including in the record the opinion of the former baseball commissioner, Ford Frick, that the major leagues should have expanded to two 12-team leagues two years ago.
WASHINGTON, March 3 President Johnson signed the new Veterans Readjustment Act today. It authorizes education, housing and other benefits for veterans who have served after Jan. 31, 1955.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, March 3 (AP) Guinea's roving Ambassador, Abdullaye Diallo, said today that Mr. Nkrumah had become President of both Guinea and Ghana. He asserted that this was the wish of the people of Guinea.
The election as vice presidents of George K. Budd, James R. Early and A. Burnett Winters was announced yesterday by the Campbell Soup Company.
ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, March 3 The Katanga region is doing its best to demonstrate to Gen. Joseph D. Mobutu, here on his first visit as President of the Congo, that he is not on enemy territory.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), March 3 Each day another group of Israelis announces that it intends to forgo part of its pay.
Good evening. Our city is facing a financial crisis.
The Hoffman Electronics Corporation has received a $6,792,250 Navy contract for production of rocket components.

A program whose potential interest was not fully realized in the performances was given by the New York Philharmonic last night in Philharmonic Hall, with Thomas Schippers as guest conductor and Guiomar Novaes as piano soloist.
Federal Reserve policy is tightening, slowly but surely, data issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York indicated.
NEW DELHI, March 3 Indian Army forces moved into the Mizo Hills District today to quell what was officially described as a revolt by tribesmen seeking independence.

MIAMI, March 3 (AP) The murder case of Candace Mossler and her nephew, Melvin Lane Powers accused of killing her multi-millionaire husband, Jacques Mossler was sent to the jury tonight on the 33d day of the trial.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (UPI) The House Public Works Committee, taking up a subject that has been discussed for several years, voted today to build an official mansion for the Vice President near Washington's Embassy Row.

SOLDIERS! You have this day at Austerlitz realized all I expected of your bravery. You have covered your eagles with immortal glory. In less than four hours, you have cut to shreds and routed an army of one hundred thousand men, commanded by the Emperors of Russia and Austria..."

A book of less than 200 pages but packed tight as a walnut with ideas was published yesterday by Doubleday. The book, "The Human Church," was instrumental is the ecolesiastical suspension of its priest-author, the Rev. William H. DuBay of Los Angeles.

The Sony Corporation of America demonstrated here yesterday how thin, plastic disks could be used to record and play-back on television screens both black-and-white motion pictures and color still photographs. Despite vehement denials by Sony officials,

MIAMI, March 3 Ogden Phipps's Buckpasser made the 30,011 fans at Hialeah today forget their displeasure with the father-and-son team of Eugene Mori and Eugene E. Mori for a few fleeting moments. The courageous colt flashed a dynamic closing burst that enabled him to win the $136,400 Flamingo by a nose over Abe's Hope of the Grand Prix Stable, with Blue Skyer a well-beaten third, 2 lengths farther back.
Harry Van Arsdale, president of the City Central Trades and Labor Council, suggested to Mayor Lindsay yesterday that the Mayor appoint a city official to act as a liaison with labor.
SAIGON, March 3 The possibility that the Vietcong may be trying to block the Saigon River to shut off a major supply route is causing concern among American officials.

WASHINGTON, March 3 The Federal Government of the United States was formed 177 years ago this week, and though nationalism' is the most powerful political force in the world today, the ideal of political federation is still very much alive.
ARCADIA, Calif., March 3 Twelve 3-year-old horses were named today for the $141,900 Santa Anita Derby on Saturday, with $96,000 and possibly a trip to the Kentucky Derby in store for the winner.

Corporate profits a closely watched economic indicator are up all right. But First National City Bank notes in its March economic letter that the fourth-quarter rise was only slightly more than seasonal despite the strong upsurge in business activity spurred by the Vietnam build-up.
A nine-story apartment building with a penthouse at 106 East 85th Street, near Park Avenue, has been sold by Charles Weiss to the Locust Hall Realty Corporation.

Twelve young heavyweights will fight in Madison Square Garden tonight for a piece of boxing's future. Jerry Quarry, a 20-year-old from Los Angeles, will meet 27-year-old Tony Alongi of Paterson in the scheduled 10-round main event.

Mayor Lindsay made public last night the new taxes he seeks to help meet a record city expense budget of more than $4-billion. Included in his proposed tax program are both a personal and a business income tax.

MONTREAL, March 3 (AP) The Cassius Clay-Ernie Terrell heavy weight title bout, rejetted by New York and voted out of Chicago, ran into another snag tonight when an official of the Montreal Athletic Commission said the Montreal Forum had refused the fight.

AFTER having made the rounds of the world's operatic centers ever since its premiere at La Scala in 1957, Francis Poulenc's "Dialogues of the Carmelites" finally received a stage presentation in New York. The New York City Opera was responsible for the local premiere. All one can say is that it was high time.

MOUTIERS, France, March 3 (AP) Christine Goitschel, the winner of the special slalom gold medal in the 1964 Olympics, suffered a broken bone in her lower right leg today when an Austrian skier fell and crashed into the French girl as she was standing beside a course.

Two state legislators and a spokesman for thousands of elderly voters accused Governor Rockefeller yesterday of bad faith in refusing to disclose his plans for taking advantage of Federal health-aid legislation.
NAPLES, Italy, March 3 Alfonso Cardinal Castaldo, Archbishop of Naples, died today in his residence after a long illness. He was 75 years old.
LONDON, March 3 The Israel Museum will receive a donation of five important but lesser known paintings by Cezanne, Gaugin and Van Gogh.
PHILADELPHIA, March 3 (AP) A gray-haired gunman killed a man and a woman today and wounded two other persons during the holdup of a finance company office. He then fled.

IT comes as a surprise to learn that New York City has had only 101 mayors in 300 years. They must have been mighty men, because no ordinary 101 mortals could have produced such an awesome legacy as the one that Mayor Lindsay, the 102d, is now trying to dispose of.
Two international events one expected, the other a surprise had an impact on commodities yesterday.
LODI, N.J., March 3 (UPI) Tax Collector Joseph Luna is a persistent fellow. He tracked down one man to a small town in Africa to collect an unpaid tax bill.

MIAMI, March 3 The excitement of an unexpectedly thrilling finish momentarily silenced the "boo" birds and evoked a spontaneous babble of shouts. But the disgruntled railbirds returned to catcalls today shortly thereafter in continuance of their disapproval of the circumstances surrounding the usually classic Flamingo Stakes, the high point of the Hialeah racing season.
Mrs. John V. Lindsay visited two Head Start centers yesterday and declared that New York had the greatest need of all communities in the country for the preschool cultural enrichment program.
Former Council President Paul R. Screvane, a Democrat and close associate of former Mayor Robert F. Wagner, has been offered and has rejected a high post in the Lindsay administration.
Directors of American Metal Climax, Inc., elected Ian MacGregor president and Wallace Macgregor senior executive vice president yesterday.
NORTH BERGEN, N.J., March 3 Transportation made bedfellows out of strangers here today.

Locked in a race to overtake a consumer with rapidly changing demands, merchants and manufacturers sought ways yesterday of joining forces by either reconciling their differences or learning to coexist peacefully.

Sylvester L. Weaver Jr., president of Subscription Television, Inc., said yesterday the company was not now financially able to resume pay-TV operations in Los Angeles and San Francisco. The company hoped to do so "ultimately," he added.
BROOKLINE, Mass., March 3 (UPI) An armored truck containing $58,000, guns and ammunition was stolen today from in front of a supermarket by a bandit who may have had a key to the truck.

PHILADELPHIA, March 3 Philadelphia tonight be came at a shrewd guess the first American city to have its Mayor, James H.J. Tate, proclaim "Ballet Festival Week." Long may Philadelphia and its admirable Mayor prosper.

HONG KONG, March 3 Communist China, asserted today that both the "hawks" and the "doves" in the Washington debate on Vietnam were "fools" whose views differed only on the means of carrying out aggression.

The American Shipbuilding Company has announced the election of John B. Kopp as senior vice president. Mr. Kopp, who formerly was president of the Ingalis Iron Works, has been a vice president of the Lorain, Ohio, shipyard since January, 1964.

CRESTED BUTTE, Colo., March 3 (UPI) Bill Marolt of Colorado University sped over the 70-gate Crested Butte slalom course in 98.21 seconds today to place first in the opening event of the 1966 National Collegiate ski championships.

Donald F. Turner, head of the Justice Department's Antitrust Division, said yesterday that "there is about as much justification today" for action against "substantial horizontal mergers as there ever has been."
WASHINGTON, March 3 Walter P. Reuther has spoken out strongly in support of Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz at a time when the official's stock with many labor leaders has sharply declined.
AUGUSTA, Me., March 3 (AP) The Sunday liquor sale referendum vote went back to the "dry" column today unofficially with the report of an error in Monmouth's official tally.
WASHINGTON, March 3 (UPI) The Civil Aeronautics Board gave National Airlines permission today to meet with its two competitors on the East Coast Florida route for a discussion of excursion fares.

WASHINGTON, March 3 President Johnson's proposal for reorganization of the Government's agencies and programs dealing with transportation left out almost as much as it included. But even so, it may be too sweeping to win Congressional approval in any form closely resembling what the
FOR President Sekou Toure of Guinea, the bold and un- expected has almost become a stock in trade.
AMERICUS, Ga., March 3 (UPI) A jury of 10 whites and two Negroes convicted a 23-year-old Negro today of fatally shooting a white marine recruit during a tense racial demonstration last summer.

From the Center for the Study of Democratic Institutions has just come its latest Occasional Paper on the Free Society. The theme is the arts in a democratic society. Although the paper is the product of a two-day discussion held several months ago at the center's headquarters in Santa

"That's right, Doug. Sell 'em at the market and get me some Treasury bills. I think I'll sit it out for a month, or two." These instructions were given by a customer to his broker earlier this week when the stock market was falling sharply.
Two scientists are back on a somewhat neglected trail first blazed 22 years ago: that of fertilizing a human egg with a human sperm in a laboratory flask.
ARCADIA, Calif., March 3 (UPI) Ismael Valenzuela suffered a broken left wrist today when he was thrown from his mount at the start of the first race at Santa Anita.

Donald Duncan, a former master sergeant of the United States Special Forces in Vietnam, told a packed Town Hall meeting last night that the United States Government had no alternative in the long run but to negotiate its way out of the war and leave Vietnam.
YONKERS, March 3 Harness racing's wheel of fortune will swing from Long Island to Westchester County tomorrow night when Yonkers Raceway opens its 17th season.
TEANECK, N.J., March 3 "How many knots will that one do?" the boat-show visitor asked hesitantly, as if unsure of his nautical terminology.

LJUBLJANA, Yugoslavia, March 3 (AP) The Canadian team put the hockey sticks it purchased from the United States squad to effective use in defeating the Americans, 7-2, as the world amateur ice hockey championship got under way today.
WASHINGTON, March 3 Representative Otis G. Pike announced today that he would seek a fourth term in the House of Representatives rather than accept a seat on the New York State Supreme Court bench.
LOS ANGELES, March 3 James Elliott resigned today as chief curator of the Los Angeles County Museum of Art to become director of the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford, Conn.
New efforts are under way to bring Hollywood to the banks of the Hudson or, at the very least, to stem the exodus of local filmmakers to points west and south.
PHILADELPHIA, March 3 (AP) Wilt Chamberlain scored 62 points as the Philadelphia 76ers posted a 135-125 victory over the San Francisco Warriors tonight in a National Basketball Association game.

In his foreword the author, in effect, apologizes for writing a biography of Gen. Robert E. Lee that follows the works of such an authority as Douglas Southall Freeman. And this despite his own accepted credentials as a Civil War historian. But he need not explain his book. It speaks for itself as a supplement, not a replacement.
LISBON--It is a quiet town, this ancient and lovely city on the hillside over the River Tagus.
Mrs. Robert F. Wagner disclosed yesterday that she would enter Lenox Hill Hospital next Friday for the removal of an intestinal tumor.
John Frank Blazier, manager of organizational planning for Dresser Industries, Inc., Dallas manufacturers of oil field supplies, died Thursday in Dallas. He was 51 years old.

Kenneth Wilson, a former vice president and director of the Forstmann Woolen Company, died in Athens Wednesday night while dining at the Athens Hilton Hotel. He was on a vacation trip around the Mediterranean with his wife, the former Louise Forstmann. He was 59 years old.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 4 --Dinny Adams, the captain and leadoff man on the Harvard varsity that won the team title for the fifth successive year, was beaten in the national intercollegiate squash racquets championship today at the Naval Academy.

Manhattan College, the winner of the new Metropolitan Collegiate Conference basketball championship, yesterday was named the 10th team to compete in the 29th annual National Invitation Tournament in Madison Square Garden.
DESIGNING, children's clothes has become almost as popular with young housewives as the morning kaffeeklatsch.

Sounds of chord clusters, stroked piano strings and wind chimes were heard in the New School auditorium last night as the Contemporary Music Society presented a concert in memory of Henry Cowell, the history-making American composer who died last Dec. 10 at the age of 68.
The writers straggled into the room, chattering, unlike older writers, and waited for things to get under way.
MONTREAL, March 4--Mr. Stampleman, 68, was retired chairman of the Gillette Safety Razor Company of Canada, Ltd. He and Mrs. Stampleman, 64, were returning from a threeweek trip to the Orient.
WASINGTON, March 4 (AP)--The Federal Aviation Agency said today that it had advanced by six weeks, to Sept. 1, the deadline for submitting final design proposals for a supersonic transport plane.
MONTREAL, March 4 (AP) --The Cassius Clay-Ernie Terrell heavyweight championship fight was on the move again today after having been rejected by the City Council of suburban Verdun.
LONDON, March 4--The chances are receding for a television confrontation during the British election campaign between Prime Minister Wilson and Edward Heath, the Conservative party leader.

Project Hope will benefit from a preview performance of Chekhov's "Ivanov," starring John Gielgud and Vivien Leigh, at the Shubert Theater on April 28. Dinner before the show at La Fohda del Sol and transportation to the Shubert will be included in the most expensive tickets, $50 a person.
WASHINGTON, March 4-- The nation's money supply decreased somewhat during February, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

SAIGON, Saturday, March 5 (Reuters)--A Vietcong bullet traveled 300 yards across a field, entered a United States marine's rifle barrel and struck the round in the chamber, causing it to explode; and the marine came out unhurt, according to a report here today.

Testimony was completed yesterday in the trial of the three men accused of killing Malcolm X. Separate summations for each defendant will begin at 9:30 A.M. Monday in Supreme Court and Justice Charles Marks said, after his charge, he had expected the case to go to the jury on Thursday.

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., March 4--Joseph Fields, a member of a famous theatrical family and co-author of many Broadway hits and movies, died here last night. Mr. Fields, who suffered from heart trouble, was 71 years old.
FLOURTOWN, Pa., March 4 --Miss Geoigia Lynne Nichols and Benjamin Keith Symmers of New York and Long Beach Island, N.J., plan to be married in October.
James E. Wilson, who pleaded guilty to burning his draft card publicly, received a two-year suspended sentence and two years' probation from Federal Judge Edward Weinfeld yesterday.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., March 4--John F. Kiely, president of the Kiely Construction Company and also of the Thomas Proctor Company, died yesterday at his winter home in Coral Gables, Fla. His age was 67 The Proctor company is one of the largest construction firms of bulkheads and marine installations in this area.

CINCINNATI, March 4 (AP) --Wilt Chamberlain scored 7 key points in the final period tonight to lead the Philadelphia 76ers to a 107-103 National Basketball Association victory over Cincinnati, ending the Royals' homecourt winning streak at 13 games.

Frenzy marked potato futures trading yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange, a welcome change after weeks of dawdling prices. In fact, yesterday proved so active that the exchange halted trading at 11 A.M. for a half hour, to give traders time to catch up with themselves as well as notify their offices.
YOSEMITE NATIONAL PARK, Calif., Mar, 4 (AP)-- A park ranger saved a bear's life with artificial respiration today.

BASKING RIDGE, N.J., March 4--John Meszar of 16 Sunnybrook Road, former associate executive director of the switching department of Bell Telephone Laboratories, died last night in Morristown Memorial Hospital. He was 64 years old.
ACCRA, Ghana, March 4-- Kwame Nkrumah accumulated a fortune of "not less than $7million" while he was President of Ghana, according to E.A. Ayeh Kumi, Mr. Nkrumah's personal financial consultant.
WASHINGTON, March 4-- The Justice Department petitioned the Subversive Activities Control Board today to order the campus-oriented W.E. B. DuBois Clubs to register as a Communist-front organization.
The Lindsay administration apparently succeeded yesterday in getting at least a six-month delay in parkway construction through Staten Island's greenbelt area.

Hannah Klein arrived at Kings County Hospital at 8:40 P.M. Thursday evening by ambulance from Brooklyn Jewish Hospital after fracturing her arm and hip in a fall in her Eastern Parkway home. Moments earlier, the ambulance had been speeding down Clarkson Avenue, dome light blinking, siren wailing.

Jerry Quarry of Los Angeles, tough, resilient and dogged, fought to a 10-round draw with the more experienced Tony Alongi of Paterson, N.J., last night and emerged as the most interesting heavyweight of Madison Square Garden's dozen.

The New York Civil Liberties Union announced yesterday that it would challenge the constitutionality of Governor Rockefeller's proposal for compulsory treatment of narcotics addicts if the Legislature approved it.
The colorful and gay Jewish festival of Purim will start at sundown today with religious services and ceremonies in homes and synagogues.

WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP)--A proxy fight is building up for control of the First Republic Corporation, a Long Island concern whose holdings include luxury motels in Miami Beach office buildings in New York and Chicago and industrial complexes in three states.

THE New York Coliseum Antiques Fair, the last but one in the winter-early spring flurry of shows, opens today. It is tramsforming the Coliseum into a miniature market town with a fair percentage of "gypsy" dealers.

AMERICUS, Ga., March 4 (AP)--Eddie Jamems Lamar, 22 years old, Pleaded guilty to a charge of voluntary manslaughter today. He had been charged with murder in the shooting of Andrew Aultman Whatley Jr. July 28. He was sentenced to five years.
Cancer specialists in Buffalo reported yesterday that by transplantations they had exchanged pieces of tumor between two men suffering from the same rare type of cancer.

WASHINGTON, March 4--A 35-year-old woman sculptor was named today to execute the "official bust" of Lyndon Baines Johnson that will join the marble portraits of 35 other Vice Presidents in the chamber and corridors of the Senate.

NASHVILLE, March 4--The engagement of Miss Julie Beth Jordan to William Robert Stiles, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert William Stiles of Evanston, Ill., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Louis Frederick Jordan of Nashville, formerly of Southport, Conn.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, March 4--The delegations of Somalia, Algeria and Kenya withdrew today from the meeting of the Ministerial Council of the Organization of African Unity, dealing another serious blow to hopes for a common stand on the Rhodesian issue.

WASHINGTON, March 4 --Senator Edward M. Kennedy severely criticized both the United States and South Vietnam governments in a Senate speech today for what he called indecision and procrastination in handling the problems of some 781,000 refugees in South Vietnam.
WASHINGTON, March 4--A drive to provide income-tax allowances for parents and others who pay for the education of college students was renewed in the Senate today.
JACKSON, Miss., March 4 --The death toll climbed today as rescue workers checked the wake of a tornado that skipped across central Mississippi.
Meteorologists, long puzzled by the violent and erratic ways of tornadoes, are mounting an intensive 75-day study of the cause and nature of the funnelshaped twisters.

MEMPHIS, March 4 (AP)-- Brig. Gen. Wilmot A. Danielson, U.S.A., ret., who directed construction of more than $200million is Army facilities during his 35-year military career, died last night. He was 81 years old and had been is declining health for several years.

NICE, France, March 4-- Former Finance Minister Valery Giscard d'Estaing has opened a drive to gain nationwide attention that his aides hope will enable hm to win the presidency when President de Gaulle steps down in seven years.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 4-- Miners at the large copper mine at Chuquicamata continued working today despite union efforts to close it down in a sympathy strike supporting the 61-day walkout at the world's largest underground copper mine at El Teniente.

Four major lumber associations reported, an increase of 11.5 per cent in production for the week ended Feb. 26 compared with the level in the 1965 week. Output fell 0.1 per cent from the preceding week.

MIAMI, March 4--A successor to Judge Robert Cannon as professional adviser to the Players' Association will be named tomorrow, when the elected player representatives of all 20 major league baseball clubs will meet here to select one.

There is a sadness along the waterfront these days. Once upon a wintertime many of the Hudson River piers echoed the rumble of handcarts toting baggage to the gangplanks of white-hulled coastal steamers that tugged at their hawsers to be off for ports down along the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts.
WASHINGTON, March 4-- James Farmer's plan to switch from civil rights demonstrations to teaching literacy is caught on political shoals.
A YOUNG woman from Cadiz, Spain, calling her self La Curra, made her New York debut at the Opera House of the Brooklyn Academy of Music last night, accompanied by 10 young men.

CARMEL, Calif., March 4-- Leonard K. Firestone of Beverly Hills, president of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company of Caiifornia, in Los Angeles; and a director of the 'parent concern in Akron, Ohio, married Mrs. Barbara Knickerbocker Heatley of San. Francisco, widow of Stuart A. Heatley, this afternoon. Mr. Heatley was a senior vice president of the Wells Fargo Bank.

TUCKAHOE, N.Y., March 4 --Warren H. Mayell, a lawyer of White Plains and Peekskill and captain of the 1929 New York University baseball team, died Tuesday at the Phelps Memorial Hospital in Tarrytown. His age was 59.

Representatives of several major unions of public employes endorsed impartial fact-finding yesterday as the best method for resolving collective-bargaining deadlocks with municipal and state agencies.
The Presbytery of Long Island, the governing unit for 59 Presbyterian churches in Nassau and Suffolk Counties, will dedicate its new headquarters in Commack tomorrow at 3 P.M.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, March 4--The killing of Communists in Indonesia continued this week despite President Sukarno's removal of Gen. Abdul Haris Nasution, who had led the army's campaign to destroy the Communist party.
MIAMI, March 4 (UPI)--A Circuit Court jury was unable to reach a verdict today after deliberations in the Mossler murder trial. The judge ordered Saturday and Sunday sessions, if neccessay.
WASHINGTON, March 4-- The United States is reacquiring some surplus military equipment from its North Atlantic Treaty allies, presumably for use in the Vietnam war.
Mary Heisig, a painter, died on Thursday in Mount Sinai Hospital. She was 52 years old and lived at 331 Henry Street in Brooklyn.

LISBON, March 4--The Foreign Minister charged today there was "increasing hostility" to Portugal among foreign correspondents here. But he announced that threatened legal proceedings against representatives of the Associated Press and Agence France Presse had been abandoned.
As everywhere else in the economy, the cost of borrowing is moving up at the 12 regional Federal Home Loan Banks.
WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP)--Dr. James L. Goddard, Commissioner of Food and Drugs, said today that the drug Peritrate Sa was safe for heart patients.
LOS ANGELES, March 4-- An elaborate study of West Virginia coal miners' respiratory troubles proved inconclusive because some of the miners' wives had worse symptoms.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., March 4 (AP)--The New York Knicks trailed Detroit almost all the way tonight but rallied to defeat the Pistons, 121-119, on three free throws by Howie Komives in the last 33 seconds.

The abrupt cessation of the wildcat strike of longshoremen in Philadelphia after a Federal judge fined their union local $100,000 a day indicates the close ties between a union's pocketbook and its sense of responsibility. The dockworkers struck in protest against a contract clause under which they lost wages if a ship failed to arrive in port on time.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 4--For the second straight day, Mickey Mantle took an unscheduled batting drill today, both left-handed and right-handed. The New York Yankees hadn't expected him to be able to do this for a week or more.
The fortunes of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company--"T" to followers of the stock ticker--are beginning to draw attention from the professional investors.

Mayor Lindsay yesterday swore in Josep Ferro, former director of operations of the Buildings Department, as the department's Deputy Commissinner for Buildings. For Mr. Ferro, whose former post paid $18,000 a year, it will mean a $500 pay cut.
Mayor Lindsay's stock fell in Wall Street yesterday in reaction to his proposal for an increase of 50 per cent in the tax rate on stock transfers in New York.
The election of William A. Lyons as president was announced yesterday in Ithaca, N.Y., by the New York State Electric and Gas Corporation.

The Continental Oil Company and the Consolidation Coal Company announced yesterday a modification of the original terms of the merger agreement between the two companies. The agreement was originally announced last October.

WILMETTE, Ill., March 4-- Mr. and Mrs. George Howard Kline have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia Ellen Kline, to George Sylvan Hoffman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin P. Hoffman. The couple plan to marry in St. Athanasius Roman Catholic Church in Evanston on April 16.

Sam Perry of Fordham has won an I.C.4-A indoor track title the last two years. Frank Costello of Maryland and Alex Schulten of Bowdoin won last year. Tom Farrell of St. John's has never won in this meet.
An agreement for the acquisition of Random House, Inc., by the Radio Corporation of America was approved yesterday by directors of both companies.
The Inter-American Development Bank initiated a new lending policy yesterday designed to help broad community development with a $20-million loan to Peru.
Sears, Roebuck Co., the mail-order chain, and GambleSkogmo, Inc., the automotive variety chain, each announced yesterday record sales for February, the first month in their fiscal years.

WASHINGTON, March 4-- The index of wholesale primary market prices declined onetenth of 1 per cent to 104.9 (1957-59 equals 100) during the week ended March 1, the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. Farm products and industrial commodities moved lower in price while processed foods rose.

MIAMI, March 4 (UPI)-- Brooks Robinson, who was voted the American League's most valuable player in 1964 and was third in the balloting last year, ended a three-day holdout today by signing his 1966 contract with the Baltimore Orioles for a "slight raise."
The election of Dr. Jonathan E. Rhoads as a director was announced yesterday in Philadelphia by the Pennsalt Chemicals Corporation.
GISBORNE, New Zealand, Saturday, March 5 (Reuters)-- This city on the east coast of North Island was shaken by a heavy earthquake at noon today (8 p.m., Friday, New York time).
SALEM, N.J., March 4 (AP) --George Agriew Chamberlain, author of the novel "ScuddaHoo! Scudda-Hay!," died today in Salem County Memorial Hospital. He was 86 years old.

PHILADELPHIA, March 4 (UPI)--The National Collegiate Athletic Association notified the University of Pennsylvania today that it has canceled the use of the Palestra for Monday night's first round of its Eastern regional tournament between Davidson and Rhode Island.
BOSTON, March 4 (UPI)-- Julian Bond, a Negro recently refused a seat in the Georgia House of Representatives, said today he would rather go to prison for two years than be inducted into the Army.
Meridian, the Hunter College student newspaper for the Bronx campus, was closed Thursday as a result of a controversy over the suspension of its editor in chief by the Dean of Students.
The American Stock Exchange made a good try at advancing yesterday, but late selling pressure erased many of the earlier gains and the market closed mixed.
BONN March 4--Two West German specialists have saved from destruction the mosaic map of Madeba, the oldest known original map of the Holy Land.
CAIRO, March 4 (AP)-- Clark Graebner of Beachwood, Ohio, and Martin Riessen of Evanston, Ill., won singles matches today in the Nations Cup tennis tournament.

If Carl Orff's "Carmina Burana" has a virtue, it is that it gets people into the New York State Theater to hear Stravinsky's "Oedipus Rex." The two were done tandem by the New York City Opera last night and it was clear that the audience came to enjoy the after-intermission Orff.

CHICAGO, March 4--The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was sued in Circuit Court today by the owner of a slum building taken over last week by the civil rights leader and three organizations of his followers in a self-proclaimed "trusteeship."

Lecture, Continuing Legal Education Committee, Queens County Bar Association, 90-35 148th Street, Jamaica, Queens, 9:30 A.M. "Jurisdictional, Commercial and Matrimonial Aspects of International Law," Fritz Weirschenk.
DOBBS FERRY, N.Y., March 4--The junkyards of New England have become to Paul Marco what the marble quarries of Italy were to Michelangelo.
PARIS, March. 4--Valery Giscard d'Estaing is a brilliant phenomenon.
NEWARK, March 4--Special offerings for antipoverty programs will be collected in Protestant churches here and in the suburbs on Sunday, the Greater Newark Council of Churches said today.

Walter N. Rothschild Jr., president of Abraham Straus, Brooklyn, sharply criticized furniture makers yesterday for turning out defective merchandise. He also voiced disapproval of some apparel and toys being produced today.

HOUSTON, March 4 (AP) --The Harris County Medical Society has urged its 1,500 members to charge an unspecified fee for filling out insurance forms that require more than a minimum amount of information, a spokesman said today.
ARCADIA, Calif., March 4-- There are seven signs on the door of Barn 68 at Santa Anita Park and they are all variations of the same theme: "Bad Dog," "Doggone Bad Dog," "Very Bad Dog," and so on.

CHATTANOOGA, March 4 (AP)--Murray Raney of Lookout Mountain, whose development of catalysts earned him international recognition, died yesterday in a hospital here of injuries suffered in a car accident Tuesday. He was 80 years old.
Dense fog delayed arrivals and departures yesterday at the three major New York metropolitan area airports.

LORMAN, Miss., March 4 (UPI)--Campus security officers and local authorities arrested Charles Evers, the Negro civil rights leader, and 200 other demonstrators today when they marched on Alcorn College, a Negro institution, to present a list of grievances.
Businessmen were urged yesterday to increase their participation in the war on poverty and to work toward the other objectives of President Johnson's Great Society concept.
The bond-market paradox was evident again yesterday-- nominally favorable trading action belied the cotinuing presence of bearish undercurrents.
The Federal Communications Commission has "suggested" to the American Telephone and Telegraph Company that it consider lower charges for service to overseas points.

Encouraging movement toward a nuclear nonproliferation agreement seems to be developing in Geneva, although massive obstacles still lie ahead. A shift in Soviet policy appears to have opened the way for the seventeen-nation disarmament conference to begin article-by-article negotiation of a treaty later this month.
The 42d Street exit of the Fraknlin D. Roosevelt (East River) Drive will be closed at 10 A.M. Monday, March 14, and remain out of service for about a year.

All those well-intentioned efforts to rehabilitate Ellis Island should be stopped immediately. The best thing that could happen to that piece of historic property would be the installation of Anna Russell there as a national institution. The comedienne was back in Carnegie Hall last night to demonstrate why to a large, loving and justifiably amused audience.
A 71-year-old woman, pronounced dead by a doctor at 5 P.M. yesterday, was discovered to be alive as she was being carried into a funeral home nearly four hours later.

Rick Barry of the San Francisco Warriors has been named the winer of the 11th Hy Turkin Award by the Metropolitan Basketball Writers Association. The trophy is presented annually to the outstanding pro rookie of the season.
WASHINGTON, March 4--The United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals assignment of patent and customs cases for the session commencing Monday, April 4, 1966:
The chief executive of the Ruberoid Company disclosed here yesterday that the concern had been approached by two major industrial companies wishing to discuss a merger.
Executive changes were announced yesterday by three major transportation companies.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 4--Ken Boyer bounded onto the little porch of the New York Mets' clubhouse at noon today, glanced at the swarm of persons crowding round the old man with the cane and said, "You'd almost think Casey was in town."

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., March 4--Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Anthony A. Carbone of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Darlene Starr Carbone, to Julien David Yoseloff, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Yoseloff of Jamesburg, N.J.
There was a lot of badinage on Wall Street yesterday about what the New York Stock Exchange could be rechristened if it ever left town in a huff over Mayor
NEW DELHI, March 4--One student was killed and eight were wounded when the police opened fire today on a crowd of demonstrators in Krishnagar in the Indian district of West Bengal.
GEORGE ROMNEY AND MICHIGAN, by Richard C. Fuller (Vantage $2.75). A look at Michigan politics.
KONG KONG, March 4(AP) --An Angry Soviet captain and his 155 crewmen were finally allowed to go ashore today, two days after their cruise ship arrived in Hong Kong.
Melvin E. Dawley, president and chief executive officer of Lord Taylor, Inc., was elected president of the Fifth Avenue Association at the group's board meeting.

ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., March 4 (UPI)--A New Jersey high school sophomore, Bill Gaines tied the world indoor 60-yard dash record of 5.9 seconds tonight in the opening session of the 1966 Amateur Athletic Union's national track and field Championships.
The stock market declined rather sharply in late trading yesterday after having shown some strength earlier in the session. Trading was only moderately active.
WASHINGTON, March 4-- Senator Jacob K. Javits withheld his support today from the New York City tax program proposed by Mayor Lindsay, but he promised to "study it most sympathetically."
LONDON, March 4--Arthur Goldberg, United States representative at the United Nations, said tonight he was confident that the United States could get the enemy in Vietnam "to mend his ways."

BALTIMORE, March 4 (UPI) --Long shots won the first two races at Pimlico today to set up a $1,440.20 daily double but the chalk players had their turn in the Glyndon Purse when Salt Spray won by five lengths at 2-5.

WASHINGTON, March 4-- Two drug manufacturers were ordered by the Food and Drug Administration today either to change the labeling on certain drugs frequently prescribed for nausea and motion sickness or to withdraw them from the market.
COLUMBIA, S.C., March 4 (UPI)--Senator Donald S. Russell, Democratic of South Carolina, announced today his candidacy for election to his Senate seat, which he obtained last spring by appointment.
Met with Cabinet to discuss administrative and organization matters; flew to his Johnson City, Tex., ranch for the weekend.

YONKERS, March 4--An 11th-hour "deal" having put off picket lines that had been threatened by the local chapter of the Congress on Racial Equality, the 17th year of harness racing at Yorkers Raceway was launched tonight without any untoward incidents.

"We have to remember that the Police Department is not an unguided missile," Mayor Lindsay remarked yesterday. His comment was a reply to critics who have been charging that the new city administration has been trying, improperly, to get its hands on the department's controls.

WASHINGTON, March 4-- The Senate Foreign Relations committee rejected today initial attempts to cut the supplemental foreign aid bill and indicated it would also reject any riders to the bill dealing with Vietnam policy.

PENSACOLA, Fla., March 4 --The second round of the $65,000 Pensacola, open tournament was postponed until tomorrow because of a heavy downpour and a lightning storm. Postponements like this one in golf always create problems for contestants and sponsors.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 4--Secretary General Thant announced today a new effort to break the deadlock between armed forces of the Greek and Turkish elements in Cyprus.

Assemblyman Louis Kalish of the 57th Assembly District in Boro Park, Brooklyn, Democratic leader of the district, died of a heart ailment yesterday at Maimonides Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 69 years old and lived at 4001 Sixth Avenue in that borough.

As inconspicuous as a convention of stockbrokers in a gypsy camp, Buildings Commissioner Charles G. Moerdler and a dozen aides and their wives last night "raided" three coffee-houses in Greenwich Village.
A modestly financed film about Jesus directed by an atheist has become the movie "sleeper" of the season.
The new Portugese airline TAP announced yesterday that it had asked the Civil Aeronautics Board for permission to fly between Lisbon and New York.

DETROIT, March 4 (AP)-- Rabbi Morris Adler, shot in the head three weeks ago during a Sabbath service in his synagogue, remained unconscious today, and Sinai Hospital officials said that "supportive measures remain necessary to maintain basic bodily functions."

SAIGON, March 4--United States fighter-bombers, apparently released from orders restricting their attacks, struck far north in North Vietnam yesterday and were reported to have cut the northwest rail line to China. Another line, in the northeast, was not attacked.
LONDON, March ,4--The Institute of Public Relations has suspended two members for a year because they used a supposedly impartial "front" organization to spread propaganda on behalf of a client.

INDIAN HILL, Ohio, March 4--The engagement of Miss Judith Ann Knight, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Lloyd Knight, to Christopher Hurd Wren, son of Mrs. Hurd Wren of Atlanta, and the late Mr. Wren, has been announced by the future bride's parents.

MIAMI, March 4--Summer A. (Huey) Long's restless oceangoing yawl Ondine, from the Larchmont Yacht Club, put into the Bertram Yacht Basin this morning to round out one of the strongest and certainly the largest gatherings of cruising yachts ever assembled for competition in Southern waters.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 4--Gulfstream Park opened its season today, the longest in the 21-year history of the local thoroughbred track. And its chairman of the board, James Donn Sr., said, "there will be betting on every race through the entire 46 days."

NORTH CONWAY, N.H., March 4--Eighteen-year-old Duncan Cullman of Franconia, N.H., and Penny Northrup, 15, of Ellicottsville, N.Y., won the first major trophies today in the three-day Eastern Alpine championships.
NEW DELHI, March 4-- Rebellious Mizo tribesmen were reported today to have attacked several more towns and outposts in their remote district in eastern India.

Frank V. Brach, chairman and president of E.J. Brach Sons and W.F. Laporte, chairman and president of the American Home Products Corporation, announced yesterday that an agreement of merger had been approved by the directors of both companies.

CHICAGO, March 4--A blizzard raged today across a vast expanse of the Northern Plains and upper Middle West. It isolated scores of cities and towns, stranded thousands of motorists and stalled passenger and freight trains.

Ninety paintings by the 19thcentury British artist Joseph Mallord William Turner arrived yesterday afternoon from London on the United States, flagship of the United States Lines. They will go on exhibition March 23 at the Museum of Modern Art.
DETROIT, March 4 (UPI)-- Auto industry leaders looked forward today to topping the elusive 200,000-unit production mark next week with the resumption of production at the American Motors Corporation.

LONDON, March 4--The main subject of public concern in Britain for the last few days has not been the coming elections or the economic situation. It has been the fate of a 10year-old girl in a children's home.
LONDON, March 4--The change in the name of the Daily Worker, Britain's Communist party newspaper, to the Morning Star and its expansion from four to six pages will take place late in April.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., March 14 (AP)--Carlyle Sitterson, acting chancellor of the University of North Carolina approved today invitations to two Communist scholars who have been asked to speak at the school.
The spot rate on the British pound closed yesterday at $2.7983, down 6 points from the level the preceding day, in moderate trading on foreign-exchange markets here.
LINCOLN, R.I., March 4 (AP)--Lincoln Downs race track was granted an extension today of the current meeting from April 18 to May 30.

MAHOPAC FALLS, N.Y., March 4--Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Joseph E. Sullivan of Mahopac Falls and Madison; Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ellen Sullivan, to Larry Burkett, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles L. Burkett of Fort Recovery, Ohio.

WASHINGTON March 4-- Mayor Richard J. Daley of Chicago told a House subcommittee today that President Johnson's plan to rebuild slum neighborhoods in American cities needed revision and substantially greater funds to achieve its goals.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 4 --Five Americans who have been under Federal arrest for three weeks are today the center of a nationalist furor over mineral prospecting and export in Brazil. Officials here said the Americans' case would go to a court in Brasilia on Monday.
The State Insurance Department is considering raising insurance rates for makes and models of cars that are involved in accidents more frequently than others.
RALEIGH, N.C., March 4 (AP)--Duke edged North Carolina, 21-20, tonight in the semifinals of the Atlantic Coast Conference basketball tournament.
ACCRA, Ghana, March 4--Of the six military coups in Africa within the last three months, the overthrow of President Kwame Nkrumah of Ghana was by far the most elaborately organized.
An influential Protestant journal has sharply criticized the "deep confusion" of United States goals in vietnam and called for the development of "some sense of proportion in relating means to ends."

SURREALISM, which only a few years ago seemed to be a dead issue so far as the New York art scene was concerned, has lately been enjoying a spirited revival. This season has already brought us full-scale exhibitions of Dali and Magritte, as well as a number of more fragmentary shows foeusing on aspects of the surrealist style.
Mayor Lindsay is asking, in his tax package, for one levy no other city in the country has--a graduated tax on all net income of city residents and on income earned in the city by nonresidents.

WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP)--Elliot M. See Jr. and Maj. Charles A. Bassett 2d of the Air Force, who were killed while in training for the forthcoming Gemini 9 three-day orbital mission, were buried today.
PARIS, arch 4--France has adopted the tactic of supporting no international monetary reform plan at all for the time being, reliable sources reported today.

HOUSTON, March 4--Senator Ralph W. Yarborough of Texas, head of one of the two rival Democratic factions that support President Johnson at home, told a cheering labor delegate audience today that Texas was undergoing a "political revolution" unrivaled in 75 years.
This Saturday and Sunday, worshipers will join their ministers, priests and rabbis

BERLIN, March 4--Church bells ring throughout Germany and an elated public fills the streets and squares in East and West Germany, striking up the hymn: "Let all now thank our Lord." The date is Nov. 1, 1976, the day of the peaceful reunification of Germany.

Genesco, Inc., has made its second offer in six years to acquire the stock of Julius Garfinckel Co., Washington, D.C., retail chain. The offer, involving about $43.5-million in convertible preferred voting stock, was rejected by Garfinckel's directors, it was reported yesterday.

The Coast Guard scheduled yesterday a formal investigation of Thursday morning's crash of the Grace Line passenger-cargo ship Santa Isabel into the Raritan River drawbridge--a railroad span linking Perth Amboy and South Amboy, N.J.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 4 --The sign shrieks "El Cid-- Topless--Mother of Eight-- Momray Spiegelman."

ROME, March 4--Special earth from the grave of President Kennedy and from St. Patrick's Hill in Ireland will be mixed in an urn to be placed in, the cornerstone of a church to be erected near Parma to the memory of the late President and dedicated to St. Patrick.
The Southern California Edison Company announced yesterday in its annual report that it expects to spend a record $1.5billion over the next five years on expansion programs.

More than 400 Brooklyn junior high school pupils were given protective shots against hepatitis yesterday after doctors said it was possible for them to have been exposed to the disease by an art teacher who licked paint brushes.
The London stock market continued to be firm yesterday and closed with a broad range of small gains.

Mayor Lindsay and the cause of civic beautification won a preliminary victory yesterday when the State Department of Public Works agreed to his request to delay construction of the Richmond Parkway on Staten Island. Overriding the legalistic quibbling of bureaucratic underlings, the department wisely acknowledged the Mayor's legal right to cancel the approval Mayor Wagner had given to the project two days before he left office.
WASHHINGTON, March 4 (AP)--The State Department reported today a further cutback in sailings by ships of non-Communist nations to North Vietnam.

ANOTHER distressing example of Hollywood fouling its nest--professionally, socially, commercially and es pecially artistically--is provided by a film called "The Oscar," which opened at the Festival and Loew's State yesterday. Obviously the community doesn't need enemies so long as it has itself.
The Chelsea Theater Center, a nonprofit community group, will begin operating tomorrow night in its new home, an Episcopal church nom designated a New York landmark.
THE delicately-tinted amber glass box framed a mo ment of a recent morning for Mrs. Albert A. List, who peered through the box to see the bright sun touching late winter in Central Park.

Mayor Lindsay proposed last night that the Legislature give the city $25-million and vastly increase its borrowing power to finance low-income and middleincome housing and the rehabilitation of slum buildings.

In the face of a threat of delay in the City Council on his tax program and opposition that ranges from Wall Street to the labor movement, Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that he would press for the adoption of his whole tax package without compromise.

The Chairman of the City Commission on Human Rights predicted yesterday that the appointment of Sanford D. Garelik as chief inspector of the Police Department would improve the department's relations with the Negro community.

KANSAS CITY, March 4 (AP)--Pennsylvania was ruled out of the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament tonight because officials at the school insisted they "would not comply" with the N.C.A.A.'S 1.6 academic legislation, N.C.A.A. headquarters said.

WASHINGTON, March 4-- President Johnson designated Secretary of State Dean Rusk today as the "director" of all overseas operations affecting two or more Government departments. Until now he has been more of a "coordinator."

WASHINGTON, March 4-- The United States moved today to fortify the new military Government in Ghana by extending diplomatic recognition and expressing hope for "mutually beneficial relations" between the two countries.
WASHINGTON, March 4-- A process developed by oil company scientists holds the promise of a pure air supply for long space and undersea missions. In the meantime,...
A 27-year-old New Jersey factory worker was arrested yesterday aboard a Washingtonbound train in Philadelphia and charged with having threatened to assassinate President Johnson.
Deputy Mayor Robert Price indicated last night that he thought it was inexplicable to defend the right of policemen to belong to the John Birch Society.

The New York Foreign Freight Forwarders and Brokers Association, Inc., asked the Federal Maritime Commission yesterday to reconsider the basic premise of a current rule that prohibits an ocean carrier's paying brokerage to a New York forwarder if the carrier or its agent is requested to perform a forwarding service outside the Port of New York area.
COURCHEVEL, France, March 4 (AP)--Jules Melquiond of France won the special slalom of the Three Valley ski week today for his first big international victory.
The wholesale commodity price Index fell to 114.4 on Thursday from 114.8 on Wednesday.

GROSSE POINTE WOODS, Mich., March 4--Mr. and Mrs. Bryce T. Lyall have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Priscilla Lyall, to John Owens Hartung. He is the son of Mrs. S.E. Hartung of Oswego, N.Y., and the late Mr. Hartung.
Cluett, Peabody Co., apparel manufacturer and retailer, announced here yesterday the election of Gordon Edwards as a director.

Fess Parker, the tall Texan who once starred on television as Davy Crockett and now plays Daniel Boone on the National Broadcasting Company series, has exchanged verbal shots with the Kentucky legislature. The actor said he was astonished that so august a body had "turned into a passel of television critics."
DOVER, Mass., March 4 (AP) --Dr. Leslie Silverman, a nationally known expert on air pollution, died today at his home here. He was 51 years old.
An overflow adolescent audience gave Patrick Sky a rousing reception at his Town Hall program last night.
