MOSCOW, March 4 (AP)-- Communist China has agreed to send a delegation to the 23d Congress of the Soviet Communist party opening here March 29, informed sources said today.

The Newmont Mining Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to divest itself of its holdings in the Phelps Dodge Corporation under a settlement with the Department of Justice of an antitrust action begun in December, 1962.

TOKYO, Saturday, March 5 --A British Boeing 707 jetliner carrying 130 passengers and crewmen crashed in flames in thick forest at the foot of Mount Fuji, about 50 miles south of Tokyo today, the Japanese Aviation Bureau announced.

WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP)--Representative Chet Holifield, chairman of the Senate-House Atomic Energy Committee, said today the nuclearpropelled merchant ship Savannah "is the biggest white elephant afloat."

Mendel Mozes, journalist and director of the Jewish Telegraphic Agency in Poland before World War II, died Thursday at the home of his daughter, Mrs. Dorothy Rawitz, in Rehovot, Israel. His age was 76.
ALBANY, March 4 (AP)-- The State Education Commissioner, making a rare intervention in a threatened strike situation, tonight directed a group of Long Island teachers not to go on strike Tuesday.
TORONTO, March 4--The Studebaker Corporation is out of the automobile business after 64 years.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 4--Don C. Silverthorne, founder and former president of the defunct San Francisco National Bank, was ordered today to undergo a 90-day psychiatric study in prison, after being sentenced conditionally to a maximum term of 60 years.
World Airways, Inc., filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday covering a proposed secondary offering of 975,000 shares of common stock.

BALTIMORE, March 4--The engagement of Miss Eileen Amy Ferrin, daughter of Mrs. Ernest C. Ferrin and the late Mr. Ferrin, formerly of New York, to Richard Lee Bazelon has been announced. Mr. Bazelon is the son of Judge David L. Bazelon of the United States Court of Appeals, and Mrs. Bazelon of Washington.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 4 (AP)--A hot-shooting St. Louis team threw a zone press at the Boston Celtics and breezed to a 132-112 National Basketball Association victory tonight.
The chairman of the City Commission on Human Rights tried to catch a taxicab last night. He caught two--both of whose drivers, he said, were discriminating against Negroes.
PHILADELPHIA, March 4-- L. Stauffer Oliver, who was President Judge of Philadelphia Common Pleas Court No. 7 at his retirement in 1959, died yesterday at the age of 86.

DANBURY, Conn., March 4 --Last autumn the Danbury Federal Correctional Institution started a work-release program under which certain prisoners were allowed to work daily at jobs in industrial plants.
Samuel I. Birnbaum, a certified public accountant, was convicted in Federal court yesterday of having given more than $20,000 in bribes to Harold Simon, an Internal Revenue Service agent.

Parks Commissioner Thomas P.F. Hoving said yesterday that he was writing to the Controller's office to ask that it return to Huntington Hartford the money he deposited with the city six years ago toward the cost of building a cafe in Central Park. Mayor Lindsay disapproved the project last month.
WASHINGTON, March 4--Cash deposits rnd withdrawals, close of business, March 1

Frank Guarrera will sing the part of Ford in the performance of "Falstaff to be given tonight at 8:15 by the Metropolitan Opera. He replaces Thomas Stewart who was to have replaced Kostas Paskalis, the baritone originally scheduled to appear.
Price increases involving paper, metal and chemical products were announced yesterday by a number of manufacturers.

READING, Pa., March 5-- Long Island University defeated the nation's top-ranked college division basketball team, Cheyney (Pa.) State, 67-64, tonight in a National Collegiate Athletic Association Eastern Regional final.

SPRING will make an early appearance this year at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx. A preview of the season can be seen indoors in the botanical garden's Main Conservatory today through March 20. On display will be freesias, hyacinths and masses of tulips, daffodils and crocuses. The show is open to the public daily from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. There is a 25-cent admission charge for adults.

STAMFORD, Conn.--Few places within an hour or so of New York are so rewarding for family sightseeing as the Stamford Museum and Nature Center. In the museum and along the nature trails, in the science building and art gallery, in the zoo and on the farm, there are objects that interest, delight and inform.
Did Martin Luther actually hammer his 95 theses to the church door in Wittenberg?

THE biggest city in Texas, the finest deep-water harbor in the Gulf; international trade, banks and know-how--all this was Galveston. But the superb prospects of this commercial paradise were killed by the complacency and greed of the few families who controlled the port; Houston oil men seized the initiative, cutting a ship channel from Houston to the Gulf in 1914; Galveston has been by-passed ever since.
MOSCOW, March 5--The Soviet Union disclosed today that neither of its two Venus probes this week had succeeded in transmitting information, or pictures of the planet back to earth.

BROOKLINE, Mass., March 5--Mr. and Mrs. James Phillips Parker of Brookline and Marblehead and Key Biscayne, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Betty Winslow Parker, to Paul Revere O'Connell Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. O'Connell of Worcester.

BUENOS AIRES--A traveler setting out to sample the manifold wonders of Argentina must be prepared to live with paradox. On the one hand, he will encounter luxurious living, Old World service, the most modern means of transport and one of the world's most sophisticated cities. Only a few hours, or even minutes, away, he may step into a world of primeval nature or of civilizations that were old when Columbus sailed.

CHARLESTON, W.Va., March 4--John D. Rockefeller 4th, a dashing, smiling 6-foot6-inch, 28-year-old social worker in a maroon Mustang, is running hard and fast in Kanawha County in his first bid for public office, a seat in the House of Delegates.

In the imperial village of Washington from which our destinies are decided, birdwatching has become the most popular rural sport; and among local ornithologists the keen Texas eye of Lyndon B. Johnson is famed for its ability to tell a hawk from a dove at impressive distances.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, March 5--The Organization of African Unity turned today to the United Nations more than to its own resources for help in bringing down the rebel white regime in Rhodesia and in ending apartheid in South-Africa.

WHEN, on Jan. 2, 1965, Ira Wallach's "Absence of a Cello" closed on Broadway following a struggle for patronage, its co-producer, Michael Ellis, decided that he needed time off from the treadmill. He had at that time co-produced altogether four shows in as many years.

ALL records will be eclipsed this summer on international airline routes linking North America with transAtlantic, Pacific and Caribbean destinations. There will be 1,556 flights a week-- with a new high of 200,206 seats--available to tourists heading out of the country.

PARIS--Under France's energetic plans for the 1966 tourist season, even such a characteristic institution as the Paris Metro is now being given a face-lifting. The stark, classic decor of the subway platforms is being brightened and, at particularly busy stations, such as Concorde on the Vincennes-Neuilly line, closed-circuit television has been installed.
MERIBEL, France, March 5 (AP)--Christi Haas of Austria defeated her 17-year-old teammate, Erika Schinegger, for the downhill title of the Three Valleys international ski competition today.
A series of four Sunday lectures at the Brooklyn Museum will be initiated today with "Greek Gold: Treasures from Greece and Persia."
A new, fully tenanted, 50story skyscraper on Park Avenue has 11 employes. An older but no less thriving 15-story office building on Fifth Avenue has no one at all on its employe roster.

MONTREAL, March 5 (AP)--Robert Arum, a New York lawyer who has been traveling in two countries seeking a site for the Cassius Clay-Ernie Terrell heavyweight title fight, said today the search had narrowed to four United States cities and three in Canada.

More than two years ago, Jacques Barzun, provost and dean of the faculty at Columbia University and infant terrible of the academic world, said the liberal arts tradition is dead or dying. Liberal arts college presidents across the country quickly felt their pulses.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., March 5--The speaker, pointed toward New York City, 85 miles to the west.

GREENWICH, Conn., March 5--Indian Harbor Yacht Club lost the opening race to Seawanhaka-Corinthian Y.C. today, then won the other races to score a 6-1 victory in their annual inter-fleet frostbite team match sailed in mist and fog and an 8-to-10 knot easterly.

PARIS. NEAR the beginning of the Rue Dauphine, as you walk up from the Seine, is an inauspicious alley leading off to the right, the kind one normally associates with sullen concierges, lumbering clochards, and furtive gray cats. Its faintly potbellied houses are now having centuries of grime washed from their wrinkled facades, but many of the inner courts remain as picturesquely unkempt as ever.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., March 5--Mr. and. Mrs. Donald Denecke Hotaling have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Donna Lynn Hotaling, to Donald Frederick Stickles 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ervin Carlton Stickles Jr. of Newtown, Conn. A spring wedding is planned.
LONDON--The British are celebrating this year the 900th anniversary of their most important church and of one of the most significant battles in this country's long history.

HAVERFORD, Pa., March 5 --Mrs. Charles Classen of Bryn Mawr and Mrs. Francis A.C. Vosters Jr. of Wilmington, Del., won the United States women's squash racquets doubles championship today for the second straight year and the third time since 1960.
Former Mayor Robert F. Wagner called on the Lindsay administration yesterday to give full answers to questions about political intervention in the selection of top officers of the Police Department.

ST.-JULIEN-DE-LAMPON, France, March 3--The castle of Fenelon was built to last. That was some 900 years ago, and lasted it has, with walls seven feet thick and magnificent imperial towers. It has repelled invading armies but now it has met its match: the sonic boom.

FOR best flavor many vegetables can be grown at home. Roadside produce markets often have wide selections but too often their varieties are chosen for high yield, appearance and keeping quality rather than for flavor. Home growers can choose their varieties for taste appeal.

WASHINGTON, March 5--Of some 720,000 hospital beds in the United States, almost one-third are judged to be obsolete in terms of the buildings in which they are housed and the services which support them. There is a higher proportion of these out-of-date and rundown hospitals in the large urban areas, where the greatest need exists, than in the small towns.
THE 1966 travel season promises to be a busy one for the world's passenger-ship lines, but one devoted to carrying passengers rather than with welcoming new ships to the seas.

ON Oct. 15, 1950, Gina Bachauer made her American debut to 35 persons in Town Hall. ATHENS, March 5--Three rocket launching pads are being prepared on Euboea Island, for nine lower ionosphere probes May 20 by Arkas and Centaur rockets of the European Space Research Agency.
NEW ORLEANS, March 5 (AP)--Just About, a 4-year-old invader from Florida, captured the 39th running of the $77,000 New Orleans Handicap today and set a track record in the process.
NEW DELHI--The carpet-weavers, shawl merchanhs, papiermache makers and woodworkers of Kashmir are readying their wares once again, for a record influx of tourists is expected this spring and summer.
ACCRA, March 5 (Reuters) --The Ghana Gazette said today it was sheer nonsense for Kwame Nkrumah to think he could rule Ghana from Guinea as head of a Ghana-Guinea union.

The Bronx school bus strike was ended last night when both sides agreed to accept Theodore W. Kheel, transit labor expert, as arbitrator, with his decision to be binding on each party.

ROME, March 5 (AP)-- Premier Aldo Moro and Senator Giuliano Pajetta, a Communist, exchanged angry remarks over the role of Italian doctors in Vietnam during a parliamentary debate on Government policy today.

BELLAGIO, ITALY. IN the awesomely lovely and serene setting of Villa Serbelloni, which is at the point where the Lake of Como divides to form its Lecco and Como arms, one of the more unusual conferences an broadcasting was held 10 days ago.

MONTEGO BAY, Jamaica, March 5 (Reuters).--Drenching rain greeted the arrival of Queen Elizabeth II in this normally sunbaked resort today and transformed an open-air reception into a soggy, indoor crush.

BOSTON, March 5--A cadre of the group that organized the unexpected victory by Henry Cabot Lodge in the New Hampshire Presidential primary in 1964 has been reassembled to offer advice to political candidates.

PORTILLO, Chile--Preparations are under way in this Andean resort for the 1966 World Ski Championships, which will be held from Aug. 4 to 14, Chileans are making the maximum possible efforts not only to be perfect hosts for the skiing competition but also to show off the nation's capacity as a ski center for enthusiasts of all levels.

Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that he would seek an amendment to the City Charter to allow all birth and death certificated to be kept at the central office of the Department of Health at 125 Worth Street.

WASHINGTON, Mar. 5--The International Bank four Reconstruction and Development is ready to help finance a new Plan aimed at using wasted natural gas from some poor countries as a source of badly needed fertilizer for other poor countries.

FORGIVE, please, as quotation from myself. In 1960 I wrote, in another place: "Is there a future for Tennessee Williams? Or is there nothing ahead of him but his past? The Federal Aviation Agency will hold a conference in Washington on March 29 and 30 to review suggestions for improving passenger evacuation and the crash-worthiness of airliners.
Yesterday's air crash near Tokyo, in which 124 persons were killed, was the fourth worst air disaster involving a single plane. Two of the others also took place near the Japanese capital.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, March 5 --A contract was signed this week between the Governmentowned Ceylon Petroleum Corporation and the Soviet Petroleum export organization, for delivery to Ceylon of refined petroleum products during 1967.

OF all the expected "surprises" that came with the announcement of nominations for Acad emy awards (and we must admit this annual ritual of announcing the nominations is rendered just a bit more amusing by the presence of the element of surprise), by far the most, truly amazing and significant surprises, indeed, were the nominations of four of the people from the filmed "Othello" for best-acting awards.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP)--The Agency for International Development has agreed to undertake a full-scale investigation of prices paid to Asian steel interests by South Vietnam with American-aid funds, Senator Birch Bayh, Democrat of Indiana, said today.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., March 5--A combat commander back from South Vietnam told President Johnson today that the United States should continue its build up so that there would be no question in the mind of the Vietnamese Communists that they must give up.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla.-- Although not a native of Florida, the beauti ful pink-plumaged flamingo has become one of the state's most interesting attractions.
Negroes who want to join volunteer fire departments in New York's suburbs charge they are being rejected because of racial prejudice.
MOSCOW--Not the least remarkable as pect of the mellowing process that has taken place in Soviet society in the last decade is its hospitality and availability to foreign tourists.

COINS continue to serve as tools for archealo gists in all part of the world as they seek to unravel and re-tie the threads of ancient history. Hardly a week goes by without a news account of how a coin discovery provided the missing piece for a puzzle concerning the economics, government, customs or even the existence of some city on tribe of antiquity.

OSLO--Last year, about three million tourists, or almost the total poptuation of Norway, visited this country. They spent about $110-million, thus contributing considerably to the nation's foreign currency purse.

ALBANY, March 5--From a nerve center on Washington Avenue here, orders go out regularly that affect more than 70 architectural firms employed by the State University in a $1.35-billion expansion program.

VIENNA, March 5--Brass bands, motorcycles and leading politicians competed for attention this afternoon in the streets of Vienna as the national election campaign ended.
A detailed plan for the merger of seven Protestant denominations into a 23-millionmember United Church has been proposed by an Episcopal delegate to the Consultation on Church Union.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla.-- The number of places for tourists to sleep in Florida stood at a record high on Jan. 1, a total of 499,009 units (or rooms) in motels, hotels, rooming houses and apartment buildings. This is an increase of 17,161 units, as compared with Jan. 1. 1965.

THE huge primrose family members among its members those hardy hybrid plants com monly called auriculas. Although they have been cultivated abroad for centuries, they are relative newcomers to American gardens.

IRON MOUNTAIN, Mich., March 5--Gusty headwinds buffeting the lofty 90-meter jumping hill atop this mining community's Pine Mountain caused the postponement of the national championships today. It was rescheduled for tomorrow morning.

New York Diary. Wednesday: Arrival at Penn sylvania Station was bad. Rubble, jackhammer blasts and black air lit by little globes of dead orange light. Figures with gray masks for faces scampered down tunnels carrying dispatch cases, undoubtedly on urgent business to Hell.
STOCKHOLM--Actually, Swedes do not bathe in the nude or sin as openly and as euthusiastical ly as some hopeful American tourists expect them to.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland--In the new climate of friendship between the two Irish Governments, a campaign to increase tourism is now under way, and the first invitations are going to the United States.

While Richard Marks was at the Hackley School in Tarrytown he was a quietly agreeable, serious boy. Sometimes he would roam the school's wide hilltop clearing and gaze down at the silvery Hudson or climb to the highest outlook to trace the shimmering outlines of the vast city to the south.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (UPI--Eighteen House Republicans moved today to steal a march on the Johnson Administration by proposing new civil rights legislation to bolster enforcement of the four major laws enacted since 1957.

PHILADELPHIA, March 5-- Comdr. John O. Ottesen, U.S.N.R., retired, of Germantown has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Mette Louise Ording Ottesen, to Robert Mason Beecroft. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund M. Beecroft of Little Falls. N.J.

WASHINGTON, March 5-- The Democrats netted more than $600,000 from their 176page publication "Toward an Age of Greatness," but they plan to give it all to a nonpartisan foundation because of the public uproar over the sale of advertising in the book to corporations.
Governor Rockefeller has offered the City University increased state aid, but only if the city matches state funds.

LONDON--Early last spring, at home in rainy London, my husband and I decided to rent the gatehouse of a chateau in southwestern France. We did this on the strength of a newspaper description, a hazy photograph and a promise of sunshine.
ANNAPOLIS, March 5--Maurice Heckscher of the University of Pennsylvania, the top favorite, was beaten in the quarter-finals of the national intercollegiate squash racquets championship today.

BALBOA, C.Z., March 5-- Gustav Wallenberg, a stage producer and former musical comedy actor in the United States and Sweden who used the name Gus Wally, died Thursday of a heart attack at Boquete, Panama. His age was 62.

A near-riot broke out in Brooklyn yesterday outside a storefront office where leaders of the W. E. B. DuBois Club held a press conference to deny that their organization was a Communist-front group, as charged by the Justice Department.

No one should begin packing this week, but there is a network of highways now under construction in Asia that will take the traveler of the future through 11 countries of the Middle and the Far East. There are two major highways in the network. One of them is scheduled for completion in late 1967 or the spring of 1968, and the other in 1970.
DEWITT, N.Y., March 5-- Miss Sarah Gordon Smith and James Thomas MacGregor plan to marry Aug. 20.

Godfrey, looking Madison Avenue-ish by virtue of his grey flannel Suit, trim mustache and ...

A bar association has instituted a suit in Federal District Court here seeking an enlarged judiciary in the state on the basis of the one-man, one-vote principle laid down by the United States Supreme Court.
WASHINGTON, March 5-- Every Monday afternoon at 4 o'clock, Representative George W. Grider of Tennessee sits down in his black swivel-chair and waits for the telephone to ring.

Mayor Lindsay conceded yesterday that if his entire tax program was adopted and the Legislature authorized an increase in the real estate tax, as he has requested, the city would have a "surplusage" of about $130-million.

BRIDGEPORT, Ala.--A few miles from this town in northeastern Alabama is a Stone Age site that is proving to be a popular attraction for space age sightseers. Russell Cave, the oldest known human habitation in the southeastern United States, has drawn an increasing number of visitors since it was opened to the public in 1961.
The housewife opening a jar of preserves or the little boy eating a piece of candy probably will not notice that the product they are eating has a new ingredient.

PENSACOLA, Fla., March 5 --Doug Sanders was disqualified for failing to sign his score card today after finishing with a second-round 67 that apparently had given him the lead in the $65,000 Pensacola open gulf tournament. His 36-hole total was 130--14 under par.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill. March 5 --The name of Adlai E. Stevenson 3d was laid before the Democratic State Central Committee this week with the suggestion that he be slated as the party's nominee for state treasurer.

WASHINGTON, March 5-- The "Johnson system" of executive administration never ceases to astonish Washington. He hedges all his bets. He always moves, but he moves in irregular jig-time, two steps forward and one Back. He is a cautious extremist, who wants to keep everybody off balance, so he backs into the future.

The Promenade at the New York State Theater, a favorite sport for after-curtain parties since the house opened in April, 1964, will reverberate with its first discotheque party on April 19. It will be held after a special gala performance of four new ballets by the New York City Ballet.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, March 5--The day that an indignant letter appeared in the columns of The Voice of Ethiopia complaining about the noise of traffic, cars on Churchill Avenue were held up by a string of donkeys and a small flock of sheep.

IF other vacationists are like our family, they have always been a little afraid of New York. It seemed like a nice place to visit, but how could one spend an entire vacation there and keep from going broke? The city, with its unlimited allures and demands, seemed unmanageable for a family vacation.

DAKAR, Senegal, Sunday, March 6 (Reuters)--Kwame Nkrumah, ousted President of Ghana, told Ghanaians today that he knew they would crush their new regime "at the appropriate time." He repeated his pledge to return home soon.

BISHOP, Calif.--High on the slopes of the arid White Mountains, at a point about 20 miles east of this eastern California town, is a fascinating and spectacular sight that is seen only by a few venturesome tourists.

CONTEMPORARY opera could use more help from the recording industry. If this seems an unreasonable statement, it is largely because opera is by nature unreasonable in economic terms. It is expensive to produce and a consumer of the time and energy of a great many people.

John Bach, the coach of Fordham University's scrappy basketball team, congratulated himself yesterday as his Rams upset Manhattan College's Metropolitan Conference champions, 82-72, in the Fordham gymnasium.

The nation is experiencing an apparent upsurge in head injuries for which doctors, medical scientists and the general public are ill-prepared, reports from a conference of leading experts suggest. Automobile accidents were described as a major factor.

PORTLAND, Ore., March 5-- Tears and laughter mixed today when 10 of the nation's leading poets staged a two-hour "readin" to protest United States policy in Vietnam.

NO one is more knowledgeable about Elizabethan his tory than the prolific A.L. Rowse, as his numerous historical works testify; and when, as in the present book, he writes of the Elizabethan-Jacobean era, what he has to say is full of interest. His prose is often, though not always, superior to that of most contemporary historians, and it sometimes sparkles with a particularly felicitous phrase.

RABAT, Morocco--Only the narrow Strait of Gibraltar separates this North African na tion from the Iberian Peninsula. However, as an obstacle to large-scale tourism, the strait seems to have been more effective than an ocean. Fewer than 500,000 tourists visited Morocco last year, as opposed to the 14-million who went to Spain.

WASHINGTON. THE large retrospective exhibition of the works of Frederic Edwin Church (1826-1900), organized by the National Collection of Fine Arts and currently to be seen at the Smithsonian Institution, is the first such survey to be devoted to this once celebrated American figure since the memorial show mounted at the Metropolitan Museum in the year of his death.

WASHINGTON, March 5-- Senior Cabinet officials of the United States and Canada ended a two-day economic conference here today with expressions of hope that they were moving toward accomodation on some vexing conflicts.

T.S. Eliot called Simone Weil "a great soul who might have become a saint." Leslie Fiedler described her as "the Outsider as saint, in an age of alienation." She herself, somewhat contemptuous of sainthood, claimed merely to be "waiting for God." Waiting --but not hopelessly like Beckett.

The engagement of Miss Virginia Battey Etheredge of Augusta, Ga., and Dallas, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Lee Etheredge Jr. of Augusta, to Donald Joseph Hodgens of Brooklyn, N.Y., and Dallas, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph H. Hodgens of Brooklyn, has been announced.

Retailers who met last week in New York at a seminar sponsored by the American Management Association indicated that they were fully aware of the changes that had come about in the distribution picture in recent years and of the need to prepare for further changes.

LIMA, Peru--This country with the short name is going a long way toward attracting tourists from the United States during the North American spring and summer. Getting a ballroom in a hotel these days is like finding accommodations during the World War II hospital shortage in England--when one had to reserve a maternity bed 11 months in advance.

MEXICO CITY--The Olympic Games will be held here in 1968, and Mexico is working on projects that will keep tourists coming long after the last fuel bill has been paid on the Olympic Torch. New hotels, new travel facilities and new attractions are modernizing the old, and always alluring, image.

CRESCENT CITY, Calif., March 1--An old stagecoach route meanders through Jedediah Smith State Redwoods Park here in the northwestern corner of California. Nearby, a lordly redwood, 20 feet in diameter and 340 feet tall, rises within a memorial groove. Many others challenge it in thickness and some are taller.
WASHINGTON, March 5-- Five VISTA Volunteers working in Alabama are carrying firearms in self-defense as a result of threats that the volunteers say have come from the white community.

DURBAN, South Africa --"The Persian Gulf," said our friends before we set out on a freighter voyage to this part of the world, "that's the end of the world!" And, after being in the Persian Gulf for one month, jockeying around while our freighter loaded and unloaded cargo and waited for permission to dock, we are inclined to agree.

MANY home gardeners are concerned about the effect of last year's drought on this year's garden. Others, worried that the water shortage might continue, are doubtful whether to plan any garden at all. The problem, however, may not be that acute. By conserving what water is available, a flourishing garden is possible, although it will involve a little additional work.

AT 3 in the morning, the son, hearing noises, comes into the kitchen and finds his father drinking tea. For the stolid, taciturn father and the born, troubled boy who will be leaving Ireland at daylight, it is the last possible moment for shouting away all the hostile years between them for splitting the shroud of silence they have woven, day by silent days ...

COPENHAGEN--The Danes stand ready to greet the more than a million visitors expected here this year. Manhattan's supply of the coveted cooperative apartments in pre-World War II buildings will soon be increased by the conversion of two more pre-war rental structures into co-ops.

WARSAW, Sunday, March 6 (AP)--Premier Jozef Cyrankiewicz warned last night that Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski and other Polish Roman Catholic bishops will be barred from foreign travel "so long as they do not change their disloyal attitude toward the Polish People's Republic."

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., March 5--Miss Cynthia Congdon Lauren, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Bertus Lauren, was married today to Wallace Albert Zellmer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Henry Zellmer of Chicago. The Rev. Charles L. Copenhaver performed the ceremony at the Reformed Church.

LOYAL devotees of the feminine "gothic" romantic must be struck with horror (of quite the wrong kind) at what is going on these days in paperback originals and even in some hardcover examples: dreadfully earnest reproductions of all the weakest cliches of the school, without an ounce of creativity or a scruple of humor in a truck load of books.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 5--East Germany's bid for United Nations membership appeared today to have definitely collapsed.

SAIGON, March 5--The 1966 rural pacification plan which will start sometime this month appears to be the best thought-out, bestled and best-supported plan ever conceived to win the allegiance of south Vietnam's peasants. But this does not necessarily mean it will succeed.
WASHINGTON, March 5-- Representatives of the nation's poor who were chosen to advise Sargent Shriver reported for work today with no shortage of advice.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., March 5 (AP)--Dr. Robert P. Grant, 50 years old, was named by President Johnson today to be director of the National Heart Institute.

Nye, the yachtsman, of Greenwich, Conn. The bridegroom's parents are Mrs. Edward Nye of Amityville, L.I., and the late Mr. Nye.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 5 --If Alabama's political reporters had been invited to a strategy session called by a handful of the state's young Republicans in late 1960, few would have bothered to take out their pencils.

CALIFORNIA horse racing is, at once, Disneyland, the pink Pussy Cat and a Rotary Club picnic. ABYDOS, United Arab Republic--When we asked what the Pharaoh Ramses II was like, our guide replied whimsically, "Oh, I think he has been reincarnated as Cassius Clay. He's an old show-off, but he's got a certain amount of charm."

HOLLYWOOD. THE other day a dep utation of top officials from the Writers Guild of America called a meeting at motion picture critics and journalists in order to file a complaint. Their beef was that the critics and reporters were snubbing screen writers.

Hillside Hospital in Glen Oaks, Queens, is constructing eight two-story garden apartment buildings on its grounds in an effort to overcome a housing problem that has troubled its staff and to serve as an aid in the recruitment of nurses.
MONTREAL, March 5 (UPI) --Jean Beliveau led a 7-2 rout of the Detroit Red Wings tonight with two goals as the Montreal Canadiens regained sole possession of first place in the National Hockey League.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., March 5--The engagement of Miss Ellen Sandra Sternberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Sternberg, to Michael C. Lawrence, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Cohen of Brooklyn, has been announced by the future bride's parents. Mr. Lawrence changed his name.

NEW LONDON, Conn., March 5--The engagement of Miss Linda Joyce Bedrick to James Schreiber, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel S. Schreiber of Spring Hill Farm in Purchase, N.Y., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Morton Bedrick.

DUDAPEST--Travelers contemplating a trip to Hungary, but harboring misgivings about conditions here, should, at the very outset, erase from their minds the kind of doubt aroused by photographs of the Berlin Wall.

WEST POINT, Miss., March 5--Civil rights workers tried but failed today to turn out enough newly registered Negroes to integrate school boards in three predominantly rural Mississippi counties.

ROME, March 5--The late Pope Pius XII, during World War II, exhorted the bishops of Germany to help the "oppressed and persecuted" not only of the Roman Catholic faith but everyone "in the name of basic human dignity," according to letters made public today by the Vatican.
LJUBLJANA, Yugoslavia, March 5 (UPI)--The Soviet Union, the defending champion, crushed the United States, 11-0, tonight and moved into a tie for first place in the world ice hockey championships.
WESTPORT, Conn., March 5 --Miss Victoria Wolffe and Mark Rockwell Lefler plan to marry here on Aug. 13.

BUDAPEST, March 4-- Profit incentives are the talk of Budapest these days because the Communist Government is looking for ways of making the wheels of a slumping socialist economy turn faster. But the profit motive is old hat to most Hungarians.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., March 5 --Dr. and Mrs. Daniel B. Hardenbergh Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ann Elizabeth Hardenbergh, to Peter Pierson Parker Jr., son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Parker of New York.

MOUNT KISCO, N, Y., March 5--The Lila Acheson Wallace Fund announced a $50,000 grant today to the Martha Graham Dance Company for a national tour. Mrs. Wallace and her husband, DeWitt, live here. They are co-chairmen of The Reader's Digest.
DETROIT, March 5--Robert Beverley Evans is a relaxed Detroit millionaire who says he has spent 35 years specializing in the reconstruction of "sick companies."

SCARSDALE, N.Y., March 5--Mr. and Mrs. Leon S. Theil have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carol Jean Theil, to Nicholas Salvatore Vazzana Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Vazzana of New York. A June wedding is planned.

Blanche Honegger Moyse brought her Brattleboro Community Chorus and the Marlboro College Chorus back to Town Hall yesterday afternoon for a program of Bach Cantatas. DEERFIELD, Ill., March 5-- Miss Carole Jane Deutch, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Deutch of Chicago and Sawyer, Mich., was married today to Peter Booth Wiley, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Bradford Wiley of Summit, N.J., and Little Compton, R.I.

ROME--A mild winter, yet one with enough snow to keep all the skiers happy from Cor tina to Mount Etna, was this year's prelude to a tourist season which, Italians hope, will be better than ever.

SYDNEY, Australia-- Every year, Australia's cities, beaches, mountains and vast open spaces become more comfortably accessible to the world traveler. WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP)--An airlift has been ordered by Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara to make sure that all National Guard members are supplied with at least a basic uniform.

HARRIMAN, N.Y., March 5 --Mr. and Mrs. Arthur L. Metze have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Louise Metze, to Neal Blackwell Freeman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm Trowbridge Freeman of Plandome, L.I.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., March 5 --Representatives of Las Vegas gambling casinos have stepped into negotiations in an attempt to settle a sevenmonth-old taxi strike that spokesmen say is now hurting the tourist trade here.

The United States is planning to establish a nationwide. Natural Disaster Warning System that may well cut in half the death toll and reduce substantially the annual economic losses caused by nature's violence.
WEST POINT, N.Y., March 5--Army won the Eastern Intercollegiate Swimming League's title today, scoring its 13th straight victory this season by beating Princeton, 62-33.
"Seventeen fabulous days in the Orient" was the enticing promise offered 75 Thermo King Corporation dealers and their wives. It was their reward for hard work.
Last Wednesday President Johnson sent a comprehensive legislative proposail to the Congress to improve the nation's health.
WASHINGTON, March 5-- Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, in a conscious dissent from Administration tactics, has publicly called for the mining of Haiphong harbor, North Vietnam's major port.

EXPERIMENTS by the Horticultural Society of New York have shown that soilless culture offers a number of advantages for the rooftop gardener. Among these are better plant growth with easier maintenance, plus important savings in weight and water. Soil has always been a ma jor problem for roof gardeners.

An industrial and commercial slum at the north end of Newark's Weequahic Park will be torn down to make way for a $50-million urban renewal project consisting of ... five tall apartment, houses, a shopping center and a park for light industry.

PHILADELPHIA, March 5-- The engagement of Miss Caroline Taylor Fearey to John Calvin Hover 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Curry Hover of Short Hills, N.J., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. John Lawrence Fearey of Chestnut Hill.
BUFFALO, March 5 (AP)-- The New York-Pennsylvania Baseball League will open its 28th season April 23.
MANILA--There are more than 7,000 is lands in the Philippine archipelago, and they stretch across the air and steamship routes from the East and West.

SWAMPSCOTT, Mass., March 5--Miss Judith Ware Bauer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Byrne Bauer, was married this morning to Lieut. (jg.) Michael Joseph Kent, U.S.N.R. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. John S. Kent Jr. of Norwell.

MADRID--The pink and white flowers of the almond trees are beginning to change the color of the landscape of southern Spain and the Mediterranean islands. The brave bulls and "matadores" are preparing for the new season, uncounted festivals and feasts are being planned and new hotels and inns are being opened.

EAST-WEST encounters in the arts are not un common, but nowhere are they so consistently held as in Honolulu, Next Friday the 1966 Festival of the Arts of This Century will bring together at the EastWest Center musicians, artists and film directors from Japan, the United States and Yugoslavia, in what has become an annual two-monthlong event.
WASHINGTON, March 5 (UPI)--The transcript of last month's Vietnam hearings by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee will soon be available to the public in a toneddown version.
East Harlem will choose, probably next month, between two rival agencies in the city's first direct election for a local community committee to develop and run antipoverty programs.

A WING to the introduction of cartridge-loading nits based on the In tamatic principle is evident in the advance notices of the national photographic trade show that opens today in Cleveland. Another marked, although not unexpected, trend is the increase in the number of new movie cameras and projectors of the Super-8 design.
Like two aggressive card players, corporations often raise their bids several times when vying for a big stake in another company. The stockholders stand to gain in such a contest.
WASHINGTON, March 5-- The proprietor of a New York City store specializing in electronics equipment peddles an intriguing little device.

The engagement of Miss Louise Lombard Stillman to Lewis Edward Lehrman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Lehrman of Harrisburg, Pa., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mrs. Lester Carson Spier and Charles Latimer Stillman of New York.

Jersey City and her sister communities of Hudson County have been skidding downhill in population, industry, jobs and housing for years. There may be hope on the horizon above the Jersey Meadows, but Federal economists are not sure when the county's potential will be turned to profit.

LONDON, March 5--Prime Minister Wilson, in Liverpool to be officially adopted as Labor candidate for the March 31 election, was asked today to save the Cavern Club, first home of the Beatles' "Mersey sound."

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., March 5--Mr. and Mrs. Edward Beattie Reynolds have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Cornelia Reynolds, to James Meyer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard H. Meyer of Tenafly, N.J.
Army, led by Donald Romash and Peter Feher, defeated Brooklyn Polytechnical Institute, 18-9, and Pace College, 15-12, in collegiate fencing matches yesterday at the Fencers Club.

DAVID SARNOFF, salty doyen of electronic prophecy, has been the heart -- and the muscle--of the Radio Corporation of America for over 45 years. At the age of 75, which he just reached, the erstwhile pugnacious immigrant youngster is still riding herd on the mammoth electronics complex that he fashioned out of a lifetime of triumphs, trials and visions.

ALGIERS--Tourism in Algeria is still very much a rich man's fancy or an adventurer's dream. Already a victim of wartime inflation, Algeria has seen prices rise steadily since her independence from France in 1962.
The Infants Home of Brooklyn is hoping to raise $30,000 from its annual three-day bazaar on March 20, 21 and 22. The event will be held in the auditorium of the home at 1358 56th Steet in Brooklyn.

Mrs. Fountain Fox-Martin of Lakeville, Conn., and New York and Milton Fox-Martin of 19 West Ninth Street have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lynn FoxMartin, to Thomas Francis Joyce 3d. He is a son of Mrs. Joyce Jr. of 75 East End Avenue and the late Mr. Joyce.
EAST HARTFORD, Conn., March 5--Not all the engines sold by Pratt Whitney Aircraft here power commercial and military jet planes.
LONDON, March 5--Edward Heath opened the Conservative party's election campaign today with a speech calling for legislation to outlaw wildcat strikes and union featherbedding.

MANCHESTER, Mass., March 5--Mr. and Mrs. Harvey H. Bundy have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Harriet Southerland Bundy, to William Townsend Burgin. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Rodgers Burgin of Milton.

ANGEL has just released its new recording to Puccini's Turandot (3 disks, 3671 mono and stereo) and it is a repeat solo triumph for Birgit Nilsson who sings the title role. She is the only singer around with the voice and icy-fiery passion of a Turandot. Her live performances of it are already Legendary, and her 1960 recording for RCA Victor still stands untouched.

WASHINGTON, March 5-- Batman, in the person of E. William Henry, the Federal Communications Commissioner, solved the Vietnam problem last night at the Shoreham Hotel, just in time for Clark Clifford, Presidential adviser, to watch his daughter Mrs. Richard Barrett, enjoin her husband from burning his draft card.

Dr. Esther M. Jackson, one of the most articulate voices among Negro theater artists, accused civil rights leaders yesterday of evading a campaign to desegregate the arts because of fear of offending their white liberal supporters.
ANN ARBOR, Mich. March 5 (UPI)--The Michigan Wolverines trounced Northwestern, 105-92, today to gain their second straight outright Big Ten Conference basketball championship.
BUKAVU, the Congo, March 5--Two years after it was ignited, the rebellion in the eastern Congo shows no signs of dying out.

RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, March 5--President Mohammad Ayub Khan of Pakistan put into words this week a new, presumably of ficial, pecking order for Washington, Moscow and Peking in their relations with the world's most populous Moslem nation.
LISBON--Portugal, a land of romantic rivers and forests, ancient palaces and churches, elegant hotels and restaurants, and unspoiled beaches and villages, wants to be known as honeymoon land, too.

DETROIT, March 5 (AP)-- Lawrence Irving Woolson, who as president of the De Soto, division of the Chrysler Corporation was credited with introducing fins to that automobile, died of a heart attack yesterday. His age was 61, and he lived in Birmingham.
Dr. Harry N. Rivlin, dean of teacher education at City University, will become dean of the School of Education at Fordham University next fall.

THERE has been no time in recent literary history when so much attention has been paid to the serious novel. Yet never before has the serious novel seemed so remote from the experience most of us recognize as real, so irrelevant to the issues that engage us most intensely, so unchallenging to the imagination, so barren of emotion and ideas, so just plain boring to get through.

WHEN moisture seeps into a basement after a heavy rain or sudden winter thaw, it is usually because excess water has accumulated in the soil around the outside of the house foundation. This water creates an underground pressure that forces the moisture in through tiny cracks, porous sections and other defects in the basement walls and floor.

Birgit Nilsson will sing Venus and Elisabeth in Wagner's "Tannhauser" when the opera has its first performance of the season at the Metropolitan Opera, on Saturday evening, March 19. It will be the first time at the Met that a soprano has taken both roles.
CENTRAL ISLIP, L.I., March 5--For some of the women living in a small, new unit of the state mental hospital here, Friday is "the hour of decision."

MOSCOW, March 8--Anna Akhmatova, the poet, died today, after a lifetime of controversy. According to Tass, the Soviet press agency, her age was 76.

EAST WILLISTON, L.I., March 5--The engagement of Miss Jane Davidson Corbett to David George Floyd, son of Mr. and Mrs. George F. Floyd of Girard, Ohio, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. James Davidson Corbett.

WARSAW--Poland is marking her millenium of nationhood this year, and, to help her celebrate, she is looking forward to having more tourists than ever before. Foreign visitors passed the million mark for the first time in 1965, and tourism officials say that early bookings for this year indicate that 1965's figure will be surpassed by about one-third.

LONDON. AN American visitor to Great Britain's folkmusic community can only experience a sense of exhilaration at the liveliness, diversity and number of activities here. The extent of the British folk-music revival may seem minuscule in comparison with the American boom because of the country's, smaller population and area. But there are other factors which make the British revival seem even deeper than the American.

NAIROBI, Kenya--Like a hippo lurching out of water after a few motionless hours, tourism in Kenya, is just beginning to show its real dimensions. Everyone knew it was there all the time, just below the surface, its snout and ears occasionally betraying its presence. But no one knew just how big the beast was really going to be.
BRUSSELS--The wouldbe traveler poring over maps and wondering whether to cross right through Belgium, stop one night in this capital city or skip the country altogether, is making a big mistake.

Wall street analysts sprinkled their talk last week with words such as "caution" and "uncertainty," in the wake of a sharp market drop followed by a rally, but many of them still think stock prices will end higher this year than in 1965.
SAIGON, March 5--United States marines and South Vietnamese paratroops fought a ferocious battle with 2,000 North Vietnamese regulars yesterday and today in the coastal province of Quangngai.

UNICEF, the United Nations Children's Fund, will benefit from the 16th annual exhibition of the United Nations Art Club in the General Assembly Lobby at United Nations headquarters, First Avenue at 46th Street, from March 16 through April 20

ALGIERS--Government officials here have disclosed that joint efforts are now being made among Morocco, Algeria and Tunisia to entice tourists across the Mediterranean and to simplify travel throughout North Africa. Among the proposals are projects calling for joint Customs operations at the borders and for a tourism bureau to represent all three countries abroad.
STONEWALL, Tex., March 5 (AP)--Twenty of President Johnson's Texas neighbors have asked him to use his influence to save their land, the Rev. Theodore Sager said today.

PINKHAM NOTCH, N.H., March 5--Mike Raymaley of the Lake Placid, N.Y., Ski Club, who finished below the top 10 in the slalom event yesterday, won the controlled downhill race in the Eastern Alpine ski championships today at Wildcat Mountain.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., March 5--Mr. and Mrs. James Kenneth Lindsay of Briarcliff Manor and Mullett Lake, Mich., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Lindsay, to Peter Stephen Tobias, son of Mrs. Julian Morris Tobias of Chicago and the late Dr. Tobias.

WASHINGTON, Mar. 5--Senator Jacob K. Javits called today for the virtual elimination of restrictions on Federal aid formulas that he said were "outof-date, arbitrary and grossly unfair to large urban states."

SOUTH WINDSOR, Conn., March 5--In the first Congregational Church of South Windsor this afternoon, Miss Abigail Samantha Lasbury, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph C. Lasbury Jr. of East Windsor Hill and Camden, Me., became the bride of John Coburn Jr. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Coburn of Needham and Cedar Point, Mass.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., March 5 --With Ron Widby hitting from the outside and Red Robbins on the inside, Tennessee beat topranked Kentucky, 69-62, today in the biggest upset of the college basketball season.

CONSTANTINE, Algeria, March 5--Col. Houari Boumediene received a warm but relatively quiet welcome to this poverty-stricken Algerian city today. It was the last stop on his first meet-the-people tour since last June, when he ousted President Ahmed Ben Bella.
CHICAGO, March 5 (AP)-- The president of the American Medical Association urged today that concerted action be taken by all branches of medicine to deal with incompetent physicians.
The President's Commission on Law Enforcement will poll households throughout the country this spring to find out how much crime is never reported to the police.

ROME, March 5 (AP)--Luigi Longo, Italian Communist party leader, returned today from three days in Poland, accusing Cardinal Wyszynski of dampening planned celebrations marking 1,000 years of Polish Christianity.

ACCRA, Ghana, March 5-- Ghana resumed diplomatic relations with Britain today. They had been broken off by Kwame Nkrumah, who was deposed as President last week by a military coup, over Britain's refusal to use arms to overthrow Ian D. Smith's rebel government in Rhodesia.

PARIS--France is looking forward to the new spring-summer season with the cheerful confidence she had in the days when visitors recognized her as the undisputed First Lady of tourism on the Continent. The morale of everyone in the tourism industry has been perked up by the progress made in eliminating, or at least in doing something about, the problems that have inspired criticism in recent years.

MILWAUKEE, March 5-- After months of controversy, Milwaukee's stalled antipoverty program was reactivated this week with a plan to give the poor a bigger voice in the progress along with the release of $280,000 in Federal funds.

SARASOTA, Fla. March 5-- J. Townsend Walker, who retired 10 years ago as a vice president of the Sitroux Company, paper products manufacturers of New York, died in Sarasota Memorial Hospital today after a short illness. He was 80 years old.

UNION, N.J., March 5--Mr. and Mrs. Paul R. Maloney have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marion Maloney, to John Joseph Dimpel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph T. Dimpel of Great Kills, S.I.

EDISON, N.J., March 5-- Teachers at the Kilmer Job Corps Center here have organized a union and plan to demand a contract that will give them a voice in educational policy so they can improve the conditions of both faculty and corpsmen.

OMAHA, Neb., March 5 (UPI)--The President has nominated two brigadier generals in the Strategic Air Command for promotion to the rank of major general, SAC announced today.

"NATURE'S Wonderland of Beauty" is the title of an illustrated lecture on wild flowers to be given by Dr. and Mrs. Matthew Ratchford at the South Salem Presbyterian Church in South Salem, N.Y., on Tuesday at 8 P.M. The lecture will be sponsored by the Basket Town Garden Club of Pound Ridge. There is no admission charge.
The chairman of the Harlem chapter of the Congress of Racial Equality was released without bail yesterday upon arraignment in Criminal Court on a narcotic charge.
THE tenth annual educational forum for horsemen at the Belmont Plaza Hotel on Tuesday is expected to attract an audience of about 300. A decade ago, no one could be sure a single person would appear.

LAHTI, Finland, March 5 (UPI)--Kalevi Laurila, Finland's new skiing sensation, won the Salpausselkae 15-kilometer cross-country race today by outdistancing an international field of world and Olympic champions.

PITTSBURGH, March 5-- Mrs. Mary Bruggeman Phillips of Pittsburgh and Benjamin Dwight Phillips Jr. of Butler, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Phillips, to John Anton Mayer Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Mayer of Pittsburgh.

ISTANBUL, Turkey--In Turkish tourism, 1966 can best be described as the "Year of the Foregone Conclusion." Every year since 1960, and particularly last year, the number of visitors to this Mediterranean-AegeanBlack Sea nation has been going up. The foregone conclusion is that there will be another rise in 1966.
DATIL, N.M.--Whizzing across southwestern New Mexico on transcontinental U.S. 60, few travelers realize that, for some 20 miles, they are on the bottom of an inland sea.
ROME, March 5--A bill to legalize birth control is scheduled to come before the Italian Parliament next week, official sources disclosed today.

Committee members for the Million Dollar Ball will hold their first meeting on Tuesday aboard buses that will transport them to the Waldemar Medical Research Foundation in Woodbury, L.I. The foundation is the beneficiary of the ball which will be given at the New York Hilton on May 6.

GUATEMALA CITY-- Central America wants tourists and looks enviously at the million or so vacationists who pour into Mexico, just to the north, every year. From Guatemala to Panama, the six tiny countries that form the isthmus between North and South America feel that they can make it worthwhile for visitors to venture a little beyond Mexico. Besides, Central America needs the money.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, March 5 (AP)--Gary Player, the South African who is the United States Open golf champion, defeated Jack Nicklaus of Columbus, Ohio, by six strokes today and won the Challenge of day and won the Challenge of the Champions six-match competition by 14 strokes.

WALTHAM, Mass., March 5 --Trinity successfully defended its New England fencing trophy at, Brandeis University today, outdueling eight other colleges in the 14th annual New England intercollegiate fencing championships.

KUALA LUMPUR, Mar. 5-- After another week of bewildering developments in Indonesia the belief is growing that President Sukarno is running into more oppo sition that he had expected when he summarily fired General Abdul Haris Nasution as Minister of Defense and chief of staff.

THE flower show has come to town. Once again the New York Coliseum is bedecked with daffodils, dogwoods and azaleas. This year's theme "Planting Keeps America Beautiful" takes its inspiration from the natural beautification program initiated by the President and Mrs. Johnson. The exhibitors are making a special effort to show home gardeners as well as communities how to plant wisely for effective garden displays.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Mar. 5-- --Construction is expected to start in April on the $4.7million Suffolk County Jail, a maximum-security institution near the County Center here.

Detgen of Perrysburg, Ohio.

Princeton's varsity fencing team gained a first place tie in the Ivy League yesterday by upsetting Columbia, 15-12, at University Gymnasium. The defeat ended Columbia's threeyear winning streak at 33 dual meets and in addition snapped the Lions string of 29 consecutive Ivy League victories.

TOKYO--Faced with vigorous new competi tion from other Asian countries in the race for the tourist dollar, Japan is responding with characteristic inventiveness and energy. LEXINGTON, Ky., March 5-- Burley tobacco in the eight-state marketing belt brought $405,570,525 in the season just ended, official figures show. A record average price of $66.81 a hundred pounds was reported by the Federal-state market news service.

TINA LESER is back. But the designer, who achieved success in the Golden Age of American sportswear, the nineteen-forties, along with Claire McCardell, Clare Potter, Tom Brigance and others who glorified casual clothes, has switched her style. A luxury ship passenger terminal on the Hudson River dotted with promenades, cafes and parking facilities is under study by the Port of New York Authority.
A number of price changes, chiefly in the chemical area, were announced by various producers yesterday.

PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla., March 8 (UPI) Gay Brewer took second place on the Professional Golfers Association winnings list today with $12,977 after earning $10,000 for his victory in the Pensacola open.
GENEVA, March 8 The Soviet Union dismissed today as having "nothing in common with disarmament" the proposal by the United States that the two powers destroy "thousands" of their nuclear weapons.

BOSTON, March 8 (UPI) A third mechanical union authorized its leaders tonight to go on strike against the Boston newspapers, which have been shut since Sunday night by a walkout of printers and mailers.

The New York Knickerbockers, who had lost six of their last 10 games, lost a 24-point lead and then had to go through a five-minute overtime session before defeating the Los Angeles Lakers, 133-132, at Madison Square Garden last night.

HONOLULU Hawaii is the youngest state, the most distant state and the only island state. It also has two special qualities with reference to the Southeast Asian war.

Dr. Benjamin G. Rosenkranz, former secretary of the New York State Optometric Association, died on Monday in Miami Beach, Fla., at the age of 78. He was a former resident of New York.

Losers outnumbered gainers by a better than three-to-two ratio in the stock market yesterday, but leading market averages closed a bit higher in active dealings.

American Metal Climax Inc., announced here yesterday the appointment of two divisional presidents, succeeding executives who were named to senior corporate posts on March 3.
LOUISVILLE, March 8 Two New York players emerged as Men's Team champions when the event ended here this afternoon at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals.

That, in any case, is what Stanley Drucker and Myor Rosen did last night. Both were playing guests of the National Orchestral association, which gave a concert at Carnegie Hall under the direction of John Barnett.

WASHINGTON, March 8 (UPI) Silverless dimes and half-dollars with only 40 per cent silver will go into circulation this week, the Treasury announced today.

The Federal Communications Commission announced yesterday that its new rules controlling virtually all forms of community antenna television would become effective April 18 for most of the country's 1,650 CATV systems.
ROME, March 8 Premier Aldo Moro's third center-left coalition government won a vote of confidence from the Senate tonight. The vote was l73 to 123. The majority needed was 149.

WASHINGTON, March 8 New York's Congressional delegation spent more than two hours this afternoon wrestling with the uncertain future of the Brooklyn Navy Yard. When they were done, it was still uncertain.
One of the most successful films of all time, Cecil B. DeMille's "The 10 Commandments," will open an exclusive engagement on May 25 at the Victoria Theater, Broadway and 46th Street.

The Quincy shipyard of the General Dynamics Corporation in Massachusetts has grown in a little over two years from a unit with no production at all to a fast-growing plant with eight shipbuilding contracts and 6,500 employes.

CANBERRA, Australia, March 8 (Reuters) Australia will borrow almost $56-million from nine American banks to buy new jet aircraft for Qantas and Trans-Australia Airlines, it was disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, March 8 General de Gaulle has put an interesting proposal to President Johnson. He wants France to maintain her old love affair with the United States, but he wants a divorce from the marriage vows of the North Atlantic treaty. He wants to retain the security of the alliance without meeting his part of the allied contract.
Malcolm X was publicly assassinated as "an object lesson" to his followers, Assistant District Attorney Vincent J. Dermody declared yesterday.

The state has started tests at Lincoln Center's two-story underground garage as a result of complaints that auto exhaust at peak hours has made some motorists sick.

WASHINGTON, March 8 A House committee, in a surprise move, approved legislation today to require that daylight saying time start and end on the same dates throughout the country. This would not affect states that choose year-round standard time.

Some of the most prominent original practitioners of the "new" economics pursued by the Johnson Administration have publicly joined ranks with more orthodox economists in demanding tax increases to curb inflation.
SAIGON, March 8 Four United States planes were shot down yesterday as Air Force and Navy pilots carried out the heaviest aerial bombardment of the war.

Oliver J. Gingold, editor of The Wall Street Journal's "Abreast of the Market" column since 1933 and a staff member since 1900, died yesterday of pneumonia in his home at 1060 Park Avenue. He was 80 years old.

YESTERDAY morning more than a thousand Brook lyn schoolchildren crowded into Brooklyn's Academy of Music to learn something about ballet and modern dance. It was one of the new experimental dance demonstrations, "Dancers at Work," arranged for children by the Harkness House for Ballet Arts.

He was 85 years old. He also maintained residences at 1040 Fifth Avenue and in Bar Harbor, Me.

Hills, retired scientific management consultant to more than 200 business and industrial concerns, trade associations, public utilities and governmental agencies, died Saturday in East Orange General Hospital.
