SANTURCE, P,R., March 9 Puerto Rico is urging continued Federal tariff protection to limit competition from foreign countries on its shipments to the mainland.

ARCADIA, Calif., March 9 (AP) Johnny Longden announced for the third or was it the 13th time that he was retiring from horse racing, but the 59-year-old jockey declared today that this time he meant it.

PARIS, March 9 The opening of the 35th Salon des Arts Menagers an annual exhibition of household arts showed how France is racing to catch up with foreign competition in domestic appliances and why a Frenchman should always be around to sell them.
WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) President Johnson, with help from Jimmy Durante and a 4year-old Hawaiian boy, opened the 1966 Easter seal campaign today.

WASHINGTON, March 9 The White House said today that when public opinions polls show a drop in support for President's Johnson's policy in Vietnam it is because people do not think he is pressing the war hard enough.

The charge of "political interference" in the Police Department is a greatly exaggerated issue. The present and former Democratic officeholders who originated and are continuing this controversy are damaging the department's good name and their own reputation for good judgment.
The Bank of America led a group yesterday, which bought $20-million of AA-rated bonds with 14 years of call protection from the East Bay Municipal Utility District, Calif.
Jack Schlosser, a certified public accountant, of 43 Shore Park Road, Great Neck, L,I., died Monday night of a heart attack at the North Shore Hospital in Manhasset, L. I. He was 48 years old.

The A.C. Nielsen Company, which is investigating what it believes was an attempt to distort its television program ratings, said yesterday the effort had been made in the "EastCentral area" of the country.
City Council President Frank D. O'Connor upbraided Buildings Commissioner Charles G. Moerdler yesterday for criticizing the Council.
ELIZABETH, N.J., March 9 (UPI) A gang of bearded robbers held up a drive-in branch of the Union County Trust Company here today and escaped with an estimated total of $68,000.

CHICAGO, March 9 John B. Bender, owner of a dilapidated South Side building taken over by the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and three civil rights groups in their slum war, today was allowed four more weeks by Judge Frank B. Machala to correct 23 violations of the city building code.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 9 (AP) Representative William B. Widnall told savings and loan officials today they were in danger of being frozen out of the moderate-income home market by what he called "Government sub-market-rate home morgage financing."

Some municipal-bond dealers almost cheered yesterday. Their market showed some semblance of life, and for this they gave their thanks to the $95.71-million issue of attractively priced Public Housing Authorities bonds that was unveiled.

NEW ORLEANS, March 9 (AP) The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit has ordered the State of Mississippi to grant a charter to the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. It also directed a Federal Court in Jackson to block quick arrests aimed at breaking up rights demonstrations.
HOLLYWOOD, March 9 A new type of motion picture venture was inaugurated in Hollywood this week with a notable absence of fanfare.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 9 Thousands of gallons of gasoline have been sent secretly to Rhodesia by South African railways through Lourenco Marques, the capital of Mozambique, The Rand Daily Mail reported today.

CAIRO, March 9 (UPI) Clark Graebner of Beechwood, Ohio, moved into the semifinals of the United Arab Republic lawn tennis championship today with a 6-3, 6-3, 7-5 victory over Bernard Montrenaud of France.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (UPI) The House Commerce Committee approved today President Johnson's world health bill. It was the first measure to clear committee in Mr. Johnson's attack on sickness, ignorance and hunger in the underdeveloped nations.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) Five priests were promoted from monsignor to bishop today and two bishops were transferred to fill vacancies in the Roman Catholic dioceses of Paterson, N.J., and Scranton, Pa.
Dr. James Allen Colston, the Negro president of Knoxville College in Tennessee, has been named president of the Bronx Community College.
NEW DELHI, March 9 The leaders of the ruling Congress party yielded tonight to a Sikh demand for a separate Punjabispeaking state.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 9 A recommendation to close a legal loophole that could permit war criminals to escape punishment was presented to the Commission on Human Rights today.
WASHINGTON, March 9 (UPI) The State Department said today that about 20,000 acres of South Vietnamese crops had been destroyed with herbicides to deny food to the guerrillas.
CHICAGO, March 9 Montgomery Ward Co. announced its acquisition today of 98 per cent of the outstanding stock of the Pioneer Trust and Savings Bank.

WASHINGTON, March 9 The automatic political liberals to whom Vice President Humphrey for years was both kith and kin are grumbling and grieving, in public and in private, over what they consider his growing apostasy.

SAN DIEGO, March 9 (AP) Vice Adm, Donald Bradford Beary, retired in 1950 after 44 years of service in the Navy, died Monday at Balboa Naval Hospital here at the age of 78. He was admitted to the hospital the weeks ago for treatment of a heart ailment.
John J. Wingerter, corporate business manager of Time, Inc., died yesterday of a massive blood clot at St. Luke's Hospital. He was 60 years old and lived at 100 West 57th Street and Spring Lake, N.J.

LOUISVILLE, March 9 At the end of the play this afternoon in the second of three qualifying rounds for the Vanderbilt Cup. The lead was held by Anthony Dionist of New York, Harlow Lewis and Peter Pender, both of Philadelphia, and Jeremy Flint of London, They totaled 271 points compared with an average of 180. All scores above average are expected to qualify and all the favored teams are in good position.

Expansion and modernization projects requiring outlays of several hundred million of dollars were announced yesterday by companies, manufacturing a variety of products from aircraft to television-picture-tube bulbs to gaseous oxygen.
The Reeves Instrument division of the Dynamics Corporation of America, announced yesterday a new generation analog device.

LJUBLJANA, Yugoslavia, March 9 (UPI) Finland scored three goals in the second period and went on to hand the United States a 4-1 defeat today in a battle of also-rans at the world ice hockey championships.

The Appellate Division granted permission yesterday to opponents of the Port of New York Authority's proposed World Trade Center to carry their case to the Court of Appeals, the state's highest tribunal.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex,, March 9 (AP) Judge John Onion sentenced two Camp Gary Job Corps trainees to prison today for the July 17, 1965, shooting of two Lackland Air Force Base airmen.
POODLES are the No. 1 choice of dog fanciers in the United States. Almost one of every three pure-breds registered with the American Kennel Club last year was a member of that chic breed.

The General Cable Corporation, a producer of wire, rod and cable, announced here yesterday the election of A. Leon Fergenson as president and chief executive officer. He succeeds James R. MacDonald, who died last week.
Just about everybody knew "Mama" at the crowded clangorous East Bronx intersection where Simpson Street, East 165th Street, Westchester Avenue and Fox Street all run together.

Charles E. Dunlap, former president of the Berwind-White Coal Mining Company of Philadelphia and for years a leading member of New York, Philadelphia and Newport, R. I., society, died Tuesday at St. Luke's Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived at 102 East 73d Street.
ALBANY, March 9 The Legislature, which had reapportionment taken out of its hands by the Court of Appeals, may get a chance to enact a redistricting plan after all.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 9--Secretary General Thant expressed deep concern today over "the escalation of fighting" in Vietnam.
The American Brake Shoe Company announced plans yesterday for a two-for-one stock split, an increased quarterly dividend and a name change to the Abex Corporation.

DETROIT, March 9 The General Motors Corporation said tonight that it had undertaken an investigation of Ralph Nader, a Washington lawyer whose sharp criticism sparked much of the current controversy over automobile safety.
PARIS, March 9 France's stubborn stand against reform of the world's money system was attacked from several directions during the meeting of the Group of Ten countries which ended today.

John F. Newman, a vice president of the Bank of New York, and known in banking circles as a specialist in mutual fund administration, died Tuesday at St. Barnabas Hospital, the Bronx. He was 60 years old and lived in Mineola,. L. I.
ROCKINGHAM, N.C., March 9 (AP) Paul Goldsmith set a track record of 116.648 miles an hour today and won the pole position for Sunday's 500-mile Peach Blossom stock car race.

WASHINGTON, March 9 A "broad, deep and thorough" investigation of the circumstances surrounding the abrupt resignation of Abba P. Schwartz, a high State Department offi cial, was called for today by Representative Henry S. Reuss of Wisconsin.

INDIANAPOLIS, March 10 (UPI) The Los Angeles Lakers, behind the shooting of Jerry West and Elgin Baylor, beat the Cincinnati Royals tonight, 119-116, and gained their fourth National Basketball Association Western Division title in the last five years.
WASHINGTON March 9 The Office of Economic Opportunity has ordered new morality standards and much stronger loyalty requirements for its antipoverty workers in community action programs.

OXFORD, England, March 9 The third time was lucky for London's Festival Ballet, with its new "Swan Lake," produced by Jack Carter and given its first British performance here last night. Twice in the past two years the company staged different versions of this most famous of all ballets, and both were flops.
PARIS, March, 9 The French Government declared today it saw no possibility of effective reform of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization through negotiation.
The price trend was up yesterday on the American Stock Exchange as most issues rebounded in quiet trading following two days of sharp declines.

SINCE the death of Henri Soule, the master res taurateur who owned Le Pavillon and La Cote Basque, there have been hundreds of inquiries at both establishments to ask if they are open. As a result Victor Jacobs, the restaurateur's lawyer and trustee of the establishments, has placed advertisements in newspapers to reassure the public that both restaurants are open.
The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation had a happy message for its 106,000 shareholders yesterday.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Thursday, March 10 (Reuters) Jakarta high school students stormed Communist China's Consulate General building and ransacked it early this morning.
The New York and the American Stock exchanges reported yesterday the changes carried below in the share holdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of listed companies.
Three more newsprint producers in Canada announced plans yesterday to increase prices by $10 a ton, to $144, effective April 1.

THE strongest player in Eastern Europe outside the Soviet Union is probably Grand Master Wolfgang Uhlmann of East Germany. His style is eclectic, versatile and deceptive. Plainly, he is a tough man to beat.
ANKARA, Turkey, March 9 A number of prominent leftists have been arrested and others have been interrogated by the police in the last two days.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, March 9 Beatrix of Orange is no fairy-tale princess and her wedding tomorrow to Claus von Amsberg will be no fairy-tale wedding, although it may look like one.

The Thermo King Corporation, which was struck by tragedy last weekend, is nonetheless hoping to continue its push to new sales records. King's senior executives and nearly 40 of its dealers and members of their families were killed in an airplane crash on Mount Fuji in Japan.
CHAPEL HILL, N.C., March 9 (UPI) A leading American Communist was barred from speaking at the University of North Carolina today, but spoke to about 2,000 students off the campus.
President Johnson made the only possible response to President de Gaulle's bid for bilateral discussions on matters that clearly affect the security of all members of the Atlantic alliance.
WASHINGTON, March 9 According to a survey made available at the Pentagon today, proportionately more Negro servicemen than whites have died in the war in Vietnam.

MONTREAL, March 9 )UPI)--The last-place Boston Bruins, set the front-running Montreal of Bernie Parent, a rookie, upset the front-ranking Montreal Canadiens, 3-1, tonight and prevented the Canadiens from increasing their National Hockey League margin.

PARODY, according to the dictionary nearest at hand, is a work in which another work is closely imitated for ridicule. That is Meaning One. Meaning Two is "a feeble or ridiculous imitation." "Hooray!! It's a Glorious Day... and All That," which opened last night at the Off-Broadway Theater Four, is a parody of musical comedies. It aims at Meaning One and land plunk in Meaning Two.
LONDON, March 9--The British Overseas Airways Corporation has canceled an order for 10 super-VC-10's, it was announced today.

The General Electric Company was accused yesterday in a $3-million antirust damage suit of attempting to monopolize the colelge-graduate market in the use of a computer program to set up a pool of students for service in industry and government.
Theodore W. Kheel believes New York is on the threshold of a tremendous growth era as a result of fundamental changes in waterfront employment that goes into effect next month.
SCARSDALE, N.Y., March 9 Miss Katherine W. Mindlin and Robert George Russo plan to marry in August.
WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) Representative John F. Baldwin of California died tonight of cancer in Bethesda (Md.) Naval Hospital. The Republican legislator, whose home was in Martinez, was 50 years old.
The stock market closed sharply higher yesterday after a four-week-long downtrend. Trading was relatively light in the recovery movement.

Lewis Hoad of Australia and Alex Olmedo of Peru, both winners of the Wimbledon championship, will meet in the opening match of the $25,000 professional tennis tournament at Madison Square Garden on Tuesday, March 22.

ORANGE, N.J., March 9 An argument over the sale of a used car brought death today to five persons, including a newborn child, in a series of bloody incidents that ended when a police marksman killed a knifewielding slayer here.

PARIS, March 9 Brigitte Bardot's promotional jun ket to the United States last December received 50 minutes of coverage on French television last night in a documentary prepared by Francois Reichenbach, the film director. It was a pretentious excursion in cinema verite, a disorganized and repetitious item of reportage that afforded little illumination of either Miss Bardot or the land that she visited to ballyhoo her latest film, "Viva Maria."

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 9 Casey Stengel's sudden ascension to the demigod status conferred on baseball figures by election to its Hall of Fame aroused unqualified approval in this vicinity today.

The leaseholds of three East Side apartment houses have been sold by Ira Berne, real estate investor, to the Plaza Management Company, one of a number of managing and investing companies owned by the realty partnership of Sol Goldman and Alex DiLorenzo Jr. The sale price was not disclosed.

The Canada Dry Corporation has been making more then 100 soft-drink flavors and markets them throughout the world. Now, it turns out, the company is making still another even softer drink that is going out of this world. It's water.
SYDNEY, Australia, March 9 Australia announced today a relaxation of laws governing the entry of nonwhites.
The Royal Dutch-Shell Group of Companies, in its report for 1965 yesterday, showed net income of $628.4-million, a rise of 6.8 per cent from the $588,310,000 cleared the year before.

Cesare Maniago accentuated the negative at Madison Square Garden last night. The lanky goalie for the New York Rangers held the Chicago Black Hawks, the powerhouse of the National Hockey League, scoreless while Earl Ingarfield poked home a third-period tally that gave the Rangers a 1-0 victory.

A champagne supper dance will be held at the Rainbow Room on March 28, after a theater party to a preview of the musical comedy "It's a Bird, It's a Plane...It's Superman" at the Alvin Theater. Sammy Davis and Vincent Sardi Jr. are co-chairmen for the evening, whose proceeds will go to the Lincoln Square Academy.
Attended swearing of Andrew Brimmer as a member of the Federal Reserve Board; sent crime message to Congress.
The Seminary Fund of the Loyola School will be the beneficiary of a luncheon, bridge party and fashion show, to be held on March 24 in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.
MIAMI, March 9 (AP) "I think the old boy has done enough," Carl Hanford, Kelso's trainer, said today.
WAYZATA, Minn., March 9 Mr. and Mrs. James Henry Binger have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Judith Binger, to Dr. Dennis George Oates, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Oates of Chisholm.

A syndicate headed by the First National City Bank and the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company was awarded $85.6million of the $95.7-million in the tax-exempt bonds the Public Housing Administration offered yesterday.
LONDON, March 9--A new home for the National Theater, Britain's famed repertory company, has been formally approved by the Government and the Greater London Council.

Allen Z. Lonstein, a 26-yearold Army reservist, was sentenced yesterday in Federal Court to one year in prison for refusing to report for induction as a draftee. This was the first prosecution of its kind in the country.
The spot rate on the British pound continued to decline on foreign-exchange markets here yesterday despite some support efforts by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
LIMA, Peru, March 9 (UPI) The Civil Aeronautics Agency is investigating the circumstances that led three air crewmen from Miami to abandon a propeller-driven Superconstellation Sunday off the coast.
HONG KONG, March 9 Communist China's leaders are indicating a belief that the danger of war with the United States has diminished.

NASSAU, The Bahamas, March March 9 Vamp X, a remarkably consistent Cal 40 sloop sailed by 27-year-old Ted Turner of the Atlanta Yacht Club and a harbitten young crew, was in almost an unassailable position today for the Southern Ocean Racing Conference champnonship.
CHESAPEAKE CITY, Md., March 9 (UPI) Kelso, the biggest money-winner in thoroughbred horse racing, was retired today because of an injury.

SAIGON, Thursday, March 10--An isolated United States Special Forces camp on the South Vietnamese-Laotian border continued to hold out this morning in the face of a 30-hour siege by an overwhelming Vietcong force.

SINCE the original sale of Manhattan, the island has been a place that teems with phenomena. But gastronomically there has been no phenomenon in recent years to equal the proliferation of Japanese restaurants, East Side, West Side and up and down the town.
The J. Henry Schroder Banking Corporation and the Schroder Trust Company announced yesterday the election of Bertram H. Witham as a director.
ARMAGH, Northern Ireland, March 9 The Irish border country is quiet but tense. The people expect new troubles, and the police are preparing as if they expected to fight in Vietnam.
Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary last night canceled an order permitting two civilian members of an Upper West Side community council to accompany policemen in a patrol car.

A State Supreme Court jury began hearing testimony yesterday to decide whether William F. Buckley Jr. had tried to "destroy" Dr. Linus C. Pauling by calling him a collaborator with Communists or whether the Nobel Prize scientist wanted to "ruin" the conservative spokesman by suing him for libel.
WASHINGTON, March 9 President Johnson has quietly authorized a major relaxation in travel regulations to permit scholars to visit Communist China and other places barred to ordinary tourists.
Raymond Fogelman, a textile manufacturer here, died Monday of a heart attack at the Honolulu Airport in,Hawaii. He lived at 1050 Fifth Avenue. He was 71 years old.

Mrs. Alice Ray Buell Morris, widow of the Rev. Dr. DuBois S. Morris, a Presbyterian minister and missionary in China, died yesterday in Roosevelt Hospital. She had been ill since breaking a hip in December. She was 87 years old, and lived at 785 Park Avenue. She also had a home on Lyons Place Road, Weston, Conn.

IRON MOUNTAIN, Mich., March 8 The old fashioned snow train almost the same as thousands of the East's skiing pioneers knew it about three decades ago isn't dead yet. It's been revived by a Chicago ski tour operator.

WASHINGTON, March 9 Harry M. Weese, a Chicago architect, has been selected by the National Capital Transportation Agency to design the stations and "conceptual plans" for Washington's $431-million subway system, the agency said today.

ELIZABETH, N.J., March 9 The Elizabeth Young Men'sYoung Women's Hebrew Association will open its seventh annual contemporary American art exhibition and sale on March 26 at its new building in Union. Gov. Richard J. Hughes and his wife are honorary patrons for the four-day show.

The Appalachian Power Company, a subsidiary of the American Electric Power Company, Inc., sold yesterday $30million of 30-year debentures to a group led by the Drexel Harriman Ripley Securities Corporation.
Hilton Edwards, director of Brian Friel's hit comedy "Philadelphia, Here I Come!", will leave for Dublin today to arrange for presentation there of Mr. Friel's next play, "The Loves of Cass McGuire."
Children cannot cope with emergency alone, so Red Cross volunteers often must help them with kindness and sustenance.

William Worthington, a former actor who served for 30 years as play reader for the Katharine Cornell-Guthrie McClintic theatrical producing office, died yesterday at Midtown Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived at 5 Tudor City Place.
The General Reinsurance Corporation announced here yesterday the election as a director of Charles W. Buek, president of the United States under a $165-a-share tender.
ALGIERS, March 9 East Germany is seeking recognition from Algeria in return for a promise of economic, technical and scientific aid and long-term credits for industrial equipment.

The J.I. Case Company, the tractor and farm machinery maker, announced yesterday in Racine, Wis., the appointment of Charles A. Anderson was president. Mr. Anderson was formerly president of the Walker Manufacturing Company, a producer of car exhaust systems.
DENVER, Colo., March 9 (AP) The Frontier Refining Company of Denver filed suit in United States District Court today against five large oil companies, seeking $15-million damages.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 9 Three thousand five hundred workers in three Anaconda Company copper mining properties Salvador, Potrerillos and Barquito staged a sympathy strike today in support of 7,000 strikers in Kennecott Copper Corporation's Teniente mine.
Nassoit-Sulzberger Co. has announced the appointment of Joseph Mandel as a vice president.
This is the time of year when some families and individuals are planning for one of the biggest single investments in their lives a vacation trip abroad.
WASHINGTON, March 9 An air traffic control satellite that foreshadows a revolution in worldwide airline communications could be in orbit next year, the Federal Aviation Agency has been told.

The Pilot Club of New York will hold its annual card and game party the evening of March 18 in the Bowman Room of the Biltmore. The club is a member of Pilot International a service organization of professional and executive business women.
The Board of Higher Education and the chancellor of the City University patched up their differences yesterday.

BONN, March 9 Chancellor Ludwig Erhard has received a note from President Johnson explaining the United States position on French plans to reform the North Atlentic Treaty Organization, a West German spokesman announced today.

WASHINGTON, March, 9 The United States is spending more than $40-million to reactivate 101 ships from the nation's reserve fleet for the Veitnam emergency sealift but is not getting its money's worth William B. Rand, president of the United States Lines, declared today.

SANTA DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, March 9 Large treasure lies beneath the stream of Dominican politics the vast land and industrial complex that was assembled by Generalissimo Rafael Leonidas Trujillo Molina before his assassination on May 30, 1961.
ALBANY, March 9 Governor Rockefeller sent to the Legislature today his long awaited bill to enable the state to get its share of Federal funds under the new Medicare program.

TOKYO, March 9 The Japan Joint Securities Company, a syndicate of brokers and dealers, sold back 10.6-billion Yen (about $29.4-million) in shares to the stock market today. The release of the shares produced no adverse impact of trading.
A Supreme Court jury began deliberating at 2:30 P.M. yesterday on the fate of the three men accused of having killed Malcolm X, the black nationalist leader.

"Demoralized and mixed-up markets such as we are now encountering in commodities and stocks alike tend as the old-timers say, 'to separate the men from the boys.' In turbulent times like these, the wisdom of trading with trends, diversifying, and utilizing stop orders to limit risks is especially apparent."

EVANSVILLE, Ind., March 9--Akron University defeated Long Island University, 74-68, and gained the semi-final round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association college division basketball tournament today.
LOS ANGELES, March 9--Mayor Samuel W. Yorty announced today that he would oppose Gov. Edmund G. Brown for the Democratic governorship nomination in the primary June 7.

ST, PETERSBURG, Fla., March 9 The Rev. Dr. J. Vincent Nordgren, a Lutheran minister who served for 14 years as pastor and executive director of New York's Seamen's Center, now Seamen's and International House, died here yesterday. He was 70 years old and had served as pastor of the Redeemer Lutheran Church here for 11 months.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 9--The staff of The Harvard Crimson began publishing a special Boston edition today to replace the strike-closed Boston dailies. It treasures the reaction it received from one woman

RIVERHEAD, L.I., March 9 The Perkins Inn, a 73-room hotel on eastern Long Island was sold at auction in Riverhead yesterday for $350,000. The four-story hotel was acquired by the South Shore Federal Savings and Loan Association of Massapequa, holder of the hotel's mortgage.

Genesco, Inc., the owner of Bonwit Teller and Henri Bendel, will make another attempt to acquire control of Julius Garfinkel Co., Washington, D.C., and its subsidiaries, Brooks Brothers and the A. DePinna Company, both of New York.

An official of the International Longshoremen's Association yesterday criticized the Waterfront Commission for refusing to issue a work permit to a dockworker who has a record of four convictions, including disorderly conduct, illegal possession of a gun, and petty and grand larceny.
"This looks like a fine tournament field. Most of the teams seem to be evenly matched. There isn't any one that seems to be a standout."
OLIVER LA FARGE liked good prose and good manners. The combination always got him a hearing. It enabled him to hold audiences that might otherwise jump away like scalded cats.

WASHINGTON, March 9 Representative Theodore R. Kupferman's campaign organization received $10,000 from a national Republican Committee to aid his successful election bid last month in Manhattan's 17th District.

Members of the 11 Democratic Reform clubs in the 19th Congressional District will vote tonight on four candidates who are seeking to oppose Representative Leonard Farbstein in the June 21 party primary.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 9 Like the Roman emperors the New York Mets kept their public docile today on bread and the Circus Maximus.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) The United States Chamber of Commerce said today that reform of the Electoral College system of electing Presidents was imperative but President Johnson's proposal "would be worse than having no reform at all."
Claude Monet's collection of impressionist paintings, willed by his son to the Academie des Beaux Arts in Paris, was the talk of the art world yesterday.
Pearl Bailey came into Philharmonic Hall last night pushing a vaudeville show ahead of her.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (UPI) A power regulator in the downtown office of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company failed today and cut off power in central Washington and scores of Government offices for 10 to 15 minutes.

Mr. and Mrs, Leonard Outh waite of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss. Ann Lucille Outhwaite, to Benjamin Schuyler Clark Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Clark of New York, Pound Ridge N.Y., and Bar Harbor Me.
ATLANTIC CITY, March 9 (AP) Ernie Terrell said tonight he would not fight Cassius Clay for the world heavyweight title in Toronto March 29 under the terms of the new contract he had just received.
On a cold night last December, a 33-year-old garbage collector stepped nervously to the firing line at the Chester Bowling Center in England.

WASHINGTON, March 9 The Senate approved the Administration's tax increase bill today after voting, contrary to Administration wishes, to keep the tax on local telephone service to private homes at 3 per cent.
PHOENIX Ariz., March 9 (UPI) Arizona health authorities declared a statewide influenza outbreak to be of epidemic proportions today after the number of reported cases had almost tripled in a week.

LOS ANGELES, March 9 Chief of Police William H. Parker, who became a center of controversy in the Watts Negroriots last August, is on an indefinite sick leave because of heart trouble, the police department said tonight.
ARCADIA, Calif., March 9 (AP) Native Diver, carrying 130 pounds, won the $27,000 San Bernardino Handicap today, equaling the track record at Santa Anita.

AT a luncheon today at the Pierre Hotel, sponsored by the local chapters of the National Home Fashions League and the American Institute of Interior Designers, Mrs. Francis H. Lenygon, a fellow of the latter organisation, will speak on _ "Gracie Mansion Its History." Mrs. John V. Lindsay is to be there as guest of honor to hear Mrs. Lenygon and to watch her show colored slides of the Mayor's 167-year-old official residence.

The New York District Council of the International Longshoremen's Association voted last night to send 2,000 to 3,000 members to Albany next Tuesday to protest expansion of the powers of the Waterfront Commission and to support legislation favored by the union.

HOLLYWOOD, March 9 Oliver Unger, an American film producer, said today that the Soviet Government has allocated $7-million as its financial contribution to the projected Russian-British film co-production, "The Royal Performance," which will be filmed in Moscow in July.

Gina Bachauer made her American debut 15 years ago in Town Hall. It was a dramatic event, for the Greek pianist came unheralded and impressed her listeners as one of the foremost artists of her day. Last night as an anniversary gesture, she repeated her formidable debut program in Carnegie Hall. And she was magnificent.

Net operating earnings of the Chemical Bank New York Trust are running about 6 per cent above those of the period a year ago, William S. Renchard, chairman, told the bank's annual stockholder meeting yesterday.

Outmoded facilities rather than imports are the cause for shutdowns of United States steel-product plants, a key group of steel importers, who account for more than 75 per cent of European shipments, asserted here yesterday.

MOSCOW, March 9 (UPI) The Soviet Union will soon launch a "space bus" carrying two or more astronants farther into space than man has ever ventured, possibly as far as 550 miles from earth, informed sources said today.
Dolly Madison Industries, Inc., has announced the election of John A. Carter and Arnold J. Adelberg as directors. Both men are divisional presidents.
Mitchell I. Ginsberg, the new Commissioner of Welfare, announced yesterday his plans for the first overhaul of the city's welfare administration since the Depression.

A Federal jury last night convicted a woman lawyer, her law clerk and a man now in prison of having conspired to bribe and intimidate a Government witness to prevent him from testifying in a narcotics conspiracy case.
Gasoline supplies in the United States rose by 400,000 barrels in the week ended last Friday, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday.
DuBois Club members filed complaints of police brutality yesterday with the City Commission on Human Rights under a seldom-involved provision that prohibits discrimination against any group.

GREAT NECK, L.I., March 9 Mr and Mrs. Max J. Halpern of Lake Success have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sandra Halpern, to Murray S. Weinstein, son of Mrs. Aaron Weinstein of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Weinstein.

MAINBOCHER'S clothes don't change very much from year to year, but neither do Rolls-Royces. And that this is probably a good thing is attested to by the phalanx of loyal patrons who beat a path to the 75year-old Chicago-born couturier's Fifth Avenue salon.

WASHINGTON, March 9 Commissioner James L. Goddard of the Food and Drug Administration acknowledged today that his agency had failed properly to enforce existing drug laws with regard to testing of the proclaimed 'miracle drug" DMSO.
Ten of 16 artists yesterday withdrew their works from an exhibition at the First World Festival of Negro Arts, scheduled to open in Dakar, Senegal, next month.

ELIZABETH, N.J., March 9 (AP) With a hunting knife for a clue, the police searched today for a heavy-set, middleaged man who fatally stabbed a 7-year-old girl at one of the busiest intersections of this industrial city.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (UPI) The license of a radio station owned by two producers involved in the television quiz show scandals of the late nineteen-fifties was renewed for one year today on the condition that the station be sold within 60 days.

The burglar alarm is only a minor instrument of the New York Symphony, but yesterday it was allowed to start the performance by going off precisely at 6:53 A.M. in the building across the street. It was a delightful change of musical mood.

The Contemporary Chamber Ensemble in Residence at Rutgers, to give it the full title, wound up its five-concert series last night at Hunter College Playhouse. All modern music should be lucky enough to get such sensitive, authoritative and well drilled performances as these four works did.
BUJUMBURA, Burundi, March 8 Premier Leopold Biha, who was critically wounded during an attempted coup last October, is struggling to save Burundi from another disastrous bloodletting.

The Railway Express Agency obtained a restraining order in Federal Court yesterday prohibiting 12 men, whom the company called leaders of a wildcat drivers' strike, from continuing the walkout or interfering with employes.
PARIS, March 9 It was a literary party for a new book, but it was different from most of the parties of that type here.
Saint Subber has two good reasons these days for feeling pleased. "The Odd Couple" and "Barefoot in the Park" are about to celebrate memorable dates.
YONKERS, March 9 Stanley Dancer's winning streak, spanning three nights, two tracks and seven races, ended tonight at Yonkers Raceway.

PLAINVIEW, L,I, March 9 The Plainview-Old Bethpage School Board ordered the closing today of three of the distriot's 12 schools for the rest of the week because of a strike called by the Federation of Teachers yesterday.
The Public Health Service and Weather Bureau warned yesterday that a large section of the Northeast Coast was likely to get an unusual amount of air pollution today and tomorrow.

REMSENBURG, L.I., March 9 Supreme Court Justice Henry M. Zaleski died this morning of a heart attack at his home on Cedar Lane here. He was 57 years old and had served in the 10th Judicial District since his election in 1960.
HERTFORD, N. C., March 9 (AP) Policemen used tear gas tonight to break up a melee between Negroes and 50 North Carolina law officers after demonstrators refused to disband a civil-rights march.
Dean John U. Monro of Harvard College has clarified the college's position on the Government's use of students' class standings to help determine draft deferments.
Market technicians are closely watching the pattern of oddlot short sales for clues to future movements in stock prices.
The city decided yesterday not to remind New Yorkers that the reservoirs had more water now than they did a year ago.
The election of Dr. Joseph P. McMurray, 54 years old, as a trustee was announced here yesterday by the Bowery Savings Bank.
ACCRA, Ghana, March 10 A decree forbidding Kwame Nkrumah and his wife and other members of the ousted regime from withdrawing funds or other assets from local banks was published today.
A California astronomer has found what he believes to be evidence that the "quasars," widely thought to be the most distant objects in the observable universe, actually are not extremely far away.
The water supply in the city's reservoirs increased yesterday by 3.1-billion gallons to 269.9 or 56.6 per cent of capacity at 8 A.M.

YONKERS, March 10 Great Credit, Adora's Dream and Vicki's Jet led eight qualifiers into next week's $25,000 Adios Spring Festival pacing series final by winning divisions of an all-star triple-header tonight at Yonkers Raceway.

A move was made yesterday, without success, to delay the retrial of George Whitmore Jr. on charges of having attempted the rape of Mrs. Elba Borrero, a nurse, in Brooklyn two years ago. Trial will begin Monday in State Supreme Court before Justice Aaron F. Goldstein.
There are wheels within wheels in the situation that produced the break between Mayor Lindsay and Council President Frank D. O'Connor over police appointments in the new city administration.

IN the snug back parlors of Amsterdam, where the ma trons sit at their round, carpetcovered tables and gossip over many cups of coffee, they say Claus Georg. Wilhelm Otto Friedrich Gerd von Amsberg, despite his long and noblesounding name, is not exactly ...

Mayor Lindsay disclosed yesterday that he planned to merge the water supply and sewage disposal agencies of the city into a new department, which he intends to call the Environmental Protection Administration.
Signed the Cape Lookout (N.C.) National Seashore Bill.
The nation's electric power production rose 8.0 per cent in the week ended March 5 from the level in the corresponding 1965 week, the Edison Electric Institute reported this week.
The Student Council at Columbia University has urged Columbia to suspend its efforts to build a gymnasium in Morningside Park and to hold "immediate" discussions with com munity groups.

Last night's New York Philharmonic concert sparkled on many levels. Van Cliburn gave a rhapsodic performance of the MacDowell D minor Piano Concerto. Thomas Schippers led the orchestra in a bright reading of Haydn's Symphony No. 92 in G ("Oxford") and a rowdy one of Gian Carlo Menotti's "Apocalypse."

WASHINGTON, March 10 Senator Jacob K. Javits urged today that the United States and the Soviet Union seek a moratorium on arms shipments to the Middle East before the "shaky" peace there deterio'rated into an East-West confrontation.
Do you know that $260-million worth of tranquilizers were produced last year!
DETROIT, March 10 A Congressional subcommittee today invited the General Motors Corporation to explain its investigation of a leading critic of industry safety practices.

Honeywell, Inc., a manufacturer of data-processing equipment and control devices, announced yesterday the appointment of Van W. Bearinger as vice president and general manager of its systems and research division.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 10 Yale University, despite the absence of Olympian Don Schollander, still had enough reserve strength left to take a slim lead over Army after the opening program tonight of the Eastern Seaboard Intercollegiate swimming championships.
HOUSTON, March 10 Prince Philip of Britain said today that tight security arranged for his protection during an unofficial visit of the United States had made him feel as if he were "under arrest."
ALBANY, March 10, (AP) Assembly Speaker Anthony J. Travia cleared the way today for enactment of a $1.50 state minimum wage by declaring he was willing to compromise with Governor Rockefeller.
President James M. Hester of New York University announced the establishment of the first department of urban anthropology in the world yesterday.

The 27th annual White Elephant Party for the benefit of the Child Adoption Service of the Children's Aid Society was held at the Waldorf-Astoria last night. The decor in the Grand Ballroom was in red, white and blue, dominated by huge white elephants, from Pepsi Cola and Lord Taylor. Tiny white elephants decorated the wine and water goblets, which were sou venirs for the guests.

OTTAWA, March 10 Canada is preparing guidelines for United States subsidiaries operating in this country that would, in effect, call on the companies to ignore President Johnson's rules. When issued shortly, the Canadian rules will make clear that American plant owners are expected to be "good Canadians" in setting policies affecting purchases and profits.
SAIGON, March 10 A United States Coast Guard cutter slammed into a Vietcong junk late last night and sank it in the Saigon River after a brief gun battle, a military spokesman said today.

WASHINGTON, March 10 A leading authority on Chinese history suggested today that high Administration officials were "too excited" over "Peking's vast blueprints" for exporting the Chinese Communist revolution.
The New York Chapter of the Arthritis Foundation plans to take its supporters on a tour of town houses and apartments April 12 and 19 from noon to 5 P.M.
Price problems continued yesterday to ruffle the newsprint, metals and chemicals industries.

CHICAGO, March 10 A libel suit seeking $8-million in damages was filed in Federal Court today against Brink's, Inc., the national protection agency. It was filed by the American District Telegraph Company, a nationwide electronic alarm service, with headquarters in New York.

NUMATA, Japan, Friday, March 11 (AP) Fire swept through two ski resort hotels in Minakami today. The police reported 31 persons were killed. Of those who died, 28 were women and three men. The police said 12 other persons were injured in the predawn blaze. All the dead and injured were Japanese.
The cost of business credit rose across the country yesterday as major banks increased their minimum rate on short-term business loans to 5 per cent from 5 per cent.
CAIRO, March 10 Fragmentary reports from Yemen indicate "hundreds of casualties" in new clashes between Egyptian and republican forces fighting anti-government tribes.

District Attorney Aaron E. Koota of Kings County has issued "a large number" of subpoenas to underworld figures to head off what he believes is an imminent gangland bloodbath for control of gambling and other interests in Brooklyn.

The engagement of Miss Miriam Ruth Messinger to Stephen Rich Koller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold J. Koller of Maplewood, N.J., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Emanuel Messinger of Forest Hills, Queens.
DETROIT, March 10 The cloud of 1.6 hangs over the National Collegiate indoor track and field championships, which open a two-day stand tomorrow at Cobo Arena.
WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) The resignation of Philleo Nash, Commissioner of the Bureau of Indian Affairs, was announced today.

NEWARK, March 10 Mrs. Geraldine Williams sat dazed and anxious in the cluttered slum residence of her murdered son and daughter-in-law today, surrounded by nine orphaned grandchildren and sympathetic relatives and neighbors.

LJUBLJANA, Yugoslavia (UPI)--The battle for the 1966 world ice hockey championship was thrown wide open today when the Soviet Union and Sweden played to a 3-3 tie and Czechoslovakia topped Canada, 2-1.
After his duties at the West 100th Street Precinct Station are over, Patrolman John Michael Donohue normally goes straight home to Brooklyn to do 25 push-ups and relax with his wife and children.
Four steamship conferences serving South American trades yesterday announced removal of freight surcharges on shipments to Brazilian ports and imposition of special charges on shipments to Argentina.

The New York Stock Exchange's threat to leave the city was given some technical support yesterday by the introduction of a data-processing and communications link between Wall Street and New Jersey. ITT Data Services, a division of the Inter national Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, opened a data-processing center at 67 Broad Street for the use of the Wall Street financial and business community.

A total of 39,000 square feet of space on the eighth floor of the Starrett Lehigh Building at 601 West 26th Street, between 11th and 12th Avenues, has been leased by Genesco, Inc., manufacturers and retailers of apparel and footwear.

WASHINGTON, March 10 The White House, stung by reaction to a proposed State Department reorganization that forced Abba P. Schwartz out of his job, declared today that President Johnson would continue to support a "liberal" foreign travel policy.

"The time has arrived when manure heaps, slaughter houses, fat and bone boiling establishments, glue manufacturies, outdoor or unsewered privies, and all kindred occupations and nuisances cannot be much longer tolerated within the built-up portions of New York or Brooklyn, however well-cared for they may be."

WASHINGTON, March 10 The outcry against President de Gaulle has started in the United States Senate with a warning by Senator Jackson of Washington that if France tries to wreck the integrated Atlantic alliance, the United States may have to reconsider its commitment to the defense of France.
THIS particular silver salmon has come to be called Indomitable out on the Pacific Coast, the scene of the most carefully documented epic journey ever made by a migratory fish.

IN "Happily Never After," which opened last night at the Eugene O'Neill, J.A. Ross has written a highly economical comedy one setting, five characters, very few laughs and almost no drama. The first act and a half are principally taken up with telling us about matters that happened off stage. The second half of the play consists of a few concocted quarrels and mechanical patching up with some more relating of off-stage action.

Events today: New York Philharmonic, Philharmonic Hall, 2:15 P.M.; Kohon String Quartet, Town Hall, 5:30; Cincinnati Symphony, Philharmonic Hall, 8:30; Chicago Symphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Vienna Choir Boys, Town Hall, 8:30; Concert in Pantomine, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30; Guarneri String Quartet, with Peter Serkin, pianist, Rogers Auditorium, Metropolitan Museum of Art, 8:30; concert of chamber music, Juilliard Concert Hall 8:30; "La Traviata," Ruffino Opera Theater, Cooper Union, 8:30.

BRADENTON, Fla., March 10 (AP) Approximately 1,000 persons turned out today for a dedication at nearby Santa Maria Island of a monument to the late Fred Hutchinson, a former major league pitcher and manager.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 114.0 on Wednesday from 114.2 on Tuesday.
MADRID, March 10 Almost 500 Spanish university students were under a police siege tonight at a Capuchin monastery in Barcelona in a dispute with the regime over academic freedoms.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, March 10 (AP) The teenage sons of the Rhodesian Prime Minister, Ian Smith, and the British Governor in Rhodesia, Sir Humphrey Gibbs, who were "kidnapped" by students last night, were released tonight.
WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) What makes the television networks drop certain programs? Bad ratings? Advertising pressure? High costs?

HAVANA, March 10 (AP) Two former army majors who were convicted of having plotted to shoot Premier Fidel Castro were sentenced to 25 years in prison today by a military court. Mr. Castro had urged that their lives be spared.
PHONE BOOTH, 152 East 55th Street. The Turtles, singing-instrumental group.

MOSCOW, March 10 (AP) The Soviet Government submitted its long awaited findings in the Newcomb Mott case to the United States Embassy here today. It repeated the contention that the young American traveler committed suicide while in Soviet custody.

WASHINGTON, March 10 The Johnson Administration and organized labor have agreed to seek a two-step increase in the minimum wage to $1.60 an hour over 23 months and to broaden the law's coverage to more than six million workers not now covered.
March 10 The New York Yankees, who have declared that they consider exhibitiongame results important this year, won their first today, 7-4, from the Washington Senators.

WASHINGTON, March 10 Testimony before a House subCommittee today indicated that both a major drug company and the Food and Drug Administration were remiss in their handling of an experimental birth control pill, MK-665.
WASHINGTON, March 10 In swift order, the Senate approved Administration requests today for economic aid for South Vietnam and additional funds to fight the war there.

WHEN Maurice and Alice Cahn went to Japan a dozen years ago, it was to sell coal. They returned with something quite different perfume. Their fragrance line, Shibui (the word is best translated as quiet elegance), is now in Bloomingdale's, Lord Taylor and Takashimaya, the Japanese department store on Fifth Avenue and 46th Street.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 10--Question No. 1: How many jobs are there on a big league baseball team? Answer: 25.

CINCINNATI, March 10 (UPI) The Boston Celtics clinched at least a second-place tie in the National Basketball Association's Eastern Division and moved within a half game of first place Philadelphia tonight with a 124-120 victory over the Cincinnati Royals.

WASHINGTON, March 10--The President's budget leaves no margin for setbacks or failures in the attempt to put men on the moon by 1970, the head of the space agency said today. In telling Congress that budget cuts are taking flexibil ity out of the Apollo lunar program, James E. Webb repeated a warning that has been sounded by space officials with increasing volume over the last three years.
The London stock market closed quietly firm in all sections yesterday, with small gains reflecting broad but modest buying.

GUATEMALA, March 10--Col. Enrique Peralta Azurdia, chief of Guatemala's military Government, was reported today to have promised to turn over power next July to whoever won last Sunday's presidential election.

William Burton, a retired engineer and long a leader of conservation and hiking groups, died Wednesday in Long Island College Hospital, Brooklyn, after suffering a heart attack on the street near his home at 196 Columbia Heights. He was 85 years old.

PAPEETE, Tahiti There is a widespread illusion that United States involvement in Vietnam is similar to France's previous involvement there again a colonial war fought by white man against Asian and therefore doomed. The illusion is catchy because of certain superficial similarities, and it is carefully fostered by our adversaries.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, March 10--Indonesian high school and university students were out in the streets of Jakarta again today, and for the second time they attacked Chinese Communist diplomatic establishments.
Mari Sandoz, one of the country's leading regional historians, who wrote extensively of the Nebraska plains, died of cancer yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital. She was 65 years old.

GENEVA, March 10 Sweden proposed today that a "verification-by-challenge" system be sought for policing a prohibition on underground nuclear explosions with the aim of breaking the East-West deadlock on inspection.

ARNOLD SCAASI usually opens his fashion collections with a bang by leading off with an evening dress, but yesterday the fireworks were bolder than usual. The trio of knee-baring shifts that stepped first into his custom dress salon at 26 East 56th Street to introduce his spring and summer collection were completely paved in neon yellow, red or green sequins.
IT usually begins harmlessly. An outboard runabout, keeping well within the posted speed limit, heads out from a Nassau County anchorage.

KEENE, N.H., March 10 Mr. and Mrs. Saul Mariaschin have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Cynthia Faith Mariaschin, to Richard Segal Melenson, son of Dr. and Mrs. David M. Melenson of Phil adelphia.

PARIS, March 10 The Foreign Ministry gave the Canadian Embassy today a memorandum detailing the actions France intends to take with respect to the integrated military commands of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and in particular with respect to the two Canadian air bases on French soil.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 10 (AP) Samuel S. Bowles, son of Chester Bowles, Ambassador to India, said today he would fight Harvard University's order that he sign a state teachers' loyalty oath or be dismissed from the faculty.

TOLEDO, Ohio, March 10 (AP) The Toledo Boxing Commission today nullified the decision for Rubin (Hurricane) Carter in a bout with Wilbert (Skeeter) McClure on Tuesday after a check of the score cards yesterday. The check disclosed an error in addition on the referee's card.

MILWAUKEE, March 10 (UPI) The state and the defense clashed today on whether Bill Veeck, a former major league owner and one of baseball's most outspoken critics, would be a witness in the Braves' antitrust trial.

RALEIGH, N.C., March 10 Syracuse and Duke will get their first, but they hope not their last, taste of action in the 28th annual National Collegiate basketball championship tomorrow night when the Eastern regional semifinals will be held in North Carolina State's Reynolds Coliseum. A crowd of 12,400 is expected to attend.

WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) Representative Adam Clayton Powell, Democrat of Manhattan, said today he would fight to block an Administration decision to require a loyalty oath for workers in antipoverty projects.
SAIGON, Friday, March 11 Ten of the generals who rule South Vietnam voted yesterday to purge the 11th, Lieut. Gen. Nguyen Chanh Thi.

Federated Department Stores, Inc., whose chain of department stores includes Abraham and Straus and Bloomingdale's units here, announced yesterday in Cincinnati the election of Herbert Austin Tripp Jr. as a corporate vice president.
The Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation had record gross and net income last year, according to the company's report issued yesterday by Darryl F. Zanuck, president.

AUBURN, N.Y., March 10 Governor Rockefeller declined today to endorse specifics of Mayor Lindsay's tax package for New York City and joined the legislative leaders in urging the Democratic-controlled City Council to act first on the Mayor's proposals.

OTTAWA, March 10 A Liberal minister's charge that the former Conservative Governthe former Conservative Government had covered up a security case involving officials and an East Germen woman threw the Canadian House of Commons into an uproar today.
WASHINGTON, March 10 Will the real Communist China please stand up?

SETTING the theme of the rooms in the House of Years at W J Sloane are dark, outsized antiques. The backgrounds are light and gay. The effect, says Blair Catterton, who was responsible for the semiannual refurbishing, is the chunky look.

St. Joseph's Hospital in Far Rockaway, Queens, will benefit from the Spring Ball on April 2 at the Seawane Club in Hewlett Harbor, L.I. Sponsoring the event, expected to become an annual benefit, is the hospital's advisory board. Arthur Schwartz, a board member, is ball chairman.
Charles Axelrod, a real estate investor and builder, died yesterday at Beth Israel Hospital following a short illness. He was 72 years old and lived at 907 Fifth Avenue.

Before a City Hall audience of more than 100, City Council President Frank D. O'Connor subjected. Buildings Commissioner Charles G. Moerdler yesterday to sharp reprimands and a barrage of angry questions.
Miss Edith Wetmore, one of the last dowagers of the Newport social set, died yesterday at her New York winter home, 1 Beekman Place. She was 95 years old.
The increase in the prime rate by a dozen leading banks caused a decline in bond prices yesterday.

A Brooklyn minister alarmed by several recent violent crimes on the streets of the Bushwick section has formed a citizens' safety patrol that will cruise the area in private cars equipped with two-way radios.

WASHINGTON, March 10 President Johnson declared today that "unless we begin now to restore the environment in and around our cities, we will be condemning a large part of our population to an ugly, drab and mechanical fate."

Power Memorial, three-time defending champion, and unbeaten Rice, advanced to Sunday's final of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association basketball playoffs last night before 5,000 fans at St. John's University. The two teams met in last year's final.
Boat-show activity in the metropolitan area continues this weekend with the opening of the annual Greater Long Island event.

Serious crimes in this country rose last year by 5 per cent and by 13 per cent the year before. Many neighborhoods in large cities exist in a condition of continuing fear and uneasiness; statistics also suggest that in many suburban towns the rate of crime is increasing as they grow in population. President Johnson's latest message on crime arrives in a context of genuine, widespread public concern.

WASHINGTON, March 10 Intercity truck tonnage and estimated freight traffic volume generated by carloadings on U.S. railroads in the week ending March 5 were both ahead of the volume in the corresponding week of 1965.
An increase in the prime interest rate by the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company touched off a selling wave on the American Stock Exchange late yesterday.
TRENTON, March 10 Gov. Richard J. Hughes has agreed to abandon the retroactive provisions of his proposed state income tax, assuring legislative passage of the tax this month.
IN "Jacobowsky and the Colonel," the 1944 play by Franz Werfel and S.N. Behrman set in World War II, Jacobowsky says to the colonel: "You have one of the finest minds of the 17th century."

The Waterfront Commission heard testimony from six subpoenaed witnesses yesterday on the operation of a longshoremen's medical center by a doctor once suspended for "deceit in the practice of medicine."

PARIS, March 10 If Amer ican broadcasting wants to make a case against the evils of governmental control of radio and television, it should stop picking on the Federal Communications Commission and have a look at the Office de Radiodiffusion-Television Francaise. By comparison with the O.R.T.F., the executives of United States TV now seem like a group of raging leftists.

WASHINGTON, March 10 The Securities and Exchange Commission, by a 4-1 vote, gave the First National City Bank of New York permission today to create the first bank-sponsored mutual fund in the United States.
EAST MEADOW, L.I., March 10 Miss Barbara Baruch and Stephen Joel Coleman plan to marry in September.
MANILA, March 10 (AP) The Philippines Government today reversed its 20-year-old policy of forbidding citizens to travel to Communist countries.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., March 10 Theodore Brigham Conklin, president of the T.E. Conklin Brass Copper ComPany, Inc., 113-115 Leonard Street, New York, died here yesterday. He was 75 years old and lived at Meadowcroft in Quogue.
Mr. and Mrs. John S. Ho of Hong Kong have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Linda Ho, to Dr. KeatJin Lee of Penang, Malaysia, son of Mr. and Mrs. Cheng Tin Lee.

WASHINGTON, March 10--United States officials affirmed today that the defense of Europe could be "worked out" if President de Gaulle carried out his threat to force the withdrawal of American and other non-French troops and bases from France.

LONDON, March 10 Gen. Sir Lewis Halliday, who won the Victoria Cross, Britain's highest award for valor, in 1900 during the Boxer Uprising in China, died today in a hospital in Dorking, Surrey. He was 95 years old.
E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., said yesterday that it would spend about a half billion dollars this year for expansion. The announcement headed a continuing list of industrial expansion plans.

On old maps it was customary to mark certain portions terra incognita unknown territory. China, big as she is and with some 700 million people, give or take 50 million, is an unknown land to Americans. Senator Fulbright and the Senate Foreign Relations Committee are once again performing a valuable public service, this time in trying to throw some light on what is to the United States a dark and mysterious land.
LONDON, March 10 Parliament was dissolved today for a new general election campaign in which the handling of economic affairs is becoming the leading issue.
Patients in a coma and near death from liver failure have apparently been saved by massive transfusions that replaced almost all of their blood, according to two medical reports.
The American people are being swept up in a wave of "false patriotism" in support of United States policy in Vietnam, Senator Wayne Morse said here last night.
David Nurmi of the Bronx is a healthy teen-ager like any other, except that he has completed Red.
The Federation Bank and Trust Company announced here yesterday the election as a director of Sol Kittay, chairman and president of the B.V.D. Company, the apparel manufacturer.

BONN, March 10 Diplomatic relations between West Germany and Israel, recently established, have reached a turning point with the interruption of negotiations on a new treaty providing economic assistance to Israel.

When the last measures of Wagner's "Parsifal" died away at the Metropolitan Opera last night, it seemed a pity that New York had been made to wait five years to hear it again. Whatever the flaws of the work's libretto or of the current production, the score is so inspired that it is a community's loss not to hear it regularly.

MIAMI, March 10 Kermit Zarley rushed to avoid being late at the start of the $100,000 Doral open golf tournament to day, then equaled the course record of 65.

The assumption of boredom and easy dismissal I do not think the assumption is, or was, mine alone says reams about the art of fiction.
WASHINGTON, March 10 A new proposal to ban virtually all man-made encroachments in the Hudson River Valley for the next three years was placed before Congress today.
Ten plaintiffs, ranging from a piano teacher to a pajama company, have joined in a damage suit against the Transport Workers Union, its leaders and the Amalgamated Transit Union.
WASHINGTON, March 10 The White House and the major economic agencies of the Government declined all comment today on the increase in the prime lending rate.
BALTIMORE, March 10 (UPI)--Old Daddy, a consist ent gelding owned by Mrs. Bernie Bond, scored a 2 -length victory at Pimlico today in the $6,500 Colonial Village Purse.

The controversy set off by recently retired high police officials who accused Mayor Lindsay's administration of exerting political influence on the Police Department exploded yesterday into new fragments.
COLUMBIA, S.C., March 10

A New York lawyer has accused Mayor Thomas J. Whelan of Jersey City and John V. Kenny, Hudson County Democratic leader, of demanding a $10,000 bribe as the price for obtaining approval to build two gasoline stations in Jersey City.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, March 10 Crown Princess Beatrix was married today to Claus von Amsberg, but the traditional glitter of a royal wedding was marred by smoke bombs hurled by youths protesting the wedding.
WASHINGTON, March 10 Executives of Ling-TemcoVought, Inc., of Dallas, a major ...
All three men charged with the killing of Malcolm X, the black nationalist leader, were found guilty of first-degree murder early today.
The appointment of Rear Adm. William A. Brockett, as president of Webb Institute of Naval Architecture was announced here yesterday by the board of trustees of the Glen Cove, N.Y., institution.

The Rev. Daniel Berrigan, the Jesuit poet, priest and critic of American policies in Vietnam, returned here this week from South America and announced that he planned to renew his peace activities "as soon as possible."

Gilbert W. Fitzhugh, president of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, was elected yesterday to the board of the Singer Company, a producer of sewing machines and other consumer and industrial products.

Reform Democrats in Manhattan's 19th Congressional District picked Councilman Theodore S. Weiss over three opponents last night to face Representative Leonard Farbstein in the June 21 Democratic primary.

WASHINGTON, March 10 Paul Mellon, reticent and softspoken philanthropist and art patron, explained today in four words the philosophy that has made him one of the world's most distinguished art collectors: "It appeals to me."

TORONTO, March 10 The total loss to stockholders and creditors arising from the collapse of the Atlantic Acceptance Corporation last summer will range from $50-million to $64-million, a Government investigating commission was told.
HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., March 10 Irving Newman, a teletype setter consultant for The New York Times, died at his home here yesterday. He was 74 years old and lived at 22 South Drive.

ALBANY, March 10 Assembly Speaker Anthony J. Travia ruled today that Mayor Lindsay's legislation for unifying transportation in New York City could not be taken up until the City Council requested it.
NAIROBI, Kenya, March 10 --Four diplomats and two journalists from the Communist bloc were deported from Kenya on short notice tonight. No reason was given.

WASHINGTON, March 10 Senate and House conferees agreed today on the final text of a tax bill that would raise nearly $6-billion in the next 15 months to help finance the Vietnam war and restrain inflation ary pressures.

BESSEMER, Ala., March 10 (UPI) William O. Eaton, one of three Ku Klux Klansmen accused of the nightrider slaying of Mrs. Viola Gregg Liuzzo died of an apparent heart attack today. The Klan charged Federal authorities with responsibility for his death.

The New York Stock Exchange stepped up the pace of its war of nerves against Mayor Lindsay's proposed increase in the securities transfer tax yesterday. It named a nine-man special committee to consider the possibility of moving some or all of the Big Board's operations out of New York.

PARIS, March 10 President de Gaulle, toasting his old friend Konrad Adenauer, said today that the solidarity and common action of Germany and France was necessary to both countries, to Europe and to the world.

LONDON, March 10 British Government officials reacted strongly today to President de Gaulle's threat to disrupt the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. What the French President had already said in a message to President Johnson was repeated in a message received by Prime Minister Wilson today.

State Senator Thomas J. Mackell, who almost won the majority leadership of the State Senate as a compromise candidate in the bitter Democratic battle in Albany a year ago, will formally announce his candidacy for Queens District Attorney on Sunday.
The Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York reported yesterday the achievement of company records last year in sales, investment return and assets.

IN the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe. **Mme. Romaine de Lyon, 32 East 61st Street, 758-2422. This revered and worthwhile New York institution, which specializes in omelets, has recently moved to new premises and it is all to the good.
CHICAGO, March 10 (UPI) Mrs. Ellen Borden Stevenson, the divorced wife of the late Adlai E. Stevenson, was declared incompetent today in Cook County Circuit Court.
LOUISVILLE, March 10 Almost all the favored teams have qualified for the knockout stages of the Vanderbilt Cup contest, that began here this afternoon.
CHICAGO, March 10 The Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago said today that domestic steel output, supplemented by imports, should be sufficient to meet what are expected to be record demands this year.
Louis David Berger of 15 West 81st Street, president of Famous Fashion Shops Ltd., died Thursday at Lenox Hill Hospital at the age of 76.
NEW HAVEN, March 10 An anonymous gift of $600,000 to establish a new medical school professorship has ben received by Yale University, it was announced today.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, March 10 (Reuters) A strike by the National Federation of Port Workers paralyzed harbor activity here today.

Funds for Canada's Shaw Festival at Niagara-on-theLake, 10 miles from Niagara Falls, are being raised by Calvin G. Rand, who organized the Niagara Foundation for the Dramatic Arts last year. It is a hobby with the 36-year-old philosophy lecturer at the University of Buffalo, whose late father, George F. Rand, was the founder of the Marine Midland Corporation, one of the largest bank holding companies in the United States.
ALBANY, March 10 (AP) The stagnant air that produced the threat of heavy air pollution has moved out of the state, the State Health Department said today.

WASHINGTON The term "Washington hostess" is casually applied to a number of prominent women and conjures up images of vast ballrooms packed with Cabinet members and ambassadors sipping champagne between decisions that will change the course of history. But in many ways this image is as much a thing of the past as an administration that has been voted out of office.
RISHRA, India, March 10 At least 12 persons were killed and scores injured today when policemen and demonstrators battled here during a general strike.
DOVER, Del., March 10, (UPI) Harry (Tubby) Raymond, successful as a football and baseball coach here, took over today as the head football coach at the University of Delaware succeeding Dave Nelson.

John Le Carre, author of "The Spy Who Came in From the Cold," has written an adventure and suspense story that will be dramatized next season on "ABC Stage '66" over the American Broadcasting Company television network.

There were many signs of spring evident here yesterday the temperature, the bright sunlight, the flower show and the bulbs that have sprung out of their winter slumber.
The British invasion of the United States art auction market, spearheaded in 1964 when Sotheby's acquired control of Parke-Bernet, will soon be augmented by Sotheby's chief rival, Christie's.

America's three top-ranked women players were named yesterday by the United States Lawn Tennis Association to represent the United States in the Federation Cup, the women's equivalent of the Davis Cup.
SAIGON, March 10 After holding off a superior enemy force for more than 36 hours, American and allied units abandoned a lonely outpost on the Laotian border late this afternoon.

BOSTON, March 10 Mr. and Mrs. William McLaughlin of BOSTON and Manchester, N.H., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Elizabeth McLaughlin, to James Mark Krainin. He is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Philip Krainin of Riverdale, the Bronx, New York, and Naples, Me.

The Greater New York chapter of the Society of Real Estate Appraisers will sponsor a one-day appraisal clinic and a 12-week introductory course in real estate appraising on Long Island. The clinic will be held on March 15 in the Garden City Hotel at Garden City. On March 17 a series of 12 weekly evening classes will start in the Little Theater on the campus of Hofstra University in Hempstead.
Four men pleaded guilty yesterday to complicity in the 1964 swindle of $1-million in bank accounts belonging to Mays department store in Brooklyn.
An increase in the prime rate to 5 per cent from 5 per cent by a leading New York City bank triggered a sharp selloff in the stock market in heavy trading late yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 10 The International Chemical Workers Union has become the first labor union to charge an employer with racial discrimination under the Civil Rights Act of 1964.
ALTHOUGH some skiers think in terms of calling it a season at this stage of winter, dozens of area operators throughout the East yesterday were still hoping for more business.
The spot rate on the British pound rallied strongly yesterday in active trading on foreign exchange markets here.
The Federal Reserve is continuing its policy of gradually tightening credit, figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York indicated.
WASHINGTON, March 10 Officials issued a forecast today of mounting enemy combat operations in Vietnam, particularly a new monsoon offensive starting in the middle of May.
The management of Julius Garfinckel Co. announced last night that it would urge its 5,500 shareholders to reject a tender offer for their shares by Genesco, Inc.

Ernie Terrell was dropped last night as Cassius Clay's heavyweight title bout opponent in Toronto, March 29. The executive vice president of Main Bout, Inc., said a new opponent would be selected for the champion by 2 P.M. today.

DUBLIN, March 10 (Reuters) Frank O'Connor, one of Ireland's best-known short-story writers, died unexpectedly at his home here tonight. He was 63 years old. The cause of death was not immediately determined.
After two days of sharp declines as a result of liquidation of contracts, cocoa futures prices rose sharply yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange.
WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP)--President Johnson was severely criticized by maritime unions today on the ground that his Transportation Message to Congress virtually ignored shipping problems.
WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) The Defense Department's count of United States servicemen killed in the Vietnamese fighting increased sharply during the week that ended Monday night.
More than 50 poets staged a marathon reading last night and early this morning before a standing-room-only crowd at the church of St. Mark's-in-theBouwerie, Second Avenue and 10th Street.

New York University's basketball team survived a gamelong assault by the Blue Demons of De Paul to score a 68-65 victory in an openinground match of the National Invitation Tournament at Madison Square Garden last night.
"The Welfare treats you like animals; they want you to be animals and if you let them get away with it you will be an animal."

A $20-million offering of Ente Nazionale Idrocarburi 6 per cent sinking-fund debentures, due in 1981, has been made in Europe by an underwriting group led by White, Weld Co., Banca Nazionale del Lavoro, Banca Commerciale Italiana and Euramerica-Finanziaria Internazionale.

SYOSSET, L.I., March 10 Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Y.W. Chan have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ginger Faith Chan, to David Bruce Miller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Wilson Miller of New Britain, Conn. The couple plan to marry in May.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., March 10 (AP) Neil H. Armstrong and Maj. David R. Scott will attempt four separate hookups with an Agena satellite and Major Scott is to float in space for 2 hours 40 minutes during next week's Gemini 8 flight.

Whenever the New York City Opera revives its production of "The Love for Three Oranges," it offers one of the pleasantest diversions in town. Last night the Prokofiev work was to be seen at the New York State Theater. Back in the company's repertory after three years' absence, it was as enjoyable as ever.
TRENTON, March 11--The Joint Legislative Appropriations Committee approved Gov. Richard J. Hughes's budget and income tax today after its Republican members angrily walked out.
