LOS ANGELES, March 11 The Apollo moonlanding program has passed a major engineering test so well as to obviate any slowdown in the schedule for a 1969 expedition, project officials reported today.

OTTAWA, March 11 The words one most often hears used to describe Lucien Cardin, are "selfless" and diligent." He is an unassuming politician with a reputation for administrative ability," one Canadian commentator wrote after one of Mr. Cardin's steps up the political ladder.

John V. Lindsay Jr., a 5year-old, freckle-faced boy in a gray snowsuit stood in for his busy father, the Mayor, yesterday at graduation exercises held by the Fire Department on Welfare Island at 10 A.M.

WASHINGTON March 11-- The index of wholesale market prices was unchanged at 104.9 (1957-59 equals 100) during the week ended Mach 8, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reportee today. Prices held steady in all three major commodity sectors--farm products, processed foods and industrial commodities.

THE nautical look in home decorating has grown in recent years from a small splash to a tidal wave. Rusty anchors guard flower beds in suburbia, capstans serve as end tables in living rooms, and naval charts paper the walls of dens and boys' rooms.
WASHINGTON, March 11 The House Appropriations Committee approved swiftly today the Administration's $13,135,719,000 supplementary appropriations request in support of the war in Vietnam.
ST. LOUIS, March 11 Harry Edison, chairman of the board and treasurer of Edison Brothers Stores, Inc., a national women's shoe-store chain; died today, after a brief illness. His age was 75.
A father and son were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of evading $158,133 in income taxes based on unreported income of $330,535.
Dr. Max A. Luria, Professor Emeritus of Modern Languages at Brooklyn College, died Thursday at his' home at 20 Pierrepont Street in Brooklyn Heights. He was 74 years old.

Thomas J. Burke, who had been steward of the New York State. Harness Racing Commission and a city detective for 24 years, died on Thursday night in his home at 63-15 Wetherole Street in Rego Perk, Queens. He was 69 years old.
Senator Jacob K. Javits disclosed yesterday that he had recommended to Mayor Lindsay before Mr. Lindsay took office that Sanford D. Garelik would make a "splendid" police commissioner.
Mayor Lindsay and Council President Frank D. O'Connor, made peace overtures to each other yesterday.

The past looks down on City Hall Park through two dusty windows on the 22d floor of the Municipal Building. Behind the windows in an L-shaped room are a few aged reminders of the city's contingent of the Grand Army of the Republic, those proud Union veterans of the Civil War who once numbered 14,000 here.

The public hearing before the Board of Education yesterday on its, proposed city-wide school reorganization was disrupted for more than an hour by shouts, songs and protests from angry residents of Harlem and East Harlem.
LONDON, March 11 Mrs. Caitlin Thomas, the widow of the poet Dylan Thomas, lost her claim today for possession of the original manuscript of her husband's play "Under Milk Wood."
The American Stock Exchange recovered a good portion of its previous day's losses in quiet trading yesterday.

KENSINGTON, Md., March 11 Mr. and Mrs. John Kilbourn Vance have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sarah Eggleston Vance, to Lieut. Peter Francis Roman, U.S.M.C. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Peter Roman of Sharon, Mass. A June wedding is planned.

LOS ANGELES, March 11 Dr. John Kenneth Galbraith, Harvard economist and former Ambassador to India, said tonight that the removal of Abba P. Schwartz from the State Department was an affront to the nation's liberals who had given strong support to the national Administration.

WILMINGTON, Del., March 11 The Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that two Cleveland men had been arrested in connection with what agents described as a scheme to sell stolen secret trade formulas and processes worth several million, dollars to the E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. in Wilmington.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 11 (AP) The novelist Ken Kesey's attempt to escape prosecution on marijuana charges became an international affair today. The Government moved to extradite him from Mexico.

NEW DELHI, March 11 At least 25 students were injured in Amritsar today as the police used batons and tear gas to break up violent crowds of student demonstrators protesting the creation of a Punjabi-speaking state.

Mrs. Robert F. Wagner, wife of the former Mayor, was admitted yesterday at 3:30 P.M. to the Wollman Pavilion of Lenox Hill Hospital. She will undergo surgery for removal of an intestinal tumor on Monday.

MONTPELIER, Vt., March 11 (AP) Gov. Philip H. Hoff, a Democrat in an historically Republican state, showed the Republican-controlled Legislature today there is more than one way to handle a member of the opposition.

BONN, March 11 The West German Government denied today repeated Israeli newspaper reports that quoted President Heinrich Lubke as having expressed "dismay" at Israeli views on German restitution payments.
TOPEKA, Kan., March 11 (AP) United States District Judge George Templar today sentenced a Fort Worth, Tex., youth to two years in prison for threatening the life of President Johnson.
A top steel executive yesterday lauded the Government's efforts to prevent inflation but he criticized its approach.

LJUBLJANA, Yugoslavia, March 11 (UPI) The battle for the 1966 world ice hockey championship was narrowed to a two-team affair today, when Czechoslovakia and the defending title holder, the Soviet Union, won them games.

NEWTON, Ga., March 10 Southern Negroes are encountering major obstacles in their attempts to elect public officials under the Federal Voting Rights Act of 1965, which became effective seven months ago.

LOS ANGELES, March 11 (UPI) Utah, the Western Athletic Conference champion, survived a second half comeback by the West Coast Athletic Con- ference titlist, University of Pacific, tonight and advanced to the finals of the National Collegiate Athletic Conference Western Regional basketball tournament with an 83-74 victory.
SINGAPORE, Saturday, Mar. 12 (UPI) The Malaysian Government's External Affairs Ministry, in a statement issued in Kuala Lumpur today, said:
LOUISVILLE, March 11 All the favored teams survived the first knockout round of the Vanderbilt Cup Contest at the American Conract Bridge League's Spring Nationals here last night.

When a nine-man New york Stock Exchange committee settles dow in this week to study, the possibility of mov- ' ing all or part of, the Big Board's operations out of State, it will have a much broader choice of options to choose from than the group.
ACCRA, Ghana, March 11 Ghana's ruling body has had second thoughts about the ouster of 1,000 Soviet technicians and teachers stationed here.

ROME, N.Y., March 11 Mrs. Grace Selden Van Wagenen Carpenter, widow of Arthur F. Carpenter, former president of the Rome Metallic Bedstead Company, died Wednesday in her dome here at 308 West Bloomfield Street at the age of 86.

FRANCONIA, N.H., March 11 A petite 13-year-old blonde, at an age when most girls who ski are in some school trying to master the rudiments, provided the major stir here today by winning a North American giant slalom championship.
Most bond prices continued to drift lower yesterday in response to the increase in the minimum lending rate announced by leading commercial banks Thursday afternoon.

JERSEY CITY, March 11 Mayor Thomas J. Whelan denounced as "maliciously untrue" today charges that he and John V. Kenny, Hudson County Democratic Leader, demanded $10,000 from a New York lawyer as the price for permission to build two gasoline stations here.
MADISON, Wis., March 11 (UPI) Jack Hood Vaughn, the new Peace Corps director, drew jeers today from Vietnam war protestors at the University of Wisconsin.
Maxine Keith, drama critic for the Municipal Broadcasting System and a theatrical press agent, was found dead yesterday at her apartment at 150 East 49th Street.

WASHINGTON, March 11 The American Medical Association has agreed to pay $25,000 in damages and publish retractions in a libel suit brought by a steel union official as an outgrowth of the battle over Medicare.
A benefit titled "A Gala Evening at Lincoln Center" will be held on April 6 to raise funds for the Children's Psychiatric Center of Monmouth County in Eatontown, N.J.

The report of the Del E. Webb Corporation disclosed yesterday a net loss of more than $13.4million for 1965. This is in sharp contrast with a net income of $1,855,068, or 28 cents a share, reported in 1964.

The Senate-House conference on the Administration's tax bill acted swiftly to work out an acceptable compromise that gave the White House most of what it had been seeking within the timetable set by President Johnson. But speed seems to be the only real virtue of this particular legislation. Senator Albert Gore correctly characterized the Administration's request as a "picayune" measure that induced an "irresponsible performance" in Congress.
One of the oldest frontier disputes in, the world Gibraltar is entering a new phase. The British, have agreed to bilateral talks with the Spaniards on "the Rock" next month.

MINNEAPOLIS, March 11 (UPI) Isidor Saslav, a 28year-old American violinist, will be the new concertmaster of the Minneapolis Symphony Orchestra beginning in September, it was announced today by Richard M. Cisek, the orchestra's managing director.

The Communist party of Indonesia (P.K.I.), which was reportedly banned yesterday by General Suharto, in 1965 was the largest Communist party ... outside the Communist countries. It had a membership of about three million members in addition to a number of "fronts."

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., March 11 (AP) Neil A. Armstrong and Maj. David R. Scott of the Air Force were given medical examinations today that lasted four and one-half hours and were declared "ready for flight" in Gemini 8 on Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, March 11 COntroller of the Currency James J. Saxon, in a complete about-face, told Congress today he opposed legislation permitting, banks to enter the mutual fund business under banking agency regulation.

DETROIT, March 11 (AP) Recorder's Court Judge Arthur J. Koscinski, charged with five counts of failing to file Federal income tax returns, today submitted his resignation in a letter to Gov. George Romney.

The destruction of Lord Nelson's monument this week reminds us that violence can still flare from the ashes of a dead imperial relationship. Ireland began to move decisively toward independence in the Easter Week Rising of 1916, which centered in the Streets around the Nelson column.
The Celanese Corporation of America announced yesterday that it is offering to the holders of its common stock rights to subscribe for 1,478,622 additional shares at $64 a share.
JERUSALEM, (Israeli Sector), March 11 A 26-year-old American tourist, Edward Levy, was returned to Israel yesterday, apparently in ill health, after nearly two years in a Syrian cell.
WASHINGTON, March 11 The Republican National Chairman, Ray C. Bliss, agreed today to add a Negro as a top-level staff member of the Republican National Committee.
A girl named Marina will receive a $50 savings bond today as one of three winners in a grade-school art contest held in conjunction with the Greater Long Island Boat Show.
LONDON, March 11 A high court judge ruled today that Walt Disney Productions has no right to object to the making of a film using live actors and called "Peter Pan."

ATTEMPTS at creating colored sculpture on an architectural scale continue to occupy an important place on the current art scene. Sculpture grows increasingly ambitious to take hold of and transform the environment. Elements of painting and architecture compete for supremacy in large constructed sculptures that boldly fill interior space, spreading themselves over the floor, reaching to the ceiling and generally asserting their visual authority over whatever Milieux they occupy.

EVERYONE, it seems, is doing it. Last week, Phila delphia and its Mayor decided to have a "ballet week." This week, Newark, and its Mayor have declared a ballet week. At this rate, in two or three years, it will be news when Peoria, Ill., does NOT have a ballet week.
PITTSBURGH, March 11 A fad for leopardskin coats came undser sharp attack to day at a national conference of conservationists.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 11 The New York Mets curtailed their practice today in order to take part in a baseball players' golf tournament, where at last they were officially conceded a handicap.
DETROIT, March 11 Ricardo Urbina of Georgetown and Bob Mead of Manhattan won titles today as the National Collegiate Athletic Association opened its indoor track and field championships.

LAREDO, Tex., March 11 (UPI) Dr. Timothy F. Leary, a former Haryard psychology lecturer widely known for experiments with hallucination drugs, was convicted today on two marijuana charges and sentenced to a maximum of 30 years in Federal prison.

MIAMI, March 11 Kermit Zarley clung to the lead in the $100,000 Doral open golf tournament today with a second round of 72. The 24year-old professional from Yakima, Wash., brought his 36hole aggregate to 137 for a one-stroke advantage.
City Council action on Mayor Lindsay's controversial tax program is not likely to be completed before "late April or early May," in the opinion of the Council majority leader, David Ross.

PITTSBURGH, March 11 (AP) A four-team fight for the title shaped up tonight among Lehigh, Penn State, Navy and Army in tie Eastern Intercollegiate wrestling championships.
TORONT, March 11 (AP) George Chuvalo signed today to fight Cassius Clay March 19 in Maple Leaf Gardens in a bout that will be billed as a world heavy weight championship match.
CALCUTTA, India, March 11 The police and demonstrators clashed again today during they second day of anti-Government rioting.

Mayor Lindsay warned New Yorkers yesterday that the water crisis was not over and that new conservation measures, to be promoted by a professional advertising campaign, would have to be imposed this summer.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, March 11 (AP) Ben Arda of the Philippines carded a 4-under-par 68 today to tie Peter Thomson of Australia at 138 for first place midway through the Malayan open golf championship.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 114.1 on Thursday from 114.0 on Wednesday.

For the last 10 years President Sukarno has ruled his nation, an archipelago of 105 million people, under a policy that he called "nasakom." In his acronym the "nas" stood for nationalist, which to Mr. Sukarno meant the military; "a" referred to "agama," or religious groups, and "kom" meant Communist or the P.K.I., Indonesia's Peking-oriented 3 million-member Communist party.

AVISITOR from Dublin once observed that in all probability more corned beef was consumed in a day in Manhattan than throughout the year on the Emerald Isle. New York is a delicatessen town, in truth a place of stand-up counters with thick-piled sandwiches, and corned beef on rye is a favorite on the East Side and the West.
Ordinarily, when a $1-billion bank merger gets approval, it's a cause for jubilation among bankers.
STORRS, Conn., March 11 (UFI) John L. Toner, assistant to Buff Donelli at Columbia the last nine years, was appointed head football coach today at the University of Connecticut.
AUCKLAND, New Zealand, March 11 (Reuters) An International meeting of airline pilots here said today that major airlines were making it difficult for them to change jobs.

Mr. and Mrs. J. Pierre Kolisch of Portland, Ore., have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Leslie Gay Kolisch, to Michael S. Taylor, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank E. Taylor of Greenwich, Conn.

IOWA CITY, March 11 (UPI) Kentucky, the top-ranked team, rallied in the final 10 minutes tonight to win from Dayton, 86-79, and advance to the quarter-final round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament.

DETROIT, March 11--Rabbi Morris Adler, spiritual leader of Detroit's largest Conservative Jewish congregation, died early today in Sinai Hospital, where he had been in a coma since he was shot Feb. 12 during a Sabbath service in Congregation Shaaray Zedek. He was 59 years old.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., March 11 (AP) Thirty-eight days ago Alvin Meinhold didn't salute the flag.

SAIGON, March 11 In Vietnam, where tales of great courage are not rare, the rescue of a downed American flier by a fellow pilot yesterday may long be remembered as a particularly daring act of heroism.
AGANA, Guam After more than two decades the cap ital of the United States territory of Guam finds itself directly involved in a war again.

CLAES OLDENBURG you know, the one who did the bid hamburgers? is having his annual show at the Sidney Jams Gallery, 15 East 57th Street, and it is a great relief to me since at last it places Mr. Oldenburg exactly where he belongs.

An imaginative and skillfully written string quartet by Iain Hamilton was given its premiere by the Kohon Quartet late yesterday afternoon in a concert at Town Hall. Mr. Hamilton is a 43-year-old Scottish composer who has lived in the United States since l96l. The work introduced was his Quartet No. 2, and it was created last year for the Kohon group.

BOSTON, March 11 (AP) Harry Dunn's second goal of the game at 15:09 of the third period lifted Clarkson to a 2-1 victory over Brown tonight in a semi-final game of the Eastern College Athletic Conference hockey tournament.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 11 (AP) Five persons were killed today when the police opened fire on copper miners attacking police headquarters at El Salvador, the Defense Ministry announced. Twenty-five persons, including some national policemen, were injured.
MIAMI, March 11 Sunny Jim Fitzsimmons, who devoted 78 years to riding and training horses, died today at the Cedars of Lebanon Hospital. He was 91 years old.
HOUSTON, March 11 Prince Philip the aviator, became Prince Philip the amateur astronaut today.

Summer'Gerard, a lawyer and real estate investor and developer, died Thursday in New York Hospital. He was 91 years old and lived at 27 East 73d Street. He was the brother of the late James W. Gerard, Ambassador to Germany before our entry into World War I.

MILWAUKEE, March 11 (AP) A lawyer jor the Braves charged today that articles by the sports editor of The Milwaukee Journal reflected hostility to baseball and contained uncomplimentary references to leading figures in the game.
BRASILIA, March 11--Five Americans, detained here for three weeks for investigation, were formally accused today of violations of Brazil's import and export laws.

Directors of Bond stores, Inc., the nation's largest clothing chain, approved yesterday a proposal for the company to buy up to 500,000 shares of Bond stock from shareholders. The price offered would be $30 per share in cash.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 11 Mickey Mantle expects to be able to play in the last half dozen New York Yankee exhibition games, during the first week in April.

KINKOLE, the Congo, March 9 The first Congolese "kibbutz" or collective farm settlement, which was organized by a Roman Catholic priest, is turning a stretch of tangled bush near the banks of the Congo River here into a promising farm.
ATLANTA, March 11 (AP) More than 700 deaths from pneumonia that grew out of influenza were reported in the United States for the week ending last Saturday, the Communicable Disease Center said today.

WASHINGTON, March 11? The United States and all its North Atlantic Treaty allies except France are reported to be drafting a joint declaration reaffirming their support for the alliance and for the principle of military integration as an essential to modern collective defense.
A miniature Gothic cathedral on Columbus Circle is being pounded into dust.
BOGALUSA, La., March 11 (UPI) A Negro Army captain preparing to ship out to Vietnam was shot by sniper while his back was turned early today.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange closed yesterday with a predominance of small losses after a quiet session.
WASHINGTON, March 11 Vice President Humphrey declared today that the United States would make no settlement in Vietnam that gave the Communists a political role they had not earned in free elections.

MORE and more, Marlboro is impressing its strength on the contemporary American musical scene. From Rudolf Serkin's summer colony are coming many of this country's brightest instrumentalists. The emphasis, as it is all summer, is on chamber music.

WASHINGTON, Saturday, March 12 United States Government officials appeared to be pleased but were cautious in their comments this morning as they received evi- ... dence of a further swing of power to Indonesia's antiCommunist military command.
KIRKSVILLE, Mo., March 11 (AP) A twin-engine Beechcraft airplane crashed 20 miles northwest of here today, killing four persons.
DUSSELDORF, Germany, March 11 Ruhr coal miners stopped work for half an hour today to protest the growing threat to their job security.

Ernest Lovett Garceau of South Woodstock, Vt., a consulting engineer who helped invent a device to measure brain waves, died of a heart attack Thursday while on a vacation at Tryon, N.C. He was 59 years old.

Max Edwin Pollock of 1125 Park Avenue, the president of William E. Pollock Co., Inc., dealers in United States Government securities at 45 Wall Street, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital. His age was 62.
The Chicago Symphony Orchestra ended its program last night in such a blaze of glory that it had to play an encore after Stravinsky's complete "Le Sacre du Printemps."
LOS ANGELES, March 11 Miss Sara Ann Miller and Peter Martin Fine plan to be married here July 31.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 11 Yale University, propelled by two of the many lively sophomores present, took a commanding lead tonight over Army in the Eastern Seaboard intercollegiate swimming championshipsat the Naval Academy.

OTTAWA, March 11 (Canadian Press) The Bank of Canada announced tonight an increase in the bank rate to 5 per cent from 4 per cent. The increase is effective Mon day. The rate has been constant at 4 , per cent since Dec. 6, 1965, when it was raised from 4 per cent.
The Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn, a stronghold of theological conservatism, is getting into the movement for ecumenism, or Christian unity.

Thirty Harlem Children with scholastic difficulties went to college yesterday to improve their reading and mathematical skills. The curriculum included training in phonetics, vocabulary, and multiplication tables.
WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) The Senate Select Committee on Standards and Conduct met today to investigate allegations involving Senator Thomas J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut.

A New Jersey commuter has voluntarily sent a check to New York City for $255.86, his estimated city income tax under Mayor Lindsay's proposed tax program.
WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) Four states Kansas, New Jersey, Maryland and Florida will put into effect this year tire safety standards suggested by the Vehicle Equipment Safety Commission.

HAVERFORD, Pa., March 11 Alfred R. Crawford, vice president for development, Haverford College, was found dead last night in the garage of his home here. Policemen said a car was in the garage with its motor running. Mr. Crawford was 57 years old. He had been a longtime resident of Pleasantville, N.Y.
PARIS, March 11 France's monetary reserves rose slightly last month, after a period of near-stability.
DETROIT, March 11 (AP) Chrysler's Corporation's 40 officers and directors collected $5,568,122 in salaries and bonuses in 1965, a decrease from the $5,890,254 they received in 1964.

WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) Negotiations between five major airlines and the International Association of Machinists were reported deadlocked today, raising the possibility of a strike threat next month.

ALBANY, March 11 Mayor Lindsay's transportation plan for New York City ran into strong opposition today from John J. Gilhooley, a Republican member of the Transit Authority, and former Mayor Robert F. Wagner, a Democrat.

The proprietor of a Harlem liquor store shot and killed two youths last night when they attempted to rob his shop at 9 West 110th Street, according to the police.

WASHINGTON, March 11 A long and bitter strike by the printing trades unions against the Kingsport Press, Inc., already the nation's oldest current labor dispute, entered its fourth year today with no sign of settlement in sight.

NEW HAVEN, March 11 Three undergraduates from New York University brandish ing foils established a new standard for excellence at the annual championships of the Intercollegiate Fencing Association here today.
WASHINGTON, March 11 Inventory accumulation by businesses slowed dramatically in January, the Commerce Department reported today.

WASHINGTON, March 11 (UPI) The White House said today that more than 40 Governors had accepted President Johnson's invitation to a luncheon and a briefing on national and world affairs tomorrow.

A 29-year-old Alabamian landed at Kennedy Airport yesterday after a $27,278 tour of Europe that he was accused of financing with a Diners Club card, which he had obtained with an $11 check that bounced.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 11--The theatrical group of Harvard College's Hasty Pudding Club today presented its "Woman of the Year, 1966" award to Ethel Merman, who has been the singing star of 13 Broadway hits.

A 30-year-old messenger for a chain jewelry manufacturing company wad shot and killed late yesterday afternoon in the corridor of the eighth floor of 74 West 46th Street, part of the midtown jewelry area.
WASHINGTON, March 11 An angry delegation of whites and Negroes from Baltimore descended on the Department of Housing and Urban Develop ment today to protest housing discrimination in their city.
WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) Seven officials of the Ku Klux Klan pleaded not guilty today in Federal District Court as they were arraigned on charges of contempt of Congress.

MURRAY LOUIS can move a muscle the way most people can move an arm. He has the most remarkable muscular control that may credibly be encountered in a dancer. And this muscular control is allied to a musicality and rhythmic sense that make him one of the three or four outstanding technicians in American modern dance.
PALOMARES, Spain, March 11 Jon Lindbergh is working under the sea off the coast here in the search for a lost hydrogen bomb.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 11 (AP) Two Federal courts today ordered total desegregation on a "freedom of choice" basis of the school systems of three Alabama counties.

MIAMI, March 11 (AP) Eleven of the best handicap horses training an Florida compete tomorrow in the $60,500 Donn Handicap at Gulfstream Park. Mrs. Ada L. Rice's Pia Star is the likely favorite, under high weight of 121 pounds.
ATLANTIC CITY, March 11 (AP) Six dresses made of a new fabric produced by a machine that combines both knitting and weaving processes yesterday in a fashion show here.

Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary yesterday called the John Birch Society "abhorrent" and said he would forbid policemen to belong "if I had the authority." he would consult with Corporation Counsel J. Lee Rankin "and be guided by his opinion" as to whether policemen could legally be members of the society.
Isidor M. Bernstein is hav0ing a one-man art show tonight in the front lobby of the Pfizer building, 235 East 42nd Street at Second Avenue.
Four major lumber associations, reported an increase of 11.0 per cent in production in the week ended March 5 compared to the level in the 1965 week. Output fell 1.3 per cent from the preceding week.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., March 11 A summer wedding is planned by Miss Bethanne McNally, whose parents, Mr. and Mrs. Harry J. McNally, have announced her engagement to Peter Richard Pouncey. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Cecil Allen Pouncey of Emsworth, Hampshire, England.
PORTLAND, Ore., March 11 (AP) Howard Morgan, a former member of the Federal Power Commission, announced today his candidacy for the United States Senate.
The stock market was unable to sustain an early recovery movement yesterday and prices at the close presented a rather confused pattern.
NASSAU, the Bahamas, March 11 Vamp X, a pale-blue Cal 40 sloop belonging to Robert E. (Ted) Turner 3d of the Atlantic Yacht Club, became the champion of the Southern Ocean Racing Conference today.
When Manuel Ycaza became ill at Santa Anita Park the other day and could not ride in the seventh race, the eyes of a 59-year-old millionaire sitting outside the jockey's room widened expectantly.
WASHINGTON, March 11 The Justice Department disclosed tonight that it had ordered an investigation of the alleged intimidation of Ralph Nader, a leading critic of auto industry safety practices.
PEKING, March 11 A calamitous earthquake has hit a densely populated area of northern China, it was disclosed today.
OTTAWA, March 11 Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson ordered today a full inquiry into an alleged security scandal during the former Conservative regime.
LONDON, March 11 Britain's trade deficit was sharply reduced last month as exports rose by 35-million ($88-million) to a new peak, the Government reported today.
A four-page leaflet entitled "Let's outlaw Floating Firetraps" is now being distributed by the National Maritime Union.
SAIGON, Saturday, March 12 Supporters of Lieut, Gen. Nguyen Chanh Thi protested today his expulsion from the junta that rules South Vietnam.

Deputy Mayor Robert Price, often referred to by his opponents as Machiavelli, Svengali, or the Monster, put down the phone with less than his usual energy. He turned sad brown eyes on the semicircle of assistants gathered in his City Hall office for a weekly meeting and muttered:

LONDON, March 11 Britain's three major political parties strongly condemned today a workers' kangaroo court that tried and fined eight fellowworkers in a British Motor Corporation plant for having refused to join a wildcat strike.

Seven thousand employes of the Braden Copper Company, a subsidiary of the Kennecott Copper Corporation, walked off their jobs Jan. 3 at El Teniente, the world's largest underground copper mine. They had asked for a 70 per cent wage in- ... crease and other benefits to meet rising living costs; the company offered a 30 per cent raise.
WASHINGTON, March 11 A roadside computer patented this week keeps a continuous watch on the density of traffic, so that the flow can be controlled.
OSAKA, Japan, March 11 (AP) An American seaman was killed today when a small Japanese tanker collided with an American freighter six miles off the coast. Five Japanese were missing.

What keeps the Vienna Choir Boys at the top of the evergrowing list of such groups? Hearing this year's crop from Vienna at Town Hall last night suggested two answers. First, they are obviously well drilled and sing with great precision, yet the effect is always one of spontaneity. Second, the members of the Knabenchor are hand picked for the sheer natural beauty of their young voices.

The 44th annual Middle Atlantic figure-skating championships opened on the Iceland Rink atop Madison Square Garden at 7:30 a'clock yesterday morning. Precisely at than minute, the first performers in the three-day event, eight brighteyed girls, reported for the juvenile singles.
Every time Kevin Loughery came down on his ankle last night it hurt. "But it doesn't matter," he said, "because we won."

THE National Broadcasting company could possibly have found a more depressing title for last night's one-hour color special than "Ballet for Skeptics," but it, would not have been easy. One day I suppose a TV concern will come up with "TV for Skeptics," which will surprise us all.

In what promises to be a nightmare to Madison Square Garden's able statistical erew, the National Invitation Tour nament will present the concluding basketball games of the first round in a double doubleheader this afternoon and tonight.

NAIROBI, Kenya, March 11 President Jomo Kenyatta warned today that Kenya's politicians would have to tread carefully and with the welfare of the people constantly in mind if the country was to escape a power struggle of the sort that has been sweeping other African countries.
WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) The Defense Department called today for the draft induction of 21,700 men for the Army in April.

MOSCOW, March 11 (UPI) Aleksi Adzhubei, former editor of the Government paper Izvestia, published his first article since he and his father-in-law, Nikita S. Khrushehev, lost their jobs more than a year ago.

Councilman Theodore S. Weiss opened his campaign against Representative Leonard Farbstein yesterday, charging that he was an apathetic legislator "who long ago lost touch with this city and its people."
The Democrats are thinking of a plan that would put politics in the same league with bigtime athletics.
A number of price changes in the chemical industry were announced yesterday.
The spot rate on the British pound continued to gain yesterday in moderate trading on foreign exchange markets here.

Leo Ullman, who retired Dec. 31 as executive vice president of Joseph H. Cohen Sons, Inc., manufacturers here of men's clothing and now a division of the Rapid-American Corporation, died Thursday in the Neurological Institute of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 67 years old and lived at 139 East 63d Street.
LOS ANGELES, March 11 (UPI) A spokesman for Project Prayer said today the group had found "legal methods which will reverse court rulings against organized prayer in public schools."
SAIGON, March 11 An American survivor of a besieged outpost near the Laotian border today told how attacking North Vietnamese soldiers were held off for 36 hours.
YONKERS, March 11 Only once in the 18 years that Archie Niles Jr. has been driving harness horses has the handsome man from Westbury, L.I., fared better than he did tonight at Yonkers Raceway.
NEW ORLEANS, March 11 Several hundred teachers went on strike today in the American Federation of Teachers' first major bargaining effort in the Deep South.
The United States Court off Appeals for the Seventh Circuit ruled today that a union could not fine its members for crossing a picket line to go to work while the union was on strike.
WASHINGTON, March 11 The Commerce Department Clamped export quotas today on cattle hides and skins "to provide adequate supplies for domestic needs."

HUNTINGTON BAY HILLS, L.I., March 12--Mr. and Mrs. George L. Schaefer have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Laura Ruth Schaefer, to Dr. Edward Merker. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Moe Merker of Mount Vernon, N.Y.

The marriage of Miss Carole Rosen to Richard Henry Nelson took place last evening at the Waldorf-Astoria. Rabbi Maurice Eisendrath, president of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, performed the ceremony.

The ones who stick it...
THERE will be more than 500 all-breed dog shows this year. But today's Saw Mill River Kennel Club fixture at the Westchester County Center, Bronx River Parkway, White Plains, N.Y., stands alone.

NASSAU, Bahamas, March 12 -"You can't win ocean races without working harder than the other guys,"said Robert E. (Ted)Turner 3d, the young Southerner who became the Southern Ocean Racing Conference champion yesterday with the first cruising yacht he has ever owned.
MIAMI BEACH--Spring is the formal season in this resort city. The terrycloth robes and sandals disappear from Collins Avenue, and are replaced by dark business suits studded with convention badges.

ALBANY, March 12--Governor Rockefeller, citing a report that hospitals need $600-million for modernization and construction, proposed today that the state make low-cost loans to public and private nonprofit hospitals used by the physically and mentally ill.
WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP)--The Presidential task force named to intensify a campaign against hunger, ignorance and disease in South Vietnam left for Saigon by plane today.
LAREDO, Tex., March 12 (UPI)--The attorney for a former Harvard professor sentenced to 30 years in prison on marijuna charges said today he would appeal on grounds that include religious freedom.
An unusual cantilever design will be incorporated in two 28story apartment buildings rising in the Horizon House complex on the brow of the Palisades in Fort Lee, N.J.

PRUNING, the most commonly practiced tree care operation, is essentially the same whether the tree is six or 60 feet tall. An understanding of pruning principles will enable the homeowner to do much of the work himself. Or it will help him evaluate the work done on large trees which have been entrusted to the skill of a professional arborist.

The engagement of Miss Carol Handler Styne, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David H. Styne of 1025 Fifth Avenue, to Laurence R. Stern, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Stern of Lawrence, L.I., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents.

The sawtooth walls and starshaped design of a nursing home rising in New Jersey are part of a Columbia University professor's prescription for bringing more light and color into the lives of the aged and infirm persons who will be admitted there.
Manhattan's constantly reaching skyline is taking on hues of black, silver and gold from the increasing use of anodized aluminum curtain wall construction.
WASHINGTON, March 12-- Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson will explore one of the country's most rugged, isolated and dangerous national parks next month in a corner of her own home state.

ACCRA, Ghana, March 12-- Lieut. Gen. Joseph A. Ankrah, chairman of the ruling National Liberation Council, declared today that the new leadership would pursue a foreign policy of "balanced neutrality."
HOUSTON, March 12 (AP) --The Houston Astrodome will have an artificial infield covering for at least the start of the 1966 baseball season.
WASHINGTON, March 12-- The Johnson Administration found it difficult today to hide its delight with the news from Indonesia pointing to the political demise of President Sukarno.
HALLANDALE, Fla., March 12--The Argentine-bred Tronado defeated a field of eight in the $59,550 Donn Handicap at Gulfstream Park today, while the favored Dapper Dan wound up fifth.

NEW HAVEN, March 12-- The New York University fencing team won the three-weapon title today in the Intercollegiate Fencing Association championships at Yale's Payne Whitney Gymnasium. It was the 15th time N.Y.U. had won the sport's most distinguished collegiate tournament, which was begun in 1894. No other school has won it so often.
Recent attacks by the Vietcong on shipping in the Saigon River have emphasized the importance of what the Navy calls inshore, coastal, shallowwater, or "riverine" warfare.
Largely because of budget cuts in the last two years, American physics has reached a stage bordering on crisis, according to a survey published yesterday by the National Academy of Sciences.

DOWN South, the chill is gone and the blossoms are at hand --right on schedule. From the Rio Grande to the Pot omac, flower festivals are about to begin. There will be a long, long trail of sun and scent, and this is the South as it was meant to be. The memory of this winter's frosty touches will make springtime all the sweeter.

PHILADELPHIA, March 12 (AP)--The Philadelphia / 76ers rallied in the final 14 minutes for a 134-126 victory over the New York Knicks tonight, increasing their Eastern Division lead in the National Basketball Association to a game over the Boston Celtics.

FRANCONIA, N.H., March 12--Paula Kenerva, the precocious 13-year-old blond from Whitefish, Mont., who arrived for the North American Alpine ski championships unheralded and undaunted, amazed onlookers again today.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.--One of the most successful toll turnpikes in the country, the 265-mile Sunshine State Parkway, carried more than 10 million vehicles last year and collected more than $14.3million in tolls, a gain of 740,295 vehicles and $1,808,068 over 1964. In 1958, its first full year of operation, the turnpike, then only 110 miles long, carried only 3.25 million vehicles.
WASHINGTON, March 12-- President Johnson announced today his intention to nominate former Gov. Farris Bryant of Florida as head of the Office of Emergency Planning.
A 9,000-volume private library of Hebrew rarities that includes a third of the 100 works printed before 1500 that still exist has just been acquired by Yeshiva University.

PHILADELPHIA, March 12 (AP)--Comdr. Edmund S. McCawley, U.S.N., retired, Pennsylvania Deputy Secretary of Forests and Waters from 1947 to 1952, died yesterday at his home in Ithan. He was 75 years old.

The possibility that residents of communities afflicted by jet noise may develop psychotic symptoms because their dreams are interrupted at night was raised here last week by a psychiatrist and a psychologist.

CHERRY HILL, N.J., March 12--Miss Cheryl Alynda Gemberling, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Allen Gemberling of Haddonfield, was married this evening to Charles Kozloff, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Kozloff of Merion, Pa. The Rev. Edwin Lane of the Unitarian Church performed the ceremony at the Cherry Hill Inn.

BALBOA, C. Z., March 12-- Field studies of the eastern sector of the Isthmus of Panama to determine the feasibility of a sea-level canal will be undertaken soon by the Atlantic-Pacific Interoceanic Canal Studies Commission.

LJUBLJANA, Yugoslavia, March 12 (AP)--The United States team built an early 5-0 lead today, then held off a rally by Poland to post a 6-4 victory in the final game for each team in the world hockey tourney.
LAREDO, Tex., March 12 (AP)--James Hines and Clyde Duncan of Texas Southern, Tony Pickett of Houston, and Wayne Badgley of Abilene Christian posted over-all meet records in the Border Olympics today.

Mrs. Helen Campbell Douglas of Cannes, France, and James Douglas of Phoenix, Ariz., have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Josalee Douglas, to Count Jean Francois de Chambrun of Paris and Lozere, France. He is the son of the Marquis de Chambrun and of Mrs. Hugot de Chambrun of Paris and Lozere.
Two 42-story skyscrapers, the tallest buildings in Southern California, are under way in Los Angeles.
PALM SPRINGS, Calif., March 12 (AP)--Two unearned runs scored by Eddie Kirkpatrick led the California Angels to a 3-2 victory over the Chicago Cubs today in a spring training baseball opener.

The head of a major maritime union predicted yesterday a "growing shortage" of pilots in the Panama Canal, which could cause a "sharp curtailment" in the number of ship passages through the 50-mile isthmus.

TOKYO, March 12--An increasing number of companies here are requiring new male employes to spend a few days in an armed forces camp before reporting to work. They see a "lack of discipline" in the young university graduates.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., March 12--Mr. and Mrs. Ira E. Hicks of New Canaan and Island, N.Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Deborah Frances Hicks, to Preston I. Carnes Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Carnes of Fairfield.

PARIS, March 12--The French Government forced members of the Chinese Nationalist embassy staff today to move out of their headquarters. Since France's recognition of Communist China in 1964, the embassy building has been the cause of a long dispute.
The Goucher College Club of New York will hold its 64th annual spring luncheon March 26 at the Plaza. Mrs. Bruce R. Jacobs and Miss Suse U. Wenzel are co-chairmen of the event.

PENSACOLA, Fla.--The highest land elevation in this state is little more than 300 feet above sea level, but Florida has a number of towns on hills whose charm is heightened by the contrast of the flat plains around them, frequently for 100 miles or more.

THE heroine of Vercors's last novel, "Sylvia," was a fox who turned into a woman. The hero of this one is a fake philosophy professor from Kamloopee, Okla., who turns into Supersalesman. More burlesque than satire, "Quota" is pertinent, amusing and harmless, as unlikely to strike fear in our hearts as the warning notice on a pack of cigarettes.

Some new city homeowners may be opening their cellars to flooding, their roadways to mud and their doors to trouble by not insisting on receiving a certificate of occupancy at the time they take title to their development homes, Highways Commissioner Harry J. Donnelly warned last week.
NEW MILFORD, Conn., March 12 (AP)--John F. Bresnahan, director of the Audit Bureau of Circulation before his retirement in 1956, died yesterday at his home. He was 89 years old.
Six state legislators picketed outside the Y.M.C.A.'s William Sloane House yesterday to show their support for workers who are trying to organize a union at the residence hall.
LOS ANGELES, March 12-- The most unexpected Democratic candidate for public office this year is counting on national Republican support--to get him out of the way.
NYACK, N. Y., March 12-- Voters in 10 of Rockland County's 12 villages will go to the polls in local elections Tuesday, but a change in partisan control is possible in only three communities.

Miss Virginia (Ginger) Powell, representing the New Haven (Conn.) Skating Club, and Miss Louise Marie Vacca of Lindenhurst, L.I., a member of the Rye (N.Y.) Figure Skating Club, took top honors in the Middle Atlantic figure-skating championships on the Iceland Rink in Madison Square Garden last night.

MIAMI--Three years ago, the City of Mia mi built the $2-million Marine Stadium on the Rickenbacker Causeway to provide tourists and residents with a bay-front seat for speed-boat races, waterski shows and other aquatic diversions.
SAIGON, March 12--Buddhist leaders, taking advantage of tension within South Vietnam's military junta, criticized the Government today and demanded the election of civilian leaders.

A collection of art since 1895 --arranged in 10 galleries here --will form an exhibition benefiting the Public Education Association. The multiple show will have a champagne preview April 26, and will be open to the public April 27 through May 21.

HONG KONG--Ask a well-versed tourist to name a place that ranks high among the world's leading supermarkets, and he will probably answer, without giving his A. P. a thought, "Hong Kong." And this summer, the largest pier market in Asia will be opened here.

PLAINVIEW, L. I., March 12--Secondary schools in the Plainview-Old Bethpage School District in Nassau County, which have been closed since last Monday by a teachers' strike, will be reopened next week, it was announced today.
PARIS, March 12--Victor Brauner, the surrealist painter, died of cancer here last night at the age of 62.
The increasing popularity of sail in the world of boating will be underscored here again this week with the staging of New York's first boat show devoted entirely to sailboats.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP)--The nation's airports were 11 per cent busier last year than in 1964, and the busiest one of all was Chicago's O'Hare International, the Federal Aviation Agency said this week.
Staphylococci, the troublesome germs that defy all conventional means of treatment, are being turned loose on themselves by a Long Island physician.
NORTH PELHAM, N.Y., March 12--George E. Burrows, police chief here since 1949, died in the New Rochelle Hospital yesterday. He was 59 years old and lived at 554 Third Avenue here.
TROY, N.Y., March 12 (AP) --Edward A. Wachter, a member of basketball's Hall of Fame in Springfield, Mass., died today in St. Mary's Hospital here. He was 82 years old.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 12--In what could be interpreted as an attempt at immediate appeal to Met fans, the New York Yankees committed seven errors today and lost to the Baltimore Orioles, 8-4.
TUCSON, Ariz., March 12 (AP)--The San Francisco Giants made 20 hits today and routed the Cleveland Indians, 17-8, in the opener of the Cactus League's baseball exhibition season.

Thursday, March 31, is an allimportant day for Americans who are 65 years of age or over. It is the last day on which they can enroll under the voluntary medical insurance program in Medicare without otherwise facing a long delay. If they become ill in the interim they are out of luck.
CHICAGO, March 12--Herbert Levy, a general partner with Payne, Weber, Jackson Curtiss, a stock brokerage firm, died Thursday in suburban Highland Park Hospital at the age of 68.

Recently, a housewife in Ridgewood, N.J., paused in the midst of zealously polishing a credenza that had been delivered just a few minutes before. With dismay, she stared at one of the doors, which had a deep gash. She ran to the door, but the delivery truck was already gone.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., March 12--Dr. and Mrs. Allen Ledyard De Camp have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Cameron De Camp, a Peace Corps volunteer at Cochabamba, Bolivia, to William Ballin Whitman, vice consul of the American Consulate at Cochabamba. His parents are Mrs. William B. Whitman of Evanston, Ill., and the late Mr. Whitman.
CHARLOTTE, N.C., March 12 (AP)--James Edward Dowd, general manager of The Charlotte Observer and former editor of The Charlotte News, died today in a hospital here. He was 66 years old.

ANNAPOLIS, Md.,, March 12 --Yale University, not taking as many first places as usual, still had enough reserve strength to convincingly capture its fourth straight Eastern Seaboard Intercollegiate swimming championship tonight at the United States Naval Academy.
While the economy grows hotter and inflationary pressures become more acute, Washington continues indecisive, at least publicly, about doing anything to cope with a deteriorating situation.
Four model houses are being displayed at a new development called Bridge-Brook Estates, off Joralemon Street near the Garden State Parkway, in Belleville, N.J.

DESCENDANTS of the people who settled in the shallow valley of the Green River founded a small hamlet called Paradise, Ky. It was well-named, for the countryside was green and pleasant and the stream teemed with fish.

GORI, U.S.S.R. -- A vast building of pale pink marble at the head of a once-elegant esplanade leaves the residents of this sleepy Georgian town uncertain whether they must act scornful or can display their civic pride again.

AUSTIN, Tex., March 12-- A. decision by Gov. John B. Connally Jr. not to attend a White House briefing today lends further credence to a report that there has been a rift between Mr. Connally and his political teacher, President Johnson.

AUBURN, Me., March 12-- Mr. and Mrs. Willis A. Trafton Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Dain Trafton, to A. Lowell Edmunds 3d, son of Dr. and Mrs. Arthur L. Edmunds of Franklin, N.H. A June wedding is planned.

The Auxiliary of St. Luke's Hospital plans its seventh annual spring fashion show and luncheon in the Plaza's Grand Ballroom for April 12. Mrs. Theron O. Worth Jr. is chairman of the event, Mrs. Roland W. Donnem vice chairman.

A panel of eight prominent Americans will conduct a public tribunal next Friday at the Carnegie International Center, 46th Street and the United Nations Plaza, to hear a series of eyewitness reports on the condition of Soviet Russia's three million Jews.

SPEAKING of ambushes, no outrider settling the Wild West was ever subject to more of them then the tourist trying to work out his own itinerary around the world with the massive airlines guide on one hand, two sets of calendars on the other and a 24-hour clock before him.

WILTON, Me., March 12-- Miss Susan Elizabeth Shepard and H. Robert Howie Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Howie of St. Paul were married here this afternoon at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Morton William Shepard Jr., former residents of Danbury, Conn. The ceremony was perfromed by the Rev. Roderick Potter, rector of St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Farmington.

The increasing variety of fares introduced by airlines last year resulted in a significant increase in complaints by passengers on refund problems, the Civil Aeronautics Board has noted in its annual report.

IT must now be an accepted but regrettable fact that, with few exceptions, English-Language writ ers on Vietnam have settled down to war reporting, and nothing else. We have been treated to enough military details to provide every magazine reader with at least one or two handy warlike solutions of the Vietnam problem--and some, at that, which are just about as good as those dreamed up by the professionals.

William Epton, a vice chairman of the pro-Chinese Communist Progressive Labor party, remained in the City Penitentiary on Rikers Island yesterday as attempts were con tinued to raise $25,000 bail for his release.
The New York Jets signed Matt Snell to a 1966 contract yesterday.

One of the most active stocks on the New York Stock Exchange recently has been the Collins Radio Corporation. Although it has been on the exchange since 1959, there has been no great amount of activity until the last few weeks. Prices rose from 55 5/8 on Feb. 18 to 70 5/8, up 3/8 on Friday. The range for 1955-66 has been 83 to 19 .

WASHINGTON, March 12-- The New York Stock Exchange has never seemed more lovably human than in its reaction to Mayor Lindsay's plan to raise its taxes. If the Mayor raises those taxes, the exchange says, it may just move out of New York altogether and settle down in some place that really appreciates it. Some place like Hoboken, N.J.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., March 12--Roland F. Elliman, a specialist in Manhattan residential real estate from 1911 through 1953, died here Thursday. He was 77 years old and lived at the Wesbourne Apartments on Alger Court.
"HOW can a woman rule this country?" demanded my 75year-old father as he heard the announcement that Mrs. Gandhi's election as Prime Minister of India was assured.

CAIRO, March 12--West Germany, moving to offset East Germany's plea for membership in the United Nations and its expanding diplomatic contacts in the Middle East, has renewed its bid to reopen relations with the Arab states on the eve of the Arab League meeting here.

THE admonition to "Go west, young man" will be heeded by two distinguished septuagenarians this summer. Roland Hayes, 78-year-old American tenor, and Alexander Kipnis. Ukrainian bass who celebrated his 75th birthday last Feb. 1, will be visiting members of the Aspen Music School faculty for the first time.

WELLSBORO, Pa.-- During the spring run-off period, now at hand and ex tending through May, the prospect of white-water boating and float trips along nearby Pine Creek draws hundreds of canoeists and raft enthusiasts to this area.

PHILADELPHIA, March 12 --A newly formed, nonprofit Quaker corporation disclosed plans today for the construction of a multimillion-dollar suburban retirement community with guaranteed lifetime medical care for about 300 residents.
WASHINGTON, March 12--Thirty-eight state Governors and the Governors of Puerto Rico, Guam and the Virgin Islands unanimously adopted today a resolution endorsing...
NEW DELHI, March 12-- Violent protests by Hindu students against the establishment of a Punjab-speaking state spread today to three more towns in the Punjab.
If European and American critics were asked to name the best book of 1965, they might have some difficulty choosing among the numerous candidates.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 12--About 170,000 students may get grants this year for study outside their own countries under an expansion of study-abroad programs, according to a new United Nations report.

HOLLYWOOD. THOUGH they pride themselves as their independence, most pres ent-day Hollywood filmmakers are nonetheless proficient organization men. To succeed in Hollywood a filmmaker today must work effectively with a wide variety of big organizations --the studios, distributors, talent agencies. There are very few real "loners" around -- men who finance their own pictures, sign their own players and arrange distribution of their films, often through haphazard channels.
An adjunct to the fashion apparel business, closely reflecting its mores, the American cosmetics industry is riding on the crest of a 15-year sales uptrend.

In fiercely competitive professional basketball, known for such giants as Wilt Chamberlain and Bill Russell, perhaps the most effective performance over the years has been turned in by a short, stocky, baldish man with a fondness for lighting a big cigar before the game is even over.
BURLINGTON, Vt., March 12--Massachusetts dethroned Rhode Island as Yankee Conference indoor track champion today.

RALEIGH, N.C., March 12-- Duke almost let a big early advantage over Syracuse slip out of its hands before rallying to defeat the Orange, 91-81, in the final of the Eastern Regional of the National Collegiate basketball tournament tonight.

WEST HARTFORD, March 12--Miss Mary Creswell Beane, daughter of Mrs. Louis B. Stoner of West Hartford and Alpheus C. Beane of New York, was married today to Oliver Field Jones, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic E. Jones of Farmington. The Rev. Charles W. Wilding performed the Episcopal service at the Stoner home.
WARSAW, March 12 (AP)-- Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski called on Poles today to pray for a visit by Pope Paul VI.

"IT all began seven years ago in the Yale Club in New York when Sir Geoffrey Crowther asked me if I would be interested in editing a collected edition of Walter Bagehot's works. He had long had the enterprise in mind: only an editor was lacking."

Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Lothringer of 345 East 56th Street and Westhampton Beach, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eve Anne Lothringer, to George Michael Dieringer, son of Mrs. Mildred Dieringer of Lawrence L.I., and the later George L. Dieringer.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 12--The New York Mets, who had never before won an opening game--in regular sesson, exhibition season, you-name-it season--won one today.

TRAVELERS, the Civil Aeronautics Board and travel agents, all of whom had been hoping that the International Air Transport Association would approve a cut soon in Pacific fares, may have to wait until next winter for a decision.

An all-out effort to develop a vaccine against the virus disease rubella is being made by Government, industry and university scientists, the director of one of the National Institutes of Health said here yesterday.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., March 12--A June wedding is planned by Miss Margaret Anne Gilbreth: Her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Daniel B. Gilbreth of Upper Montclair and Nantucket, Mass., have announced her engagement to Henry Carmack Nipper. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Lee Nipper of Jacksonville, Fla.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., March 12 (AP)--City leaders issued a public appeal for qualified Negro applicants for the Birmingham police force.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 12--The redwood timber industry mounted an offensive this week against a proposed national redwood park.

WASHINGTON, March 12--In the course of one day, which was yesterday, Congress and its committees sanctioned appropriations of $13billions of existing and prospective revenues of the Federal Government to support the mounting of the war in Vietnam. And it entered on the final stages of restoring another $6-billions in taxes that only recently were canceled.

LONDON, March 12--Sir Sydney Camm, the airplane designer who gave the Royal Air Force the Hurricane fighter of World War II fame, the Hunter fighter and other warplanes, collapsed and died today on the Richmond golf course, on the outskirts of London. He was 72 years old.
AUBURN, N.Y., March 12 (AP)--Kennard Underwood, banker and former Cayuga County judge, died last night in the Auburn Memorial Hospital. He was 79 years old.

BOSTON, March 12--Clarkson College's hockey team established its right to the East's No. 1 rating tonight by routing Cornell, 6-2, to capture the Eastern Collegiate Athletic Conference tournament championship at the Boston Arena.
Defense industries are expected to generate at least 10,000 new jobs this year in Minnesota.
The decision to have George Chuvalo meet Cassius Clay for the heavyweight championship of the world was made at the very highest levels of government, according to usually unreliable sources.
A Waterfront Commissioner last week accused Theodore W. Kheel of bias in the current debate on legislation to change the ground rules of the agency's policing job in the port.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, March 12--Lieut. Gen. Suharto, Indonesia's new military leader, moved quickly today to utilize powers bestowed on him by President Sukarno.
LONDON, March 12 (UPI) --Communist Chinese weightlifters bettered three listed world records at a competition in Peking, the Hsinhua, official Chinese press agency, said today.
Japan is the leading builder and operator of merchant ships excelling, 100,000 deadweight tons, the Maritime Administration reported last week.
The Carnegie Corporation of New York announced yesterday a $300,000 grant to improve Negro higher education in the South.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., March 12 --Miss Joan Fox Paxton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Keith Paxton of Essex Fells, was married this afternoon to Henry Edison Bliss, son of Mr. and Mrs. George O. Bliss of Wilmette, Ill.
LAKELAND, Fla., March l2--"Have you checked everything" asked Charley Dressen, letting just a trace of anxiety creep into his normally confident voice.

WORCESTER, Mass., March 12--Mr. and Mrs. Robert Samuel Horner have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Hart Horner, to Peter Baldwin Schwab, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Baldwin de Villiers Schwab Jr., of Schenectady, N.Y. A June wedding is planned.
The boating industry has begun a talent search for "high-level vocational students" to fill its widely varied job needs.

President Sukarno's attempt to reverse the antiCommunist, anti-Chinese tide in Indonesia appears to have failed. The army leaders are back in control after a three-week inter-regnum, and there is every outward evidence that they have vastly more popular support than Sukarno was able to muster.
ATLANTA, March 11-- Howard H. Zehr Jr., one of two full-time white students at Atlanta's predominantly Negro Morehouse College, has a secure future for the next four years.
NAIROBI, Kenya, March 10 --Somalia has become the focus for Soviet military assistance and instruction in East Africa, and is a source of mounting anxiety to the Ethiopian and Kenyan Governments.
Antonia Lavanne, a soprano who has performed in several concerts of contemporary music since her debut here in 1962, sang her second New York recital late yesterday afternoon in Town Hall.

KANSAS CITY, March 12 (UPI)--Al Tucker scored 41 points tonight and led Oklahoma Baptist University to an easy 88-59 victory over Georgia Southern for the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics basketball championship.

GEORGETOWN, British Guiana--On the eve of its independence, British Guiana is mak ng a strong bid to attract tourists. Virtually ignored until now because of its relative remoteness, in addition to a series of political crises, this scenic country has much to interest the traveler.
Miss Jean Herskovits and Armand Lindenbaum plan to marry in June.

MONTE CARLO, Monaco--The dominant sound here these days is not the click of dice or of a white ball bouncing from slot to slot on one of the roulette tables at the famous Casino. Even the roar of the sports cars--another Monegasque phenomenon--is all but obliterated by the staccato beat of jackhammers and rivet guns.

PORTLAND, Ore., March 12 --A bitter Democratic senatorial primary fight began taking shape this weekend with the prospect of bringing Senator Wayne Morse, Oregon Democrat, home to attack Administration Vietnam policies in speeches all over Oregon.

MAAN, Jordan, March 12 (Reuters) -- Searchers combed the ruins of this flood-ravaged city tonight for 150 people known to be still missing following sudden torrential rains that made 3,000 homeless and killed at least 70.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, Sunday, March 13 (UPI)--A strong 90-second earthquake hit the sleeping capital of Nationalist China early today. At least 11 persons were hurt when two buildings toppled in Taipei.
WASHINGTON, March 12-- President Johnson sent to Congress this week a green-covered report on a subject destined to occupy more of his attention in the months ahead: manpower.
The Metropolitan Opera Ballet will give the world premiere of Antony Tudor's "Concerning Oracles" in a special ballet evening on Sunday, March 27.

CHAPPAQUA, N.Y., March 12--In the First Congregational Church of Chappaqua this morning, Mrs. Jeannette Rule Hodgson, widow of Henry Hoyle Hodgson, was married to Theodore Foucar Eberle. The Rev. Dr. Edwin D. McLane performed the ceremony.

The Concert Artists Guild will give its annual benefit dinner concert on April 27 at the Pierre's Grand Ballroom. David Sarnoff of the Radio Corporation of America will be honored for his "vision which established and broadened the means for conveying music to millions."

The snarl of red tape that has separated prospective and qualified buyers from actual ownership of brownstone dwell ings in a city-sponsored rehabilitation program in the West Side Urban Renewal Area may be cut this spring. Rehabilitation of existing residential buildings is a key element in the renewal effort.

SAIGON, Sunday, March 13 --Three barges laden with about 350 tons of ammunition exploded and sank early yesterday in the Saigon River, two miles north of the capital. No one was aboard, and there were no casualties.

The Rev. Hilary G. Jakowski, assistant spiritual director ford the Catholic Foreign Mission Society of America at Maryknoll (N.Y.) Seminary, died on Friday in Roosevelt Hospital after open-heart surgery. His age was 55.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., March 12--V. S. Pritchett, British author and critic, will be writer-in-residence at Smith College for the 1966-67 academic year. He will succeed James Farl Powers, who is serving this year as the college's first writer-in-residence.
OLD FIELD, L.I., March 12 --A marshy, 146-acre tract here on Long Island Sound has been acquired by the State University as the core of a research center for marine sciences.

The metropolitan area's action-loving sports fan will be able to swing into a gallop tomorrow. The cry at Aqueduct will be "It is now post time," and some 40,000 customers are expected to be on hand for the first race at 1:30 P.M.

The audacious proposition that any one book can describe the growth (or dimunition) of freedom from 1800 until the present, with even a glimpse into the future, would surely daunt most historians. But not Prof. Herbert J. Muller, author of "The Loom of History" and "The Uses of the Past," who already has chronicled the history of freedom in both the ancient and modern worlds.
"Someone please get me my milk," yelled a fidgety Wilt Chamberlain, slumped next to his locker yesterday amid the turmoil of the Philadelphia 76er dressing room at Madison Square Garden.
NEW DELHI, March 13--A 15-year-old boy was killed today when the police in Amritsar opened fire on crowds demonstrating against a Punjabispeaking state.

ST. LOUIS, March 13 (AP) Lee Meriwether, the city's much-traveled centenarian, who was a lawyer and an author, died last night at the age of 103. He was recovering from a hip fracture suffered March 5 in a fall at his home, when he was stricken, apparently by a heart attack.

Revenues of the Columbia Broadcasting System are expected to continue to grow and the company should have improved profits this year, William S. Paley, chairman, said in the company's annual report issued over the wekend.
Charles H. Goody, a realestate operator who was active in civic work and philanthropies, died at Manhattan General Hospital Saturday. He was 75 years old and lived at 268 Montgomery Street, Brooklyn.

HATO REY, P.R., March 13--Puerto Rico's Secretary of Labor has expressed concern that 27,000 jobs here would be endangered by the hourly minimum wage bill reportedly agreed on last Thursday by the Johnson Administration and Congressional Democrats.
WASHINGTON, March 13 (UPI) Ralph Nader, the critic of the automobile industry's traffic standards, will testify Wednesday on President Johnson's traffic safety legislation.
Aeschylus's trilogy, "The Oresteia," as adapted by Robert Lowell, Pulitzer Prize-winning poet, is under consideration for production next season by the Lincoln Center Repertory Company.

Mrs. Vicky Hilzenrath Brody of 2 Fifth Avenue, wife of Leonard Brody, former vice president and treasurer of Hudson National, Inc., a dealer in vitamins, died yesterday in Beth Israel Hospital, after a short illness. She was 58 years old.
The bond market will receive a severe test this week, with more than $1-billion of securities expected to be offered for sale, one of the largest weekly totals on records.:

Following is a weekly listing of unaudited net asset value of closed-end investment fund shares, as reported by the companies through the Association of Closed-End Investment Companies at the close of business Friday.

The sound of Leopold Stokowski's American Symphony Orchestra is always something to marvel at. Even with considerable change in personnel each year, Mr. Stokowski's relatively young group plays with warmth, responsiveness and freshness.
On Broadway there are two kinds of auditions. The first is for discovering talent. The second is for raising money.
FAIRLAWN, N.J. March 13 Maxwell Golburgh, a real-estate broker here, died today in St. Joseph's Hospital, Paterson.
Last October a New York art dealer set a world auction record for a painting by Cezanne when he paid $800,000 for a landscape entitled "Houses in Provence" on behalf of an anonymous buyer.

A proxy fight for the control of the management of the Studebaker Corporation at the company's annual meeting on April 28 seems almost certain, according to sources close to the present Studebaker management.

SAIGON, March 13 (Reuters) General Thi today dismissed reports that he had flown north to rally support in his former command zone. He said he could not discuss his plans, which have been a subject of constant speculation since Thursday.

LIFE, in J.P. Donleavy's fictional vision, is a gigantic breast, and the struggle of life is to get at it. There are some fortunates who succeed "those are the grabbers at life's banquet" and some unfortunates, Mr. Donleavy's protagonists, who don't. "I'm elbowed to crawling around under the table scooping up the crumbs," Samuel S ruefully laments.
Fred H. Hill has purchased the five-story mansion at 7 East 96th Street, just off Fifth Avenue.
John J. Gilhooley, a member of the Transit Authority, said yesterday that a 5-cent rise in the 15-cent fare was inevitable next year.

The misty figure of "poor old Ireland" evoked each St. Patrick's Day by Irish-American folk memories has become about as authentic as an Englishman's brogue. Kathleen Mavourneen has vanished down the old bog road and the road has been paved.
LIKE just about all the 1.5million American couples who were married in 1962, Ellen Moss and Stanley Poler wanted a house of their own within sharply defined limits of budget.
PARIS, March 13 The French challenge to NATO appears to have been an intensely personal act by President de Gaulle. There was an aura of Louis XIV about his action ...

PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 13 George E. Adams, first graduate of Rhode Island State College, now the University of Rhode Island, and first dean of the university's College of Agriculture, died yesterday at his home on the campus in Kingston. He was 91 years old.

PARIS, March 13 Forty-six more paintings by Claude Monet that were in his house at Giverny in the valley of the Seine have been left to the small museum here that last week inherited an extraordinary collection of 92 oils, watercolors and gouaches.

WASHINGTON, March 13 A spokesman for national food store chains termed "restrictive and retrogressive" today the broad recommendations for regulation of the food industry made recently by the staff of the National Commission on Food Marketing.

MIAMI, March 13 Premier Fidel Castro denounced Communist China tonight in terms more vehement than he has used thus far. He charged that Peking had mounted a campaign against Cuba inspired by "fascist methods and those of Goebel."
WASHINGTON, March 13 Vice President Humphrey said today that the United States' policy on China should be one of "containment without necessarily isolation."
MUNICH, Germany, March 13 (UPI) West Germany's newest neo-Nazi political party made some gain in municipal elections in Bavaria today, compared with last year.
Philip Sherberne, president of the National Student Association, plans to leave on a factfinding trip to South Vietnam next week that will include conferences with student leaders in that country.
BRUSSELS, March 13 In a joint venture which they say marks a first for the American steel industry, two companies with complementary talents have built a steel mill in eastern Belgium.
Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes said yesterday a lower Manhattan expressway was essential to move traffic more freely between the Holland Tunnel and the Manhattan and Williamsburg Bridges.
THERE are straws in the wind to indicate an encouraging pattern in the vicinity of the Lincoln Center for the Per forming Arts, which is relatively impoverished in the gastronomic sense.

Tenants living in three buildings in which Robert Hecht, the father-in-law of Buildings Commissioner Charles Moerdler, has an interest complained yesterday of lack of heat and hot water, dirty conditions, broken windows and rats.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., March 13 (AP) Ben Fenn of Flushing, Queens, won all five events in the senior men's division of the Diamond international indoor speed skating championships today and easily defeated his nearest rival, Dave Lisi of Rochester by 15 points.

PLAINVIEW, L.I., March 13 The Plainview Federation of Teachers and Dr. Robert F. Savitt, Superintendent of Schools for the Plainview-Old Bethpage district, announced this evening that the strike of teachers here had been called off.

OSLO, Norway, March 13 (Reuters) Bjoern Wirkola of Norway, the winner of the two jumping competitions in this year's World Nordic ski championsips, set an unofficial world record today with a jump of 146 meters (479 feet) on the Vikersund Hill near Drammen, south of Oslo.
WASHINGTON, March 13 A three-judge Federal court has ruled in unequivocal terms that state laws aimed at curbing or harassing the sale of imported meat are unconstitutional.
CAIRO, March 13 (Reuters) Jan-Erik Lundquist of Sweden won the men's singles title in the United Arab Republic international lawn tennis tournament today.

DANANG, South Vietnam, March 13 Most of the shops in this seacoast garrison town closed for a half day today in protest against the dismissal of Lieut. Gen. Nguyen Chanh Thi as commander of the army's I Corps area.

The Lindsay City Hall team, with the Mayor himself playing right end, met newsmen in touch football in Central Park yesterday and, again, the administration and the newsmen were unable to agree upon what happened:

ROSLYN ESTATES, L.I., March 13 Miss Anne Elise Kemper, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kosciusko Kemper 3d, was married today to Michael Edward Howard Bernhardt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Bernhardt of Brooklyn.
SAIGON, Monday, March 14 A firing squad of 10 military policemen executed a wealthy South Vietnamese businessman before dawn today in the central marketplace.

ROME, March 13 Pope Paul VI, in what was considered a reference to President de Gaulle's recent moves against the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, said today he was praying that "the spirit of concord may reign among men."
ROCKINGHAM, N.C., March 13 (AP) Paul Goldsmith, a lean Midwesterner driving a year-old Plymouth, won the Peach Blossom 500-mile stockcar race today.

DUBLIN, March 13 (UPI) An Irish Army demolition squad blasted the remains of the Lord Nelson monument into dust today. Thousands of Dublin onlookers roared their approval by singing an independence song, "A nation once again."
The Federal Revenue man may project an almost friedly image to at least one group of taxpayers those over age 64 for the Government has made a special effort to ease their burden.
Three families who were moved out of their slum dwellings during a cold wave six weeks ago and into the Astor Hotel at city expense are scheduled to leave the hotel today and tomorrow.
Marilyn Aschner, an 18-yearold Queens College student with a big forehand, is the new Eastern women's indoor tennis champion.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector) March 13 Edward J. Levy, the 26-year-old American who was released Thursday after almost two years in a Syrian cell, may return to the United States in a few days.
PHILADELPHIA, March 13 Stanton Hales, a graduate student at Harvard, won the Middle Atlantic badminton title today by defeating the defending champion, Dick Gorman, in the final, 15-3, 15-7.

SAIPAN, Mariana Islands, March 13 By courtesy of the Central Intelligence Agency, a start has been made in erasing the "Quonset image" of the American administration of the Trust Territory of the Pacific Islands.

A Queens Councilman said yesterday that the Lindsay administration had reached basic agreement with the CBS television network on a request by CBS to make available secret police files for a television crime series.
LOS ANGELES, March 13 (UPI) Britain's Prince Philip visited briefly today with former President Eisenhower in the Palm Springs area, then flew here on his tour of the United States.

FRANCONIA, N.H., March 13 Johnny Clough, the former Middlebury College captain and present assistant ski coach at Dartmouth, completed an impressive sweep of the North American Alpine championships today.

A nation striving to eliminate poverty cannot ignore the plight of the working poor--men and women whose full-time earnings are too low to bring them and their families above the subsistence threshold. The Federal Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 is a principal instrument for lifting the living standards of workers at the bottom of the income scale and also for protecting responsible employers against sweatshop competition.
BRUSSELS, March 13 (AP) The Liberal party agreed today to form a coalition government with the Social Christians, bringing a month-long political stalemate close to solution.
The retail price of seven brands of cigarettes is expected to go up a penny a pack today and price increases probably will follow for all major brands.
SAIGON, March 13 A South Vietnamese political "crisis" is always complex, and the one that began last Thursday is no exception.

Once again everyone concerned with the Vietnamese war has to face the unhappy truth that Saigon governments are unstable. If Premier Ky surmounts the political crisis that has come out of the dismissal of General Thi from the ten-man directorate, it would still be a fact that Marshal Ky will have a delicately balanced, precarious government without an ascertainable popular basis.
A leading civic group has urged Mayor Lindsay to keep the primary responsibility for planning the reconstruction of the city in the hands of the City Planning Commission.
The chairman of the City Commission on Human Rights said yesterday that policemen who were members of the John Birch Society should not be assigned to police civil rights demonstrations.
The Chemical Fund, Inc., announced over the weekend the election of Robert C. Perez, 39 years old, as a vice president.
