THE National Collegiate basketball tournament moved along in close to predicted fashion over the weekend as the field was narrowed to Kentucky, rated No. 1 in the nation; Duke, rated No. 2, Utah and Texas Western.
BOSTON, March 13 (AP) The Boston Celtics kept alive their hopes for a 10th straight Eastern Division title in the National Basketball Association today by crushing the Baltimore Bullets, 129-98.
Newspaper publishers continued over the weekend to join forces in opposition to a $10-a-ton increase in newsprint prices.
The first ship built in Britain for Rumania since 1935 was launched last week in the shipyard of Sir James Laing Sons, Ltd.

CASABLANCA, Morocco, March 13 West German President Heinrich Lubke said here today that Bonn "does not want to compete with France" in granting economic aid to countries like Morocco. Dr. Lubke is on a private visit as a guest of King Hassan II.
Representatives of about 30 Spanish-speaking groups formed a preliminary citywide HispanoAmerican Committee yesterday to convey grievances and community development proposals to City Hall.

Ashton Dunn, senior vice president of the William H. Clark Associates, a New York business-executive recruiting agency, died yesterday at the Neurological Institute of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 59 years old and lived at 157 East 72d Street.
The Women's Division of the American Jewish Congress will present its annual Louise Waterman Wise Distinguished Service Awards at a luncheon on March 28 in the Plaza's Grand Ballroom.

With the air-conditioning out of order, the temperature in the crowded auction room of the Parke-Bernet Galleries on Saturday night was a trifle high. But it was one occasion in which an onlooker could fan himself without fearing that the gesture would be interpreted as a bid.
PARIS, March 13 The American economic miracle suddenly looks less miraculous to many European authorities.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 13 (AP) Frank Bolling and Ron Fairley the player representatives of the Atlanta Braves and the Los Angeles Dodgers, respectively indicated today that their teams might oppose the nomination of Marvin J. Miller as the executive director of the Players' Association.

SINGAPORE, March 13 While the position is still not clear in Jakarta, it seems apparent in a review of the events of the last few days that the army commander, Lieutenant General Suharto, and Gen. Abdul Haris Nasution, the former Defense Minister, have persuaded Presi dent Sukarno to give the army a free hand.
Harvey Rothenberg's nemesis is bright red with gold lettering and it rests on the desk in front of him most of the day.
WASHINGTON, March 13 The Soviet Union has made unusually frank disclosures of failures encountered by its Venus 2 and Venus 3 spacecraft.

The color television program on which Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson guided viewers around Washington and campaigned for a more beautiful America will be repeated from 4 to 5 P.M. April 10, Easter Sunday, by the American Broadcasting Company network. It was first televised last Thanksgiving.
Joan Baez returned to New York Sunday afternoon after an absence of more than a year and a half and was greeted by an enthusiastic audience that filled Philharmonic Hall to capacity.

VENICE, Calif., March 10 Every evening a group of painters, poets and beatniks collects in front of a boarded-up cafe on a beachfront street here. Huddled together in the chill darkness, the group argues about art and politics, munches on fruit and cake donated by passersby, and keeps a vigil.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 13 A major cricket match that had been rained out would stir more excitement in South Africa than the current election campaign, which is nearing its halfway mark.
To those who live with history, the glories of yesterday are the ashes of today. Inexorable change inevitable and inescapable dooms in time all human institutions.
Miss Gail Myra Hirschorn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David L. Hirschorn of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to Robert Mayer Evans. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Emanuel J. Evans of Durham, N.C.

WHITE PLAINS, March 13 Ch. Top Brass of Gladgay, the best of all breeds at Providence's golden anniversary show yesterday, had to be content to be merely the best miniature poodle today at the 26th Saw Mill River Kennel Club show.
BALTIMORE, March 13 (AP) Keith Molesworth, director of player personnel for the Baltimore Colts professional football team, died of a heart attack in his home yesterday. He was 60 years old.
CARACAS, Venezuela, March 13 (UP) Kathy Whitworth of San Antonio, Tex., carded a four-under-par 71 today and won her second consecutive Lagunitas women's golf tournament with a 144 for 36 holes.
The American Merchant Marine Institute, the largest of the nation's shipowners associations, made public yesterday its recommendations for a new national maritime policy.

McLEAN, Va., March 13 Mr. and Mrs. David Norton Yerkes have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Catharine Martindale Yerkes, to Ira Joel Frantzman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Frantzman of New York and Larchmont, N.Y. The wedding is planned for May.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., March 13 Odell S. Hathaway, a former president of the Outdoor Advertising Association of America, died yesterday of a heart attack in Daytona Beach, Fla., where he was vacationing. He was 64 years old.

ALBANY, March 13 Members of the commission appointed by the Court of Appeals to redraw the state's legislative district lines spent the weekend piecing together the last remaining controversial districts.
TORONTO, March 13 Three months ago, forecasters predicted that economic growth in Canada would relax this year to 6 to 7 per cent from the feverish 9 per cent rates of 1964 and 1965.
CHICAGO, March 13 (AP) Bobby Hull scored his 52d goal of the season tonight as the Chicago Black Hawks gained a 5-1 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs in a National Hockey League game.

Proposals to outlaw "shackle and hoist" methods employed in the Jewish ritual slaughter of steers, calves and lambs in New York State were hotly debated yesterday at a meeting of Friends of Animals, Inc.

Col. John Reynolds, U.S.A., retired, a founding partner of Reynolds, Wolcott Flack, lawyers of 36 West 44th Street, died yesterday in the Veterans Administration Hospital at First Avenue and 24th Street. He was 82 years old.

Mayor Lindsay, the police and a nucleus of Times Square businessmen deserve every encouragement in their resolve to clean up the neighborhood. Once the center of elegant hotels, fine restaurants and all that is glamorous and exciting about the theater, the Times Square area has become pockmarked with all-night movies, honkytonks and pornographic book venders and is a gathering place for panhandlers, alcoholics and perverts.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, March 13 (Reuters) Harold Henning of South Africa won the Malayan open golf championship at the Royal Selangor Club here today.
Marietta (Ohio) College defeated Agnes Scott College of Decatur, Ga., by 230 to 115 yesterday on the "College Bowl" program over the National Broadcasting Company television network.
OTTAWA, March 13 Leader of opposition parties today planned their strategy for using an alleged security case to bring down the Liberal Government.

CAIRO, March 13 President Gamal Abdel Nasser's efforts to organize an anti-Western conference of African-Asian leaders in Cairo later this month have run into too many obstacles and the meeting will not be held, usually well-informed Egyptian circles disclosed today.
NORTH SALEM, N.Y., March 13 San Miguel, a reformed hunter, made a sweep of three classes to win the open jumper championship at the Salem View Farms horse show today.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), March 13 An Israeli expert on nuclear affairs cautioned the nation today against concentrating on the United States in seeking financial assistance for construction of a nuclear desalting plant.

Robert M. Schuchman, the first national chairman of Young Americans for Freedom, a conservative youth organization, died Friday of a cerebral hemorrhage in the Albert Merritt Billings Hospital of the University of Chicago. His age was 27.
LONDON, March 13 (Reuters) Prime Minister Wilson's Labor party appears headed for a strong victory in the March 31 elections, according to Gallup Poll results published today.
RIO DE JANEIRO Persistent price increases are tormenting the Brazilian public and eroding confidence in the Government's anti-inflation program.
TAMPA, Fla., March 13 Dr. William L. Prager, former head of the chemistry department at City College of New York and a specialist in biochemistry, died here yesterday. He was 84 years old.
The waterfront industry has appealed to the Governors of New York and New Jersey to support legislation tightening control over the size of the longshore work force in the Port of New York.
Jim O'Connell of City College won the fifth annual Bob Preston Memorial five-mile run around Yankee Stadium yesterday.

Exactly six and a half years ago today Sept. 14, 1959 the new Aqueduct race track opened for the first time, to a crowd of 42,473 customers. The attendance was a highly satisfactory one, but there were some observers who attributed the turnout only to the carnival aspect of something new. They were uncertain that such a vast plant constructed at a cost of $33million, could become a financially solvent operation.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 13 The New York Mets made their first television appearance of the season today and showed the folks back home what all the fuss had been about 24 hours earlier.
William A. Bartel has resigned as chairmen of West, Weir Bartel, Inc., and will leave the agency next month to join its biggest client the Celanese Corporation of America.
American scientists are engaged in a search that is probably the largest ever conducted for one of the smallest things that afflicts mankind.
NEW ORLEANS, March 13 (UPI) About 400 of the city's 4,000 public school teachers voted tonight to continue indefinitely a collective-bargaining strike they started Friday.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 13 From the evidence in the corridors and meeting rooms here, it is scarcely apparent that in the last nine months governments have been toppled in seven African nations.

THE program offered yesterday afternoon at the Kaufmann Hall of the 92d Street Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association was described, by the new organization presenting it, ChoreoConcerts, as "a cross-section of contemporary choreography." You can, if you have the breath left, say that again.

MIDLAND, Tex., March 13 The principal executives of major oil companies are coming to the rich Permian basin region of west Texas on Tuesday for a celebration, and for their annual appearance before the Texas Railroad Commission.
ST. LOUIS, March 13 (AP) The St. Louis Hawks, fighting for a playoff berth in the Western Division, rallied for a 115106 National Basketball Association victory over the Cincinnati Royals today.
DETROIT, March 13 (UPI) Rabbi Morris Adler, a nationally known Jewish leader who was assassinated before his congregation, was buried today.
A quiet, almost gentlemanly struggle is being waged in Albany for direction of the nearly $4-billion in state retirement funds. Political power, reaching into every corner of ...

Unbeaten Rice High School, led by Bob Lienhard's 25 points and Lou LaSalle's 22, rallied yesterday to beat Power Memorial, 68-58, and capture the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association basketball championship.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 13 The Lebanese Government, moving against banned political parties, arrested yesterday six of their leaders and two owners of printing presses charged with issuing their propaganda.

LJUBLJANA, Yugoslavia, March 13 (AP) Vyachelsav Starshinov scored three goals in the first period today as the Soviet Union defeated Czechoslovakia, 7-1, for its fourth straight world hockey championship.
Dance competition in three divisions and a series of exhitions by new champions brought the 44th annual Middle Atlantic figure-skating championships to a close yesterday.
A TAIL-ENDER'S unexpected and prolonged re sistance almost upset the form during the last hour of the recent Hastings International Tournament in England.
To the roars of "Hail, Cesare," the 1965-1966 National Hockey League season became the might-have-been for the New York Rangers last night.
SAIGON, March 13 A third day passed without major ground fighting in South Vietnam today, and bad weather continued to hamper air strikes in the North.
WASHINGTON, March 13 The nation's railroad unions strongly attacked the Johnson Administration's wage-price guideposts today and claimed an exemption from their application.

WILLIAM MOONEY'S oneman show, "Half Horse, Half Alligator," which opened at the Players Theater in Greenwich Village last night, had what must rank as one of the oddest out-of-town tryouts of any show now on or off Broadway.
Secretary of State Dean Rusk was urged yesterday by the American Jewish Congress to repudiate what was termed the "ugly practice" of excluding Jews from diplomatic posts in Arab countries.
Directors of the Advertising Research Foundation have elected Sherwood Dodge, a vice president of Young Rubican, Inc., to succeed Alcuin W. Lehman as president.

UNDER MILK WOOD," which Dylan Thomas wrote for radio, filled the television screen with poetry last night on Channel 13. The American Conservatory Theater wisely emphasized that the work remains, as the poet himself termed it, a play for voices.
Students at Union Theological Seminary are organizing a depositors' boycott against the First National City Bank to try to force the bank to close its three branches in South Africa.
LOUISVILLE, March 13 As the final session of the Open Pair championship began here tonight, Oswald and James Jacoby of Dallas were leading the field of 242 pairs with 475 points.
Twelve hundred teenage girls filled the Fordham University gymnasium with cheers in the Catholic Youth Organization's 11th annual cheerleading contest yesterday.

Great Banking Houses "The Merchant Bankers," by Joseph Wechsberg, will be published by Little, Brown on May 26. The book reports on banking activities of the Hambros, the Barings, S.G. Warburg, Lehman Brothers, the Rothschilds, Herman Josef Abs and Raffaele Mattioli.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, March 13 The Indo nesian masses first heard the voice of Lieutenant General Suharto on the night of Oct. 1, 1965. The general, with elite troops in his Strategic Reserve Command, had just captured the Government radio station from rebel forces ...

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Monday, March 14 (Reuters) Foreign Minister Subandrio, a chief target of anti-Communist student demonstrations that led to the power change here, and his associate, Third Deputy Premier Chairul Saleh, are being held by the army at Bogor, student sources said today.
DETROIT, March 13--The automobile industry's 1967 models will reflect the growing enchantment with a highly successful styling concept vaguely described as "sporty."
WASHINGTON, March 13 Industry representatives and patent lawyers will attend meetings in Washington and New York this week to discuss a proposed world patent index.
The appointment of Capt. Charles C. Wright as master of the 14,812-ton Matson Lines passenger vessel Mariposa has been announced effective April 17.
It may have been too earlyfor St. Patrick's Day and too chilly for St. Patrick's Day but it certainly felt like St. Patrick's Day in a number of towns yesterday afternoon.
WASHINGTON, March 13 President Johnson's effort to hold down domestic spending to free funds for defense needs faces an increasingly hostile Congress.

MIAMI, March 13 Phil Rodgers used a long-shafted putter and a novel putting grip to win the $100,000 Doral open golf tournament today. His unusual procedure was highly effective, for he closed with a 70 for a 72-hole aggregate of 278 and beat Kermit Zarley and Jay Dolan by one stroke.

WASHINGTON, March 13 Mr. and Mrs. Adolph John Pessel have announced the engagement of Mrs. Pessel's daughter, Miss Ardra Hall Johnston, to Kaj Ingemar Sundberg. He is the son of the late Dr. and Mrs. Karl Filip Sundberg of Uppsala, Sweden. The wedding is planned for March 26 in St. Mary's Chapel of the Episcopal Cathedral of SS. Peter and Paul.
PITTSBURGH, March 13 A new market balance seemed to be steering steel mills toward new records last week without disrupting supply.

WASHINGTON, March 13 The concept of a North Atlantic alliance based on a Big Three core consisting of the United States, Britain and West Germany is beginning to receive serious consideration in high Administration circles.

ACCRA, Ghana, March 13 With unconcealed relish, Lieut. Gen. Joseph A. Ankrah asserted today that Kwame Nkrumah had trained Guinean exiles to overthrow Sekou Toure, the very man who has granted him asylum.

WASHINGTON, March 13 Negroes who pioneered school integration in many areas of the South stand to be penalized by new desegregation guidelines that were issued last week by the Office of Education, civil rights leaders are saying.
ROYAL BOX, Americana Hotel, Seventh Avenue and 52d Street. Ella Fitzgerald, singer.

IT was mutual admiration day Friday at Macy's as a small group of socially prominent women held pale blue deckle-edged programs and watched the store's collection of European couture imports and the linefor-line copies.
Three children died in a tenement fire in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn yesterday, while their shrieking mother sought in vain to save them.
OXFORD, Miss., March 13 (AP) A group of professors at the University of Mississippi said today they would make a Federal Court attack on a 12year-old segregation strategy law.

BALBOA, C.Z., March 13 The Panama Canal is considering fresh approaches to recruit channel pilot trainees in case the Vietnam situation exhausts the normal supply from the United States merchant marine.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, March 13 (Reuters) Nationalist China charged France today with having broken international law by evicting the staff from the former Nationalist embassy in Paris.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 13 Andrew Goodman, president of Bergdorf Goodman Company, and Mrs. Goodman were held at the Beirut airport for more than five hours this morning and then sent to Athens on a Yugoslav plane.
Yale's swimmers, New York University's fencers and Lehigh's wrestlers were in familiar territory Saturday first place.

Although President Johnson's political situation has not seriously deteriorated, he is weaker than he was a year ago. The criticism of his Vietnam policy by the "peace Democrats" in the Senate is the first serious, sustained assault that he has had to withstand since entering the White House.
GENEVA, March 13 Reuters)--The Chief Justice of the United States, Earl Warren, was elected here today chairman of a new World Association of Judges dedicated to the cause of world peace through law.

NAIROBI, Kenya, March 13 Vice President Oginga Odinga formed a radical opposition party tonight only a few hours after President Jomo Kenyatta had driven him from power in the ruling Kenya African National Union.
SYDNEY, Australia, March 13 (Reuters) Capt. Walter M. Schirra Jr. predicted today that the United States would beat Russia in landing a man on the moon and before 1970.

Bernard Lepkopfker of Judo Twins regained the over-all grand championship he held in 1963 and 1964 and the New York Athletic Club successfully defended its team championship yesterday in the fifth annual Metropolitan judo championships at the New York A.C. gym.

Dr. Richard L. White, a surgeon and cancer researcher, died of cancer Saturday in the Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 37 years old and lived at 42 Kenwood Drive in Tenafly, N.J.
CAPE KENNEDY, FLA., March 13 Despite a day-long downpour here, preparations for the launching of the Gemini 8 mission Tuesday morning moved along today without interruption.

The appointment of Mrs. Emma Bowen as executive secretary of the New York City Community Mental Health Board was announced yesterday by Dr. Marvin E. Perkins, City Mental Health Commissioner. The board has responsibility for coordinating, improving and expanding mental health services here.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., March 13 Mr. and Mrs. William Francis Mulhall have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ellen Maureen Mulhall, to Michael Xavier Morrell, son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert X. Morrell of Los Angeles.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 13 The danger in writing about Sunny Jim Fitzsimmons is that everything is likely to come out in superlatives. It can't be avoided, though, because the magic spell this remarkable man was able to weave around all who came in contact with him leaves them powerless to resist the temptation.
MOSCOW, March 13 (UPI) The Soviet merchant marine ranks sixth in the world, Viktor G. Bakayev, Merchant Marine Minister, said today in an interview in the newspaper Krasnaya Zvezda.

BILLINGS, Mont., March 7 Are the "Morning Star People" hungry? Do many of these 2,887 Northern Cheyenne Indians, whose ancestors were brutally hounded by Federal cavalry after the Custer massacre, still live in dire poverty?
A New York minister proposed yesterday that Protestants and Roman Catholics join Jews in observing Saturday instead of Sunday as the Sabbath.
MIAMI, March 13 To hopeful youngsters and marginal players, exhibition games are as memorable as the real thing.

OUT of 1,330,290 Americans who applied for passports last year, 198,310 were under 20 years of age four times as many as a decade ago. The Port of New York Authority stopped counting juvenile heads two years ago, but in 1963 it found that 65,850 youngsters between 2 and 12 departed for foreign points from airports in this area, an increase of 120 per cent in a sevenyear period.
WASHINGTON, March 13 The following is a list of loans and other aid extended last week by United States and other international lending agencies here:

"Marat/Sade," the Royal Shakespeare Company's hit at the Martin Beck Theater, may extend its engagement for the third time. If it can be arranged, the Peter Weiss drama will continue an added two weeks, through April 30.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, March 14 The Indonesian Government today ordered all members of the Indonesian Communist party and organizations affiliated with it to report to their military commanders before the end of the month.

CHICAGO, March 14 Senator J.W. Fulbright called on the nation's universities today to give the United States the intellectual insight to meet the crisis of Asia and to prevent the "calamity of a war with China."
Mayor Lindsay denied yesterday that an increase in the 15-cent subway fare was "inevitable" next year. But he did not guarantee that the fare would not go up.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (UPI) Representative John Bell Williams demanded in effect today that House Democrats oust Harley O. Staggers as chairman of the Commerce Committee next year and put himself in the post.
SAN SALVADOR, March 14 This country's growing Christian Democratic movement scored close to a three-to-one victory in municipal and congressional elections here yesterday.

New-car sales set a nearrecord pace for the first 10 days of March, with each of the Big Three in the industry General Motors, Ford and Chrysler reporting over-all sales gains from the levels last year.

NAIROBI, Kenya, March 14 Tom Mboya, Secretary General of Kenya's ruling political party, the Kenya African National Union, accused the party's major dissidents today of having concealed their role in a new opposition to save their political skins.
George O. Nodyne, president of the East River Savings Bank, was elected president of the Commerce and Industry Association of New York yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (UPI) Speaker John W. McCormack announced today the appointment of the Rev. Ed- ward Gardiner Latch, pastor of the Metropolitan Memorial Methodist Church here, to succeed the late Rev. Bernard Braskamp as Chaplain of the House.

The Park Department is withdrawing all its deposits from the Federation Bank and Trust Company and is placing its two largest accounts $6,946.31 and $4,203.53 in the Freedom National Bank and the Carver Federal Savings and Loan Association, both in Harlem.
SANTA ROSA, Calif., March 14 J. William Terry, a news writer, editor, novelist and lecturer, died here today. He was 75 years old.

WELLESLEY, Mass. March, 14 Dr. Andr e Bruel, emeritus professor of French at Wellesley College, died Thursday at Hollins, Va., where she was a visiting professor at Hollins College. She was 70 years old and a resident here.

HEWLETT BAY PARK, L.I., March 14 Mr. and Mrs. Richard H. Grant have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Leslie Sue Grant, to Samuel Miller Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Smith of Rye, N.Y. The couple plan a September wedding.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 14 Edgar Kaplan of New York and Norman Kay of Philadelphia won the open pair championship at the American Contract Bridge League's spring nationals here last night with a score of 866 points. They also were the winners earlier in they remain in contention in the men's team event, and they remain in contention in the Vanderbilt Cup, which...
Thomas Morgan Prytherch of Old Brookville, L.I., a former vice president and chief executive officer of Wamsutta-Pacific Company, textiles, died Saturday in La Jolla, Calif. He was 64 years old.

QUISQUEYA, Dominican Republic, March 14 Joaquin Balaguer, a small man, stood on a little wooden rostrum next to an ancient church and, facing the tall, white chimney of a sugar mill, addressed a crowd of 300.
The appointment of Matthew Polon as president and general manager of RKO Theatres was announced yesterday by the Glen Alden Corporation.

Mayor Lindsay has revived the proposal for a new consolidated passenger ship terminal for trans-Atlantic liners. The finest passenger vessels afloat the United States, the Cunard Queens, the France, the proudest ships flying the flags of Italy, the Scandinavian and other countries embark and discharge their passengers now at gloomy, cavernous, obsolete piers, admirably equipped with every inconvenience.

ALBANY, March 14 Governor Rockefeller sent the Legislature a bill today that would give the Bistate Waterfront Commission power to control and cut down the size of the work force on the New YorkNew Jersey docks.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) President Johnson, noting the fifth anniversary of the Alliance for Progress today, sounded a new call to the Western Hemisphere "to enlarge our truly revolutionary cause the cause of enlarging the lives of all our people."
WASHINGTON, March 14 The Treasury three-month bill rate soared to a record high today, easily surpassing the previous peak reached at the auction of Feb. 14.

INDIANAPOLIS, March 14 (UPI) Several previously unpublished poems by James Whitcomb Riley have been found scrawled on the flyleaves of library books at Shortridge High School here. The poems in the poet's own hand were found in volumes of Mr. Riley's poetry that he had given to his nephew, Edmund Eitel, a 1903 Shortridge graduate.
A decrease of 64.6 per cent in felony crimes on the New York subways was reported yesterday by the Transit Authority.

As part of the Lincoln Center Student Program, the Juilliard Dance Ensemble is, for the third year, going around New York public schools and offering a mixed program of classic ballet and modern dance.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 14 A poll showing that Americans are willing to have their Government negotiate with the Vietcong to settle the Vietnam war was released today by a group of Stanford.

CAIRO, March 14 The Arab states are preparing a joint declaration calling on the United States to reject reported Israeli pressure for new American arms, on the ground that such a deal would upset the balance of power in the Middle East, Arab sources said today.
The Irving Trust Company, New York, announced yesterday the election as a director of Wayne Hicklin, president of Avon Products, Inc.
The International Chamber of Commerce urged yesterday the early establishment of guarantees to protect foreign private investment against political risks.

WASHINGTON, March 14 Representative Benjamin S. Rosenthal, Democrat of Queens, said today that the National Commission on Food Marketing "will make its own independent recommendations." He is a member of the commission.
LONDON, March 14 (AP) A Michelangelo sculpture insured for 3-million ($8.4-million) goes on public display tomorrow after years of quiet display behind closed doors.
PARIS, March 14 Most of the 46 Claude Monet paintings in the second cache of his works inherited by the Academie des Beaux Arts here are studies, not finished canvases, it was disclosed today.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., March 14 An 85-year-old widow was playing the organ in her 30-room mansion here last night when four masked bandits entered, told her she played the organ "real good," tied her up and fled with an undetermined amount of cash and jewelry.

WASHINGTON, March 14 The State Department insisted today that it did not practice discrimination in assigning foreign service officers such as by excluding Jews from diplomatic posts in Arab countries.

DENVER, March 14 Senator Gale W. McGee forecast today that this year's election campaigns would produce "the largest and best-financed right-wing extremist assault on the sensibilities of the voters in American history."
BARRANQUILLA, Colombia, March 14 (Reuters) Marty Mulligan of Italy and Francois Jauffret of France played what was believed to be the longest major tennis tournament match on record today.
ALBANY, March 14 New York became today the 24th state to ratify the constitutional amendment establishing procedure for taking over the functions of a disabled President.
OHRBACH'S showed yesterday how dressed up the well-dressed man could be and also how undressed the well-dressed woman could be.
Henri Soul , the owner of Le Pavillon and La Cote Basque restaurants, who died on Jan. 27, left "a watch to my dear friend J. Edgar Hoover," his will disclosed yesterday.
NORWALK, Conn., March 14 Chester H. Stevens, a retired New York banker died yesterday after a long illness. He was 79 years old and lived at 219 Wolfpit Avenue.

WASHINGTON, March 14 Total world reserves, known as international liquidity, rose only $1.3-billion last year, well under the average for previous years, the International Monetary Fund reported today.

Bob Nevin, capain of the New York Rangers, was selected as the recipient of the New York Catholic Youth Organization's annual "most popular Ranger player" award by the 278,000 C.Y.O. members throughout the New York Archdiocese. Vic Hadfield came in second in the poll.
LE ROY, N.Y., March 14 (AP) Rear Adm. Stanton W. Salisbury, retired, former Chief of Navy Chaplains, died last night in a hospital at nearby Batavia. He was 75 years old and lived here.
The election of Dr. Harold Weisberg, dean of the Graduate School of Arts and Sciences of Brandeis University, as chairman of B'nai B'rith's Adult Jewish Education Commission was announced yesterday.
GENEVA, March 14 In a case whose roots go back to the Congress of Vienna in 1815, three men pleaded not guilty today in the Federal courthouse in Lausanne to charges of terrorism.

The city's Board of Ethics announced yesterday that it is investigating the fact that the in-laws of Buildings Commissioner Charles G. Moerdler and one of his top deputies have interests in slum dwellings that are in violation of the Building Code.

New York University had one of the finest hours in its long basketball history last night on the Madison Square Garden court. The Violets overcame a tenacious Wichita State team in overtime, 90-84, in a quarterfinal game of the 28th National Invitation Tournament witnessed by a crowd of 12,877.

LONDON, March 14 President de Gaulle's moves against the North Atlantic alliance were criticized today by Foreign Secretary Stewart as a blow to "the whole integrated system of defense upon which the security of the West and the freedom of mankind depends."
The stock market declined sharply yesterday, with losses ranging to 6 points in some of the volatile issues. Many investment-grade issues also were hard hit.
DALLAS, March 14 (AP) Henry R. Stern, writer of popular music, died in his Dallas apartment yesterday. He was 91 years old.

Within the next few days the New Jersey Legislature will vote on Governor Hughes's $870 million budget, and the new state income tax proposed by the Governor to finance it. The state urgently requires the additional revenue for better schools, for better highways, for local property relief.

LONDON, March 14 Eric Lubbock, whose campaign posters proclaim him "The Orpington Man," thinks he can prove that in an election dominated by massive party machines a lone Liberal can win by dint of personality and individuality.
Boys will be boys and, boys' wear manufacturers and retailers hope they will be strongly influenced by the fashion changes sweeping the apparel industry this year.

RIO PIEDRAS, P.R., March 14 The University of Puerto Rico's new president looked this week to New York and Spain to help double his faculty from 2,000 to 4,000 in the next eight years. The challenge is to meet doubling student enrollment.
CHICAGO, March 14 (AP) A new antibiotic for treating gonorrhea has shown favorable results in preliminary tests, a medical report said today.

STAMFORD, Conn., March 14 Charles James Noth, vice president of Merchandising Enterprises, Ltd., a marketing concern in New York, died today in Misericordia Hospital, the Bronx. He had been injured in an automobile accident on March 5. Mr. North, who was 44 years old, lived on Webb's Hill Road here.

WASHINGTON, March 14 Ever since man found words to identify his fellow creatures and the inanimate objects in his environment he has expanded them into descriptive figures of speech. This has been done most frequently in the identification of groups whose members are more or less united on a common attitude toward disputed issues of politics, religion, and so on.

ARCADIA, Calif., March 14, (UPI) Johnny Longden, who ended his 40-year riding career Saturday in storybook fashion when he won the $125,000 San Juan Capistrano Handicap aboard George Royal, appeared in racing silks for the last time today to receive the plaudits of the public, the track and his fellow jockeys.
Communist China's nuclear and missile potential and its capabilities for modern military technology are important background in the current debate about the Vietnamese war.
The election of Alvin E. Heutchy as a vice president was announced here yesterday by the F. M. Schaefer Brewing Company.

CAIRO, March 14 The French Government, which has nearly completed an agreement with the United Arab Republic on compensation for confiscated French properties here, will soon send a Cabinet minister on an official visit to Cairo. It will be the first such visit since the Suez crisis of 1956.
TRENTON, March 14 The Assembly Appropriations Committee favorably reported the controversial state income-tax bill tonight, clearing the way, for a vote on the Assembly floor.

YONKERS, March 14 Three men, representing groups vitally affected by the current con- tract dispute between the United States Trotting Association and Yonkers Raceway, will meet tomorrow in the midtown Manhattan offices of the New York State Harness Racing Commission.
Joey Archer of the Bronx, who has fought and advertised for his punching rights, went to court yesterday in an effort to get a shot at Jos Torre's light-heavyweight title.

PHANRANG AIR FORCE BASE, South Vietnam, March 14 On Nov. 1 of last year the first bulldozer lowered its blade into the dry cactus-dotted earth outside this coastal village 65 miles northeast of Saigon.

Andrew E. Valentine, general civil defense coordinator of the New York Telephone Company since 1959, died Friday in Lisbon, where he and his wife, Mrs. Barbara Horlock Valentine, had gone on vacation. Mr. Valentine was 59 years old. His office was at 140 West Street. He lived at 29 Albemarle Road, Westbury, L.I.
PARIS, March 14 Officers of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization were reported today to be looking over sites in Belgium for new military headquarters.

WOLCOTT, Conn., March 14 The senior class of this small Connecticut town's high school has sent out petitions seeking support of United States policy in Vietnam to the more than 17,000 public high schools in the nation.

JOHN MICHAEL is a name likely to become as familiar to American men in a few months as it already is to the Duke of Bedford, the Earl of Snowdon, the Aga Khan, Rudolf Nureyev, the dancer, and Cliff Richards, the British pop singer. All show up regularly at one of the 16 John Michael men's clothing shops in Londonn.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 14 Eddie Stanky appeared at the New York Mets' baseball training base today as the new manager of the Chicago White Sox, a team that wears blue uniforms with striped socks, and said: "We will go as high as our pitching will carry us."
The New York Stock Exchange announced that it had given member concerns permission yesterday to establish "guaranteed corporate subsidiaries."
BUCHAREST March 14 Ioan Gradinaru and Eugenia Hanu have been warned to come off their high horse.

CHICAGO, March 14 (UPI) A report in the current issue of the Archives of Environmental Health, published by the American Medical Association, today noted a possible relationship between barometric pressure changes and suicide.
WASHINGTON, March 14 A number of colleges and universities, including large Eastern ones, have refused to tell the Office of Education how many Negroes and other nonwhite students they have.
Whisky, money, food and personal correspondence were smuggled to favored prisoners in the Federal House of Detention here in a plot uncovered by Warden Walter Fitzpatrick.
Lykes Bros. Steamship Company announced yesterday another major acquisition in its program of diversification.
ALBANY, March 14 The court-appointed commission assigned to map new districts for members of the Legislature turned in its plan this afternoon, 10 hours before its midnight deadline.
After a brief early show of strength, prices of most stocks on the American Stock Exchange weakened yesterday in moderate trading.
The stroke of a pen with which Mayor Lindsay signed his first local law yesterday did more than rename a 28acre Queens park for the designer of the Miss Liberty 25cent piece.

What seemed to be a radio advertisers' boycott of Cassius Clay has led to cancellation of plans to broadcast the heavyweight champion's fight with George Chuvalo in Toronto on March 29. Many of the 42 advertisers who were offered sponsorship said they did not want to become involved because of the controversy about the champion.

VIENNA, March 14 Leonard Bernstein had an audience of Viennese music lovers wild with enthusiasm at the Vienna State Opera tonight, at a memorable premiere of a new staging of Verdi's "Falstaff" by the Italian director Lucchino Visconti.
WASHINGTON, Tuesday, March 15 (AP) Senate Democratic Leader Mike Mansfield says he will not seek Senate ratification of the consular treaty with Moscow this year.
Human concepts of good and evil have evolved through natural selection, much as the physical features of human anatomy, a biologist said last night.
MOSCOW, March 14 (AP) The Soviet Communist party assailed some Soviet publications, movies and authors today for neglecting Communist dogma and taking a Western type of approach in depicting life.

ALBANY, March 14 "Travia for Governor" buttons blossomed on the lapels of most Democratic Assemblymen today, but Assembly Speaker Anthony J. Travia, Democrat of Brooklyn, disclaimed any part in starting a gubernatorial boom for himself.

LONDON, March 14 (AP) Sir Samuel Oaki Quashie-Idun, former president of the East African Court of Appeal and a prominent Ghanaian, died yesterday in London's University College Hospital. He was 64 years old.

PHILADELPHIA, March 14 Mr. and Mrs. James Whitney Marvin of Chestnut Hill have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Frances Marvin, to James Bryson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Cyril Hastings Bryson of Swarthmore. A June wedding is planned.
At noon yesterday, St. John's Roman Catholic Church did not have a belfry, spire or Latin cross. At 2:55 P.M. it had all three. Instant medievalism had come to the Bronx.
The spot rate on the British pound eased yesterday, closing at $2.7958, down 8 points from Friday's level, in fairly moderate trading on foreign-exchange markets here.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 14 President Eduardo Frei Montalva banned a march on this capital by striking copper miners today and led a mass political meeting against Communist intervention in Chile's affairs.
Steel production climbed 1.2 per cent last week, to the highest weekly total since last June, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
HONG KONG, March 14 Chinese Communist leaders told their people today that an offer of friendship from Vice President Humphrey was "a kiss of Judas."
Maurice Knapp, a lawyer day of a heart attack at his home, 300 West 60th Street. He was 70 years old and his office was at 99 Park Avenue.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., March 14 The launching of Gemini 8 with two astronauts and 60 frog eggs, scheduled for tomorrow morning, was postponed today at least 24 hours.
ROME, March 14 Abie S. Nathan, the Israeli who made a solo "peace" flight to Egypt last month, arrived here today in the hope of a meeting with another seeker of peace, Pope Paul VI.

CYRIL CONNOLLY, the English critic and editor, has drawn up a list of the 100 works that in his opinion made the most substantial contributions to the modern movement in literature. His charming little book serves as a melancholy reminder that the golden age of 20th century fiction has drawn to a close.

WASHINGTON, March 14 In discussing the issue of the Vietnamese war during the 1964 campaign, President Johnson used to tell friends that his opponents were welcome to advocate "more war or more appeasement."

ALBANY, March 14 Despite charges that it would "make Jesse James look pretty mild," a bill permitting corporations to advertise in political campaign journals was passed by the Assembly today and sent to Governor Rockefeller.

SAIGON, March 14 (AP) United States Marine and Air Force jets pounded a North Vietnamese regiment holding the Ashau Special Forces camp today, apparently silencing its antiaircraft defenses despite the heaviest groundfire yet encountered in South Vietnam.
WASHINGTON, March 14 The Government agreed today to send a team of experts to California to try to work out problems in urban renewal.
MASON CITY, Iowa, March 14 (AP) The Northwestern States Portland Cement Company reported "a major breakthrough in cement production" today through computer control of a giant rotary kiln.
STATE COLLEGE, Pa., March 14 A private funeral service for Arthur Sullivant Hoffman, a magazine editor, an author and a teacher of fiction writing for more than 50 years, was held today.

BONN, March 14 Spokesmen for West Germany's two major political parties expressed anxiety today over the surprising gains scored by the extreme right-wing National Democratic party in yesterday' communal elections in Bavaria.
1966 Special Committee on Principles of International Law Began study of principle of nonintervention in domestic affairs of states.

SAIGON, March 14 John W. Gardner, United States Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, arrived today with a team of 22 other experts to study ways in which the United States can help the South Vietnamese Government win the hearts, minds and loyalty of its people. make a quick splash," Mr. Gardner said in a statement.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 114.3 on Friday from 114.1 on Thursday.

The Kips Bay Boys Club will hold its sixth Spring Boutique on Monday morning and afternoon in the clubhouse auditorium at 301 East 52d Street. The wares, which have been donated, will include Easter hats, new or almost new clothing, art objects, books and furniture.
The Lawyers Committee on American Policy Towards Vietnam criticized yesterday a resolution of the American Bar Association that affirmed the legality of United States actions in Vietnam.
American teen-agers tend to believe that they are now leading a good life and that it will get even better according to a nationwide survey made public yesterday.

Attracted by fine weather and by the prospect of watch- ing one of the best horses in training compete, a crowd of 46,593 attended the earliest opening program in the history of the New York thoroughbred racing yesterday at Aqueduct.

AUTHENTIC "sportsman's paradises" a favorite and overworked phrase in brochures are few and far between. Usually, they are far off the beaten track, catering only to those with the means and time to sample the sport at their leisure.
The Appellate Division ruled yesterday that a customer whose credit was unlawfully extended in violation of the 70 per cent stock margin requirement was entitled to sue his stock broker for damages.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 14 A single by Bobby Richardson with two out in the bottom of the ninth inning gave the New York Yankees a 5-4 exhibition baseball triumph over the Boston Red Sox today, and evened the Yanks' record at two victories and two defeats. The Sox have lost all five of their games.

HONG KONG, Tuesday, March 15 (Reuters) Communist China accused the Japanese Government today of an attempt to help the United States introduce nuclear weapons into Japan for use against China and other Asian countries.

Jack and Louis Brause, realty investors have begun assembling a site for a large apartment house in the Lincoln Center area by contracting to buy four five-story apartment houses at 129 to 135 West 67th Street, between Broadway and Amsterdam Avenue.
The New York Times announced yesterday that Max Falk, formerly the advertising manager, had been named advertising director.

WHEN Cecil Farris Bryant declared himself a can didate for Florida's Democratic gubernatorial nomination in 1956, the consensus of the backroom cognoscenti was: "He'll never make it, he's able and brilliant but the voters will never warm up to him."

An exhibition of autograph letters, programs, signed photographs and other memorabilia relating to the League of Composers will open today at the Vincent Astor Gallery of the Library and Museum of Performing Arts at Lincoln Center.
BOSTON, March 14 (AP) Mediators began a round of talks today with publishers and nonstriking mechanical unions that have not signed contracts with the Boston newspapers.

MEMPHIS, March 14 Mrs. Margot Edwards Patton of Memphis, daughter of Frank B. Edwards of Spartanburg, S.C., and the late Mrs. Cary Lindsay Edwards was married Saturday to L. Jerome Alexandre of Mill Neck, L.I., and Greenville, S.C. He is a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. James Henry Alexandre of New York and Long Island.

CHATHAM, N.J., March 14 Mr. and Mrs. Henry E. Sharpe have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Jean Sharpe, to Dr. E. John Steinhilber 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest J. Steinhilber Jr of Frankfort, N.Y. They plan an April wedding.

A voluminous and voluptuous voice returned to the Metropolitan Opera last night when Eileen Farrell appeared with the company for the first time this season, singing the part of Maddalena in "Andrea Chenier."

TUCKAHOE, N.Y., March 14 Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Hanlon have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Emily Hanlon, to Edward James Tarasov. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo P. Tarasov of Framingham, Mass.
The Little Orchestra Society, directed by Thomas Scherman, will give eight Tuesday-evening concerts at Philharmonic Hall next season.

TEL AVIV, March 14 David Oistrakh played two violin concertos with the Israeli Philharmonic Orchestra and two encores for an enthusiastic audience of 3,000 in his Israeli debut tonight. The Russian artist has scheduled 11 performances in 15 days here.

Salt marshes, swamps and estuaries have long been regarded as wastelands. For decades they have been dredged and filled to create real estate more or less suitable for housing developments, industrial sites and highways, or merely used as city dumps.
Mrs. Robert F. Wagner, wife of the former Mayor, was describe as in "excellent condition" after an operation yesterday for removal of a partial obstruction of the intestine.
Energetic sixth graders at P.S. 125 in Harlem, no strangers to poverty themselves, opened a World's Fair for CARE yesterday to buy school kits for the needy children of India.

Yesterday's selloff was so sharp than no more than a baker's dozen stocks on the Big Board gained more than a point, and news that might point, and news that might ry as recently as a month ago created not a ripple.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange drifted lower yesterday after a firm opening.

WASHINGTON, March 14 A long struggle to extend Federal safety regulation to small, independent coal mines employing 14 or less persons ended today with final Congressional approval of a bill repealing the small operators' exemption from the Federal Coal Mine Safety Act.
CARACAS, Venezuela, March 14 (AP) President Raul Leoni's Government coalition broke up today, but the three governing parties agreed to consider a reorganization.
Summary of the Day
LONDON, March 14. A rare American Revolution dollar dated 1776, made of pewter, was sold here today for the equivalent of $812.
The naming of Dudley Dowell as national chairman of the 1966 United Negro College Fund campaign was announced yesterday. Mr. Dowell is president of the New York Life Insurance Company.

WASHINGTON, March 14 Secretary of the Treasury Henry H. Fowler indicated today that he believed there had been excessive alarm in business circles about the boom conditions in the economy. But he left open the possibility of a "moderate" tax increase to cool off the boom.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 14 Just how peaceful life is among the New York Yankees this spring may be surmised from the following: A bitter controversy causing dissension among the stars is over a game lost 13 years ago.

Concert performances of two Handel operas, "Xerxes" and "Rodelinda," will be presented at Carnegie Hall early next season by the Handel Society. "Xerxes" will be given on Nov. 20 and 25 and "Rodelinda" on Nov. 23 and 29.

The Chase Manhattan Bank, the largest in New York and second in size in the nation only to the Bank of America, is offering to pay 5 per cent for largedenomination negotiable time certificates of deposit maturing in 1967.
Reform Democrats hope to field candidates against Charles A. Buckley's shaky Bronx organization in more than 3,000 of the 3,600 county committee contests this year.
Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that he was "ready to fire" about 300 street-hole inspectors who are "traditionally appointed by political clubhouse leaders."
WASHINGTON, March 14 Man appears to be losing his fight against drought, famine and air pollution despite "exciting" scientific advances, a panel of specialists said today.

The somewhat baffling two faces of DMSO were described here yesterday at an international meeting. This compound has been acclaimed as good for a great many human ailments and yet has been withdrawn from use in humans because of evidence that it has bad effects on animals' eyes.
CAIRO, March 14 United Arab Airlines is negotiating with two American manufacturers for the purchase of new jets valued at about $30-million, reliable sources disclosed today.
LONDON, March 14 Truman Capote's "In Cold Blood" has arrived in Britain to the accompaniment of extraordinary acclaim and one major piece of severe criticism.
FRANKFURT, Germany, March 14 (AP) Prof. Peyton Rous of Rockefeller University in New York was given the Paul Ehrlich and Ludwig Darmstaedter Prizes today for his pioneering work in cancer research.

A Greek investment banker said here yesterday that his country's economic growth rate must be accelerated from the present 7 to 8 per cent a year to 12 per cent if Greece wanted to be strong enough to compete with Western Europe by 1984.

MINEOLA, L.I., March 14 Support for two bills in Albany that would preserve the neighborhood school concept and limit the state's power to end racial imbalance in school districts was voted today by the Nassau County Board of Supervisors.
VIENTIANE, Laos, March 14 Government and neutralist forces in Laos suffered serious reverses in the northeast over the weekend, according to reliable military sources here.

The Long Mile Rubber Company, a division of the Associated Oil and Gas Company, has announced the election of Morton H. Broffman as president. He formerly served as executive vice president of the L.A. Darling Company.
The American Library Association has chosen Mrs. Elizabeth Borten de Trevino and Miss Nonny Hogrogian for its Newbery and Caldecott awards for the most distinguished children's books of 1965.

WASHINGTON, March 14 Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz, saying it was "cockeyed" to worry that the unemployment rate was getting too low, today urged continued efforts to cut the rate still further.

NEW ORLEANS, March 14 (AP) The World Boxing Association Executive Committee dropped Cassius Clay yesterday as its No. 1 heavyweight contender and replaced him with Zora Folley, who agreed to fight Ernie Terrell for the heavyweight title here May 16.

The fight to determine who should control New York State's pension funds is really a fight over who should derive the benefit from them. But there is a danger that the political clash of personalities will overshadow this key issue.
HOLLYWOOD, March 14 Surrounded by a covey of beaming starlets, Britain's jaunty Prince Philip toured a movie studio today and basked in some Hollywood-style hospitality.
CALAIS, France, March 14 (Reuters) Seven British students, including a girl, crossed the English Channel today on a second-hand fourposter.

Trade was light and mixed in the grain futures market with prices of most contracts showing very little net change. Corn and oats showed a slight tendency toward weakness, but other grains and soybeans were mostly slightly firmer.
Mayor Lindsay has expanded the power of the City Administrator, Timothy W. Costello, to set standards of efficiency for departments and evaluate their performances.

TORONTO, March 14 (Canadian Press) Within 15 months of buying control of Aurora Leasing Corporation, Ltd., with money from its own treasury, C. Powell Morgan, Harry Wagman and William Walton made a profit of $97,272, a royal commission was told Monday.

THERESA, N.Y., March 14 Mr. and Mrs. Augustine J. McDonald have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Elizabeth McDonald, to Jean Felix Boulin. He is the son of Mrs. Victor Boulin of Scarsdale and the late Mr. Boulin.
Contact lenses, if improperly fitted or improperly worn, can be permanently damaging to the eye and sometimes blinding, according to a nationwide sur- vey.

NEW ORLEANS, March 14 (UPI) Striking school teachers manned picket lines at almost one-third of the public schools here today but school board officials said there was a decrease in teacher absenteeism and that all schools functioned normally.
The Puritan Fashions Corporation, an apparel manufacturer, announced here yesterday the appointment of Louis Walker as administrative vice president.
NEW DELHI, March 14 Hindus and Sikhs battled in New Delhi's streets today as a wave of violence over proposals for a Punjabi-speaking state spread.
WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) The Senate passed and sent to President Johnson today a bill to discontinue the Postal savings system.
A stubborn and smoky fivealarm fire heavily damaged 15 stores in four buildings at Lexington Avenue and 125th Street in Harlem last night.

A former patrolman who took bribes for himself and others in the Police Department to protect gamblers, according to the District Attorney's office, was sentenced in Supreme Court yesterday to a prison term of a year and a half to three years.

WASHINGTON, March 14 Sports writers were dispatched to sundry world capitals with instructions to size up the prospects for the 1966 international season much as they might report on the outlook for the baseball pennant races from spring training camps. The object was to cover the diplomatic story, for a change, with men accustomed to finding out what the score is. Their reports follow:

WASHINGTON, March 14 Senator Mike Mansfield told the Senate today that President de Gaulle might have performed a "needed service" in forcing the other members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization to re-examine the entire structure of the alliance.
PARIS, March 14 Odd- ments on a tour of Europe through a 21-inch screen:
PRINCE PHILIP of Britain likes gin and tonic with lemon, not lime.
There were 46,000 seamen jobs in the American merchant marine last year, and 39,340 reports of seaman injuries and illness, for a combined frequency rate of 85 per cent.
The money and capital markets, faced with one of their most active weeks in history, got off to a running start yesterday as terms were set on more than $575-million of securities.

For ten days an art dealer had tried to see William Randolph Hearst, who was spending a fortune for works of art. The dealer could not pass a Hearst receptionist. Deciding on something dramatic, the dealer cut his wrists, only slightly, in front of the receptionist. Mr. Hearst rushed out. Eventually, the dealer made a sale.

Willye White, the National Amateur Athletic Union broad jump champion, will receive the Baron de Coubertin Fair Play Trophy in Paris Thursday. Rene Maheu, the director general of UNESCO, will make the presentation.

M. Lowenstein Sons, Inc., the textile producer, reported yesterday that its earnings last year were the highest in 10 years, with net profits totaling $6,080,808, a gain of 68 percent over the $3,626,693 earned the year before.
Chief Inspector, Sanford D. Garelik said yesterday that there was evidence that more than half the burglaries reported here last year had been recorded as lesser crimes.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 14 "Wait until Mickey Mantle gets a load of the new uniform number they've promised me," said Phil Linz gleefully. The one-time supersub of the Yankees is now a member of the Phillies, a team that was jostled considerably during the off-season through wholesale trades. The happy-go-lucky versa- tility kid was standing by the batting cage with Dick Groat and Bill White, both former Cardinals.
Gerardo A. Re and his son, Gerard F. Re, former American Stock Exchange specialists, moved yesterday in Federal Court to set aside their conviction on stock fraud charges
The 12:10 Aqueduct special didn't stop at Aqueduct yesterday, the early arrivals picked and bet without a program and at least two women couldn't read the pari-mutuel tickets they bought.
Ten years ago tonight, on March 15, 1956, "My Fair Lady" had its Broadway premiere at the Mark Hellinger Theater and she's been dancing every night, if not all night, somewhere ever since.
WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) The Rev. Theodore C. Petersen, said by his order to be the oldest living Paulist father, died of a heart attack today in downtown Washington. He was 83 years old.
The American Can Company announced here yesterday the appointment of John E. Goode as vice president, administrative assistant, manufacturing, a new post.

WASHINGTON, March 14 Hearings being held now on the anti-poverty program's needs for its third-year indicate which experiments look shaky and the changes that may be made. The House hearings resume tomorrow.

The Brown Company, a New England pulp and paper producer, is holding discussions concerning a possible merger with the KVP Sutherland Paper Company, it was announced yesterday by Frank T. Peterson, president of Brown, and Dwight L. Stocker, president of KVP.

The commander of a police precinct covering Greenwich Village said yesterday that a crime-curbing suggestion by a special assistant to Mayor Lindsay would create more problems than it would solve and would add needless costs.
Nearly half the country's interneships went begging as hospitals were informed yesterday that American medical schools were able to supply only 7,588 internes of 13,463 requested.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 14 (AP) Phil Linz drove in three runs and Doug Clemens two today as the Philadelphia Phillies ended a three-game losing streak with a 5-3 decision over the Minnesota Twins. The defeat was the fifth in a row for the American League champions.
WASHINGTON, March 14 Premier Fidel Castro indicated today that a Cuban break in relations with Communist China was imminent.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), March 14 Jerusalem's Mayor, Teddy Kollek, defended himself today against a charge that he had undermined the dignity of his office by posing with Marlene Dietrich.
The loser in last November's mayoral race told the Democratic party's winners last night what they must do to succeed again.

After eight years of sporadic investigation and numerous court battles, the State Com- mission for Human Rights has made a preliminary finding that there is "probable cause to credit" allegations of anti-Cath- olic bias at Queens College.
The election of Robert E. Scheuing as president was announced yesterday by the Hempstead Bank of Hempstead, L.I. He succeeds Joseph C. Mueller, who has relinquished the post because of ill health.
Mayor Lindsay and his family spent their first night in Gracie Mansion Saturday, amid stacks of moving cartons and mounds of excelsior.
HORSHAM, England, March 14 (Reuters) Henry Revell Harmer, stamp dealer who auc- tioned the collections of Presi- dent Franklin D. Roosevelt and King Farouk, died here Satur- day. He was 96 years old.

OTTAWA, March 14 The Government of Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson established today a judicial inquiry under Justice Wishard F. Spence of the Canadian Supreme Court to examine charges involving relationships between Gerda Munsinger and former Conservative Cabinet ministers.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (UPI) Senator Paul H. Douglas, Democrat of Illinois, accused the Government today of bungling, stupidity and possible plagarism in turning down an offer of a process for making protein-rich fish flour.
SINGAPORE, March, 14 Jakarta remained under firm army control today. Sukarno was still in Bogor, where he is reported to have freedom of movement.
A program inaugurated by the Red Cross Youth Program nearly 10 years ago has earned the enthusiastic support of parents, teachers and others concerned with the problems of youth.
PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla., March 14 (UPI) The Professional Golfers' Association fined Doug Sanders and Paul Bondeson $100 each today for violation of P.G.A. tournament regulations.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, March 14 (AP) Brig. Gen. Antonio Imbert Barreras, head of the junta regime during the civil war last year, tonight challenged former President Juan Bosch to a duel.
Prices moved higher yesterday for beer and cigarettes in the New York area and for newsprint in the eastern United States and Canada.

Political unrest that brought army takeovers in six Central and West African countries within four months has now erupted in East Africa. In Kenya, President Kenyatta has broken openly with Vice President Oginga Odinga, who has formed an oppostion party that could split the country on dangerous tribal lines. In Uganda, Prime Minister Obote has staged his own brand of coup and alienated forces that might bring him down if they could coalesce.
The Real Estate Square Club, a Masonic organization, has named Jack Resnick as Realty Man of the Year, the 13th such citation made by the club.
GUATEMALA, March 14 (UPI) Julio Cesar Mendez Montenegro, the Revolutionary party candidate, has been elected President of Guatemala, official returns from the March 6 elections indicated today.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., March 14 Mr.and Mrs. William J. Kelemen have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Ann Kelemen, to Roderic Vincent Noonan, son of Mrs. Gregory F. Noonan of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Federal Judge Noonan of the Southern District of New York. A September wedding is planned.
DANANG, South Vietnam, March 14 About 7,000 people, many of them students, demonstrated today in Hue, north of here, in favor of demands by South Vietnam's Buddhist leaders for a civilian government.
MONTREAL, March 14 (Canadian Press) R.A. Emer- son, who worked his way up from the bottom to the presidency of the Canadian Pacific Railway, died at home Sunday. He was 54 years old.

A Department of Agriculture report issued after the close of trading on Friday that storage stocks of potatoes had dropped 24.99 million hundred weight resulted is considerable buying of potato futures yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. April and May deliveries were most active.
The bearded, turbaned Sikhs, whose religion was founded by famed as fighting men since they resisted Mogul oppression in the early 17th century.

AN old-fashioned church supper was served here a few nights ago to Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey and 600 other guests. The "homecooked chicken dinner" came steaming out of a milliondollar array of glittering stainless steel that is perhaps the only church kitchen of its kind in the world.
From time to time, it has been suggested that agencies be given bylines on their ads partly as a means of recognition of any outstanding effort and partly as an incentive to make better ads.
YONKERS, March 15 A counterfeit twin double ticket worth $792.80 was cashed at Yonkers Raceway Saturday night, the track management disclosed tonight.
The fifth Easter Sunday luncheon and fashion show for the benefit of the Easter Seal Society will be held at the Plaza.
The election of Rogers Bayles as a director was announced here yesterday by the Home Insurance Company. He succeeds the late James R. MacDonald, former president of the General Cable Corporation.

William F. Kerby, 57 years old, was elected yesterday as president and chief executive officer of Dow Jones Co., Inc., publisher of The Wall Street Journal and operator of the Dow Jones financial news ticker service.

DETROIT, March 15 (AP) Mayor Jerome P. Cavanagh of Detroit said today that he would announce on Saturday whether he will oppose the the former Governor of Michigan, G. Mennen Williams, for the Democratic nomination to the United States Senate.

The operations of the Campbell Soup Company and its subsidiaries in the three and sixmonth periods ended Jan. 30, resulted in record sales and earnings, according to the report yesterday of W.B. Murphy, president.
Selwyn Lemchen, general merchandise manager of the Topps discount store division of Interstate Department Stores, Inc., announced new merchandising appointments yesterday.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 15 Arab Premiers were re ported today to have asked oil companies operating in their countries to meet the budgetary deficit of the United Nations Arab Refugee Operation. The demand would pose a difficult problem for more than 50 United States and European corporations.
WASHINGTON, March 15 President Johnson today evplicitly assigned Secretary of State Dean Rusk the job of overseeing and coordinating participation in the work of international organizations.

WASHINGTON, March 15 The Defense Department said today that it had asked the United States military command in Saigon for information about reports of South Vietnamese treachery and cowardice at Ashau, the Special Forces outpost that was overrun last week by the Vietcong.

Guatemala confounded all the skeptics by holding a fair election for the presidency and Congress. The left-of-center reformist, Mario Mendez Montenegro, won 45 per cent of the presidential vote. The Government-favored candidate, Colonel Aguilar, received only 32 per cent and another military candidate, Colonel Ponciano, the remainder. Professor Mendez's Revolutionary party won 30 of the 56 legislative seats and therefore has a majority in Congress.

BUCHANAN, N.Y., March 15 The refueling of the nuclear reactor at Consolidated Edison's electric generating plant in Indian Point, on the Hudson River near here, was in its final stages late this afternoon.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, March 15 Hundreds of thousands of Indonesians gathered in Jakarta's Banteng Square today to show support for Lieutenant General Suharto, the Indonesian radio reported.
WASHINGTON, March 15 (UPI) The House Commerce Committee opened hearings today on more than 40 bills to reduce the 50,000 deaths a year on the nation's highways.
BRADENTON, Fla., March 15 (UPI) The Kansas City Athletics extended their exhibition baseball winning streak to three games in defeating the Detroit Tigers, 7-6, today.
The controversial chemical called DMSO will probably be used within a year to help save victims of serious heart attacks, members of a medical research team said here yesterday.
NEW ORLEANS, March 15 (UPI) The American Federation of Teachers today called off its three-day-old strike of New Orleans public schools.
The National Dairy Products Corporation is budgeting capital expenditures this year at a record $52-million. In 1965 the company invested $37.8-million.
WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP) The Interstate Commerce Commission will meet tomorrow to discuss possible emergency measures to ease the railroad boxcar shortage in the West, it was announced today.
Florence Vandamm, a leading stage photographer here until her retirement 15 years ago, died yesterday of a stroke in Doctors Hospital. She was 83 years old and lived at 100 West 57th Street.
The Transit Authority announced yesterday that it would begin tomorrow to pay the wage increases granted in the settlement of the January bus and subway strike.
JERSEY CITY, March 15, (UPI) A synagogue has donated $100 to St. Peter's College "as a token of deep affection" for the president of the Jesuit institution.

The Villanova Wildcats yielded a 15-point lead midway through the last half, then staved off a closing rush by Boston College in the final minute to gain an 86-85 victory at Madison Square Garden last night. The victory sent Villanova into the semifinals of the National Invitation Tournament.
CHICAGO, March 15 The University of Chicago-Army Medical Research Project said today that prison volunteers had been used to help develop an antimalaria drug that is now being tested in Vietnam.
The State Legislature has looked squarely at one of the current evils in political finance and embraced it.
WASHINGTON, March 15 A bill to erect a "modest" $750,000 home for the Vice President moves to the House floor this week.

NAUGATUCK, Conn., March 15 This rubber manufacturing town's fleet of police ve hicles three cars and a motorcycle rolled again today after being put out of action for 20 hours by an upwelling of old-time Yankee frugality.

The performance of the old general was a wonderful piece of acting not just puppetry, for in this context puppetry has no more meaning. The puppets are only the surprising means to a perfectly conventional end.
NEW CITY, N.Y., March 15 Rockland County Supervisors unanimously approved a motion today to create a 12-man County Committee on Natural Beauty, one of the first in the nation.
"Have you named your opening-day pitcher?" Walter Alston was asked, during lengthy questioning about his star holdouts.

SAIGON, March 15 One of South Vietnam's most impor tant Buddhist leaders today called the military Government "rotten" and hinted that Buddhists and students might take to the streets to try to bring it down.

Byron H. Pyle, a former president of the Kennedy Van-Saun Manufacturing and Engineering Corporation of New York and Danville, Pa., died Monday in Roosevelt Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived at 785 Park Avenue.

MOSCOW, March 15 Forty of the Soviet Union's most prominent liberal intellectuals were reported today to have petitioned the Soviet Government in writing to protest against the conviction and sentencing of two Russian writers, Andrei D. Sinyavsky and Yuli M. Daniel.
The Italian government has given $500,000 to the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts.

An organization of 45 Orthodox rabbis filed a $1-million libel suit yesterday against Friends of Animals, Inc., The New York Times, and 58 individuals over an advertisement that appeared in The Times March 1 under the heading: "Is Kindness to Animals a Threat to Religious Freedom?"

CARBONDALE, Colo., March 15 Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Perry of Mount Sopris Hereford Ranch have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Rosamond Underwood Perry, to Thomas Ramsay Turnbull. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. William Turnbull of Far Hills, N.J.
PARIS, March 15 (UPI) The French Communist party today made freedom of expression and freedom of religion for all the official party line.

THE Soviet film version of "Hamlet," which hit a ca pacity audience between the eyes when it was shown at the opening of the New York Film Festival in 1964, finally came in for a straight run at the Plaza yesterday. It arrives in good time to afford a contrast to the recent "Othello" as an example of putting Shakespeare on the screen.

MONTREAL, March 15 (UPI) Bobby Hull of the Chicago Black Hawks, who passed one milestone last week with his record-breaking 51st goal, set his sights today on another National Hockey League standard 96 points in a single season.
Chief Inspector Sanford D. Garelik announced the start of a "top priority" crackdown by the police in Greenwich Village and the Times Square area yesterday.

As one of the big wheels churning up France's New Wave, the writer-director Jean-Luc Godard has created a ripple with "Band of Outsiders," which took up residence at the Beekman Theater yesterday. The seriocomic adventure, first exposed to a New York Film Festival audience in September, 1964, is guaranteed to enchant the avant-garde coterie that first took him to its mysterious heart in 1961 with the appearance of "Breathless."

LONDON, March 15 Gaston Henry-Haye, French Ambassador to the United States during World War II, won an apology and "suitable" damages today for libelous statements about him in the book "The Quiet Canadian."
WASHINGTON, March 15 Congress gave final approval to a $6-billion tax rise today amid growing signs that a second increase was in the offing. President Johnson promptly signed the bill.
KATHERINE ANNE PORTER, who won the Na- tional Bank Award for fiction yesterday, was described by the judges as "a dedicated and uncompromising literary artist, successful almost in spite of herself."
Katherine Anne Porter, James Dickey, Janet Flanner and Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr. received the National Book Awards last night in a stylish ceremony at Philharmonic Hall.

Buildings Commissioner Charles G. Moerdler vowed yesterday that he would take his father-in-law and his deputy's mother-in-law into court if they did not correct building code violations in property they own.

An offering of 650,000 shares of the common stock of the Hanes Corporation was marketed yesterday through a nationwide group of 150 underwriters led by Wertheim Co. and Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc.
Blair Co., Granbery, Marache, Inc., announced at the annual meeting yesterday that the company would again be known as Blair Co., Inc., effective April 1.
Mrs. John V. Lindsay, who has carved a far more active role as the city's first lady than her recent predecessors, has also acquired a larger staff than any of them had.
WEST PATERSON, N.J., March 15 Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas Both have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alice Both, to Dr. George L. Becker Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Becker of Paterson.
WASHINGTON, March 15 Joseph Palmer 2d, a career diplomat with long experience in African matters, was designated by President Johnson today to be Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs.
Irving Spiegel, a reporter for The New York Times, has been awarded the first annual Stanley M. Isaacs Mass Media.
"Play Florida horses," the man said confidently. "Stay off the ones from Pimlico. Horses depend on their legs. In Florida, they walk 'em in salt water."

David J. Miller, 23-year-old pacifist convicted of publicly destroying his draft card, received a three-year suspended sentence and was placed on probation for two years yesterday by Federal District Judge Harold R. Tyler Jr.
WASHINGTON, March 15 Staughton Lynd of Yale, contending that the Government's cancellation of his passport abridges his freedom of speech, sued today for its return.
LEWES, Del., March 15 (AP) The Cape May-Lewes Ferry lost $2.1-million in its first full calendar year, the Delaware River and Bay Authority reports.

LOS ANGELES, March 15 Gov. Edmund G. Brown said tonight that he had been "tipped three days ago" that there might be difficulty in the Watts area. As a result, he said, he had alerted National Guard officers.
Eddie's Ginger is a pet that probably never will be seen in a show ring. But yesterday the 9-month-old golden retriever became one of the most celebrated pups in the history of pure-bred dogs.

WEST ENGLEWOOD, N.J. March 15 The engagement of Miss Laura Nina Gagliardi, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Giocondo Gagliardi, to Edward A. Stettner of New Brunswick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick A. Stettner of Massapequa Park, L.I., has been announced by the future bride's parents.

The chairman of the United States Steel Corporation obliquely challenged the Government's anti-inflationary wageprice guidelines yesterday and gently lectured the Administration on the issue of public interest.

The phonograph record of the year was declared to be "A Taste of Honey" at last night's Grammy awards presentations held simultaneously in the Astor Hotel here and in Nashville, Chicago and Los Angeles.

MOSCOW, March 15 (UPI) Valery Brumel, the worldrecord high jumper, has rebroken a bone in his right leg while convalescing from injuries received in a motorcycle crash five months ago, Tass, the of ficial Soviet press agency, said today.

Back home after almost two years in a Syrian prison, 25year-old Edward Jay Levy said yesterday that he thought a United States passport would protect him when he strolled across the Syrian-Israeli border, in June, 1964, intending to hitchhike to Istanbul.
GRONINGEN, the Netherlands, March 15 (Reuters) Dr. Frits Zernike, winner of the Nobel Prize for Physics in 1953, has died, it was learned here today. He was 77 years old.

WASHINGTON, March 15 Recent diplomatic contacts with Hanoi indicate that North Vietnam is assuming an even more negative attitude than in the past on the question of a negotiated settlement of the war.

BETHESDA, Md., March 15 Rear Adm. Harold Sloop Berdine, a retired Coast Guard officer who won two Legion of Merit awards during World War II, died of a heart ailment last Saturday at the National Medical Center here. He was 64 years old.
ST. LOUIS, March 15 (AP) The Rev. Dr. Ben Mohr Herb ster, president of the United Church of Christ, said tonight that his two million-member church was starting a priority program for world peace.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., March 15 There is no substitute in baseball for stout pitching and muscular batting and the New York Yankees got both of these ingredients in breezy Municipal Stadium today. The Bombers zeroed in on four pitchers for 13 hits, the top total of the Grapefruit League season for them, to defeat the Atlanta Braves, 7-2, before a crowd of 2,500.
