But the behavior of the press was so clumsily overdrawn in the script that it could not compare with the vivid reality of the actual newsreels to which the simulated scenes were matched. And the omission of any hint that the Dallas police failed to establish firm ground rules for the hordes of reporters was a puzzling oversight.

WASHINGTON, March 15 The Federal Trade Commission, in a four-to-one split decision, ordered the National Tea Company today not to acquire any additional food retailing companies during the next 10 years.
LONDON, March 15 Madagascar will let Britain station a detachment of the Royal Air Force on the island to tighten the watch over tankers that try to break the oil embargo against Rhodesia.

NEW DELHI, March 15 One person was killed today when the police opened fire on a violent crowd in Panipat, 45 miles north of here, as protests against a Punjabi-speaking state continued to sweep the Punjab.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 15 The quarter-final matches of the Vanderbilt Cup contest in the Spring Nationals of the American Contract Bridge Association ended here in the early hours of this morning amid triumph, tension and heartbreak.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 15 The United States agreed today that a reference to anti-Semitism should be included in the future United Nations convention on the elimination of all forms of religious intolerance.
The bond market is carrying this week's huge load of new securities with surprising ease so far.

FLOWER HILL, L.I., March 15 Mr. and Mrs. Angelo J. Ritacco have announced the engagement of Mrs. Ritacco's sister, Miss Marianne Pascale, to Lieut. Robert William Scronic, U.S.A., son of Mrs. Frederick Clapp of West Hartford, Conn.

A one-day meeting of housing industry leaders on the subject of outmoded local building codes will be held on Thursday, Mar. 24, at the National Housing Center in Washington, D.C. The meeting has been called by the National Housing Center Council, which is composed of 40 large manufacturers of housing products.

PAPEETE, Tahiti President Sukarno has surely been the most histrionic of contemporary statesmen and for a long time he dazzled the Indonesians by appealing to their sense of drama. But much as the Javanese, above all, adore their traditional shadow theater, in real life they hunger also for an element of substance. This craving, quite evidently, Sukarno was unable to satisfy.
GREENVILLE, S.C., March 15 (AP) Mrs. Ella Mae Hollingsworth and her daughter, charged in the theft of $560,000 from John D. Hollingsworth, an industrialist, won directed verdicts of acquittal today.

THE jewels on the guests seemed to be competing with those on exhibition at the vernissage held Monday night at the Finch College Museum of Art, 62 East 78th Street. A display called "Art in Precious Jewelry" sat in velvet-lined vitrines; the guests' jewels were on more varied backgrounds.
Two more schools have been formed here to raise acting standards to a higher level.

With appeals from realestate assessments starting, Mayor Lindsay yesterday named a Republican, former Assemblyman Anthony P. Savarese Jr. of Richmond Hill, Queens, to fill a vacancy on the seven-member Tax Commission.
The New York City Colony of the National Society of New England Women will hold its annual benefit card party on the afternoon of March 24 at the Waldorf-Astoria.

The Lindsay administration's first capital budget was approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate, which added more than $4-million to it, and by the City Council, which cut more than $3.5-million from it.

THE seventeenth annual National Book Awards week has come and is now about to go. The Awards only four of them this dreary March are reported elsewhere in The Times; they bring a modest $1,000 each to the winners, probably more than that in personal prestige and sales of their books.
BRYN MAWR, Pa., March 15 Dr. Ralph Cooper Hutchison, former president of Lafayette College and Washington and Jefferson College, died of leukemia today at Bryn Mawr Hos pital. He was 68 years old.
LONDON, March 15 Jo Grimond, the Liberal leader, said tonight that there was a good argument for "limited devaluation" of the pound if accompanied by other measures to tighten the British economy.

MIDLAND, Tex., March 15 Some of the top leaders of the United States oil industry told the Texas Railroad Commission today that another prosperous year was in sight. They disagreed only on the size of increase in demand for oil products this year.
SYDNEY, Australia, March 15 Oil was discovered in the Bass Strait between Victoria and Tasmania today, thus opening up a third oil-bearing area in Australia.
WASHINGTON, March 15 (UPI) The Justice Department relayed to President Johnson tonight reports on the outbreak of violence in the Watts district of Los Angeles.
The Man of the Year Award of the Foreign Commerce Club will be presented tonight to Emile Heyrman, president of the Belgian Line.

"CBS REPORTS" took an hour-long look at the role of individual debt in the American economy last night, and came to the not-too-surprising conclusion that the consumer needs to be protected from his own improvidence.
HARTFORD, March 15 Connecticut stock insurance companies won a major battle today against nine out-of-state mutual insurances companies.
Cocoa futures prices continued to rise yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange.
"The Long, Long Trail," by Virginia Weisel Johnson, which Houghton Mifflin will publish on April 19, is a book about the high country of the West.

The First National Bank, the First National Bank of Chicago and associates submitted the winning bid yesterday for $7.5million of triple-A-rated South Carolina bonds. A bid of 100.00135 for a 3.40 per cent coupon set an annual average interest cost of 3.3998.

The fastest and most famous skiers in the world landed at Kennedy International Airport yesterday before moving on to Stowe, Vt., the first stop of a three-week competitive visit to the United States. These young racers made up the Austrian, French and Swiss national teams, which will compete at Stowe this weekend, at Sun Valley, Idaho, March 25-27, and at Heavenly Valley, Calif., April 1-3.
WASHINGTON, March 15 George Meany has told President Johnson that organized labor, which has been criticizing the Administration in public, holds no animosity toward the President.

MADRID, March 15 The Spanish Parliament overwhelmingly approved today a press law that purports to abolish direct domestic censorship, but Generalissimo Francisco Franco's regime retains enough controls to keep freedom of the press a highly academic issue.

One of the comparative little guys in the computer business, Scientific Data Systems, flexed its muscles yesterday by announcing a new data processing system that may cause more than a little concern to the giants that dominate the business.
JOHN SURTEES of England, who suffered serious injuries seven months ago while practicing for a race at Mosport, Canada, is back in action.
ALBANY, March 15 Legislative leaders said today that they were near agreement on a compromise bill to overhaul New York State's 179-year-old divorce law.
In an extraordinary flip-flop, the Bank of America, the nation's largest bank, has rescinded a rate increase that it charges on automobile loans. The increase was announced last week.
A mixed-up computer sent an ailing, 11-month-old infant on a wild goose chase Monday afternoon in an ambulance through the streets of Brooklyn.
VERO BEACH, Fla., March 15 (AP) The Los Angeles Dodgers' holdout shortstop and captain, Maury Wills, agreed to terms tonight for a salary reported to be $75,000.

The State Department confirmed today that a United States military jet plane had secretly transported Princess Beatrix of the Netherlands and her bridegroom on part of their wedding trip but the royal couple seems to have been overcharged at least $7.88.
IF the wind blows on Easter Sunday, hats should roll all over town.

Judge Birdie Amsterdam ruled here yesterday that two insurgent directors of the Paramount Pictures Corporation had "an absolute and unqualified right" to examine the concern's books and financial records going back to Jan. 1, 1961.

On the basis of the facts as thus far revealed, an injustice is being done City Buildings Commissioner Charles G. Moerdler in the inferential suggestions that he is somehow involved as a slumlord or guilty of protecting relatives who are.

BONN, March 15 Chancellor Ludwig Erhard termed "unthinkable" today any reorganization of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization that would lead to the establishment of a German general staff and an independent German army.

The Curtis Publishing Company reported yesterday a net operating loss of $3.4 million for 1965, a 79 per cent cut in the $15,721,000 operating deficit of 1964. The 1965 results did not include an extraordinary gain of $14.3-million from the sale of assets.
TEHERAN, Iran, March 15 (Reuters) The Shah of Iran opened a giant new oil loading terminal at Kharg Island in the Persian Gulf today.

"THE GROUP," the dramatization of the Mary McCarthy novel directed by Sidney Lumet and featuring Joan Hackett, Candice Bergen, Elizabeth Hartman, Shirley Knight, Joanna Pettet, Mary-Robin Redd, Jessica Walter and Kathleen Widdoes, opens at the Astor, TransLux East and Murray Hill Theaters.

The Belgian American Educational Foundation yesterday replaced eight directors who op posed the transfer of $900,000 of its funds to the Herbert Hoover Birthplace Foundation. Last year the organization also ousted members who objected to the move.
Orders to be placed in the next three months to meet military requirements in Vietnam and other areas will absorb 15 to 20 per cent of the nation's wool textile capacity.
Candidates with Republican backing were winning most races for mayor, trustee and police justice in early counts of communities in both Westchester and Rockland Counties.

MOSCOW, March 15 Diplomats in Moscow have been hearing persistent reports of the movement of Soviet troops in large units to positions in Mongolia as a show of strength on the frontier of Communist China.
WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP) Gov. Edmund G. Brown said today that California had begun a pilot program to make "the full range of state services" available "under a single roof."

ROME, March 15 The Italian Chamber of Deputies voted back into power tonight virtually the same Government, pledged to integrated European and Atlantic alliances, that it unseated 53 days ago in a dispute over state nursery schools.
ORLANDO, Fla., March 15 (AP) Jim (Mudcat) Grant, the Minnesota Twins pitcher, arrived in Orlando today and signed his 1966 contract with Calvin Griffith, the club president.
The spot rate on the British pound showed moderate improvement yesterday in quiet trading on foreign exchange markets here.
Bob Stallings knocked down Henry Wallitsch twice last night and went on to record a unanimous six-round decision in the heavyweight main event at Sunnyside Garden, Queens.

WASHINGTON, March 15 The Administration's fair housing bill, which is to go to Congress in a few days, is a sweeping proposal that stands little chance of passage in an election year, Congressional sources said today.

CHICAGO, March 15 Democratic, domestic politics took precedence over royalty tonight when Mayor Richard J. Daley skipped a scheduled airport reception line for Britain's Prince Philip and rode off with Vice President Humphrey instead.
The New York Stock Exchange had no comment yesterday on whether or not it planned to follow the lead of the American Stock Exchange and introduce women clerks on the trading floor.
The directors of the Georgia-Pacific Corporation proposed yesterday a five-for-four stock split. The move is subject to shareholders' approval at the annual meeting on April 27 in Augusta, Ga.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange continued to decline on a broad front yesterday.

Martin Tananbaum and Walter J. Michael, the presidents of Yonkers Raceway and the United States Trotting Association, respectively, the two organizations locked in a contract-dispute, met Tuesday with Robert A. Glasser, the chairman of the New York States Harness Racing Commission. At the conclusion of the session, arranged by Glasser, the chairman announced:

WASHINGTON, March 15 Senator Henry M. Jackson suggested today that the United States consider withdrawing the nuclear warheads provided to France if General de Gaulle pulled French forces out of allied integrated commands.
EUTAW, Ala., March 15 (AP) The appointment yesterday of Greene County's first Negro deputy sheriff was lauded by white leaders and condemned by civil rights forces today.
Signed $4.8-billion supplemental military authorization; saw Senator Magnuson (D., Wash.), Representative Kirwan (D., Ohio), and former G.S.A. Administrator
WASHINGTON, March 15 New York and other Northeast states have been urged to prepare for a fifth year of drought "as a matter of prudent public policy."

The election of Samuel S. Brand to the new post of vice president for systems and procedures was announced here yesterday by the McCrory Corporation, which operates a chain of apparel, variety and automotive supplies stores.

A. Sutton of the Harvard Club defeated E. Rohdenburg, also of the Harvard Club, 15-10, 18-17, in the first quarter-final match of the National Squash Tennis Association limited tournament at the Harvard Club last night.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 15 A ghost team, known as the Los Angeles Dodgers, made a somewhat spectral appearance in St. Pete today for a game with the New York Mets. Most of the Dodger substance was missing. Sandy Koufax and Don Drysdale are holding out for the fantastic sum of a million bucks for a joint three-year contract. Maury Wills checked in tonight at Vero Beach, where he ended his salary hassle.

LONDON, March 15 Television's first biographical play on Lee Harvey Oswald, assassin of President Kennedy, was presented this evening on the British Broadcasting Corporation's network known as B.B.C. 1. The 105-minute simulated documentary was a decided disappointment, a largely artificial undertaking that lacked theatrical persuasiveness and sustained insight of characterization.

Philip J. Levin, a New Jersey real estate operator who is the largest single stockholder in Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Inc., sent a four-page registered letter yesteday to Robert H. O'Brien, M-G-M president, demanding that he be allowed to examine the film company's books.
Delores Hodgens and Samuel Howard, duo-pianists, made their New York debut last night at Town Hall in a recital in which all individuality was submerged to the glory of the team.

OTTAWA, March 15 Mrs. Gerda Munsinger denied before Canadian radio and television audiences tonight that she was ever a Communist spy. She could not have been, she declared, because "the Russians ruined my life."
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 15 Walter W. Heller, who served both men as an economic adviser, asserted tonight that Presidents Kennedy and Johnson were the first modern economists to hold the Presidency.
The wholesale commodity price index advanced to 114.5 on Monday from 114.3 on Friday.

A blue-ribbon commission that was appointed to investigate last summer's riots in the Watts area of Los Angeles warned in its report last December that the August riots would be a mere "curtain-raiser" for future violence unless a "revolutionary attitude" was adopted toward racial problems.

JAPAN'S classic puppet theater Bunraku, which last night opened its first New York season at the City Center, is a theater of fantasy, a theater of disbelief, a theater of high seriousness where dolls take a time-honored place as classic actors in a heroic theater dating back to the 18th-century.

The effort to separate all of American opinion on the war in Vietnam into two and only two distinct categories was assiduously promoted by Governor Reed of Maine, speaking at the White House the other day.

LOS ANGELES, March 15 Hundreds of Negro teen-agers rioted this afternoon in Watts, the same poor section of the city that was torn by racial disorders last summer. Two men were killed and at least 25 were injured.

The speculation over whether Dr. Harry D. Gideonse would remain as president of Brooklyn College ended yesterday with the announcement that he would become chancellor of the New School for Social Research.
LOS ANGELES, March 15 (AP) The United States and Australian tennis professionals remained deadlocked after the second session in their Davis Cup-style challenge round last night.
SAIGON, Wednesday, March 16 United States officials expressed the belief today that South Vietnam's continuing political unrest had become critical.

SINGAPORE, March 15 Indonesia's generals took over President Sukarno's political power mainly because they thought Foreign Minister Subandrio and the Chinese Communist Foreign Minister, Chen Yi, were plotting against them, informed sources said today.

A former police lieutenant and the retired head of the New York Telephone Company's security division, who have been involved in a gambling conspiracy investigation, were indicted yesterday on charges of income tax evasion.

THE upswing in interest in education, particularly in mathematics, has resulted in some new publications on the subject. The following books, each covering a special area, have recently been published:
DENVER, March 15 A leading farm authority saw little hope today for accomplishing the agricultural reforms in Vietnam envisioned by President Johnson in his recent Honolulu declaration.
The election of William E. Leistner as a vice president and a director of the Witco Chemical Company was announced here yesterday.

DETROIT, March 15 (AP) The show will go on but backstage for a young student nun forbidden by the Vatican to play one of the leads in a University of Detroit campus production of an 18thcentury Italian farce.

CHICAGO, March 15 (UPI) Abe Saperstein, the basketball entrepreneur who built the Harlem Globetrotters into one of the world's best-known road shows, died tonight in Weiss Memorial Hospital of a heart attack. He was 63 years old.
My Fair Lady" at the Criterion Theater.
The Metropolitan Opera National Company has added two weeks of performances in Mexico to its first North American tour.
WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP) President Johnson has asked all Government agencies to submit revised budget estimates by April 1.
When bright, hot August days bring millions of New Yorkers to our beaches and swimming just well enough to get into serious trouble.
There will be a new island in New York Harbor off the Battery today a tropical island complete with swaying palm trees, banana trees and some sand, rocks and grass.

A Marine Corps instructor at the Air War College used to compare the organization of the Navy Department to a "can of angleworms." Through the decades a patchwork of modernization had been laid over a skeletal structure that was older than coalburning ships. That the organization has managed to adapt itself to the technological revolution is chiefly attributable to the professional competence of the officers who headed its bureaus and subdivisions.
The New York Rangers, who have a streak of six straight National Hockey League games without defeat at Madison Square Garden, will be opposed there by the Boston Bruins tonight.

WITH one member of European royalty after another whipping through New York to boost his or her nation's exports, it was only natural that a good many merchandisers here should have dreamed up some kind of promotion to honor every goodwill ambassador.

WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP) United Air Lines said today it would appeal to the United States Supreme Court a lower court ruling that allcargo carriers have exclusive right to offer "blocked space" rate reductions.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 15 (AP) Dave Smalley, an alumnus and assistant coach the last four seasons, was named today head coach of the Navy basketball team.

GENEVA, March 15 The United States urged the Soviet Union today to reconsider its rejection of President Johnson's offer of a "verified freeze" of the production of missiles and other strategic vehicles for launching nuclear bombs.

JACKSON, Miss., March 15 The militantly segregationist Americans for the Preservation of the White Race called off today its proposed "ride in" to Oxford Friday to protest an appearance by Senator Robert F. Kennedy at the University of Mississippi.

WASHINGTON, March 15 Nobody knows what President de Gaulle will do next, not even his own ministers, but there is a feeling here that his decision to withdraw from the integrated North Atlantic command will be followed by an attempt to restore the Franco-Russian Alliance.
ALBANY, March 15 The State Commissioner of Education ruled today that public school authorities may not unreasonably compel students to wear a particular kind of clothing.

WASHINGTON, March 15 Twenty-five Republican members told the House today that without effective foreign aid the United States would face the choice of either fighting Vietnam-type wars or retreating into "illusory isolation."

AMITYVILLE, L.I., March 15 Negro youngsters from New York City who live here with relatives and foster parents have been characterized as "carpetbaggers" and burdens on the school system by a member of the Amityville school board.
Inflight Motion Pictures, Inc., announced here yesterday the election as a director of I.W. Burnham 2d, senior partner in Burnham Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 15 "Sandy Koufax and Don Drysdale may be worth two or three million dollars," said Lou Johnson, the right fielder for the Los Angeles Dodgers, "but wouldn't it be a great joke if we won the pennant without them."

Mario Mirangda, a Chilean pianist who made his New York debut in 1959 and played all of Granados's "Goyescas" at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in 1962, gave a recital in Carnegie Hall last night. His program consisted of Haydn's Sonata in E minor, Op. 53; Schubert's Sonata in B flat major, Op. Post., and Chopin's Four Ballades.

The Johnson Administration seems to be making a conscientious effort to restore the consensus on economic policy that had prevailed before the Federal Reserve took independent action to stem inflation last December.
WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP) Mrs. Paul Mellon was honored today for her work in design and development of two White House gardens.

WILMINGTON, Del., March 15 The stockholders of the Hercules Powder Company, meeting in the campus-like setting of the companys' sun-filled research center here learned this morning that estimated first-quarter sales and earnings would set records for the period.

PITTSBURGH, March 15 (AP) An eight-hour show on June 30 at a suburban supper club, which will include a world lightweight championship fight, a gourmet dinner, cocktail party and floor show, was announced today.
The Jewish Chronic Disease Hospital in Brooklyn will benefit from events planned for today by five auxiliaries.

DAYTON, Ohio, March 15 (UPI) The Cincinnati Royals snapped a four-game losing streak tonight by trimming the New York Knickerbockers, 125107, in a National Basketball Association game at the University of Dayton Field House.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 15 Drastic community action was urged today by a panel of psychiatrists and obstetricians at the Yale New Haven Medical Center to counter an alarming increase in illegitimate child births among unwed teen-aged girls.
PARIS, March 15 On the consumer front, Franco-American relations took a turn for the better today.

KEY WEST, Fla., March 15 (UPI) A contract was awarded today to construct a desalting plant so that this island city can get its drinking water from the sea. The projected plant was described as "the world's largest."

WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP) The United States has quadrupled its military cargo shipments to Vietnam in the last year, officials disclosed today. They also said the United States had adequate shipping capacity to meet foreseeable requiremets.

BUENOS AIRES, March 12 "We shall either achieve rapid evolution or confront social catastrophe," Raul Cardinal Silva Henriquez, the outspoken Roman Catholic primate of Chile, warns in an interview with a popular weekly.
The New York City Veterans Administration has scheduled Saturday office hours to handle increased inquiries on the G.I. bill recently passed by Congress.
Ball to Mark 50 Years Of Gilbert Miller Plays A golden anniversary ball for Gilbert Miller, doyen of the international set of theater producers, will be held April 13 at the Astor Hotel.

ALBANY, March 15 Governor Rockefeller depicted himself today as a mediator trying to bring about a consensus on Mayor Lindsay's controversial tax and transportation plans to get them through the Legislature.

The University of Nebraska sold yesterday $13-million of revenue bonds to a group led by Lehman Brothers and Phelps, Fenn Co. The issue was priced on reoffering to yield from 3.50 per cent in 1969 to 4.20 in 2001.

Shareholders of the Continental Telephone Corporation and Telephones, Inc., at separate meetings yesterday approved the merger of Telephones into Continental. Consummation of the merger is subject to approval of regulatory authorities.
Some 6,500 members of the Soviet elite from Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin down will soon be receiving what for them may be disturbing though enlightening reading matter.

OTTAWA, March 15, (Canadian Press) Permission to enter the St. Lawrence Seaway this spring has been granted to three Russian ships, Dr. Pierre Camu, president of the Canadian Seaway Authority said last night.
SANTIAGO, March 15 A Communist-sponsored general strike failed today but half of Chile's critical copper industry remained paralyzed by labor conflicts.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Wednesday, March 16 After solving several last-minute problems that might have scrubbed the flight, technicians pushed the countdown early the day for the blast-off later this morning of the Gemini 8 mission to achieve the first link-up of two vehicles in space.

CINCINNATI, March 15 Three Federal Aviation Agency tower controllers and a survivor of a plane crash last November testified today that they had not noticed anything unusual about the flight before it ended in death for 58 passengers.

HARTFORD, March 15 An attorney for a youth charged with draft evasion said today that he would attempt to subpoena Americans and Vietnamese, including an American naval officer he says is being held prisoner in North Vietnam, to testify that United States troops in Vietnam were guilty of criminal acts.
WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP) Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson saw the circus today with 6,000 underprivileged children, about half of them preschool children from Head Start programs.

WASHINGTON, March 15 President Johnson signed today the $4.8-billion supplemental defense authorization bill and declared that the overwhelming vote by which it had passed showed that Congress stood behind "our fighting men in Vietnam."

WASHINGTON, March 15 The Rev. Dr. John C. Bennett, president of Union Theological Seminary, opened a three-day National Inter-Religious Conference on Peace here today by calling on religious leaders to work for a change in the American policy of attempting to isolate Communist China.

Are you satisfied with the results? That's the question Deputy Mayor Robert Price asked last night as he beamed down on 500 persons from a Brooklyn neighborhood that has been subjected to a 30-day "crash cleanup program."
Sol Goldman and Alex DiLorenzo took title yesterday to three East Side hotels and three smaller properties for a reported total price of $10.1-million.

ALBANY, March 15 (AP) Nearly 4,000 men, most of them longshoremen in work clothes, demonstrated today outside the Capitol to protest Governor Rockefeller's support of bills that would increase the Waterfront Commission's control over hiring practices.
Governor Rockefeller's proposal for the mandatory treatment of narcotics addicts was strongly endorsed yesterday by five of six witnesses before the State Investigation Commission.

The president of the Cox Broadcasting Corporation asserted yesterday in Atlanta that its activities in the communityantenna television field would probably not be influenced widely by increased Federal regulation.
The Columbia Broadcasting System and Warner Brothers Pictures have established a partnership to produce and finance motion picture films, to be shown first in theaters and later on television.
McCall Coporation, the publisher, agreed in principle yesterday to acquire the Safran Printing Company of Detroit for about $16-million in cash.

Investigation Commissioner Arnold G. Fraiman announced the suspension last night of a mechanical engineer assigned to inspect school construction for the Board of Education on charges of soliciting a bribe.

The United States Borax and Chemical Corporation has announced the election of Norman J. Travis as vice chairman. He is a director of the company and a senior executive of several of its foreign units.

The Women's League for Israel will award its annual Freedom Cup to Mrs. Zena Harman for "her service to the Jewish people, the State of Israel and UNICEF." The presentation will be made at a luncheon of the league in the Americana hotel on April 26.

WASHINGTON, March 15 A court decision of last week that invalidated a Mississippi election because Negro voters were excluded will give important support to the Voting Rights Act, Federal officials said today.
LOS ANGELES, March 15 Britain's Prince Philip flew to Chicago today after charming a large banquet with his acerbic wit and helping Hollywood entertainers spoof the British monarchy.
WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP) Top Air Force officials told Senators today that they had borrowed some bombs and ammunition from European reserves for Vietnam operations.

Further price advances in cigarettes yesterday increased the prospect that the rises would hold. And, in a separate price development, recent advances in newsprint brought a demand for a Congressional investigation.
Dr. Timothy J. Leary announced yesterday that he would appeal, on grounds of religious freedom, his conviction last week in Texas on charges of having illegally transported marijuana.
A $500,000 grant to the city school system to start development of a high school curriculum for students not planning to go to college was announced yesterday by the Ford Foundation.
A $500,000 grant to the city school system to start development of a high school curriculum for students not planning to go to college was announced yesterday by the Ford Foundation.
The stock market lost further ground yesterday despite a rebound in the final 30 minutes. The rail and glamour issues again bore the brunt of the decline.

PITTSBURGH, March 15 An increase of $20-million above tha 1964 backlog indicates substantial earnings in 1966 and 1967, Richard P. Brown, vice president for finance of the Mesta Machine Company, said today.
ALVIN, Tex., March 15 (AP) Nine men were injured tonight when an explosion rocked the Monsanto Chemical Company's Chocolate Bayou plant near here and set off a flash fire.
Trans-Atlantic passenger steamship rates are scheduled to go up again next year.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., March 16 Miss Barbara Johnson Scholl and Thomas Sands Baker, seniors at Denison University, plan to marry, Mr. and Mrs. Julian S. Scholl have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Davidson Baker of Villanova, Pa.

Herbert A. O'Brien, a former judge of the Domestic Relations Court in Queens who was the subject of Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia's classic comment, "When I make a mistake, it's a beaut," died yesterday at the Fairview Nursing Home in Forest Hills, Queens. He was 91 years old.
FULTON, Mo., March 16 (AP) The first 120 tons of the biggest jigsaw puzzle ever to cross the Atlantic arrived in Fulton today.

WASHINGTON, March 16 A New Jersey union leader asserted today that he would not reduce the size of a huge contract he had won, regardless of how much pressure the Johnson. Administration applied against him.

Thousands of New Yorkers will celebrate today the probable 1,577th birthday of Patrick the son of the deacon Calpurnis, and the grandson of the Presbyter Potitus known as St. Patrick, the patron saint of Ireland.
DANANG, South Vietnam, March 16 General Thi urged the people of Danang today to end school boycotts and work stoppages, to remain calm and to resume a normal pattern of life.

Phil Bard, a graphic artist, died on Saturday at the Jewish Chronic Disease Hospital of Brooklyn, where he had been under treatment for nearly two years. He was 54 years old and formerly lived in Manhattan.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles F. Pruesse of New York and East Hampton, L.I., have announced the marriage of their daughter, Miss Sandra Courter Preusse, to George Balmforth Johnston Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Johnston of Louisville, Ky.
TRENTON, March 16--After six hours of desultory debate, the Assembly gave Gov. Richard J. Hughes the narrowest of victories tonight when it approved a state income tax and an $870-million budget.

TORONTO, March 16 (AP) The Montreal Canadiens, with goals by Bobby Rousseau and Gilles Tremblay in the opening 40 seconds, went on to defeat the Toronto Maple Leafs, 7-2, in a National Hockey League game tonight.

David Kapp has been elected president of the Record Industry Association of America. He succeeds Goddard Lieberson, president of Columbia Records, who held the post for two years. Mr. Kapp is head of Kapp Records, Inc.
LONDON, March 16 A largepostcard-sized early-15th-century painting of St. George and the Dragon was sold here today for the equivalent of $26,552 a square inch.
HOUSTON, March 16 The thruster that apparently stuck on Gemini 8 tonight is one of 12 small engines that are supposed to keep the spacecraft going on an even keel.
TORONTO, March 16 Canadian investors were asked by the Government today to avoid buying Eurodollar issues ...
WASHINGTON, March 16 Industrial production and personal income advanced strongly in February, Government reports disclosed today.
WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) New export controls on hides were criticized today by House Republicans from the Middle West.
HOUSTON, March 16 The docking of the Gemini 8 spacecraft with an Agena rocket today was the first test in space of a maneuver vital to the United States moon flight program.
BOSTON, March 16 Senator Edward M. Kennedy and two other Massachusetts political leaders today urged both sides in Boston's 11-day-old newspaper strike to cooperate with Federal and state mediators.
BONN, March 16--As a result of rising labor costs, Volkswagen prices will "most probably" go up by as much as $62 on all models, a company spokesman said today.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) Julian Bond, an outspoken critic of United States policies in Vietnam, asked the Supreme Court today to clear the way for him to take his seat in the Georgia House of Representatives.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Thursday, March 17 The Gemini 8 astronauts suddenly lost maneuverability of their craft last night after making the first docking in space.

The New York Chapter of American Women for Bar-Ilan University will hold its 1966 Merit Award Luncheon on Monday in Delmonico's. Mrs. Samuel Nirenstein is luncheon chairman, and Mrs. Joseph S. Greenberg is chapter president.
SAIGON, March 18 Thousands of South Vietnamese crowded Saigon's Buddhist headquarters compound tonight to listen to a yellow-robed monk demand that military government be ended.

Switchboards of the three national television networks were deluged with telephone calls here last night from persons protesting the cancellation of entertainment shows for news coverage of the emergency splashdown of the Gemini 8.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) The Senate Select Committee on Standards and Conduct said today it had requested and received from Senator Thomas J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, further information about his trip to Germany in 1964.
The wholesale commodity price index maintained Tuesday the level it reached Monday which was 114.5.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., March 16 Elliott Schuyler Phillips, past president and chairman of the board of the Devoe Raynolds Company, a paint manufacturer, died here yesterday in St. Mary's Hospital after a short illness. He was 73 years old and maintained residences in Palm Beach and Greenwich, Conn.

WASHINGTON, March 16 The National Gallery of Art celebrates its 25th anniversary tomorow night, with a gala centering upon the exhibition of 202 paintings and 44 water-colors and drawings from the collections of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Mellon and Mrs. Mellon Bruce. Mr. Mellon and Mrs. Bruce are the children of Andrew Mellon, who established the gallery in 1937, four years before it opened in 1941 no time ago.
LONDON, March 16--All six members of the European Common Market, including France, told Britain today that they would like to see her join.

The only husband and wife meployed in a Broadway box office are Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Melnick. They are two of the three ticket distributors at the Brooks Atkinson Theater, where Mr. Melnick is also the head treasurer.
MOSCOW, March 16 The Soviet Union brought its two space dogs safely back to earth today after 22 days in orbit and frequent transits through the hazardous radiation belt ringing the earth.
SALT LAKE CITY, March 16 (AP) The First Presidency of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints issued a statement today denying that the church has any connection with the John Birch Society.

WASHINGTON, March 16 The Pentagon said today it has Lieutenant Coffee listed as "missing" as a result of "hostile fire." Officials said they had no official information that he was alive and appeared surprised by the reported letter. Until they see it, they said, they would withhold comment on its contents.
Dr. and Mrs. Kalman C. Mezey have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Yolanda Irene Mezey, to Douglas W. Hershey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold W. Hershey of Hershey, Pa.
The Western Union Telegraph Company took its first step yesterday towards its previously announced goal of establishing a nationwide information utility.
Mayor Lindsay has set up an interdepartmental group to give himself a greater voice in the selection of sites for housing projects erected by the New York City Housing Authority.
An 11-year-old boy, whose father has devoted most of his time to seeking a cure for hemophilia, died of the blood disease yesterday at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, N.Y.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) Congress was asked today to authorize a five-year program for control of trachoma, an eye disease, among Indians. A preventive mental health project in Alaska also was proposed.

CHICAGO, March 16 Prince Philip of Britain scoffed today at what he termed "a lingering suspicion that Britain is oldfashioned, sleepy and rather soft" in a speech that highlighted a fast-paced tour of the city.
NASSAU, The Bahamas, March 16 (Reuters) A fire destroyed the Paradise Island Ocean Club today, causing a loss estimated at $2.8-million.
PALO ALTO, Calif., March 16 Lieut. Comdr. Mary Frances Kelly, Nurse Corps, U.S.N., and Lieut. Comdr. John J. Walsh, U.S.N., plan to marry in the spring.
The Board of Education voted 5 to 4 last night to oppose the purchase of books produced at the strikebound Kingsport Press when other books of "equal value" were available.

HOUSTON, March 16 (AP) The wives of Neil A. Armstrong and Maj. David R. Scott of the Air Force had big smiles but few words tonight after learning their husbands were safe following Gemini 8's emergency landing in the Pacific.

BONN, Mar. 16 A spokesman for Fried Krupp confirmed today that the giant West German industrial company was negotiating with three Spanish companies for participation in a new steel complex to be built in Spain.

OTTAWA, March 16 A Canadian diplomat returning from a special peace mission to Hanoi and Saigon said last night that the International Control Commission could be an instrument to take the Vietnamese conflict to the converence table. But he said he believed India and Poland, which with canada make up the commission, considered the time for negotiations was not yet ripe.

Special to The New York Times NORTHBROOK, Ill., March 16 George H. Struthers, vice president in charge of merchandising for Sears, Roebuck Company, died today at his home. He was 51 years old and lived at 325 Pebblebrook Road.
"I pledge to make Dunkin' Donuts fresh every four hours, 24 hours a day. I will recreate all 52 varieties exactly as taught to me by the master chefs at the university..."

WASHINGTON, March 16 Despite "real concern" in Europe over the "invasion" of American business investment, the climate for investment remains good in most individual countries, a survey sponsored by the Atlantic Council concluded today.
The head of the American Association of Advertising Agencies assumed a rather unusual stance yesterday in the continuing controversy over consumer protection.
The New York State Attorney General is recommending a state law granting qualified immunity to accredited art experts who judge art works to be false.
TWO great names in furniture design Knoll, which is synonymous with modern today, and Thonet, which was synonymous with modern in the 19th century introduced new designs yesterday.

STE. AGATHE, Quebec, March 16 Two years ago J.A. (Larry) Ratelle decided to give up skiing. He offered two reasons. One was that a job as tourist promotion director in the Laurentians was keeping him too busy. The other was his weight. "I have a pretty good appetite," he ...
The New York Stock Exchange's board of governors is scheduled to meet today, and one item high on the agenda is likely to be the fate of the Big Board's proposed new $50-million building.

OLD GREENWICH, Conn., March 16 Robert Anton Langer, who designed the street and fountain lighting at the 1964-65 World's Fair, died Sunday at his home. He was 52 years old and lived at 8 Cove Ridge Lane.

WASHINGTON, March 16 Two China scholars contradicted today in the Senate Foreign Relations Committee the ideas that Peking is devoting itself to "promoting revolutions around the world" and that it has a "magic formula" for subverting underdeveloped nations.
WASHINGTON, March 16 The United States and the Soviet Union have reached agreement on a new cultural exchange program extending through 1967, the State Department announced today.
GUATEMALA, March 16--Amid considerable nervousness and uncertainty, Guatemala appears to be headed toward a civilian government with cautious reformist plans.

WASHINGTON, March 16 M.A. Schapiro Co., Inc., the brokerage house, urged the Securities and Exchange Commisison today to order the New York Stock Exchange "to rescind or modify" a rule that forbids members to deal in listed stocks with non-members.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (UPI) A special Civil Aeronautics Board report has exonerated the Boeing 727 jetliner as a safe, "excellent" plane that represents an advancement in aeronautical design, it was learned today. Four of the planes have crashed since July, claiming 264 lives.
Chief Inspector Sanford D. Garelik announced yesterday that more than 50 men and women had been arrested in the first day of the Police Department's campaign to clean up the Times Square area.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 16 Just about a year ago, the Los Angeles Dodgers humiliated Whitey Ford to the tune of 11 runs in five innings. But the seasoned left-hander got a measure of revenge today in breezy Holman Stadium as the New York Yankees whipped through their third straight victory by defeating the Dodgers, 9 0. It was the Dodgers' fourth straight loss.

This book, despite its somewhat melodramatic title, is a solid, documented study of the conflicts of interest, manipulations, distortions and prevarications and outright corruption that have marred the image of the United States Government over the past 15 years.
HOUSTON, Thursday, March 17 The flight of Gemini 8 changed from a calm and routine space mission into a life or death drama in just a matter of moments last night.

LIMA, Ohio, March 16 (UPI) The destroyer that tonight picked up the Gemini 8 astronauts, Neil A. Armstrong and Maj. David R. Scott of the Air Force, was named after a World War II hero who lived about 20 miles from Mr. Armstrong's hometown.

Mrs. Lillian Doris Mosesco, who retired in 1960 as senior book writing consultant at Prentice-Hall, Inc., publishers, was fatally injured last Friday in an automobile accident at Macunqie, Pa., where she had a residence. She was the wife of Filippus Mosesco.
The scheduled boxing match between Cassius Clay and George, Chuvalo took form yesterday as a nontitle epic that could go down largely unsung, unseen and unpaid-for.
A group of Staten Islanders brought suit in State Supreme Court yesterday to force an immediate start on the projected parkway through the borough's green-belt area.

Edward J. Madden, founder and executive director of InterCounty Blood Banks, Inc., died Tuesday in St. Francis Hospital, Miami Beach, of a heart ailment. He was 75 years old and lived at 89-11 153d Street, Jamaica, Queens.

ALBANY, March 16 A man whose conviction for stealing $5 worth of candy led to 24 years of illegal confinement in a state hospital for the criminally insane was awarded $115,000 today by the State Court of Claims.

The State Department of Public Works failed over an eight-year period to claim $27.3-million owed to it by the Federal Government because of "serious weaknesses" in its accounting procedures, an audit showed yesterday.

ORLANDO, Fla., March 16 At the start of the exhibitiongame schedule, Wes Westrum, the New York Mets' manager, said his prime objective would be the development of young pitchers to round out the club's staff.

BERKELEY HEIGHTS, N.J., March 16 Joseph Ishill, operator of the Oriole Press, a oneman printing, publishing and bookbinding establishment here, died Monday in his home at 11 Hamilton Terrace. He was 78 years old.
WASHINGTON, March 16 The Administration will ask Congress to make it a Federal crime to intimidate or to harm persons engaged in the desegregation of public facilities.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., March l6 (AP Thomas Yould, oldest Mason in the United States, died today at the Minnesota Masonic Home in Bloomington. He would have been 109 years old on April 13. Officials at the home said Mr. Yould died in his sleep.

LONDON, March 16 (AP) Manchester City bought Colin Bell, an inside forward, tonight from Bury for $126,000, only a few hours before the trading deadline in the English Soccer League. Players signed after midnight cannot play in games affecting league standings.
The fourth one-minute commercial in the "Batman" television show is having repercussions.
LOS ANGELES, March 16 A tense and unhappy calm reigned in the Watts area today bolstered by heavily augmented patrols of shotgun-carrying policemen.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 16 California's turbid political waters were further roiled today with the declaration of candidacy by a Negro for the Democratic nomination for Governor.
The switch to one-way traffic is still a divisive issue on Fifth and Madison Avenues, two months after it was made on Jan. 14.
The surge to higher money rates in the short-term money market continued yesterday.

Fred Meissner, a founder and former president and chairman of the Meinhard Commercial Corporation, factors, died of a heart attack Monday in his home at 35-27 161st Street, Flushing, Queens. His age was 72.
The controversial chemical DMSO might prove useful in malaria control, a scientist suggested here yesterday.
SYDNEY, Australia, March 16 Two thousand people cheered, shouted and waved placards here tonight as 12 young men burned their draft cards in protest against Australia's part in the Vietnam war.

J. Victor Herd, chairman of the Continental Insurance Company, said at the annual meeting yesterday that 1966 earnings were expected to be about $5 a share. The company earned $3.92 in 1965, including an underwriting loss of 75 cents.
WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) B. Mendel Rivers, chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, temporarily shelved today hearings on the Administration's $59.8-billion defense budget for next year.

PHILADELPHIA, March 16 Francis Reeves Strawbridge Jr., a vice president and director of Strawbridge Clothier, died yesterday of a heart attack aboard the liner Constitution while on a Mediterranean cruise. He was 55 years old and lived in West Chester.
The first of Mayor Lindsay's Little City Halls is not at 208 New Lots Avenue in Brooklyn. In fact, it isn't anywhere yet.

A cache of arms that included two rifles, a crossbow and 28 magazines of .30-caliber ammunition was seized last night in a Harlem building occupied by the Black Arts Repertory Theater, the police reported.

The City Planning Commission has recommended major modifications in plans for the World Trade Center, including terms that would give more money to the city and businessmen uprooted by the $525-million complex proposed for Manhattan's Lower West Side.
WASHINGTON, March 16 Far-reaching legislation to provide greater national uniformity in daylight saving time passed the House today with surprising ease. The vote was 291 to 93.
PIMLICO, Md., March 16 (UPI) Charlie Baltazar, the leading rider at Pimlico, capped a triple today with a length victory aboard Tide Mill in the feature race.

CHICAGO, March 16 (UPI) Goalie Glenn Hall stopped all but one of 39 Detroit Red Wing shots tonight to spark the Chicago Black Hawks to a 4-1 victory and keep them only one point behind Montreal in the National Hockey League.

Does a person have the right to sue if he has been injured in an accident caused by a friend or relative driving the car in which he was riding? That question has stirred considerable controversy. Much of the insurance industry and some 30 states, either by law or court decision, say no, except under certain circumstances.
JULLUNDUR, India, March 16 An old Sikh priest charged today that 400 Hindu demonstraters attacked his temple yesterday during a protest against the decision to establish a Punjabi-speaking state.
WARSAW, March 16 (UPI) Ambassador John A. Gronouski of the United States and Ambassador Wang Kuochan of Communist China discussed the war in Vietnam and Chinese-American issues for three hours today.
LOS ANGELES, March 16 (UPI) A former Marine who survived the fighting in Korea and Vietnam without a scratch was severely beaten yesterday in the new outbreak of violence in the Watts area.
DENVER, March 16 James G. Patton retired tonight as president of the National Farmers Union after 25 years in the post.

The $4.8-billion supplementary defense authorization signed by President Johnson this week was notable because it brought forth the first serious Congressional debate of the Vietnam war.
Two newsprint producers who recently attempted to raise prices by $10 a ton said yesterday that they would settle for a $5 increase to take effect May 16.
CHICAGO, March 16 Charles W. Bryan Jr., president of the Pullman-Standard Car Manufacturing Company from 1950 to 1959, died yesterday in Wesley Memorial Hospital. He was 76 years old.

WALTHAM, Mass., March 16 (AP) Two Brandeis University graduate students were killed today when their small plane nicked a campus library roof, hit a tree and crashed in flames almost in the center of the Brandeis campus.
The Ingersoll-Rand Company had the highest sales and earnings in its 95-year history in 1965, the concern's annual report disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 16 The House Foreign Affairs Committee indicates great dissatisfaction today with the $3.4billion foreign aid program proposed by President Johnson for the fiscal year beginning July 1.

NORWICH, England, March 16 Edward Heath, the Conservative party leader, challenged Prime Minister Wilson and the Labor party tonight to the opportunity opened by France's new attitude toward British membership in the European Common Market.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 16 (A.P.) George C. McConnaughey, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission from 1954 to 1957, died of cancer today at the age of 69.

WASHINGTON, March 16 The chief investigator for the Congressional committee examining the antipoverty campaign flew to Los Angeles today to look into the rioting that erupted in the Watts area yesterday.
A sharp rise in Maine potato futures prices was a feature of the activity on the commodities markets yesterday.
CAIRO, March 16 (Reuters) Torben Ulrich of Denmark and Sergei Lichachev of the Soviet Union gained surprise singles victories in the Alexandria tennis championship today.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 16 (AP) Hal Lanier drove in tree runs with a inside the park homer and two singles today in leading the San Francisco Giants to a 7-3 exibition baseball triumph over the California Angels.
CLEARWATER, Fla., March 16 (AP) Paul Richards, dropped by the Houston Astros as general manager last December, joined the Philadelphia Phillies today as a "special assignment scout."
DETROIT, March 16 The Detroit Symphony has conceled its 1966 summer season because of inability to reach a new contract with members of the orchestra.

LOUISVILLE, March 16 Three New York stars seemed on the way to victory in the Vanderbilt Cup final here this afternoon. With 36 of 72 boards completed, Tobias Stone, William Eisenberg and Leonard Harmon, all of New York, Robert Goldman of Philadelphia and Ivan Erdos of Los Angeles held a substantial although not decisive lead of 27 international match points.
WASHINGTON, March 16 Leaders of the National InterReligious Conference on Peace laid plans today for a symposium on peace that would bring together leaders of the world's major religions.

ORLANDO, Fla., March 16 The new man on the professional tour is Gary Player. After an absence since August from United States fairways, the little South African will tee off here tomorrow in the $110,000 Florida Citrus open golf tournament.
WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) Dr. Joseph F. Sadusk Jr. announced today his intention to resign as medical director of the Food and Drug Administration, effective April 15.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 16 Dr. Walter W. Heller, the economist, recommended today that the Administration "move swiftly to shape a program of temporary tax increases" because he sees signs that "the fine mist of incipient inflation may be turning into light rain."
GENEVA, March 16 The Lutheran World Federation announced today that it would hold its next assembly in 1969 in the East German city of Weimar.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 16 (AP) The Smithsonian Institution photographed reflections of the Gemini 8 spacecraft and its Agena target tonight from a tracking station about 20 miles north of Johannesburg.

The Rent and Rehabilitation Administration sent out notices yesterday to Buildings Commissioner Charles G. Moerdler's father-in-law that rents would be reduced in two Bronx tenements he owned unless repairs were started within seven days.

MILAN, Italy, March 16 (AP) Simmenthal of Italy, led by Bill Bradley and Skip Thoren of the United States, trounced Real Madrid of Spain, 93-76, tonight and became the first Italian team to qualify for the four-team final of the European Champions Cup basketball tournament. The other three teams have not yet qualified.

CINCINNATI, March 16 (AP) Two ground witnesses testified today before a Civil Aeronautics Board that they saw an American Airlines Boeing 727 jet flying "very low" before it crashed into a Kentucky hillside last Nov. 8, killing 58 of 62 persons aboard.
MILWAUKEE, March 16 (AP) The state of Wisconsin won a battle today to have Ford Frick's "facts" book placed in evidence in its antitrust suit against the National League and the Braves.
JACKSON, Miss., March 16 (UPI) Representative Prentiss Walker, Republican, qualified today to oppose Senator James O. Eastland, Democrat, in Mississippi's 1966 election for the Senate.
GENEVA, March 16 The continued advance of westward of cholera from the Asian regions where the disease has long been prevalent is causing growing concern to the World Health Organization.
Council President Frank D. O'Connor called upon the Legislature yesterday to seek a "middle ground" on transportation unification in New York City rather than accept Mayor Lindsay's merger program.

WASHINGTON, March 16, (UPI) William McChesney Martin, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, generally endorsed today legislation aimed at stripping the billiondollar Alfred I. du Pont Trust of its industrial holdings.

"I believe this time we have deployed a little faster with bigger force." That was the comment of Mayor Samuel W. Yorty of Los Angeles after the police had effectively stifled a developing riot in the Negro neighborhood of Watts. Only two persons were killed and 25 injured this time; last August there were 34 dead and more than a thousand injured.
New rules covering shipments in containers were put into effect yesterday by the North Atlantic Continental Freight Conference.

THE Chicago master Ed Formanek, while winning the recent "United Nations" open in his home city, ceded only a half-point in the seven games of the Swiss system. The player who dented Formanek's score was Ted Pehnic of Indiana, Black in a Ruy Lopez that revolved around the speculative exchange of a rook for bishop and two pawns.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., March 16--Alan K. Lauckner, who was long active in banking and financial circles in New York, died yesterday at Mountainside Hospital here. He was 69 years old and lived at 51 South Park Street.
WASHINGTON, March 16 (UPI) The Civil Aeronautics Board gave Trans Caribbean Airways permission today to put into immediate effect a special New York-San Juan fare for older persons.
ROME, March 16 Pope Paul VI today told Able S. Nathan, the Israeli "peace" pilot, that he would try to help bring Arab and Jew together in peace.
ATLANTA, March 16 (AP) Attorney General Arthur K. Bolton said today that Dr. I. H. MacKinnon, superintendent of Milledgeville State Hospital, had been padding his expense account.

PARIS, March 16 The Guide Michelin handed down tonight its annual judgments on the tables of France. It ousted a famous restaurant from its pages, demoted dozens more, and saluted several rising stars, chiefly outside Paris.

HOBOKEN, March 16 (UPI) Athletic directors from the 37 universities and colleges that make up the Middle Atlantic Conference ruled today that any school with 900 men or more cannot use freshmen in varsity sports. The previous ruling set the limit at 750 men.
Bernard Port, a neatly dressed man in a brown suit, peered at the stock tape yesterday afternoon and puffed on his cigar as LIL, the symbol for Lily-Tulip Cup, crossed at 34 1/8.
WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) A House Labor subcommittee approved today a bill that would increase the $1.25an-hour minimum wage to $1.40 next Feb. 1 and to $1.60 a year later.

The first boat show in New York devoted entirely to sail began its five-day run in the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and 66th Street, yesterday with light attendance and high hopes. There were 50 boat exhibits and others devoted to accessories.

ORLEANS, France, March 15--To relieve Orleans' main problem--housing the Orleanais-- Mayor Roger Secretain would like the United States Army to build more of its own housing for some of the 13,000 Americans it has brought here.
The Vacation Camp for the Blind will celebrate its 40th anniversary at a supper dance to be held in the Grand Ballroom of the Pierre on March 27.
The Peoples Gas Light and Coke Company and the Northern Illinois Gas Company, both of Chicago, are studying the possible advantages of a merger.

HUNTING dogs beagles, bluetick hounds and coon- hounds among them were a particular prey of dognappers, said Frank J. McMahon of Washington, the director of field services for the Humane Society of the United States, yesterday.

BALTIMORE, March 16 (AP) The Baltimore Bullets defeated the New York Knickerbockers, 118-113, in a rough National Basketball Association game tonight and clinched a spot in the Western Division playoffs.

IT's been a long time since so many little men, in terms of basketball, have had such an opportunity to be the big stars of the two most important postseason college tournaments. Army's short team doesn't have a starter over 6 feet 3 inches, but the Black Knights have advanced ...
DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, March 14 President Julius K. Nyerere emphatically rejected today the idea that Tanzania had fallen under the influence of Communist China.
NAIROBI, Kenya, March 16 Three more foreign Communists a Czechoslovak diplomat, a Russian reporter and a Russian businessman were ordered today to leave the country.

TWELVE Negro dance companies will certainly take part in the First World Festival of Negro Arts, to be held between April 1 and 24 in Dakar, Senegal. There should have been 13, but the unlucky 13th is the American Negro Dance Company, and its participation is now in serious doubt.
NEW DELHI, March 16 Three members of the Congress party were burned to death last night in Panipat, 45 miles north of here.

James Battista figured he could build a little dream house on the 107-by-73-foot lot he bought in Rosebank, Staten Island. But 50 feet by 73 feet of the lot are paved like a street, look like a street and are used as a street by everyone who wants to turn off St. Mary's Avenue into Vermont Avenue.

The Flintkote Company filed suit yesterday against the Armstrong Cork Company and two of its New York sales outlets, charging infringement of a patent on a cushioned sheet vinyl flooring product on which Flintkote says it holds an exclusive license in this country.

Hallmark Cards, Inc., announced yesterday the election of a new president and the consolidation of international activities into a new unit. The presidency went to Donald J. Hall, 37-year-old Dartmouth graduate, who has been administrative vice president since 1958.

SOMERS, N.Y., March 16 The honor of this country hamlet as the birthplace of the circus in the Western Hemisphere was restored today by an announcement that for six months its mail will be stamped "Cradle of the American Circus."
An Irish-American charged yesterday that he was discriminated against by a hiring boss on the Brooklyn waterfront.

A syndicate jointly managed by the Crocker-Citizens National Bank and the Wells Fargo Bank apparently submitted the winning bid yesterday for $6.87million of Walnut creek, Calif., general obligation bonds.

BERKELEY, Calif., March 16 Two top administrators in the University of California at San Diego withdrew their resignations today. John S. Galbraith, chancellor, and Robert H. Biron, vice chancellor for business and finance, said they had been influenced by "expressions of confidence from the faculty and from the community."

WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) The State Department announced today the appoint ment of Philip B. Heymann as acting administrator of the Bureau of Security and Consular Affairs, succeeding Abba P. Schwartz.
BONN, March 16 A West German newspaper reported today that Gerda Munsinger, the central figure in Canada's Governmental crisis, worked as a secretary in NATO's headquarters in Fontainebleau in 1954.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., March 16 (AP) The state police arrested the Rev. Virgil O. Harrold, dairyman and retired Lutheran minister, on a malicious-trespass charge today after he rebuilt a cattle pen on a new but unopened section of Interstate Highway 69.

WASHINGTON, March 16 Democratic members of the Joint Economic Committee of Congress said unanimously today that there was "increasing evidence daily" that a general tax increase would be needed this year to restrain inflation.
HONG KONG, March 16 The North Vietnamese regime told its people today to prepare for a "protracted war" in which they would have to rely mainly on their own forces to defeat the United States.
MIAMI, March 16 An extensive purge is under way in Cuba's Foreign Trade Ministry, the Havana radio announced today.

ORLANDO, FLA., March 16 By the time the World Series ended last October, the cells in Sam Mele's mental battery had begun to run dry. It had been an exhausting year. By dint of some superior thinking and opportunistic help from his players, the manager of the Twins had manipulated his hired hands to an American League pennant.

MIAMI, March 16 Joe Schmidt of Miami, the defending over-all champion, took the doubles lead in the international midwinter Sunfish Class championships today by logging a first and third in two races.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (UPI) The Social Security Administration today said it had taken steps to insure that Government-hired contractors administering the Medicare program provide equal employment opportunities.

KINGS POINT, L.I., March 16 M. Mal Deitch, president of the Shorehaven Beach Club in the Bronx, and managing director of the Green Hills Country Club, Greenwich, Conn., died yesterday in his home at 24 Sinclair Drive. He was 57 years old.

LOS ANGELES, March 16 (AP) Don Drysdale, half of baseball's famous holdout pitching pair, disclosed today that he and Sandy Koufax had offered the Los Angeles Dodgers alternatives to their purported $1-million, three-year contract demands.
Aided by a sharp rebound in late trading, the stock market closed mostly higher yesterday after erratic fluctuations in earlier dealings. Trading was only moderately active.

WASHINGTON, March 16 President Johnson summoned his senior foreign policy advisers to the White House today to discuss questions raised by President de Gaulle's challenge to the military structure of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
SUMTER, S.C., March 16, (UPI) Federal agents seized 250 tons of machine gun parts and bullets today in a raid on a deserted warehouse.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 16 Anti-Semitism was cited as a form of prejudice, for the first time today in a United Nations international convention.
BONN, March 16 One of Washington's chief trade negotiators told a West German audience tonight that 1966 had become the "year of decision" for the Kennedy round of tariff reduction negotiations.

TRUMBULL, Conn., March 16 Mrs. Augusta Shipp Rusk, mother of Dr. Howard A. Rusk, chairman of the department of rehabilitation of New York University Medical Center and a contributing editor of The New York Times, died today at St. Joseph's Manor here. She was 95 years old.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 16 Britain, France and the United States declared today that attempts by East Germany to establish itself as a separate state "can only frustrate" efforts to reunify Germany through free elections.

Unlike some film companies, which tend to regard the press either patronizingly or with suspicion, United Artists makes a point of the availability of its officers to reporters, especially when times are good.

HARTFORD, March 16 Anthony Keller of New York, a former public relations writer for National Education Television, was appointed today as executive director of the Connecticut Commission on the Arts, created by the 1965 General Assembly.

One would expect the pattern to change, but it doesn't. Simply because the artist is Artur Rubinstein. Last night for the pianist's only New York recital this season, Carnegie Hall was jammed; the stage held as many people as the law allows; eminent musicians dotted the audience; the applause and cheers were lavish. And it was all justified.

YONKERS, March 16 In harness racing, ill-mannered horses, those with a chronic record of "breaking" or those that have not competed over a 30-day span, must start in a qualifying race before members of the New York State Harness Racing Commission before they are permitted to "go" in a wagering event.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 16 Mrs. Louise Wyman Jones, who received the Distingushed Service Medal while serving in the Women's Auxiliary to the British Army during World War I, died in her home yesterday. She was 72 years old and the wife of DeWitt C. Jones Jr., former resident counsel to the New York Stock Exchange.

The Dexter Chemical Corporation, a producer of chemical specialties for the textile, paper and paint industries, announced the appointment here yesterday of Frank P. Greenspan as vice president for research and development.

Last night's "Parsifal" at the Metropolitan Opera was a pretty static affair. It is by no means an action opera; but the singers seemed more rooted to the stage than usual and, the music failed to build sufficient tension to sustain the long acts. Georges Pretre again was the conductor.

The Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra is becoming almost as familiar a visitor to New York as its cousin from Cleveland. Last night the orchestra played its third concert of the month at Philharmonic Hall; tonight it will play in Carnegie Hall.

A survey of tenant rosters in two Park Avenue buildings put up three years apart offers reassurance that the city's 19year-old office building boom may continue, sustained by corporations that keep moving to ever-newer quarters.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) The Justice Department said today Johnson Johnson, Inc., the nation's oldest and largest manufacturer of baby and first-aid products, has agreed to a court order barring it from entering into any restrictive agreements with its distributors.

Dr. Bernard E. Donovan, the Superintendent of Schools, disregarded the advice of his legal experts and said yesterday afternoon that Jewish pupils would be permitted to wear yarmulkes, or skullcaps, in school.
March 16 The Security Council voted unanimously today to expand the life of the United Nations peace-keeping force in Cyprus until June 26.

PARIS, March 16 Gardner Ackley, President Johnson's chief economic adviser, told European economic authorities today that the United States was already preparing for a quick tax increase if necessary. He argued that it was not necessary yet.
The spot rate on the British pound declined in active trading yesterday on foreign-exchange markets here.
A 22-year-old dancer who came here with the Hungarian National Ballet and Folk Ensemble has requested asylum in the United States.

A way around a major obstacle to Mayor Lindsay's proposed tax program legal clearance for the City Council to share enactment of tax bills with the Legislature appeared to have been found yesterday.
David Dubinsky, a spry, pep- pery 74 years old, jolted his colleagues and the garment industry yesterday by resigning as president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union.

WASHINGTON, March 16 President Johnson watched the launching of the Gemini 8 spacecraft today and then said that the United States still intended "to land the first man on the surface of the moon in the decade of the sixties."

PARIS, March 16 (UPI) President Charles de Gaulle has reportedly decided to postpone his plans to challenge the United States in the field of communications satellites and electronic brains.

Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary announced yesterday that he had designated two of his top Negro aides to pass on the character qualifications of Negroes and Puerto Ricans who have been rejected for appointment as policemen.

WASHINGTON, March 16 The newest thing for the American man is the life-size party doll. She stands 5'5" tall, measures 40"-20"-40" in bust, waist and hips, respectively, and is built of "soft skin-like extremely durable vinyl."
The bond market continued yesterday to handle this week's king-sized volume of new issues with a dispatch that lifted the spirits of Wall Street's investment bankers.

HOUSTON, March 16 Mrs. Nancy du Pont Bruns, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest du Pont Jr. of Wilmington, Del., was married this afternoon to Edward Arthur Curran, son of Dr. and Mrs. William L. Curran of Stamford, Vt.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., March 16 (AP) Charles Whittingham, the trainer for the Howard B. Keck stable, confirmed today that Saber Mountain, California's leading Kentucky Derby hope, had been injured and would be out of action for six months.

WASHINGTON, March 16 Defense Department officials confirmed today that some South Vietnamese troops had been shot by their American and Vietnamese comrades when they overloaded evacuation helicopters after the outpost at Ashau had been overrun by enemy forces last week.
The four basketball teams that meet tonight in the semifinals of the National Invitation Tournament at Madison Square Garden scattered yesterday in four directions.
WASHINGTON, March 16 (UPI) President Johnson took a few minutes out of his busy schedule today to enjoy Washington's spring-like weather.
WASHINGTON, March 16 The Johnson Administration opposed today suggestions from two Senators that would require Federal safety standards on 1968 or 1969 model cars.
The railroads serving the Pacific Northwest are suffering the severest box-car shortage in peacetime history.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, March 16 President Sukarno declared tonight that he was still in full control of Indonesia and had not delegated his authority to anyone.
In the paddock, the highpitched whinnying of nervous young 2-year-olds signaled the approach of another round in racing's biggest gamble.
WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) The Interstate Commerce Commission said today it would provide advance notice before announcing decisions in three of the biggest railroad cases of its docket.

BANMETHOUT, South Vietnam, March 16 (AP) The United States Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, John W. Gardner, today inspected education and medical facilities for Vietnam's mountain tribesmen. The tribesmen, called montagnards, have long accused the Saigon regime of ignoring them.

The Administration's tax bill has been signed, sealed and delivered right on schedule. It was approved with such great speed and so little debate largely because it asks no real sacrifice from taxpayers. The report that the Administration is preparing contingency plans for a fresh round of tax increases even before the ink has dried on its brand new law is an indication of its mildness.

WHO on earth could come from a place called Spearfish, S.D., spend his formative years during Prohibition and wind up as one of the world's undisputed authorities on wines? Frank Schoonmaker, that's who.
SCARLET-COATED riders galloped, hounds bayed and the sound of the hunting horn rang through Central Park yesterday morning, startling passing motorists, cyclists and possibly the squirrels.

WASHINGTON, March 16 President Johnson signed a bill today authorizing United States participation in the Asian Development Bank. He also announced that the United States was pledging half of the $24.1million needed to construct in Laos the largest Mekong River project to date.

The General Dynamics Corporation is the apparent low bidder on a Navy contract to build a submarine supply tender. The company's bid was $36,392,157 but it may not automatically receive the contract as other factors are considered before assigning the award.
SAIGON, March 16 Guerrillas surrounded a battalion of American paratroops this morning in the heart of the Vietcong jungle stronghold known as War Zone D, about 35 miles northeast of the capital.
With Mayor Lindsay present, the executive board of the Metropolitan Regional Council voted yesterday to incorporate so it could qualify for Federal funds available for area planning.
