The St. John's University chapter of the United Federation of College Teachers asked the State Supreme Court yesterday to force the reinstatement of 31 teachers who had been summarily dismissed.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) Six civilians died for every Vietcong killed in some recent search-and-destroy missions in South Vietnam, Representative Clement J. Zablocki, Democrat of Wisconsin, said today.
WEST BROMWICH, England, March 15 Donald Finney is the chief works inspector in a West Bromwich auto equipment factory. He has a slender build, a foxy grin and an obsession about colored immigrants.
ALBANY, March 16 The Assembly overrode the objections of Roman Catholic members today and voted to end the mandatory matching of 2 religions in the adoption of children.

The Humanity Club of Brooklyn will hold its 10th dinner on Saturday evening in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. Proceeds will go to the 25 philanthropic and medical research agencies the club has sided in the last 10 years.
WILDFOWL hunters with an interest in stamps may now purchase a 5-cent commemorative stamp marking the 50th anniversary of the Migratory Bird Act.

LONDON, March 16 The international conflict over the establishment of color TV standards in Europe has taken a new twist with the disclosure that the Soviet Union's refined system called Secam IV is being demonstrated in London.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange rebounded yesterday along a broad front in quiet trading.

WASHINGTON, March 16 The Securities and Exchange Commission made public today the proposed schedule of fees that it plans to charge brokerage firms that it regulates directly because they are not members of the National Association of Securities Dealers.

HARTFORD, March 16 David H. Mitchell 3d, who has charged that the United States is committing war crimes in Vietnam, was found guilty in United States District Court here today of "knowingly and willfully" failing to report for induction into the armed forces.
GLOVERSVILLE, N.Y., March 16 Governor Rockefeller said today that the question of the Legislature's raising the minimum wage to $1.50 before Federal action was taken "is settled, except for details."
A long-range weather forecast that was issued yesterday indicates the Northeast is still firmly in the grip of the longest drought in the region's history.

CINCINNATI, March 17 Changes in flight and flightcheck procedures and in altimeter equipment adopted by American Airlines since the fatal crash of an American Boeing 727 Astrojet here last Nov. 8 were outlined today during the closing session of a Civil Aeronautics Board hearing into the accident.

INDEPENDENCE, Mo., March 17 (UPI) Opening of a new exhibit featuring memorabilia of the friendship between Sir Winston Churchill and former President Harry S. Truman was announced today by Dr. Philip C. Brooks, director of the Truman Library.
DETROIT, March 17 (UPI) The Detroit Red Wings scored three goals in the first two periods tonight to gain a 4-2 victory over the Boston Bruins in a National Hockey League game.
CHICAGO, March 17 (AP) A minority Chicago Cubs stockholder filed suit today seeking to force Phil Wrigley, the club owner, to install lights for night baseball at Wrigley Field.

The New York Civii Liberties Union protested yesterday the Police Department's campaign against undesirables in Greenwich Village and the Times Square area as the number of arrests passed the 100 mark.
WASHINGTON, March 17 President Johnson's legiislative program suffered two sharp setbacks in Congress today.

The police are looking for possible links between a fanatically militant black nationalist group, whose arsenal was found Wednesday in a West 130th Street brownstone, and other racist groups in Harlem.
NAHA, Okinawa, Friday, March 18 (AP) "It looked awful lonesome down there. They were just little dots on that great big ocean."

DELANO, Calif., March 17 (AP) One hundred fifty men and women, carrying sleeping bags and paper sacks of clothing, began an improvised 300mile, 25-day march to the state capital today to protest wages and working conditions in the grape fields.
LANCASTER, England, March 17 The ruddy-faced farmer fidgeted in his chair as Humphry Berkeley urged the 50-odd people in the church hall to vote Conservative in Britain's general election March 31.
WASHINGTON, March 17 (UPI) The Senate confirmed today the nomination of Dixon Donnelley to be Assistant Secretary of State for Public Affairs.
The Swedish American Line yesterday accepted its new 26,677-ton liner Kungsholm in the River Clyde, near Glasgow, Scotland.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., March 17 Mrs. Margaret Annunziato Milone, wife of Salvatore Milone, Republican leader of Rockville Centre and president of the general contracting company of Dominick Milone, Inc., died early today after a brief illness at her home at 19 Bradford Court here. She was 56 years old.

The rather deliberate progress of divorce law reform in New York 179 years to liberalize a statute setting adultery as the sole grounds for divorce is at last moving a bill toward the floor of the Legislature.
WASHINGTON, March 17 (UPI) A House agriculture subcommittee approved today a bill striking at stealers of pet animals and inhumane dealers in research animals.
SCARSDALE, N.Y., March 17 Dr. and Mrs. John B. Train have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss. Felice Stephanie Train, to Max Bernard Rubin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Aaron Rubin of New York.

HOLLYWOOD, March 17 Some influential directors here are planning to launch a vigorous counterattack in their campaign to reduce or eliminate commercial interruptions from motion pictures shown on television.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 17 The Soviet Union reiterated support for East German membership in the United Nations today but refrained from asking the Security Council to consider the matter.
Batman, Robin, Superman, Napoleon Solo, Illya Kuriakin all heroes of modern derring-do.

ORLANDO, Fla., March 17 The road back for Jim Bouton hit a slight detour in Tinker Field today. The Yankee righthander, making his second start of the Grapefruit League campaign, was clubbed convincingly as the Minnesota Twins defeated the Yankees, 5-1.
PARIS, March 17 Abie S. Nathan, the Israeli peace flier, arrived in Paris by commercial airliner today and announced that having seen the Pope, he now hoped to talk with President de Gaulle.
HOUSTON, March 17 (UPI) The Gemini 5 astronauts were officially awarded today the world records for endurance and distance in space, even though they now are second best in both categories.
MOSCOW, March 17 (Reuters) Two sleepy dogs were shown on Russian television tonight, still wearing the space jackets they used on their recent 22-day flight.
THREE designs by Paco Rabanne of Paris almost stopped the show before it began yesterday as Alexander's introduced its European couture import and line-for-line copies to the press.

WHITE PLAINS, March 17 The engagement of Miss. Lois Ford and Virgil D. Vochoska, both of Anchorage, Alaska, has been announced by the future bride's mother, Mrs. Frank W. Ford, Miss Ford is the daughter also of the late Mr. Ford, who had been an assistant State Attorney General. The couple plan to marry May 27.
LONDON, March 17 Valery Tarsis, the Russian author of "Ward 7," who has been deprived of Soviet citizenship announced today that he planned to become a Greek subject and settle in Italy.

Ralph F. Colin, administrative vice president of the Art Dealers Association of America, charged yesterday that Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz, who has been conducting hearings on fraudulent art practices, "has been more interested in publicity than in sound legislative results."
Durable press, one of the most dynamic developments in apparel, is faced with a lack of uniform standards for quality and performance.

The Westchester Day School of Mamaroneck, N.Y., will mark its 18th anniversary at a dinner Sunday at the Pierre. Mortimer Solomon is general chairman of the event, whose proceeds will go to the school's scholarship fund.
Cocoa futures declined yesterday in moderately active trading on the New York Cocoa Exchange.

Max Bohland, a suspended housing inspector who was sentenced to a 30-day jail term for contempt when he refued to continue answering questions before a grand jury, was indicted here yesterday on charges of perjury in connection with the answers he did give the panel.
The boys on Madison Avenue have been running all manner of things up the flagpole for years. The latest thing to be run up is a real flag.

ITHACA, N.Y., March 17 Seven boys from the George Junior Republic, a private home and school for troubled children, held a Freeville, N.Y., couple at bay for two hours Wednesday night and then stole the couple's car and drove off.
ALBANY, March 17 The divided Legislature voted overwhelming approval today of a reduced version of Governor Rockefeller's $3.9-billion state budget.
TWO pairs of designers, one consisting of Italian sis ters, the other of French and Italian co-workers have sent spring-into-summer fashions to Bloomingdale's. All will be available Monday.
LOUISVILLE, March 17 The North American In ternational Team surged back to win the Vanderbilt Cup here in the early hours of this morning after trailing almost throughout the 72board final match.

The American Broadcasting Company announced yesterday that "ABC Stage, '66," a series of hour-long dramas, musicals and other shows, would make its television debut Sept. 14 Thomas W. Moore, network president, said the shows would be presented every Wednesday from 10 to 11 P.M.
Dr. Arthur A. Traum, a general practitioner in the Bronx, collapsed and died Wednesday, apparently of a heart attack, as he emerged from 50 Park Place. He was 65 years old.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., March 17 James F. Egan, an account executive for Morton E. Segal Co. and formerly director of the labor relations board of the Ward Baking Company for 22 years, died in his home on Weir Lane Tuesday night. He was 60 years old.
LONDON, March 17 A record price for a print 32,000 ($89,600) was paid by an anonymous buyer here today for a late-15th-century engraving by the German master known by the initials P.M.
LOS ANGELES, March 17 A withering crossfire of political accusations emerged today after Tuesday's violent outbreak in the Watts area of south Los Angeles.

FREEHOLD, N.J., March 17 Superior Court Judge Herbert Horn today reserved decision in a suit brought by County Prosecutor Vincent P. Keuper to determine if the sale of the 1958 novel "Candy" should be banned in Monmouth County.
GENEVA, March 17 Semyon K. Tsarapkin, the chief Soviet delegate at the 17-nation disarmament conference, is leaving for Moscow in the next few days.
BONN, West Germany, March 17 (Reuters) One of West Germany's top space experts said today that the emergency aboard the American Gemini 8 space craft yesterday was a blessing in disguise.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., March 17 Mrs. Eleanor Frances Naess of New Canaan and Erling Dekke Naess of New York and Bermuda have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Astrid Margaret Naess, to Allen Ledyard Lindley Jr. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lindley of Rye, N.Y. A late April wedding is planned.
A court fight over the desegregation of Norfolk's public schools ended today after a decade of litigation.
MALVERNE, L.I., March 17 ?The public schools here were boycotted today in the latest of a series of protests against the state's order to end racial imbalances in the school district.

WASHINGTON, March 17 Senator Wayne Morse called today for a law authorizing the Federal courts to consider taxpayers' challenges of Federal grants to parochial instiutions.

GUATEMALA, March 16 The leader of Guatemala's principal guerrilla movement has rejected the idea of a truce between his forces and a democratic civilian government that will probably take power in a few months.

NAHA, Okinawa, Friday, March 18 In excellent health and spirits after a hearty meal and eight hours sleep aboard a speedy destroyer, Neil A. Armstrong and Maj. David R. Scott arrived at Okinawa this morning.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., March 17 Space agency engineers sought an explanation today for the mysterious failure that forced Gemini 8 to cut short its flight yesterday.

MOSCOW, March 17 (UPI) The Soviet Union told its people today that the Gemini 8 space capsule had been forced to land before the "main elements" of its flight could be carried out.

WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) More than 2,000 American fighting men have been killed in combat in Vietnam and nearly 10,000 wounded since last summer, when President Johnson ordered United States ground units into the war on a big scale.

Jean Nebbia, a 52-year-old French national described by the Government as the central figure in a narcotics conspiracy ring, chose prison yesterday rather than disclose the source of $100,000 cash bail.

He was 76 years old and lived on Tower Hill Road, Scarborough, N.Y.

There was nothing forgiving about Bob Knight in defeat last night. His slender right arm shot forward and punched a wall locker. He kicked at a door. His narrow eyes were red and he cursed. His team had lost a basketball game.

The Civil Aeronautics Board's objective of reducing the number of United Statesflag air carriers to South America from three to two was advanced yesterday with the announcement that Braniff Airways had signed an agreement with Pan American World Airways to buy Pan Am's 50 per cent interest in Pan AmericanGrace Airways (Panagra).
Bond prices climbed sharply yesterday after Gov. Richard J. Hughes rejected the underwriting proposal for $440-million of New Jersey Turnpike Authority revenue bonds.

Dr. Robert Rosenfeld, a retired Brooklyn physician and gynecologist, died last night at his home, 1208 Eastern Parkway. He was 84 years old.

WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) The State Department reported today that Syria had not told the truth when she denied in 1964 that she held an American citizen in prison.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., March 17?Irritated by a faculty that had banned their participation in the St. Patrick's Day Parade in New York, more than 100 girls from Marymount College staged a march of their own here this morning.
PARIS, March 17 Parisians struggled today with a partial railway strike that slowed but did not halt commuter traffic.

The promotion of British fashions for men in the United States is being used by retailers to focus attention to all men's wear, whether produced in Britain or domestically, Gerald M. Abrahams, chairman of the British Menswear Guild, said yesterday.

David Flaherty, younger brother of the documentary film pioneer, Robert Flaherty, died early yesterday afternoon at the New York Infirmary of internal complications following a recent operation. He was 69 years old.

The honeymoon between the Congress and the National Arts and Humanities Endowments is still on. To judge by last week's hearing before a Senate Appropriations subcommittee in Washington, love, as Wintergreen predicted in "Of Thee I Sing," is still sweeping the country.

TRENTON, March 17 The New Jersey Turnpike Authority postponed a proposed $440-million bond issue today because of high interest rates. The bonds were to pay for a massive widening of the northern 30 miles of the turnpike.

YONKERS, March 17 With only a bit more than a quarter to go, Del Insko, driving Vicki's Jet in tonight's $25,000 Adios Spring Festival final at Yonkers Raceway, wouldn't have given a wilted shamrock for his chances. Hemmed in on three sides, Vicki's Jet appeared to be hopelessly locked in along the rail, with no possible means of escape.

Chalet Suisse, 45 West 52d Street, CI 5-9781. There is a definite appeal about Swiss cooking at its best, and the Chalet Suisse is probably the best of Manhattan's Swiss restaurants. The specialties such as minced veal a la Suisse cheese ramequin and fondue are excellent here, and the Swiss and Alsatian wines available by the bottle and by the glass are pleasant.
The Atlanta Arts, Alliance has announced an ananonymous gift of $2.5-million toward the construction of the Atlanta Memorial Cultural Center.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, March 17 High school and university students took to Jakarta's streets again today to protest the inclusion of leftists in President Sukarno's Cabinet.
BOSTON, March 17 (AP) The president of the Boston newspaper printers union said today that ways to end the 12-day strike were in the hands of insurance actuaries.
India, which experts agree is capable of producing nuclear weapons, has developed a "limited guided missile," a leading scientist said today.

MINNEAPOLIS, March 17 (AP) John McLennan fired home a 20-foot shot with just over four minutes left to give Clarkson a 4-3 victory over Denver tonight in a semi-final game at the National Collegiate Athletic Association hockey championships.

A blue-ribbon faculty committee of the University of California's troubled Berkeley campus yesterday recommended sweeping changes intended to open the door wide to experimentation. But while the professors went all out for academic reform, they appeared determined to hold the line against direct student participation in top-level policy-making.

The sculpture suspended over the grand foyer of Philharmonic Hall a shower of 190 polished gold metal strips called "Orpheus and Apollo" has been cited by the Buildings Department for violating the Building Code.
Gian Carlo Menotti's "The Consul," revived last night by the New York City Opera at the New York State Theater, proved that it hasn't lost its melodramatic power.

NEW DELHI, March 17 The police fired today on a violent crowd in the town of Ludhiana, 200 miles northwest of New Delhi, injuring 12 persons. But rioting in other Punjabi towns was reported to be subsiding.

OXFORD, Miss., March 17 Officials of the University of Mississippi added their pleas this afternoon to those of state authorities for Mississippians to remain calm during the visit tomorrow of Senator Robert F. Kennedy, who will speak at the university here.
The presidient of the American Association for Jewish Education called yesterday for "wall-to-wall Judaism" as a way of restoring the relevance of religious education to Jewish youth.
ORANGE, N.J., March 17 Walter W. Martin, retired treasurer of the Cities Service Oil Company, died yesterday at St. Mary's Hospital here. He was 77 years old and lived at 20 Elliott Place.
HUE, South Vietnam, March 17 Lieut. Gen. Nguyen Chanh Thi, former ruler of South Vietnam's five northern provinces, received a triumphant welcome today on his return to this ancient imperial capital.

BRUSSELS, March 17 Gardner Ackley, the Johnson Administration's top economist, said tonight that the United States economy might be expanding more rapidly than the strong pace expected less than two months ago.
A dinner at Sardi's East on March 30 has been arranged to precede a theater party that evening of the Society of St. Johnland at "Sweet Charity" at the Palace Theater.

SINCE Daniel Defoe wrote a popular story about the adventures of a shipwrecked sailor on a desert island scores (perhaps hundreds) of novelists have written books about similar situations. There is something highly attractive to a creative imagination in the problems of a man alone, struggling to survive and to conquer not only nature but loneliness.

A rise of 15 to 20 per cent in the number of infants born with narcotics addiction was reported yesterday by Hospitals Commissioner Alonzo S. Yerby. He said that 800 addicted babies were born to addicted mothers in the city last year.

HAVANA, March 17 Maj. Efigenio Almeijeiras was dismissed today as Armed Forces Vice Minister and stripped of his military rank and will be tried by court-martial "for activities contrary to revolutionary morals."
PHILADELPHIA, March 17 Dr. Edward Bell Krumbhaar, pathologist and educator, died yesterday at his home in the Chestnut Hill section here. He was 83 years old.

WILMINGTON, Del., March 17 First-quarter net profit was estimated at $1.3-million by Lehigh Valley Industries, Inc., at its annual meeting today. This compares with $368,000 for the first quarter of 1965. Because of a tax-loss carry-over the company is not liable for Federal income-tax payments.
The United States Trust Company of New York announced yesterday the election of G. Daniel Brooks and Walter N. Rothschild Jr. to its board of trustees.
ORLANDO, Fla., March 17 Sam Snead, who still sidesteps when he sees a rocking chair, led wath a 66 in the $110,000 Citrus open golf tournament today.

Studies on animals indicate that a very common air pollutant nitric oxide may result in people feeling "unaccountably pooped," a California pollution expert said here today.

SINGAPORE, Friday, March 18 The Indonesian Army arrested the First Deputy Premier, Dr. Subandrio, and 14 other leftist ministers today to satisfy the "anger of the people," the Jakarta radio disclosed.

BLUE POINT, L.I., March 17 The Suffolk Republican chairman, Arthur M. Cromarty, announced today that he would resign at the end of this month to seek appointment to the State Supreme Court. He has conferred with Governor Rockefeller about succeeding Justice Henry M. Zaleski, who died last week.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., March. 17 (UPI) Cassius Clay asked his draft board today to switch his classification, from 1-A, but the board rejected the religious ground of his Muslim beliefs as a basis for a change in draft status.

MANHASSET, L.I., March 17 Frank M. Rhatigan, executive secretary of the American Surgical Trade Association for 13 years, died Monday, at University Hospital, Birmingham, Ala., after surgery. He was 74 years old and lived at 26 Cove Drive.

BONN, March 17 The West German Government has approved an $87.5-million guarantee of credit to finance the construction of a big steel plant in Communist China by a European consortium headed by Demag A.G., a Ruhr steel and machinery company.

ALBANY, March 17?Mr. and Mrs. Whitman Daniels have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jocelyn Daniels, to Paul Alan Ferguson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Ferguson of Royal Oak, Mich. A July 2 wedding at St. Andrews Episcopal Church in Ann Arbor, Mich., is planned.

WARSAW, March 17 (UPI) The Communist leadership and the Roman Catholic hierarchy apparently have agreed, to settle a three-month-old dispute over an invitation to German bishops to a Polish celebration. MIAMI, March 17 Former Major Almeijeiras is generally considered to have been one of Cuba's most courageous guerrilla fighters.

The Bank of New York and the Empire Trust Company, two of New York's smaller commercial banks and both active in investment management, announced yesterday they have agreed in principle on the terms of a merger.
Two women were run over twice, by different cars, yesterday morning in an accident on upper Fifth Avenue. Four other women also were injured.
Portsmouth, Va., awarded yesterday $8.5-million of various purpose bonds to a group managed jointly by Blyth Co., Inc., and Eastman Dillon, Union Securities Co.
WASHINGTON, March 17 The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported the following spot primary market prices for the dates shown:
The following reports were provided yesterday by operators of the ski areas. Messages were filed at times indicated in parentheses.
IN the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

Joseph Palmer II has impressive qualifications to be Assistant Secretary of State for Africa. A career diplomat, he has had long experience of the new Africa and is held in esteem by many of its leaders. His relations with the career officers who staff and in many cases head the United States missions in Africa should be easier than those of his predecessor, G. Mennen Williams.
Two major companies in the building-supply business the American Radiator and Standard Sanitary Corporation and the United States Plywood Corporation are holding exploratory merger conversations.

POCHUN, South Korea, March 8 Pfc. Bang Seung Ok is paid 300 won a month, or about $1.10. In his 15 months in the South Korean Army, he has never gone out for an evening, he says, "because I dont have enough money."
BUFFALO, March 17 Mr. and Mrs. Walter Joseph Mahoney have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Moira Anne Mahoney, to Gerald Mark Gallivan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo James Gallivan.

The Board of Education was temporarily prevented yesterday from putting into effect a conditional boycott on books produced by the strikebound Kingsport Press, one of the country's major manufacturers of textbooks.
Thomas Schippers, who made a good impression last week leading Haydn's "Oxford" Symphony, was pale by comparison in last night's New York Philharmonic Concert.
NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., March 17 (AP) Bell Aerosystems' X-22A V/STOL aircraft, which can take off and land vertically and fly horizontally, was given its first flight test today.
A special committee of leaders of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union failed yesterday ot persuade David Dubinsky to reverse his decision to resign as president.

BRADENTON, Fla., March 17 Paul Richards sauntered along the stands toward the Kansas City clubhouse a couple of days ago. He moved in his usual, indolent fashion. At that time there was no need for him to hurry because he had no place to go. As the unfrocked general manager of Houston he had been wandering from camp to camp, making his own talent appraisals for the future.
The soundest bet on the card at Aqueduct yesterday disappointed the crowd of 25,272 and it also cost the management a good chunk of money.

What's in a name? Will the Universal Match Corporation smell as sweet to stockholders if it becomes UMC Industries, Inc.? Will United States Rubber Company smell as sweet if it becomes Uniroyal, Inc.? Management of the two companies feel they will smell even sweeter.
LUSAKA, Zambia, March 17 The Anglo-American Corporation, Zambia's largest copper combine, announced today it would open a new mine that would increase copper output by 32,000 tons a year.
SANTIAGO, Chile, March 17 President Eduardo Frei Montalva has won an important victory over Chile's powerful Communist opposition with the unwitting help of Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba.
The Assembly passed today a bill that would require all automobiles in New York, beginning with 1968 models, to be equipped with a pollution-control device.

Word that the New York Stock Exchange would not take over its proposed building site gave a glimmer of hope last night to Mrs. Louis Petersen, a diminutive, grayhaired woman who has been fighting to save her antique four-story house.
Cooper Industries, Inc., a manufacturer of diesel engines and compressors, announced yesterday in Mount Vernon, Ohio, the election of Robert B. Gilmore as a director.

There really isn't much good to be said of March, especially if it is viewed through the eyes of a trout fisherman. It is simply 31 dreadful days to be endured until April 1, the official start of the trout season in New York.

Vincent C. Ziegler, president of the Gillette Company, announced at the annual meeting yesterday that earnings for the March quarter would total about 43 or 44 cents a share, compared with 39 cents a share in the quarter a year ago.
WASHINGTON, March 17 The United States was informed several weeks ago by West Germany of the proposed sale of a steel mill to Communist China that had led the tempt to discourage the transaction.

WASHINGTON, March 17 Charles E. Bohlen, the United States Ambassador to France, was reported to have stressed here today that President deGaulle's condemnation of the North Atlantic Treaty's military-integration principle essentially missed the point.
Miss. Ruth M. Adams, dean of Douglass College, the women's unit of Rutgers, New Jersey's State University, will become president of Wellesley College on July 1.
Stocks closed higher in the slowest trading since midNovember; volume, 5.46 million shares.

WHEN Clarence House opened five years ago in two small rooms on the 12th floor at 38 East 57th Street, its main competitors (all purveyors of decorative fabrics for 50 years or more called the newcomer a flash in the pan. The two dozen designs offered by Clarence House, according to its rivals, could be found in other fabric collections.
WASHINGTON, March 17 Secretary of State Dean Rusk told Congress today that the Administration's $3.4-billion foreign aid program was "essential to United States security and national interest."

JAPAN'S classic puppet theater, Bunraku, continued its first New York season last night at the City Center with a completely new program, shorter aad perhaps just a shade less rewarding than the first.
COME AND SEE MY SHINING PALACE, by Nicholas Samstag (Doubleday, $4.95). A story about magazines and adertising.

BOSTON, March 17 The Johns-Manville Corporation, producer of building materials, expects both its sales and earnings this year to exceed the record levels of 1965, stockholders were told at the annual meeting today.
ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, March 17 (Reuters) Troops were moved up to the border with Guinea today to block any attempt to send Guinean forces through the Ivory Coast to Ghana.

WYOMISSING HILLS, Pa., March 17 Mr. and Mrs. J. Harold Fisher have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Michael Fisher, to Dr. Richard Sandler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Sandler of Malden, Mass. A June wedding is planned.
The British pound registered gains in quiet trading on foreign-exchange markets here yesterday. The currency closed at $2.7959, up 10 points from the level the day before.
THE future of mud-filled Little Neck Bay was de scribed once again yesterday in terms that would have done justice to a South Sea Island travelogue.

WASHINGTON, March 17 President Johnson called on Federal executives today to devise programs to make sure that Negroes were not prevented from taking Federal jobs because of a lack of housing or failure to get adequate education.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 17 John W. Gardner, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, said tonight that United States' support of a South Vietnamese social revolution was "going to have to go more slowly than we had hoped."

HOUSTON, March 17 Tape recordings made during the Gemini 8 crisis last night gave no indication of any panic aboard the spacecraft as it tumbled violently out of control over the Indian and Pacific Oceans.

The perennial battle over court control of adoptions is raging once more in Albany. The Assembly has passed a bill which would continue indefinitely the concurrent jurisdiction over adoptions of the Surrogates' Courts and the Family Court. This is clearly an attempt to block the intent of the court reform plan put into effect in 1962 by constitutional amendment. The Senate should block this retrogressive step.
PHALODI, India (AP) Here in the great Indian desert many families select one boy to spend his entire life hauling water from the nearest oasis.

Since then the idea of national independence has become an international fetish. Among the billion people who have either created new states since World War II or who are about to do so, one finds...

WASHINGTON, March 17 Republican Congressional leaders accused the Johnson Administration today of resorting to "statistical hocus-pocus" for political gain in its official reports on the country's economic condition.
NYLSTROOM, South Africa, March 17 (Reuters) Jaap Botha, who helped capture the late Winston Churchill during the Boer War, died of a heart attack in a retirement home here today. He was 83 years old.

PALO ALTO, Calif., March 17 Communist China was pictured today as favoring "a frozen relationship a continued impasse" with the United States for many years. Instead of adopting a softer line, whoever eventually succeeds Mao Tse-tung as Peking's leader was held likely to adopt a world posture of belligerent aggressiveness at least matching Mr. Mao's.

The Board of Elections here notified Governor Rockefeller and leaders of the Legislature yesterday that the delay in redrawing the state's legislative district lines made it impossible to hold primaries on June 21, as required by law.

Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that weaknesses in the accounting system used by the State Department of Public Works were the responsibility of the Democratic administration that preceded him in Albany.

BONN, March 17?President de Gaulle's proposals to alter the North Atlantic Treaty Organization "strike at the core of the Western alliance," Foreign Minister Gerhard Schroder declared today during a debate in Parliament.
A convention of the Syrian Antiochian Orthodox Archdiocese of North America, elected three clergymen yesterday as nominees to succeed the late Metropolitan Antony Bashir, who died on Feb, 15.

Maritime Administrator Nicholas Johnson, who serves also as director of the National Shipping Authority, will leave Washington next Thursday for a three-week inspection tour of United States maritime operations in the Far East, it was announced yesterday.

E.J. Korvette, Inc., reported yesterday higher sales for the 26 weeks ended Jan. 30, but lower earnings than in the like period of last year. Sales totaled $431,940,000, compared with $385,132,000 last year, and net income was $7,887,000, or $1.53 a share, against $9,137,000, or $1.79 a share a year earlier.
SAIGON, Friday, March 18 (AP) Cam Ban Nhu, a Vietnamese businessman of Chinese descent was killed today in a shooting in Cholon, the Chinese sector of Saigon.

WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) Senator J.W. Fulbright said today that the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, of which he is chairman, would continue its inquiry into Communist China to hear "rebuttal witnesses" sponsored by Republicans.
Studebaker owners of America, take heart! You may not be able to buy a replacement model next year, but if you blow a gasket, you'll still be in business.

The flooding of the equipment room of the nearly completed ice skating rink and swimming pool at Harlem Meer in Central Park caused about $175,000 damage, Park Commissioner Thomas P.F. Hoving has disclosed.
More than 1,100 persons attended the 21st annual Ball of the Year in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria last night for the benefit of Boys Towns of Itaty.

Two comedies, "Jack, Be Nimble" and "Goodbye, Raggedy Ann," are to be produced next season by H.C. Potter, who will direct both, and Richard Myers. They formed a partnership in 1959, but the team has not been able to find the right script to put on until now.
The New York Stock Exchange canceled plans yesterday to construct a new $50million headquarters building in lower Manhattan and intensified the search for a possible home outside the city.

WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) The Justice Department said today the 10th Circuit Judicial Council might permit District Judge Stephen S. Chandler of Oklahoma City to take on new cases if certain conditions were met.

Frank D. O'Connor has never made a secret of the fact that he wants to run for Governor. When asked outright if this is his plan, he will deny it, but deny it with a grin so broad that there can be no doubt that he is running. In a politician, that amounts to refreshing candor. The Allstate Insurance Companies reported yesterday that it achieved new highs in sales, number of policyholders and claims settled in 1965.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., March 17 Mr. and Mrs. Edward I. Martin, formerly of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Charlot Niles Martin, to James Edward Grisham, son of the late Mrs. John Lodetti of El Cerrito, Calif.
EAST LANSING, Mich., March 17 (AP) Michigan State today extended Duffy Daugherty's assignment as head football coach through the 197071 school year.

Suntan lotion was smuggled into the Federal House of Detention by a prison employe to help a prisoner attain a healthy, out-door look, United States Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau said yesterday. The prisoner became tan, he added, while lolling on the outdoor recreation solarium, on the roof of the three-story prison.

WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) Corporations issuing public reports, paid cash dividends totaling $756-million during February, an increase of $143-million from February of last year, the Department of Commerce said today.
Heroically emerging from a storm of Roman pizzas, Don Fullmer of West Jordan, Utah, will defend his American middleweight title against Jose Gonzalez tonight at Madison Square Garden.

Arguing that the constitutional guarantee of religious freedom permits him to use marijuana and to encourage others to use it, Dr. Timothy J. Leary is appealing his conviction on two counts of illegally transporting the drug and of failing to pay a tax on it. He sees his case as raising a serious issue of public policy, and in this he is right.

"The most important thing about the Red Cross people in Vietnam," says an ex member of the Green Berets who spent 18 months in the fighting,"is that they are there. They weren't drafted, they don't have to go ... but they cared enough to come with us."

The Federal Reserve continued to keep a firm hand on the money market in the week ended last Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Bor rowings of some Federal Reserve member banks from the Reserve System exceeded surplus or excess reserves held by other member banks by an estimated average of $225million a day.
NEW HAVEN, March17 Robert Brustein has taken the first steps in what he hopes will be a reshaping of the Yale Drama School, of which he was recently appointed dean, effective July 1.

WASHINGTON, March 17 Protestant, Roman Catholic and Jewish religious leaders called on President Johnson today to seek a new cease-fire in Vietnam starting Good Friday, April 8, and to consider "an immediate halt" to bombing raids in North and South Vietnam.

The guild has predicted for this year, stronger colors, emergence of the shaped look (clothes following body lines instead of hanging straight from the shoulder) and wider neckties. All in all, Mr. Abrahams said, it is a bolder look.
WASHINGTON, March 17 The United States Chamber of Commerce has begun an unusual campaign to prevent the reappointment of Gerald A. Brown to the National Labor Relations Board.
CHICAGO, March 17 (AP) The Chicago and North Western Railway, seeking a merger with the Rock Island line, said today it was making its exchange of stock offer available to Rock Island stockholders.
WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) President Johnson selected Bernard Zagorin today to be the first United States director of the new $1-billion Asian Development Bank.
Westchester County will join the boat-show parade today with the opening of the sixth annual Westchester Boat, Marine and Sport Show.
DUBLIN, March 17 The patron saint of Ireland was honored today in solemn religious ceremonies and colorful pageants throughout the republic.
Prince Philip of Britain, wearin a green necktie, arrived from Chicago yesterday on a threeday visit to promote British imports and help raise money for an American charity.

Ever since Joseph M. Valachi opened a window on what goes on within the Mafia, in his testimony before a Senate committee in 1963, there has been a growing public interest in the behind-the-scenes doings of this loosely knit nationwide criminal junta.
Revlon, Inc., reported yesterday that sales and earnings in 1965 reached the highest level in the company's 33-year history.
The London Stock Exchange closed steady yesterday after a session of light trading. Most industrials showed small gains.
CHICAGO (UPI) Fringe benefits such as health and retirement programs cost employers of white collar workers $19 for each $100 in salary, according to a Commerce Clearing House report.

ALBANY, March 17 The sponsors of a divorce-reform bill introduced earlier this year expressed fear today that a new bill being drafted by legislative leaders may be so, "inferior" as to be meaningless.
Mayor Lindsay demanded yesterday more than $21-million in Federal funds for two New York Harbor improvements.

WASHINGTON, March 17 For the first time a Congressional group has proposed that it help the space agency plan specific flights. The planning role has been a jealously guarded role of the Executive branch.

Lieut. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, director of the Selective Service System, told 700 Columbia, University students yesterday that he sympathized with persons who had conscientious scruples against taking part in a particular war.
Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes said yesterday that the city's long-delayed $100million plan to computerize traffic control will get its first workout in Queens in about six months.
Two patrolmen were arrested and charged yesterday with having attempted to rape a young Japanese woman in the back seat of a police radio car.
DANANG, South Vietnam, March 18 Several hundred South Vietnamese soldiers carried banners and signs here today to denounce leaders of the military junta in Saigon.

WASHINGTON, March 18 A vastly enlarged program of Federal aid to rescue city transit systems from financial disaster was strongly recommended today by John J. Gilhooley, acting chairman of the New York City Transit Authority.

WASHINGTON, March 18 Adolph Rupp, whose Kentucky basketball team played in the semi-finals of the National Collegiate championship tonight, was named college coach of the year by the United States Basketball Writers Association today.
LOS ANGELES, March 18 California political circles were agog tonight over the expected entry of Lloyd N. Hand into the race for the Democratic nomination for lieutenant governor.
WASHINGTON, March 18 The White House today announced the resignation of Lloyd N. Hand as the State Department's Chief of Protocol.

The First National City Bank of New York rejected yesterday a demand by students at Union Theological Seminary that the bank close its three branches in South Africa, according to two of the students.

The board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange insists that it is "keenly aware of the city's problems"; yet its decision to cancel plans to build a new headquarters at the tip of Manhattan and to step up its inspection of possible sites in other states suggests that the board thinks there is more to be gained by flamboyant threats than by quietly discussing its problems with the Mayor.
To a builder, a closet is a space, a horizontal pole and a door. A fancy closet is one with electric light.

DETROIT, March 18 (UPI) Car output topped 200,000 units last week for the first time since mid-December, Ward's Automotive Reports said today. Production pushed to 200,916, it said, as the American Motors Corporation reopened its Kenosha, Wis. assembly plant and built 7,676 cars.
WASHINGTON, March 18 New orders for durable goods dipped slightly in February but remained well above the level of shipments, the Commerce Department reported today.

SAN JUAN, P.R., March 17 Puerto Rico's pioneer program for organizing neighbors to help themselves plans to reach nearly 30 per cent of the island's population this year with the aid of Federal antipoverty funds. The hope is a rise to 40 per cent next year.

MOSCOW, March 18 (UPI) Aleksei Leonov, the Soviet cosmonaut who was the first man to float in space outside his spacecraft, said today that his movements had caused his six-ton Voskhod spacecraft to begin rotating unexpectedly.
Federal District Court Judge Wilfred Feinberg was sworn in yesterday as a member of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit by Chief Judge J. Edward Lumbard.
STAMFORD, Conn., March 18 Mrs. Doris Battles of White Plains has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Dianne Seymour, to Arthur Ashe Jr., son of Mr. Ashe of Richmond and the late Mrs. Ashe.

The West German Government has apparently observed all the diplomatic niceties in its deal that enables a consortium of private companies to sell Communist China $150 million in "non-strategic" steel works. It arranged that companies from other Western countries take a share in the transaction; ...

SAN FRANCISCO, March 18 The president of a small plastics manufacturing company and his foreman have been arrested by San Mateo County authorities in an industrial espionage case involving the planting of a microphone in a window frame over the desk of the president of a competing company.
MOSCOW, March 18 (AP)--Scientists who have examined the Soviet space dogs, Blackie and Breezy, reported today they had found "no symptoms of disturbances due to cosmic rediation."

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., March 17 James F. Egan, an account executive for Morton E. Segal Co. and formerly director of the labor relations board of the Ward Baking Company for 22 years, died in his home on Weir Lane Tuesday night. He was 60 years old.

THE newly elected presiident of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union is an articulate, businesslike man with a great capacity for the painstaking work that is required to run the complex operations of a 447,000-member union.

The John Birch Society charged yesterday that a police official had "harassed and intimidated" policemen who belong to the society and had improperly "ordered them to produce names of other policemen whom they know to be members."
The Buildings Department ruled yesterday that a sculpture suspended over the grand foyer or Philharmonic Hall did not obstruct an escalator, and thus did not violate the Building Code.
TOKYO, March 18 (Reuters) Japan Air Lines and All Nippon Airways announced today a reduction in their flights between Tokyo and Osaka following three air crashes in the last six weeks.
WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) An Army private, Robert Luftig of New York City, is challenging, in a court suit, the Government's right to send him to Vietnam.

BUKAVU, the Congo When a non-Congolese finds mag- ic in the name Congo, he is probably thinking of this city, which lies on the green shores of Lake Kivu, a caressing hand, its fingers pointed out toward the lake's clear surface.
WASHINGTON, March 18 (UPI) The House reclamation subcommittee today approved legislation to turn Grand Coulee Dam in Washington into the world's most powerful hydroelectric project.

LYME, Conn., March 18 Mrs. Hester Bill Brown, widow of Randolph F. Brown, who had been vice president of the Bill Brothers Corporation, publishers of trade magazines, died of a heart attack yesterday at her home here on Salem Road. She was 73 years old.

The Church sees it as its most serious duty to safeguard and protect the gift of faith in its married couples as well as in its children. And for this very reason it tries in every way to see that Catholics join in matrimony only with Catholics.
The black nationalist group whose arms cache was discovered this week was merely a 10-to-12-man splinter of the Black Arts Repertory Theater, according to the police.
WASHINGTON, March 18 The United States Chamber of Commerce told Congress today that taxes should not be increased to combat inflation this year or any other year.

That Russian contribution to operatic verismo, Shostakovich's "Katerina Ismailova" made its seasonal entry at the New York State Theater last night under the auspices of the New York City Opera. Accordingly, the stage was given over to seduction, lechery, murder, adultery, suicide and a succession of wholly unpleasant characters.

Noel Harrison, the 32-yearold son of the stage and film actor Rex Harrison, will be costar with Stefanie Powers next season in "The Girl From U.N.C.L.E." on the television network of the National Broadcasting Company.
WASHINGTON, March 18 The R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company rolled back a price increase on cigarettes today at the urging of President Johnson.

WASHINGTON, March 18 The National Gallery of Art's 25th anniversary celebration, which may go down in history as the only time the usually sedate museum resembled Grand Central Terminal in a rush hour, was inadvertently upstaged socially last night by members of the very family who made both the gallery and the celebration possible.
The Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale announced yesterday the appointment of a Paulist priest to the staff of the American Foundation of Religion and Psychiatry.

YES IS FOR A VERY YOUNG MAN," one of Gertrude Stein's last works, was given its television premiere last night by the Theatre Company of Boston on Channel 13. The two-act play affirms Miss Stein's stature as one of the larger bores of her time and proves once again that as a playwright, she always was a better self-publicist.
Newsprint mills on the North American continent set a record for production in February.
Prize gems in an extraordinary collection of jewelry were silently fought over yesterday at an auction that set a new record for the valuable trinkets of a single owner.

WASHINGTON, March 18 Chief Justice Earl Warren, 75 years old tomorrow, favors compulsory retirement for aging Federal judges but not until the two other branches of the Government adopt compulsory retirement rules.
Simmonds Precision Products, Inc., has announced in Tarrytown, N.Y., the election of Douglas M. Coombs as a vice president and general counsel.
The British pound fell slightly in moderately active trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday, closing at $2,7954, a drop of 4 points from Thursday.
PARIS, March 18 It took four formal meetings and continual informal consultations for 14 NATO countries to produce their declaration on France.

BRUSSELS, March 18 (AP) The Social Christian Premierdesignate, Paul Vanden Boeynants, told King Baudouin tonight that he had finally reached agreement with the Liberals on a coalition cabinet, ending the 36-day Belgian Government crisis.
COPENHAGEN, March 18 (AP) Osvald Helmuth, Denmark's greatest musical-hall comic who strode the boards for nearly 60 years, died tonight. He was 71 years old.

Robert Friede, 25-year-old grandson of the late Moses L. Annenberg, former publisher of The Philadelphia Inquirer, pleaded guilty yesterday to second-degree manslaughter and unlawful possession of heroin.
WASHINGTON, March 18 A broadcasting union is threatening to black out television and radio broadcasts from the White House on two networks.

The Republican leaders of the State Senate and Assembly told Mayor Lindsay yesterday that his tax program did not stand a chance of passage in Albany unless the city's 15-cent transit fare was increased.
The wholesale commodity price index maintained Thursday the level of 113.4 it reached Wednesday.
STANFORD, Calif., March 18 Prof. B. Davie Napier of the Yale Divinity School has been appointed Dean of the Chapel at Stanford University effective next fall.

Prince Philip touted British merchandise yesterday after assuring a group of business men that British merchants, sometimes considered stodgy, were now quite ready to "jump through a hoop and dye their hair pink to make a sale."
COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 18 (AP) Gov. Roberto Sanchez Vilella of Puerto Rico called today for a vote to determine the future relationship between his island home and the United States.

Pope Paul VI's reformulation of the regulations governing marriage between Roman Catholics and persons of other faiths is characteristically cautious. It is a response to the prevailing ecumenical spirit and to progressive thinking within the Church, but it is a limited response.

One way to win a bet at the race track is to look around for a jockey with the same name as yours, play him regardless of form, then go to the window and collect. That's exactly what John Martin of Nassau County did in the third race at Aqueduct yesterday.
