General Super Markets, Inc. and the Supermarkets Operating Company have obtained a show-cause order against opponents of their proposed merger, it was announced yesterday.
BOSTON, March 18 (UPI) Federal and state mediators met with representatives of six nonstriking unions today in an effort to settle the 13-day Boston newspaper strike.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., March 18 Mr. and Mrs. Abbas Ordoobadi have announced the engagement of their niece, Miss Shirin Estakhri, to Count Alexander von der Pahlen, son of Count and Countess Freidrich Konstantin Johan von der Pahlen of Buenos Aires. The wedding will take place in Europe in late spring.
John E. Green, insurance underwriter at Lloyd's, popularly known as Lloyd's of London, died of cancer Thursday at his home in London. He was 66 years old.

ORLANDO, Fla., March 18 While Gary Player was being eliminated and Sam Snead's score was leaping to 76, Gardner Dickinson took the 36-hole lead today in the $110,000 Florida Citrus open golf tournament. A second round of 68, three under par, gave Dickinson an aggregate of 137 on the Rio Pinar Country Club course.

The legal section of the Buildings Department, it was learned yesterday, has prepared a questionnaire asking its inspectors for details on any multiple dwellings owned by them, their spouses or children. It does not mention in-laws.
Red measles is looked upon by most people as a fairly harmless disease that most children must suffer during their growing years. But measles can be a crippler and a killer.
WASHINGTON, March 18 Representative Joseph Y. Resnick, Democrat of New York, doubled this week as an inventor.

COLLEGE PARK, Md., March 18 At 10 o'clock last night Larry Conley, one of Kentucky's basketball stars, was running a fever of 102 degrees. He was given a chest rub, made to breath over a vaporizer for two hours and put to bed under three blankets. The fever broke about 2 A.M.
TUSCALOOSA, Ala., March 18 Senator Kennedy completed his day by flying here to the scene of another famous Federal-state confrontation, the University of Alabama, for a second speech.
OXFORD, Miss., March 18 Senator Robert F. Kennedy, once an object of general hatred in this state, was greeted with brimming cordiality today at the University of Mississippi.

Several concerns announced plans for expansion yesterday. The Tennessee Corporation, a subsidiary of Cities Service Company, said it would begin work soon on a sulphuric acid plant at Augusta, Ga., estimated to cost nearly $3-million.
The first integrated or door-todoor American-flag overseas container ship service was started here yesterday by United States Lines.
HOUSTON, March 18 A quick solution to the cause of the Gemini 8 failure appeared in the offing today.

ONE of the virtues of Chinese cooking and it is a cuisine that abounds in virtues that appeal to the palate is the rapidity with which some of the choicest dishes are prepared. This pertains particularly to dishes made with the technique called stir-frying, and the number of dishes made with this technique are legion.
The closed-circuit telecast of the March 29 bout between Cassius Clay and George Chuvalo in Toronto was banned in Boston, Miami Beach and San Antonio yesterday.

Conference, New York City Department of Welfare branch, National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, Brotherhood in Action Center, Seventh Avenue at 40th Street, 9:30 A.M. Luncheon, noon. Speaker: William H. Booth, chairman, New York City Commission on Human Rights.
LONDON, March 18 Prime Minister Wilson laid down unyielding conditions tonight for British entry into the Common Market.
Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary is going to go calling on New Yorkers in their homes.

BOSTON, March 18 (AP) Doug Barkley, a defenseman for the Detroit Red Wings of the National Hockey League, was resting comfortably today after undergoing a second operation for an eye injury suffered in a recent game.

ALBANY, March 18 The state has quietly begun to transfer more than 600 inmates from institutions for insane criminals to civil hospitals. It is taking them out of the prison hospitals to comply with a recent United States Supreme Court decision.

Mrs. Albert Fried, president of the National Women's League of the United Synagogue of America, will be honored by the league's Brooklyn Branch at a luncheon Monday at the Deauville Caterers at 3939 Shore Parkway, Brooklyn.
HOLLYWOOD, March 18 (AP) Lynda Bird Johnson, spending her 22d birthday weekend with George Hamilton, the actor, today joined him in a tour of MGM studio where he works.
HERTFORD, N.C., March 18 (UPI) A group of about 100 Negroes staged a 14-mile march to nearby Edenton today to dramatize alleged social injustices "all over North Carolina."

WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP)--Despite prospects of somewhat larger demand for food overseas, farmers have reported that they intend to plant about two million fewer acres for 1966 production than the 307 million acres they used last year.
FIFTY years ago this month, the Forum Exhibition of Modern American Painters opened in the old Anderson Galleries on East 40th Street.
Banks in Pittsburgh, Detroit, and Oakland., Calif., have increased the rates they are offering to pay on individual time and savings deposits.
A public hearing on the condition of Jewish religious and cultural life in the Soviet Union was held yesterday at the Carnegie International Center, opposite the United Nations headquarters.

WEST NEW YORK, N.J., March 18 Brother Alban Aloysius, a member of the Christian Brothers Order, who taught mechanical drawing at the St. Joseph's Catholic Boys High School here since 1961, died yesterday at Christ Hospital in Jersey City. His age was 70.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, March 18 Juan Bosch, president of the Dominican Revolutionary party, disclosed today that its executive committee had called a national convention April 9 to decide whether to participate in the elections set for June 1.

ELIZABETH, N.J., March 18 C. Arthur Oakley of 545 Chilton Street, a stationer and a civic leader for 50 years here and a former member of the board of directors of the Elizabethport Banking Company, died today at the Elizabeth General Hospital. He was 83 years old.

Twelve members of the National Renaissance party, a neoNazi group, held a public meeting last night before a generally hostile audience at the Robert F. Wagner Junion High School, 220 East 76th Street in the Yorkville section.
THOMAS DUNN'S Festival Orchestra gave its penul- timate concert of the season in Philharmonic Hall last night. As usual there was interesting repertory and a fine soloist.

SYDNEY, Australia, March 18 (Reuters) Jim Grelle of Portland, Ore., clipped 1.8 seconds off the Australian 2,000meter record tonight. Grelle, 29 years old, running in the rain over a track covered by more than an inch of water in places, was clocked in 5 minutes 7.4 seconds.

OLD BROOKVILLE, L.I., March 18 Mr. and Mrs. S. Reed Anthony have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Magdelaine Richmond Anthony, to Charles Clifford Cullen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Cullen of Malverne.

TORONTO, March 18 Canadian newsprint producers, criticized in the past as an oligopoly with power to administer prices, have apparently run into administered prices themselves in the form of President Johnson's price guidelines.

Chas. Pfizer Co., Inc., the drug maker, is entering the aerospace and electronics business through the purchase of the Space Age Materials Corporation for 23,992 shares of Pfizer common stock worth about $1.7-million, it was disclosed yesterday.
SAIGON, March 18 A company of South Vietnamese Government troops repulsed an attack by a Vietcong battalion last night on a camp in the vicinity of Hue, 400 miles northeast of Saigon.

DARIEN, Conn., March 18 Rinks representing the Canadian Club of Boston, skipped by Peter Lee, and the Riverside (New Brunswick, N.J.) Curling Club, skipped by Thomas Foster, won quarter-final matches in the annual Nutmeg Curling Club mixed bonspiel for the Golden Handle Trophy today.

WASHINGTON, March 18 The index of wholesale primary market prices was unchanged at 105.2 of its 1957-59 base during the week ended March 15, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. Farm products and processed foods declined in price, while industrial commodities advanced.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 18 Roger Maris made his 1966 debut, Al Downing made a discouraging type of mistake and Joe Pepitone drew a reprimand but no fine today as the New York Yankees began a five-game "home stand" by losing to the Atlanta Braves, 7-0. The Yankees made only two hits for the second day in succession.

A PLAYER who has to make the opening lead against a no-trump contract should not automatically lead his longest suit. If his hand is weak, lacking in side entries, there is little point in establishing a suit.

The Paul Kuentz Paris Chamber Orchestra, which made its local debut under Mr. Kuentz's direction is the Metropolitan Museum of Art's Rogers Auditorium last night, turned out to be very much worth bringing over.

A new opera of some stature, considerable color and great volumes of sound was introduced last night when the Opera Theater of the Manhattan School of Music gave the premiere of Nicolas Flagello's ...
SOFIA, Bulgaria, March 18 Last month 99.85 per cent of Bulgaria's voters elected all 415 candidates of the Fatherland Front to the 416 seats in the People's Assembly, the Parliament.
An increase of $201-million from January 31 to the end of February in customers' netdebit balances carried by New York Stock Exchange member firms was disclosed yesterday.

TUCSON, Ariz., March 18 (AP) The Cleveland Indians of the American League scored five runs in a six-hit fifth inning today, and beat the San Francisco Giants of the National League, 6-2. The loss was the first for the Giants after six straight exhibition victories.
PHILLIPSBURG, N.J., March 18 (AP) On Nov. 16, 1910, Andrew N. Arvesen, just out of the Navy, went to work for New York City's old IRT Subway Company as an electrician at $2.50 a day.

WASHINGTON, March 18 The United States joined today with all its North Atlantic Treaty allies except France in declaring that both the treaty and its principle of military integration were "essential" to Western security.
Stockholders of the Clark Oil and Refining Corporation approved yesterday at a special meeting in Milwaukee a previously proposed 2-for-1 stock split of the common shares.
WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) President Johnson announced today he wants to put an Indian, Robert LaFollette Bennett, in charge of the Interior Department's Bureau of Indian Affairs.

WASHINGTON, March 18 Communist China was described before the Senate Foreign Rela- tions Committee today as a military "paper tiger," incapable at present of carrying out a program of expansionism and desirous of avoiding a military confrontation with the United States.
The promotion of Jared J. Cummins to vice president from assistant vice president was announced yesterday by the Reinsurance Corporation of New York.
A two-week retrospective program of movies bby Albert Lewin, the director-writer-producer, will start Tuesday at the Gallery of Modern Art.

An inspector for the State Labor Department was arrested yesterday on a charge of having demanded and accepted a bribe from a hotel owner. The inspector was identified as Irving S. Vichinsky, 44 years old, of 2485 East Seventh Street, Brooklyn.

BEIRUT, Lebannon, March 18 The Baghdad radio reported today that four generals and a colonel had been discharged from the army in neighboring Syria and that one of the generals had been arrested. Two others were already in jail.
With nearby deliveries hitting new seasonal highs for the fifth successive day, futures prices of Maine potatoes were 21 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) higher to a point lower yesterday.
WINTER PARK, Colo., March 18 (AP) Ray Miller of Ogden, Utah a member of the National Alpine ski squad won the giant slalom race today at the National junior ski championships.

The Erie Forge and Steel Corporation of Erie, Pa., was reported yesterday to have made an offer to acquire the Park Drop Forge Company of Cleveland in an exchange of stock valued at more than $15-million.
All drugs approved as safe by the Food and Drug Administration before 1962 are now to be screened for effectiveness, it was announced in Washington yesterday.
If a brokerage firm has a "large position" in a company the "best advice" is not to put out a market letter on the stock Lawrence M. Greene, treasurer of the Dreyfus Corporation, said yesterday.

MOSCOW, March 18 The Soviet Government newspaper, Izvestia, urged today the establishment of an international commission to verify the discovery of a United States hydrogen bomb off Spain and to observe raising of the 20-megaton weapon.

Events today: "The Barber of Seville," Metropolitan Opera, 2 P.M.; "Street Scene," New York City Opera, 2:30; Vienna Choir Boys, Town Hall, 2:30; Cosmopolitan Young People's Symphony, Brooklyn Academy, 2:30; Lenore Engdahl, pianist, Town Hall, 5:15.

CLEVELAND, March 18 Bob Seagren, a handsome, 19year-old student at Glendale (Calif.) College, broke his twoweek-old world indoor record for the pole vault tonight. He cleared 17 feet inch in the 26th annual Cleveland Knights of Columbus meet.
A Queens bus driver who helped a policeman in trouble with a hostile crowd has been paid for the time he spent testifying in court, the Transit Authority said yesterday.
Benjamin Franklin and De Witt Clinton, the only unbeaten teams in the Public Schools Athletic League, moved into the semi-final round of the city basketball playoffs yesterday.
The New York and the American Stock Exchanges reported yesterday changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of listed companies.

NORMAL, Ill., March 18 (UPI) Five records fell tonight in the college-division swimming and diving championships. National collegiate team standings, firmly dominated, by California schools, remained unchanged with the defending champion, San Diego State, in the lead.

MAMARONECK, March 18 The poorest neighborhood in this generally affluent community is facing another summer with its youth center still unfinished because the volunteers who were building it have run out of money.
ORANGE, N.J., March 18 (AP) One fireman was killed and 11 persons injured 10 of them firemen in a fire here tonight that destroyed a sixstory apartment house and another building under construction.

BOGOTA, Colombia, March 18 "We don't need a general on horseback or a donkey and we are not going to have one," a typically apolitical army officer declared at dinner the other night. He was referring to the former dictator, Gen. Gustavo Rojas Pinilla, who has re-emerged as an important factor and has cast a shadow over the national elections to be held Sunday.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, March 18 President Sukarno finally gave in tonight to demands for a purge of leftists in the Indonesian Government.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 18 Every day for the last two and a half weeks, the 53 New York Mets in training here have been awakened by a telephone call at 7 A.M., have had breakfast in a private dining room, have left by bus for the ball park at 9, have started ...

Montgomery Ward Co., one of the nation's largest operators of retail merchandising and catalogue businesses, achieved a 10 per cent increase in earnings on a 3 per cent sales gain in the fiscal year ended Feb. 2, Robert E. Brooker, president, reported yesterday.
The Federal Aviation Agency has agreed to a 30-day test in two cities of a new air traffic procedure proposed by airline pilots last January to reduce the danger of mid-air collisions.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) Representative Bob Wilson, Republican of California, charged today that a Democratic party book lauding Johnson Administration accomplishments had been compiled by Federal employes.

It is something of an anachronism, and an extraordinary one at that, that the volunteer, unpaid fire department has survived so extensively in the suburbs around New York City. These companies number into the hundreds and they do an excellent job, as a rule, thanks to the sacrifice of time and convenience of the men who serve, on call day and night.
A maverick strategy in the antipoverty program designed to supplant the whole public welfare system has begun to take shape in New York and other cities in the last few months.
The London Stock Exchange closed the week with narrowly mixed changes yesterday. Business was light as weekend influences and pre-election uncertainties combined to curtail buying.
MIAMI, March 18 The national champion, Jim Nolan of Chicago, today won the 1966 mid-winter international Sunfish doubles championships over a 24-boat fleet.

The First National City Bank, New York's largest bank in overseas operations, is continuing to branch out. The Federal Reserve Board has announced approval of branches for the bank in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, and Piraeus, Greece.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 18 Less than two years after bitter fighting ended in the Congo, the former Belgian territory is stable enough to permit technical assistance forces to turn over their work gradually to the Congolese.
Bond prices dipped early yesterday, influenced by the Federal Reserve figures on banking system reserves and business loans, but they later recovered and closed with gains from Thursday.
SEA CLIFF, L.I., March 18 Theodore Sheridan Clark, president of the Sheridan Division of the Harris-Intertype Corporation, died yesterday at Stratton, Vt. He was 68 years old.

WHATEVER would Peter Stuyvesant have thought, on whose farmland St. Mark's Church-in-the-Bouwerie was originally built? What, for that matter, would Dr. William Norman Guthrie have thought, who at the beginning of the century introduced pagan frescoes and Greek dancing into the church to increase congregations?
The South Shore National Bank, Quincy, Mass., and the Wellesley National Bank, Wellesley, Mass., announced yesterday that their directors had approved the terms of a merger plan.
The Studebaker Corporation indicated yesterday that directors might consider dividend payments in cash or stock to common shareowners.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) Federal agencies were told by the Civil Service Commission today that they should make public the names, titles, grades, salaries and duty stations of Federal employer when such information is requested.

Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Schmidt of Sonderborg, Denmark, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss. Elin Schmidt, to Dr. Peter Ashley Philips, son of Dr. and Mrs. Milton B. Philips of Mount Vernon, N.Y.
The Collins Radio Company has announced the election of Robert D. Johnson as a vice president. He continues as a regional general manager.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 18 (AP) Carol Mann of Towson, Md., shot a par 71 in the second round of the $10,000 St. Petersburg women's open golf tournament today to take a one-stroke lead with a 139 total.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) President Johnson was told today that Latin America was trapped in a vicious circle in which social discontent discouraged economic development and the lack of this development built up tensions.

The Police Department said yesterday it had made it more difficult for division commanders to post "raided premises" signs in bars and other establishments and to put uniformed patrolmen in places so designated.
RALEIGH, N.C., March 18 (AP) T. Lamar Caudle, par doned by President Johnson for a Federal conviction, filed today for the Democratic nomination in North Carolina's Eighth Congressional District.

Wall Street brokers generally applauded yesterday the New York Stock Exchange's cancellation of plans to build a $50million headquarters in lower Manhattan in the face of a threatened increase in stocktransfer taxes.

According to the famous "Body of Liberties" which was adopted by the Great and General Court of Massachusetts in 1641, "Every man ... shall have liberty to come to any Town meeting, and either by speech or writing to move any lawful, seasonable, and material question."
WASHINGTON, March 18 A sweeping attack on jet aircraft noise was proposed to the President today by his chief science adviser.
WASHINGTON, March 18 The White House, after raising last-minute objections, abruptly reversed itself tonight and accepted the terms of a new cultural exchange agreement with the Soviet Union.
SALT LAKE CITY, March 18 A Federal judge issued a preliminary injunction today halting enforcement of an obscenity law enacted last month in the city of Provo.
Owens-Illinois, Inc., the glass producer, announced yesterday in Toledo, Ohio, the appointment of W.A. Schaich as vice president in its administrative division.
The American Stock Exchange ended the week on an upbeat yesterday as the market advanced on a broad front in stepped-up trading.

When the New York Stock Exchange decided Thursday to cancel plans for a new Broad Street headquarters it raised a cloud of questions over the future of a six-block downtown area questions that may not be answered for weeks or months.
Red Auerbach will jump off the Boston Celtics' bench at Madison Square Garden for the last time tonight as the New York Knickerbockers face the perennial National Basketball Association champions.

The McCrory Corporation disclosed yesterday the terms of its exchange offer for the common stock and convertible subordinated debentures of S. Klein Department Stores, Inc. McCrory owns about 19 per cent of Klein's common stock and has announced it is seeking majority control.

Shareholders of the Witco Chemical Company, Inc., met here yesterday and approved a management proposal to merge the Kendall Refining Company into Witco. Kendall will now become a wholly owned subsidiary of Witco.
The time has come, Theodore Mann said yesterday, to overhaul Off Broadway. "Otherwise," he said, "it will evaporate."
SAIGON, March 18 Fifteen South Vietnamese peasants were killed today and four wounded when a Vietcong mine exploded on a dirt road in the rich ricelands 240 miles northeast of Saigon.
Eighteen years ago a New York University basketball team reached the final of the National Invitation Tournament only to lose to the St. Louis Billikens.
WHAT'S new, "PousseCafe"? Answer: Nothing good. The musical of that name, which opened last night at the 46th Street Theater and which I saw at its last preview, is dismal.

BETHESDA, Md., March 18 Prof. Leon Carroll Marshall, an educator, a Government official and an author, died today at Suburban Hospital here. He was 87 years old last Tuesday. His residence was in Chevy Chase.
MINNEAPOLIS, March 18, (AP) Michigan State, gained the National Collegiate Athletic Association hockey tourney final with a 2-1 victory over Boston University tonight.

MOSCOW, March 18 (UPI) The Russian Chief Justice who sentenced two Soviet authors to prison for having published anti-Soviet books abroad was heckled publicly by a large group of Soviet writers, informed sources declared today.
The city's Board of Elections split sharply yesterday on the possibility of holding a primary election in the latter part of June.
WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) United States exporters were forbidden today to send Rhodesia virtually any commodities useful to its economy.

Mayor Lindsay's tax program has raised some novel constitutional problems because the city is attempting to tie the new personal income and business taxes to the state taxation system. There is excellent reason for doing this, for economy of administration and for taxpayer convenience. And it is important that a sound legal approach be preserved to avoid later litigation, or at least to minimize it.

ROME, March 18 The Vatican announced today retroactive cancellation of excommunications of Roman Catholics married by non-Catholic clergymen. A number of cautions and provisional changes in rules for marriages between Catholics and non-Catholics were also made public.
The nation's power production rose 9.3 per cent in the week ended March 12, compared with the level in the 1965 week, the Edison Electric Institute reported this week.
Jose Gonzalez of Arroyo, Puerto Rico, became the middleweight champion of West Jordan, Utah, last night with a 12round unanimous decision over the bull-necked, barrel-bodied Don Fullmer.
Louis Stulberg, a 64-year-old former garment cutter, was elected yesterday to succeed David Dubinsky as president of the 447,000-member. International Ladies Garment Workers Union.
STOWE, Vt., March 18 In weather close to being summery and on snow close to being slush, Switzerland's Alpine skiers ran wild in the opening event of the national championships today.

HAVANA, March 18 (Reuters) Drinking, dancing and dirty jokes the enticements that some Western capitalist embassies here offer their guests, according to Premier Fidel Castro were barred today to most Cuban officials under new Government regulations.
The Brooklyn classis of the Reformed Church in America took issue this week with a proposal that Protestants and Roman Catholics join Jews in observing the sabbath one Saturday instead of Sunday.

CINCINNATI, March 18 The United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit handed down today an opinion setting aside a 1960 Federal Trade Commission ruling ordering the Procter Gamble Company to divest itself of the assets of the Clorox Chemical Company acquired in 1957.

A legislative battle between diverse waterfront interests will open in Albany on Monday when action is expected on measures to change the rules under which the Waterfront Commission polices the Port of New York.

GENEVA, March 18 The Federal Court in Lausanne today found three men guilty of having resorted to terrorism in seeking to redress what they hold to be an injustice done the Jura region of Switzerland by the Congress of Vienna in 1815.
The Rev. Guy Louis Morrill of 77 Seventh Avenue, a retired Presbyterian minister, died Thursday at the College Nursing Home, Flushing, Queens. His age was 92.
WASHINGTON, March 18 In the United States Court of Claims the following proceedings were had today:
NEW DELHI, March 18 A committee of India's Parliament recommended today that the northwestern state of Punjab be divided to establish a Punjab-speaking state.

CAIRO, March 18 (UPI) A Soviet-built Egyptian airliner with about 30 persons aboard crashed and burned in a sandstorm tonight while coming in for a landing at Cairo Airport. Persons at the scene said there were no surviviors.
The Police Department sealed off 14 Greenwich Village blocks to most motorists last night, but not without complications.

"Demonstrations of the tea ceremony will be held here every afternoon," said Koji Kamiya, a Japanese architect. He pointed to an unlikely spot in the bustling, second-floor lobby of the Union Carbide Building.
Stock prices edged forward yesterday as the market extended its cautious recovery through the third consecutive session. Trading again was light by recent standards.
Three young brothers were killed and their mother critically injured by a two alarm fire that destroyed their two-story house at 43-11 20th Road, Astoria, Queens, yesterday.

SAIGON, March 18 South Vietnam's ruling military junta voted at a meeting today to make no concessions to anti-Government Buddhist agitators so long as it is under Buddhist pressure. A communique issued after the threehour meeting said the generals had resolved to defeat Communist aggressors, to build democracy, to make the social revolution work and "to improve the people's living conditions."

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 18 The Government banned the antiapartheid Defense and Aid Fund today. Detectives raided the offices of the fund and home of persons connected with it. No arrests were made.
Mrs. Enid Tribe Oppenheimer, a physiologist at Columbia University's Institute for Cancer Research, died yesterday at her home, 1050 Fifth Avenue. She was 80 years old.
Thomas D. Campbell, one of the world's largest wheat growers, died yesterday in Pasadena, Calif., where he lived. He was 84 years old.

Gerald J. Dean, who had been a partner in Naylor, Foster, Dean Aronson, formerly a law firm here, died of a heart attack Thursday in the Bethesda General Hospital in Boynton Beach, Fla. He was 71 years old and had been living in Delray Beach, Fla. He had long been a resident of Larchmont, N.Y.

Four major lumber associations reported an increase of 7.4 per cent in production for the week ended March 12, compared with the level reached in the corresponding 1965 week. Output fell three-tenths of 1 per cent from the preceding week.
WICKLIFFE, Ohio, March 18 Nine youths were arrested here last night for harassing students and hitting a rabbi at the Telshe Yeshiva College in this Cleveland suburb, according to the police.
A total of 391,107 daily jobs were filled by longshoremen in the port last month the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor reported yesterday.
THE RIVERBOAT, Empire State Building, Fifth Avenue and 34th Street. Glenn Miller's Orchestra, directed by Buddy DeFranco.

The short-interest position of issues traded on the New York Stock Exchange rose to 10,642,174 shares on March 15 from a revised total of 10,373,123 shares in mid-February, the exchange reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 18 The Federal Government, local communities and private agencies must take swift action to save rapidly vanishing open space in urban areas, a Government report said today.
WASHINGTON, March 18--President Johnson met for two hours today with civil rights leaders in what was apparently a general discussion of racial problems.

YONKERS, March 18 Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Fortchern Keating have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anne Mercedes Keating, to Stephen Edmund Carl Hintz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Hintz of Eugene, Ore.

COLLEGE PARK, Md., March 18 Kentucky demonstrated its right to the No. 1 ranking in the nation tonight by beating the No. 2 team, Duke, 83-79, in the semi-finals of the National Collegiate basketball championship.

WASHINGTON, March 18 Waste fluids from the Rocky Mountain Arsenal, pumped into a 12,000-foot-deep shaft, appear to have caused a series of minor earthquakes near Denver, Colo., since the spring of 1962, the United States Geological Survey said tonight.

The Board of Education's decision to curtail purchase of textbooks produced by the strikebound Kingsport Press in Tennessee when other books "of equal value" are available violates the principles of sound educational leadership.

"Absolutely horrible" operating results in the first two months of 1966 and the resignation of his vice president in charge of marketing were announced yesterday by Robert M. Morris, president of the Wheeling Steel Corporation.
"WE'RE not afraid of expensive clothes that are truly young," said Jean Rosenberg, vice president of Henri Bendel and formerly buyer for Bendel's Fancy, the store's designer ready-to-wear salon.

Three representatives of the National Student Association left yesterday for Saigon to gather the views of South Vietnamese university students on the war, United States policies and on the viability of their own Government.

Mr. and Mrs. Robert B. Kolodney of West Hartford, Conn., and New York have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Lynn Kolodney, to Paul S. Magid. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Magid of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Palm Beach, Fla.

HOLLYWOOD. FROM Talkeetna, Alaska, to Okefenokee, Ga., there will soon be, courtesy of the electronic age, two new household words: "chutzpah" and "Zero." It's a world Sholom Aleichem never dreamed of when Zero Mostel, resplendent in a tuxedo and color TV, comes tripping onto the stage of "Carol + 2" and hugs red-headed Carol Burnett and kisses carrottopped Lucille Ball for his network appearance in a one-hour CBS special at 8:30 P.M. Tuesday.

A LECTURE series, model Long Island gardens, a contest for grade school art ists and an educational program presented by high school students will highlight this year's Long Island Garden Show. It opens Saturday at Roosevelt Raceway, Westbury, and will continue through April 3. The event will be sponsored by the Long Island Nurserymen's Association and will feature 65 competitive classes.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., March 19 In Our Lady Help of Christians Roman Catholic Church today, Miss Nancy Ann Wittel, daughter of Fred B. Wittel and the late Mrs. Laura B. Wittel, was married to Michael Raymond Deddish Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Deddish of Pelham, N.Y.

MANILA, March 19 (UPI) Gabriel (Flash) Elorde, the world junior lightweight champion, floored Ismael Laguna of Panama twice tonight and went on to gain a unanimous 10round decision in a nontitle fight.

Mayor Lindsay's transportation plan has drawn such heavy criticism from both flanks it goes too far; it does not go far enough that he and his aides have been reinforced in their conviction that they must be doing something right.
Strong curbs on Rockland County apartment developments, described in a recent study as poorly planned, have been urged by the Rockland County Planning Board.
Loring Revere Hoover, a retired lawyer and investment banker, died Friday at the Polyclinic Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived at 21 East 27th Street.

"WHAT is the current state of the American short story?" I was asked by a student of mine the other day. I have something of a reputation as a shortstory expert, based mainly on the fact that L. Rust Hills once kept a story of mine for six months before rejecting it. The student has something of a reputation as an applepolisher.

It was vital for France's fourteen allies to meet General de Gaulle's challenge to NATO with a reassertion of Atlantic unity, as they now have done. But their joint declaration that the present military organization of the alliance is "essential and will continue" is a statement of faith that unfortunately evades reality.

STEWARTSVILLE, N.J., March 19 Dr. and Mrs. Joseph C. Humbert have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Emilie Herold Humbert, to William Curran Mules. His parents were the late Mr. and Mrs. Paul B. Mules of Baltimore.
WASHINGTON, March 19 Anthony J. Travia, the Speaker of the New York State Assembly, is being actively advanced here to fill a $30,000-a-year vacancy on the Federal District Court bench in Brooklyn.
SAIGON, March 19 An important by-product of the growing American involvement in South Vietnam is the commercial and industrial training the people of the country are receiving.

A BREEZE sprang up and the fog began to disappear, luckily for Andrew Jackson and his motley army awaiting the British attack below New Orleans on Jan. 8, 1815. Jackson's backwoodsmen could now give full effect to their long rifles, which had far greater range and accuracy than the enemy's muskets. That day the Americans won a "miracle victory."
The appointment of Edward Schmeltzer as managing director of the Federal Maritime Commission was announced last week by John Harllee, chairman of the regulatory agency.
UNION, N.J. March 19 A new $1-million theater for the performing arts will be dedicated at Newark State College here at 8:30 P.M. Monday.

BONN, March 18 West Germany's Social Democratic party has sent a scathing reply to an "open letter" from East Germany's Communist party that called on the socialist parties to cooperate in seeking the reunification of Germany.

"Yes, Virginia, there is an Alliance for Progress." Hardly anything has been heard of it recently; but anniversaries have their uses and it is five years since President Kennedy made his historic speech to the Latin-American diplomatic corps in Washington outlining the concept and giving it a name.

Arnold (Red) Auerbach, excited, exciting inventive and always brilliant, said goodby to Madison Square Garden last night just the way you might have expected. His Boston Celtics routed the New York Knickerbockers, 126-113, and kept their title hopes alive.

The seventh Boy Scout Gala for the benefit of the Greater New York Councils of the Boy Scouts of America will take place on May 16 in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. Mrs. Joseph P. Binns is general chairman of the dinner dance.

ST. ALBANS, England March 18 "Do you believe in a Socialist Britain?" a young man in the audience of college students asked aggressively. It was clear that he did and that he doubted that the Labor candidate did.

A luncheon will be held in the Grand Ballroom at the Plaza on March 30 to celebrate the 10th anniversary of the women's division of the American Society for Technion, the Israeli technological institute.
ATLANTIC CITY, March 19 (AP) Hackensack High beat Woodrow Wilson of Camden, 57-52, in the Group IV semifinal of the New Jersey State Athletic Association basketball tournament tonight.

ORLANDO, Fla., March 19 The admission tickets sold today for the $110,000 Florida Citrus open golf tournament were all stamped: "At 3 o'clock take an orange juice break." By that hour, Gardner Dickinson had absorbed enough sunshine and pars to keep the thirdround lead at the Rio Pinar Country Club course.
SAIGON, March 19 A company of United States marines was attacked by Vietcong guerrillas this morning near Danang, 380 miles northeast of Saigon.

GREENVILLE, L.I., March 19 The audience in the Little Theater at C.W. Post College, grew silent as five teen-agers wearing surgeon's caps, marks and gowns, filed out of the wings and onto the stage in front of a red velvet curtain.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 19 Miss Kathleen Ann Brady, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Brady of Southport, Conn., was married this morning to Lieut. (jg.) Jay Noel Whiting, U.S.N., son of Mr. and Mrs. W.W. Whiting of Wausau, Wis.

DAMASCUS, Syria, March 19 (AP) Syria rejected today a protest by the United States concerning an American citizen who was kept incommunicado in a Syrian prison for almost two years after crossing the frontier from Israel

PUNTA ARENAS, Chile Some of South America's most majestic and savage mountain scen ery awaits the visitor to this southernmost region of the hemisphere. The main attraction is, by far, the Paine Mountain range, which rises up dramatically from the edge of the windswept, grassy plain.

A.D. MANSFIELD, the Alexandria, Va., dog show superintendent, and James A. (Jim) Cowie of Commack, L.I., a Scottishborn long-time professional handler of gun dogs, took important steps last week. Mansfield sold his business. Cowie retired.

Cost reductions that were the aim of a little-noticed provision of the National Housing Act of 1965 and of new lending authority for savings and loan associations are beginning to trickle down to home buyers.

THE discovery that present-day American thinking about China remains a conglomerate edifice of truths, half-truths, assumptions, legends, prejudices and contradictory opinions is hardly a piercing insight. The estimate that United States China policy, once labeled by The Economist as "that masterpiece of diplomatic immobility," may now be outdated scarcely ranks as a breakthrough in political reporting.

DALAT, South Vietnam, March 19 (UPI) South Vietnam's first woman mayor took office today in this central highlands resort, 140 miles north of Saigan. She is Nguyen Tyu Hua, a 48-year-old mother of three.
PARIS, March 19 (AP) Abie S. Nathan, the Israeli peace pilot who flew to the United Arab Republic last month on a peace mission at his own initiative, is not going to see President de Gaulle.
RIVER VALE, N.J., March 19 Anisette Schneider, a 15year-old high school freshman from Brooklyn, had the most successful day in her short riding career at the Holiday Farm Horse Show today.
ROCHESTER, March 19 (AP) The Karavan team of Rantoul, Ill., fired a 2,903 series tonight at the opening of the American Bowling Congress tournament to take first place in the regular team division.
NEW DELHI, March 19 The arms embargo on India by Western countries is hampering India's efforts to strengthen her defenses against the threat of Chinese aggression, the Defense Ministry said today.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 19 The smallest state in the Union offers a small prize for a small slogan for its 1967 automobile registration plates.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP) President Johnson has signed a bill providing for the appointment of 45 additional Federal judges 35 for the District Courts and 10 for the Circuit Courts of Appeals, the White House announced today.
ATHENS, March 19 The Greek Government announced today that it planned to hire American management to replace Greek bureaucracy and speed economic development.

PHOENIX, Ariz, March 19 (AP) Tomas Koch of Brazil and Joaquin Loyo-Mayo of Mexico upset Arthur Ashe and his teammate, Dave Reed, 6-3, 6=4, in a Thunderbird tennis tournament semifinal doubles match today.

Miss Jacqueline Coates, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Fletcher Coates of New York and Chatham, Mass., and David Clayton Spinney of DorChester, Mass., son of Mr. and Mrs. Clayton W. Spinney of Marblehead, Mass., were married here yesterday in the Friends Meeting House according to the custom of the American Society of Friends.
The Navy's Military Sea Transportation Service has invited bids from the maritime industry for a number of longdistance towing jobs.

A New York rabbi charged yesterday that the "sacred cow of consensus" was beginning to displace the "sacred cause of individual conscience and conviction" in relation to this country's policy in Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, March 19 The biennial selection of the 41 men and women who give New York State much of its image on Capitol Hill will get under way unobtrusively early next month. The nominating petitions that begin circulati.ng on April 5 will open up another chance for the state's voters to reshape still further the delegation that represents them in Congress.
WASHINGTON, March 19 One of the greatest torrents of mail to strike Congressional offices in recent years has been generated by an issue that most of the public is completely unaware of.
Steam and diesel, the present standard methods of merchant ship propulsion, may start giving way to the gas turbine the seagoing equivalent of a jet aircraft engine in about five years.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 19 19 An 8-month-old tricolor Cherrivale Pit, owned and bred by Mr. and Mrs. Gustave Sigritz of Lebanon Ohio, was selected best of 120 puppies in the Collie Club of America Futurity today.
The Macdougal Street area of Greenwich Village was tense last night as the police continued their drive to clean up the cabaret and coffeehouse district.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 19 A new menace of city life "mental pollution" is rapidly becoming more pernicious than air or water pollution, according to the World Health Organization.
PHILADELPHIA, March 19 Flyswatters, soap, razor blades and powdered drinks are being collected for servicemen in Vietnam by a Temple University coed club called XYW.
ATHENS, March 19 Greek officials fear a new crisis in Cyprus today after Gen. George Grivas, the island's Athens-appointed defense chief, defeated President Makarios's bid to curb his powers.
The New York Urban League will hold its first Frederick Douglass Awards Dinner on May 2, in the Imperial Ballroom at the Americana.

SCATTERED signs that the camera industry has been receiving some public encouragement for the production of darkroom equipment and accessories were noted at the national trade show held recently in Cleveland. A few exhibitors estimated that the increase in darkroom activity over the last few years possibly runs as high as 10 per cent.
BRUSSELS, March 19 A center-right coalition Government took office tonight, ending a political crisis that had caused widespread anxiety.

PATERSON, N.J., March 19 Mrs. Jean Cohen Serwer has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Cathi Lee Cohen of New York, to Norman Karr, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sol Kartzevitz of Jackson Heights, Queens.
BALTIMORE, (UPI) Palm Court, a filly up from the claiming ranks, romped to a five-length victory in the $28,050 Nellie Morse Handicap over six furlongs at Pimlico today.
BALBOA, Panama, C.Z., March 19 The quick beaching of the Norwegian freighter Pacific Express after the ship had struck a rocky section of the Canal bank late yesterday prevented her from sinking.

The American bald eagle is the nation's proud symbol. But its home is in the wild, lonely places, and the relentless outward push of civilization erodes its habitat. At the rate at which this great bird is disappearing, the eagle may soon become a bitter symbol of man's carelessness toward his fellow creatures on this planet.

Most apartment seekers make at least casual reference to the floor plans provided by building owners. Using these outline charts, anyone looking for an apartment can tell at a glance the size and number of the rooms and their relationship to each other.

BIRD IN HAND, Pa. Here in Lancaster County, below the high-speed Pennsylvania Turnpike and above U.S. 30, the congested Lincoln Highway, motorists are more likely to encounter horsedrawn vehicles than anywhere else in the country. They are the buggies and wagons of the Old Order Amish, a strict religious sect centering in this vicinity. The Amish, in accordance with their religious beliefs, neither own nor operate automobiles.
LISBON, March 19. Portugal warned her allies in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization today against bringing about a situation that would make negotiations for French cooperation impossible.
A luncheon and fashion show will be given on Saturday in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria by the National Tay-Sachs Association.

An electrifying closing rush by the King Ranch's Seaman thrilled the crowd of 50,023 at Aqueduct yesterday. Competing in the $28,250 Paumonok Handicap at six furlongs, Seaman overtook the top-weighted Time Tested in the final yards and won by a neck over Dinny Phipps's representative, with the Grace Creek Farm's Amastar next, four lengths back.

PICASSO is not an unknown quantity at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 76th Street and Madi son Avenue; but until very recently Debussy was at least as a commodity. Consequently there was some apprehension last year at the gallery when a patron suggested that its main salesroom would make a rather elegant little concert hall during off-hours. Doubtless it would, certain officials said to themselves, but concerts at Parke-Bernet? Is it really ... us?
The volume of new bond issues for sale last week seemed formidable as Wall Street headed into its heaviest schedule on record last Monday.
SAIGON, March 19 The threat of Buddhist demonstrations against the Government of Premier Nguyen Cao Ky evaporated tonight.
The United Nations Association of New York has scheduled a tour of private art collections for the afternoons of March 29 and April 2. The association's educational program will benefit.

February shipments of acetate yarn and rayon by United States producers in February came to 117.5 million pounds, or 1.5 per cent below the 119.2 million pounds shipped in January, the Textile Economics Bureau, reports.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., March 19 The Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Kenneth G. Neigh have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Judith Ann Neigh, to Walter David Gierhart, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack F. Gierhart of Royal Oak, Mich.

AS if Venice weren't beautiful enough to be one of the world's major tourist attractions, it will institute a Verdi Festival next summer. From midJuly through August it will present a cycle of the composer's works at various sites throughout the city.
WINTER PARK, olo., March 19 (AP) Mike Porcarelli, 15 years old, of Wakefield, Mich., won the boys slalom crown today in the national junior ski championships.
Generally good weather prevailing at a time when spring apparel is the main feature in the nation's stores has helped retail figures to reach substantially higher levels than a year ago.

MOST gardeners assume that bamboo will survive only in tropical climates, mainly because it grows in many jungles throughout the world. Just a brief glance at a world map, however, will show that New York City lies on the same latitude as the northern parts of Japan, Korea and China, all regions of intense winter cold and of dense stands of bamboo, many of which have been in existence for centuries.
Cargill, Inc., will soon start construction of a 3.5-millionbushel grain elevator on the Houston Ship Channel to handle expected increases in grain exports.
The nation's top cigarette makers, beset by rising tobacco costs, endeavored last week to give their financial ledgers a healthier glow by raising the wholesale prices of most cigarette brands.
AUSTIN, Tex., March 19 The one-party government of President Johnson's political allies in Texas faces a double challenge this year from the liberal Democrats at the left and the Republican right.

A 110-year-old music company whose profits began to mount when it decided to "dediversify" during the Depression was added to the Wall Street roster recently with the listing of its shares for the first time on the New York Stock Exchange.
RICHMOND, March 19 (AP) Edward F. Gahan, a former newspaperman and public-relations man died yesterday at the age of 50.
HOLLYWOOD, March 19 (AP) Lynda Bird Johnson, who turned 22 years o fage today, celebrated the event at a small, private party in the home of her current escort, George Hamilton, the actor.

YONKERS, March 19 Cardigan Bay, the 10-year-old New Zealand bred gelding, who has earned $368,750 since he arrived here in February, 1964, will be among the starters in the $100,000 International Pace at Yorkers Raceway April 14.

LISBON, March 19 Portugal marked on Tuesday the completion of five years of costly guerrilla war in Africa with no prospect of peace in the near future. The Portuguese press hailed national sacrifices 'and called for a continued struggle.

CAIRO, March 19 The race to save the temples of Abu Simbel from the rising waters of Nasser Lake is going so well that the reconstruction of the temples on high ground will be completed two years ahead of schedule, according to project officials.
The stock market's speedy five-week slide deepened to 9 per cent in the averages early last week before a rebound occurred, but there wasn't much bounce in the upswing.
HONG KONG, March 19 In Communist China today, when it comes to treating the sick, witches are out but eels' blood is in.

HO-HO-KUS, N.J., March 19 Mr. and Mrs. James L. Monley have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Lynne Monley, to M. Reid Macfarlan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Malcom V. Macfarlan of Hawthorne.
THE theme of this year's National Coin Week, Friendships Flower Through Numismatics," could be appropriately converted into "Coin Collectors Flower Through Research."

PLAINFIELD, N.J., March 19 The marriage of Miss Barbara Welles, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Sherrerd Welles, to Daniel Arthur Edwards Jr., son of Mrs. Lucy Genero Edwards, took place this afternoon.
Paul R. Screvane is reported to be under consideration for the post of New York regional administrator of the new Department of Housing and Urban Redevelopment.

The nation's electric housewares industry stands poised for a "tremendous" breakout this year and in years to come, according to Willard H. Sahloff, vice president and general manager of the housewares division of the General Electric Company, Bridgeport, Conn.

A 120-MILE steel rightway between Burling ton and Bellows Falls will be the scene of a "Vermont Steam Weekend" on April 30 and May 1. This route comprises two segments of the old Rutland Railroad, which is now operated under different names by different owners.
WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP) Chief Justice Earl Warren celebrated his 75th birthday tonight at what he called "the first birthday party I've had since I was a boy."
ATHENS, March 19 Greek and American experts hope to discover Helike, an ancient Greek town that vanished 2,339 years ago in the Gulf of Cor inth.

ANGKOR, Cambodia Hidden deep in the jungles of central Cambodia are the mag nificent ruins of the vast temple-city of Angkor. Although the United States has no diplomatic relations with Cambodia at present, the Cambodian Government still welcomes and encourages Americans to visit these monuments to the great Khmer civilization, which flourished between the 9th and 12th centuries.

CHAPPAQUA, N.Y., March 19 Miss Melinda Weld Herbert and Charles Weston Greenlee plan to marry July 16. Mr. and Mrs. Joseph M. Herbert have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles P. Greenlee of Allison Park, Pa.

In St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church at 404 East 87th Street yesterday afternoon, Miss Carmela M. Barbuto, daughter of Mrs. Agazio Barbuto of Wallingford, Conn., and the late Mr. Barbuto, was married to Prof. John I. Griffin, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. John A. Griffin of New York.

LUXEMBOURG For the hurrying American tourist, Luxembourg is the place to slow down and relax. It is no bigger than Rhode Island, and one can see a great deal of its lakes, rivers, forests and castles in a single day of easy driving.
ACCRA, Ghana, March 19 After years of facing to the East and campaigning for a "socialist" revolution in Africa, Ghana minus Kwame Nkrumah is now trying to walk a diplomatic tightrope.

FOURTEEN Manhattan Chess Club Stars, a notable assemblage of the country's finest talent, are currently contending in the club's annual round robin. New York's famous Manhattan, probably the strongest chess club in the Western Hemisphere, was founded in 1877. It has always been the proving ground for play at the highest level.
DARIEN, Conn., March 19 Miss Elizabeth Burleigh Johnson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Richard Johnson, was married today to John Theodore Larson, son of Mr. and Mrs. John O. Larson.

MANY trees, shrubs and vines are dioecious, that is, the male or staminate (pollen bearing) flowers and the female or pistillate (fruit-producing) flowers are borne on separate plants. Thus the gardener who buys woody plants without regard for this may be in for some disappointments.

DARIEN, Conn. March 19 Mr. and Mrs. Francis J. Pataky have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Charlotte Pataky, to Charles Packard Henderson Jr. He is the son of Judge Henderson of the Mahoning County Probate Court and Mrs. Henderson of Youngstown, Ohio.

Walter Kennedy, the president of the National Basketball Association, rejected a protest by the New York Knickerbockers yesterday and ruled that the Bullets had won Thursday night's rough contest at Baltimore, 118-113.

GUATEMALA, March 19 One of the most precious allies that people with money and power have in Latin America, is Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba. He is to them what the scarecrow is to the farmer. Two elections a month apart have illustrated this thesis in Central America. Last month in Costa Rica and this month in Guatemala, Communism became the main issue most of it illegitimate and spurious.

MADISON, N.J., March 19 Miss Susan Elizabeth Wight, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Welles Wight, was married today to Jeremiah Carter Poinier, son of Mrs. Robert Sargent of Summit and John Poinier of Short Hills.

Once more, last week, astronauts soared above the atmosphere and gazed at the heavens in their stark beauty, undiminished by the filtering effects of the atmosphere. But since human eyes only see some wavelengths of light, what the astronauts saw did not seem particularly remarkable. If they could have seen other wavelengths, such as x-rays, they would have seen a very different sky.

WHO have been the major 20th-century poets writing in English? So far, at least: Yeats, Pound, Eliot and Wallace Stevens. The recognition of Stevens is the most recent. Three of the poets are linked. Stevens stands alone, much like his contemporary of long neglect, the composer Charles Ives. Both men were willing to stick to insurance for a living and to free their compositions for posterity.

Igor Ter-Ovanesyan of the Soviet Union broad jumped 26 feet 10 inches yesterday in an indoor track and field meet at Leningrad, according to a report received here from Tass, the official Soviet press agency.
ARZEW, Algeria, March 19 President Houari Boumediene reaffirmed here today Algeria's determination to control all foreign capital invested in the developing oil and gas industry.

WESTERLY, R.I., March 19 Mr. and Mrs. Robes B. Perry of Westerly and Weekapaug have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lynn Hartley Perry of New York, to David Arthur Harding, son of Mrs. H. Arthur Harding of Clayton, Mo., and the late Mr. Harding.

TOKYO Seven countries of eastern Asia Japan, South Korea, Nationalist China (Taiwan), Hong Kong, Macao, the Philippines and Thailand have formed a regional organization to promote tourism to and within the area. It is called the East Asia Travel Association, and it will have permanent executive offices and a secretariat in Tokyo.

GAINESVILLE, Fla. The Florida State Museum, a branch of the University of Florida, has received a $1,112,642 grant from the National Science Foundation for the construction of a new museum building costing $2.2-million. The 1965 State Legislature appropriated $350,000 for the project, and an additional $800,000 will be raised by private subscription.
LOS ANGELES, March 19 The Watts Towers, a 100-foothigh system of spires constructed by an immigrant tile setter, are emerging as the focal point of an ambitious experiment in "social engineering."

MADRID, March 19 A tubular object, presumed to be a missing United States hydrogen bomb, was gingerly shifted along the Mediterranean Sea bottom today to prevent it from vanishing in a submarine canyon.
Construction in New England in 1965 aimed at the $2.5-billion mark and just missed.
Texas Western upset topranked Kentucky, 72-65, and won the National Collegiate championship last night at College Park, Md.

ALBANY, March 19 (AP) Governor Rockefeller was portrayed as a red-suited Santa Claus pondering his future. Senator Robert F. Kennedy was depicted as the leader of a band of swaggering Democratic "pirates." A terrifying lottery vampire lusted for the "taxpayers' blood."
ALBANY, Calif., March 19 (AP) Lush Life and Gamin scored upset victories in the split divisions of the San Francisco Mile at Golden Gate Fields today.
MOSCOW, March 19 (AP) Mikhail G. Pervukhin, pushed out of the Soviet leadership by Nikita S. Khrushchev nine years ago, has returned to prominence, Izvestia indicated today.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 19 Two new pitchers from whom the New York Yankees expect considerable help had their spring records somewhat tarnished today in the course of a 6-4 loss to the Chicago White Sox.

WASHINGTON, March 19 Congress is not the only location of a strong feeling that a succession of developments in the world has imposed the necessity of a truly objective over-all reappraisal of the foreign policies of the United States. Although President Johnson, Vice President Humphrey and Secretary of State Rusk create the impression that this feeling is not shared in the Administration, it is an active subject of favorable discussion on the secondary policy-making level.

TOKYO, March 16 When Bin Akao draws respectful crowds of several hundred at one of the busiest intersections in Tokyo, some detached observers consider it a significant indication of the new mood appearing in Japan these days.

WASHINGTON, March 19 Negro leaders warned this week that citizens of the District of Columbia were finally nearing "an overt expression of frustration" over the refusal so far of Congress to grant an elected local government.
A new $1.25-million bus garage in Jamaica, Queens, has made the "Get-Even Special" from Aqueduct to Yonkers Raceway a sure thing.

NEW HAVEN, March 19 The wedding of Miss Elizabeth Rives Fowlkes and Richard Cushman Carroll Jr. took place today in the Marquand Chapel of the Yale University Divinity School. The bride is the daughter of Mrs. Randolph Crump Miller and the late Rev. Paschal Dupuy Fowlkes, Chaplains Corps, U.S.A. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. Carroll, associate dean of Yale College, and Mrs. Carroll.

BOSTON Although almost any Bostonian with the price of a round-trip plane ticket heads for Florida during the winter, 550,210 of them took the subway recently to see the city's first Winterfest, a cultural romp that filled the new War Memorial Auditorium.
EDINA, Minn., March 19 Miss Karen Janet Gilfillan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John B. Gilfillan, was married today to Jerome James Monasch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome A. Monasch of New York.
One meet record was broken land another tied in the championship events of a New York senior metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union swimming meet yesterday at the New York Athletic Club.
The over-the-counter market continued to lose ground last week in quiet trading.
ENCINTO, Calif., March 19 (AP) Buster West, dancer and comedian in vaudeville and on Broadway, died yesterday of a brain tumor. He was 64 years old.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand There is an obvious connection between General de Gaulle's progressive withdrawal from Eastern and Western alliance commitments. His staged retreat from SEATO provoked few loud complaints since that pact has always been relatively flabby. However, the accelerated snipping of French ties with NATO has brought the free world to the edge of crisis. NATO, unlike SEATO, is of primordial importance.
An art auction and brunch will be held at the Pierre on April 17 at 12:30 P.M. to benefit the New York Society for Ethical Culture and the scholarship program of the Ethical Culture schools.

UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., March 19 Miss Candace Ann Shedd and Robert Michael Vancko, graduates of Pennsylvania State University, were married this afternoon in the university's Helen Eakin Eisenhower Chapel. The Rev. Richard Wentz performed the Unitarian ceremony.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 19 (AP) Superior Court Judge Charles Fairhurst has ordered Harvard University to retain Samuel B. Bowles, an economics instructor, on the faculty pending final determination of the constitutionality of the Massachusetts teachers loyalty oath.

OTTAWA, March 19 (AP) Abolition of all tolls on the St. Lawrence Seaway, improved navigation on the St. Lawrence River, and facilities to speed ship traffic in the Lelland Canal were urged Thursday by the Dominion Marine Association.

HERE'S a complicated and a dull subject, but an important one: the problem of repeats. A repeat in music is a note-fornote restatement of a portion of a composition, directed by the composer. In standard sonata form, for example, the exposition is almost always supposed to be repeated. In Bach movements, especially those in binary form, repeat signs ask the performer to replay each section. And so on.
MIAMI, March 19 The Cuban Government, concerned about the slowness of the sugar harvest, is mobilizing a vast labor force from the cities.
It has been estimated by the Government that threefourths of the people working in the United States by 1975 will be dealing with products that do not even exist today.
