RYE, N.Y., March 19 Miss Lucia Lorraine Elmore and Ross Coleman Santy plan to marry in June. Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Elmore have announced their daughter's engagement ho he son of Dr. and Mrs. Albert C. Santy of New York.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 19 The engagement of Miss Edith Hill Postlewaite to Noel E. Hanf has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. David M. Postlewaite, her parents. Mr. Hanf is the son of Mrs. Noel E. Hanf of Ossining, N.Y., and the late Mr. Hanf.

The survival kit that is issued to soldiers and airmen in Vietnam is making some news on its own. It contains just about everything a soldier might need in an emergency, ranging from dysentery pills, bouillon cubes and various medicines to a fishing kit, a sewing kit and a saw.
LOS ANGELES, March 19 That quadrennial political circus called a California campaign is in full cry again, producing surprises galore for a fascinated, it bewildered, audience of millions.

STAMFORD, Conn., March 19 Miss Alice Ann Buckley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice J. Buckley, was married this afternoon to John Handly Caldwell, son of Mrs. Perry Wilgus of Marion, Ind., and the late John Caldwell.

MIAMI, March 19 Jim Nolan, the national champion, won the final two singles races today in a rally that earned him the over-all title in the 1968 mid-winter international Sunfish championships on Biscayne Bay.

RUMFORD, R.I., March 19 Mr. and Mrs. Charles Crosley Horton have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Kingsley Horton, to Arthur Ingraham 3d, son of Mr and Mrs. Ingraham Jr. of Providence and Little Compton.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 26 American literature is getting wider circulation in Eastern Europe today than ever before because of the initiative of a United States Information Agency officer and some Yugoslav publishers.
SEOUL, South Korea, Sunday, March 20 (UPI) The National Assembly approved today sending 20,000 more troops to join anti-Communist forces in South Vietnam. The reinforce will go in June or July.
WILMINGTON, Del., March 19 (AP) Hugh Martin Morris, a former United States District Court judge and an authority on patent law, died today at his home here. He was 87 years old.

ROSELLE, N.J., March 19 Brother John William of the Marist Brothers of the Schools, a teacher of religion and French at Roselle Catholic High School since 1962, died of pneumonia Thursday in St. Elizabeth's Hospital, Elizabeth. He was 27 years old.
LOS ANGELES, March 19 "Watts cannot pull itself up by its own bootstraps. Watts has no bootstraps."
SYDNEY, Australia, March 19 New Guinea natives who keep to the tribal customs have decided to introduce standard prices for buying brides.

LONG before Andre Malraux analyzed contemporary appreciation of art in terms of the photograph, Japanese photographers were creating with great skill and imagination an "imaginary museum" of those objects of art which respond best to interpretative treatment.
The city will build a 200-bed mental health center for Yorkville and East Harlem; Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday.

THE debate revolves about these two of the 10 original Amendments to the Constitution known collectively as The Bill of Rights: Article I, which provides that "congress shall make no laws respecting an establishment of religion ... or abridging the freedom of speech or of the press ..."; Article VI, which provides that "In all criminal prosecutions, the accused shall enjoy the right to a speedy and public trial, by an impartial jury...."
For the last three weekends, in competition or just fooling around, Bob. Seagren has polevaulted 17 feet. Twas not always thus. He thinks his vault of 6 feet 1 inch may have been more worthy.

Ann Clary Engaged To Hugh D. Graham GREAT FALLS, Mont., March 19 Mr. and Mrs. Robert Ford Clary Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ann Clary, to Hugh Davis Graham, son of Dr. and Mrs. Otis Graham of Greenville, Tex. A spring wedding is planned.

PARK RIDGE, N.J., March 19 In Our Lady of Mercy Roman Catholic Church this afternoon, Miss Karen Jeanne Patricia Bald, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Bald of Hillsdale, was married to Frederick Michael Ackerman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick P. Ackerman of River Edge.

LET'S not tell the children (even though they probably suspect it), but just the thought of visiting a hospital for repairs unnerves most adults. The banks of operating room lights, like so many giant flies' eyes, the cold, impersonal machinery terrifying. Maybe we are the ones who need something that soothes and smoothes the way. As a book that prepares the child for the hospital this new "Curious George" is one of the best.

Valuable real estate is where you find it or detect it. Sometimes this takes a bit of deduction. In New Jersey recently, careful study by two young investors led to the imminent moving of a river and to the moving of a boundary between two towns.
MENLO Park, Calif., March 19 Mrs. Harold J. Noble has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Joyce R. Noble, to David Freiberg, son of Mr. and Mrs Sidney Freiberg of New York.

WINER HAVEN, Fla., March 19 The first time Tony Conigliaro stepped into a batting cage in a Red Sox uniform was at the Arizona training camp two years ago. Heralded as the finest Boston prospect since the arrival of Ted Williams more than a quarter of a century earlier, the big youngster was extremely self-conscious because his debut was being studied appraisingly by Williams himself.
WASHINGTON, March 19 (UPI) A trial examiner for the National Labor Relations Board ruled today that the double royalty the United Mine Workers tried to collect on nonunion coal was illegal.
The onrushing popularity of the Batman ranging from toys and a Life Magazine cover to a television show helped to push shares of National Periodical Publications last week to a new high of 45 .
HARRISBURG, Pa., March 19 "I never thought I'd live to see the day when Pennsylvania would have a labor shortage, but that's what we've got."

THOMASVILLE, Ga., March 19 St. Thomas Episcopal Church was the setting tonight for the marriage of Miss Fontaine Maury Flowers, daughter of William Howard Flowers Jr., a State Senator, and Mrs. Flowers of Thomasville and Highlands, N.C., to Thomas Garcin Parker. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Macdonald Parker of Greenwich, Conn., and Smith's Parish, Bermuda.

SEA CLIFF, L.I., March 19 Sailing to windward like a witch, Marshal (Skip) Moorhouse of the Cooper River yacht Club fleet of Collingswood, N.J., led after three races today in Sea Cliff Yacht Club's 13th annual spring Penguin Frostbite Regatta.
SCARSDALE, N.Y.,March 19 The marriage of Miss Jane Dillon McDermid, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Manewal McDermid, to Sten Anders Wiberg of Nassau, the Bahamas, took place this afternoon.

MOSCOW, March 19 (Reuters) Andrei D. Sinyavsky, Russian writer jailed for publishing stories satirizing Soviet society, has written an essay in prison on two of the world's greatest satirists, informed sources said today.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 19 Mr. and Mrs. Walker W. Stevenson Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Stevenson, to Francesco D. Copello of Florence, Italy. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Francesco Copello of Santiago, Chile.
The Negro is slowly finding his way onto Madison Avenue, but apparently is still not convinced the road to advertising is really open to him.

WARSAW, March 19 (AP) United States diplomats have told Polish officials that it would provoke a hostile reaction from the American public to bar Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski from a planned trip to the United States in August or to keep United States Roman Catholic leaders from attending the May 3 celebration of 1,000 years of Christianity in Poland.
IN flipping through the temptation-laden pages of the latest wish book otherwise known as a sporting goods catalogue to come to hand, the eye fell on an item worth more than its weight in gold.

WASHINGTON, March 19 "The Grown-Ups: What They're Really Like," written under the influence of Newsweek's March 21 cover story, "The TeenAgers: What They're Really Like," and several hundred other journalistic and television studies of American youth.

HOMESTEAD, Fla. The tourist traveling along the interior roads of south Florida at this time of year often gets the impression that the entire area is covered by a series of enormous commercial farms. This is not too far from the truth, if one excepts the intervening Big Cypress Swamp and the sawgrass Everglades.
NEW BRITAIN, Conn., March 19 Miss Jane Fluke Tisher, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Paul Winslow Tisher, was married tonight to Robert Porter Powell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Walrath Powell.

HAVERFORD, Pa. March 19 Diehl Mateer Jr. of Bryn Mawr, pa., and Ralph Howe of Oyster Bay, L.I., won two matches in straight games today in reaching the semi-final round in defense of their United States squash racquets doubles championship at the Merion Cricket Club.
WASHINGTON, March 19 The National Commission on Food Marketing has knocked out of its recommendations' for regulating the food industry a proposal to prohibit trading stamps.
Teachers in the city schools, who were absent in the first week of the January transit strike will be paid for the days they missed, Theodore Lang, deputy superintendent of schools, said yesterday.
DENVER, March 19 The Army announced today that it was "speeding up" a study to determine whether deep-well disposal of poisonous wastes from lethal nerve gas had been causing earthquakes here.

A truck bearing a 20,000-ton generator rumbled across a new bridge in East Pakistan recently. Soon after it passed, a herd of goats clattered over the same $1-million span, which is part of a $10-million road project supported by American aid.
The Berkeley campus of the University of California, which became a symbol of student revolt in 1964, now appears determined to lead the nation in academic reform.

EUGENE GENOVESE defines the issue his book is dedicated to in the following words: "Slavery came to look as [the] essense of a proper social order and therefore moral." These circumstances made the conflict between North and South irrepressible.

SAN JUAN, P.R., March 17 It was late at night when former Governor Luis Munoz Marin unexpectedly dropped into a beach colony in tiny Rincon for supper. Within minutes, the Mayor, other leaders and their families swarmed to greet "el vate" Puerto Rico's "bard."
LONDON, March 19 At the halfway mark in the campaign, all the signs point to a big victory for Prime Minister Wilson and the Labor party in the general election March 31.
The Securities and Exchange Commission got a soft, though not necessarily subtle, reminder from the brokerage firm of M.A. Schapiro Co. last week.

CONCORD, Mass., March 19 Mr. and Mrs. Harris Fahnestock have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Joan Whedon Fahnestock, to Morrie Ruvinsky. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. David Ruvinsky of Chomedy, Que.
BASINGSTOKE, England, March 19 (Reuters) An influenza epidemic sweeping parts of southern England has killed 23 women patients in one hospital near here.
WASHINGTON, March 19 Organized labor's effort to win legislation to east restrictions on picketing at construction sites is running into opposition on Capitol Hill.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 19 The amazing Mets carried Wes Westrum's inspirational campaign to heights that amazed even Westrum today, when Ron Swoboda pinchhit a home run in the 13th inning that defeated the Cincinnati Reds, 8-7.
WASHINGTON, March 19 Among the many adages of Wall Street, there is this one: Money runs from uncertainty.
WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP) House members spent $472,800 last year on trips that took them to almost every nation in the world.
THE experienced home craftsman who has power tools which enable him to make accurate woodworking joints usually will tackle building projects that include the construction of sliding drawers.
Few drugs have experienced so rapid a rise in use and so sudden a fall as DMSO, the industrial solvent that is said to be useful in treating almost any human ailment.
BONN, March 19 Hundreds of Western European companies may eventually take part in the consortium that will build a big steel-producing complex in Communist China, industrial sources said today.

LONDON The Atlantic Passenger Steamship Conference announced last week that steamship fares between North America and Europe would be increased by $15 during next year's high season and by $5 in the low season. Eastbound high season is May 1 to Aug. 7; westbound is July to Oct. 7.

NEW DELHI, March 19 Last Monday, in one of this city's crowded shopping areas, bearded, turbaned Sikhs in their traditional blue warrior's dress charged through the streets waving their long curved swords.
EUGENE, Ore., March 19 (AP) A young wife's courage and a quick dash by the police stopped a gunman from killing anyone last night.
The National Hemophilia Foundation will gain from a tour of five art collectors' homes April 12 from 1:30 P.M. to 5. The sponsor is the Foundation's metropolitan women's division.
The New York Times Weekly Index of Business Activity rose to 305.1 in the week ended March 12 from 288.6 a year ago. In the preceding 303.1.

WITHOUT even trying, a group of movie sets has become a major force in the develop ment of home furnishings design. They are disseminating today's most avant-garde ideas. Often, film viewers are seeing "the new" even before it is shipped to stores.
MINNEAPOLIS, March 19 Michigan State capped its tremendous comeback by crushing Clarkson, 6-1, tonight for the National Collegiate hockey championship.
Virginia took a step forward in the highly competitive area of industrial development during its General Assembly session ended March 12.
The United States Coast Guard has issued new regulations for all general cargo vessels under the United States flag that load bulk grain.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 19 A faculty member of the American University in Beirut left the country today amid a dispute that appeared to threaten academic freedom at the century-old institution.

A London real-estate firm that specializes in the sales of large estates in the British Isles is offering Mereworth Castle, one of England's most stately homes, which is owned by a great-grandson of Marshall Field Sr., the Chicago merchant.

NAHA, Okinawa, March 19 The heat-blackened Gemini 8 spacecraft will be flown back to the United States Monday. Its once shiny metal hull dulled by the intensive heat of re-entry into the earth's atmosphere, the two-ton capsule lay in two sections tonight in a closely guarded hangar at the Naval air installation near Naha.

A FIGURE bulking large behind the Turner show that opens Wednesday at the Museum of Mod ern Art is Lawrence Gowing, whose steady-on title is Keeper of British Paintings (a British-ism for "curator") at London's Tate Gallery. Gowing not only helped to put together the show of the 19thcentury artist's work, but wrote the dazzling catalogue essay and shepherded the pictures here.

LAS VEGAS, N.M. Out in the wide prairie about 29 miles north of New Mexico's own Las Vegas, far from neon lights, billboards and the roar of traffic, a first-rate and authentic slice of American history awaits visitors to the northeastern corner of this state.

The meat industry is up in arms over the export quotas for hides that the Department of Commerce has established to head off a domestic shortage. The quotas supplement a system of compulsory export licenses established earlier.

Meeting, Ethical Culture Society of Queens, Queens School, 83-96 117th Street, Kew Gardens, Queens, 11:45 A.M. "American Youth and Public Service: The Peace Corps and the Encampment for Citizenship," Douglas Kelley.
DETROIT, March 19 Mayor Jerome P. Cavanagh, brushing aside "pronouncements of some leaders that my time has not yet arrived," opened a primary battle today for the United States Senate.
WASHINGTON, March 19 The Federal Government has started a quiet but seemingly firm campaign against alleged religious discrimination in insurance companies.

Mr. and Mrs. Henderson Mathews of 120 East 71st Street and Brewster, N.Y., have made known the engagement of Mrs. Mathews's daughter, Miss Marion Speakman Holder, to Robert Edward Merritt. He is the son of Mrs. Elizabeth F. Merritt of Port Chester, N.Y., and the late Eugene F. Merritt.

LAKE GEORGE, N.Y. Motorists tooling along U.S. 9, which passes through this popular Adirondack Mountain community, have been puzzled over the activity around the excursion boat Ticonderoga. In the summer, this vessel makes a daily run up to Ticonderoga and back.
BONN, March 19 The West German Government's Science Council is revising its rating of degrees for medical education.

THE musical revue as changed a lot since the day Helen Morgan climbed down off the top of that piano and combed her hair. Chorus girls have been replaced by current events, terpsichore by topicality. Now five remarkably talented young men and three remarkably attractive young women mostly from South Africa have brought us "Wait a Minim," an ethnic carnivale which gives the revue formerly the bastard child of the legitimate theatrical family new status.
SANTA CRUZ, Canary Islands, March 19 (UPI) An engine-room explosion set off a fire today in an old Spanish tanker here, killing at least one person and injuring 10 others.

BOGOTA, Colombia, March 19 The leaders of Colombia's armed forces assured the nation in an announcement today that there would be no Army take-over regardless of the outcome of tomorrow's Congressional elections.
The ancient art of tattooing will find a friend in court tomorrow the New York Civil Liberties Union.

MOSS is perhaps the most neglected plant in American gardens. If it appears at random, it is likely to be raked away or dug out as a weed for its presence is thought by many as a sign of poor, acid or over-moist soil. Actually, moss is a versatile, ornamental plant. Gardeners need only take note of how moss is esteemed and employed in Japanese gardens to appreciate its potential in home gardens.
A suggestion that sales could be bettered if manufacturers would try to improve their relations with retailers was put before an American Management Association seminar on retailing a few days ago.

The Kimberly-Clark Corporation announced last week that it had developed a machine capable of producing tissue paper faster than ever before achieved on a tissue machine. The device is completing trial runs at the concern's consumer mill in Memphis.
LUSAKA, Zambia, March 19 President Kenneth Kaunda asked today for the political and economic support of the United States in the campaign to isolate and destroy the independent Rhodesian Government.

HONG KONG, March 19 The Soviet Union was reported today to be experiencing difficulties in shipping aid supplies to North Vietnam because of the recurrence of a dispute of last year with Communist China over transit arrangements.

MINNEAPOLIS, March 19 Vice President Humphrey said tonight that the Chinese Communists are making the surrender of Taiwan a condition for opening talks with the United States on any easing of relations between the two countries.

RYE, N.Y., March 19 Jim Prigoff of the City Athletic Club, seeded No. 1, and John Power's of D.K.E., seeded No. 2, won first and second round matches today in the second annual Rye Squash Barn Invitation squash tennis tournament.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 20 (AP) Bob Veale, a lefthander pitcher, drove in two runs with a single in the second inning, carrying the Pittsburgh Pirates to a 3-2 baseball exhibition victory over the Philadelphia Phillies today.
BILL RUSSELL, in talking to Bill McSweeny, has produced a fascinating book about himself. It is heartfelt, angry, sometimes disquieting and frequently instructive.

A 27-room stone mansion of Georgian design, together with a seven-room house of similar design, built in the late 1930's at Ridgefield, Conn., has been sold on a 12-acre tract to David Trompeter of Greenwich.

Since 1917 the Red Cross has been channeling the interests and energies of young sters into community service and civic responsibility through its school programs. For example, a sewing class might make garments for patients in a veteran's hospital, a cooking class might provide refreshments for a birthday party at a children's center, and a woodworking class might make tables for a hospital recreation room.

A Federal Aviation Agency official proposed last week a test of the ability of small planes and helicopters to furnish an emergency airlift into and out of New York's "inner city" in the event of a national defense or other calamity.
THE 15th year of United Nations postage stamps will be celebrated during the eighth International Stamp and Coin Show at the Americana Hotel, Seventh Avenue and 52d Street, which opens Friday.
Waterborne commerce in the United States last year rose to a new high of 1.26 billion tons.

WASHINGTON, March 19 One United States condition for the resumption of surplus food aid to the United Arab Republic was restrictions on the production of Egyptian cotton, which Cairo has been using to purchase Soviet arms, it was disclosed today.
Tickets for the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated.
Prince Philip of Britain and Mayor Lindsay of New York met for the first time yesterday and discovered they had much in common.

AGANA, Guam, Feb. 28 Inspired by the admission of Hawaii to statehood, political leaders of the 48,000 residents in the Territory of Guam are demanding more self-government and closer integration with the continental United States.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., March 19 E. Chester Peet Jr. won a six-race championship series frostbite regatta at the Larchmont Yacht Club today. A fleet of 29 Interclub dinghies raced in a light, erratic southwest breeze of three to eight knots.

Hearings on a bill to put the Post Office's parcel post business on a self-supporting basis and which threatens to put REA Express out of business began recently before the postal rates subcommittee of the House.
Pedestrians along the St. Lawrence River between Lake Ontario and Lake St. Francis have been reminded by the Department of Transport that the "only safe practice will be to keep off the ice."
MONTREAL, March 19 (AP) Second period goals by Claude Larose, Claude Provost and Bobby Rousseau carried the Montreal Canadiens to a 6-2 victory over the New York Rangers tonight.
The international motor-racing set has started its annual trek to Sebring, Fla., Where next Saturday the 15th 12-hour contest for sports, sports prototype and Grand Touring cars will be run.

PHILADELPHIA, March 19 (AP) The Philadelphia, 76ers clinched at least a tie for the Eastern Division title of the National Basketball Association tonight by edging the Cincin nati Royals, 127-121, for their 10th straight victory.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., March 19 Miss Marilyn Sayles Moore, daughter of Mrs. Arthur Gordon White of Los Angeles and Charles Sayles Moore, was married this afternoon to Gerald Francis Murphy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter J. Murphy of Bloomfield.

Inauguration of a roll-on, roll-off cargo ship service to Vietnam is one of the measures under consideration by military shipping experts to improve the supply situation, a high-ranking naval officer told a Congressional panel last week.

Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that Teodoro Moscoso, a leading Puerto Rican economist and former United States Ambassador, had been appointed a special consultant on Puerto Rican community affairs and economic development here.

WASHINGTON, March 19 Two Associate Justices of the Supreme Court, a pair of Cabinet members and the Rockefeller who would like to be Governor of Arkansas were among those at the Hilton Hotel last night for the second annual Bal du Futur.

MANY contract bridge tournament players complain bitterly about deals that have been manufactured by a computer, as they are for numerous major competitions. Players who have poor scores are happy to put the blame on the computer for the freakish or tricky nature of the deals with which they have had to contend.
Beginning tomorrow, Cleveland will play host to its largest industrial audience of the year.
Senator Jacob K. Davits will leave Tuesday on a goodwill tour of South America in a demonstration of bipartisan support for President Johnson's inter-American policies.

MOSCOW, March 19 (UPI) Lieut, Col. Aleksei A. Leonov and Col. Pavel I. Belyayev had to ski 12 miles last year after their pioneer Voskhod II spacecraft landed in the snow-covered Ural Mountains, the Soviet Union disclosed today.

FRANCONIA, N.H. Even if another snowflake does not fall in the Eastern ski country this season, the winter of 1965-66 is going to be looked upon by resort operators as one of the best on record. The reason is a cooperative weather pattern that kept the slopes and trails cloaked with cover through the season's first three months.

The receipt of eight shipbuilding orders last month, four for the construction of bulk carriers and four for the conversion of dry cargo ships, was announced here last week by Nippon Kokan K.K., Japan's only integrated shipbuildersteelmaker.

WASHINGTON, March 19 Mrs. Graeme Korff has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Alice Korff, to William Hall Boardman Jr. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Boardman of Chestnut Hill, Mass., and Sutton Island, Me.

The world's foremost players, from Australia, Europe, South America and the United States, compete for a record pot of prize money this week in the first tennis attraction offered at Madison Square Garden in three years.

Ogden Phipps's Buckpasser, the winner of the Flamingo and the favorite to capture the Florida Derby and the Kentucky Derby, has suffered a quarter-crack but remains a probable starter in the Florida Derby April 2 at Gulfstream Park, Eddie Neloy, the horse's trainer, announced yesterday.
MIAMI At the western boundaries of the painstakingly civilized resorts of Palm Beach, Boca Raton, Fort Lauderdale and Miami lies the ancient, enigmatic Everglades.

William H. Booth, chairman of the City Commission on Human Rights, acting under the investigative powers granted the commission last December, has informed 15 corporations, doing business with the city that he will insist on hiring without racial discrimination.

Apparel and outerwear accentuating British styling is gaining in popularity, reports from stores to resident buying offices indicate. Reports on various departments follow:

RECENT work accomplished in hybridizing camellias has made growers less dependent upon chance seedlings and mutations for new varieties. During the past few years, however, some exceptional chance seedlings have appeared.

THE oboe is not often called upon to perform a dazzling virtuoso role over the span of a whole album, but it does so in spades in the recent Columbia release, The Baroque Oboe, with Harold Gomberg as the star performer (ML 6232, stereo MS 6832).

HUNTINGTON, L.I., March 19 Mr. and Mrs. Karl H. Bonawandt have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Darron-Jo Ann Bonawandt, to Ray Rolston Hicks Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hicks of Madisonville, Tenn.

THE trouble with writing a first novel (like "The Ginger Man") that becomes a point of reference for critics is that it may come to act upon its author not as a stage in his progress but as a burdensome, ghost-ridden past from which he cannot escape. To complicate his life further, J.P. Donleavy had contrived, in Sebastian Dangerfield, a character whose energies had by no means been exhausted by the novel he agitated.
American Jews were urged yesterday to include a statement on the plight of Soviet Jews when they observe the Passover holiday in their homes.

COUSIN JOE, the sublime New Orleans blues singer who nightly slays what is left of the sporting crowd in the Vieux Carre, has in his capacious repertoire a song about a woman with a fiftydollar hat sitting on a nickel head. It took Stephen Longstreet, the author and illustrator of "Sportin' House," 30 years to put a nickel hat on a fifty-dollar head.
A 10-month delay in setting up a program of legal services for the poor here was attacked as "cruel" and "unforgivable" yesterday by Senator Robert F. Kennedy.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., March 19 Harvard and Princeton tied at three victories each in the intercollegiate courttennis tournament today at the Tuxedo Racquets and Tennis Club.
The chairman of Mayor Lindsay's Housing Task Force criticized the city administration yesterday for being too hasty in prosecuting violations of the housing code.

HARRISBURG, Pa., March 19 A golden retriever who ranked among the first 10 of the country's sporting dogs became best in show tonight in the 31st and largest event of the Harrisburg Kennel Club. He was Ch. Cragmount's Hi-Lo, owned by Mrs. Charles W. Engelhard of Far Hills, N.J. The judge who put him up, Col. Edward D. McQuown of Xenia, Ohio, could not have been more enthusiastic.

Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Ryan Ketcham of New York have announced the engagement of Mrs. Ketcham's daughter, Miss Judith Clap Riley, to Frederic Harold Mummert of San Francisco. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold L. Mummert of Camp Hill, Pa. A May wedding is planned.

MACOMB, Ill., March 19 (AP) Led by Richard Loyd, who won two events and placed second in all-round, Northwest Louisiana State dethroned Western Illinois for the National Association for Intercollegiate Athletics gymnastic championship today.

New York will get a new corporate citizen next week when Schlumberger, Ltd., moves its headquarters from Houston to 277 Park Ave.

In the publicity given Medicare before and after its passage, an equally significant program resulting from the Social Security amendments of 1965 has largely been overlooked. This is the revision of the Kerr-Mills program aimed at a complete system of tax-supported health care for all the needy.

WASHINGTON, March 19 It is almost an article of faith among Americans that decision-making is inevitably improved by increased reliance upon science. Nowhere is this more apparent than in the law's traditional deference to expert psychiatric evidence in determining the sanity of accused persons.

HOUSTON, March 19 A short circuit in the wiring of a maneuvering rocket was officially cited today as the probable cause of the failure of the Gemini 8 mission while the spacecraft was linked with a target craft in orbit Wednesday.

HAVING plucked a "Cactus Flower" from the Paris boulevards and transplanted it here with a green thumb to make other Broadway gardeners green-cheeked with envy, David Merrick happily reports that he's been gardening again in France in preparation for his 1967-68 harvest. Most of next season's crop is planted, some, in fact, already germinating nicely.

Mr. and Mrs. David Hale Halpern of 1095 Park Avenue have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Linda Halpern, to Freeman Arthur Shore. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Josselyn M. Shore of Kings Point, L.I. A late May wedding is planned.

The appointment of Jewett T. Flagg, a leader in the textile industry, as chairman of the fund-raising drive of the National Council on Crime and Delinquency was announced yesterday.
PRINCETON, N.J., March 19 (AP) The Central New Jersey Track Club of Chatham easily defended its New Jersey Amateer Athletic Union track and field titles in the annual indoor meet held at here today.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla. Spring vacationing in the Sunshine State has been growing at a rapid rate. In April, May and June of 1960, the tourist total, as estimated by the Florida Development Commission, was 2.7-million; in the same quarter of 1965, it was more than four million.

Mexican cuisine may not be the most subtle, but it is certainly one of the most interesting. Recipes are given here for a menu built around an incredibly appetizing flank steak stuffed with corn bread. Other dishes include savory seviche made with raw spiced fish, the well-known guacamole, a sauce and a dessert. Beer is recommended as the beverage for this meal.
SAN JUAN CAPISTRANO, Calif., March 19 (AP) St. Joseph's Day arrived again today and, true to legend and song, the swallows came back to Capistrano, right on schedule. Some came back ahead of time.

Paramedics technicians, nurses and the like receive some scientific and medical training but not the four-year medical education that M.D.'s do.
HELSINKI, Finland, March 19 More than two million Finns will begin voting tomorrow in a parliamentary election that may significantly alter the composition of Finland's coalition Government.

WASHINGTON, March 19 A planning study released today warned that population growth in the Washington area, the fastest-growing metropolis in the country, is causing "explosive expansion and consumption of land." It recommended steps toward a regional planning system.

Houston, March 19 (AP) The space agency showed tonight a color movie strip taken by the Gemini 8 astronauts Wednesday during their docking with an Agena rocket and their uncontrollable ride through space.

JOHN ARDEN, the English dramatist, who was born in 1930, studied architecture at Cam bridge and Edinburgh, but he began writing plays as a schoolboy. He was practicing as an architect when he was given his first professional play production a Sunday night performance by the English Stage Company of "The Waters of Babylon" in 1957.
HALLANDALE, Fla., March 19 (AP) Walnut Hill Farms' Pillanlelbun scored his first victory in the United States today with a smashing triumph in the $30,985 Green Valley Handicap at Gulfstream Park.

The Barnard College Club of New York is sponsoring a tour of six private art collections to be held on Saturday afternoon. Dr. Rosemary Park, president of Barnard College, is honorary chairman for the tour. Proceeds will go to the college's scholarship fund.

MADRID, March 19 France's disengagement from North Atlantic Treaty arrangements is enhancing the importance of Spain as a Western defense bastion.

A group of young homeowners and would-be owners who are trying to reclaim and restore a deteriorated but historic section of downtown Brooklyn have accused neighborhood banks of thwarting their efforts by refusing to grant mortgages.
The Brooklyn Longshoremen's Medical Center, which treated 19,773 patients in the year ended last September, is planning an expansion that would cost $750,000.
ATLANTA, March 19 Mr. and Mrs. Robert Lamar Craven have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Ann Craven, to Frank Hay Briggs Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Briggs of Pittsburgh.

PEPYS' DIARY AND THE NEW SCIENCE. By Marjorie Hope Nicolson. 198 pp. University Press of Virginia. $5. Samuel Pepys, a man of unbounded curiosity, kept a detailed diary, from 1660 to 1669, of his encounters and explorations. Much of his curiosity was directed toward the "new science" then emerging from myth and superstition.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 19 With the spring training period half over, here is a report on the leading "question mark" Yankees:

NEWARK, March 19 A state Young Republican committee investigating charges of racial and religious bigotry among the so-called "rat finks" in the organization heard charges today that prominent members sang anti-Semitic and racist songs on several occasions and an anti-Catholic lyric at least once.
CHICAGO, March 15 University administrators, having rediscovered their students, are not sure what to do about them.

KAZANLUK, Bulgaria Every May and June, the fields hereabouts are filled with pink and white roses. For this section of Bulgaria, between the Balkans and the Sredna Gora Mountains, is called the Valley of the Roses, and from here comes the rose attar that is the base of the best perfumes of Paris and the world.

COLLEGE PARK, Md., March 19 Texas Western, overlooked in preseason ratings last December, became the collegiate basketball champion for the first time by whipping longtime powerful Kentucky, 72-65, tonight in the final of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

Donated art auctioned on the evening of May 11 at the ParkeBernet Galleries will raise money for the new building and endowment fund of the Whitney Museum of American Art. The museum building is under construction at Madison Avenue and 75th Street.

THE Greater New York Orchid Society will hold a lecture on "The Art of Flower Illustrations" by Jeanne Holgate on Wednesday at the Hotel Lexington, Empire Room, at 8 P.M. Mrs. Holgate is the official artist to the Royal Horticultural Society Orchid Committee.

PARIS. TELEVISION and the transistor radio are having a mounting impact on the culture of the emerging nations of Africa. The latest developments in electronics have notably speeded up the evolution of communications on a continent where knowledge of the world often has not even extended to an awareness of a tribe a few miles away.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 19 (AP) The National Democratic Front announced today that it was pulling out of Venezuela's three-way Government coalition. The party was the minor partner in President Raul Leoni's regime.
PARIS, March 19 (UPI) French coal miners today joined the protests against President de Gaulle's economic policies.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 19 (AP) Marilynn Smith of Jupiter, Fla., made a run for the lead in the St. Petersburg women's open golf tournament today, but Carol Mann remained one stroke in front with a one-over-par 74 for a 54-hole total of 211.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 19 Mrs. Benton A. Bull of Princeton and the Thousand Islands at Gananoque, Ont., has made known the engagement of her daughter, Miss Cynthia Ann Bull, to Franklin Harri Frederick. He is the son of Mrs. Evelyn M. Frederick of Richmond Hill, Queens, and Clarence E. Frederick of Eagle River, Wis.
The Right Rev. Jonathan Goodhue Sherman was elected bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Long Island yesterday on the first ballot, defeating seven other candidates.

A conservationist told a meeting in Pittsburgh last week that that his studies disclosed that if present population trends continued, this country in the next 15 years would have about 9.5 per cent of the world's population but would be using 83 per cent of the world's natural resources.
HARTSDALE, N.Y., March 19 Mr. and Mrs. Philip Zaetz have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Natalie Gail Zaetz, to David Paul Mayer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Mayer of New Rochelle.
Leading experts in the electronics and electrical engineering field will gather here tomorrow for the International Convention of the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, Inc.

WESTWOOD, Mass., March 19 Mr. and Mrs. Roger H. Hallowell have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Beatrice Weeks Hallowell, to Antony Edgar of Brooklyn, N.Y., son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Dixon Edgar of Washington.

ALEXANDRIA, United Arab Republic, March 19 (UPI) Marty Riessen of Evanston, Ill., moved into the final of the Alexandria tennis championships today with a 6-3, 6-1, 6-0 victory over Torben Ulrich of Denmark.

NASHVILLE, March 17 The main debate here, after the question of which song writer is second best to Roger Miller, is whether the next Governor of Tennessee will be a friend of President Johnson or a friend of the Kennedys.

At a welfare center in the Bronx clients meet regularly to complain to officials, most decisions are made without consulting headquarters and caseworkers have been relieved of mountains of paper work. All this is contrary to traditional Welfare Department procedure.

Senator Jacob K. Javits joined other top state Republican leaders yesterday in saying that Mayor Lindsay's tax program could not pass in Albany without the Mayor's pledge that the city's transit fare would be increased.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 19 The historic Benicia Federal Arsenal is on the way to becoming a modern industrial complex.
STORRS, Conn., March 19 Central Connecticut, paced by Walt Fitzpatrick, overtook Providence and Yale in the final event to win the Connecticut Relays for the first time today.

Mrs. Lawrence Milton Shapiro of 55 Central Park West has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Nancy Joan Shapiro, to Robert Charles Kolodny, son of Dr. and Mrs. Maxwell Howard Kolodny of Scarsdale, N.Y.
CONWAY, Ark., March 19 Gerald Malella of Central Washington broke two of his own records in the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics swimming and diving championships yesterday.
CUTCHOGUE, L.I., March 19 An angry group of farmers complained this week that the Federal Government had defeated their plan to renovate the dipalidated migrant labor camp here.

LOS ANGELES, March 19 (UPI) Marc Savage polevaulted 16 feet 6 inches today for the best collegiate mark of the early outdoor track and field season. His triumph helped the University of California, as Angeles gain a 99-46 victory over Brigham Young University.
OTTAWA, March 19 The Government announced this week a $112-million program to fight poverty among Canada's Indians.

For those who want to outshine their friends, eye-popping fashions glow in the dark. They're in new fluorescent fabrics that are neon-bright on their own and, under the ultraviolet light found in some dark nightclubs, have an unearthly glow. The avant-garde always startles but here is a glimmering of what's coming for today's open-minded girls who want to shock: wham-bang luminous designs and surrealist eye make-up.

HOUSTON, March 19 (AP) The world champion Los An geles Dodgers committed three errors on an infield of synthetic grass tonight but defeated the Houston Astros, 8-3, for their first victory in seven exhibition games.
The first running of Pratt Whitney Aircraft's JTF17A engine, a power plant proposed for a United States supersonic transport, is scheduled for late this spring, the company has announced.
Massive hand-hewn timbers, some of them from dismantled Japanese country homes that were 150 years old, are being used in constructing a new Japanese restaurant on Manhattan's East 56th Street.

Watch the willows and you need no almanac to know when the season turns. They respond to the tides of daylight as few other trees, gauging the sun's progress northward as certainly as a sundial. By the time of the vernal equinox, which occurs today, they are ready for spring. Their catkins, kitten-soft and fresh as the dawn, have begun to burst buds, and once they appear the green leaves are not far behind.

NORTH CONWAY, N.H., March 19 Miss Elizabeth Louise Doig, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Spencer Doig, was married today to Michael Trent Smither, son of Dr. and Mrs. A. Garnett Smither of McLean, Va.

The schedules for Yachts Racing Association of Longs Island Sound championship closed-course competition in mid-Sound and the Connecticut area have been drawn up, and, while official approval remains to be given, extensive changes are not likely.

CHESTNUT HILL, Mass., March 19 Miss Nancy Ellen Coleman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Joseph Coleman of Boston, was married today to Ens. A. Heaton Robertson 3d, U.S.N.R. He is the son of Mrs. Raynham Townshend Jr. of New Haven, and Mr. Robertson 2d of Coral Gables, Fla.
FRANKFORT, Ky., March 19 The 1966 biennial session of the Kentucky General Assembly ended yesterday as one of the most productive in recent history.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP) President Johnson sent Congress today a plan to double spending on water research in the next five years and to study even such novel ideas as watering southern California by towing in Arctic icebergs.

MANCHESTER, N.H., March 19 The Brookside Congregational Church was the setting this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Louise Arnold Rix, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Rudolph Rix, to Frederick Franklin Moon 3d. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. F. Franklin Moon of New York and Lloyd Neck, L.I.

At twilight in summer, white and cream flowers develop a mysterious fluorescence. The effect lasts about half an hour, but may be extended by a full moon or soft lighting. One bed from a Twilight Garden of annuals on display in 1965 at Michigan State University is illustrated below. Seed of petunia, snapdragon, salvia and balsam is started indoors now; the others are seeded in place in May.

Lou Rossini looked dazed as the awards were being passed around at Madison Square Garden yesterday. His chin rested on his right hand, his eyes stared past the commotion in the center of the court while thousands cheered.
Miss Deirdra Joy Gray and Ian Leslie Polow plan to marry at the Plaza on Aug. 14.
HOT SPRINGS, Ark., March 19 (AP) Earl Allen's Swift Ruler turned in another recordbreaking performance today and scored a half-length victory in the $10,000 Razorback Handicap at Oakland Park.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, March 19 The appointment of Adam Malik as Second Deputy Premier and Foreign Minister in President Sukarno's new Cabinet has indicated the ending of Indonesia's alliance with Communist China and a return to nonalignment.
WASHINGTON, March 19 The United States and the Soviet Union signed an agreement today extending their cultural exchanges for two years.
Lake Havasu City, Ariz., a boating town in the middle of nowhere, was back in the news the other day. As usual, the news concerned a fast boat.

A 16-year-old girl was stabbed late yesterday afternoon in the Port Authority Bus Terminal at Eighth Avenue and 40th Street while she was struggling with a youth who attempted to snatch her purse.

Leonie Rysanek, soprano, will return to the Metropolitan Opera on Friday, April 1, to sing Lednore in Beethoven's "Fidelio." Birgit Nilsson will sing the title role in a nonsubscription performance of Puccini's "Tosca" the next evening.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., March 20 "Those people were sold a dream," said Mayor H. George Buckwald.
BUFFALO, March 20 (AP) John Keith, a 21-year-old California skater, captured the United States open indoor speed skating championship today. upsetting favored Bob Fenn of New York by a point.

The controversy over the capture of Berlin in the spring of 1945, one of the most divisive issues among the World War II Allies, is revived by Cornellus Ryan in his new book, "The Last Battle."

Avant-garde designers may be dishing out dresses with cutouts over the hips, extremely short skirts, bull's eyes over the bosom, and see-through evening gowns, but Seventh Avenue is still making a significant amount of money manufacturing and selling what fashion pace-setters consider square.

New traffic patterns on 12th Avenue from 22d to 40th Street were put into effect yesterday by the Department of Traffic to make driving easier and to improve pier loading operations along the Hudson River waterfront.

A rabbi, preaching in a Protestant pulpit yesterday, called on Pope Paul VI to lift the ban on Roman Catholic membership in Masonic lodges.

ROME, March 20 The approaching merger of Italy's two largest industrial-chemical companies Montecatini and the Edison group will produce a $3.8-billion giant warming up for competition on an intercontinental scale.

BOGOTA, March 20 (AP) The National Front was ahead in vote totals tonight, but the opposition seemed to be winning enough seats to prevent the Front's gaining the twothirds control of Congress it sought.

Friday, April 15, will be a double-headache day for New York taxpayers. It is the deadline for filing both the state and Federal income-tax returns. The task, however, has been somewhat easier since 1960, when the state introduced procedures that conform fairly closely with the Federal pattern.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., March 20 Miss June Yayoi Kusumoto, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Kusumoto of Hilo, Hawaii, became the bride today of Lieut. James William Hoffman, Army Corps of Engineers, in the home of his parents, Mr. and Mrs. Milton N. Hoffman. Rabbi Max Eichorn performed the ceremony.

Gov. Richard J. Hughes of New Jersey said last night he would seek an appointment this week with Keith Funston, president of the New York Stock Exchange to discuss a relocation of the exchange in his state.
The debate opening in Albany this week on legislation involving the waterfront may well determine whether the Port of New York grows to its full potential, Theodore W. Kheel said yesterday.

Bantering and waving, Prince Philip of Great Britain ended a "very successful" 11-day tour of the United States yesterday with nearly a million dollars "in the bag" for children's charities.

The chairman of the City Commission on Human Rights said yesterday that he had given the building trades unions a deadline of a week to file reports on what progress they had made in integrating their memberships and apprentice programs.

NEW York players dominated the major cham- pionships in the recent Spring Nationals in Louisville, winning the Vanderbilt Cup, the open pairs and the men's teams. LOS ANGELES, March 20 (UPI) The Los Angeles Lakers eliminated the San Francisco Warriors from the Western Division playoffs by ending the regular season with a 124112 National Basketball Association victory tonight.

Mayor Lindsay urged yesterday that "third-party umpires" help settle the Vietnam war. "I don't think anything is accomplished or has been accomplished in fact by increasing acceleration," he said.
The Newspaper Reporters Association of New York City named yesterday six reporters of three metropolitan newspapers as winners of annual Byline Awards for outstanding journalistic achievement.

BERKELEY, Calif., March 20 An international exhibition of the motorized art form called kinetic sculpture has drawn large numbers of spectators here this weekend to the University of California's art gallery.
Richard Lucian, a 25-year-old graduate physics student at Adelphi University, won the Road Runners Club of New York's 12-mile handicap race in the Bronx yesterday.

Miss Dianne Joy Steckman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sol Steckman of Forest Hills, Queens, was married yesterday to Howard Melvyn Nashel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Nashel of West New York, N.J. Rabbi Joshua Derby performed the ceremony at the Regency. He was assisted by Cantor Joseph Feuer.

SINGAPORE, Monday, March 21 (Reuters) President Sukarno has asked the Indonesian army leaders to whom he handed over power nine days ago to allow him to return to his childhood home in East Java, diplomatic sources said today.

Henry Sobel, board chairman of Sobel Affiliates, Inc., general and life insurance concern at 116 John Street, and founder of its predecessor concern, Henry Sobel Co., in 1904, died yesterday in his apartment in the Park Royal Hotel, 23 West 73d Street. He was 90 Years old.
WOONSOCKET, R.I., March 20 Buell W. Hudson, editor and publisher of The Woonsocket Call, died of a heart attack here today. He was 63 years old.

NAIROBI, Kenya, March 20 (AP) Sister Mike of Worcester, Mass., received permission from the Vatican to learn to operate a plane. Today she is believed to be Africa's only flying nun.

"At places along the route he [Mayor Lindsay] appeared to receive as many boos as cheers, and there was at least a scattering of hoots and catcalls on each block." From The Times account of the Mayor's march up Fifth Avenue in the St. Patrick's Day Parade.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, March 20 The only unusual noise heard today in Jakarta came from students celebrating their victory in the arrest of 15 leftist Cabinet ministers and their replacement with ministers chosen by Lieutenant General Suharto.

News that an American undersea craft has located the hydrogen bomb missing off the coast of Spain brings hope for a swift and safe end to the anguish aroused earlier this year when an American jet bomber collided with the tanker plane refueling it.

CHICAGO, March 20 (UPI) Ken Wharram scored his seventh game-winning goal of the season in the third period tonight to give the Chicago Black Hawks a 4-2 victory over the Montreal Canadiens. The Hawks gained their first home decision of the campaign over the National Hockey League leaders.

E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co, announced over the weekend a reduction of about 12 per cent in its domestic prices of heavy denier nylon staple and-tow. The items affected range from 6 denier to 18 denier.

The Legislature's two top Democrats expressed opposition yesterday to any increase in the city's 15-cent transit fare. They joined Mayor Lindsay in declaring there was no reason to tie a fare rise to action on the city's request for new taxing power.

YONKERS, March 20 The marriage of Miss Arlene Beth Kagle to Philip J. Friedman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel N. Friedman, took place here this afternoon. Rabbi Alexander Rosenberg performed the ceremony at the home of Dr. and Mrs. Louis Kagle, parents of the bride.

FOPT MYERS, Fla., March 20 (AP) Singles by Bob Bailey and Jerry May scored the tying and go-ahead runs in the sixth inning as the Pittsburgh Pirates beat the Philadelphia Phillies, 5-4, today in an exhibition baseball game.
PITTSBURGH, March 20 Over-all demand for steel was still climbing last week, but there was some uncertainty about the outlook for uncoated sheet.

Eddy Phillips, a tenor who made his debut here in 1959, included works by Handel, Bach, Duparc and Obradors in the program he sang at Carnegie Recital Hall late yesterday afternoon. His accompanist was Jonathan Brice.
Three prominent Asia scholars disagreed yesterday with the policy statement on China signed by 198 other members of the Association for Asian Studies and made public in Washington.
WASHINGTON, March 20 Following are votes of delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll-calls in Congress during the week ended yesterday:

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) The Federal Trade Commission, which watches business mergers closely for possible violations of anti-trust laws, says thre's a direct relation between good times and the volume of mergers.

All it takes to put on a successful concert is to present a Bach program performed by the New York Chamber Soloists for a friendly, informed audience in Rogers Auditorium at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. This, in any case, is what happened on Saturday night, and the formula worked perfectly.
The United States Steel Corporation has given the World's Fair $100,000 to make the Unisphere a permanent exhibit in Flushing Meadow Park, Robert Moses announced yesterday.
KADENA AIR FORCE BASE, Okinawa, March 20 With 14 huge planes waiting on the ground and 10 more on the way, it was just an average Sunday afternoon at the Airlift Command Post here.

WASHINGTON, March 20 Congress is preparing to act speedily if the Administration should request a general tax increase. But there is no prospect of a radical departure from established legislative procedures.

MIAMI, March 20 (AP) Tommy Agee slammed a home run and a single, Don Buford hit a double and a triple and the Chicago White Sox capitalized on four wild pitches to beat the Balitmore Orioles, 5-2 today.

LAKE AMBOSELI, Kenya, March 20 "Odinga hasn't been around for days," the leatheryfaced camp manager said. "He's not far away. He never gets too far away. He may have been frightened a bit by some of the loud shouting, but I wouldn't be too sure about that."
Something is being done to improve the accuracy with which the existence of job vacancies is reported.
The City College liberal arts faculty, in a move to alleviate freshman confusion and senior boredom, has suggested the first substantial revision in the college's curriculum in 38 years.

MADRID, March 20 Hopes for the rapid recovery of an unarmed United States hydrogen bomb from the bottom of the Mediterranean off the Spanish coast were disappointed this weekend when the bomb apparently moved to a precarious location at the edge of an underwater canyon.
BLACK and white op art and bright red Paisley print decorate two new Paper Caper dresses made by Scott Paper Company.
BEIRUT, Lebanon The gaunt, gray-haired refugee, wearing a threadbare burnoose and a soiled turban, stood before his tiny concrete shelter in Jordan looking westward toward Israel.
CANNES, France, March 20 (UPI) Graham Stillwell of Britain won the men's singles final at the Carlton tennis tourney today by beating a Colombian, William Alvarez, 6-4, 1-6, 6-3.
Net income of Moore McCormack Company, Inc., last year fell to $1,949,000, or 82 cents a share, from $6,734,000 or $2.90 a share in 1964 the company announced yesterday.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., March 20 Thaddeus Suski, a former New York actor and producer, who owned the historic El Paseo here, an area of restaurants and shops, died Friday of a heart attack. He was 47 years old.

Miss Susan Donner Lewis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Emanuel P. Lewis of 21 East 87th Street, was married yesterday to Douglas West, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel W. West of 175 East 62d Street. Rabbi David Seligson performed the ceremony at the Harmonie Club, 4 East 60th Street.
Michigan State captured its first National Collegiate hockey championship and three smaller colleges successfully retained national titles Saturday.
Notre Dame and Georgetown Universities will receive $8-million each, if the 1933 will of a spinster bank secretary is found valid.
EACH day at 6 A.M., Kimon S. Kouros brings his pots to a boil on the island of Mykonos and begins dyeing wool the way the Greeks there have done for centuries.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) Senator J.W. Fulbright said today that President de Gaulle might be right in suggesting reorganization of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, but that General de Gaulle's way of making suggestions was often "insulting."

FANTASTIC VOYAGE, by Isaac Asimov, based on the screenplay by Harry Kleiner from the original story by Otto Klement and Jay Lewis Bixby (Houghton Mifflin, $3.95). Science-fiction story about a trip through the human blood stream.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) A Federal Reserve Board survey indicated tonight that banks made relatively little immediate use of the authority given them in early December to raise, interest rates on time deposits.

AUSTIN, Tex., March 20 President Johnson, whose personal intervention helped save Texas' leading liberal Democrat in 1964, is playing a role of studied neutrality in this year's intraparty warfare in the state.

Guiomar Novaes plays Chopin and Schumann. The announcement of such a recital is quite enough to make music lovers hurry to the appropriate box office to buy tickets for the event. Thus, Philharmonic Hall was almost filled yesterday afternoon for Miss Novaes's appearance, her third in New York in this 51st season of her performances here.
A blacksmith will fly to Miami from California today to treat the valuable and slightly injured right front hoof of Buckpasser.

MONROVIA, Liberia, March 20 (AP) Heavily armed Guinean troops were reported to be massed on the border with the Ivory Coast today in what could be the start of a move to drive across the Ivory Coast to Ghana.
Luther Lassiter of Elizabeth City, N.C., with four victories and no defeats, became the sole leader in the world championship pocket billiard tournament here after two days of play.

In a match that lasted two hours, Bart Brownstein and Gary Walter defeated Jack Senz and Mel Sokolow, 16-18, 17-18, 15-12, 15-13, 15-14, and won the Lone Star Boat Club invitation Class B and C squash racquets doubles title yesterday.
The Pentaquoit Athletic Club won the New York senior metropolitan wrestling championship yesterday at Bayshore High School.
DENVER, March 20 The Denver Committee to Improve Racial Relations held its first and only "seminar" this weekend. The effort cost local members of the John Birch Society at least $1,000.

STOWE, Vt., March 20 In an awesome display of strength, France's men skiers finished one, two, three for the second straight time today, and their countrywomen won more honors as the national Alpine championships ended.
Senator Jacob K. Javits urged the United States Government yesterday to invite Communist China to negotiations for a peaceful settlement of the Vietnam war.
WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) The Atomic Energy Commission indicated today that the Soviet Union had staged an underground nuclear test, its second in five weeks.

One of the truly resplendent dramatic soprano voices of the present day belongs to Regine Crespin, the French singer who gave a recital last night in Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
Hudson River water is scheduled to begin flowing into the city's water supply system today.
Deputy Mayor Robert Price was offered a month ago a "high-level" position in Governor Rockefeller's re-election campaign, perhaps as campaign manager, but turned it down.

Kurt Loewenberg, president of Brandeis, Goldschmidt Co., Inc., international metal merchants with headquarters in New York, died yesterday at New York Hospital after a short illness. He lived at 65 Central Park West and was 66 years old.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., March 20 Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Edward Lovas have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Linda Marie Lovas, to John Gregory Hoeschler, son of Mr. and Mrs. James William Hoeschler of La Crosse, Wis., and Dresbach Beach, Minn.

An unpublished fiction work by Dylan Thomas, "Rebecca's Daughters," will be issued by Little, Brown on April 27. The work was commissioned as a screenplay and written in the form of a novel.

ALBANY, March 20 Facing a critical deadline, the Rockefeller administration has finally come up with the economic yardstick that will determine which New Yorkers will qualify for aid to the "medically indigent" under the Federal Medicare program.

The Federal Government is reportedly intensifying action to stop private employers from discriminating against potential employes on the basis of creed or national origin as well as race. Such a policy is, of course, requisite to full compliance with the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and a long series of Presidential orders calling for equal employment opportunity in companies with Government contracts.

Emil Katzka, a trial lawyer and theater "angel," died yesterday morning at the home of a daughter, Mrs. James N. Green, in Livingston, N.J. He was 69 years old and lived at 280 Riverside Drive.

THE jacket of "You Don't Say" hints that Benjamin DeMott is Amherst's own Tom Wolfe. At the top there is the smart-alecky title, at the bottom, the author's name. In between, in pop-patriotic colors, is a comic strip speech balloon empty. This is a pun, a literalism you don't say, I don't (or won't) say possibly a publisher's put-on, though it seems doubtful Mr. DeMott would play that kind of butt.
LONDON, March 20 The World Cup, the solid-gold trophy presented to the world soccer champion, was stolen today from a display case in Central Hall, Westminster.
SAIGON, March 20 Almost unnoticed in the anxiety caused by political turmoil throughout South Vietnam, the war against the Vietcong has been pressed unceasingly by allied troops in the last week.

Janet K. Weil, executive director of the Kidney Foundation of New York since 1956, was found dead Saturday morning in her room at the Concord Hotel, 130 East 40th Street. Death was attributed to heart failure caused by visceral congestion. She was 45 years old.

Miss Barbara Bleecker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis K. Bleecker of Long Beach, L. I., was married last evening to Benjamin Appelbaum, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Appelbaum of Bayonne, N.J. Rabbi Ephraim Kolatch performed the ceremony at the Sheraton-East. He was assisted by Cantor David Kusivitsky.

CONFLICTING duties and nothing but conflicting duties have so far kept me from reviewing the latest Dance Theater Workshop series, "Saturdays at Nine," which opened at 215 West 20th Street on Feb. 19 and will close Saturday.

BOSTON, March 20 (UPI) John Bucyk scored two goals tonight and led the last-place Boston Bruins to a 4-3 triumph over the New York Rangers. Boston climbed within 4 points of fifth-place New York in the National Hockey League standings.
BOSTON, March 20 (AP) The Boston Celtics rallied in the second half and defeated the Cincinnati Royals, 121-104, today on the final day of the National Basketball Association's regular season.
DETROIT, March 20 (AP) The St. Louis Hawks rallied in the last five minutes and beat the Detroit Pistons, 121-117, today in a National Basketball Association game.

YEARS have not dimmed the spirit of the New York international master Alex Kevitz, many times holder of the Manhattan Chess Club championship. Having captured the title in the nineteen-thirties, forties and fifties, he has declared his intention to do it again in the sixties.

The Federal Reserve received some sharp criticism from the Congress over the weekend of it policies regarding the more than 5 billion checks that it currently processes each year checks whose value averages about $7-billion a day.

NEWARK, March 20 Three members of Young Republican organizations denied under oath today sworn accusations that they had sung racist and antiSemitic songs.

The Charles Bruning Company is taking an unusual approach to introduce a new desktop electrostatic copying machine. It is using a book that was designed and written for children and very young children, at that.

ROME, March 20 A small group of Spanish youths demonstrated before Pope Paul VI today for greater autonomy in the region of Catalonia, a scene of recent student unrest.

John J. Berger, board chairman of the Greater New York Mutual Insurance Company, died yesterday of a heart attack in St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived at 40 East Ninth Street.

ORLANDO, Fla., March 20 Lionel Hebert, who began his golf career as an 8-year-Old barefoot caddie, won the $110,000 Florida Citrus open tournament today. The 38-year-old professional from Lafayette, La., won by two strokes with a 72hole total of 279 after finishing with a 69 at the Rio Pinar Country Club course.

If any further proof were needed of the continuing love affair between publishing and electronics, Sylvania Electric Products, Inc., and the Reader's Digest Association, Inc., provided it yesterday by announcing they had formed a joint group to investigate the potential of electronic systems in education.

Five full floors have been leased by Marsteller, Inc., an advertising and public relations agency, in the 31-story office tower under construction on the east blockfront of Third Avenue between 52d and 53d Streets.

HOUSTON, March 20 (AP) Three Los Angeles Dodger pitchers scattered seven Houston singles over seven innings today as the world champions won, 4-1, and swept a two-game exhibition series that introduced major league baseball to an infield of synethetic grass.

Mrs. Bert Greene Warenoff, who was assistant executive secretary to former Mayor Robert F. Wagner and secretary to his first wife, the late Susan Edwards Wagner, died yesterday in the French Hospital. She was 68 years old and lived at 25 Central Park West.
WASHINGTON, March 20 President Johnson has decided not to reappoint James J. Saxon, the controversial Controller of the Currency, when his five-year term expires, according to authoritative sources.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 20 The lowly Yankees humbled the mighty Mets, 5-4, today, in the first "new era"' confrontation of New York's major league baseball teams. An upstart Yankee, Roy White, stole home in the fourth inning for the winning run.

SEA CLIFF, L.I., March 20 Scoring third and first-place finishes today, Frank McConnell of the Port Washington, L.I., Penguin fleet won the 13th annual Sea Cliff Yacht Club invitation frostbite regatta on Hempstead Harbor, with 24 points.
BRISTOL, Tenn., March 20 (UPI) Dick Hutcherson of Keokuk, Iowa, drove his 1966 Ford to victory today in the annual 250-mile Southeastern 500 stock-car race.

BAGAMOYO, Tanzania, March 17 This is the old Africa. A listless town under the pitiless sun, a decaying state house where once German officers sweated into their high collars and longed for the pines of Prussia, old men dozing in the sun, children running naked in the dusty streets, a coconut plantation.

PINEHURST, N.C., March 20 Edward Stevens, who retired in 1946 as vice president and general manager of the New Haven (Conn.) Clock Company, died here today. He lived in Sewickley, Pa., and formerly in Greenwich, Conn.

A sale and an auction of art objects, graphics, antiques and paintings will be held on Saturday and Sunday in the auditorium of the New York Psychoanalytic Institute, 247 East 82d Street. The proceeds will benefit the Treatment Center of the Institute, which serves adults and children at clinic fees.
A FLAMING crown roast of lamb garnished with fresh mint or water cress and clusters of grapes can provide a dramatic presentation at a spring dinner party.

PANAMA, March 20 The discovery of an arms cache and a camp believed to be a training center for pro-Communist guerrillas was reported by Panamanian authorities today as an Organization of American States commission was meeting on ways to keep the peace in the Western Hemisphere.

YARMOUTH, Me., March 20 The New England Town Meeting, an institution dating from Colonial days, is being buffeted by pressures of an expanding urban society.

TAMPA, Fla., March 20 (AP) Deron Johnson hit a three-run homer in the 13th inning today as the Cincinnati Reds broke a five-game losing streak with a 6-3 baseball exhibition victory over the Boston Red Sox.

The New York City Board of Elections has notified legislative leaders and Governor Rockefeller that it cannot possibly prepare for a primary election by the appointed date of June 21. The eighth annual Salute to Youth International Ball of the International Cultural Centers for Youth took place last evening in the Imperial Ballroom of the Americana. It attracted 800 people.

Henry Robbins of Iowa Falls, the bride's uncle.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 20 (AP) An agreement on a formula to end an 11-week strike at the big Kennecott Copper Corporation properties southeast of Santiago was reported to have been reached tonight. But there were conditions attached that might prevent a quick return to work, it was said.
Baltimore, which has been without a legitimate theater for touring shows this season, will get a new one in time for Thanksgiving.
The election of Albert V. Maniscalco as a director was announced over the weekend by the Community National Bank and Trust Company of Richmond.

The American Express Company achieved a 24 per cent increase in its 1965 profit on a gain of 17.3 per cent in revenues. Both revenues and earnings were the highest in the company's 115-year history, Howard L. Clark, president, reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) Lieut. Gen. Willard S. Paul, who directed personnel operations for the United States Army in Europe during World War II, died tonight in Walter Reed Army Hospital. He was 72 years old.

WASHINGTON, March 21 The North Atlantic Treaty allies, after 17 years of firmness before Soviet threats and blandishments, find themselves split 14 to 1 over a single issue: integration.
