FISHERS ISLAND, N.Y., March 21 Ordinarily this resort island, favored by the wealthy, is so quiet that the one-man police force does not keep crime statistics.
WASHINGTON, March 21 The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

Mrs. Stella Baar Celler, wife of Representative Emanuel Celler, Brooklyn Democrat, dean of the House and chairman of its Judiciary Committee, died yesterday of a heart ailment in New York Hospital. She was 75 years old and lived at 9 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn.

THERE was something that came along later called "My Fair Lady" that had a modest run on Broadway, but the really great one was "Pins and Needles." They put it on last night on Channel 13, and the songs of social significance were as lilting and provocative as they sounded back in 1937 when the International Ladies Garment Workers Union gave it for the first time.
A glow of happy excitement settled over 1,100 women at Alexander's yesterday as they combined fashion bargain-hunting with a champagne luncheon, all in the name of sweet charity.

The Council of American Artist Societies yesterday presented gold medals for achievement in the arts to Mrs. Anna Hyatt Huntington of Bethel, Conn., Sculptor; Irving Stone of Beverly Hills, Calif., author of "The Agony and the Ecstasy," and to 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation, producer of "The Agony and the Ecstasy," the motion picture about Michelangelo.

Edward E. Baker, a lawyer with an office at 66 Court Street, Brooklyn, who retired last year as chief clerk of the Brooklyn office of the Board of Elections, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived at 501-A Surf Avenue, Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, March 21 George Meany today firmly asserted organized labor's political independence and urged union members to support their friends in 1966 elections regardless of party affiliation.
A study by three New York doctors has sharpened the debate over the value of antiallergy injections for reducing the hay fever sufferer's sensitivity to ragweed pollen.
Miss Michele Eads Clarke was married to Peter Robin KirwanTaylor of London on March 12. Justice of the Peace Henry Perkins performed the ceremony at Sugarbush Valley in Waitsfield, Vt.
It was ideal hunting weather for the more than 60,000 engineers who were in New York yesterday for the opening of the 1966 international convention of the Institute of ...
NEW DELHI, March 21 The land that gave the world the modern doctrine of nonviolent protest has been going through one of its worst bouts of violence in years.

NEW HAVEN A college professor, a printing company executive, a part-time caterer and a lawyer were among 4 men and 11 women who gathered recently for the first adult evening class at the only private, nonprofit technical school in this country that trains expert chefs the Culinary Institute of America. Its nine buildings on a 10-acre campus on elmlined Prospect Avenue here include two complete demonstration kitchens, where the evening classes are being held.

AMHERST, Mass., March 21 Dr. Franklin Patterson, director of the Lincoln Filene Center for Citzenship and Public Affairs at Tufts University, and a national leader in educational research and development, was named today the first president of Hampshire College here. His appointment is effective April 16.
A fifth Canadian producer of newsprint, Kruger Pulp and Paper, Ltd., announced yesterday it had cut a planned increase to $5 from $10 a ton and postponed the effective date six weeks, to May 16.
WASHINGTON, March 21 The two top men in the Food and Drug Administration's Bureau of Medicine turned in surprise resignations today, effective tomorrow.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., March 21 (UPI) At least 40 persons, including 12 policemen, said today that they saw a strange flying object guarded by four sister ships land in a swamp near here Sunday night.
The young manager of a West Side hotel was fatally wounded yesterday by a hatchetwielding assailant who critically injured a 73-year-old clerk when he tried to intervene, the police reported.
MOSCOW, March 21 (AP) The Soviet Union launched today its second apparently unmanned Cosmos satellite within a week.

On the eve of an important conference on the United States payments deficits, the National Industrial Conference Board issued yesterday a 200-page study critical of a major Administration program aimed at ending the deficit.
The stock market advanced yesterday for the fourth consecutive session. Trading was only moderately active.

New Jersey must in the near future make both short- and long-range decisions of incalculable importance. Tomorrow the Senate is to vote on the proposal for a graduated state income tax. Yesterday the fourth constitutional convention in the state's history convened at Rutgers University to draft a new permanent reapportionment plan for the Legislature.
ALBANY, March 21 Mayor Lindsay's campaign pledge to build vest-pocket parks all over New York City got halfway through the Legislature today.
Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz has started a grand jury investigation into reports of ticket scalping and "ice" on Broadway.
The incoming president of Wellesley College said yesterday that birth control information should be given out at the all-girls school.
Directors of the Magnavox Company proposed yesterday a two-for-one stock split and an increase in the quarterly dividend.

The Hundred Year Association of New York has elected Robert S. Curtiss as president. Mr. Curtiss, a former president of the Real Estate Board of New York, is head of Horace S. Ely Co., real estate concern.
The American Stock Exchange continued to move upward yesterday for the third consecutive session and trading was active.

LONDON, March 21 (UPI) British professional golf received a big boost today when Aluminium Limited of Canada (ALCAN) announced that it would sponsor two new international championships next year with a record $55,000 as the top prize.
YONKERS, March 21 Josedale Go Lucky, the 7-to-5 choice in tonight's featured one-mile pace at Yonkers Raceway, finished a distant eighth in the race, won in 2:05 by Guy K. Dudley.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., March 21 Gov. Orval E. Faubus, who has dominated Arkansas politics for 12 years, announced today with an if that he would not seek a seventh consecutive term this year.

MOHEGAN LAKE, N.Y., March 21 Mr. and Mrs. Harold G. Rosenberg have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Gail Rosenberg, to Joel Gary Jacobson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin Jacobson of Detroit. A June wedding is planned.

BONN, March 21 (Reuters) Two American-designed F-104 Starfighter jets crashed in West Germany today. The crashes came only three days before a scheduled parliamentary debate on the many Starfighter accidents in this country.
Canon John Heuss, rector for the last 14 years of historic Trinity Church, at Broadway and Wall Street, died Sunday night at his home at 133 East 64th Street. He was 57 years old.
WASHINGTON, March 21 (UPI)?The House voted, 303-to-0 today to speed mail delivery for United States troops serving abroad.
Luther Lassiter of Elizabeth City, N.C., won his fifth straight match and held the lead last night in the world pocket billards championships at the Commodore Hotel.
The wholesale commodity price index maintained Friday the level of 113.4 which it reached on Thursday.

GREAT NECK, L.I., March 21 Miss Susan Weiss and Stephen J. Gross plan to marry April 30. Mr. and Mrs. Solomon Weiss have announced the engagement of their daughter to the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Gross.

As owners of The New York Herald Tribune, The New York Journal-American and The New York WorldTelegram and Sun, we will file notice Tuesday, March 22, with the Department of Justice of our intention to merge our three papers into a single new company, World Journal Tribune, Inc., which will publish a morning paper (The Herald Tribune), an afternoon paper (The World Journal) and a Sunday paper (The World Journal and Tribune).

MADRID, March 21 The United States hydrogen bomb lying on a steep underwater Mediterranean slope was reported tonight to be in danger of rolling into a deep four-footwide trench. Recovery operations there could be beyond the capability of equipment now at the scene.
HYDE PARK, N.Y., March 21 (AP) Jose Torres said today that he would defend his world light-heavyweight title against the No. 1 contender, Wayne Thornton of Fresno, Calif.
WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) W. Tapley Bennett, Ambassador to the Dominican Republic during the worst of its internal troubles, is being moved to Portugal, the White House announced today.

WASHINGTON, March 21 Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, retired Army Chief of Staff, argued today that the United States must define its political goals in Vietnam more sharply or face expansion of the war without apparent limits.

OSLO, Norway, March 21 Ski patrols today found the bodies of the seven men in the crew of a United States C-130 military transport plane that crashed early yesterday on a 2,650-foot mountain in northern Norway.
Stocks closed higher in moderately active trading; volume, 7.23 million shares.

WASHINGTON, March 21 The Supreme Court agreed today to review the case of two Maryland Negroes convicted of rape by a jury from which the prosecution had withheld evidence of the complainant's long record of sexual promiscuity. Also withheld from the jury was a false report to the police of another alleged rape.
C. Jay Parkinson, president of the Anaconda Company, said release of the Government's stockpiled copper was "necessary and advisable."
DENVER, March 21 A geologist suggested tonight that major earthquake disasters might be averted by intentionally inducing a series of minor tremors.

GRANTS, N.M., March 21 (AP) Homestake-Sapin Partners, a uranium mining and milling enterprise at Ambrosia Lake, announced today it would sell 628,000 pounds of U-308 uranium concentrate to a West German electric utility company.
Primavera, the annual spring dance of the junior committee of the Outdoor Cleanliness Association of the City of New York, is planned for the Versailles Room of Carlton House on Saturday.

ROME, March 21 Pope Paul VI made a ceremonial call upon President Giuseppe Saragat at the Quirinale Palace today to thank the Chief of State for Italy's hospitality to the prelates who attended the Ecumenical Council Vatican II.

BOSTON, March 21 (AP) The president of the striking printers' union said today an actuarial study had shown that Boston newspaper publishers could give a cash raise to printers and mailers without harming a health-welfare and pension plan.
What is believed to be a discovery of major importance in the cancer field has been reported by a team of scientists from Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons.
GENEVA, March 21 United Nations economists see "every prospect that the long-sustained expansion in the United States will continue throughout 1966."
The director and 28 staff members of the Block Development Project, an East Harlem antipoverty agency, announced yesterday, that they would resign April 1.

To play or not to play? That is the question these days for Vladimir Horowitz, who rides it like a man on both ends of a seesaw. He has two Sunday afternoon dates on option at Carnegie Hall, and in a week or so he must decide whether he will pick up either, both or none.
The New York Knickerbockers, losers of 13 of their last 15 games, end their National Basketball Association season tonight against the St. Louis Hawks at Madison Square Garden.

Plans are under way for two office skyscrapers in the midtown area in the 40's. One structure is planned on the southeast corner of Fifth Avenue and 45th Street and the other is projected for the west side of the Avenue of the Americas between 43d and 44th Streets. Both structures are being designed by the architectural firm of Emery Roth Sons.
HONG KONG, March 21 Communist China has protested to Indonesia against "a new, outrageous attack" on the Chinese consulate in Macassar, the capital of Celebes Island.
WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) The first optometrists will be drafted in July, the Defense Department said today.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 21 The Los Angeles Dodgers, the winners of the World Series last October, currently arouse more interest in interviews than they do in playing. They showed up here today and promptly proved the point by answering all sorts of questions and then neatly losing to the New York Yankees, 3-0.
The British pound declined slightly in moderate trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday. The currency closed at $2.7948, down 6 points from Friday.
WASHINGTON, March 21 The first warm day occurred and everybody went out of doors singing "Hurray, hurray for the first warm day" and "The robin is i-cumen in."
CHICAGO, March 21 Norman A. Stepelton, president of the National Tea Company, took a cheerful view today of the company's troubles with the Federal Trade Commission.
LONDON, March 21 (Reuters) Scotland Yard investigated today the possibility that students had stolen the World Cup, soccer's top trophy, as a joke.

LONDON, March 21 The image of Britain as a law-abiding nation is not altogether free of ghosts in the electronic age. More than 10 per cent of the country's families regularly evade the annual tax on television receivers.

Henry H. Henley, president of McKesson Robbins, Inc., announced the appointment yesterday of Robert U. Sternfels as vice president, assistant to the president, a new post. Mr. Sternfels will be concerned with the drug area of the business.
That merger feeling spreading throughout Western Europe is about as strong in the Netherlands as it is anywhere.

YORK, Pa., March 21 Mr. and Mrs. Clair E. Delle have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Diane Elizabeth Delle of New York, to Richard Brant Ward, son of Mrs. Ward S. Ward of West Orange, N.J., and the late Dr. Ward. A June wedding is planned.
SAIGON, March 21 South Vietnam's Buddhist leaders turned the other cheek today to what they regarded as a slap from Premier Nguyen Cao Ky.

The puppet East German regime, which imprisons eighteen million people behind barbed-wire and denies them reunification with West Germany, has no place in the United Nations an organization of independent states.
A nine-acre site in the South Bronx was approved yesterday by the Site Selection Board for the projected 850-bed, $42-million Lincoln Hospital.
THE hunting safari business must be taking an up swing, judging from the number of Africa-bound hunters this corner has heard of recently.

LEYTON, England, March 21 A former Foreign Secretary of Britain is fighting for his political life in the same northeast London suburb that handed him a humiliating rebuff 14 months ago. Patrick Gordon Walker professes to be more confident now. He is pleased with his personal canvassing to regain his seat in the House of Commons and happy that racial issues have not figured so far in the campaign.
Spring continued at Philharmonic Hall last night with the second and last installment of "Primavera 1966," the baby festival of Italian Baroque music that began on Sunday.
ADULTS who are looking for guidance in the selection of children's books may find the following new booklets helpful.
TAMPA, Fla., March 21 (AP) Jim Maloney, the Cincinnati Reds' pitching star, ended his holdout today by signing a contract for a salary estimated at $46,000.
Steel production continued to climb last week, the American Iron and Steel institute reported yesterday.
WARSAW, Poland, March 21 (UPI) Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski, Poland's Roman Catholic primate, said today that he might get into even more trouble if he could speak more freely.

The National Wage Policy Committee of the United Mine Workers of America began a series of meetings here yesterday to hear reports on the union's contract negotiations. with the country's soft-coal operators.
The Goldfield Corporation has acquired the Yellowstone Park Company and has agreed in principle to acquire the Everglades Park Company.

AT the top of three flights of spiral, metal staircase in midtown Manhattan, a frosted-glass office door bears a one-word sign: EROS. Inside sit three file cabinets filled with biographical material on Anthony Comstock, the first 12 issues of H.L. Mencken's American Mercury
The Hearst newspaper empire, which once had three major papers in New York City, has been represented here by just The Journal-American since The Mirror died on Oct. 16, 1963.

FALMOUTH, Mass., March 21 Mrs. Musch G. Kayajan has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Ann Margaret Kayajan, to Lewis L. Bruggeman, son of Mr. and Mrs. L. Leroy Bruggeman of Suffern, N.Y. A May wedding is planned.

THE two session charity tournament at the New York Hilton on Sunday was a personal triumph for Milton Zipser, a past president of the Greater New York Bridge Association, which organized the event. Some $2,000 was raised for the American Contract Bridge League's Charity Fund.

United Artists, which will soon put into United States release the Italian-made Western, "For a Few Dollars More," has made a deal with the same star and production team to finance and distribute a second Western, "Two Magnificent Rogues."

DETROIT, March 21 Senator Jacob K. Javits assailed the "timidity" of President Johnson's anti-inflation policies today and called for immediate spending cuts and a "modest and temporary" tax increase.
Lorraine Prieur, 19-year-old pianist from Montreal, is gentle and demure in appearance, and she wore a soft pink dress for her New York debut at Carnegie Recital Hall last night.
A further shake-up appears to be due in the management of the financially beleaguered Wheeling Steel Corporation.

SAIGON, March 21 The ground war in Vietnam increased in intensity today with South Vietnamese Government troops reporting 198 enemy soldiers killed and United States Marines reporting 96 more of the enemy dead.
RALEIGH, N.C., March 21 (AP) The Ku Klux Klan has decided on a new approach to the hostile Lumbee Indians if you can't lick 'em, recruit 'em.
DETROIT, March 21 (AP) Production lines hummed busily this week as the United States auto industry strove to make March the third 900,000unit month in automotive history.
The Metropolitan Opera and its stagehands have signed a new three-year labor contract in advance of the June 27 expiration of the old one.
A dissident stockholder group of the Boston Maine Corporation formally opened its proxy contest yesterday for control of the railroad holding company.
DANANG, South Vietnam, March 21 (UPI) Bus and pedicab drivers ignored today Premier Ky's warning against antigovernment demonstrations and paraded for a return to civilian rule.
Potato futures, which showed record movement from storage in February, set new lifetime highs in contracts for nearby delivery yesterday for the sixth trading session in a row.

Mrs. John V. Lindsay, who said she was "brought up on hand-me-down clothes from my friends," helped start the 70th annual spring salvage drive of the Volunteers of America yesterday by giving away two of her husband's suits on the steps of City Hall.

An offering of 200,000 common shares of the Warner Brothers Company at $36 a share was made yesterday by an underwriting group led by Lehman Brothers. Proceeds from the sale, together with funds from a direct placement of notes earlier in March, will be used to repay short-term loans. The Bridgeport, Conn., company manufactures foundation garments and men's and women's sportswear.

COHASSET, Mass., March 21 The engagement of Miss Elizabeth Ayers Eaton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis F. Eaton Jr., to John Hancock Kimball Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Kimball of Lynnfield and York Harbor, Me., has been announced by the future bride's parents.
CHELSEA, N.Y., March 21 Water from the Hurson River started its long journey into New York City's taps today.
Gary Mineau doesn't have to walk horses in Middleburg, Va., any more and his wife doesn't have to baby-sit to supplement his salary.
Prices advanced a shade in quiet trading on the London Stock Exchange yesterday.
A rise in interest rates on savings certificates has gone into effect at the Meadow Brook National Bank because of "increased competition on the part of banks for investible funds."

Justino Diaz, 26-year-old bass with the Metropolitan Opera Company, received the city's Handel Medallion yesterday from Mayor Lindsay. The Mayor described it as "the city's highest award for cultural achievement."
WASHINGTON, March 21 Delegates from impoverished neighborhoods astonished a national meeting of community action agencies here today by saying that the poor should not necessarily lead the poor.
One of the Soviet Union's outstanding young poets, Andrei Voznesensky, arrived here late Sunday for a poetry-reading tour of the United States.
The damage done to the President's low-income housing subsidy bill by a House Appropriations subcommittee can and should be repaired before it is too late.

WASHINGTON, March 21 Communist China was portrayed before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today as an international outcast that would have to abandon its militant foreign policy to regain its lost prestige even in the Communist world.
The top four seeded players advanced to the quarter-finals yesterday in the 22d annual interscholastic squash-racquets tournament at the Racquet and Tennis Club.

MOSCOW, March 21 A responsible figure in the Soviet political hierarchy has suggested that government elections might be more meaningful if there were more than one candidate for each place on the ballot.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) A decision to sell 200,000 tons of stockpile copper was welcomed today by two Senators from copper-producing states, Mike Mansfield, Democrat of Montana, and Frank E. Moss, Democrat of Utah.
WASHINGTON, March 21 Three Senators criticized today the proposed construction of a $150-million steel mill in Communist China by European concerns.

NEW HAVEN, March 21 Kingman Brewster Jr., president of Yale University, announced the appointment today of Howard T. Phelan, director of management operations, to a new post as director of university development.
ALBANY, March 21 The Public Service Commission told Governor Rockefeller today that the November power blackout had jolted the state's major utilities out of their "it can't happen here" complacency.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (UPI) The Supreme Court refused today to review the jury tampering conviction of Henry F. Bell of New York in connection with the trial in 1962 in Nashville, Tenn., of James R. Hoffa, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.
Emil Katzka, a trial lawyer and theater "angel," died Sunday morning at the home of Green, in Livingston, N.J. He was 69 years old and lived at 280 Riverside Drive.

The current complicated cigarette price situation became a little more muddled yesterday when the American Tobacco Company halved a previously announced increase in wholesale prices for most of its brands.

WASHINGTON, March 21 The antitrust laws appear to present no barrier to the planned New York newspaper merger if, as the three newspapers involved have indicated, they have all been steadily losing money.

The largest central cutting warehouse in the apparel industry, a 100,000-square-foot structure to handle about 18 million garments a year, is due to be put into operation by January, 1967, by Bobbie Brooks, Inc.

Justice Aaron F. Goldstein denied an application yesterday by Assistant District Attorney Benjamin Schmier at the beginning of the Whitmore trial yesterday to lock up the jury. The defendant, George Whitmore Jr., is on trial for the second time for the attempted rape and assault of Mrs. Elba Borrero two years ago.
WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., March 21 The New York Mets capitalized on five errors by the Atlanta Braves tonight to score a 7-2 victory in their first night game of the spring exhibition season.

Mayor Lindsay and Gov. Robert Sanchez Vilella of Puerto Rico agreed yesterday on calling a high-level meeting of officials representing their administrations late this year to discuss common problems.
NOTTINGHAM, England, March 21 (UPI) Alan Rudkin, the British and Empire bantamweight champion, blood dripping from a cut right eye, scored a 10-round decision tonight over Rual Vega of Mexico.
AUCKLAND, N.Z., March 21 Competition between British and United States aircraft manufacturers to break into the short-haul jet market in Australia and New Zealand is becoming more intense.
The Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority, headed by Robert Moses, defied City Hall anew yesterday by advertising for bids, returnable Thursday, for borings for a ...
Ralph G. Klieforth, president of the Universal Motor Company and a dominant figure in the pleasure boating industry, died yesterday at his winter home in Sun City, Ariz. He was 64 years old.
Emil Katzka, a trial lawyer and theater "angel," died Sunday morning at the home of Green, in Livingston, N.J. He was 69 years old and lived at 280 Riverside Drive.

The current complicated cigarette price situation became a little more muddled yesterday when the American Tobacco Company halved a previously announced increase in wholesale prices for most of its brands.

WASHINGTON, March 21 The antitrust laws appear to present no barrier to the planned New York newspaper merger if, as the three newspapers involved have indicated, they have all been steadily losing money.
WASHINGTON, March 21 The Treasury bill rate fell sharply at today's auction to the lowest level since early January, the Treasury disclosed tonight.
Warner Bros. Pictures, Inc., in a second diversification move this year, is forming a wholly owned subsidiary to produce cosmetics, Jack L. Warner, president, announced yesterday.
Yeshiva University announced plans yesterday for a Graduate School of Humanities and Social Sciences that it considers "a new departure" in American graduate education.

Conference, International Executives Association, Statler Hilton Hotel, 9:45 A.M. Speaker: E.A. Gallagher. Luncheon, 12:30 P.M. Speaker: Governor Rockefeller. Afternoon session, 2:30. Dinner, 7 P.M. Speaker: Frank D. O'Connor, President, City Council. Continues tomorrow.

Judge Charles Marks of the Supreme Court of the State of New York issued an order yesterday for the Studebaker Corporation and its transfer agent, the First National City Bank, to show cause why they should not be made to provide the company's stockholder list to Richard D. Gittlin, a stockholder.

LESS than 24 hours after Prince Philip of Britain flew out of New York, the Duke and Duchess of Windsor sailed in aboard the liner United States which docked yesterday at 8 A.M. "We are sorry we couldn't see him," said the Duke, whose abdication in 1936 to marry Mrs. Wallis Warfield Simpson began the events that put Queen Elizabeth II on the throne with Prince Philip as her consort.
Mead Johnson Co. is embarking on a "public service" advertising campaign devoted to family planning and aimed not only at physicians but also at brides and mothers.
WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) The Navy announced today the appointment of Comdr. Veronica M. Bulshefski as director of the Navy Nurse Corps.
WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) It comes as a surprise to the White House that there is a new chrysanthemum named "Lady Bird."

FRANKLIN, Tenn., March 21 (AP) Thomas P. Henderson, one of eight Army officers from Tennessee who tried to kidnap Kaiser Wilhelm of Germany at the end of World War I, died here last night. He was 83 years old.
The State Senate's proposal to let New York's Mayor circumvent the special selection panel in making appointments to the Board of Education would wipe out an effective school reform measure.
CHICAGO, March 21 A group of Chicago civic and professional leaders called today for a reappraisal of United States policy in Southeast Asia.
A parent in the Bronx has started legal action demanding the dissolution of the Board of Education here because it is appointed, not elected.

WASHINGTON, March 21 By a vote of 5 to 4, the Supreme Court upheld today the obscenity conviction of Ralph Ginzburg, publisher of "Eros" and other erotic literature, and decided that "titillating" advertising could be proof that the advertised material was obscene.
A Golden Anniversary Ball has been arranged for April 13 to help Gilbert Miller celebrate his 50th year as a theatrical producer.

PHILADELPHIA, March 21 Mr. and Mrs. Morris Seitz have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Judith Seitz, to Bruce Warren Rodin, son of Dr. and Mrs. Eugene Rodin of Hempstead, L.I.A June wedding is planned.

WASHINGTON, March 21 President Johnson authorized today the release of 200,000 tons of copper from the Government's strategic stockpile to meet urgent defense needs. It was the second such action taken by the President in a little more than four months.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 21 A constitutional convention on legislative reapportionment convened here today in the Rutgers University gymnasium and elected a Democrat as president.
HOUSTON, March 21 Two seasoned astronauts and a rookie were named today to take the first ride in the nation's Apollo mooncraft.

Henry Jeter, a powerful 21year-old hospital attendant from White Plains, produced the most excitement last night during the 16-bout program of the 40th annutal Golden Gloves boxing championship at Madison Square Garden.

UNION, N.J., March 21 Before more than 500 guests, including educators, state and area officials, representatives of business and cultural leaders, the new $1-million Newark State College Theater for the Performing Arts was dedicated here tonight.
ELIZABETH, N.J., March 21 A photograph of this city's burly chief of police, slightly altered with make-up, is being circulated throughout the East on "wanted" posters.

NO writer testifies more convincingly than William S. Burroughs that art is a way (perhaps the best way) of staring death straight in the eye and living to tell about it. A TINY opera, (about 17 minutes long), with a tiny cast (two singers) and a tiny orchestra (six players) received its world premiere last night at the McMillin Theater. Peter Westergaard was the composer; he is one of the Columbia University Group for Contemporary Music, which sponsored the event.
Admiral of the Fleet, the Earl Mountbatten of Burma, K.G., G.C.B., G.C.S.I., G.C.I.E., G.C.V.O., D.S.O., P.C., won an American award last night. But it had Dwight D. Eisenhower's name on it.
Henry D. Patton, a retired lawyer and a former magistrate, died yesterday in New York Hospital. He was 89 years old and lived at 2431 Webb Avenue in the Bronx.

MOSCOW, March 21 In the remote port of Ambarchik, overlooking the frozen East Siberian Sea nearly 4,000 miles northeast of Moscow, the handful of hardy inhabitants may soon have the glow of television to warm the long winter night.
The election of Roger D. Williams as executive vice president and general manager was announced here yesterday by Rheingold Breweries, Inc.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 22 (AP) The Maryland Senate reversed itself tonight and by a vote of 16-11 approved repeal of the state's 305-year-old law prohibiting interracial marriages.

Men have a strange propensity for seeing what they expect or want to see, as any magician knows. This trait, probably more than any other, accounts for "flying saucer" episodes like the ones reported yesterday and Monday in Michigan.

Events today: Wagner's "Tannhaeuser," Metropolitan Opera, 8 P.M.; Menotti's "The Consul," New York City Opera, New York State Theater, Lincoln Center, 8:15; Cesare Siepi, basso, Philharmonic Hall, 8:30; Natalie Burgess, soprano, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Gilbert Reese, cellist, Town Hall, 8:30.
The Southern Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday gains of 8 per cent in operating revenues and 6 per cent in net income for 1965.
The election of Charles F. Brau as chairman was announced yesterday by the Group Five Savings Bank Association of New York.

Forty-five inmates of Dannemora and Matteawan State Hospitals for the Criminal Insane were transferred yesterday without incident to seven civil hospitals, under the terms of a recent United States Supreme Court decision. The Court held that persons committed for crimes had the right, if mentally ill, to the same considerations accorded to any mentally ill person.

WASHINGTON, March 22 The strenuous contest for what has been called "the scientific prize of the century" a highpowered atom smasher has been narrowed to six locations, including the Brookhaven National Laboratory on Long Island.

WASHINGTON, March 22 A coalition of unions has asked the General Electric Company and the Westinghouse Electric Corporation for early meetings to lay the ground work for the biggest set of labor negotiations.

WASHINGTON, March 22 The arrest of a young Capitol janitor in the slashing and robbing of a Congressman in his office late last night caused new demands today for the overhaul of the patronage-appointed Capitol Police Department.
A Bronx Supreme Court jury acquitted a Housing Authority policeman yesterday of stealing building materials from a project on his beat.
A struggle between two antipoverty groups in East Harlem has ripped apart a third.
The New Yorker Magazine, Inc., which thrives on its publication's air of subtlety and gentle humor, held its annual meeting yesterday in much the same atmosphere.

Larry Terrell of St. Paul's and Sandy McAdoo of Penn Charter, seeded No. 1 and No. 2, respectively, each advanced with a pair of victories yesterday to the finals of the 22d interscholastic squash racquets tournament at the Racquet and Tennis Club.
WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP) Because of a declining birth rate, the population of the United States grew last year at its slowest pace since 1945, the Census Bureau reported today.

Mrs. E. Griffith Parsly, wife of the president of the Eastern Illinois Water Company and the Industrial Water Supply Company of Illinois, died Monday in her home at 25 Fifth Avenue. She was 80 years old.
BONN, March 22 West Germany will submit "constructive proposals" for disarmament to all other nations within a few days, Chancellor Ludwig Erhard said today.

Dr. Ralph E. Lapp, the physicist who worked on the atom bomb project, said last night that he was not surprised when a hydrogen bomb was lost recently off the Spanish coast after a midair plane collision. He said he was aware of at least 10 "nuclear accidents."

LIMA, Peru, March 22 Senator Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York, said today that inter-American development efforts so far "do not represent the breakthrough necessary to satisfy the growing and just demands of the peoples of the Americas."
MADRID, March 22 The United States Navy was reported tonight to have prepared plans to blast open a rocky gorge 3,000 feet under the sea if the lost hydrogen bomb rolls into it.

The Episcopal Mission Society will benefit from two spring dinner dances, the first on April 22 at the clubhouse of the Junior League of New York, 130 East 80th Street, and the second on May 6 at the Glen Island Casino in New Rochelle, N.Y.
Andrei Voznesensky, visiting Soviet poet, was warmly received at Columbia University last night as he gave the first poetry reading of his United States tour.

Mr. and Mrs. James H. French of New York and Sagaponack, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carey Barbara French, to John Alden Millard. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Alden S. Millard of Muncie, Ind.

WASHINGTON, March 22 Attorney General Nicholas deB. Katzenbach called today for an outright ban on wiretapping if Congress cannot agree on a bill for court-approved wiretapping by law-enforcement officials.
A program to prepare Christians for the possibility of renewed relations with churches in Communist China was announced yesterday by the United Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A.

THE "Don't Panic Cookbook" is an illustrated booklet that suggests seven menus for the bride's first seven days. Recipes are given for the main courses, and hints for success in making such dishes as veal marsala, quiche lorraine and chicken breasts tarragon.
WASHINGTON, March 22 The Administration asked Congress today for increases in highway-use taxes to yield $1.6-billion over a seven-year period.

TRENTON, March 22 Gov. Richard J. Hughes conceded dramatically this evening that he was "not hopeful" that the Senate would pass his income tax bill tomorrow, but said, "I don't think the tax is dead."
BALTIMORE, March 22 The world's largest barge, the 475foot Caribbean, was launched here today at Bethlehem Steel Corporation's Sparrows Point shipyard.

NEW DELHI, March 22 India's Prime Minister, Mrs. Indira Gandhi, called today for greater cooperation between the advanced and the developing nations to raise the living standards of people in lessdeveloped areas.

Robert Moses, chairman of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority, declared yesterday that the agency was merely living up to its obligations under law in continuing planning work for a third tube for the Queens-Midtown Tunnel.
The New York Knickerbockers gave Coach Dick McGuire a proper season's farewell at Madison Square Garden last night, beating the St. Louis Hawks, 126-125.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, March 22 (AP) The National Assembly elected Premier C.K. Yen as Vice President of Nationalist China today. He got only 37 more votes than the required majority.
WASHINGTON, March 22 The General Motors Corporation apologized today before a Congressional committee for investigating the private life of an outspoken advocate of safer cars.

MOSCOW, March 22 A Soviet art critic urged today that the official doctrine of socialist realism be liberalized to recognize esthetic contributions of experimental art movements active in Russia before the 1917 Bolshevik Revolution.

Stanislaw Skrowaczewski, conductor of the Minneapolis Symphony, likes contemporary music and apparently introduces as much of it as he can into his programs. It was not surprising, therefore, that two 20th-century works were included in the Philadelphia Orchestra concert he conducted last night at Carnegie Hall. Mr. Skrowaczewski was appearing as a guest of the Philadelphians, whose musical director is Eugene Ormandy.
The "Golden Horseshoe" in its reincarnation at the new Metropolitan Opera House in Lincoln Center was unveiled yesterday. About 150 invited visitors toured the house from the cavernous Level C, 36
Members of the New York Stock Exchange urged their leadership yesterday to consider "most seriously" moving the nation's largest securities market to another state.

PARIS, March 22 The average Anglo-Saxon man even if he is slim and tall enough to wear them still seems scared to death of Pierre Cardin's clothes for men. At the showing today of his new men's wear in Cardin's silkylooking green haute couture salon, some American men froze, and a French girl giggled out loud, when a model walked out wearing a velour hat shaped like a cut-off stovepipe.
PARIS, March 22 President de Gaulle's newest hospitable overtures about British membership in the European Common Market have aroused less excitement in the Common Market than in Britain.
TOKYO, March 22 (AP) Four earthquakes, one of great intensity, shook northern China today, apparently not far from the town of Singtai, hit hard by two earth shocks earlier this month.
The money and capital markets continued yesterday to reflect the recent change in investor psychology that has pushed prices up and interest rates down for more than a week.
Stock prices advanced yesterday despite late profit taking in some volatile issues as the market extended its recovery movement for the fifth successive session.
WASHINGTON, March 22 Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall promised today "a new period in the history of the Bureau of Indian Affairs," including a reorganization "at the top level."
TORONTO, March 22 (AP) Cassius Clay and George Chuvalo were pronounced physically fit for their March 29 heavyweight fight after a medical examination today.

Television's "middle-Atlantic format," which combines the novelty of European settings with the familiarity of American accents, will be extended this summer to three series of musical variety shows. All performers will be Europeans, but the host of each show will be an American whose voice has long been familiar to television viewers in this country.
Fairfax M. Cone called for an end yesterday to what he termed "the constant carping at business practices and business morals and business-forprofit."
Trading quickened on the London Stock Exchange yesterday and public and institutional buying helped selective issues across the board.
WASHINGTON, March 22 President Johnson replied in measured terms today to the March 7 letter from President de Gaulle on the current crisis in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
David E. Bell, the United States foreign aid chief, was asked yesterday if he was going to join the Ford Foundation. He replied, "It may happen and it may not."
WASHINGTON, March 22 The Senate gave its overwhelming approval today to a $13.1-billion appropriation bill to finance the war in Vietnam.

Dr. Frida Meitner Frischauer, mathematician and educator, died yesterday in Roosevelt Hospital at the age of 77. She fell Monday on the steps in front of her home at 50 West 70th Street. A spokesman for the Chief Medical Examiner's Office said an autopsy showed that death resulted from a fractured skull.

CANTON, Ohio, March 22 (UPI) Eight men who helped carve out the colorful history of professional football were named today for induction this summer into the national professional football Hall of Fame.

Directors of both boards have approved in principle a plan under which the Ashland Oil and Refining Company will acquire Warren Brothers Company in exchange for Ashland stock with a market value of more than $38-million.
BALTIMORE, March 22 Major manufacturers have made no effort to produce car tires that comply with Maryland's safety regulations, which go into effect July 1, state officials said today.
DONCASTER, England, March 22 (AP) Forty-nine horses, headed by Riot Act, were named today for tomorrow's one-mile Lincolnshire race one that could make history.
WASHINGTON, March 22 Following is a transcript of President Johnson's news conference today in his office:

Mr. and Mrs. Herbert B. Woodman of New York and Arlington, Vt., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sarah Jean Woodman, to John Morton Stopford. He is the son of the Right Rev. Lord Bishop of London Robert W. Stopford and Mrs. Stopford.
Special Committee on Colonialism--Adopted draft resolution relating to petitions from Aden.

La Banque Continentale, the Franklin National Bank's excursion into the haut monde, opened for business yesterday, but it cannot be said that the clientele was exactly knocking down the doors of the posh establishment on the southeast corner of 60th Street and Fifth Avenue.
Navy fire fighters off the coast of West Africa discovered last week that fire can be fought with coffee not the liquid but the bean.

The City Council unanimously adopted a resolution yesterday calling on the state Legislature to adopt all pending legislation intended to relieve public employes from penalties of the state's Condon-Wadlin Law.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 22 Kurdish insurgents in Iraq have been split by an organizational quarrel between Gen. Mustafa al-Barzani, the guerrilla commander, and the Kurdish Democratic party, according to reliable reports reaching here.
WASHINGTON, March 22 The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

Despite mutual as well as conflicting interests, neither the United States Government nor the business community has shown an active desire to establish close working relationships in the field of foreign trade, export managers were told yesterday.

The statement on China by 198 Asian scholars opposed by only nineteen other members of the Association for Asian Studies shows where the weight of informed American opinion lies. The country's Asian experts believe overwhelmingly that Peking's continued isolation is in the interest neither of the United States nor of world peace.
HELSINKI, Finland, March 22 The election triumph of the moderate Socialists was widely viewed today as a reaction against the long domination of Finnish politics by the Center party.

WASHINGTON, March 22 The Atomic Energy Commission has announced that three European utilities will buy 1,525,000 pounds of uranium ore from American producers to obtain fuel for planned nuclear power plants in Germany and Switzerland.

WASHINGTON, March 22 Mr. and Mrs. Paul C. Aiken have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia Kay Aiken, to Francis Higdon Mattingly, son of Brig. Gen. Thomas William Mattingly, Army Medical Corps, retired, and Mrs. Mattingly of Bethesda, Md.

WASHINGTON, March 22 President Johnson, citing some declines in business indicators, made clear today that he was not yet convinced that a tax increase was needed to slow down economic expansion and inflation.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 22 One of the more unusual and baffling developments last season was the way three of baseball's better pitchers got themselves so turned around that they dragged their teams down with them as helpless managers watched with growing dismay and horror.
WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP) The State Department is considering a request for help by a Soviet scientific research ship in the Philippines, officials said today.

COLUMBIA, S.C., March 22 Former Gov. Ernest F. Hollings, now a Charleston at torney, challenged Senator Donald S. Russell today for the Democratic nomination to a two-year seat in the United States Senate.

TORONTO, March 22--General Motors of Canada, Ltd., a wholly owned subsidiary of the General Motors Corporation, is planning to produce in Canada about 75,000 cars and trucks for the United States market during the 1967-model year.

WASHINGTON, March 22 The pressure seems to be building up in the Senate for a policy of bombing, mining or blockading the North Vietnamese harbor of Haiphong, and one reason for the pressure is obviously the forthcoming elections.
Dr. Heinrich B. Waelsch, professor of biochemistry at the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University, died yesterday in his home, 90 Morningside Drive. He was 61 years old.

Charles Seligson, trustee for Ira Haupt Co., which went bankrupt as a result of the $150-million food-oil scandal, has been given court permission to file a suit against the New York Produce Exchange.
ALBANY, March 22 Assembly Speaker Anthony J. Travia, ridiculed today the Republican plan to adjourn the Legislature in two weeks.

Dr. Marian Tyndall, a specialist in rheumatic disorders and emeritus instructor in clinical medicine at Cornell University Medical College, died Monday night in her home, 108 East 82d Street. Her age was 68.

ROME, March 22 The Most Rev. Arthur Michael Ramsey, Archbishop of Canterbury and Anglican Primate of All England, arrived by air today for meetings with Pope Paul VI on relations between the Anglican and Roman Catholic Churches.

HOUSTON, March 22 (UPI) Cleveland (Big Cat) Williams, floored for a 5 count in the second round, scored a unanimous 10-round decision tonight over Mel Turnbow, 22year-old heavyweight from Paterson, N.J.
Chief Inspector Sanford D. Garelik disclosed yesterday that groups of six-foot patrolmen trained in judo had been patrolling Central Park and other parks since March 4.

MIAMI, March 22 The New York Mets had a bigger worry today than losing a 5-3 ballgame to the Baltimore Orioles, which they did. Their star second baseman, Ron Hunt, watched the game from the press box with a muscle spasm in his back that made his immediate future unsure.
The savings market was in turmoil yesterday.
SAIGON, March 22 After nine months in the wings, the Buddhists have proved in recent days that they are still a major power in Vietnamese life.
The Liberal party declared its opposition yesterday to any increase in the city's 15-cent transit fare.

Dr. and Mrs. Anthony Russell Sherman of St. Croix, the Virgin Islands, formerly of Montclair, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Georgia Sherman, to Thomas Harter Bachrach Glick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Bachrach Glick of Darien, Conn.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., March 22 A Lutheran theologian predicted today that the theological "progressivism" engendered by the Vatican Ecumenical Council would continue unabated despite some Protestant misgivings.
HILLSDALE, Mich., March 22 (UPI) A civil defense director, an assistant dean and 87 coeds reported that a glowing object flew past a college dormitory and hovered in a swamp for hours.

The Consolidated Edison Company disclosed yesterday that it would ask the Supreme Court to reverse lower-court invalidation of its proposed $162-million power plant at Storm King Mountain on the Hudson River.
The career of Orval E. Faubus has been a depressing study in the political success to be achieved by a guileful opportunist.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, March 22 President Joseph D. Mobutu stripped Parliament of the last of its functions and assumed all national legislative powers today.

Abraham Lincoln's letter to an 11-year-old girl who sug gested that he grow whiskers was sold at auction last night for $20,000. The purchaser was David L. Wolper of Hollywood, whose Wolper Productions produces documentary films for television.

As a rule, religious-inspirational books are considered outside the general book critic's proper realm. One rational izes that they appeal to a highly specialized, if enormous, mail-order audience, and that they have nothing much to do with "literature."
Luncheon meeting, National Businessmen's Council, Commodore Hotel, noon, Speaker: Eugene P. Foley, Assistant Secretary of Commerce.
The Israeli "peace" pilot, Abie J. Nathan, arrived here last night from Paris to begin a 10day, one-man crusade for peace between Israel and the Arab states.
BOSTON, March 22 Attorney General Edward W. Brooke of Massachusetts outlined today a Vietnam policy that placed him close to the position of the Administration.
WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP) Allegheny Airlines said today its net income last year was $1,308,381, or 81 cents a share.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 113.3 on Monday from 113.4 on Friday.
Nassau County awarded yesterday $19,745,000 of A-rated various purpose bonds to a group managed by the Chase Manhattan Bank and the Bankers Trust Company.
WASHINGTON, March 22 Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz announced today an attack on serious problems of unemployment in Harlem and in the Watts area of Los Angeles.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., March 22 (AP) Jackie Warner drove in three runs before being injured and the California Angels routed the Cleveland Indians, 11-0, today for their fifth straight Cactus League victory.

SUN VALLEY, Idaho, March 22 Billy Kidd, America's foremost skier, was scratched today from the United States team because of an injured ankle. Kidd's absence seriously weakens the home forces that are to compete against the powerful teams of Austria, Switzerland, France and Canada for the Werner Cup.
The Detroit Red Wings will be minus Roger Crozier, their regular goalie, when they face the New York Rangers tonight in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden.

ONE of the most successful players in the recent Spring Nationals in Louisville was Edgar Kaplan of New York, who won the Men's Teams and the Open Pairs in partnership with Norman Kay of Philadelphia.
BOSTON, March 22 (UPI) Govs. John A. Volpe and George Romney announced today a joint program to promote traffic safety in Massachusetts and Michigan.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 22 Pierre J. Huss, foreign correspondent for the Hearst Headline Service, died of a heart attack today after collapsing in the lobby of the United Nations Secretariat. He was 59 years old.
The Borden Company expects its first-quarter sales and earnings to be the highest in the company's history, Francis R. Elliott, president, said at a news conference here yesterday.
Received credentials from Sudanese Ambassador; sent request to Congress for additional $200-million to carry forward development of supersonic transport plane; held impromptu news conference.
WASHINGTON, March 22 The Administration won the opening skirmish of a "guns vs. butter" battle with House approval today of legislation to build a $750,000 house for the Vice President.

WASHINGTON, March 22 The tentative, authorization granted yesterday by the Controller of the Currency, James J. Saxon, for the formation of a new national bank in San Francisco may run into serious opposition from two other Government agencies, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and the Federal Home Loan Bank Board.
Eastern Air Lines is resuming payment of dividends.

Mr. and Mrs. Louis Richman of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Edith Richman, to Henry Walter Weiss, son of Dr. Harry H. Weiss of 70 East 10th Street and the late Mrs. Henrietta Weingarten Weiss.
Hair spray is apparently gaining sufficient acceptance by men to lead two more long-established companies Guerlain and Ed. Pinaud to prepare their own lines of it for release this month.

BOGOTA, Columbia, March 22 Carlos Lleras Restrepo moved closer to the presidency of Colombia today as his middle-of-the-road reform parties maintained their lead in the counting of votes cast in Sunday's congressional elections.

The New York City Opera last night gave its sole performance this spring season of Strauss's "Capriccio." Really, no company can do this difficult masterpiece justice without intensive study and rehearsal. The City Opera's production has its moments, but largely it was the opera itself or rather, as Strauss called it, the "conversation piece for music in one act" that was convincing.
WASHINGTON, March 22 President Johnson derided today suggestions that the Democrats would lose heavily in the November elections and that the Vietnam War would cost the party seats in Congress.

The Court of Appeals' promulgation yesterday of the legislative reapportionment plan prepared by its special commission is a long step forward toward final settlement of this thorny problem. The court has done well in filling the void left by the Legislature's blatant irresponsibility. Thanks to the court, New York State will elect a constitutional legislature of 57 Senators and 150 Assemblymen next fall in place of the present gerrymandered, swollen monstrosity now sitting at Albany.

EVENINGS FOR NEW MUSIC, last night in Carnegie Recital Hall, led off with Anton Webern's Quartet (Op. 22). This is a classic, like. It was followed by Bo Nilsson's "Zwanzig Gruppen," for flute, clarinet and oboe. This is not a classic, but its post-Webern patterns only take up five minutes or so.

Registration will be open until March 26 for a summer science program in anthropology and archeology that will begin June 27 at the Brooklyn Children's Museum. The program, for high school juniors and seniors, will include excavations at prehistoric sites on Staten Island as well as seminars with visiting anthropologists.

About 400 youngsters at Erasmus Hall's ancient gymnasium and 300 more at Richmond Hill High's gym created a din to rival that in Shea Stadium during a Met rally as Erasmus Hall, the defending Public Schools Athletic League basketball champion, and DeWitt Clinton won semi-final games in the city tournament yesterday, Clinton and Erasmus will meet Friday on a neutral high school court in a repeat of last year's pairings. Erasmus won last year.
The British pound again declined slightly in moderate trading on foreign-exchange markets here yesterday. The currency closed at $2.7942, down 6 points from the level on Monday.

Rodney Laver lost five successive games and the opening set before the top favorite from Australia let loose in murderous fashion with the volley and overhead and defeated Michael Davies of Wales in the $25,000 professional tennis tournament at Madison Square Garden yesterday. The scores were 4-6, 6-3, 6-1.

ALBANY, March 22 The legislative reapportionment plan drafted by a judicial commission and adopted today by the Court of Appeals is a two-volume, limited edition that weighs more than five pounds and is as thick as the Manhattan Telephone Directory.

WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP) President Johnson jovially wound up his impromptu news conference today by entertaining "my favorite girl friend" Courtenay Lynda Valenti, 2 -yearold daughter of Jack Valenti, an assistant to the President.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., March 22 One of three suspects in a gangland-style shooting of a Bridgeport discount store executive was arrested early this morning at his home in Massapequa, Long Island.
SAIGON, March 22 United States Air Force Thunderjets flying armed reconnaissance over North Vietnam raked a convoy of 50 trucks with machine-gun fire for more than two hours yesterday afternoon.
The board of trustees of the New York Medical College Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospitals was ordered yesterday to reinstate Dr. Ralph E. Snyder as president of the hospital and dean of the college.
State Education Commissioner James E. Allen Jr. disclosed yesterday his opposition to Governor Rockefeller's proposal to establish five new undergraduate liberal arts colleges in New York City.
Joseph Curran, president of the National Maritime Union of 40,000 seamen, was invested last night as an honorary fellow of the Hebrew University of Jerusalem.

WASHINGTON, March 22--A State Department spokesman said today that Miss Frances G. Knight, director of the department's Passport Office, had been reproved by her superiors for cables asking two American embassies to keep an eye on an American professor when he goes to Europe this fall.
CHEYENNE, Wyo., March 22 (AP) A raging blizzard lashed the Great Plains with heavy snow and winds up to 75 miles an hour today. It closed schools and highways and made travel risky.
The American Stock Exchange made it four-in-a-row yesterday as most Stocks advanced in active trading.
The new Madison Square Garden, being built atop Penn Station, will contain the largest bowling facility in Manhattan, a Garden spokesman announced yesterday.

INDIVIDUAL meat pies can provide a, change of pace for dinner or luncheon. The following recipe combines veal, ham and apple in a salty cracker crust and tops each pie off with fluffy mashed potatoes.
THEY'RE as hot as sesame seed bagels, the most public of public sweethearts since Mary Pickford and Douglas Fairbanks (to whom he is related on his mother's side).

The arts of Japan, in a festival that clearly shows the influences of Western contemporary trends, opened yesterday at the Union Carbide Building, Park Avenue and 47th Street. This is the first stop in a tour that will take the festival to Chicago, San Francisco and Pittsburgh.
"The best laid schemes o' mice and men gang aft a-gley," Gwen Davis, author of "The Best Laid Plans," agreed yesterday.
GENEVA, March 22 The United States tried today to advance the negotiations for a treaty to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons but was balked by the Soviet Union.
The engagement of Miss Maureen R. Dinan to Ronald S. Ziemba has been announced by her grandmother, Mrs. William R. Macdonnald of New York.
WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP) The Senate passed today legislation designed to bring uniformity in daylight saving time throughout the nation.
In a surprise move, Edward L. Cushman, vice president of the American Motors Corporation, resigned yesterday.

AUSTIN, Tex., March 22 (AP) The Texas Railroad Commission has raised the state's oil allowable rate to a record of 33.7 per cent of potential production for April, usually the month when demand for crude oil slackens.
LONDON, March 22 "Little Englanders" was the scornful name given to those in Britain who opposed the Boer War, saying that the English should concern themselves only, with England.
Stocks closed higher in more active trading; volume, 8.91 million shares.
An experiment that could cut the time needed to rehabilitate a slum building to 48 hours will begin next month in the laboratory of a rotting tenement on East 5th Street.
The 10-cent cup of coffee became a little scarcer last week when four Horn Hardart Automats quietly raised their prices to 15 cents.
One of the nation's foremost electronic engineers has proposed that the United States construct a radio telescope of 10,000 steerable dishes that would cover an area 10 miles across.
ALBANY, March 22 The Court of Appeals ordered into effect today a reapportionment plan that party leaders said could bring about another politically split Legislature after the November election.

PARIS, March 22 (UPI) One hundred thousand gas and electrical workers struck at midnight tonight. The walkout threatened to be the most crippling in the current wave of nationwide strikes protesting President de Gaulle's economic austerity program.

GENEVA, March 22 John Harlin, a 30-year-old American from Los Altos, Calif., fell more than 3,000 feet to his death today off the sheer north face of the Eiger in central Switzerland. An experienced climber, he ran a mountaineering school at Leysin.
WASHINGTON, March 22 (UPI) The Senate Minority Leader, Everett McKinley Dirksen,introduced a proposed constitutional amendment today to permit voluntary prayer in public schools.
A navigators' strike has shut down the worldwide operations of Air-India, including its transAtlantic route, the airline reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 22 The House Democratic leadership asked Senate Democratic leaders today to look into the possibility of the Senate's acting first on legislation to ease restrictions on picketing of construction sites.
ANKARA, Turkey, March 22 There is a saying in Turkey that it is not the Government but the opposition that rules the country. Rarely has that saying seemed more appropriate than in recent weeks.

A number of next season's prospects for Broadway were disclosed yesterday. Alexander H. Cohen said he will import three plays from London, "The Homecoming," "At the Drop of Another Hat" (a sequel to "At the Drop of a Hat") and "You Never Can Tell." The first two will be presented here on successive nights during Christmas week.
Rubber, zinc, gum and newsprint figured in price changes yesterday.

Richard R. Pivirotto, president of the Joseph Horne Company, Pittsburgh department store, has been elected a vice president of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation, parent company of Horne, Lewis P. Seiler, president of Associated, announced yesterday.
Senator Robert F. Kennedy was granted a visa yesterday to visit South Africa, but not for the date he had planned.
The Johnson Administration's controversial attempts to combat inflation through its wage-price guideposts seems to be following the pattern established in Europe, where ...
The city is installing a $348,000 computer in its Department of Finance in an effort to simplify and eliminate some clerical tasks, Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday.

GLEN RIDGE, N.J., March 22 Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Gary Mowder have made known the engagement of Mrs. Mowder's daughter, Miss Annette Hare Richard, to Leroy Francis Lowey Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Lowey of Richmond Hill, Queens.
Newman Levy, a retired lawyer, who was widely known as a writer of light verse, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived at 52 West 58th Street.

A corporate executive, whose company derives about 25 per cent of its income from international operations, cautioned yesterday against expecting "too much more" from private business in helping to alleviate the country's payments difficulties.
"Maybe I'm crazy, but I like it here!" That's what Red Cross clubmobile girl

COCOA, Fla., March 22 (AP) Frank Carpin, the pitcher, drove in two runs with an eighth-inning bases-loaded infield hit today to break a 3-3 deadlock and give the Houston Astros a 5-3 exhibition baseball victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.
TRENTON, March 22 The State Supreme Court was asked today to overturn a manslaughter conviction of a Negro because the judge used the word "nigger" at his trial.

WASHINGTON, March 22 Talk with Ralph Nader about food and sooner or later he will laughingly tell of the time he won a $20 bet by eating two 12-inch strawberry shortcakes at Boston's Durgin-Park restaurant. Or the morning, after a roast beef breakfast, when on a...
OTTAWA, March 22 (AP) Canada's international payments deficit rose to $1,136,000,000 last year from $433million in 1964, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today.
PRINCETON, N.J., March 22 (AP) Vu Van Thai, South Vietnam's Ambassador to the United States, said tonight that Communist China was entitled to belong to the United Nations.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 22 The Soviet delegation threw open its doors today to 17 American teenagers for an afternoon of songs, talks and treats.

Twenty-three of 39 underworld figures responded yesterday to subpoenas issued by Brooklyn District Attorney Aaron E. Koota, who seeks to head off a gangland war for the control of gambling and other interests in Brooklyn. However, their scheduled appearance before a grand jury was deferred until next Monday.
The time has about arrived for a halt to the political buck-passing on Mayor Lindsay's new tax program.
While medical reports on Buckpasser's ailing hoof continued to arrive from Florida yesterday, another top 3-yearold limped to the sidelines here.
James A. Davis, senior partner in Davis Quat, lawyers at 259 Broadway, died yesterday in his home, the Gramercy Park Hotel, 52 Gramercy Park North. He was 82 years old.
ARE moose ready to become part of the Great Society? Reference, of course, is to the bulbous-nosed, bellthroated, palmated antlered variety, rather to any fraternal order.
Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower has come out in favor of sending draft-card burners to jail "at least for the war's duration."

SAN FRANCISCO, March 22 (AP) An overflow crowd of spectators cheered wildly at the City Hall here yesterday as the Board of Supervisors voted down two proposed freeways on which the Federal Government was willing to put up $280-million.
The 29th anniversary dinner dance of the Lillian R. Spector League, an affiliate of the Jewish Chronic Disease Hospital in Brooklyn, will be held in the St. Regis Roof on Saturday evening.
WOLVERHAMPTON, England, March 22 (UPI) Jack Bodell of Britain outpointed Giuseppe Migliri of Italy tonight in a 10-round heavyweight fight.
LOS ANGELES, March 22 Lloyd N. Hand formally announced his candidacy today for the Democratic nomination for lieutenant governor.
LONDON, March 22 Prime Minister Wilson was nursing an inflamed and painful eye tonight after being struck by a thin glass vial thrown by a 15-year-old boy.
A leading Jesuit magazine has called upon Roman Catholic bishops in the United States to authorize a "reliable and impartial study" on whether priests should be allowed to marry.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., March 22 Robert H. Wells, founder and president of Wells and Associates, Inc., management consultants here, died Sunday at the Montcalm nursing home. He was 65 years old and lived at 17 Trinity Place here.
In a departure from traditional theater policy, "The Gospel According to St. Matthew" will be presented in the suburbs on an advanced-sale, reservedseat basis.

LOS ANGELES, March 22 Henry Miller, who will shortly celebrate his 75th birthday, busily embarked on his second career this week. The controversial and often-banned writer, who frankly admits "I've written everything I want to say," has emerged as a popular painter here.
The city's Landmarks Preservation Commission announced yesterday the designation of 12 additional structures as landmarks.
Ruza Pospinov sang the role of Madelon for the first time with the Metropolitan Opera in the season's seventh performance of Giordano's "Andrea Chenier" last night.

LONDON, March 22 (UPI) The Labor party lifted its ban on the American director Joseph Strick today and agreed to permit him and his camera crew to attend its campaign rallies for a television documentary film on the British general elections.

SINGAPORE, March 22 Foreign Minister Adam Malik said today that Indonesia's foreign policy would be "independent and active." This indicated a return to the nonaligned position that preceded the far-left, pro-Peking policies of the last several years.
BRUSSELS, March 22 About 8,000 employes of three European international organizations began a 24-hour strike today for higher pay.

Thousands of books were moved five blocks yesterday from the old to the new Queens Borough Central Library from the high-ceilinged but cramped elegance of the past to the streamlined, spacious functionalism of tomorrow.

ALBANY, March 22 Governor Rockefeller is pressing Senator Jacob K. Javits to accept now a role in next fall's state campaign that could effectively bar the Senator from seeking the governorship himself.
New-car sales in the United States slipped in the mid-March period, reports from Detroit disclosed yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. Leonard S. Granby of 141 East 88th Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mina Lee Granby, to James A. Leiter, son of Mrs. Benjamin Goldman of 1100 Park Avenue and the late Dr. H. Evans Leiter.
My Fair Lady" at the Criterion Theater.
AN ebullient troika galloped full tilt across the screen last night Carol Burnett, Lucille Ball and (he should show up more often and better) Zero Mostel.
The city has begun an intensive study of the possibility of trying again a dramatic experiment it made in the 1949-50 water shortage: rainmaking.

BONN, March 22 The wave of anti-German feeling in many countries represents a "serious threat" to democracy in West Germany, Dr. Richard Jager, the Federal Minister of Justice, warned in an interview last Friday.
Edward I. Koch, Greenwich Village Reform Democratic leader, announced yesterday he would seek the Democratic nomination for the City Counsil seat formerly held by Theodore R. Kupferman.

WASHINGTON, March 22 J.P. Stevens Co., one of the nation's largest textile producers, was found guilty today of "flagrant unlawfulness" in trying to block a union organizing drive in its Southern plants. The National Labor Relations Board, in a unanimous decision, ordered the company to restore,

WASHINGTON, March 22 The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission has ruled that it does not have jurisdiction in the plight of two Negro scientists who could not find housing near their place of employment.s
REMARKS are not literature, we were told by Gertrude Stein. To this might be added: Chatter is not drama.

Joe Lynch, a former Georgetown miler now competing for the New York Athletic Club, will replace Robin Lingle on a six-man United States team, which departs Wednesday for the Southern Games in Trinidad.
The decisions of the Supreme Court on Monday establishing new tests of obscently have thrown portions of the publishing and entertainment worlds into confusion and consternation.

ADELAIDE, Australia, March 22 (AP) Jim Grelle of Portland, Ore., beat Ron Clarke of Australia in the two-mile run and young Richmond Flowers Jr. of Tuscaloosa, Ala., scored a double in the hurdles today in a triangular track and field meet involving the United States, Australia and the Soviet Union.

LONG BEACH, Calif., March 22 (UPI) Juan Marichal, who almost pitched the San Francisco Giants to the 1965 National League pennant, ended a 23-day holdout today when he agreed to a contract calling for a little more than $70,000.
CLEARWATER, Fla. March 22 (UPI) Bobby Wine's home run in the 12th inning today gave the Philadelphia Phillies a 3-2 exhibition baseball victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers.
MINNEAPOLIS, March 22 Vice President Humphrey's prestige is at stake in Minnesota this year, but so far he has made no move to resolve a remarkable political situation.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 22 (UPI) The San Francisco Warriors dismissed Alex Hannum as coach today and named a former Boston Celtic star, Bill Sharman, to replace him.

WASHINGTON, March 22 President Johnson announced today that he would send his press secretary and closest aide, Bill D. Moyers, and two other top Government officials to South Vietnam next Tuesday as part of his continuing survey of the social and economic needs of the country.
The printers union here proposed yesterday that the three New York newspapers planning to merge be restricted temporarily by the Justice Department from disposing of any equipment or plant.
Adrian C. (Ace) Israel resigned yesterday as president of Bache Co., Inc., one of the nation's leading stock brokerage concerns.

R.H. Macy Co., Inc., which operates a nationwide chain of 51 department stores, achieved new sales and earnings records for the 26 and 52 weeks ended Jan. 29, according to unaudited results issued yesterday.

In an otherwise dull trading day for commodities, copper futures managed to spark some interest on the selling side. Prices plunged the 2-cents-apound limit, but there was such a rush to sell that only 16 trades could be completed during the day. Overhanging the market at day's end were orders to sell about 422 contracts.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 22 Just how inexorably baseball's wheel of fortune keeps turning was vividly demonstrated today as the Detroit Tigers defeated the New York Yankees, 7-4.
MILAN, Mich., March 22 (AP) Joseph M. Valachi, the man who broke the Mafia blood oath of secrecy, was brought today to the Federal prison here, which the Government hopes will be his final home.

HARRISBURG, Pa., March 22 A special legislative committee voted today to cite Commissioner E. Wilson Purdy and three of his subordinates in the Pennsylvania State Police for criminal contempt in ignoring its subpoenas to appear at a hearing last week into alleged wiretapping by the force.

WASHINGTON, March 22 The Justice Department filed a lawsuit today to prevent Alabama from prolonging the terms of local white officials in a county where Negro voter registration has caught up with white registration.

HAUPPAUGUE, L.I., March 22 Plans for a court campaign to force the integration of Long Island's volunteer fire departments, which are now virtually all white, were announced last night by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

The apparel industry's biggest merger, a $35-million stock-andcash purchase of the Colonial Corporation of America by the Kayser-Roth Corporation, was approved yesterday by the shareholders of both companies.
A burglary suspect who said he had a set of keys that would open any parking meter in Queens and that he paid $300 a week for their use was arraigned yesterday in Queens Criminal Court.
WASHINGTON, Marrh 22 The top Federal shipping official told Congress today that a number of economic problems must be solved if this country is to have an effective merchant marine.

Ed Kelly of Baltimore snapped the unbeaten string of the former champion, Luther Lassiter, and Irving Crane of Rochester scored a tourneyhigh run of 141 last night at the world pocket billiards championships at the Hotel Commodore.

AUSTIN, Tex., March 22 Texans who did not pay their poll tax of $1.75 by the deadline on Jan. 31 turned out in unexpected numbers during a special 15-day free registration period, after a Federal Court ruled that the state tax was unconstitutional.

A new statewide committee of religious and civic leaders yesterday accused legislative leaders in Albany of "contempt" for their fellow legislators and the public in failing to open a debate on "meaningful" divorce reform.

SHE started the first boutique and wishes to heaven she had tried to register as a trademark the use of the word for a fancy accessory shop. (In Paris it had been used to denote a less than ordinary place.) She was the first go show halter necklines, sweaters for formal wear, little jackets that matched cocktail or evening dresses, and beach hats that came down over the eyes and had little windows.
FORT WORTH, March 22 (AP) The Kimbell Art Foundation has agreed to sell an ancient art treasure to the Los Angeles County Art Museum for $300,000.
MONTVALE, N.J., March 22 John Wallace Foster, chairman of the board of Tingue, Brown Co., manufacturers of industrial textiles, died at his home here today. He was 70 years old.
Smokers have already started to pay more for cigarettes even though the White House pressured most of the cigarette manufacturers to rescind their recently announced price increases.

The contents of the 500-room Shelburne Hotel at Lexington Avenue and 37th Street are being sold at a series of auctions. It has been reported that plans are under way to convert the 40-year-old building to an apartment hotel.
BERLIN, March 23 (UPI) Dr. John Slawson, executive vice president of the American Jewish Committee, today warned against overestimating the danger of extreme neo-nationalism in Germany.
The Heywood-Wakefield Company, a furniture maker in Gardner, Mass., has announced the appointment of George H. Heywood Jr. as president.
The bond market paused in its upward trend yesterday morning but only briefly.

The New Jersey Supreme Court announced yesterday that presiding judges of the 21 county District Courts had been asked to urge principals in civil suits to use six-man juries to speed trials and reduce court costs.
ALBANY, March 23 All motor vehicles registered in the state would have to pass annual safety inspections under a bill that narrowly won final passage in the Legislature today.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., March 23 (AP) Jack McCloskey, whose University of Pennsylvania basketball team won the Ivy League championship this year, was hired today to coach Wake Forest of the Atlantic Coast Conference.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) The House accepted today a technical Senate amendment to assure Congressional scrutiny of Pentagon spending and then sent to President Johnson an emergency $13.1billion appropriation to help finance the Vietnam war.

Throughout the recent controversy over the administration and financing of the City University the Joint Legislative Committee on Higher Education, under chairmanship of State Senator Manfred Ohrenstein, has provided an object lesson in responsible fact-finding, with a view to constructive planning.
DONCASTER, England March 23 (AP) The American-bred favorite, Riot Act, got off fast and put on a strong finish today for a half-length victory in the one-mile Lincolnshire Handicap.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 23 The touring golf professionals, like Prof. Henry Higgins of "My Fair Lady," have grown accustomed to a face. Week after week they are delighted to play for big purses. When a larger one comes along, they show no sign of shock.
ALBANY, March 23 The Democrats served notice today that they would try to blame Governor Rockefeller if tuition fees are established at the City University of New York.
The Supreme Court's affirmance on Monday of the obscenity conviction of Ralph Ginzburg, publisher of Eros, has revived the near-moribund state and Federal anti-pornography laws.
Miss Patricia M. Higgins and John Joseph Brennan plan to be married in August.
Public hearings are to begin here Oct. 17 on the Consolidated Edison Company's proposed $162-million power plant at Storm King Mountain.
"A cleanup!" the Brooklyn merchant snorted in dis gust. "They're cleaning up who?"

President Johnson at his latest press conference cited a number of economic developments to prove why it would be unwise to step "on the brakes too fast" to counter inflation. Retail sales in January and February ran behind November and December;
