WASHINGTON, March 23 With the help of civil rights leaders, President Johnson has apparently persuaded Congress to transfer the Community Relations Service to the Department of Justice.

LAFAYETTE, La., March 23 (AP) Republicans have made another dent in once Democratic Dixie. A Republican candidate won a Louisiana legislative seat in one of the few parishes (counties) carried by President Johnson in 1964.

SINCE this column drew attention last week to the plight of the American Negro Dance Company and its inability to raise the necessary $130,000 to represent American dance at the First World Festival of Negro Arts in Dakar, Senegal, quite a lot has been happening.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 23 Just when it seemed that the New York Mets were ready to hit their established mid-season stride, they went one step beyond today.
WASHINGTON, March 23 The Supreme Court ruled today that a company's sale of the same product at two different prices can be a violation of antitrust laws.

The Off Broadway production of "The Underpants" has been delayed as a result of the dispute between the Society of Stage Directors and Choreographers and the League of Off Broadway Theaters and Producers. The society is seeking recognition from the league.
WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) President and Mrs. Johnson entertained members of the Federal judiciary at the White House tonight.
EDINBURGH, Scotland, March 23 (Reuters) Andrew Grimond, eldest son of the Liberal party leader, Jo Grimond, was found dead in his apartment here tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 23 The head of a Madison Avenue agency operating a network of industrial undercover agents admitted today planting a spy for drug manufacturers in a Connecticut wholesale drug concern.

YONKERS, March 23 The 10-man United States syndicate that recently paid $125,000 for Orbiter, the New Zealand champion pacer, will have to shell out an additional $3.15 for a patch that Del Insko placed over the 7-year-old gelding's left eye before he won a mile qualifying event at Yonkers Raceway in impressive style today.

A burglary ring that made master keys to the city's parking meters and then rented them to thieves on a weekly basis has apparently been smashed, Queens District Attorney Nat H. Hentel said yesterday.
CARACAS, Venezuela, March 23 (AP) Police searched today for Mrs. Anna Spring Hitz after a court issued a warrant for her arrest on a defamation complaint.
NEWARK, March 23 (AP) A $388,900 judgment has been awarded against eight directors of Office Buildings of America, Inc., a bankrupt real estate syndicating concern here.
SAN FRANCISCO, Match 23 (AP) A thousand diamonds, valued at $100,000, were reported missing today from a safe deposit box at the Hilton Hotel.

GREENWICH, Conn., March 23 John O. Ekblom, former chairman of the board of the Hupp Corporation, heating and refrigeration equipment manufacturers, died today at the Westchester Division of New York Hospital in White Plains. He was 71 years old and was a resident of Greenwich.

Former Assemblyman Hyman E. Mintz was sentenced yesterday to a year in jail on his conviction of conspiring to bribe a detective to obtain grand jury secrets. His co-defendant, Carl Kaplan, former police chief of Fallsburgh, N.Y., received a six-month sentence. Both were found guilty here on Feb. 25.

WHEN the entry list for the International Kennel Club show in Chicago closed with 3,420 dogs, even an old pro like George F. Foley, who has been running such events as a superintendent for more than 50 years, was surprised. The event will be on April 2 and 3.

A 2.5-million share offering of General Telephone and Electronics Corporation common stock a block valued at $104,375,000 was oversubscribed yesterday after it was placed on the market at $41.75 a share.

Woody Klein, Mayor Lindsay's press secretary, said yesterday the Mayor believed that the Metropolitan Opera House at Broadway and 39th Street "should be saved and used for some constructive purpose." "He has one or two staff members working on it," Mr. Klein added.
Kitty Carlisle's lifetime dream to sing for the Metropolitan Opera is expected to come true this winter, barring unforseen developments.

Hardly anything could better point up the reasons for unification of the city's transportation policy-making agencies than Robert Moses' current defiance of City Hall on a third tube for the Queens Midtown Tunnel. The Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority, under Mr. Moses' chairmanship, advertised for bids for borings for the tunnel less than two weeks after Mayor Lindsay had publicly opposed the project.
World auction records were set last night for sculpture by Auguste Rodin, Henri Matisse and Henry Moore and for paintings by Fernand Leger and Piet Mondrian.
The nation's electric power production rose 4.9 per cent in the week ended March 19, compared with the level in the 1965 week, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 23 A program for a Vietnam settlement was offered today by the American Friends Service Committee as an "11thhour appeal for sanity."

MOSCOW, March 23 The in- ternational Communist move- ment passed a milestone today on the way to eventual breakup, in the opinion of foreign analysts here, with the refusal of Communist China and some of its ideological allies to attend the 23d Soviet party congress next week.

A GREAT figure of the past came upon the stage of the Longacre Theater last night through the theatrical magic of Hal Holbrook. He brought Mark Twain back to life to stir the laughter and stab the conscience of a public yearning for such a voice as that of the nation's one true comic genius.

SAIGON, Thursday, March 24 (AP) A strong Vietcong force struck at a South Vietnamese Government base 20 miles north of Saigon late last night, touching off a four-hour battle that could be heard in the capital.

NEWPORT, R.I., March 23 (AP) The death on March 10 of Miss Edith Wetmore, prominent in Newport social activities for many years, brought about dissolution of a $5-million trust fund, it was learned today.
The British pound was slightly off in moderate trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday. The currency closed at $2.7935, down 7 points from Tuesday.

Dr. and Mrs. George Clinton Andrews of New York and Lake Placid, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Alice Andrews, to Ernest Powell Brinkley Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Brinkley of Raleigh, N.C.
WASHINGTON, March 23 A system to help prevent mid-air collisions is "closer to realization" than at any time since a search for one began 11 years ago, airline representatives said today.

ATLANTIC BEACH, L.I., March 23 Harry Meyerson of 101 Richard Street, president of Central Rigging and Contracting Corporation of 280 Madison Avenue, New York, and Milford, Conn., died yesterday in Mount Sinai hospital, New York. He was 69 years old.
ALBANY, March 23 The legislative reapportionment plan adopted yesterday by the Court of Appeals faced a series of challenges today.
WASHINGTON, March 23 Local antipoverty agencies across the nation were ordered today to open all their books for public inspection upon demand.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., March 23 A Massapequa, L.I., furniture salesman, held in the shooting here Monday of the president of a discount store, was arraigned today and charged with assault with intent to commit murder.
WASHINGTON, March 23 After Monday's decision in the Ginzburg case it is obvious that the Supreme Court is in over its head on the smut issue.
CHICAGO, March 18 The slogan of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s first civil rights campaign in the North is evident almost everywhere in the Negro district on Chicago's West Side.
National Pickle Week is gone And so are Kidney Day, Nutrient Value of Eggs Day and Youth Foot Health Week.
A little more than two years from now, Jacques Piccard and four crewmen will use the Gulf Stream to carry them on a 2,000-mile undersea voyage from Florida to Nova Scotia.

George Bernard Shaw's "Heartbreak House," a comedy dealing with the problems, weaknesses and failures of 20thcentury civilization, will be televised on Channel 13's "Sunday Showcase" at 9 P.M. on April 17.

SYOSSET, L.I., March 23 Boris Krasulin, First Secretary of the Soviet Mission to the United Nations, was driving on the Long Island Expressway this morning when he noticed that he was 23 miles from United Nations headquarters in Manhattan.

LOS ANGELES, March 23 (UPI) Don Drysdale said today the salary dispute involving him, Sandy Koufax and the Los Angeles Dodger management had reached the stage where the two pitching stars had "no reason to believe" they would play in 1966.
JAKARTA, Thursday, March 24 (AP) President Sukarno appeared last night at a Pakistani diplomatic reception and declared: "I have not been ousted."

HOLLYWOOD, March 23 The Writers Guild of America today voted its award for the year's best comedy screenplay to Herb Gardner for "A Thousand Clowns." Morton Fine and David Friedkin won the award for the best-written drama for "The Pawnbroker." Ernest Lehman was honored for the bestwritten musical, "The Sound of Music."
A scheduled 56-hour fast was started at Queens College yesterday by some 50 students protesting United States involvement in the Vietnam war.
BASS RIVER, Mass., March 23 Abbott Kittredge Spencer, a retired New York advertising executive, died yesterday in the Megansett Nursing Home after a long illness. He was 63 years old.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 23 For the second time in less than a week the Soviet mission held a briefing for correspondents today and a spokesman answered questions.
T. William Rodes, tanker operations manager for the Union Carbide Corporation here, died Tuesday in Galveston, Tex. He was 6l years old and lived at 18 Springfield Avenue, Cranford, N.J.
PHOENIX, Ariz., March 23 (AP) A 2-run ninth-inning rally, with two out, gave the Cleveland Indians a 2-1 victory over the San Francisco Giants today.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 23 (AP) Gov. John H. Chafee announced today that he would seek a third two-year term.
The Kennecott Copper Corporation announced here yesterday the election of Russell DeYoung, chairman of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, as a director.

John M. McLaughlin, administrative assistant to the president of the Bilbyrne Corporation, consulting engineers of 50 Church Street, died Tuesday in his home at 30-02 Broadway, Astoria, Queens. He was 50 years old.

One of Britain's most publicized young theatrical lions, John Arden, the playwright, arrived in New York yesterday afternoon looking like a lamb somewhat unshorn and unshaven, perhaps, but so might anyone who had just stepped off the jet from London.

JULIO BOLBOCHAN, a Buenos Aires businessman whose hobby is chess, plays adroitly enough to have been selected as one of the 16 contenders in the current 27th International Tournament at Mar del Plata, Argentina.
The appointment of former Acting City Labor Commissioner James J. McFadden as executive director of the New York City Institute of Industry and Labor, a new organization, was announced yesterday.
NORFOLK, Va., March 23 (AP) Russell Stanger, 42 years old, assistant conductor of the Minneapolis Symphony Orchestra, will become conductor of the Norfolk Symphony Orchestra.

Rear Adm. Richard P. McCullough, who commanded a converted yacht that sank a German submarine in World War I, and was decorated for intelligence work in World War II, died Tuesday at the Naval Hospital in Philadelphia. He was 85 years old and lived at 53 Rockview Avenue, North Plainfield, N.J.

President Johnson flew into New York unexpectedly and in secrecy yesterday to join in a half-hour funeral service for Mrs. Stella Baar Celler. His presence was a tribute both to her and her husband, Representative Emanuel Celler.

DARIEN, Conn., March 23 Dr. Gregory C. Coffin, who stirred up controversy during his four and a half years as superintendent of schools, has resigned to become superintendent of the Evanston, Ill., school system.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 23 President Sukarno is being virtually ignored by the military, which has in effect taken power in Indonesia. His telephones have been cut, his helicopters are suddenly being serviced and his palace guard escort is itself "escorted."
WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) A scientist can get funds for space research more easily than for weather studies, a Senate subcommittee was told today.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., March 23 The University of Notre Dame formally opened a Graduate School of Theology and an Institute for Advanced Religious Studies at a special academic convocation here tonight.
DETROIT, March 23 (AP) A one-man grand jury indicted Wayne County Sheriff Peter Buback and Undersheriff James Bommarito today on seven counts of willful neglect of duty.
RAHWAY, N.J., March 23 Harry Green of 160 Coddington Street, founder and head of a retail furniture house and long a Jewish leader here, died yesterday at a nursing home in Elizabeth. His age was 59.
The wholesale commodity index fell to 113.0 on Tuesday from 113.3 on Monday.

I am very pleased to address the Foreign Service Institute this morning and to come here to meet with so many Americans that are preparing to serve their country abroad. As one who believes that we cannot shorten our reach in the world, I am greatly encouraged by the number and the quality of those who are studying at this institute. You have the gratitude of your countrymen and my own assurance of support.
TEL AVIV, March 23 There was confusion here today over a Supreme Court judge who circumvented Israeli legal obstacles to a wedding here by marrying his fiancee in New York.
The appointment of Stanley R. Spinola as supervising customs agent of New York has been announced by Lester D. Johnson, United States Commissioner of Customs.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) A House committee was told today a state highway department study had shown that 68 per cent of the automobile drivers killed in traffic accidents on the state's highways had had enough alcohol in their blood to intoxicate them.
The Students for a Democratic Society filed suit yesterday in Federal Court to compel the Transit Authority to accept a subway advertisement protesting the war in Vietnam.
WESTFIELD, N.J., March 23 The Rev. William M. Moore of 551 Downer Street, pastor of the Metropolitan Baptist Church in nearby Scotch Plains for 22 years, died today in his home at the age of 66.
The world's richest golf tournament, offering more than $200,000 in prize money, will be held next year and in 1968 at the Westchester Country Club in Harrison, N.Y.
WASHINGTON, March 23--Secretary of the Treasury Henry H. Fowler strongly indicated today that there would be no decision on an anti-inflation tax increase until the end of April.
The Board of Higher Education is considering the possibility of relocating three municipal colleges on part of the site of the old Washington Market in lower Manhattan.
CLEVELAND, March 23 The Cleveland Trust Company filed a suit in Common Pleas Court today to seek an opinion on the legality of the bank's controversial practice of voting its own stock held in trust.
PERTH AMBOY, N.J., March 23(AP) Construction workers will attempt to move the damaged center of a railroad swing bridge over the Raritan River into place Saturday so that repairs can be started.
Sales of the nation's leading chain stores and mail order houses increased sharply in February, according to a survey made yesterday by The New York Times.

Heresy trials have become unfashionable as means of settling ecclesiastical disputes, but it is helpful to recall that the situation was not always so. In this volume Matthew Spinka translates the account of the trial of John Hus by Peter of Mladonovice, one of the few witnesses sympathetic to the early Bohemian reformer.
The Ronson Corporation had a 15.9 per cent increase in profits last year on a sales gain of 10.9 per cent, the annual report disclosed yesterday.
The Transit Authority is conducting engineering surveys in Times Square to determine the feasibility of establishing a subway power-distributing substation under 43d Street.

FOR 16 seasons Cesare Siepi has been one of the glor ies of the Metropolitan Opera, but during that period the Italian bass has only intermittently ventured on the recital stage here. Last night, after a nine-year lapse, he appeared at Philharmonic Hall in a solo program of songs and arias.

Richard (Pancho) Gonzalez of Los Angeles, courted by promoters, adored by galleries and merely tolerated by rivals, meets Lew Hoad of Australia tonight in the $25,000 professional tennis tournament at Madison Square Garden. Yesterday, Hoad warned Gonzalez to be prepared.

FULLERTON, Calif., March 23 (UPI) A minister and his wife, both white, will give up a 2-year-old Negro boy they adopted a year ago because they have been "harassed, humiliated and threatened" by persistent telephone callers.
CORNING, N.Y., March 23 Governor Rockefeller voiced confidence today that Senator Jacob K. Javits would ultimately agree to direct the Governor's campaign for re-election in November.
TORONTO, March 23 Holders of $16.8-million in subordinated notes of the now-insolvent Atlantic Acceptance Corporation threw in the legal sponge today and, in effect, accepted their loss.
WEST LONG BRANCH, N.J., March 23 An award of $400,000 to Monmouth Collge for an addition to the Guggenheim Memorial Library was announced today by Dr. William G. Van Note, president of the college.

PARIS, March 23 Some of the most important works by Georges Braque and Pablo Picasso came back to France for the first time in 50 years as part of a French-Czechoslovak exhibition at the National Museum of Modern Art.
WINTER HAVEN, Fla., March 23 The New York Yankees, who had hit only five home runs in 12 games this spring, suddenly found the range today, whacked four and overpowered the Boston Red Sox, 8-6.

ALBANY, March 23 (AP) The Senate voted today to authorize pari-mutuel betting on quarter horse racing in New York State after a bitter debate marked by a charge that one of Governor Rockefeller's key aides exerted pressure for the measure.

WHITE PLAINS, March 23 Harry Wolfe Meidman, founder and director of the Knollwood School for children in Elmsford, died today in White Plains Hospital. He was 57 years old and lived an Old Knollwood Road, Elmsford.

NEW ORLEANS, March 23 Development of a new yardstick to determine the "reasonableness" of ocean shipping rates in United States foreign trade was urged here today by an official of the Federal Maritime Commission.

New York's commercial banks and mutual savings banks locked horns in Albany yesterday over a bill that would give mutual savings banks the right for a five-year period to convert into commercial banks.
SUMMIT, N.J., March 23 Mrs. Florence E. Bartholomew, of 22 Plymouth Avenue, wife of Albert J. Bartholomew, former principal of Summit High School, died Monday at Overlook Hospital.

William Glasgow Thompson, a retired assistant vice president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and a key negotiator in installation of the world's first underseas telephone cable system, died yesterday in New Rochelle (N.Y.) Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived at Chatsworth Gardens in Larchmont, N.Y.
LOS ANGELES, March 23 The embattled Los Angeles County Museum of Art was plunged today into a new controversy with county officials over the display of two works of art denounced as pornographic.
WASHINGTON, March 23 The threat of a partial broadcasting blackout of President Johnson's speeches was apparently removed today at a meeting of broadcasting unions and management.

WASHINGTON, March 23 From Austin to Boston, from Miami to Madison to Minneapolis, and from Nashville to Sacramento, Democrats are stirring to the prospect of a battle for control of the Presidential succession.

STOWE, Vt., March 23 Chiharu (Chick) Igaya, a former Dartmouth star, who won the 1956 Olympics slalom silver medal for Japan at Cortina D'Ampezzo, Italy, appeared on Spruce Peak today with a protege his 3-yearold son, Takaharo. Since the friendly, black-haired youngster ...

A lawyer for the Studebaker Corporation contended yesterday that Richard D. Gittlin, a partner in the brokerage firm of Kleiner, Bell Co., breached Securities and Exchange Commission proxy rules when he solicited "authorizations" from 42 other stockholders in the South Bend, Ind., concern.

BRUSSELS, March 23 The Executive Commission of the European Economic Community or Common Market said today that it did not know whether employes who participated in a 24-hour strike for higher salaries would lose a day's pay.

The Delaware River Basin Commission acted in Philadelphia yesterday to extend to the end of May the drought emergency that it declared last July. The emergency would have expired on April 1. The commission reported a general improvement of water conditions in the basin.

BERLIN, March 23 The East German Communist party said today that the recent exchange of letters between it and the West German Social Democrats signified the beginning of a dis- cussion on divided Germany that could lead to a peaceful solution of the German question.

GREENFIELD, Mass., March 23 Mr. and Mrs. Arthur William Sherman have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Linda Sherman, to Ralph Carlton Johnston, son of Mr. and Mrs. R.A. Johnston of Fremont, Neb.

TEL AVIV, March 23 Foreign Minister Abba Eban told the Knesset (Parliament) in Jerusalem today that the outlook for peace between Israel and the Arabs has improved because Arab countries were rejecting Egyptian domination.
WASHINGTON, March 23 Senator Edward M. Kennedy demanded today that the State Department explain its legal authority for "shadowing" American citizens traveling abroad.

A detective shot a 16-year-old Bronx youth last night after the boy had stabbed him in the chest following a long chase, the police reported. The youth, with wounds in the right and left shoulder, was reported in good condition at Lincoln Hospital. The detective's condition was described as serious.
The voters of Ashdown, Ark., approved a $50-million bond sale yesterday to finance the construction of a paper mill for the Nekoosa-Edwards Paper Company.
A plan in principle was agreed to yesterday under which the Riegel Paper Corporation will acquire the Kalamazoo Paper Company for stock worth about $25.5-million.
LONDON, March 23 A comparison of the use of television in election campaigns in Britain and the United States finds delightful differences and diverting similarities.
THE women who believe in letting fashion work for them and do not consider themselves pace-setters were out in force Tuesday as Elizabeth Arden introduced her collection for spring and summer.

Your Holiness, dear brother in Christ, it is with heartfelt gratitude and brotherly affection in Christ that I greet you as your guest in this Vatican City. I greet you in my office as Archbishop of Canterbury and as President of the Lambeth Conference of Bishops from every part of the Anglican communion throughout the world.
Justice Haim Cohn of the Israeli Supreme Court was married here yesterday to an Israeli music critic, but he may have to go before his own court colleagues to find out whether his marriage is valid.

WAYLAND, Mass., March 23 Mr. and Mrs. Allan R. Finlay of Wayland and Falmouth have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Morrill Finlay, to the Rev. Donald Machell Dunbar, assistant rector of St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Weston. He is the son of the Rev. Howard R. Dunbar, rector of Trinity Episcopal Church in Newton Centre, and Mrs. Dunbar of Newton Centre and Brewster.

Robert M. Wolf, president of the George J. Wolf Realty Company of Jersey City, has been named chairman of the Area Development Council of Jersey City, the city's official Industrial development agency.

ROME, March 23 Pope Paul VI and Dr. Arthur Michael Ramsey, Archbishop of Canterbury, met in a simple, historic ceremony in the Sistine Chapel today to exchange a "kiss of peace" and hopes for Christian unity.
The New York Philharmonic will present a festival of music by Igor Stravinsky at Philharmonic Hall between June 30 and July 23.

LONDON, March 23 Dr. Arthur Michael Ramsey, the Archbishop of Canterbury, has never hesitated to veer from precedent or even to shock. It is, therefore, expectable that he should be the Primate of the Church of England to pay the first official call on a Pope in 400 years.

SARASOTA, Fla., March 23 (UPT) The Chicago White Sox, who lead the Grapefruit League standings, gained their sixth consecutive exhibition baseball victory today as they rallied in the ninth inning to beat the Cincinnati Reds, 4-3. The White Sox now have won 12 of 14 exhibition starts.

PITTSBURGH, March 23 (UPI) Television will never replace a gorilla's mate. This became all too clear today at the Highland Park Zoo when a television set was placed in the cage of a male gorilla whose intended mate had died.
HONG KONG, March 23 The Chinese Communist party has rejected an invitation to attend the 23d congress of the Soviet party opening Tuesday.
BOSTON, March 23 Massachusetts members of the John Birch Society are being urged to work for the defeat of a bill that would establish civilian police review boards in the Commonwealth.

HONG KONG, March 23 (AP) Newspapers here reported today the death of Mrs. Li Tsungjen, wife of the former Vice President of Nationalist China who defected to Communist China in July after 15 years of self-imposed exile in the United States.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 23 (AP) Ford Stables' Kauai King put on a powerful stretch run to win the $18,550 Fountain of Youth Stakes at Gulfstream Park today and became a solid choice for the Florida Derby April 2.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 23 (AP) Harvard University and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology have agreed to provide half of a $1-million fund for development of lowrental housing and other Improvements here, it was announced tonight.
WASHINGTON, March 23 The International Monetary Fund permitted India today an emergency drawing of $187.5million to help meet the problems caused by the recent drought.
Gilbert Reese, a cellist who made his debut in 1949 when he was 22 years old, last night played his first Town Hall program since 1959.
KARACHI, Pakistan, March 23 In Rawalpindi today, Pakistan displayed her Communist-made military equipment.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., March 23 A junior committee has been formed to encourage couples between the ages of 25 and 40 to support the New Jersey Symphony.
Political animosity between the Soviet and Chinese Communists appears to be reaching a climax after more than a decade of tension.
Democrats at City Hall said yesterday that the Lindsay administration was delaying passage of the Mayor's own tax program.
The chairman of a major New York advertising agency counseled Western advertisers yesterday not to settle for "branchofficer service" just so they could boast having an Eastern agency.
TRENTON, March 23 Gov. Richard J. Hughes announced today that his efforts to establish a state income tax had failed.

The Supreme Court's decisions in the three obscenity cases strike the proper balance in a field where there are extremely difficult issues of law and public policy. Mr. Justice Brennan and his majority colleagues have shown wisdom and moral courage in the subtle and arduous task of upholding the law against obscenity while still protecting liberty of expression.

LONDON, March 23 At Convent Garden tonight the Royal Ballet danced for the first time "Les Noces" in the version created for the Diaghilev ballet in 1923. Four decades ago, London critics found this work dreary.

OCEANSIDE, L.I., March 23 James Raver has made known the engagement of his daughter, Miss Bonnie Sue Raver, to Robert S. Roxenberg. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Herman M. Roxenberg of Forest Hills, Queens.

Mrs. Bryce has raced for many years under the name of Mill River Stable. She has homes in New York, Newport, R.I., Nassau and South Arlington, Vt. Her 2,000 acres in Vermont include 200 devoted to a horse-breeding farm called Mill River Stud.

WASHINGTON, March 23 President Johnson said today that the United States, "with 13 of her other allies," would press forward without France "to preserve and to strengthen" the North Atlantic Treaty alliance and organization.

WASHINGTON, March 23 The Chinese Communist party's announcement that it would not attend the Soviet Communist party congress presents North Vietnam with a dilemman, and analysts here are watching the situation closely.

WASHINGTON, March 23 The transportation to the United States of almost a seventh of Cuba's population has been requested by relatives living here, in accordance with the refugee agreement by the two countries last November.
The London Stock Exchange was firm yesterday on renewed public and institutional support.

THE Town and Country Bridge Club in Great Neck, L.I., one of the most successful clubs in the metropolitan area, recently held a special game to honor its president, Henry Buckstein, on his elevation to life master status.
LONG BEACH, Calif. The Cleveland Indians may have the closest approximation to Sandy Koufax or Don Drysdale that the American League can come up with this season.

A Health Department order to reduce by 25 per cent the services at city Child Health Stations has been quickly rescinded following protests from physicians and civic leaders, it was disclosed last night.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) The Treasury Department said today eight European and Asian countries had signed agreements to ban from their United States export trade wigs made from hair obtained in Communist China, North Korea and North Vietnam.
The three New York newspapers planning a merger hope to begin their new operation a few days after receiving clearance from the Department of Justice, it was indicated yesterday.
SALISBURY, N.C., March 23 (UPI) Bud Collins, tennis writer for the Boston Globe, was named the winner today of the Martini and Rossi award for outstanding writing about a sportsman's sport.

The Central Committee of the Communist party of the Soviet Union deems it necessary to inform you of our position on the new steps taken by the Chinese Communist party that are aimed at strengthening the divisive line in the Socialist community and in the Communist world movement, as well as of the conclusion we draw from these facts.
NEW DELHI, March 23 India voiced growing concern today over alleged Pakistani efforts to destroy the "spirit of Tashkent."
The stock market declined yesterday in quiet trading after a cautious advance that had prevailed through five consecutive sessions.
The American Stock Exchange declined at the close of trading yesterday as late selling erased most of the earlier gains.

The Buildings Department yesterday showed off its new "forest" green inspectors' uniform the uniform that has the inspectors, who have been in plainclothes, gnashing their teeth and battling in court.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 23 A few hour after Casey Stengel had been notified that he had been elected to the Hall of Fame, a champagne party was tossed in his honor in the press room. Ol' Case was aglow even before he had taken his first sip of bubble water. Such was his delight that he talked longer, louder and more uninterruptedly than normal, not that he ever could be accused of reticence.
The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation announced the election here yesterday of James V. Lester as a vice president.
All New York-based members of the New York Stock Exchange have been sent a declaration of war.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (UPI) The International Association of Machinists threatened today to strike five major airlines April 23 in a wage dispute involving 34,000 mechanics and ground crew members from coast to coast.
Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that the New York Stock Exchange would find "scorched earth instead of greener pastures" if it tried to move out of New York.

Sinclair-Koppers Company, a joint venture owned by the Sinclair Oil Corporation and the Koppers Company, said yesterday it would cut the price of certain medium and highimpact polystyrene materials April 1.

If Nat H. Hentel, the Queens District Attorney, were easily discouraged, he would have given up his citizen's hot line after its first half-hour of operation last night. The first five calls that came in, taken by Mr. Hentel himself, were from:
Ciba, Ltd., of Basel, Switzerland, reported yesterday that its net profits last year rose to $9,099,500, from $8,587,300 in 1964.
An assistant district attorney declared yesterday that he was "not sure" that Richard Robles was the killer of Janice Wylie and Emily Hoffert even though he has been convicted of the crime.
Bad weather cast clouds of doubt over some crop and shipping prospects yesterday. As a result, futures of potatoes moved sharply ahead in price, and grains and soybeans also advanced.
The Detroit Red Wings, short two regular defensemen, had enough skill and strength to overcome the New York Rangers, 2-1, in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night.
THE HAGUE, Netherlands, Thursday, March 24 (AP) A wave of anti-government votes gave Dutch parties on both ends of the political spectrum gains in state legislative elections, results showed today.
First-quarter earnings of the Burroughs Corporation will approximate $3,875,000, or 50 cents a share, Ray R. Eppert, chairman, told stockholders at they annual meeting in Detroit yesterday.

George A. Murphy, chairman of the Irving Trust Company, the smallest of New York's major banks, was sharply criticized at his annual meeting yesterday by minority shareholders dissatisfied with the bank's progress and with its failure to pay a 2 per cent stock dividend.
S. Clark Lilley, president of the United Elastic Corporation, was elected yesterday to the additional post of chairman.

As always, a wide variety of music (and sometimes nonmusic) was heard last night in the Music in Our Time concert at the Kaufmann Auditorium of the 92d Street Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association.
BALTIMORE, March 23 The steel industry's extended vacation plan has not created the jobs expected of it, the president of the United Steelworkers of America said here today.
An often-decorated former New York City detective was sentenced yesterday to two and a half to five years for extortion.

VANCOUVER, B.C., March 23 (Canadian Press) Ron Northcott of Canada scored his fifth straight victory today and prepared to clash with Dr. Joe Zbacnik of the United States in the international curling championship here.
LONDON, March 23 (AP) Julie Christie tonight won the British Film Academy Award as best British actress of the year for her performance in "Darling."

The national policy committee of the United Mine Workers of America authorized their international officers yesterday to call a strike "if necessary" to enforce their demands for a new bituminous coal contract. More then 100,000 miners in 25 states would be affected.
While other colleges have big fund drives and huge endowments, Parsons College of Fairfield, Iowa, gets along happily almost entirely on the tuition fees paid by its students.
The Lindsay administration opened a drive last night to recruit 1,000 disadvantaged youths for a new police cadet corps before the summer begins.
BARCELONA, Spain, March 23 (UPI) The terms of four Americans and a Spanish woman imprisoned in a murder case two years ago have been shortened by an amnesty, it was announced today.

MANILA, March 23 (UPI) The captain of a Soviet research vessel, stranded in the Philippines without money, has explained that he went to the United States Embassy for help "because we consider the United States Government a friend of Russia."

DENVER, March 23 The future of rural electrification in Colorado has been placed in "critical jeopardy," Norman M. Clapp asserted today.

A Brazilian paper manufacturer has asked the Federal District Court in Washington, D.C., to enjoin the Inter-American Development Bank from authorizing financial assistance for the expansion of a competing paper pulp mill.

SOME of the zaniest furs in the world have come down a narrow, red-walled staircase at 127 East 60th Street and passed under an infinitesimal awning marked "Kuku." Now the firm of Kuku, which is made up of a former store buyer, Reinette Foster, and a former model, Joan Thornton Booker, has applied the same tongue-in-cheek charm to its first collection in fabric.

The junior committee of the Bal Rouge et Noir will meet for cocktails on Tuesday at Renfield Importers, 425 Park Avenue. The importers are donating liquor for the party and for the ball to be held April 20 at the New York Hilton as a benefit for Irvington House.

SAIGON, March 23 Premier Nguyen Cao Ky, faced with unrest by Buddhist and student groups, indicated today that a national election to replace his military Government might take place earlier than expected.

Cicero Murphy of Brooklyn and the defending champion, Joe Balsis of Minersville, Pa., remained tied for second place, one game behind Luther Lassiter of Elizabeth City, N.C., in the world pocket billiards championships at the Hotel Commodore last night.

BRUSSELS, March 23 Belgium's new Premier, Paul Vanden Boeynants, appealed today to his countrymen to put aside political, ideological and cultural differences and support his center-right coalition Government.
A joint program to improve the skills of British and American marketing executives was announced here yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board and Britain's National Marketing Council.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., March 23 Richard T. Madden Jr., an assistant professor of marketing at Pace College, Manhattan, and a lecturer on marketing at "St. John's University, Jamaica, Queens, died todaly in Mount Vernon Hospital after a brief illness. He was 40 years old and lived at 18 Douglas Place, Eastchester.
LISBON, March 17 Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar has warned that the Western powers should no longer expect "automatic cooperation" from Portugal.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 23 The Soviet Union is making an effort to improve or consolidate diplomatic and economic relations with the three revolutionary Arab states, Syria, Iraq and the United Arab Republic, observers here believe.

The Navy's struggle to retain its tennis courts, admiral's quarters and officers' clubhouse at the Naval Shipyard in Brooklyn will not be allowed to foul up the city's plan for conversion of the area into an industrial park after the yard closes June 30, an aide to Mayor Lindsay said yesterday.
BALTIMORE, March 23 Morris A. Kasoff, president of the Key Wine and Liquor Company and a prominent civic leader, died here today in Union Memorial Hospital. He was 55 years old.

Because of the scarcity of ground-floor space on midtown Fifth Avenue, side street quarters in the East 40's and 50's between Fifth and Park Avenues are now leasing for up to $1,600 a front foot a year, an official of Julien J. Studley, Inc., reported yesterday. The rents now are double those of five years ago, he said.

ALLENTOWN, Pa., March 23 Mr. and Mrs. Albert Grim Herman have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Janet Louise Herman, to Dr. Benjamin Hall Alexander, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald William Alexander of Palm Beach, Fla.

BOSTON, March 23 (UPI) The Cincinnati Royals blew a 15-point third-quarter lead tonight but rallied in the final minutes for a 107-103 victory over the Boston Celtics in the opener of their playoff series.
CHICAGO, March 23 Two experts on China from Columbia University urged tonight that United States policy be shifted to anticipate the regime that will follow Mao Tse-tung's death.
BONN, March 23 Chancellor Ludwig Erhard was elected chairman of the Christian Democratic party without opposition at the closing session of the annual party convention today.
THE Connecticut Fish and Game people issued a warning bulletin the other day concerning a criminal element that seems to arise like crocuses each year at this time.

CHATHAM, N.J., March 23 The engagement of Miss Catherine Ann Bernhard to Allan Russell Raymond, son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Russell Raymond of Hampton, N.H., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Frederick T. Bernhard.
Many Aqueduct bettors don't like the track's new pari-mutuel tickets. Neither do some of the cashiers who pay off the winners.
The president of the city's largest Puerto Rican rights group urged Teodoro Moscoso yesterday to form a resident committee of advisers on Puerto Rican affairs here.
The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company announced here yesterday the elections of John D. Harper and Ben W. Heineman to its board. The appointments increase the number of directors to 27.
Larry Terrell, a 17-year-old St. Paul's senior, won the 22d annual interscholastic squash racquets championship on the courts of the Racquets and Tennis Club yesterday.

The Communist party of China has received the letter of the Central Committee of the Communist party of the Soviet Union dated Feb. 24, 1966, inviting us to send a delegation to attend your 23rd Congress as guests.

THE idea of an old-fashioned stock pot is not for eign to the residents of Manhattan. At least not to Alice Loebel. The way she puts it, the stock pot is more or less the focal point of her menu planning, which is considerable.
PARIS, March 23 (Reuters) Two French soldiers were accused tonight of demanding $40,000 ransom for the World Soccer Cup, stolen in London on Sunday.
SYDNEY, Australia, March 23 Parliamentary members of the ruling Liberal and Country parties unanimously supported the Government's policy of aid to Vietnam today.

ALBANY, March 23 The leaders of the Legislature unwrapped their long-awaited divorce bill today and were immediately greeted with cries of foul from the proponents of reform whose own bill has been kept bottled up in committee.

CHICAGO, March 23 (AP) Deputy Secretary of Defense Cyrus R. Vance said today that United States forces in South Vietnam now totaled 220,000. This is 5,000 more than the total listed by Secretary of defense Robert S. McNamara three weeks ago. Mr. McNamara has authorized an increase to 235,000 men.

THEY seemed to think that life is too short to be ignoble. Their epic fights were resolved in decent privacy. When their arduous sessions ended they presented the revolutionary United States all 13 of them with a majestic Constitution.
TORONTO, March 23, (UPI) Cassius Clay said today that he hoped to knock out George Chuvalo in their 15round bout at Maple Leaf Gardens next Tuesday.

LOS ANGELES, March 23 A June wedding in San Francisco is planned by Miss Ann Kneedler and David French Fletcher. Mr. and Mrs. Harry Lawenda of Belair have announced the engagement of Mrs. Lawenda's daughter. Mr. Fletcher is the son of Mrs. Frederick E. Palmer of Belvedere and the late Dr. Harold Fletcher of Ross.
PARIS, March 23 There has been a distinct and unexpected turn-around in France's attitude toward foreign businesses which means American businesses for the most part establishing themselves here.
MINNEAPOLIS, March 23 The second major blizzard of the month paralyzed the upper Midwest's largest cities today, isolated scores of communities, marooned hundreds of motorists and killed 26 persons.

NAHA, Okinawa, March 23 With the inauguration of a wealthy conservative politician as the first indirectly elected chief executive of the Ryukyu Islands, United States authorities are looking forward to nearly three years of political stability.
Rolls-Royce will publicly introduce its first completely new car here in 10 years at the International Automobile Show, opening April 9.

WASHINGTON, March 23 James J. Saxon, the fiery Controller of the Currency, recommended here today that Congress consider freeing bank holding companies to diversify into non-banking ventures. He made the proposal while sharply criticizing proposed legislation that would extend the Federal Reserve Board's regulatory authority over bank holding companies.

The Bal des Berceaux, an annual party given by the Committee of French-American Wives, will be held on April 16 at the Pierre. Proceeds will be shared by the Save the Children Federation and the Refuge des Petits, a children's home in Hyeres, France.
The Soviet-Chinese dispute is now more bitter and deep-seated than ever before. This basic fact emerges from two key documents whose contents have become public knowledge this week.
The offensive waged by Genesco, Inc., to acquire control of Julius Garfinckel Co. ran into some unexpected opposition yesterday.

When Keith Funston went through his morning mail yesterday, he found various suggestions to move the New York Stock Exchange to Philadelphia, New Haven and Rah way, N.J. At the bottom of the half-foot stack was a postcard that said, "Why not Daytona Beach, Fla.?"

The deterioration of stock prices over the last several weeks, interrupted by the recent rally, has raised a question as to the possible effect on stocks owned on margin. These stocks are bought and maintained, in part, with loans. Use of credit allows larger purchases, thereby increasing the profit potential. But it also increases the risk of loss.

WASHINGTON, March 23 The United States will reopen with West Germany and other European countries the advisability of permitting Communist China to purchase a $150-million steel mill from a European industrial consortium, the State Department disclosed today.

John J. McCormick, president of the John J. Reynolds Ap praisal Company, will be the speaker at a dinner meeting on Thursday at 6:30 P.M. of the Greater New York Chapter of the Society of Real Estate Ap praisers. MOSCOW, March 24--High- ranking delegations from North Vietnam and North Korea will attend the Soviet Communist party's 23d congress, despite China's denunciation and boy cott of it, informed sources said today.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, March 24--"Forward Rhodesia" is this embattled country's official slo gan, but "We're getting away with it" may mirror its mood more accurately.

Rebuffed in an attempt to introduce testimony on two al leged murder confessions by George Whitmore Jr., the de fense counsel ended his case abruptly yesterday in Whit- more's trial for attempted rape and assault.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., March 24--United States Representa tive James D. Martin announced today that he would seek the Republican nomination for Gov ernor of Alabama.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 24 --A divorced mother of five goes into Federal Court here tomorrow to seek the return of her children from the foster homes and juvenile institutions to which the State of Kentucky has committed them because she married a Negro.

LOS ANGELES, March 24-- The abstract figure of a girl reclining atop a sewing machine today became the focal point of a controversy that threatens to cut off public support from the year-old Los Angeles County Museum of Art.

The American Stock Exchange came alive yesterday after weeks of comparative inactiv ity, with volume the heaviest in almost four years.

GLASGOW, Scotland, March 23--Nothing quite like it has been seen before in British politics. The fast and furious campaign swing of Edward Heath, with his chartered DC-3 touching down at some of the country's most forsaken air ports, and a few cow pastures as well, is as close as Britain has come to an American-style Presidential campaign.

SUN VALLEY, Idaho, March 24--The powerful French na tional ski team took a com manding lead today for the Werner Cup following the sla lom races that opened a three- day international meet at Sun Valley.

SEBRING, Fla. March 24-- Practice times don't tell every- thing in automobile racing, but they reveal a lot. So, after to day's long daylight and evening tune-ups for Saturday's 12-hour international championship race here, one point is definite: Ferrari is still a potent factor.
WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP)--Mrs. Lyndon B. John son has a new spring wardrobe of evening and daytime fashions designed primarily by two Americans--Mollie Par- nis and Adele Simpson.

LONDON, March 24 (Reu ters)--Prince Philip, the Duke of Edinburgh, husband of Queen Elizabeth, was shown swearing at a British film crew in Houston, Tex., during a television program screened here last night.
BOSTON, March 24 (UPI) --Two masked gunmen took "close to $300,000 worth" of diamonds from a downtown jewelry store today.

WASHINGTON, March 24-- Federal savings-and-loan asso ciations in the West, which have had a prevailing dividend rate of up to 4.85 per cent, were freed today to increase the rate to 5 per cent on accounts of $2,500 maintained for at least six months.

Lieutenant Ward is the son of Mrs. Reynolds Ward of Clinton, Conn., and the late Rockwell B. Ward of West Hartford, Conn.

PHILADELPHIA, March 24 (AP)--John V. Fallon, manager of financial advertising for The Philadelphia Inquirier, died yes terday in his hotel room here. He was 67 years old.

BRUSSELS, March 24--Sev eral years ago, when he was a Cabinet minister, Paul Vanden Boeynants called a news conference to contradict complaints that meat prices were too high. He used as props a round of beef and a butcher knife.

CHICAGO, March 24--Mayor Richard J. Daley challenged critics of Chicago slum condi tions today to form nonprofit construction and rahabilitation corporations for new housing. He included religious leaders among the critics.

Pepsico, Inc., attained rec ord sales and earnings in 1965, despite a strike of eight months in the New York City area, Herman W. Lay, chair man, and Donald M. Kendall, president, reported yesterday.
George R. Leighton, author and journalist, died Wednesday at his home, 211 East 18th Street. He was 64 years old.
