In this City of Rome, from which St. Augustine was sent by St. Gregory to England and there founded the Cathe dral See of Canterbury, to ward which the eyes of all Anglicans now turn as the centers of their Christian communion, His Holiness Pope Paul VI and His Grace Mi chael Ramsey, Archbishop of Canterbury, representing the Anglican communion, have met to exchange fraternal greetings.
HAUPPAUGE, L.I., March 24--Suffolk detectives were working today on the case of the stolen loot.

PARIS, March 24--French officials showed irritation today over publication of President Johnson's confidential reply to President de Gaulle on the dis pute over the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
HOUSTON, March 24 (AP) --George W. Murphy, a Hono lulu industrialist, purchased to day the controlling interest in the Reed Roller Bit Company from John W. Mecom, a Hous ton oil man and publisher.
SEVILLE, Spain, March 24 (AP)--Mrs. John F. Kennedy will attend the fourth annual Spring Charity Ball here on April 17, the organizing com mittee has announced.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 24--Tommy Bolt, who has tossed a club or two in the past, threw par for a six-stroke loss today. In the first round of the $82,000 Greater Jacksonville open golf tournament, the 47- year-old former United States Open titleholder scored a 66 to lead by one stroke.

ST. LOUIS, March 24 (UPI) --Petitions were circulated on the Washington University cam pus today calling for retention of a faculty member who the petitioners said "brought a com petent Marxist approach to eco nomic problems."

WASHINGTON, March 24-- A list of 15 cities and counties where local officials have been formally granted "veto powers" over poverty projects was made public today by the Office of Economic Opportunity. The list included New York.
A Japanese bank economist predicted here yesterday that trade between his country and the United States would reach $5-billion this year, an increase of $500-million over last year's volume.
"Terror tactics" including a "bomb threat" are being used to fight a proposed housing project in the Bronx, according to State Housing Commission er James W. Gaynor.
Luncheon, French Chamber of Commerce in the United States, Essex House, 12:30 P.M. Speaker: Maurice Schumann.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 24--The Wellesley Club of Central New Jersey is sponsor ing the Princeton Antiques Show, "Living with Antiques," to be held at the Princeton Day School next Thursday through Saturday. A town house and a country house furnished from the stock of about 30 antiques dealers, primarily from New Jersey, Pennsylvania and New England, will be set up in the school's gymnasium.
The British pound was steady in moderate trading on foreign exchange markets here yester day. Its closing quotation was $2.7939 up 4 points from Wednesday.
WASHINGTON, March 24--In the Supreme Court of the United States today, the fol- loming proceedings were had:
GENEVA, March 24--Alek- sei A. Roshchin formally re placed Semyon K. Tsarapkin today as Soviet delegate to the 17-nation disarmament confer ence.
The Dorian Quintet, a cham ber music group, is visiting Brooklyn College and will give a first "reading" today of works by three campus composers.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, March 23 --Taiwan is drifting toward a new role in the world commu nity.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., March 24 (AP)--Deputy Sheriff David Fitzpatrick showed photographs today of streaks of light in the sky that he said were made by unidentified flying objects he observed in the sky over south east Michigan nine days ago.

CANBERRA, Australia--The Americanization of Australia began in early 1942 with the fall of Singapore, the Battle of the Coral Sea and the arrival on this continent of Gen. Doug las MacArthur. A weak and iso lated nation realized it depended for its existence on the United States. Since then a generation has matured which has no mem ories of the formidable prewar...

BUENOS AIRES, March 24 --Inter-American development experts said today that the Al liance for Progress goals of eco nomic growth for Latin Amer ica were theatened by insta- bility of income from foreign exchange.
ROME, March 24 (UPI)-- Cardinal Spellman, Archbishop of New York, has taken up the role of "petitioner" in the case for beatification of Pope Pius XII, Vatican sources re- ported today.

Federal Judge Robert Shaw has approved a reorganization plan for the Harbor Tank Stor age Company, Inc., which went into bankruptcy as a result of the $150-million food-oil scandal engineered by Anthony (Tino) DeAngelis.
The Abitibi Paper Company, Ltd., the Canadian newsprint producer, said yesterday it would postpone the effective date of its $5-a-ton increase in the price of newsprint in the East to June 1.

"A man did something, I don't know what, and the police wanted him, and he kissed his wife and baby and ran away. Then he hid in a house, and the police looked for him. Why they looked in the drawers I don't know."
WASHINGTON, March 24 (UPI)--Staughton Lynd refused today to give the State Depart- ment a flat assurance he would not again go to North Vietnam.

A new Criminal Court pro cedure that would eliminate questioning, fingerprinting and booking a prisoner at a police station and taking photographs of him at Police Headquarters is under study by the Lindsay administration. It would also prevent the police from ques tioning an arrested person ex cept in the presence of a lawyer.
UNITED NATIONS, March 24--Secretary General Thant began consultations today to avert the threatened breakup of the United Nations peace force in Cyprus because of lack of funds.
BONN, March 24--The United States Embassy will take up with the Foreign Min istry the question of how to block West German participa tion in a proposed $150-million steel complex for Communist China.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given every Friday on this page. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost of dining in any particular establishment.
BENTON, Tenn., March 24 (AP)--Two University of Ten nessee football players were killed and a third injured today in a car-truck collision on U.S. 411 south of here.

MINEOLA, L. I., March 24 Martin J. Steadman, a reporter for The New York Herald Trib une, was designated tonight by the Nassau Democratic execu- tive committee as the party's candidate for Representative from the Fourth Congressional District.
The bond market moved up and down indecisively early yesterday and then dropped sharply late in the afternoon. The result at the close was the largest decline in prices in al most a month.

The leaders of the State Legislature--Speaker An thony J. Travia of the Assembly; Earl W. Brydges, majority leader of the Senate, and John H. Hughes, chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee--have now brought forward their own proposal for reforming the state's antiquated divorce law. It is far inferior to the bill put forward by the Joint Legislative Com- mittee after extensive study and numerous public hearings.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 24--St. Petersburg, a retirement haven of 225,000 persons on Tampa Bay, could be pardoned today if its views of New York baseball were a trifle distorted.

THE women who have trav eled the long gilt-chair road of Paris couture fash ions, line-for-line copies and custom-order duplicates came to the end of the journey yesterday as they watched the last, and largest, import collection of the season.
WASHINGTON, March 24 (UPI)--The House Agriculture Committee unanimously ap proved today legislation de signed to end the growing traf fic in stolen pets for research purposes.
Some of the country's fore- most racqueteers will gather at the Princeton Club today for the start of the three-day national squash tennis championship tournament.

These are suits by Virginia residents to have declared un constitutional Virginia's poll tax. The three-Judge District Court, feeling bound by our decision in Breedlove V. Suttles, 302 U.S. 277, dis missed the complaint. See 240 F. Supp. 270. The cases came here on appeal and we noted probable jurisdiction.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 112.8 on Wed nesday from 113.0 on Tuesday. The index, compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, stood at 103.4 on March 24, 1965.

Luther Lassiter of Elizabeth City, N.C., continued to hold the lead in the world pocket bil liard championship today. He defeated Jim Moore of Albu querque, 150-30, bringing his won-lost record to 8-1.
SKI area operators had to take a long look at their terrain yesterday before de termining how to assay con ditions for the weekend. It wasn't easy.
MOSCOW, March 24--Com munist party leaders across the Soviet Union are expressing concern about the impact of Western shortwave broadcasts among ordinary Soviet citizens.
License Commissioner Joel L. Tyler said yesterday that he would seek a change in news stand regulations to allow tem porary employes to operate stands when the licensee is ill or on vacation.

Alex DiBrizzi, general vice president of the Atlantic Coast District, International Long shoremen's Association, was in dicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of em bezzling $3,000 of union funds.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- The Supreme Court declared Virginia's poll tax unconstitu tional today in a decision broad enough to eliminate the other existing poll taxes in Alabama, Mississippi and Texas.
WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP)--The Government plans to dispose of 20,000 tons of tin from the strategic stockpile in the year starting April 1, in formed sources said today.
The new state law exempting 32,000 city transit work ers from the penalties of the Condon-Wadlin law was upheld yesterday by Supreme Court Justice William C. Hecht Jr.

The fund-raising campaign for Camp Vacamas in Butler, N.J. will open with the annual luncheon and fashion show of the Women's Division of the Camp Vacamas Association in the Versailles Room of the Astor on April 2.

"U Thant: The Search for Peace," by June R. Bingham, will be published by Knopf on April 18. The author of this bi ography of the Secretary Gen eral of the United Nations is the wife of Jonathan B. Bingham, who was an American Repre sentative at the United Nations. Mrs. Bingham visited U Thant's native Burma and she has re constructed his life from his...
Mrs. Joseph A. Neff has con tributed $200,000 to the new Metropolitan Opera House in Lincoln Center.
PARLIER, Calif., March 24 --A colorful column, banners flying, moved along back high ways in the San Joaquin Valley today, past pruned vineyards, tomato and cotton fields and rich plowed land.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 24 (UPI)--Kaiser Cement and Gypsum Corporation, and its subsidiary, Kaiser Gypsum Com pany were accused of price fixing and attempting to mono polize the nation's wallboard industry in a $3.5-million anti trust suit filed yesterday in United States District Court, by Pensinger Brothers Supply Company.

MONTREAL, March 24 (AP) --Dave Keon and Frank Mahov lich scored the only goals of the game with less than four minutes remaining tonight as the Toronto Maple Leafs de feated Montreal, 2-0, in a Na tional Hockey League game.
PALM BEACH, Fla., March 24--Mrs. Mary Lummus Krum ing of New York, widow of Paul Reginald Kruming, was married today to J. Gordon Douglas Jr. of Newport, R.I., and New York.

KINGSTON, N.Y., March 24 (AP)--Mrs. Harry H. Flem- ming, mother of Arthur S. Flemming, president of the University of Oregon who was Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare under President Eisenhower, died today in King ston Hospital. She was 86 years old and had suffered a stroke about 10 days ago.
The Contemporary Music So ciety's final concert of the sea son last night at the Guggen heim Museum Auditorium pre sented two husband-wife teams in a program of modern music.
Angel Cordero moved his arm wildly in the jockeys' room at Aqueduct yesterday as he groped for the English words to describe Fleet Admiral's victory in the feature race.

THE Cavendish Club, to which most New York experts belong, invariably offers warm welcome to visit ing stars of the bridge world. The hospitality ceases, how ever, at the card tables, and the visitors often go home slightly chastened.

LOS ANGELES, March 24 (UPI)--Don Drysdale entered negotiations today for a long- term movie-television career and J. William Hayes, an at torney, said the odds were "100 to 1" against Drysdale or Sandy Koufax playing for the Los Angeles Dodgers this year.

A member of the State Com mission for Human Rights found yesterday that the airline industry should not be allowed to set arbitrary age limits for stewardesses that were below standard retirement ages of other airline employes.

SPRINGFIELD, Ore., March 24 (UPI)--An ex-convict, flee ing the police after wounding a patrolman, held a truck driver and his wife hostage in their home for eight hours today and then shot himself to death.
WASHINGTON, March 24-- The Selective Service System issued tonight its new criteria for deferment of college stu dents under the 2-S classifica tion.
LARGO, Fla., March 24-- Miss Deirdre Ellis Conrad plans to be married in August to George Woodrow Frank Jr. Her sister, Miss Diane Johnston Conrad, plans to be married to Christian Klem Jacobsen.

Leonard Bernstein, Harold Clurman, Aaron Copland, Agnes de Mille, Gian Carlo Menotti, Tony Randall, Artur Rubin- stein, George Szell, Jennie Tou- rel and Peggy Wood are among the figures in the world of mu- sic and drama who have de clared,t hemselves in favor of saving the old Metropolitan Opera House from demolition.

Events today: "Un Ballo in Maschera," Metropolitan Opera, 8 P.M.; "Don Rodrigo," New York City Opera, New York State Theater, 8:15; Buck Ovens and his Buckaroos, Car negie Hall, 8:30; Monique Ley- rac, chanteuse, Town Hall, 8:40; Jean Graham, pianist, Carnegie Recital Hall.
TORONTO, March 24--"I am a jet," said Cassius Clay, "and all the rest is props. Box ing will never be the same. Once you been in a jet, you not ever really happy in a prop again."
The New York Jets, who have been searching for football players with speed, came up yesterday with plenty of speed in a small package.
PARIS, March 24--Harry Belafonte arrived here today to sing for civil rights and said he would also raise his voice to end the war in Vietnam and apart held in South Africa.

An alleged "muscle man" who enforced payment of gam bling losses by bettors, and also protected a bookie when he could not pay off, was indicted here yesterday on charges of conspiracy and bookmaking as a felony.
Clarence H. Faust will re tire in the coming month as vice president of the Ford Foundation's domestic pro grams and as president of the foundation-supported Fund for the Advancement of Edu cation.
SAIGON, March 24--South Vietnamese troops last night beat off attacks on two widely separated camps, killing 229 guerrillas, a military spokes man said today.

The operator of a Broadway talent booking agency was ar rested yesterday by postal in spectors on charges of defraud ing more than 100 small colleges and organizations throughout the country of more than $100,000.

Despite the negative Soviet response, amendments the United States has submitted at Geneva to its draft treaty on nuclear nonproliferation represent an im portant step forward. The changes close verbal loop holes, clarify the Western intent and provide precise terms for negotiation. Undoubtedly, Britain's dis armament minister, Lord Chalfont, will press these during his current Moscow visit.
NEW DELHI, March 24-- Prime Minister Indira Gandhi left today on a trip to the United States that is expected to set the tone for Indian-American relations for months if not years.

Is Professor Lemon partial? Not at all. But many readers will be partial to Profes sor Lemon after they read his book. In this bright study of lyric poetry and contempo rary criticism he shows all of us partial critics how to judge a poem for its coherence and its congruence--that is, its integrity as a symbolic whole and its relation to the immediate world.
Myles Rosenthal had a dream. Yesterday he stood and watched as two men with acetylene torches cut his dream into scrap.

We have yet to see convincing evidence that the proposed increase in the stock transfer tax is as "in tolerable" or "inequitable" a burden as is claimed by Keith Funston, the energetic president of the New York Stock Exchange.

PERIODICALLY this corner comes up against non- hunting persons who labor under the impression that there is a huge annual toll among hunters. When it is pointed out just how low the accident rate is, they usually look skeptical.
A second East German writer has been refused his govern ment's permission to attend the three-day International Writers Conference of Brooklyn Center of Long Island University, which opens Friday.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., March 24--Harry V. Hanley, a retired acting detective captain in the New York Police Depart ment, died yesterday in a hos- pital here after a long illness. He was 78 years old and lived here at 8 Yates Boulevard.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 24 (AP)--Miss Susan F. (Dob bie) Coleman was married to Theodore S. Bassett of London and New York on Monday at the home of her father and step mother, Mr. and Mrs. George L. Coleman.
ANKARA, Turkey, March 24 --An offer by Switzerland two weeks ago to use her good offices in the Cyprus dispute has received a cool reaction in Turkey.
IN the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

Justice Owen MCGivern of the New York State Supreme Court has ruled that "The Girl from 'Peyton Place'"--a biog raphy of the late Grace Me- talious--is not unfairly damag ing to the publisher of "Peyton Place" and "Return to Peyton Place."
SANTA CRUZ, Calif., March 24 (AP)--Dr. Oswald H. Rob ertson, an originator of the blood bank, died last night after a heart attack. He was 79 years old.
WHEELING, W.Va., March 24 (UPI)--The Wheeling Steel Corporation filed a $60-million damage suit today against the United States Steel Corporation and the Triangle Conduit and Cable Company.
WASHINGTON, March 24-- Vice President Humphrey re assured union leaders today that President, Johnson and the Democrats would fulfill their political promises to organized labor.

LONDON, March 24--Twelve miles off England's south- east coast stands a platform that during World War II was used as an anti-aircraft gun station. Today it is the site of Radio Essex, the newest of the pirate broadcasters that ring the British Isles and pump American-style radio onto the mainland.

HOUSTON, March 24 (UPI) --Technicians have discovered a "pretty serious" problem in the Agena target satellite, the space agency revealed today. The trouble, apparently in a yaw hydraulic system, sent the Gemini docking satellite into a series of unexpectedly high or bits last week, according to Melvin Brooks, Agena systems engineer at the agency's manned spacecraft center near here.

RABAT, Morocco, March 24-- The Moroccan Government to day closed high schools to sev eral thousand students and evicted 255 university students after they staged a strike yes- terday commemorating the first anniversary of riots that swept Casablanca, killing over 100 people.

Spurred by sharp increases in capital spending by business and industry, contracts for the future construction of factories, offices, stores and other non residential buildings rose sharp ly last month, offsetting de clines in other areas of con struction.
The Flying Tiger Line, founded after World War II by a group of returning veterans and today the nation's largest all-cargo air carrier, is taking its first flight into a new market.

Merger talks are being held by the Hertz Corporation and the United Exposition Service Company of Chicago. The mul ti-million-dollar transaction would involve an exchange of stock, it was disclosed yester day.
An art auction to benefit the Downtown Community School, 235 East 11th Street, will take place tonight at 8.
The Federal Reserve stepped up its campaign for volun tary credit restraint yesterday. In a policy address, William F. Treiber, first vice president of the Federal Reserve Bank.

WASHINGTON, March 24-- Estimated railroad freight traf fic volume generated by car- loadings and intercity truck tonnage in the latest week end ed March 19 were both consider ably ahead of the volume in the corresponding week of last year.
AMES, Iowa, March 24 (UPI) --Oklahoma took an early lead with 14 points today after the first round of the National Col legiate wrestling championships.
BOAT owners who like to stay one status symbol ahead of their neighbors have been given a new opportu nity. This season, they will be able to go to sea to the strains of taped music.
VANCOUVER, B.C., March 24 (Canadian Press)--Chuck Hay's Rink from Perth, Scot land, scored a 14-7 upset today to gain the final in the inter national curling championship against favored Canada.
Potato futures extended their recent rally yesterday by set ting some new life-of-contract highs. Continued strength in the cash price apparently spur- red futures trading.

Peggy Allenby, an actress known to television viewers as Mattie in the WCBS-TV serial, "Edge of Night," died Wednes day in Park West Hospital after a brief illness. She lived at 160 West End Avenue and was 65 years old.

PHILADELPHIA, March 24 --Dr. Alfred Newton Richards, a noted pharmacologist who was president of the National Acad emy of Sciences from 1947 to 1950, died today in his home in Bryn Mawr. He was 90 years old on Tuesday.
Arthur M. Ross, a man who must keep a sharp pencil as Commissioner of Labor Statis tics, predicts that the gross national product will rise to $735-billion this year.
WASHINGTON, March 24-- Exports rose 4 per cent and imports 3 per cent in February over the January level, the Commerce Department reported today.
Four theater men from re gional companies reported yes terday they were not having much luck in their search for good actors. Each emphasized the shortage.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 24 (AP)--The United States Court of Appeals upset today the Federal Trade Commis sion's practice of allowing two commissioners to make bind ing decisions.
WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP)--Three newsmen and two journalism deans have been named to the five-man admis sions committee of the newly formed Washington Journalism Center.

MADRID, March 24--Maj. Gen. Delmar E. Wilson, com mander of the 76th United States Air Force, based in Spain, announced today the completion of clean-up opera tions in the Palomares area, where three hydrogen bombs fell Jan. 17 following a midair collision between a B-52 jet bomber and a KC-135 refueling tanker. Underwater efforts to recover the fourth bomb con tinued offshore.

Changes proposed by legisla tive leaders in the state's 18th- century divorce law were de scribed yesterday by a family law expert as "the most repres sive divorce legislation ever thought of in America."
The board of the Paramount Pictures Corporation elected two new members yesterday and voted to eliminate cumulative voting from the company's cer tificate of incorporation.

WASHINGTON, March 24-- The first practical effects of France's withdrawal from the integrated NATO command are likely to be felt in West Ger many. Once France withdraws her ground and air units from the allied command in that country, for example, the United States will almost certainly be obliged to withdraw the U.S. nuclear weapons made available to the French forces there under American control.
Edward A. O'Neal, chairman of the Monsanto Company, ex pressed concern yesterday over three international situations that "constitute a triple threat to the American economy."

"I AIM to make shoes that people will either go wild about or loathe," said Moya Bowler, 25-year-old British shoe designer, as she peeked around a hank of the bru nette hair that has been cropped to fall over one eye by Vidal Sassoon.
LONDON, March 24 (Reu ters)--A special committee of the Ministry of Trade called today for a complete overhaul of the British shipbuilding in dustry to make it competitive in the world market.
Andrei Voznesensky, the vis iting Soviet poet, won a rousing reception last night when he re cited his poetry in Russian to a capacity audience of 2,000 at the Hunter College auditorium.
WASHINGTON, March 24-- The Supreme Court took the following actions today:
LONDON, March 24--The Cambridge University varsity eight-oared shell sank in the Thames today, 48 hours before the 112th annual race against Oxford.
Early buying subsided quick ly on the London Stock Ex- change yesterday and prices drifted lower toward the end of the session.

The poll tax has finally been killed in America, and all who recognized it as one of the most odious devices for preventing Negroes from voting will rejoice at its demise--even if they would have preferred a dif ferent manner of execution.

OMAHA, Neb., March 24 (AP) --The sun broke through today over the northern Middle West, left heavily snow-coated by the second severe blizzard this month and thoroughly chilled by bitter cold that moved in behind the storm.

THREE dancers and one folk singer make up a tiny touring package called Frances Alenikoff's Theater of Dance and Song. This small package delivered itself to New York last night at the Judson Hall, and one is at something of a loss to know to whom it is addressed.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 24 --Mr. and Mrs. Richard E. Pearce have announced the en gagement of their daughter, Miss Sally Therese Pearce, to Michael John McNulty, son of Mr. and Mrs. John McNulty of Niagara Falls, N.Y.
The Communications Satel lite Corporation was asked yes terday to consider launching the first satellite for telephone, tele vision and other communica tions transmission within the United States.
Mayor Lindsay said last night that if his tax and transit pro grams were not passed, "I will take to the streets to remind the voters in the fall that Albany--all of Albany--is re sponsible."

Henry R. Luce, editorial chair man of Time, Inc., has sold his 28-room Georgian home on a 100-acre estate in Ridgefield, Conn., to Hans P. Kraus of New Rochelle, a publisher and deal- er in rare books.
State Senator Manfred Ohrenstein is drafting two elec tion-law changes that could pre cipitate bitter Albany struggles.
City officials are considering the possibility of introducing tokens for parking meters in an effort to combat looting.

JERSEY CITY, March 24 (AP)--Train schedules are be ing revised by the Jersey Cen tral and Pennsylvania Railroads to take the guess work out of arrival times on the shore line while the Raritan River bridge is being repaired.

BALTIMORE, March 24 (AP) --Len Wilkens scored a field goal and two fouls in the final 19 seconds tonight as the St. Louis Hawks upset the Balti more Bullets, 113-111, in the first game of the National Bas ketball Association's Western Division semi-final playoffs.
Steadily, week after week, the Federal Reserve is moving to ward tighter money.

The Department of Agri culture has borrowed a cargo and port expert from the Carolina State Ports Author ity to send to India to expe dite the unloading of grain moving to Indian ports in considerable volume from this country.

AIR FORCE ACADEMY, Colo., March 24 (AP)--Defend ing champion Roy Saari of Southern California overtook Bill Farley of Michigan in the last lap today and won the 500- yard free-style opening event of the National Collegiate Athletic Association swimming cham pionships.
WASHINGTON, March 24 --Private power companies gained another major victory today over public power ad vocates for the development of the Snake River on the Idaho-Oregon border.

Richard (Pancho) Gonzalez of Los Angeles, the former world champion, scored a fantastically easy victory over Lewis Hoad of Australia last night in the $25,000 invitation professional tennis tournament at Madison Square Garden.
ATLANTA, March 24 (AP) --Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., Negro civil rights leader, has been denied a visa to visit South Africa, which has long followed a policy of strict racial segregation.
WASHINGTON, March 24-- The Justice Department asked a Federal court today to invali date Mississippi laws prescrib ing qualifications for jury serv ice.
ALBANY, March 24--The politically divided Legislature ran into another dispute over re apportionment today.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., March 24 --A finding of discrimination by Motorola, Inc., against a Negro job applicant was re versed today by the Illinois Supreme Court.

There is a story, perhaps apocryphal, that on the eve ning in June, 1963, when "Cleo- patra" had its world premiere here, a 20th Century-Fox exec utive emerged from the Rivoli Theater exclaiming, "By golly, It'll make a million!"

LAKELAND, Fla., March 24--It was Mickey Mantle Day at the Yankee Sta dium last September and a thunderous roar cascaded from the stands when the lion of the hour stepped to the plate for his first turn at bat. Joe Sparma, the Detroit pitcher, threw one past him and the umpire halted play to hand the ball to Mickey as a souvenir. During this thoughtful little ceremony, the husky Sparma lumbered in from the mound.
A tug-of-war is going on here and in Albany between various port interests seeking to change the authority of the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor.
ST. LOUIS, March 24 (UPI) --The St. Louis Post-Dispatch reported today that North Viet namese diplomats "have begun a new flurry of activity, laying down three conditions for peace negotiations."

BONN, March 24--The Bundestag rejected tonight a Social Democratic attack on Chancellor Ludwig Erhard's Government for its failure to reduce the number of accidents involving the West German Air Force's American-designed fighter-bomber, the Starfighter.
The city's water storage having risen to 64.2 per cent of capacity, Mayor Lindsay was asked yesterday at a news conference if he planned to lift the restrictions on water use.
WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP)--The Supreme Court ruled today that violation of contract suits under the Taft- Hartley Act was subject to varying state statutes of limi tations.

TRENTON, March 24--The crushing defeat Gov. Richard J. Hughes suffered yesterday when his income tax program col lapsed once again emphasized a paramount reality in New Jersey political life: Popular political power can still be throttled in the private world of the county political boss.
Charges against six men who were arrested last week in a Harlem repertory theater that housed a bizarre collection of weapons were dismissed yester day by Criminal Court Judge Vincent P. Rao.

ROME, March 24--Prof. William McGlashan Duffus of Washington and Rome died here last Sunday of complica tions resulting from injuries sustained in an automobile ac cident last month in Portugal. He was 80 years old.
Hunt Foods and Industries, Inc., is a much larger stock holder in the Crucible Steel Company of America than it was believed to be, according to figures released yesterday.
The stock market failed to develop any decisive trend in yesterday's relatively light trading.
Three men destroyed their draft cards here yesterday and several hundred students on three New York college cam puses took part in protests against United States policies in Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, March 24-- The State Department indicated today that it would henceforth decide on a case by case basis whether to honor requests by the Federal Bureau of Investi gation for reports by United States embassies on the activ ities of Americans traveling abroad.

Ogilvy Mather Interna tional, Inc., ended its silence yesterday about going pulic. The agency announced it had filed a registration statement with the Securities and Ex- change Commission on the pro posed sale of 349,883 shares of common stock.
Three career city policemen, all assistant chief inspectors, will be promoted Monday to fill the highest posts on the force under the department's Chief Inspector, Sanford D. Garelik.
NEW DELHI, March 24--Op position Members of Parliament charged today that the Govern ment had gravely insulted Is rael by snubbing her President when he passed through India recently.

THE parade of out-of-town orchestras continues, and last night in Carnegie Hall we had the Houston Sym phony conducted by Sir John Barbirolli. By now they are beginning to be old friends, and once again orchestra and conductor gave a fine concert.
AUSTIN, Tex., March 24-- Ronnie Dugger, editor of a liber al political journal, The Texas Observer, withdrew today as a candidate for the United States Senate seat once held by Presi dent Johnson.
The following reports were provided yesterday by operators of the ski areas. Messages were filed at times indicated in paren theses.
KATONAH, N.Y., March 24 --William Edward Annin Jr., a real-estate salesman, died to day at his home on North Salem Road here. He was 73 years old.
Canon John Heuss, rector of Trinity Church, was buried in the Trinity churchyard yes terday after a requiem mass in the historic church at Broad way and Wall Street.

LONDON, March 24--"What did the Tories ever do for mort gage payers in 13 years?" Har old Wilson asked a pleased par tisan audience in Nottingham the other night--and Leicester the same night, and other audi ences day after day.
MINNEAPOLIS, March 24 (UPI)--A prominent scientist said today that the Poage bill goes so far it will hamper medi cal research.

YONKERS, March 24--Black Mail, an undistinguished son of little-known sire (Eben Scot) captured the sixth race at Yonkers Raceway tonight, paid the meeting's high $2 win- mutuel of $107.90 and paved the way to a twin double re turn of $40,212,60.

A DOUBLY pleasant occa- casion. One of the best of Of Bertolt Brecht's plays has at last reached New York (22 years after it was written). In presenting it, the Lincoln Center Repertory Theater has given us its best production to date, and a good produc tion by any standards.
GLASGOW, March 25 Crime and punishment have become major political issues in this Labor stronghold of 1.2 million people.
Arthur H. Harlow Jr., president of Group Health Insurance, Inc., died yesterday at New York Hospital. He was 57 years old and lived at 1199 Park Avenue and in Pound Ridge, N.Y.
SAIGON, March 25 Premier Nguyen Cao Ky announced tonight that South Vietnam would be given a constitution within two months.

TORONTO, March 25 George Chuvalo is a bum, says a man who is betting on him, but a bum with heart. Cassius Clay is a talented fighter, but a dog. And at odds of 7-1, the true sportsman has to back the bum with heart against even the greatest dog in the world.
LONDON, March 25 Seven book publishers owned by the International Publishing Corporation are to be merged to form Britain's largest producer of books.
GENEVA, March 21 The world's oldest permanent disarmament conference entered its fifth year this week showing no signs of age or achievement.

YONKER, March 25 Sheer Genius, the 15-to-1 outsider in the one-mile handicap event, won the featured pace tonight at Yonkers Raceway. The race was a thriller, in which Billy Haughton rallied with the victor, who defeated Yankee Mick by a nose in 2:04 2/5 and returned $32.60 for $2 to win.
BETHESDA, Md., March 25 Miss Mary L. McCarran, a daughter of the late Senator Pat McCarran and a former Roman Catholic nun, died of cancer here today at her home. She was 59 years old.
The head of the pressmen's union here questioned yesterday whether the proposed merger of three New York newspapers would be in the public interest.

BERLIN, March 25 Horst Fischer, a former SS doctor, was sentenced to death today by East Germany's Supreme Court for crimes against humanity. He was responsible for the deaths of at least 70,000 inmates of the Nazis' Auschwitz camp.
Mrs. Dryfoos Has Child

The State Board of Regents backed the opposition yesterday of State Education Commissioner James E. Allen Jr. to Governor Rockefeller's proposal to build one or more State University colleges in New York City.

MADRID, March 25--The undersea struggle to raise the hydrogen bomb lying deep in the Mediterranean off the Spanish coast was frustrated again today when a line that had finally been attached to the five-ton weapon snapped.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 25 Mickey Mantle made, his first appearance of the year in the New York Yankees' line-up today 58 days after undergoing an operation on his right shoulder amid considerable doubt that his 16-year playing career could continue.

BUENOS AIRES, March 25 A Latin-American leader said today that the success of the Alliance for Progress "depends more on the sum of internal efforts by each country than on the volume of foreign aid."
WASHINGTON, March 25 Butter went out of Army and Air Force rations in favor of margarine today, but the Navy will still get some of the higherpriced spread.

SEBRING, Fla., March 25 Jochen Rindt, a young Austrian driving star, had the distinction of winning the first race in the newly activated trans-American sedan championship today, leading a field of 44 cars in the four-hour contest over Sebring's 5.2-mile course. This was the main preliminary to tomorrow's 16th annual 12-hour race for manufacturers' world championship points.

The Motion Picture Association of America, the film industry's trade organization, is expected early next month to end an almost three-year search for a new president to succeed the late Eric Johnston.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP) Turkey's President, Cemal Gursel, flew homeward today, still critically ill and in a coma after a series of strokes. President Johnson paid his respects at the airport before the suddenly arranged flight on a United States Air Force plane left Andrews Air Force Base, in Maryland. Mr. Johnson went to the airfield by helicopter.
Stolen stock certificates valued at $1.5-million were recovered last night by detectives of the District Attorney's office.

PARIS, March 25 The possibility of a twin merger of France's four biggest banks all nationalized into two bigger banks is being rumored again. According to official sources, there is no actual plan under way but the idea has been discussed.
MANILA, March 25 The Philippines is debating its role in Vietnam with intensity.

WASHINGTON, March 25 Secretary of State Dean Rusk said today that he was conducting a personal investigation into the reporting by United States embassies on the activities of American citizens traveling abroad.

The supposed favorite for the Democratic nomination is also in difficulty. A report from City Hall a few days ago noted that the strategists furthering the cause of Frank D. O'Connor for Governor were divided. Some favor an aggressive campaign for the honor of running against Governor Rockefeller. Others prefer that he "confine himself to the constructive positions that grow out of his role as Council President."

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 25 Gay Brewer scored par again today as he took a threestroke lead in the $82,000 Greater Jacksonville open golf tournament. Although the temperature dropped to 38 degrees, Brewer shot a hot 66, his 14th round under 70 this year, for a 36-hole aggregate of 133.
Two or three years ago any denomination that considered itself "progressive" in the area of civil rights would have blushed at the thought of establishing an all-Negro organization within its ranks.
A cargo shipper can now collect damages in Federal court if a steamship company discriminates against him by rejecting his goods and accepting consignments of his competitors.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 25 Met-hood, like membership in some strict religious sect or in the Mafia, can never be relinquished once acquired.
WASHINGTON, March 25 Vice President Humphrey forecast today that "much needed revisions" of the North Atlantic Treaty structure would derive from the latest French dispute with the United States. I
A large part of the success of last night's Metropolitan Opera performance of Verdi's "Un Ballo in Maschera" was due to Sherrill Milnes, who was singing his first Renato with the company.
Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary said yesterday that he was in favor of the "immediate arraignment of prisoners" and of "removing them from the custody of the police" once they were arraigned.

JACKSON, Miss., March 25 Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. was cheered by 6,000 Mississippi Negro teachers here today as he endorsed the demand of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. that Negro needs cannot be put on a priority list but must be provided "all and now."

Five men were arrested yesterday by agents of the Internal Revenue Service and the New York police on charges of failing to have the required $50 gambler's tax stamp while allegedly engaged in policy ring activities. The Government estimated the ring has grossed $3.5-million a year.
The price direction was up and the pace was fast yesterday on the American Stock Exchange.
The Amateur Athletic Union's Eastern Wrestling championships, produced and directed by and starring Bill Farrell, opened last night at the New York Athletic Club.
WASHINGTON, March 25 A 60 per cent cut in funds sought by the Administration for a newly authorized rent supplement program was voted today by the House Appropriations Committee.
The nuclear-power reactor industry lost another manufacturer yesterday with the announcement that the AllisChalmers Manufacturing Company has decided to "seek no further complete reactor projects."

What is the difference between national brands and store brands and why should the former cost more than the latter? In a landmark decision by the United States Supreme Court, the nation's consumer goods and retail industries have been told for the first time that a producer's offering of the same product under various labels or brands at different antitrust laws.

Celeste Holm leaves for a State Department-sponsored tour of the Middle East and the Scandinavian countries in May in a program exploring the relationship between men and women from the point of view of different authors.
MOSCOW, March 25 The Soviet Union disclosed today plans for the construction of railroad systems permitting the operation of passenger trains at speeds up to 150 miles an hour.
WASHINGTON, March 25 Recent complaints that American shipyards are unwilling to modernize and spend money to remain competitive were denied here today by a leading American shipbuilder.
The race to capture the containerized shipping market on the Atlantic will enter a new stage next month when SeaLand Service starts the first complete trailership service.

WASHINGTON, March 25 Although the Interstate Commerce Commission eight days ago told all of the nation's railroads to return any box cars of the Great Northern and the Northern Pacific Railways to those lines, spokesmen for both carriers said today that so far they had not noticed any appreciable gain in the number of cars returning home.

The bluecoats of the tactical police and the peajackets of the unbarbered youth mingled but did not mix it up last night on the Macdougal-Bleecker Street axis of the Greenwich Village coffeehouse circuit.

DURHAM, N.C., March 25 (AP) New York University won two of the three individual titles today in the National Collegiate fencing championships and became a strong favorite for the team title, which will be decided tomorrow.

BONN, March 25 West Germany offered today to exchange declarations with the Soviet Union, Poland, Czechoslovakia and "any other East European state" renouncing the use of force in the settlement of international disputes.

SUN VALLEY, Idaho, March 25 The skiers of Austria, a nation long supreme in the Alpine skills, were heard from today on the downhill course at Sun Valley. Racing against four nations in an international team event for the Werner Cup, the nine skiers in the tight black uniforms and blue helmets won both the men's and women's downhill races and accumulated a whopping 87 points to go ahead of the favored French team.
Backed by a spiritual-singing band of 500 rooters, DeWitt Clinton High brought the Public Schools Athletic League basketball title back to the Bronx yesterday.

AINTREE, England, March 25 (UPI) Highland Wedding, owned by Thomas McCoy Jr., of Haverford, Pa., and Charles Burns of Toronto, was made a 5-1 favorite tonight to capture tomorrow's Grand National steeplechase and complete a big betting coup.

New Yorkers do not need a contamination count to know that their city is dirty. The sooty fallout is everywhere on floors, window sills and streets. It is harmful to health, messy and irksome; its cost to the city and its residents comes to an estimated halfbillion dollars yearly. Clearly, an effective clean-air law is essential if New York is to become and remain a fit place to live.
BRUNSWICK, Me., March 18 The background shows a stretch of sandy beach. But the scene is marred by the ugly skeleton of an abandoned automobile, its gaping body filled with empty beer cans.

SOME of the most interesting bridge playing problems revolve around control of the trump suit. If the declarer is forced to ruff at an early stage, reaching a point at which a defender has trump length equal to his own, both sides may be in for an analytical headache.
WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP) Two Republican members of the House antipoverty subcommittee said today its hearings on the program had been a "whitewash."
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, March 25 The Government today ordered the registration of every man in the country 17 to 60 years old.

A former Congressional investigator who is the defendant in a $1.5-million damage suit brought by the A.C. Nielsen Company admitted freely yesterday that he rigged the rating of four programs nationally televised by the major networks.

The first quarter of this year is expected to be the best one in both sales and earnings for the Dictaphone Corporation, Lloyd M. Powell, president, told the shareholders at the annual meeting yesterday in the Biltmore Hotel.
PHOENIX, Ariz., March 25 The president of the American Cancer Society urged here today that scientists take more chances in applying experimental techniques to the treatment of human cancer.
Gov. Richard J. Hughes of New Jersey and Gov. James A. Rhodes of Ohio visited Wall Street yesterday in hopes of wooing the New York Stock Exchange to their states.
Mayor Lindsay swore in three new $25,000-a-year Criminal Court Judges for 10-year terms yesterday. He also designated an aide, Werner H. Kramarsky, as the city's first computer coordinator.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 25 The United States was said today to be weighing a plan that could provide United Nations membership for the two Chinas Communist and Nationalist.

WASHINGTON, March 25 The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia ruled today that Negro citizens in Jackson, Miss., must be given a hearing on their charges of racial discrimination in broadcasting by a local television station.

Andrei Voznesensky, the Russian poet who is on a threeweek reading tour of the United States, says there are advance orders in the Soviet Union for 300,000 copies of a forthcoming slim volume of his verse. But a "paper shortage," he adds, is likely to reduce the printing by one-half that number.

For the third day in a row, copper futures moved up sharply yesterday and more than erased two days of decline at the week's start. The upward influence continued to be reports of a spreading strike of mine workers at Nchanga, Zambia, a copper producing center.

Six writers sat in the center of a basketball court at Long Island University's Brooklyn Center yesterday and talked about whether literature should lean toward alienation or commitment. They were setting the tone of an International Writers Conference that will continue through Sunday.

Mayor Lindsay is about to announce the formation of a Public Development Corporation to coordinate the city's campaign to halt the flight of industry, attract new factories and thus avert racial unrest by providing blue-collar jobs.

WASHINGTON, March 25 William L. Slayton, Commissioner of Urban Renewal for the last five years, resigned from the Department of Housing and Urban Development today. This left secretary Robert C. Weaver temporarily without an experienced man to run key "downtown" programs of urban redevelopment.

Richard (Pancho) Gonzalez was beaten in the $25,000 invitation tennis tournament at Madison Square Garden last night, and there will be an allAustralian final this evening between Rodney Laver and Kenneth Rosewall, the two top favorites.
DETROIT, March 25 An investigator for the Air Force said today that at least two of southern Michigan's mysterious "flying objects" were nothing more than marsh gas.
WASHINGTON, March 25 The shoe industry has promised the Government a general holdthe-line policy on prices if export controls are maintained to keep down the price of hides, and hence leather.

WASHINGTON, March 25 The index of primacy market prices was unchanged at 105.2 (1957-59 equals 100) during the week ended March 22, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. Farm products moved higher in price while processed foods declined. Industrial commodities averaged unchanged.

It would be a mistake to read international significance into Finland's election returns. The Social Democratic party, traditional whipping boy of the Soviet Union, made a spectacular comeback. With a gain of eighteen seats in Parliament, unprecedented in the postwar period, it jumped from third to first among the nation's parties.

The Lindsay administration has revised priorities that had been set for urban renewal programs and asked the Federal Government to allocate $22.4million in the current fiscal year for three projects Atlantic Terminal in Brooklyn, Arverne in Queens and Metro North in East Harlem.

As the engineers that invaded New York last Monday for the convention of the Institute of Electrical and Electronic Engineers folded their slide rules and left for home yesterday, one thing was apparent: The electronics business is booming.

MOSCOW, March 25 The Soviet leadership has accomplished a major feat of intramural Communist maneuvering, senior diplomats said today, in drawing leaders of almost all the world's Communist parties to Moscow despite Communist China's boycott.
WITH a tax form in one hand and a tape meas ure in the other, the householder of today takes measurements of the home office for both monetary and linear dimensions.

MIAMI BEACH, March 25 Members of the American Textile Manufacturers Institute, here for the organization's 17th annual meeting, expect Government orders for woven goods to rise substantially in the second quarter.

ON the principle, not necessarily sound but at least convenient, that the biggest show gets first spot, attention is called to the Japan Art Festival that opened at the Union Carbide Building, 270 Park Avenue, last Tuesday.

There was effervescence to spare yesterday evening at Town Hall, as Monique Leyrac made her American concert debut. Fresh from prize-winning appearances in Europe and her native Montreal, the Canadian singer breezed through about two dozen folk, popular and novelty tunes with never less than a full measure of savoirfaire.
Demonstrations in protest against United States involvement in the Vietnam war were staged yesterday in cities across the nation and abroad.
If college seniors returning home for spring vacation exhibit certain schizoid tendencies, they have cause.
Just when Aqueduct's followers of form well aware spring is here were hoping for Florida weather, winter returned yesterday to numb them back to reality.

ALL of us, I'm sure, extend congratulations to Gwen Davis (Mrs. Donald Mitchell) on the birth of her daughter, Madeline Anne, last Tuesday. As for Miss Davis's comedy, "The Best Laid Plans," which opened last night at the Brooks Atkinson, it is not nearly so pleasant a subject. Let's attend to it quickly so that we can get back to the happier news.

CHICAGO, March 25 Paul B. Moses, a 37-year-old assistant professor of the history of the arts at the University of Chicago, was found shot to death today on a residential street on the Northwest Side of Chicago. He had been shot once in the back of the head, apparently at close range.
Legislative opposition to Mayor Lindsay's tax proposals stiffened yesterday in the wake of the Mayor's threat to campaign against legislators who vote against his fiscal program.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 25 A Federal judge here declined today to take jurisdiction over a new and complex kind of civil rights conflict that appeared to touch intimately two of the most deeply seated anxieties of many whites and Negroes.
After faltering late Thursday, the bond market continued downward yesterday.
BERKELEY, Calif., March 25 Arthur J. Goldberg, United States delegate to the United Nations, and Clark Kerr, president of the University of California, overcame antiwar demonstrators today.

ALBANY, March 24 Out of the shadows of political obscurity and the wreckage of the Democratic party, a new power figure is arising in the Legislature. Anthony J. Travia, as Speaker of the Assembly, now wields more governmental authority than any other Democrat in New York State, hold ing veto power over thousands of bills and billions of dollars. The politics of Mr. Travia's power are simple.

SINGAPORE, March 25 Hsinhua, the official Chinese Communist press agency, was ordered closed temporarily in Indonesia today and its correspondents' visas were withdrawn "because of its continued hostility to Indonesia," the Jakarta radio reported.
Mayor Lindsay's proposed revisions of the City Council bill on air pollution would weaken rather than strengthen the measure, key supporters of the bill believe.
CAIRO It is fair time in Cairo, but that has different meanings for the Government and for ordinary Egyptians.

BOSTON, March 25 (UPI) A seminarian said today that he and seven fellow students at St. John's Roman Catholic Seminary were expelled for a silent protest intended to promote an audience with Richard Cardinal Cushing.

Congress is taking a fresh look at community antenna television (CATV) systems in order to determine just what to do about them. Its hearings, which follow new regulatory measures for CATV announced by the Federal Communications Commission, should help clear up the confusion surrounding this new and growing field: Once a mere curiosity, it has developed into a lucrative but messy growth industry.
The Paramount Pictures Corporation's two dissident stockholders formally notified the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday that they intended to wage a proxy fight for control of the company.
A study of the heliport atop the Pan Am Building by the Department of Marine and Aviation will recommend that it be allowed to stay where it is.
THE 3 year-old boy perched on a barber's chair summed up the current look in haircuts for the young.

FREDERICTON, N.B., March 25 On a red-plush throne between life-size portraits by Sir Joshua Reynolds of King George III and Queen Charlotte, the chief justice of New Brunswick intoned the ceremonial speech opening the new session of the Provincial Legislature.
The General Motors Corporation announced yesterday the promotion of three senior executives.
Corporation Counsel J. Lee Rankin yesterday "strongly endorsed" the State Judicial Conference's recommendation to the Legislature for the creation of 54 judgeships in this area.

ATHENS, March 24 Prem ier Stefanos Stefanopoulos and George Grivas, commander of the Cypriot forces, tonight de nied newspaper allegations that they had planned to topple President Makarios's Cyprus Government.
Joe Williams was charged yesterday with lying about his belly dancers.
WASHINGTON, March 25 The cost of mortgage money rose again last month for purchasers of new homes, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported today.

IN 1941, after 12 years of tempestuous public service as a prosecutor and special investigator, Bernard Botein went back into a calm private law practice, which he welcomed with the thought: "I'm glad to be able to live quietly again, and my wife is doubly glad. But if the Gov ernor should call tomorrow and draft me for some special work, I suppose I'd be on the next train to Albany."
The stock market edged ahead yesterday in moderately active trading with the recent highfliers making the best gains.
WASHINGTON, March 25 American business plans a 24 per cent increase in investment abroad in plant and equipment this year to a record $8.8-billion, the Commerce Department reported today.
WASHINGTON, March 25 Mark S. Watson, military correspondent of The Baltimore Sun, died at his home in Baltimore today after a short illness. He was 75 years old.

Representative Wright Patman, head of the House Banking and Currency Committee and the Joint Economic Committee, said yesterday he intends to introduce a bill on Monday that would bar commercial banks from selling negotiable certificates of deposit.

WEST POINT, N.Y., March 25 Plebes and parents weekend began today at the United States Military Academy, and Thomas E. Piazze, a native of Peru, came to see Cadet Thomas E. Piazze Jr., his spit-and-polish image.

WASHINGTON, March 25 A plan of the Chicago North Western Railway to raise $47million of new funds through issuance of new first mortgage bonds to be sold privately was rejected today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

PARIS, March 25 Month after month France buys another 30 tons of gold or more from the United States. Is there a limit? The gold portion of French monetary re serves has risen now to 87 per cent, from 72 per cent when the gold-buying tactic began, and the total reserves have risen to $5.5-billion.

WHEN the New York City Ballet opens its 42d New York season on Tuesday next at the New York State Theater, Lincoln Center, it will have a box-office advance of at least $500,000, the largest pre-sale of tickets the company has ever enjoyed in the 18 years of its existence.

Governor and Mrs. Rockefeller attended the St. Mark's Methodist Church Cotillion in the Imperial Ballroom at the Americana last night. The event, called Le Bal des Fleurs, bbenefited the United Stewardship Crusade of the church at St. Nicholas Avenue and 137th Street.

Efforts of a dissident group of Studebaker Corporation stockholders to obtain a list of all of the company's shareholders for use in a proxy fight received a setback yesterday in the Federal District Court for the Southern District of New York.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP) The Senate sent to President Johnson today a bill authorizing $750,000 for a Vice President's house on Massachusetts Avenue, in the Embassy Row section of northwest Washington.

State Supreme Court Justice Hecht has upheld the special law the Legislature rushed through last month, excusing New York's transit workers from the penalties that supposedly became mandatory when they struck for twelve days in January.

PARIS, March 25 It was the turn of French railroad engineers to halt work today, and more than 80 per cent heeded the call. They all but cut off freight traffic and reduced passenger operations by half.

Forty-second Street near Times Square is under attack again, as it has been often in the last 30 years, but none of the criticism or cleanups so far has changed the fact that it is profitable the way it is.

Dr. Franklin Hollander, attending gastrointestinal physiologist and chief of the GastroIntestinal Physiology Research Laboratory at Mount Sinai Hospital, died Thursday in his home, 120 East 81st Street. He was 67 years old.
Hyman E. Mintz, who began serving a one-year prison sentence for bribery on Wednesday, died yesterday in Bellevue Hospital after a heart attack. He was 57 years old.

Eight prominent professors of international law have strongly criticized a proposal by Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor that the Port of Haiphong be mined.
WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP) Senator Warren G. Magnuson said today that American motorists were not adequately protected against the risks of unsafe automobile tires.
The directors of Lehn Fink Products Corporation turned receptive to a renewed offer made yesterday by Sterling Drug, Inc., in the proposed acquisition involving close to $66-million.
WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP) Senator Warren G. Magnuson said today that American motorists were not adequately protected against the risks of unsafe automobile tires.

REYNOLDS PRICE'S second novel celebrates youth, remembered through a glass brightly. It dances without falter ing among the pitfalls that confront a writer dealing with such a dangerous subject. He hears all the gentle reverberations of those moment's when definition arrives.

The Board of Education disclosed tentative plans yesterday for sending city teachers into parochial schools and providing other special services to help disadvantaged children attending nonpublic schools.
Detectives discovered a complete set of 41 master keys for the city's 61,000 parking meters yesterday in a safe-deposit box leased by a man described as the kingpin of a meter-looting ring.
PITTSBURGH, March, 25 (UPI) The Westinghouse Electric Corporation today rejected a union suggestion for early meetings to review contract matters before negotiations this fall.
Harold L. Bache became president as well as chairman of Bache Co., Inc., yesterday.

Schenley Industries, Inc., in its report yesterday covering the six months ended Feb. 28 indicated net earnings of $12,361,758, equal to $2.41 a common share. This compared with $11,404,094, or $2.23 a share, for the six months to Feb. 28, 1965.
WASHINGTON, March 25 Federal controls on imports of heavy fuel oils were removed today, opening the East Coast to such shipments.
The Alvin, a curiously shaped midget submarine, somewhat resembles a chewed-off cigar with a helmet.

WASHINGTON, March 25 The Bell System is studying ways to automate its telephone information service. The operator will not be eliminated, but her work will be considerably lightened. Three engineers in the Bell Telephone Laboratories at Murray Hill and Holmdel, N.J., were granted a patent this week for a basic method of storing names, addresses and numbers, and getting them out quickly.
There was disappointment yesterday at the Chicago headquarters of the Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company.

WASHINGTON, March 25 Secretary of State Dean Rusk ruled out today any further steps toward improved relations with Communist China until the Peking regime modified its policies of mili tancy and self-imposed isolation.

WHEN Chester Weinberg opens his first dress col lection under his own name in May, he will be following a trail blazed by a number of dress designers in recent years. The path has not only lead to structural changes in the dress business but also produced a new attitude toward fashion.
WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP) Maj. Gen. Myron C. Cramer, Army Judge Advocate General in World War II, died today in a nursing home here. He was 84 years old.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 25 (UPI) Tronado, a LatinAmerican horse with a fancy step, will head a field of nine, and possibly 10, distance runners tomorrow in the $100,000 added Gulfstream Park Handicap.

Paul Crissman, a 6-foot-4-inch sophomore from Southern California College, is the first player from a Far West school to win the small-college individual scoring title, according to the figures released by the National Collegiate Athletic Association.
Midshipman Timothy M. Cohane Jr., has been elected captain of the Navy basketball team for the 1966-67 season.
In the last few years a terrifying and ugly new phrase has entered the medical lexicon--the "battered child syndrome."
Mayor Lindsay ordered the city's tax collectors yesterday to treat the citizens more kindly.

ANKARA, Turkey, March 26 --Premier Suleyman Demirel said today that his Government would send new anti-Communist legislation to Parliament within 60 days because the present law is too "loose and vague."
YONKERS, March 26--Sampson Knight, driven by George Phalen, stormed through on the outside in the closing strides to win the $5,000 Rockland County Pace at Yorkers Raceway tonight.
TOKYO, March 26--Japan will stress Asian agricultural development and cooperative projects to promote economic growth during the ministerial meeting of Southeast Asian nations here April 6 and 7.
LONDON, March 26--One night this week on the campaign trail Harold Wilson began an offthe-cuff speech by saying, "The country can see what the issues are ...."

It may offer little consolation to the housewife forced to pay 89 cents a pound for pork chops, compared with 65 cents only a year ago, but the present inflation is quite a bit different from those in the recent past.
A Congress of Liberty, which will bring together the world's leading statesmen and scholars, will be one of the principal events commemorating the bicentennial of the American Revolution in 1976.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, March 26--Prime Minister Ian D. Smith suggested today that Rhodesia might find it advantageous to declare itself a republic.

BECKLEY, W. Va., March 26 --The Beckley Presbyterian Church was the setting this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Carolyn Tieche Smith, daughter of Gov. and Mrs. Hulett Carlson Smith, to Paul Randall Hutchinson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hutchinson.
A new all-night coffee shop will open at La Guardia Airport in about six months, a Port of New York Authority spokesman said yesterday.

Seven years ago John V. Lindsay was a freshman member of Congress lost in the swirling crowd of an overwhelming Democratic House of Representatives, and Nelson A. Rockefeller was the new Governor of New York and a bright Presidential prospect.

PENSYLVANIA STATION has become little more than a hole in the ground--30 of its giant Doric columns strewn as landfill in a Secaucus dump. The Brokaw mansions at Fifth Avenue and 79th Street disappeared--zot!--one weekend last spring.

FOR most fans, wrestling brings to mind muscular bodies capable of performing great feats of strength. At St. George's School pitched high above the Atlantic Ocean in Middletown, R.I., the mat sport is being dominated by skinny Ed Wheeler.

BRICK TOWN, N.J., March 26--A black cocker spaniel, Ch. Pinefair Password, owned and bred by Mrs. H. Terrell Van Ingen of Greenwich, Conn., won the best-in-show trophy today at the first Sand and Sea Kennel Club event at the Ocean Ice Palace.

RONDA, Spain--High in the hills above the Costa de Sol is this town, a Spanish jewel set on a bluff overlooking a 400-foot-deep gorge and surrounded by a chain of mountains called the Serrania de Ronda.

WASHINGTON, March 26-- The United States Government recently ordered Professor H. Stuart Hughes of Harvard shadowed by its gumshoes when he goes to Europe later this year. The Government suspects the professor of harboring unorthodox political views.
AIR FORCE ACADEMY, Colo., March 26 (UPI)--The University of Southern California won its fourth straight National Collegiate swimming championship tonight, beating Indiana, 302-286.

LOS ANGELES, March 26--"The negotiations have reached the point where they come down to basic principles," says Sandy Koufax of the holdout campaign he and Don Drysdale are jointly waging against the Los Angeles Dodgers. NAHA, Okinawa, March 22 --Almost anything needed for Americans to fight the war in Vietnam, from shoelaces to giant tractors, can be found on this island in what has become the world's largest military supply depot.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., March 25--The results of the Ecumenical Council Vatican II got their first major exposure before an American audience this week.

Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary announced yesterday a program for modernizing the "entire department."
HOUSTON, March 22--The Gemini 8 astronauts' brush with disaster has revived with a new urgency proposals that the United States establish a space rescue service.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla.-- The 169-year-old Cathedral of St. Augustine, which was built for a parish dating back to 1597, has recently undergone extensive restoration and enlargement as part of a $2-million program.

A high school elaborately equipped to help students familiarize themselves with their earth and space environments was dedicated recently in the northern New Jersey village of Allendale.

IN the spring of 1964, the first recording issued under the Nonesuch label was released. If it was noticed at all by titans of the recording industry, it probably drew no more than a sneer. It was devoted entirely to chansons by Claude Le Jeune
COIMBRA, Portugal-- This ancient university town, with its blackcaped students and ro mantic gardens, will offer new attractions to visitors this year.

MADRID, March 26--Two high-ranking Soviet tourism officials visited Spain this week in the latest illustration of the quietly but steadily developing ties between this country and the Communist nations.
WASHINGTON, March 26-- The National Commission on Food Marketing may recommend a "little Wagner Act" for farmers.

A man-made spacecraft has soft-landed on the moon.

The State Commission of Investigation yesterday recommended compulsory treatment for narcotics addicts and stronger powers for the police to combat the narcotics prob lem. It said the problem was "greater now than it has ever been--and it is growing."
LONDON, Monday, March 28 --The Times of London will drop its front-page classified advertisements and change to a news format on May 3.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 27-- The most frequently heard question in Jakarta today is how President Sukarno can be retained as head of state and at the same time be kept from interfering, in the work of the new Government.

WASHINGTON, March 27-- Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India arrived in the United States today for a twoday meeting with President Johnson designed more to produce mutual understanding than specific agreements.
The Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union voted yesterday to strike if it did not obtain a satisfactory contract under a proposed newspaper merger here.
PITTSBURGH, March 27--A major automobile company reduced its steel-buying programs last week. The adjustments deferred April orders until May.

THE Hungarian grand master Lajos Portisch got off to a flying start in the current 27th International Tournament at Mar del Plata, Argentina. After drawing his first-round game with Sammy Reshevsky of the United States, he won the next four straight.

Richard Cardinal Cushing, Roman Catholic Archbishop of Boston, declared yesterday that the right to dissent must be preserved at "whatever cost." The Boston prelate warned, however, that while Americans were free to disagree with the law, they must not disobey it.

THE checks for Paris copies now being signed by some of the city's most prominent women may not be as profuse as spring daffodils, but to New York stores they are equally beautiful and much more enduring.

BURLY and bushy-browed, dressed in a well-cut dark suit, Leonid Ilyich Brezhnev is the Soviet organization man, with the bland, tough look of an engineer who was suddenly elected chairman of the board.

With elections in the 50,000member National Maritime Union scheduled to begin next Friday, Joseph Curran is seeking his 13th term. He has been president of the seamen's group since it was founded in 1937.
BRUSSELS, March 27-- Union Miniere du Haut-Katanga, one of Belgium's blue-chip stocks, expects to resume paying a regular dividend to its 120,000 stockholders, some of whom are Americans.
GENEVA, March 27--Quality has replaced quantity as the main objective of the Soviet bloc's economic planners, the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe said today.

Assembly Speaker Anthony J. Travis balked yesterday at immediate action on the new, much-criticized divorce-reform bill. His move indicated that he might agree to soften some of its most restrictive provisions.
